title: James
long_summary:
The decision to escape changes everything. Jim faces an impossible choice: accept being sold away from his family or risk everything for freedom. His flight to Jackson Island intersects with Huck Finn's own desperate escape from an abusive father, setting both on a perilous river journey that will test every assumption about survival, loyalty, and what it means to be free.

This bold reimagining shifts the entire narrative lens. Jim emerges not as a secondary figure but as a fully realized protagonist whose wit, courage, and moral complexity drive the story forward. The familiar landmarks of Twain's original—treacherous weather, unexpected allies and enemies, the con men Duke and Dauphin—take on new meaning when filtered through Jim's perspective and agency.

Everett masterfully balances devastating social critique with moments of sharp humor, creating a work that both honors and fundamentally challenges its literary predecessor. The result interrogates the very foundations of American storytelling, asking who gets to be the hero of their own narrative and what voices have been silenced in our most celebrated tales.
short_summary: Everett reimagines Huckleberry Finn from Jim's perspective, transforming literature's most problematic friendship into something honest and profound. Both harrowing and ferociously funny, with Jim finally given the agency and intelligence he deserves.
author_bios: Percival Everett teaches as Distinguished Professor of English at USC and has established himself as one of contemporary literature's most versatile voices. Among his notable works are Dr. No (NBCC Award finalist and PEN/Jean Stein Book Award winner), The Trees (Booker Prize and PEN/Faulkner Award finalist), Telephone (Pulitzer Prize finalist), So Much Blue, Erasure, and I Am Not Sidney Poitier. His honors include the NBCC Ivan Sandrof Life Achievement Award and Yale's Windham Campbell Prize. His novel Erasure became the Academy Award-winning film American Fiction. Everett lives in Los Angeles with writer Danzy Senna and their children.
quotes:
"Percival Everett is a giant of American letters, and James is a canon-shatteringly great book. Unforgiving and compassionate, beautiful and brutal, a tragedy and a farce, this brilliant novel rewrites literary history to let us hear the voices it has long suppressed."

—Hernan Diaz, author of Trust

"This is a brilliant, accessible, and very necessary companion to Huckleberry Finn."

—Dave Eggers, author of The Eyes and the Impossible

"James is funny and horrifying, brilliant and riveting. In telling the story of Jim instead of Huckleberry Finn, Percival Everett delivers a powerful, necessary corrective to both literature and history. I found myself cheering both the writer and his hero. Who should read this book? Every single person in the country."

—Ann Patchett

title: Between the World and Me
subtitle: Notes on the First 150 Years in America
long_summary:
Ta-Nehisi Coates sits down to write his teenage son a letter about what it means to navigate America in a Black body. This correspondence becomes something far more expansive—a reckoning with centuries of violence, exploitation, and systemic racism that continues to shape contemporary life.

Drawing from his own intellectual awakening and lived experiences across different landscapes—from university halls to urban neighborhoods, from historical sites to the homes of grieving families—Coates constructs a framework for understanding how racial mythology has been foundational to American society. His personal journey of discovery becomes a lens through which to examine how this mythology continues to manifest in police violence, mass incarceration, and the ongoing devaluation of Black lives.

The result is an unflinching examination of American racial dynamics that refuses easy consolation or false hope. Instead, it offers clear-eyed analysis rooted in historical understanding and paternal love, creating space for honest conversation about the realities his son will inherit and navigate.
short_summary: Coates writes to his teenage son about inhabiting a Black body in America, weaving personal narrative with historical analysis. A searing meditation on race that illuminates four centuries of American history through one father's urgent, necessary reckoning.
author_bios: Ta-Nehisi Coates has written several influential works including The Beautiful Struggle, We Were Eight Years in Power, The Water Dancer, and Between the World and Me, which earned the National Book Award in 2015. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, Coates currently resides in New York City alongside his wife and son.
quotes:
"I've been wondering who might fill the intellectual void that plagued me after James Baldwin died. Clearly it is Ta-Nehisi Coates. The language of Between the World and Me, like Coates's journey, is visceral, eloquent, and beautifully redemptive. And its examination of the hazards and hopes of black male life is as profound as it is revelatory. This is required reading."

—Toni Morrison

"Ta-Nehisi Coates is the James Baldwin of our era, and this is his cri de coeur. A brilliant thinker at the top of his powers, he has distilled four hundred years of history and his own anguish and wisdom into a prayer for his beloved son and an invocation to the conscience of his country."

—Isabel Wilkerson, author of Caste & The Warmth of Other Suns

"Brilliant . . . a riveting meditation on the state of race in America . . . [Coates] is firing on all cylinders, and it is something to behold: a mature writer entirely consumed by a momentous subject and working at the extreme of his considerable powers at the very moment national events most conform to his vision."

—The Washington Post

title: Sing, Unburied, Sing
long_summary:
At thirteen, Jojo finds himself caught between worlds—searching for guidance from his grandfather Pop while grappling with the absence of his father Michael, who's been imprisoned. His mother Leonie struggles with her own demons, including drug addiction and the weight of an interracial relationship in the South. She's haunted by visions of her deceased brother, a connection that brings both solace and torment.

The family's journey to collect Michael from Mississippi's infamous Parchman penitentiary becomes a reckoning with generational trauma and the lingering wounds of racial violence. Along the way, Jojo encounters the spirit of another young boy—a former inmate whose story illuminates the prison's dark legacy and the cyclical nature of suffering that has shaped the region.

Through multiple perspectives, the novel examines how the past refuses to stay buried, how family bonds can both sustain and suffocate, and how young people inherit the unresolved pain of previous generations. The supernatural elements serve as a bridge between historical injustice and contemporary struggle, revealing how trauma echoes across time and bloodlines.
short_summary: Thirteen-year-old Jojo navigates a family road trip to pick up his father from Mississippi's notorious Parchman prison. Ward weaves together the living and the dead in prose that's both lyrical and unflinching.
author_bios: Jesmyn Ward earned her MFA from the University of Michigan and has been honored with numerous prestigious awards including the MacArthur Genius Grant, a Stegner Fellowship, the Strauss Living Prize, and the 2022 Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction. She is a two-time National Book Award winner for Fiction, receiving the honor for both Sing, Unburied, Sing and Salvage the Bones. Her other works include Where the Line Bleeds and the memoir Men We Reaped, which earned the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. Ward teaches creative writing at Tulane University and makes her home in Mississippi.
quotes:
"Ghosts, literal and literary, haunt nearly every page of Sing, Unburied, Sing — a novel whose boundaries between the living and the dead shift constantly, like smoke or sand. Set on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi (a place rich in oil rigs and atmosphere, if almost nothing else), the book's Southern gothic aura recalls the dense, head-spinning prose of William Faulkner or Flannery O'Connor. But the voice is entirely Ward's own, a voluptuous magical realism that takes root in the darkest corners of human behavior ... Ward, whose Salvage the Bones won a National Book Award, has emerged as one of the most searing and singularly gifted writers working today."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Sing, Unburied Sing is Ward's third novel and her most ambitious yet. Her lyrical prose takes on, alternately, the tones of a road novel and a ghost story ... Sing, which is longlisted for a 2017 National Book Award, establishes Ward as one of the most poetic writers in the conversation about America's unfinished business in the black South."

—The Atlantic

"The connection between the injustices of the past and the desperation of present are clearly drawn in Sing, Unburied, Sing, a book that charts the lines between the living and the dead, the loving and the broken. I am a huge fan of Jesmyn Ward's work, and this book proves that she is one of the most important writers in America today."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

title: Evicted
subtitle: Poverty and Profit in the American City
long_summary:
Eight Milwaukee families navigate the brutal mathematics of survival in America's rental market, where a single missed payment can spiral into homelessness. Matthew Desmond's immersive investigation reveals a system where displacement has become profitable, trapping vulnerable tenants in an endless cycle of instability.

Living alongside his subjects in neglected neighborhoods, Desmond captures the impossible calculations families make daily—choosing between medicine and rent, heat and groceries. These aren't isolated tragedies but symptoms of a larger machine that extracts wealth from those who can least afford it. Children switch schools repeatedly, parents lose jobs due to constant moves, and entire communities fracture under the weight of perpetual uncertainty.

This isn't merely an exposé of individual hardship but an examination of how America's housing crisis manufactures and sustains poverty. Desmond connects the dots between policy failures and personal devastation, showing how the absence of stable shelter undermines every other aspect of human flourishing. The result challenges readers to reconsider fundamental assumptions about economic mobility and the true cost of inequality in contemporary America.
short_summary: Following eight Milwaukee families through eviction court and precarious rentals, Desmond shows how housing instability isn't just a symptom of poverty—it's a cause. Riveting narrative meets agenda-setting research.
author_bios: Matthew Desmond founded Princeton University's Eviction Lab and serves as the Maurice P. During Professor of Sociology there. His work Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City earned him the Pulitzer Prize, National Book Critics Circle Award, and PEN/John Kenneth Galbraith Award. Desmond received a MacArthur Fellowship and regularly contributes to The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"After reading Evicted, you'll realize you cannot have a serious conversation about poverty without talking about housing. . . . The book is that good, and it's that unignorable."

—Jennifer Senior, New York Times

"This book gave me a better sense of what it is like to be very poor in this country than anything else I have read. . . . It is beautifully written, thought-provoking, and unforgettable."

—Bill Gates

"My God, what [Evicted] lays bare about American poverty. It is devastating and infuriating and a necessary read."

—Roxane Gay, author of Bad Feminist and Difficult Women

title: Homeland Elegies
long_summary:
In this genre-defying memoir-novel hybrid, questions of American identity become deeply personal as an immigrant family navigates the fractured landscape of contemporary America. The narrative weaves between intimate family moments and broader cultural reckonings, examining how the events of September 11th reshaped not just foreign policy but the very notion of who gets to belong in America.

Moving from small-town America to the corridors of European power to the mountains of Afghanistan, the book interrogates the cost of assimilation and the weight of inherited trauma. Financial ruin shadows working families while Wall Street prospers, immigrants face mounting hostility, and America's foreign interventions create new cycles of violence. Through unflinching self-examination and sharp social observation, this work refuses easy answers about patriotism, faith, and the American dream, instead offering a complex portrait of what it means to love a country that may not love you back.
short_summary: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning author comes a genre-bending work that follows an immigrant father and son searching for belonging in post-Trump America. Raw, ambitious, and unflinching in its examination of identity and home.
author_bios: Ayad Akhtar writes novels and plays that have reached audiences across more than two dozen languages worldwide. His theatrical and literary achievements include the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, the Edith Wharton Citation of Merit for Fiction, and an Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, establishing him as a distinctive voice in contemporary American literature.
quotes:
"[A] moving and confrontational novel . . .  Homeland Elegies deals in ambiguities that were beyond the pale of public discourse in the years after 9/11. . . . He has an unerring sense for the sore spots, the bitter truths that have emerged from this history."

—Hari Kunzru, New York Times Book Review

"At the core of this flashing, kinetic coil of a story -- part 1001 Nights, part Reality TV -- is a passionate, wrenching portrayal of Americans exiled into 'otherness'."

—Jennifer Egan, author of Manhattan Beach and A Visit From the Goon Squad

"Homeland Elegies is the astonishing work of an absolutely brilliant writer. With exquisite prose and lacerating honesty, Ayad Akhtar reveals the intersections of art, finance, race, religion, academia, and empire, and in the process, shows us a troubled reflection of our country in the twenty-first century."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment

title: Say Nothing
subtitle: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland
long_summary:
A mother of ten vanishes from her Belfast home in 1972, dragged away in front of her children during one of Northern Ireland's darkest periods. Decades later, when her remains surface on a remote beach, the discovery reopens wounds that an entire community had tried to bury.

Keefe transforms this single disappearance into a lens through which to examine the complex web of violence, loyalty, and betrayal that defined the Northern Irish conflict. The narrative weaves between bomb-makers who risked everything for their cause, intelligence operatives playing deadly games of cat and mouse, and political figures who later rewrote their own histories when peace negotiations began.

This investigation reveals how a society torn apart by guerrilla warfare continues to grapple with questions of justice and memory. The book captures the moral ambiguity faced by those who lived through the conflict—former fighters questioning whether their actions served a noble cause or simply perpetuated cycles of revenge, and survivors struggling to find meaning in their losses.

Through intimate portraits of both perpetrators and victims, the story illuminates how political violence reshapes entire communities, leaving scars that persist long after the guns fall silent.
short_summary: Using one notorious killing as its foundation, Keefe excavates the brutal history of the Troubles and its lasting wounds. Masterful true crime that reads like a thriller while honoring the human cost.
author_bios: Patrick Radden Keefe writes for The New Yorker and has penned several New York Times bestsellers, including Rogues, Empire of Pain (which earned the Baillie Gifford Prize), and Say Nothing, recipient of a National Book Critics Circle Award and recognized by The New York Times Book Review as among the Twenty Best Books of the 21st Century. His accolades include a Guggenheim Fellowship, the National Magazine Award, and the Orwell Prize. He also served as executive producer for the acclaimed FX adaptation of Say Nothing.
quotes:
"Meticulously reported, exquisitely written, and grippingly told, Say Nothing is a work of revelation. Keefe not only peels back, layer by layer, the truth behind one of the most important and mysterious crimes of a terrible conflict; he also excavates the history of the Troubles, and illuminates its repercussions to this day."

—David Grann, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Killers of the Flower Moon

"Patrick Radden Keefe's gripping account of the Troubles is equal parts true-crime, history, and tragedy. Keefe's incisive reporting reveals the hidden costs of the Troubles, illuminating both the terrible toll of the conflict, and how it continues to reverberate today. A must read."

—Gillian Flynn, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Gone Girl

"Resolutely humane. . .Say Nothing [has an] exacting and terrifying lucidity. . .meticulously reported. . .Keefe's narrative is an architectural feat, expertly constructed out of complex and contentious material, arranged and balanced just so. . .an absorbing drama."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

title: Building Stories
long_summary:
Chris Ware has crafted something unprecedented: a graphic novel that exists as physical puzzle pieces scattered across fourteen different formats. Readers receive a box filled with books, magazines, newspapers, and pamphlets—each component designed to be discovered in whatever sequence feels right.

The story centers on a woman caught between isolation and connection, examining how creative ambitions can wither alongside romantic relationships. Ware dissects the particular melancholy of educated adults who find themselves suspended between what they imagined their lives would become and the reality of unfulfilled potential.

Drawn from a decade of contributions to major publications, this collection weaves together previously published pieces with extensive new material. The result challenges every assumption about how stories should unfold, inviting readers to become active participants in constructing meaning. Rather than following a predetermined path, you create your own journey through this meditation on modern loneliness and the small moments that define our days.
short_summary: An innovative graphic novel that arrives as 14 separate reading formats in a keepsake box, exploring loneliness and missed opportunities through Ware's masterful visual storytelling. Read in any order you choose.
author_bios: Chris Ware stands among today's most celebrated cartoonists, having revolutionized the graphic novel form. His work Jimmy Corrigan: The Smartest Kid on Earth earned the Guardian First Book Award and recognition from The Times (London) as one of the century's essential reads. Both The New York Times and Time magazine selected Building Stories for their annual top fiction lists. Ware regularly contributes to The New Yorker and his art has been featured at prestigious venues including the Whitney Biennial and Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . As usual, Mr. Ware's style is a model of compression in both word and picture. Less usual, for the genre as a whole, is the vividness with which he limns his heroine's intense, if fairly ordinary, inner life . . . The lack of clear structure, much less traditional linearity, turns reading into an unusually active process. This is a great, easily ownable work of art."

—The New York Times

"There's no writer alive whose work I love more than Chris Ware. The only problem is it takes him ten years to draw these things and then I read them in a day and have to wait another ten years for the next one."

—Zadie Smith, author of Swing Time & NW

"Ware provides one of the year's best arguments for the survival of print . . . the spectacular, breathtaking visual splendor make this one of the year's standout graphic novels."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Underground Railroad
long_summary:
Cora exists on the margins even within the confined world of a Georgia cotton plantation, where survival demands constant vigilance against both overseer's whip and fellow slaves' scorn. Caesar's arrival changes everything—his proposal to flee northward offers a lifeline she cannot refuse, despite the deadly consequences of capture.

Whitehead transforms America's most famous symbol of liberation into startling reality: locomotives thunder through subterranean passages, carrying freedom seekers between stations that reveal the nation's varied cruelties. Each destination confronts Cora with different manifestations of racial terror, from medical experimentation to false utopias built on violence.

This reimagining of historical trauma refuses easy comfort, connecting slavery's horrors to contemporary injustices through Cora's odyssey. Whitehead excavates the psychological and physical brutalities that shaped American identity, creating a narrative that functions both as thrilling escape story and unflinching examination of how the past continues to wound the present. The novel demands readers confront uncomfortable truths about freedom's true cost and the persistence of systemic oppression.
short_summary: Cora escapes slavery via Whitehead's literalized Underground Railroad—actual trains running beneath the antebellum South. Each state offers new horrors and revelations in this Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead has earned recognition as one of America's most vital contemporary voices, winning two Pulitzer Prizes for The Underground Railroad and The Nickel Boys, with the former also receiving the National Book Award. The #1 New York Times bestselling writer has produced twelve works spanning fiction and nonfiction. Both the MacArthur Foundation and Guggenheim Foundation have honored his contributions to literature, and he makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"Terrific."

—Barack Obama

"A triumph."

—The Washington Post

"Potent. . . .  Devastating. . . . Essential."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

title: Bring Up the Bodies
long_summary:
The king's patience has reached its breaking point. After years of upheaval to secure his marriage to Anne Boleyn, Henry VIII finds himself trapped with a wife who has delivered everything except the male heir he desperately needs. Her razor-sharp wit and defiant nature, once captivating, now threaten the delicate balance of court politics.

Thomas Cromwell recognizes opportunity in the king's growing frustration. With Katherine of Aragon's death removing the last obstacle to a clean slate, Cromwell begins weaving the intricate plot that will eliminate Anne from the chessboard of Tudor politics. As Jane Seymour quietly positions herself as the next queen, Anne discovers that her intelligence and fierce independence—her greatest strengths—have become liabilities in a world where survival depends on submission.

Mantel crafts a psychological thriller from the final chapter of Anne Boleyn's life, examining how power shifts and alliances form when a queen's fate hangs in the balance. The novel dissects the machinery of political destruction, revealing how quickly triumph can transform into catastrophe in Henry's volatile court.
short_summary: Thomas Cromwell orchestrates Anne Boleyn's downfall in this masterful sequel to Wolf Hall. Mantel transforms familiar Tudor history into something fresh and terrifying, following three weeks of conspiracy that will end with an execution.
author_bios: Hilary Mantel wrote the acclaimed Thomas Cromwell trilogy, with Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies each earning the Booker Prize. The Mirror & the Light, which completed the series, reached the top of the New York Times bestseller list upon publication. Throughout her career, she published seventeen books, including her memoir Giving Up the Ghost, and received numerous honors such as the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction, Walter Scott Prize, Costa Book Award, and Hawthornden Prize. The British government recognized her contributions to literature by naming her Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2014. She passed away in 2022.
quotes:
"Two years ago something astonishingly fair happened in the world of prestigious prizes: the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction for 2009 both went to the right winner. The book was Hilary Mantel's Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year…It was a hard act to follow. But the follow-up is equally sublime…That ironic ending will be no cliffhanger for anyone even remotely familiar with Henry VIII's trail of carnage. But in Bring Up the Bodies it works as one. The wonder of Ms. Mantel's retelling is that she makes these events fresh and terrifying all over again."

—The New York Times

"the finest works of historical fiction in contemporary literature."

—The Washington Post

"In Mantel's hands, Cromwell's cunning, morally complicated orchestration of that historic slice through the royal neck is as exciting as any thriller."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Behind the Beautiful Forevers
subtitle: Life, Death, and Hope in a Mumbai undercity
long_summary:
In Mumbai's Annawadi slum, families navigate the promises and perils of India's economic boom with fierce determination. Abdul transforms discarded waste into opportunity, while ambitious Asha pursues her own path toward upward mobility, hoping her daughter might break barriers as the community's first college-educated woman. Even the most vulnerable residents dare to imagine better futures.

Yet prosperity remains elusive as false accusations shatter lives, economic downturns reverse progress, and deep-seated divisions over religion, caste, and class erupt into violence. Katherine Boo spent years documenting these intersecting stories, revealing how global economic forces reshape intimate human experiences.

This work demonstrates journalism's power to illuminate hidden worlds with novelistic depth. Through meticulous observation and storytelling craft, Boo captures both the resilience and fragility of people pursuing dignity amid systemic inequality. The result challenges readers to confront uncomfortable truths about development, justice, and what it means to build a life against overwhelming odds.
short_summary: Families in a Mumbai slum chase dreams of prosperity as India transforms around them. Boo's immersive reporting reveals how global forces play out in individual lives with devastating clarity.
author_bios: Katherine Boo writes for The New Yorker and previously worked as a reporter and editor at The Washington Post. Her journalism has earned her a Pulitzer Prize, MacArthur Fellowship, and National Magazine Award for Feature Writing. She has spent the past decade working between the United States and India. Behind the Beautiful Forevers marks her debut book.
quotes:
"[An] exquisitely accomplished first book. Novelists dream of defining characters this swiftly and beautifully, but Ms. Boo is not a novelist. She is one of those rare, deep-digging journalists who can make truth surpass fiction, a documentarian with a superb sense of human drama. She makes it very easy to forget that this book is the work of a reporter. . . . Comparison to Dickens is not unwarranted."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Riveting, fearlessly reported . . . [Behind the Beautiful Forevers] plays out like a swift, richly plotted novel. That's partly because Boo writes so damn well. But it's also because over the course of three years in India she got extraordinary access to the lives and minds of the Annawadi slum, a settlement nestled jarringly close to a shiny international airport and a row of luxury hotels."

—Entertainment Weekly

"It might surprise you how completely enjoyable this book is, as rich and beautifully written as a novel. In the hierarchy of long form reporting, Katherine Boo is right up there."

—David Sedaris

title: Trust
long_summary:
In the glittering world of 1920s New York finance, Benjamin and Helen Rask command attention as titans of wealth and influence. Their story becomes the subject of a popular 1937 novel called Bonds, which captivates readers with its tale of financial empire-building and the human costs of extreme prosperity.

Yet fiction rarely tells the complete story. Hernan Diaz constructs a fascinating meta-narrative that presents multiple accounts of the Rasks' lives, each offering different perspectives on the same events. Through four interconnected documents—including the novel-within-a-novel, personal memoirs, and private papers—readers encounter conflicting versions of truth.

At the heart of this literary maze stands a woman determined to separate reality from carefully constructed lies. Her investigation reveals how those with power shape the stories told about them, and how financial influence can distort even the most basic facts. The novel examines the relationship between money and narrative control, questioning whose voices get heard and whose get silenced in the official record of history.
short_summary: Four nested narratives tell competing versions of a 1920s Wall Street tycoon and his wife's rise to power. Diaz crafts an ingenious literary puzzle that questions who controls stories and how money warps truth itself.
author_bios: Hernan Diaz received the Pulitzer Prize and achieved New York Times bestseller status for Trust, which has been translated into more than thirty languages. The novel earned him the Kirkus Prize and a Booker Prize longlist nomination, while publications including The New York Times, The Washington Post, NPR, and Time magazine selected it among their 10 Best Books of the Year. His earlier work In the Distance was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Diaz has been honored with a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Whiting Award, and the John Updike Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"Intricate, cunning and consistently surprising…Much of the novel's pleasure derives from its unpredictabiility...Add Henry James to Wharton, and Thomas Mann too...Exhilarating and intelligent novel."

—The New York Times

"The only certainty here is Diaz's brilliance and the value of his rewarding book…In execution it's an elegant, irresistible puzzle."

—The Washington Post

"Diaz understands, and deeply, how strange money is, as an omnipotent and imaginary substance that controls our lives. Trust glints with wonder and knowledge and mystery. Its plotlines are as etched and surreal as Art Deco geometry, while inside that architecture are people who feel appallingly real. This novel is very classical and very original: Balzac would be proud, but so would Borges."

—Rachel Kushner, New York Times bestselling author of The Mars Room

title: Thirteen Days in September
subtitle: Carter, Begin, and Sadat at Camp David
long_summary:
Three men gathered at a presidential retreat in Maryland during the autumn of 1978, carrying with them the weight of decades-old animosities and the fragile hope of peace. Carter's audacious gamble to isolate Begin and Sadat from outside pressures created a pressure cooker of diplomacy that teetered between breakthrough and collapse.

Wright reconstructs this extraordinary diplomatic marathon, tracking how religious convictions, personal grudges, and political survival instincts shaped every conversation. The author reveals how Carter's Methodist faith clashed and connected with Begin's Orthodox Judaism and Sadat's Islamic worldview, creating unexpected moments of understanding amid bitter disagreements.

The narrative captures the human drama behind closed doors—Begin's theatrical outbursts, Sadat's calculated charm, Carter's relentless mediation—while examining the broader forces that had kept the region locked in conflict. Wright shows how this unlikely trio, supported by a cast of advisors and spouses, managed to craft an agreement that has survived decades of regional upheaval.

This account demonstrates how personal relationships can reshape geopolitics, offering insights into both a remarkable diplomatic achievement and the ongoing challenges that continue to define Middle Eastern relations.
short_summary: Wright delivers a riveting day-by-day account of the 1978 Camp David negotiations, when Carter brought together Begin and Sadat to forge the Middle East's first modern peace treaty.
author_bios: Lawrence Wright contributes to The New Yorker as a staff writer while working as both playwright and screenwriter. His literary output spans two novels, among them Thirteen Days in September and The End of October, plus eleven works of nonfiction. His book The Looming Tower earned the Pulitzer Prize, joining other notable titles like Going Clear and God Save Texas in his bibliography. Wright makes his home in Austin, Texas.
quotes:
"It is brilliant penetrating scholarship. . . . Wright expertly captures every move of the three-way realpolitik chess match. By using each man's biography to illuminate the history of his respective nation, he not only chronicles Camp David but elucidates the issues that continue to plague the Middle East."

—Jeff Labrecque, Entertainment Weekly

"A unique moment in history superbly captured . . . a day-by-day account of the tense negotiations that shaped these historic talks . . . Yet another triumph for Wright."

—Kirkus

"Meticulously researched . . . almost nail-bitingly tense . . . an authoritative, fascinating, and relatively unbiased exploration of a pivotal period and a complicated subject."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Warmth of Other Suns
subtitle: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration
long_summary:
Between 1915 and 1970, six million African Americans abandoned the Jim Crow South in search of better lives elsewhere in America. Isabel Wilkerson transforms this massive demographic shift into an intimate chronicle by following three individuals whose personal odysseys illuminate the broader experience.

Meet Ida Mae Gladney, who traded Mississippi sharecropping for Chicago's promise in 1937. Follow George Starling's 1945 escape from Florida's citrus groves to New York's streets. Witness Robert Foster's cross-country drive from Louisiana to California in 1953, chasing dreams of medical practice without racial barriers.

Through meticulous research and vivid storytelling, Wilkerson reveals how these internal refugees navigated dangerous travels and rebuilt their identities in foreign territories. Their stories expose both the violence they fled and the discrimination they encountered in supposedly welcoming destinations. This narrative excavates a hidden chapter of American history, demonstrating how individual acts of defiance collectively reshaped the nation's social and cultural landscape. The result is both historical documentation and literary achievement—a testament to human resilience that reframes our understanding of twentieth-century America.
short_summary: Through three deeply personal stories, Wilkerson transforms the Great Migration into intimate human drama. Six million journeys from South to North become unforgettable individual portraits of courage and reinvention.
author_bios: Isabel Wilkerson earned both the Pulitzer Prize and the National Humanities Medal for her groundbreaking journalism and literary work. Her debut book, The Warmth of Other Suns, became a New York Times bestseller and captured the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction, later earning recognition as one of Time's 10 Best Nonfiction Books of the 2010s. Wilkerson has served on faculty at Princeton, Emory, and Boston Universities while sharing her expertise through lectures at over two hundred academic institutions across the globe.
quotes:
"A landmark piece of nonfiction . . . [Isabel Wilkerson's] closeness with, and profound affection for, her subjects reflect her deep immersion in their stories and allow the reader to share that connection."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"[An] extraordinary and evocative work."

—The Washington Post

"[An] indelible and compulsively readable portrait of race, class, and politics in twentieth-century America. History is rarely distilled so finely."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
long_summary:
Music becomes the thread connecting disparate lives in this innovative novel that jumps between eras and perspectives. At its center are two figures: a record industry veteran grappling with his fading relevance, and a kleptomaniac assistant whose stealing habit masks deeper wounds. But their story expands into a rich tapestry of interconnected characters whose lives span from the raw energy of 1970s punk clubs to a technology-saturated future.

Egan constructs her narrative like a playlist, with each chapter offering a different voice and timeline. The novel examines how music shapes identity and memory, following characters as they navigate the gap between youthful dreams and adult compromises. Some chase fame that proves hollow, others find unexpected redemption in small moments of grace.

What emerges is a meditation on aging, ambition, and the ways our past selves echo through time. The experimental structure mirrors the fragmented nature of memory itself, creating a reading experience that feels both intellectually ambitious and emotionally resonant. This is fiction that captures how the songs of our youth continue to play in the background of our lives, even as everything else changes.
short_summary: Interconnected stories spanning decades follow aging punk rocker Bennie and his troubled employee Sasha, plus a host of other characters whose lives intersect. Music pulses through this virtuosic exploration of time, memory, and human connection.
author_bios: Jennifer Egan has written six works of fiction, including Manhattan Beach, which received the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction, and A Visit from the Goon Squad, honored with both the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Critics Circle Award. Her other novels include The Keep, Look at Me (a National Book Award Finalist), and The Invisible Circus, along with the story collection Emerald City. Egan's fiction has been featured in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"A spiky, shape-shifting new book. . . . A display of Egan's extreme virtuosity."

—The New York Times

"Frequently dazzling. . . . Egan's expert flaying of human foibles has the compulsive allure of poking at a sore tooth: excruciating but exhilarating too."

—Entertainment Weekly

"If Egan is our reward for living through the self-conscious gimmicks and ironic claptrap of postmodernism, then it was all worthwhile. . . . [A] triumph of technical bravado and tender sympathy. . . . Turn up the music, skip the college reunion and curl up with The Goon Squad instead."

—The Washington Post

title: Washington Black
long_summary:
Young Wash lives in bondage on a Caribbean sugar plantation until an unexpected turn of fate places him in service to Christopher Wilde, his master's unconventional brother. Unlike anyone Wash has ever encountered, Wilde opens doors to scientific discovery and intellectual freedom that seem impossible for someone of Wash's circumstances.

Their relationship takes a dramatic turn following a violent incident that forces both to become fugitives. What begins as desperate flight evolves into an extraordinary odyssey that carries them from tropical islands to Arctic wastelands, through European capitals and North African cities. Yet the very circumstances that forge their connection contain the seeds of its destruction.

As Wash navigates a world that refuses to see his full humanity, he must confront fundamental questions about belonging, autonomy, and self-determination. The novel examines how individuals can transcend the limitations imposed upon them while acknowledging the lasting impact of trauma and displacement. Through Wash's journey across continents and cultures, the story illuminates both the possibility of transformation and the complex legacy of exploitation.
short_summary: When a young slave becomes manservant to his master's abolitionist brother, their unlikely bond leads to adventure and betrayal across continents. Epic historical fiction about freedom, identity, and what it means to be truly human.
author_bios: Esi Edugyan has achieved international recognition through her acclaimed novels exploring themes of identity and history. Washington Black earned her the Scotiabank Giller Prize while receiving finalist recognition for both the Man Booker Prize and Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize. Her earlier work Half-Blood Blues similarly captured the Scotiabank Giller Prize and reached the Man Booker Prize shortlist. Throughout her career, Edugyan has received prestigious fellowships in the United States and Europe, and she currently makes her home in Victoria, British Columbia.
quotes:
"A thrilling page-turner . . . also a lyrical contemplation of captivity and freedom, and the scars that stay with us for life."

—Marsha Lederman, Globe & Mail

"Edugyan's magnificent third novel again demonstrates her range and gifts . . . Framing the story with rich evocations of the era's science and the world it studies, Edugyan mines the tensions between individual goodwill and systemic oppression, belonging and exclusion, wonder and terror, and human and natural order . . . Crafted in supple, nuanced prose, Edugyan's novel is both searing and beautiful."

—Publishers Weekly

"High adventure fraught with cliffhanger twists marks this runaway-slave narrative, which leaps, sails, and soars from Caribbean cane fields to the fringes of the frozen Arctic and across a whole ocean . . . One of the most unconventional escapes from slavery ever chronicled . . . Edugyan displays as much ingenuity and resourcefulness as her main characters in spinning this yarn, and the reader's expectations are upended almost as often as her hero's. A thoughtful, boldly imagined ripsnorter that broadens inventive possibilities for the antebellum novel."

—Kirkus

title: The Yellow House
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
A shotgun house in New Orleans East becomes the unlikely narrator of a century of American dreams deferred and family resilience tested. Sarah M. Broom excavates the layers of memory, neglect, and love embedded in the walls where she grew up—a structure that sheltered twelve siblings but couldn't protect them from the forces of urban decay and institutional abandonment.

This isn't simply a story about Hurricane Katrina's destruction, though that catastrophe looms large. Instead, Broom traces how systemic inequality slowly eroded her neighborhood long before the storm arrived. She examines the weight of place on identity, the way geography shapes destiny, and how families create meaning within spaces the outside world has written off.

Broom's narrative moves between intimate family portraits and broader questions about who gets to call a place home in America. Her mother's fierce determination to hold their world together becomes both inspiring and heartbreaking as the house itself seems to resist her efforts. The result is a meditation on belonging that challenges romantic notions of New Orleans while honoring the complex reality of those who built lives in its overlooked corners.
short_summary: A transformative memoir about family, place, and the inexorable pull of home, centered on a shotgun house in New Orleans East. Broom traces a hundred years of history through her family's relationship to a house that became both sanctuary and burden.
author_bios: Sarah M. Broom has contributed to publications including the New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, The Oxford American, and O, The Oprah Magazine. Born and raised in New Orleans, she earned her Masters in Journalism from UC Berkeley in 2004. Her writing has been recognized with a Whiting Foundation Creative Nonfiction Grant in 2016, and she was a NYFA Fellowship finalist in 2011. Broom has also held fellowships at Djerassi and MacDowell. She currently resides in New York state.
quotes:
"[A] forceful, rolling and many-chambered new memoir.... [Broom's] memoir isn't just a Katrina story — it has a lot more on its mind. But the storm and the way it scattered her large family across America give this book both its grease and its gravitas.... This book is dense with characters and stories. It's a big, simmering pot that comes to a boil at the right times.... This is a major book that I suspect will come to be considered among the essential memoirs of this vexing decade. There are a lot of complicated emotions coursing through its veins. It throws the image of an exceptional American city into dark relief."

—New York Times

"One of the year's best memoirs, The Yellow House finds an epic, fascinating, empathetic history of New Orleans within the life of one woman, her family, and the home they grew up in...The book is at once intimate and sprawling, spinning at times dozens of stories in what amounts to a vital reframing of a misrepresented community, and an urgent meditation on the American dream."

—David Canfield, Entertainment Weekly

"A heartfelt but unflinching recovery project . . . Broom's lyrical style celebrates her family bonds, but a righteous fury runs throughout the narrative at New Orleans' injustices, from the foundation on up. A tribute to the multitude of stories one small home can contain, even one bursting with loss."

—Kirkus

title: Five Days at Memorial
subtitle: Life and Death in a Storm-Ravaged Hospital
long_summary:
The floodwaters rise around Memorial Medical Center as Hurricane Katrina transforms New Orleans into a disaster zone. Inside the hospital, medical staff confront an unthinkable reality: they cannot save everyone. Sheri Fink takes readers into the heart of this medical and moral crisis, where doctors and nurses must navigate impossible decisions about life and death.

The aftermath proves equally devastating. Criminal investigations target healthcare workers, questioning whether their actions during those catastrophic days crossed the line from mercy into murder. Fink's exhaustive investigation reveals the complex web of circumstances that led to these tragic choices.

This meticulously researched account exposes fundamental questions about medical ethics, disaster preparedness, and human behavior under extreme duress. Through intimate portraits of the people caught in this crisis, Fink illuminates the devastating gaps in our emergency response systems and the moral complexities that emerge when survival itself becomes uncertain.
short_summary: Physician-journalist Sheri Fink's Pulitzer Prize-winning investigation into the patient deaths at Memorial Medical Center during Hurricane Katrina. A gripping blend of medical ethics, legal drama, and disaster reporting.
author_bios: Sheri Fink wrote Five Days at Memorial and War Hospital, both New York Times bestsellers. Working as a correspondent for The New York Times, she received a Pulitzer Prize for international reporting covering the West Africa Ebola crisis. Her investigative piece "The Deadly Choices at Memorial" earned both a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting and a National Magazine Award. Fink brings unique perspective from her background as a relief worker in disaster zones and holds both an M.D. and Ph.D. from Stanford University.
quotes:
"Dr. Fink more than delivers. She writes with a seasoned sense of how doctors and nurses improvise in emergencies, and about the ethical realms in which they work. The first half of this book, which is well paced, covers the five days of the title. Then the viewfinder shifts to an entwined legal and political story in which state authorities pursue a homicide investigation. That so many people, starkly divided over the question of whether crimes had been committed, come off as decent and appealing makes this book an absorbing read. Dr. Fink brings a shimmering intelligence to its many narrative cul-de-sacs, which consider medical, legal and ethical issues…. By reporting the depth of those gruesome hours in Memorial before the helicopters came, and giving weight to medical ethics as grounded in the law, Sheri Fink has written an unforgettable story. Five Days at Memorial is social reporting of the first rank."

—Jason Berry, New York Times

"[Fink] has shaped her research into an elegant narrative, Five Days at Memorial, with all the page-turning pull of a novel, no easy feat given the complexity of the story… riveting."

—Entertainment Weekly

"In this astonishing blend of Pulitzer Prize–winning journalism (Fink, who also has an M.D. and Ph.D., won the award for the investigative reporting on which this book is based) and breathtaking narration, she chronicles the chaotic evacuation of the hospital and the agonizing ethical, physical, and emotional quandaries facing Memorial nurses and doctors, including a nightmarish triage process that led to the controversial decision to inject critically ill patients with fatal doses of morphine in order to refocus attention on those with a chance of surviving."

—Publishers Weekly

title: There There
long_summary:
The Big Oakland Powwow becomes the focal point where a dozen lives intersect, each person arriving with their own burdens and hopes. Jacquie Red Feather fights to rebuild connections with family after battling addiction. Dene Oxendene channels grief over his uncle's death into meaningful work at the gathering. Young Orvil steps into the dance circle for the first time, embracing traditions that feel both foreign and familiar.

As their paths cross during this single day, these characters illuminate the realities of Indigenous identity in contemporary America. Orange captures the tension between preserving cultural heritage and navigating modern urban existence, revealing how historical trauma echoes through generations while also celebrating resilience and community. The narrative builds toward a climactic convergence that transforms individual struggles into collective experience, examining what it means to belong when your people's story has been fragmented and displaced.
short_summary: Twelve Native Americans from different walks of life converge on the Big Oakland Powwow in this explosive debut. Orange weaves their stories into a devastating portrait of urban Indigenous life—full of poetry, rage, and unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Tommy Orange earned his MFA from the Institute of American Indian Arts and draws from his experience growing up in Oakland, California, as an enrolled member of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma. There There, his debut novel, earned him finalist status for the 2019 Pulitzer Prize and won the 2019 American Book Award.
quotes:
"Bravura… There There has so much jangling energy and brings so much news from a distinct corner of American life that it's a revelation… its appearance marks the passing of a generational baton."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"There There drops on us like a thunderclap; the big, booming, explosive sound of 21st century literature finally announcing itself. Essential."

—Marlon James, author of A Brief History of Seven Killings

"Commanding...The propulsion of both the overall narrative and its players are breathtaking as Orange unpacks how decisions of the past mold the present, resulting in a haunting and gripping story."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Story of the Lost Child
long_summary:
In this culminating novel, two women navigate the complexities of middle age while their extraordinary bond continues to define them both. Elena has circled back to her origins after building a life elsewhere—marriage, motherhood, and literary success in Florence couldn't keep her from returning to Naples and the love that has endured across decades.

Meanwhile, Lila remains entrenched in the very world both women once dreamed of escaping. Her business acumen has brought wealth but also dangerous entanglements with the corruption and violence that plague their old neighborhood. Despite—or perhaps because of—her refusal to leave, she has emerged as an influential figure in a community that both shaped and scarred her.

The novel examines how these two brilliant women, now in their sixties, reckon with the paths they've chosen and the dreams they've abandoned. Their relationship, forged in childhood and tested by rivalry, betrayal, and divergent destinies, remains the most enduring constant in lives marked by profound transformation. This final installment reveals how friendship can be both anchor and catalyst, sustaining us even as it challenges everything we think we know about ourselves.
short_summary: Elena returns to Naples after decades away, drawn back to both the man she's always loved and her complicated friendship with Lila. The final volume of Ferrante's acclaimed quartet.
author_bios: Elena Ferrante wrote The Days of Abandonment, Troubling Love, and The Lost Daughter, which have all been adapted for film. Her published works include Frantumaglia: A Writer's Journey, Incidental Inventions, and the children's book The Beach at Night. Europa Editions published her four-volume Neapolitan series—My Brilliant Friend, The Story of a New Name, Those Who Leave and Those Who Stay, and The Story of the Lost Child—from 2012 to 2015. HBO adapted My Brilliant Friend for television in 2018.
quotes:
"The conclusion of Ferrante's four-book saga defies the laws of diminishing returns, illuminating the twined psychologies of its central pair—intractable, indelible, inseparable—in one last blast of X-ray prose."

—The New York Times

"It's spectacular, but you will only realize how spectacular The Story of the Lost Child is if you do not cheat. You must read the three earlier (also superb) Neapolitan Novels or the perfect devastation wrought by the conclusion of this last novel will be lost on you."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"The Neapolitan novel cycle is an unconditional masterpiece."

—Jhumpa Lahiri

title: Going Clear
subtitle: Scientology, Hollywood, and the Prison of Belief
long_summary:
Lawrence Wright dissects one of America's most secretive organizations through exhaustive reporting that spans decades of research and hundreds of interviews. This deep dive into Scientology reveals how a struggling science fiction author transformed his ideas into a global movement that blurs the lines between self-help, religion, and corporate enterprise.

The narrative traces two pivotal figures: L. Ron Hubbard, whose personal struggles and creative ambitions gave birth to an entirely new belief system, and David Miscavige, the young successor who inherited control of a sprawling organization. Wright methodically unpacks the institution's elaborate belief structure, its aggressive pursuit of Hollywood stars, and the dedicated followers who commit their lives through extraordinary contracts spanning centuries.

Beyond exposing internal practices, Wright grapples with fundamental questions about religious freedom and institutional power in America. His reporting illuminates how Scientology operates as both spiritual movement and business empire, challenging readers to consider where legitimate religious practice ends and something else begins.
short_summary: Wright's meticulous investigation exposes the inner workings of Scientology, from L. Ron Hubbard's origins to celebrity recruitment and billion-year contracts. Fearless journalism meets stranger-than-fiction reality.
author_bios: Lawrence Wright contributes regularly to The New Yorker while maintaining careers in theater and film. His extensive bibliography spans fiction and nonfiction, featuring novels such as Thirteen Days in September and The End of October alongside investigative works like Going Clear, God Save Texas, and The Looming Tower, which earned him the Pulitzer Prize. Wright makes his home in Austin, Texas.
quotes:
"An eye-opening short biography of Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard and a long-form journalism presentation of the creature Hubbard birthed: a self-help system complete with bizarre cosmology, celebrity sex appeal, lawyers, consistent allegation of physical abuse, and expensive answers for spiritual consumers."

—Publishers Weekly

"A hotly compelling read. It's a minutiae-packed book full of wild stories."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Lawrence Wright brings a clear-eyed investigative fearlessness to Scientology—its history, theology, its hierarchy—and the result is . . . evidence that truth can be stranger even than science fiction."

—Lisa Miller, The Washington Post

title: On Immunity
subtitle: An Inoculation
long_summary:
Motherhood transforms Eula Biss into an anxious detective, questioning everything that might threaten her child's wellbeing. The air he breathes, the food he eats, the medical decisions she makes—all become sources of potential danger in her mind.

What begins as personal worry evolves into something far more expansive. Biss examines how we think about protection and vulnerability, both as individuals and as a society. She traces the stories we tell ourselves about contamination and safety, drawing connections between literary works, scientific history, and contemporary anxieties.

Through conversations with fellow mothers and deep dives into cultural texts, she uncovers the complex web of beliefs surrounding medical intervention and bodily autonomy. Her investigation reveals how individual choices ripple outward, affecting entire communities in ways we rarely consider.

This isn't simply a book about vaccines—it's an exploration of how fear shapes our decisions and how those decisions bind us together. Biss demonstrates that the question isn't whether we can protect ourselves from the world's dangers, but how we navigate our shared vulnerabilities with wisdom and compassion.
short_summary: New motherhood sparks an investigation into vaccine fears and the mythology of immunity. Biss weaves personal anxiety with cultural criticism, revealing how our bodies and fates remain inescapably interconnected.
author_bios: Eula Biss has written four books, most notably the bestselling On Immunity: An Inoculation, which The New York Times Book Review selected as one of 2014's ten best books, and Notes from No Man's Land: American Essays, which earned the National Book Critics Circle Award for criticism. Her essays and articles have been published in Harper's Magazine, The New York Times, and The Believer. She has received fellowships from the NEA Literature program, the Howard Foundation, and the Guggenheim Foundation.
quotes:
"On Immunity casts a spell...There's drama in watching this smart writer feel her way through this material. She's a poet, an essayist, and a class spy. She digs honestly into her own psyche and into those of 'people like me, ' and she reveals herself as believer and apostate, moth and flame."

—The New York Times

"Biss, while making an unimpeachable case for childhood vaccination, delves into the metaphors that accompany notions of purity and invasion and recounts the medical history of vaccine development. It's a touching personal story that seeks to understand why the antivax crowd exists and why it's such a well-meaning, if misguided, movement."

—Publishers Weekly

"Biss ably tracks the progress of immunization...Biss also administers a thoughtful, withering critique to more recent fears of vaccines--the toxins they carry, from mercury to formaldehyde, and accusations of their role in causing autism. The author keeps the debate lively and surprising...but arrives at a clear point of view: Vaccinate. Brightly informative, giving readers a sturdy platform from which to conduct their own research and take personal responsibility."

—Kirkus

title: All Fours
long_summary:
What begins as an escape route becomes something far more complex in this audacious exploration of female desire and reinvention. A middle-aged artist abandons her planned road trip almost before it starts, trading the open highway for a motel room where she embarks on an unexpected reckoning with her own life.

July crafts a story that refuses to follow predictable paths, diving headfirst into questions about marriage, motherhood, and the ways women negotiate their own wants against societal expectations. The novel dissects the particular challenges of being forty-five and female, examining how desire shifts and evolves even as the world insists it should remain fixed.

With her trademark blend of humor and unflinching honesty, July transforms what could be a simple midlife crisis narrative into something far more nuanced and surprising. The result is a book that challenges readers to reconsider their assumptions about women's lives, relationships, and the courage required to reimagine one's existence entirely.
short_summary: When a semi-famous artist abandons her cross-country road trip thirty minutes in, checking into a roadside motel instead, chaos and reinvention follow. July's brilliant second novel mines desire, identity, and midlife with characteristic wit and unflinching intimacy.
author_bios: Miranda July works across multiple creative disciplines as a writer, filmmaker, and artist. Her literary achievements include the New York Times bestselling novels All Fours and The First Bad Man, along with the story collection No One Belongs Here More Than You. All Fours earned recognition as a finalist for the National Book Award, the Women's Prize, and the Carol Shields Prize for Fiction. July has received a Guggenheim Fellowship and was named one of TIME magazine's "100 most influential people of 2025." She makes her home in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"All Fours has spurred a whisper network of women fantasizing about desire and freedom...It's the talk of every group text."

—The New York Times

"A giddy, bold, mind-blowing tour de force by one of our most important literary writers."

—George Saunders, Booker-Prize winning author of Lincoln in the Bardo

"Characteristically witty, startlingly intimate. . .This tender, strange treatise on getting out from the 'prefab structures' of a conventional life is quintessentially July."

—Kirkus

title: Martyr!
long_summary:
Addiction, grief, and questions of identity converge in the life of Cyrus Shams, a poet wrestling with the weight of his family's Iranian history. The death of his mother in a military incident over the Persian Gulf has left him adrift, while memories of his father's grueling work in American slaughterhouses add another layer to his sense of displacement.

Cyrus becomes fixated on stories of martyrdom, drawn to figures who died for causes greater than themselves. This obsession pulls him deeper into his family's past, where he discovers an uncle who once moved through war zones as a figure of comfort for the dying. A chance encounter with artwork in a Brooklyn gallery opens new questions about his mother's true identity, forcing Cyrus to reconsider everything he thought he knew about her life.

Kaveh Akbar's debut novel examines how we construct meaning from fragments of memory, cultural inheritance, and personal loss. Through Cyrus's journey toward sobriety and understanding, the book interrogates what it means to honor the dead while learning to live fully among the living.
short_summary: A newly sober son of Iranian immigrants embarks on a search for family secrets that leads him to a terminally ill painter in the Brooklyn Museum. Electrifying, funny, and wholly original.
author_bios: Kaveh Akbar has published poetry in The New Yorker, The New York Times, The Paris Review, and The Best American Poetry, among other publications. He wrote the poetry collections Pilgrim Bell and Calling a Wolf a Wolf, as well as the chapbook Portrait of the Alcoholic. Akbar also served as editor for The Penguin Book of Spiritual Verse: 110 Poets on the Divine and currently resides in Iowa City.
quotes:
"Kaveh Akbar is a radiant soul, a poet so agile and largehearted it comes as no surprise that his first leap into fiction is elegant, dizzying, playful. MARTYR!  is the best novel you'll ever read about the joy of language, addiction, displacement, martyrdom, belonging, homesickness for people longed for but forever unknown, the way art as eruption of life gazes back into death, and the ecstasy that sometimes arrives—like grace—when we find ourselves teetering on the knife-edge of despair."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates and Furies, Arcadia & Florida

"An absolute jewel of a novel. A diamond. I haven't loved a book this much in years. Kaveh's writing is so thoroughly powerful and gorgeous you can feel it from where dreams come, and in all over your brain, and straight from the bottom of your heart. This book does everything. It is so entirely funny and sad and true and beautiful. Kaveh Akbar is one of my favorite writers. Ever."

—Tommy Orange, author of There There

"I disappeared into Martyr!—utterly consumed by it—and then it returned me to the world with wider eyes, a swollen heart, and sharpened nerve endings. This is a book that understands the strangeness and grief and ecstasy of being alive; that understands the strange envelope of a body, the proximate sublime on the bare chest of a beloved; the baffled wonderment of sobriety, the grief that spans every scale of the human project—and, more than anything, the impossible salvation of love persisting not despite but through these materials. Kaveh Akbar writes with the staggering entirety of his mind and heart, and Martyr! will stay in my soul for good—a fever dream, a reckoning, a heartbreak, a shattering and mending, a delight—its double-helix of dreams and conversation now part of my own DNA for good."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

title: The Passage of Power
subtitle: The Years of Lyndon Johnson
long_summary:
This biographical masterpiece captures Lyndon Johnson during six pivotal years that defined both his legacy and America's trajectory. Johnson enters this period as an unrivaled master of Senate politics, yet his presidential ambitions crumble when the Democratic nomination slips to the younger, more charismatic Kennedy.

What follows reveals the brutal realities of political hierarchy. Johnson finds himself stripped of influence, relegated to a ceremonial role that offers neither the power he craved nor the respect he demanded. The Kennedy inner circle treats him as an outsider, while Robert Kennedy wages a personal campaign to diminish his standing.

Then November 22, 1963 changes everything. In an instant, Johnson must navigate the most challenging transition in American political history—assuming leadership of a traumatized nation while working with a staff that viewed him as an interloper. Yet this moment of crisis becomes his greatest triumph. Johnson transforms grief and uncertainty into legislative momentum, pushing through landmark civil rights measures and launching an ambitious campaign against poverty that reshapes the federal government's role in American life.

This volume illuminates how personal ambition, political genius, and historical circumstance converged to create one of the most consequential presidencies in modern American history.
short_summary: Caro's masterful fourth volume chronicles Johnson's transformation from powerless Vice President to commanding President following Kennedy's assassination. Epic in scope, intimate in detail, and essential for understanding American political power.
genres: Biography & Autobiography / Presidents & Heads Of State
author_bios: Robert A. Caro has earned the Pulitzer Prize for Biography twice, recognizing his groundbreaking works on Robert Moses and Lyndon Johnson. His writing has garnered the National Book Critics Circle Award three times, alongside numerous prestigious honors including the National Book Award, the Gold Medal in Biography from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and the Francis Parkman Prize. President Barack Obama presented him with the National Humanities Medal in 2010.
quotes:
"By writing the best presidential biography the country has ever seen, Caro has forever changed the way we think, and read, American history . . . Although the amount of research Caro has done for these books is staggering, it's his immense talent as a writer that has made his biography of Johnson one of America's most amazing literary achievements . . . Caro's chronicle is as absorbing as a political thriller . . . There's not a wasted word, not a needless anecdote . . . Most impressively, Caro comes closer than any other historian could to explaining the famously complex LBJ . . . Caro's portrayal of the president is as scrupulously fair as it is passionate and deeply felt . . . The series is a masterpiece, unlike any other work of American history published in the past. It's true that there will never be another Lyndon B. Johnson, but there will never be another Robert A. Caro, either."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"A breathtakingly dramatic story about a pivotal moment in United States history [told] with consummate artistry and ardor . . . It showcases Mr. Caro's masterly gifts as a writer: his propulsive sense of narrative, his talent for enabling readers to see and feel history in the making and his ability to situate his subjects' actions within the context of their times . . . Caro manages to lend even much-chronicled events a punch of tactile immediacy . . . Johnson emerges as both a larger-than-life, Shakespearean personage—with epic ambition and epic flaws—and a more human-scale puzzle . . .  Mr. Caro uses his storytelling gifts to turn seemingly arcane legislative maneuvers into action-movie suspense, and he gives us unparalleled understanding of how Johnson used a crisis and his own political acumen to implement his agenda with stunning speed. Taken together the installments of Mr. Caro's monumental life of Johnson form a revealing prism by which to view the better part of a century in American life and politics."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"An addictive read, written in glorious prose that suggests the world's most diligent beat reporter channeling William Faulkner. Passage is an essential document of a turning point in American history. It's also an incisive portrait of one great, terrible, fascinating man suddenly given the chance to reinvent the country in his image."

—Darren Franich, Entertainment Weekly

title: The Candy House
long_summary:
Tech entrepreneur Bix Bouton discovers the ultimate digital innovation through an unlikely encounter with academics studying memory externalization. His breakthrough spawns "Own Your Unconscious," a technology that transforms how humanity experiences the past by making every forgotten moment retrievable and shareable.

This memory revolution fractures society into opposing factions: those who mine personal data for profit and others who recognize the devastating cost of surrendering mental privacy. Through this speculative lens, Egan examines how digital advancement threatens the very essence of human intimacy.

The novel's structure mirrors its themes, employing wildly diverse storytelling methods—from collective narration to social media fragments—that demonstrate how technology fragments our ways of communicating and understanding each other. Each narrative experiment reveals new dimensions of characters struggling to maintain genuine relationships in an increasingly surveilled world.

Egan crafts a meditation on whether authentic connection can survive when our innermost thoughts become tradeable commodities, questioning what we lose when we digitize the most private corners of consciousness.
short_summary: Egan imagines a near future where technology allows people to access and trade memories. A dazzling exploration of authenticity and human connection told through an astonishing array of narrative styles.
author_bios: Jennifer Egan has published six works of fiction, including the Andrew Carnegie Medal winner Manhattan Beach and the Pulitzer Prize-winning A Visit from the Goon Squad, which also earned the National Book Critics Circle Award. Her other novels include The Keep, Look at Me (a National Book Award Finalist), and The Invisible Circus, plus the story collection Emerald City. Jennifer Egan's fiction appears regularly in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"The novel — with its prismatic plotting and ever-shifting chorus of seekers, kooks, and visionaries — feels less like a house than a honeycomb full of fantastical rooms, each one alive and thrumming with bright, weird humanity."

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"This is minimalist maximalism. It's as if Egan compressed a big 19th-century triple-decker novel onto a flash drive… Egan goes all in on the power of storytelling and of fiction."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A brilliant demonstration of the unquantifiable pleasures of great fiction."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
long_summary:
In 1951, a young African American woman died of cervical cancer in Baltimore, leaving behind five children and a legacy she never could have imagined. Doctors had harvested cells from Henrietta Lacks without her consent, and those cells defied every biological rule—they multiplied endlessly in laboratory conditions where all other human cells died.

These remarkable cells became the backbone of countless medical breakthroughs, from polio vaccines to cancer treatments to fertility research. They generated billions in profits for pharmaceutical companies and research institutions. Yet for decades, the Lacks family lived in poverty, unaware that their mother's biological material was revolutionizing medicine worldwide.

Journalist Rebecca Skloot spent years investigating this story, forming deep bonds with Henrietta's children as they grappled with profound questions about medical ethics, racial inequality, and scientific progress. The result examines how one woman's cells transformed modern medicine while highlighting the complex intersection of race, class, and medical research in America. This account challenges readers to consider who owns our biological material and whether scientific advancement justifies the exploitation of vulnerable communities.
short_summary: The extraordinary true story of Henrietta Lacks, whose cells became the foundation of modern medicine while her family remained unaware and uncompensated. Skloot weaves science, ethics, and deeply human drama into an unforgettable narrative.
author_bios: Rebecca Skloot has contributed science writing to The New York Times Magazine, O, The Oprah Magazine, and Discover, earning recognition for her accessible approach to complex topics. She served as correspondent for NPR's Radiolab and PBS's Nova ScienceNOW, and co-edited The Best American Science Writing 2011. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, her first book, immediately topped The New York Times bestseller list and received best book honors from over sixty publications in 2010. Skloot established and leads The Henrietta Lacks Foundation.
quotes:
"Skloot's vivid account begins with the life of Henrietta Lacks, who comes fully alive on the page. . . . Immortal Life reads like a novel."

—The Washington Post

"Gripping . . . by turns heartbreaking, funny and unsettling . . . raises troubling questions about the way Mrs. Lacks and her family were treated by researchers and about whether patients should control or have financial claims on tissue removed from their bodies."

—The New York Times

"A rich, resonant tale of modern science, the wonders it can perform and how easily it can exploit society's most vulnerable people."

—Publishers Weekly

title: No One Is Talking About This
long_summary:
The digital age has created a new kind of celebrity, and our protagonist finds herself at its center—a figure whose online presence has grown beyond her control. Her existence splits between virtual validation and mounting anxiety as she becomes convinced that countless digital voices are reshaping her very thoughts.

The internet becomes both sanctuary and prison, a space where meaning fractures into endless fragments of images and references that defy comprehension. Climate catastrophe, economic uncertainty, and widespread isolation form the backdrop of this hyperconnected yet profoundly disconnected world.

Then reality intrudes with devastating clarity: urgent messages from her mother signal a family emergency that cannot be reduced to posts or pixels. The collision between her online persona and this intimate crisis forces a reckoning with what remains genuinely human in an age of digital saturation.

Lockwood constructs a narrative that mirrors our contemporary moment—fragmented yet unified, absurd yet deeply felt. This exploration of modern consciousness questions whether authentic connection can survive in a landscape designed for performance, ultimately revealing how love persists even within the chaos of our networked existence.
short_summary: When a social media celebrity's hyper-online existence collides with a devastating family crisis, she must navigate between the absurd digital void and raw human connection. Lockwood captures our fractured moment with startling precision.
author_bios: Patricia Lockwood wrote the bestselling novel No One Is Talking About This, which earned Booker Prize and Dylan Thomas Prize recognition and appeared on The New York Times Book Review's 10 Best Books of 2021 list. The Atlantic included it among their Great American Novels of the past century. Lockwood has also published the memoir Priestdaddy and two poetry collections, and serves as a contributing editor at the London Review of Books.
quotes:
"[Lockwood is] a master of startling concision when highlighting the absurdities we've grown too lazy to notice . . . It's a vertiginous experience, gorgeously rendered but utterly devastating. I rattled around the house for days afterwards, shattered but grateful for the reminder that the ephemeral world we've constructed online is a shadow compared to the pain and affection we're blessed to experience in real life."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"I really admire and love this book. Patricia Lockwood is a completely singular talent and this is her best, funniest, weirdest, most affecting work yet."

—Sally Rooney, author of Normal People and Conversations with Friends

"Reading Patricia Lockwood feels like looking through a kaleidoscope built by a mischievous sorcerer—the world is suddenly rearranged in fragments that are cosmic, wondrous, humiliating, and profane. No One Is Talking About This is a furiously original novel, alive and unstable; the book builds to a reminder of how devastation and connection produce each other, endlessly and surprisingly, both on the internet and in human places that our shared digital consciousness can never reach."

—Jia Tolentino, author of Trick Mirror

title: Just Kids
subtitle: An Autobiography
long_summary:
Two aspiring artists forge an extraordinary bond in late 1960s New York, their friendship becoming the foundation for both survival and creative awakening. As one discovers her calling in poetry and music while the other finds his artistic voice through the camera lens, they navigate the vibrant underground scene that pulses through the city's most legendary venues and neighborhoods.
