As lawsuits mounted and evidence accumulated, the family deployed armies of lawyers and PR specialists to deflect responsibility for the addiction crisis ravaging communities nationwide. This extraordinary work of investigative journalism illuminates how extreme wealth can insulate perpetrators from accountability, offering a chilling examination of power, privilege, and the human cost of unchecked corporate greed in contemporary America.
short_summary: Three generations of the Sackler family built a fortune on Valium and OxyContin while their name graced museum walls worldwide. Keefe's devastating investigation reveals how philanthropy masked the ruthless tactics behind America's opioid crisis.
author_bios: Patrick Radden Keefe writes for The New Yorker and has penned several New York Times bestsellers, including Rogues, Empire of Pain (which earned the Baillie Gifford Prize), and Say Nothing, recipient of a National Book Critics Circle Award and recognized by The New York Times Book Review as among the Twenty Best Books of the 21st Century. His accolades include a Guggenheim Fellowship, the National Magazine Award, and the Orwell Prize. He also served as executive producer for the acclaimed FX adaptation of Say Nothing.
quotes:
"An engrossing (and frequently enraging) tale of striving, secrecy and self-delusion….Keefe nimbly guides us through the thicket of family intrigues and betrayals… Even when detailing the most sordid episodes, Keefe's narrative voice is calm and admirably restrained, allowing his prodigious reporting to speak for itself. His portrait of the family is all the more damning for its stark lucidity."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"A brutal, multigenerational treatment of the Sackler family… Keefe deepens the narrative by tracing the family's ambitions and ruthless methods back to the founding patriarch, Arthur Sackler…His life might be a model for the American dream, if it hadn't arguably laid the foundations for a still-unfolding national tragedy."

—Brian Mann, NPR

"A damning portrait of the Sacklers, the billionaire clan behind the OxyContin epidemic. If you are someone who engages in this kind of sneaky conduct, the last person you want reporting on you is Keefe….[He] has a knack for crafting lucid, readable descriptions of the sort of arcane business arrangements the Sacklers favored. He is also indefatigable….The Sackler infighting described in Empire of Pain will surely prompt many comparisons to the HBO series Succession."

—Laura Miller, Slate

title: Men We Reaped
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
The arithmetic of loss becomes unbearable: five young men from Jesmyn Ward's Mississippi community dead before their time. Her brother Joshua among them. Each death carries the weight of circumstances beyond individual choice—the legacy of systemic racism, economic deprivation, and limited opportunities that shape life in the rural South.

Ward examines how place and race intersect to create a landscape where young Black men face impossible odds. She traces the connections between historical injustice and present-day tragedy, revealing how poverty becomes a trap that spans generations. Her perspective as someone who left this world through education, then returned to witness its ongoing devastation, allows her to illuminate both the love that binds these communities and the forces that tear them apart.

This memoir refuses easy answers while demanding difficult questions about American inequality. Ward's unflinching examination of her own survival—and the guilt that accompanies it—creates a testament to those who didn't escape, and an indictment of the systems that made their deaths feel inevitable.
short_summary: Ward examines the deaths of five young men in her life—including her brother—and finds the devastating truth in rural poverty and systemic racism. Heartbreaking and essential.
author_bios: Jesmyn Ward earned her MFA from the University of Michigan and has been honored with numerous prestigious awards including the MacArthur Genius Grant, a Stegner Fellowship, the Strauss Living Prize, and the 2022 Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction. She is a two-time National Book Award winner for Fiction, receiving the honor for both Sing, Unburied, Sing and Salvage the Bones. Her other works include Where the Line Bleeds and the memoir Men We Reaped, which earned the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. Ward teaches creative writing at Tulane University and makes her home in Mississippi.
quotes:
"Men We Reaped reaffirms Ms. Ward's substantial talent. It's an elegiac book that's rangy at the same time. She thinks back about her brother, and about her old dead friends, and about their nighttime adventures in cars. Then she declares, 'I don't ride with anyone like that anymore.'"

—Dwight Garner, New York Times

"An assured yet scarifying memoir by young, supremely gifted novelist [Jesmyn] Ward... With more gumption than many, Ward battled not only the indifferent odds of rural poverty, but also the endless racism of her classmates... A modern rejoinder to Black Like Me, Beloved and other stories of struggle and redemption - beautifully written, if sometimes too sad to bear."

—Kirkus

"Ward has a soft touch, making these stories heartbreakingly real through vivid portrayal and dialogue."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Great Believers
long_summary:
Yale Tishman's world splits in two during the mid-1980s: his days are spent building something meaningful at a Chicago art gallery, chasing an incredible acquisition of 1920s artwork that could define his career. His nights belong to grief, as AIDS tears through his community with relentless precision. The disease claims his friends one after another, leaving Yale to navigate an increasingly empty landscape where funerals replace celebrations.

Decades later, Fiona crosses an ocean to Paris, driven by desperation to find her daughter who has vanished into the shadows of a dangerous cult. Her search forces her into the company of an old friend whose camera once captured the very crisis that defined Yale's era. Through their reunion, Fiona must finally examine how those years of loss carved deep channels through her own life, influencing choices that eventually drove her daughter away.

These parallel journeys—one through the epicenter of a health crisis, another through the aftermath of family fracture—reveal how trauma echoes across generations, and how the human capacity for connection persists even when everything familiar has been stripped away.
short_summary: Two interconnected stories of love and loss unfold across 1980s Chicago and present-day Paris. As the AIDS epidemic devastates one man's world, a woman decades later reckons with how that crisis shaped her life.
author_bios: Rebecca Makkai earned recognition for The Great Believers through its Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award nominations, ultimately receiving the ALA Carnegie Medal, Stonewall Book Award, Clark Prize, and Los Angeles Times Book Prize. The New York Times included the novel among 2018's Ten Best Books. Her published works also feature novels The Borrower and The Hundred-Year House, alongside the collection Music for Wartime. Currently a 2022 Guggenheim Fellow, Makkai leads MFA workshops at University of Nevada, Reno at Lake Tahoe and Northwestern University while directing StoryStudio Chicago as Artistic Director.
quotes:
"Tearjerker… The Great Believers asks big questions about redemption, tragedy, and connection. Makkai has written her most ambitious novel yet."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Stirring, spellbinding and full of life."

—Téa Obreht, New York Times bestselling author of The Tiger's Wife

"The Great Believers kept me up reading late into the night, and I'd wake up thinking about Makkai's vibrant, complex, and deeply human characters. This is an immersive, heartbreaking novel—I loved it."

—Maggie Shipstead, author of The Great Circle & Astonish Me

title: State of Wonder
long_summary:
Dr. Marina Singh has spent years avoiding the high-stakes decisions that once defined her medical career, finding refuge in the predictable world of pharmaceutical research. Her carefully constructed existence—built around a tentative romance with her supervisor and the steady rhythms of laboratory work—crumbles when her friend Anders Eckman dies under mysterious circumstances in the Amazon.

Reluctantly accepting a mission to investigate Anders's fate, Marina finds herself navigating the treacherous waters of the Amazon basin in search of a missing research team. Led by the brilliant and intimidating Dr. Annick Swenson, these scientists have been developing a potentially world-changing fertility drug while maintaining radio silence for months.

The jungle becomes a crucible where Marina must reckon with her abandoned ambitions and the mentor who shaped—and scarred—her early career. As she uncovers the truth about the research project and its moral implications, she faces choices that will force her to examine the person she became versus the doctor she once dreamed of being. The Amazon strips away her defenses, demanding she confront not only the mysteries surrounding her colleague's death but the compromises that have defined her life.
short_summary: When a colleague dies mysteriously in the Amazon, pharmaceutical researcher Marina Singh must venture into the jungle to uncover the truth. There she confronts her formidable former mentor and a research project that challenges everything she believes about science and morality.
author_bios: Ann Patchett has written multiple novels, including the recent #1 New York Times bestseller Tom Lake, along with nonfiction works and children's literature. Among her many honors are the PEN/Faulkner Award, the Women's Prize for Fiction, and the Book Sense Book of the Year. The Dutch House earned her a Pulitzer Prize nomination. Time magazine recognized her as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World, and President Biden presented her with the National Humanities Medal. She operates Parnassus Books in Nashville, Tennessee.
quotes:
"An engaging, consummately told tale."

—New York Times

"This is surely the smartest, most exciting novel of the summer."

—Washington Post

"The Amazon setting is something Patchett does rather marvelously.… The book is serious, but also so pleasurable that you hope it won't end."

—NPR

title: Caste
subtitle: The Origins of Our Discontents
long_summary:
America operates under a hidden hierarchy that transcends traditional discussions of race and class. Isabel Wilkerson dissects this invisible framework by examining how rigid social stratification functions across different societies and time periods. Her analysis draws connections between three distinct contexts—the American experience, India's traditional structure, and the systematic persecution in Nazi Germany—to illuminate universal patterns of human ranking.

Through personal narratives featuring historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr. and baseball legend Satchel Paige, alongside contemporary stories and her own experiences, Wilkerson demonstrates how this buried system infiltrates daily interactions and life outcomes. Her investigation reveals the mechanisms that have quietly organized American society for generations, showing how an unacknowledged ladder of human worth continues to influence behavior, opportunities, and national direction.

The work concludes with a vision for transcending these artificial barriers, suggesting pathways toward recognizing our shared humanity and dismantling the structures that divide us.
short_summary: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Warmth of Other Suns examines the unspoken caste system that has shaped America. Wilkerson reveals how our lives remain defined by an invisible hierarchy of human divisions.
genres: Social Science / Social Classes & Economic Disparity
author_bios: Isabel Wilkerson earned both the Pulitzer Prize and the National Humanities Medal for her groundbreaking journalism and literary work. Her debut book, The Warmth of Other Suns, became a New York Times bestseller and captured the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction, later earning recognition as one of Time's 10 Best Nonfiction Books of the 2010s. Wilkerson has served on faculty at Princeton, Emory, and Boston Universities while sharing her expertise through lectures at over two hundred academic institutions across the globe.
quotes:
"This book has the reverberating and patriotic slap of the best American prose writing. . . . Wilkerson has written a closely argued book that largely avoids the word 'racism,' yet stares it down with more humanity and rigor than nearly all but a few books in our literature. . . . It's a book that changes the weather inside a reader."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A surprising and arresting wide-angle reframing . . . Her epilogue feels like a prayer for a country in pain, offering new directions through prophetic language."

—Bilal Qureshi, The Washington Post

"This enthralling exposé deserves a wide and impassioned readership."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Tenth of December
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In this remarkable collection, ordinary moments become extraordinary through Saunders' lens, revealing the unexpected connections that bind us together. A chance encounter between a troubled teenager and a man facing his mortality transforms both their lives at a frozen lake. A veteran struggles to readjust to civilian life, finding humor and pain in equal measure. A suburban afternoon turns dangerous when violence intrudes on a family's peaceful world.

Saunders excels at illuminating the contradictions of contemporary American life, where comedy and tragedy exist side by side. His characters—outsiders, dreamers, survivors—face impossible choices that reveal their essential goodness despite circumstances that might suggest otherwise. Each story operates as both intimate character study and broader social commentary, examining how people maintain hope and dignity when life tests their limits.

The collection demonstrates Saunders' remarkable range, moving seamlessly between laugh-out-loud moments and scenes of genuine pathos. Rather than offering easy answers, these stories ask difficult questions about compassion, redemption, and what it means to be human in an often inhuman world.
short_summary: Saunders crafts stories that are simultaneously hilarious and heartbreaking, finding profound humanity in unlikely encounters. His characters—misfits, soldiers, suburban families—navigate life's absurdities with grace and grit.
author_bios: George Saunders has published thirteen books, including his Man Booker Prize-winning novel Lincoln in the Bardo and five story collections such as the National Book Award finalist Tenth of December and Liberation Day (which President Obama selected as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). The New York Times included three of his works—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—in their 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. Saunders teaches at Syracuse University and hosts Story Club on Substack.
quotes:
"A visceral and moving act of storytelling…No one writes more powerfully than George Saunders about the lost, the unlucky, the disenfranchised."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Tenth of December shows George Saunders at his most subversive, hilarious, and emotionally piercing. Few writers can encompass that range of adjectives, but Saunders is a true original—restlessly inventive, yet deeply humane."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of A Visit from the Goon Squad

"George Saunders is a complete original, unlike anyone else, thank god—and yet still he manages to be the rightful heir to three other complete American originals—Barthelme (the lyricism, the playfulness), Vonnegut (the outrage, the wit, the scope), and Twain (the common sense, the exasperation). There is no author I recommend to people more often—for ten years I've urged George Saunders onto everyone and everyone. You want funny? Saunders is your man. You want emotional heft? Saunders again. You want stories that are actually about something—stories that again and again get to the meat of matters of life and death and justice and country? Saunders. There is no one better, no one more essential to our national sense of self and sanity."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

title: Secondhand Time
subtitle: The Last of the Soviets
long_summary:
Russia's transformation from Soviet state to capitalist society unfolds through intimate conversations with citizens who lived through decades of upheaval. Alexievich spent twenty years collecting testimonies from people across the former USSR, creating a mosaic of personal experiences that reveals how political collapse reshapes individual lives.

These are not the voices of politicians or historians, but of teachers, factory workers, pensioners, and young adults—people whose memories span Stalin's purges, Soviet pride, and the confusion of sudden freedom. Their accounts reveal the emotional complexity of losing an entire worldview: the nostalgia for certainty alongside relief from oppression, the material hardships of transition mixed with new possibilities for self-expression.

The book captures a society caught between past and future, where some mourn the loss of Soviet idealism while others embrace change despite its difficulties. Through these layered testimonies, we see how ordinary people make sense of extraordinary historical moments, and how personal stories illuminate the human cost of political transformation in ways that official records cannot.
short_summary: Nobel laureate Alexievich weaves together voices of ordinary Russians to chronicle the collapse of the Soviet Union and its aftermath. An extraordinary oral history that captures both collective trauma and individual resilience.
author_bios: Born in Ukraine in 1948, Svetlana Alexievich grew up in the Soviet Union and later lived in Belarus, spending years in exile across Western Europe. Beginning her career in journalism, she pioneered a distinctive approach to documenting history through collected testimonies. Her books include War's Unwomanly Face (1985), Last Witnesses (1985), Zinky Boys (1990), Voices from Chernobyl (1997), and Secondhand Time (2013). The Swedish Academy honored her with the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature for her "polyphonic writings, a monument to suffering and courage in our time."
quotes:
"Already hailed as a masterpiece across Europe, Secondhand Time is an intimate portrait of a country yearning for meaning after the sudden lurch from Communism to capitalism in the 1990s plunged it into existential crisis."

—The New York Times

"A trove of emotions and memories, raw and powerful . . . [Secondhand Time] is one of the most vivid and incandescent accounts of [Soviet] society caught in the throes of change that anyone has yet attempted. . . . Alexievich stations herself at a crossroads of history and turns on her tape recorder. . . . [She] makes it feel intimate, as if you are sitting in the kitchen with the characters, sharing in their happiness and agony."

—The Washington Post

"[Alexievich] documents the last days of the Soviet Union and the transition to capitalism in a soul-wrenching 'oral history' that reveals the very different sides of the Russian experience. . . . [Her] work turns Solzhenitsyn inside out and overpowers recent journalistic accounts of the era. . . . She spends hours recording conversations, sometimes returning years later, and always trying to go beyond the battered and distrusted communal pravda to seek the truths hidden within individuals."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Stay True
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Two college students couldn't be more different in their approach to American identity. One embraces mainstream culture wholeheartedly, while the other cultivates his outsider status through underground music and alternative scenes. Their unlikely bond develops through shared late-night conversations and the ordinary rhythms of university life, bridging what initially seemed like an unbridgeable cultural divide.

Their friendship becomes a lens for examining what it means to belong in America when you don't fit neatly into prescribed categories. Both young men navigate the complex terrain of Asian American identity, each choosing different strategies for finding their place in a culture that often renders them invisible.

Tragedy strikes without warning, cutting short a relationship that had begun to redefine both of their understandings of authenticity and connection. In the aftermath of devastating loss, writing becomes a way to preserve not just memory, but the profound questions their friendship raised about identity, culture, and the unexpected ways people can matter to each other. This memoir transforms personal grief into a broader meditation on how we construct meaning from the fragments of our experience.
short_summary: Hua Hsu excavates the friendship that defined his college years—and the violent loss that ended it. A profound meditation on grief, identity, and the art that helps us make sense of senseless tragedy.
author_bios: Hua Hsu teaches Literature at Bard College and writes for The New Yorker as a staff contributor. His work includes serving on the executive board of the Asian American Writers' Workshop. Previously, Hua Hsu held fellowships at both the New America Foundation and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center at the New York Public Library. He makes his home in Brooklyn with his family.
quotes:
"[Hsu] is that rare thing: a chronicler and critic who [engages] fully, emotionally as well as intellectually, with every subject. . . In Stay True Hsu makes us see how his and Ken's and their friends' stories are tossed on the sea of history, how identity takes shape from a thousand factors, how personalities flow into one another, how chance and destiny can be hard to tell apart."

—Lucy Sante, The New York Review of Books

"At once a coming-of-age memoir, a devastating elegy for a departed friend, and a mixtape of all the music and other shards of culture and experience that coalesce into an identity, Stay True is wildly original. Hua Hsu writes with such grace and wry humor about so many things: friendship and loss, being young, the joys of hanging out, the pleasures and comforts of inconsequential passions. A glorious, unforgettable book."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award and New York Times bestselling author of Say Nothing and Empire of Pain

"Stay True feels like one of those books that is the sum total of a writer's life in thinking, craft, and curiosity, made felt at last, so that when the sentences come, they come with a deliberate, patient, and precise force. Hsu takes on the central theme of a friend's violent loss and casts from that void a story that, somehow, despite the hurt and confusion, embraces the world around it with a steady and capacious centrifugal force. This is the endeavor of writing at its most open, meticulous, forgiving and tender—which is to say, this is writing at its best."

—Ocean Vuong, New York Times bestselling author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

title: Euphoria
long_summary:
In the remote Territory of New Guinea during the 1930s, three ambitious anthropologists find themselves caught in a web of scientific rivalry and forbidden attraction. Andrew Bankson, a solitary British researcher, has been documenting the Kiona people for years, but personal demons and professional isolation have pushed him to despair.

Everything changes when he encounters Nell Stone and her volatile husband Fen, fellow researchers fleeing a dangerous situation with a hostile tribe. Despite Nell's fragile health, the couple remains determined to make groundbreaking discoveries. Bankson introduces them to the Tam people, a matriarchal society with rich artistic traditions, setting in motion a complex triangle of desire, ambition, and betrayal.

As their research deepens, so do the emotional entanglements between the three scholars. Professional boundaries blur as intellectual fascination transforms into something far more perilous. The novel examines how the pursuit of knowledge can become consuming, and how the line between observer and participant dissolves in the heat of discovery and desire.
short_summary: Three anthropologists in 1930s New Guinea become entangled in a love triangle that threatens their work and their lives. Inspired by Margaret Mead's controversial expeditions, this is intellectual passion at its most dangerous.
author_bios: Lily King has written six novels, including Euphoria and Writers & Lovers, along with the story collection Five Tuesdays in Winter. Her fiction has earned numerous honors, including the Kirkus Prize, the New England Book Award for Fiction, the Maine Book Award for Fiction, and a Whiting Award. King's novels have reached international audiences through translation into twenty-eight languages. She makes her home in Portland, Maine, and her work has appeared on the New York Times bestseller list.
quotes:
"Atmospheric...A small gem, disturbing and haunting."

—Kirkus

"The love lives and expeditions of controversial anthropologists Margaret Mead, Reo Fortune, and Gregory Bateson are fictionalized and richly reimagined in New England Book Award winner King's (Father of the Rain) meaty and entrancing fourth book...King's immersive prose takes center stage. The fascinating descriptions of tribal customs and rituals, paired with snippets of Nell's journals—as well as the characters' insatiable appetites for scientific discovery—all contribute to a thrilling read that, at its end, does indeed feel like 'the briefest, purest euphoria.'"

—Publishers Weekly

"Atmospheric and sensual, with startling images throughout, Euphoria is an intellectually stimulating tour de force."

—NPR

title: The Sixth Extinction
subtitle: An Unnatural History
long_summary:
Throughout Earth's history, catastrophic events have repeatedly decimated life on our planet. Today, scientists believe we're witnessing the beginning of a sixth mass extinction—and this time, humans are the asteroid.

Journalist Elizabeth Kolbert embarks on a global investigation, traveling alongside researchers who are documenting this unprecedented biological crisis in real time. From coral reefs in the Pacific to mountain slopes in South America, she reveals how human activity is reshaping the natural world at an alarming pace.

Through encounters with species both vanished and vanishing—the Panamanian golden frog, the great auk, Sumatran rhinos—Kolbert weaves together stories of loss that illuminate our planet's fragile biodiversity. She traces how our understanding of extinction has evolved since the concept first emerged in 18th-century France, connecting past discoveries to present-day revelations.

This investigation forces uncomfortable questions about humanity's role as both observer and architect of Earth's biological future. Kolbert's reporting transforms abstract scientific data into visceral reality, showing how the choices we make today will echo through geological time.
short_summary: Kolbert follows scientists across the globe documenting the mass extinction unfolding before our eyes. A masterwork of science writing that's both intellectually rigorous and deeply moving.
author_bios: Elizabeth Kolbert has written Field Notes from a Catastrophe, The Sixth Extinction—which earned her the Pulitzer Prize—and Under a White Sky, recognized by The Washington Post as a top ten book of the year. As a staff writer for The New Yorker, Kolbert has been honored with two National Magazine Awards and the Blake-Dodd Prize from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She makes her home in Williamstown, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"An epic, riveting story of our species that reads like a scientific thriller--only more terrifying because it is real. Like Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, Elizabeth Kolbert's The Sixth Extinction is destined to become one of the most important and defining books of our time."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon & The Lost City of Z

"[The Sixth Extinction] is a wonderful book, and it makes very clear that big, abrupt changes can happen; they're not outside the realm of possibility. They have happened before, they can happen again."

—President Barack Obama

"Elizabeth Kolbert's cautionary tale, The Sixth Extinction, offers us a cogent overview of a harrowing biological challenge. The reporting is exceptional, the contextualizing exemplary. Kolbert stands at the forefront of what it means to be a socially responsible American writer today."

—Barry Lopez, author of Arctic Dreams

title: Intimacies
long_summary:
At the International Court in The Hague, a multilingual interpreter seeks refuge from her past while wrestling with questions of belonging and identity. Her professional life intersects dangerously with personal turmoil as she becomes consumed by a violent incident witnessed by her friend Jana, developing an intense connection with the victim's sister.

Simultaneously, she finds herself interpreting for a former president facing war crimes charges, positioning her at the center of explosive international tensions. Her romantic entanglement with Adriaan grows more complicated as his unresolved marriage creates additional instability in her already fractured world.

Operating between languages and cultures, she must navigate the treacherous terrain of institutional power while confronting her own capacity for obsession and self-deception. The boundaries between her professional duties and personal desires blur as she grapples with fundamental questions about loyalty, justice, and the price of seeking sanctuary in an uncertain world.
short_summary: An interpreter at The Hague's International Court becomes entangled in personal dramas and political controversy. Kitamura crafts a taut exploration of identity, power, and the search for home.
author_bios: Katie Kitamura has written four novels, including A Separation and Intimacies, with the latter earning longlist recognition for both the National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award, plus finalist status for a Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her literary achievements include receiving the Rome Prize in Literature and a Lannan fellowship. Kitamura's novels have reached international audiences through translation into twenty-one languages, and she currently serves on the creative writing faculty at New York University.
quotes:
"[C]ooly written and casts a spell… One of Kitamura's gifts… is to inject every scene with a pinprick of dread…. One of the best novels I've read in 2021… A taut, moody novel that moves purposefully between worlds."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Katie Kitamura's fourth novel spins a taut web of dread from the start. . . In cool, spare prose, Kitamura asks the book's animating query: How should you go about your little life in a world where horrible things are happening?"

—Stephanie Hayes, The Atlantic

"Fans of sparse millennial tales: Run, don't walk."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois
long_summary:
Ailey Pearl Garfield finds herself torn between two worlds that seem impossible to reconcile. Her urban upbringing with educated, ambitious parents stands in stark contrast to her summers in rural Georgia, where family secrets run as deep as the red clay soil. There, her great-grandmother's ghost seems to whisper from every corner of the ancestral home, while her color-conscious grandmother enforces rules that feel like relics from another era.

The young woman's search for identity becomes a reckoning with American history itself. As Ailey digs into her family's roots, she discovers a tapestry woven from threads of triumph and trauma—stories of enslaved ancestors, Indigenous heritage, and white lineage that complicate easy narratives about race and belonging. Each revelation forces her to confront uncomfortable truths about how the past continues to shape the present.

This multigenerational chronicle examines what it means to inherit both privilege and pain, to carry forward the dreams and nightmares of those who came before. Through Ailey's eyes, readers witness how one family's journey mirrors the broader African American experience, revealing how personal identity and national history remain inextricably linked.
short_summary: Ailey Pearl Garfield navigates between her accomplished urban family and her rural Georgia roots, uncovering generations of ancestors whose stories reveal the complexity of Black American identity. A sweeping family saga that traces centuries of history through one woman's search for belonging.
author_bios: Honorée Fanonne Jeffers writes across multiple genres as a novelist, poet, and essayist. The Love Songs of W. E. B. Du Bois, her first novel, achieved remarkable success as a New York Times bestseller and Oprah's Book Club selection, earning the National Book Critics Circle Award and Dayton Literary Peace Prize alongside a National Book Award nomination. Jeffers has published five poetry collections, including The Age of Phillis, which received the NAACP Image Award.
quotes:
"The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois is epic in its scope. [It] traces the story of a family, the town in Georgia where they come from, and their migration outward over generations. The word epic is overused these days, but this book was meant to be an epic and it is. . . . This is one of the most American books I have ever read. It's a book about the United States. It's a book about the legacy of slavery in this country. . . . And it's also a book about traumas and loves that sustain over generations."

—Noel King, NPR

"Whatever must be said to get you to heft this daunting debut novel by Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, I'll say, because The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois is the kind of book that comes around only once a decade. Yes, at roughly 800 pages, it is, indeed, a mountain to climb, but the journey is engrossing, and the view from the summit will transform your understanding of America. . . . With the depth of its intelligence and the breadth of its vision, The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois is simply magnificent."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Jeffers crafts not just a history of Black women in the United States but an essential way of looking at their inheritance—one that folds familiarity into proficiency. Generous, wise, and fearless, she travels through the wounds of past and present with remarkable grace and gripping narratives."

—Kirkus

title: Cleopatra
subtitle: A Life
long_summary:
The last pharaoh of Egypt commanded vast wealth and wielded unprecedented influence across the Mediterranean world, yet history has reduced her to little more than seductive myth. This biography cuts through millennia of distortion to reveal a ruler whose political acumen and diplomatic brilliance far exceeded her legendary beauty.

Cleopatra's reign was marked by calculated violence and strategic alliances that would determine the fate of empires. She eliminated rivals within her own family while forging crucial partnerships with Rome's most powerful leaders. Her connections to Julius Caesar and Mark Antony were not mere romantic entanglements but sophisticated political maneuvers that secured Egypt's position on the world stage.

Drawing from ancient sources long overshadowed by theatrical interpretations and Hollywood spectacle, Schiff reconstructs the true story of a monarch who spoke nine languages, commanded naval fleets, and negotiated with the cunning of a master diplomat. This is the portrait of a woman who understood that survival required both intellectual prowess and ruthless pragmatism, whose death marked the end of an era and the beginning of Roman dominance.
short_summary: Stacy Schiff strips away centuries of myth to reveal the real Cleopatra—brilliant strategist, master negotiator, and the most powerful woman in the ancient world. A luminous biography that reads like epic drama.
author_bios: Stacy Schiff has written Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov), which earned the Pulitzer Prize, and Saint-Exupéry, a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Her other works include A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America, recipient of the George Washington Book Prize, Cleopatra: A Life, honored with the PEN/Jacqueline Bograd Weld Award, and The Witches: Salem, 1692. She holds fellowships from both the Guggenheim Foundation and the National Endowment for the Humanities, and belongs to the American Academy of Arts and Letters. Schiff makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Stacy Schiff does a rare thing: She gives us a book we'd miss if it didn't exist."

—Wall Street Journal

"A masterpiece."

—Daily Beast

title: Ordinary Notes
long_summary:
Christina Sharpe constructs a revolutionary literary mosaic through 248 interconnected fragments that accumulate into something far greater than their individual parts. This experimental work defies conventional boundaries, blending intimate family history with broader cultural examination to illuminate the complexities of Black experience across time.

Central to this tapestry is Sharpe's relationship with her mother, Ida Wright Sharpe, whose influence permeates every page—teaching the author both how to observe and how to look away, instilling a deep appreciation for language and aesthetics. Through this maternal lens, Sharpe develops what she calls an aesthetic of beauty as methodology, creating space for voices and stories that might otherwise remain unheard.

The book operates as both archive and prophecy, collecting fragments toward a "Dictionary of Untranslatable Blackness" while interrogating how memory functions in spaces of commemoration. Sharpe's innovative approach creates a new kind of literary architecture—one that mirrors the multifaceted nature of the lives and histories it seeks to honor, resulting in a work that is simultaneously deeply personal and expansively communal.
short_summary: In 248 interconnected notes, Sharpe weaves personal artifacts with public history to create an immersive meditation on Black existence. A genre-defying work that practices beauty as method and forges new literary forms.
genres: Social Science / Cultural & Ethnic Studies / American / African American & Black Studies
author_bios: Christina Sharpe wrote In the Wake: On Blackness and Being, which The Guardian recognized among 2016's finest books, and Monstrous Intimacies: Making Post-Slavery Subjects. She holds the position of Canada Research Chair in Black Studies in the Humanities at York University in Toronto.
quotes:
"A deft blend of memoir, theory, archival documents and lyrical reflections. . . . [Ordinary Notes] build[s] into a mosaic that holds the relentless terror of Black life as well as its undeniable beauty. . . . By turning her gaze inward, Sharpe offers a framework for understanding how to move forward, even when burdened by all the knowledge of the world's cruelty. . . . [Sharpe's] most liberating and poetic experiment yet."

—The New York Times

"A genre-defying, impressionistic series of meditations on history, identity, and the way we live now."

—Toronto Star

"Ordinary Notes is like an intellectual ice climb—you move along a careful series of handholds to cross a terrain that might otherwise seem impassable, and afterward, you are amazed at the passage. At once an act of careful attention and a juxtaposition of observations and questions, the result is a powerful vision of American life, drawn from the Black intellectual history and aesthetics that Sharpe has cultivated as the means to her own liberation, so that she might offer it to others."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write An Autobiographical Novel

title: The Power
long_summary:
Four lives across different continents intersect in unexpected ways: a privileged teenager in Nigeria, a foster child caught between faith and survival, a ruthless politician chasing power, and a street-smart Londoner with family complications.

Their stories collide when biology takes a sharp turn. Young women everywhere discover they possess an extraordinary—and terrifying—new capability that can cause unbearable agony or instant death through physical contact. This singular evolutionary shift doesn't just alter individual lives; it completely restructures society itself.

Naomi Alderman constructs a speculative narrative that interrogates the very nature of dominance and submission. As those who were once marginalized suddenly command unprecedented influence, the established order crumbles and rebuilds itself in shocking ways. The novel serves as both an adrenaline-fueled thriller and a mirror reflecting the power dynamics that shape our reality, forcing readers to confront difficult questions about authority, gender, and what happens when the balance tips completely.
short_summary: Teenage girls develop the ability to inflict pain and death with their touch, upending civilization. Alderman's speculative thriller follows interconnected lives navigating this new world order.
author_bios: Naomi Alderman wrote The Power, which earned the Women's Prize for Fiction and appeared on year-end lists from The New York Times, The Washington Post, and the Los Angeles Times. Barack Obama and Bill Gates both selected it among their annual recommendations. Margaret Atwood served as her mentor through the Rolex Arts Initiative, and Alderman holds a Fellowship with the Royal Society of Literature. Her novels have reached readers in over thirty-five languages. She also helped create the celebrated game Zombies, Run! and teaches creative writing as a professor at Bath Spa University.
quotes:
"Electrifying! Shocking! Will knock your socks off! Then you'll think twice, about everything."

—Margaret Atwood

"I was riveted by every page. Alderman's prose is immersive and, well, electric, and I felt a closed circuit humming between the book and me as I read."

—Amal El-Mohtar, The New York Times

"Alderman's writing is beautiful, and her intelligence seems almost limitless. She also has a pitch-dark sense of humor that she wields perfectly."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

title: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny
long_summary:
A chance encounter on a train becomes the catalyst for an extraordinary love story that spans continents and generations. Two souls find each other at pivotal moments in their lives: she's an emerging writer grappling with creative demons and family expectations after returning to India from America, while he's a journalist escaping family pressures and seeking his place in New York's unforgiving landscape.

Their connection defies the awkward history of failed family matchmaking that once pushed them apart. Now, as adults shaped by different worlds, they must navigate the complex terrain of modern identity—caught between the pull of tradition and the promise of reinvention. Their relationship becomes a lens through which to examine the profound questions of belonging: How do we honor our heritage while forging our own path? What sacrifices does love demand across cultural divides?

This expansive novel weaves together themes of artistic ambition, family loyalty, and the immigrant experience, creating a rich tapestry that illuminates the universal struggle to find one's place in an increasingly fragmented world. It's a story about the courage required to choose love over expectation, and the price of living authentically in the space between two cultures.
short_summary: Two young people whose fates intersect across continents and years in this epic of love, family, and the space between India and America. A sweeping exploration of tradition and modernity from the Booker Prize-winning author.
author_bios: Kiran Desai wrote the novels Hullabaloo in the Guava Orchard and The Inheritance of Loss, which earned her both the Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award. She was born in India, moved to the United States at age sixteen, and currently makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Kiran Desai reveals the breadth and depth of time, how it weighs on families and nations caught within the drama of history. She captures this with a rare and astute sensitivity that, no matter her subject, casts a light on our present."

—Hisham Matar, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of The Return

"Literary love stories are vanishingly rare these days, and The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny is that even more precious thing: a love story that's also profound, sparkling, funny, exquisitely written, and that teaches us how to live in full-throated exultation for the astonishments of this world. It has so many urgent things to say—about the costs and consolations of art, about power and class and race and freedom—that reading the book feels like a long conversation at night with your most interesting and ardent friend."

—Lauren Groff

"A powerful novel by a writer strong enough to pull back together worlds that are being pulled apart."

—Mohsin Hamid, New York Times bestselling author of Exit West

title: Baldwin: A Love Story
subtitle: A Love Story
long_summary:
James Baldwin's genius didn't emerge in isolation—it was forged through profound connections with four remarkable men who became his artistic catalysts and emotional anchors. This groundbreaking biography illuminates how Baldwin's relationships with painter Beauford Delaney, Swiss lover Lucien Happersberger, Turkish actor Engin Cezzar, and French artist Yoran Cazac provided the raw material for his transformative literature.

Through meticulous archival research, Nicholas Boggs reveals the intricate ways Baldwin channeled the tensions and passions of these bonds—spanning continents, cultures, and artistic mediums—into the essays, novels, and plays that would challenge America's conscience. From Harlem's streets to Parisian cafés, from Swiss mountains to Istanbul's ancient quarters, Baldwin's geographic and emotional odyssey becomes a map for understanding how personal intimacy fueled public art.

This is Baldwin as we've never seen him: not just the towering intellectual and civil rights voice, but the vulnerable man whose capacity for love became inseparable from his revolutionary vision. Boggs demonstrates how Baldwin's queerness and his relationships with these men weren't separate from his political consciousness—they were essential to it.
short_summary: The first major Baldwin biography in decades reveals how his intimate relationships—with mentors, lovers, and collaborators—shaped his revolutionary work. Drawing on new archival discoveries, it's a richly immersive portrait of the whole man.
author_bios: Nicholas Boggs began his Baldwin scholarship as a Yale undergraduate when he discovered the author's forgotten children's book Little Man, Little Man at the Beinecke Library. This find led him to locate the book's illustrator and co-edit its celebrated 2018 reissue. Boggs has contributed to The Cambridge Companion to James Baldwin among other scholarly works. He has earned a 2023 Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant and fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities, Yale's Beinecke Library, the Schomburg Center, and the National Humanities Center. He has also completed residencies at Yaddo and MacDowell. Boggs studied at Yale, American University, and Columbia, and currently resides in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"A virtuosic feat of literary imagination, rhapsodic and transportive. Stunningly, it answers not only the question of who James Baldwin was but how he made and remade his art and his world. Fast-paced and, at times, movingly tender, with love palpable throughout, the total effect is symphonic. This book deserves a standing ovation."

—Ilyon Woo, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Master Slave Husband Wife

"Nicholas Boggs's monumental biography considers James Baldwin through the prism of love, placing four beloved men at the center of his writing, his activism, his political consciousness, his philosophy, and his life. We have been presented with many partial Baldwins over the years, but here is the whole loveable man: the radical and the celebrity, the civil rights hero and the downtown playwright, the cosmopolitan jet-setter and the son of East Harlem. Compulsively interesting and beautifully written—there is something to treasure on every page. I absolutely loved it."

—Zadie Smith

"Gorgeous. Nicholas Boggs's storytelling, so tenderly rendered, brings us the beautiful yet tattered heart of not only Baldwin the intellectual and artist, but Baldwin the vulnerable, yearning, flesh-and-blood person. This book is so important and timely."

—Imani Perry, National Book Award winner for South to America

title: Demon Copperhead
long_summary:
In the hollows of Appalachia, a red-haired boy faces a gauntlet of American failures—broken schools, predatory foster systems, and the opioid crisis that devours his community. Armed with sharp humor and stubborn resilience, he battles invisibility in a society that has written off places like his.

This contemporary retelling of Dickens' classic follows a young narrator as he confronts institutional neglect while clinging to the mountain landscape that both nurtures and traps him. Athletic dreams collide with harsh realities, love brings both salvation and devastation, and survival becomes an art form practiced daily.

Kingsolver channels Dickens' social conscience into a distinctly American tragedy, illuminating how poverty perpetuates itself across generations. Yet within this cycle of abandonment emerges a voice of startling clarity—one that refuses to be silenced or forgotten. The result is a testament to storytelling's ability to transform pain into power, giving voice to those society overlooks.
short_summary: A boy born to nothing in Appalachia navigates foster care, addiction, and systemic neglect with fierce wit and determination. Kingsolver's Dickensian epic captures rural America with devastating precision and unexpected hope.
author_bios: Barbara Kingsolver has written ten bestselling books, including Unsheltered, The Bean Trees, and The Poisonwood Bible, alongside poetry, essays, and the children's book Coyote's Wild Home. Her novels have reached readers in thirty languages and garnered major recognition, including the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for Demon Copperhead, the National Humanities Medal, and the National Book Foundation's Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters. She makes her home on a farm in southern Appalachia.
quotes:
"An Appalachian David Copperfield. . . . Demon Copperhead reimagines Dickens's story in a modern-day rural America contending with poverty and opioid addiction. . . . Like Dickens, she is unblushingly political and works on a sprawling scale...Episode by episode she persuasively conveys the mind of a teenage boy. . . . It's hard to think of another living novelist who could take a stab at Dickens and rise above the level of catastrophe."

—The New York Times

"An epic…brimming with vitality and outrage….the rare 560-page book you wish would never end."

—People Magazine

"With its bold reversals of fate and flamboyant cast, this is storytelling on a grand scale. . . . As Demon discovers, owning his story—every part of it—and finding a way to tell it is how he'll wrest some control over his life. And what a story it is: acute, impassioned, heartbreakingly evocative, told by a narrator who's a product of multiple failed systems, yes, but also of a deep rural landscape with its own sustaining traditions."

—The Guardian

title: A Marriage at Sea
subtitle: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck
long_summary:
Maurice and Maralyn couldn't be more different—he's withdrawn and meticulous, she's magnetic and driven. Yet both refuse to settle for ordinary lives. Their solution? Abandon everything familiar, purchase a sailboat, and disappear into the open ocean.

Their 1972 departure marks the beginning of an extraordinary journey that transforms from dream fulfillment into nightmare. After months of successful sailing, a collision with a whale leaves their vessel destroyed and the couple stranded in a small life raft, surrounded by endless Pacific waters.

What emerges is far more than a tale of physical endurance against impossible odds. Confined in their floating prison, hunger and desperation strip away all pretense, revealing the raw truths of their relationship. Each day tests not only their will to live but their capacity to coexist when escape is impossible.

This gripping account examines how crisis can simultaneously destroy and strengthen human bonds. Elmhirst crafts a narrative that oscillates between heart-stopping maritime drama and intimate psychological study, questioning whether love can survive when two people have nowhere left to hide from each other or themselves.
short_summary: When a breaching whale destroys their boat in the Pacific, Maurice and Maralyn face months adrift in a rubber raft. An electrifying survival story that's equally about enduring the ocean and each other.
author_bios: Sophie Elmhirst has established herself as a distinguished journalist, contributing regularly to The Guardian Long Read and The Economist. Her writing has been featured in prestigious publications including The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, and Harper's Bazaar. She has earned recognition with the British Press Award for Feature Writer of the Year and a Foreign Press Award. Based in London, Elmhirst brings her journalistic expertise to A Marriage at Sea, which marks her debut as a book author.
quotes:
"A beautiful meditation on endurance, codependence, and the power of love. A dazzling book."

—Patrick Radden Keefe

"Stark, elemental, and sure to be a classic."

—Hampton Sides

"An enthralling, engrossing story of survival and the resilience of the human spirit."

—Bill Bryson

title: Midnight in Chernobyl
subtitle: The Untold Story of the World's Greatest Nuclear Disaster
long_summary:
In the predawn darkness of April 1986, a catastrophic explosion at a Soviet nuclear facility forever altered our understanding of atomic energy and government accountability. What followed was decades of deliberate obfuscation, official denials, and carefully crafted narratives designed to obscure the truth.

Adam Higginbotham strips away these layers of deception through exhaustive research and firsthand testimonies from survivors, engineers, and officials who lived through those harrowing days. His investigation reveals not just the technical failures that led to catastrophe, but the human decisions, institutional pressures, and systemic flaws that made disaster inevitable.

This account transcends typical disaster narratives by examining how ordinary people responded to extraordinary circumstances—from plant workers racing against time to contain the damage, to residents forced to abandon their homes forever. Higginbotham illuminates the intersection of scientific hubris, political corruption, and individual courage in ways that resonate far beyond nuclear policy.

The result is both historical reckoning and cautionary tale, demonstrating how the pursuit of technological progress without adequate safeguards can unleash consequences that span generations and continents.
short_summary: Ten years of investigation yields the definitive account of Chernobyl. Higginbotham cuts through decades of propaganda to reveal the human story behind history's worst nuclear disaster.
author_bios: Adam Higginbotham contributes to major publications including The New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, Wired, GQ, and Smithsonian. He has written Midnight in Chernobyl, which received the William E. Colby Award and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Nonfiction, along with Challenger: A True Story of Heroism and Disaster on the Edge of Space. Higginbotham currently resides in New York City with his family.
quotes:
"Superb, enthralling and necessarily terrifying . . . the accident unfurls with a horrible inevitability. Weaving together the experiences of those who were there that night, Higginbotham marshals the details so meticulously that every step feels spring-loaded with tension. . . . Amid so much rich reporting and scrupulous analysis, some major themes emerge. . . . Higginbotham's extraordinary book is another advance in the long struggle to fill in some of the gaps, bringing much of what was hidden into the light."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Adam Higginbotham's brilliantly well-written Midnight In Chernobyl draws on new sources and original research to illuminate the true story of one of history's greatest technological failures—and, along with it, the bewildering reality of everyday life during the final years of the Soviet Union."

—Anne Applebaum, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Gulag: A History and Red Famine: Stalin's War On Ukraine & Iron Curtain

"Here is a triumph of investigative reportage, exquisite science writing, and heart-pounding storytelling. With Midnight in Chernobyl, Adam Higginbotham gives us a glimpse of Armageddon, but carries it off with such narrative verve that he somehow makes it entertaining. One thing is assured: After reading this astonishing, terrifying book, you will never think of nuclear power in quite the same way again."

—Hampton Sides, author of In the Kingdom of Ice and On Desperate Ground

title: The Tiger's Wife
long_summary:
The death of her grandfather sends young physician Natalia on an unexpected journey through memory and myth in post-war Eastern Europe. Armed with little more than his treasured copy of The Jungle Book and fragments of the stories he once shared, she begins to uncover secrets that stretch far beyond her family's history.

At the heart of her investigation lies a figure known as "the deathless man"—someone who appears throughout her grandfather's past at pivotal moments. Yet it's another story, one he never shared, that proves most revealing: the tale of a tiger's wife, a legend that bridges the gap between village superstition and lived experience.

Obreht constructs a narrative where ancient beliefs collide with modern realities, showing how communities devastated by conflict find meaning through the stories they tell. Natalia's search becomes something larger—an exploration of how folklore preserves truth that facts alone cannot capture. The novel examines the ways people process trauma and loss, revealing how mythic thinking helps us navigate experiences too complex for rational explanation alone.
short_summary: In war-torn Balkans, a young doctor unravels her grandfather's mysterious death through his tales of a mythical tiger and an immortal stranger. Obreht weaves folklore and reality into something luminous and unforgettable.
author_bios: Téa Obreht gained international recognition with The Tiger's Wife, which earned the 2011 Orange Prize for Fiction and was a National Book Award finalist. Her follow-up novel, Inland, became an immediate bestseller and received the Southwest Book Award while earning Dylan Thomas Prize finalist status. Originally from the former Yugoslavia, Obreht has contributed to The New Yorker, The Atlantic, Harper's, and Zoetrope: All-Story, with her work featured in The Best American Short Stories. She currently lives in Wyoming.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . a richly textured and searing novel."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Spectacular . . . [Téa Obreht] spins a tale of such marvel and magic in a literary voice so enchanting that the mesmerized reader wants her never to stop."

—Entertainment Weekly

"That The Tiger's Wife never slips entirely into magical realism is part of its magic. . . . Its graceful commingling of contemporary realism and village legend seems even more absorbing."

—The Washington Post

title: The Director
long_summary:
Celebrity crumbles faster than expected. G.W. Pabst arrives in Hollywood as European cinema royalty, yet finds himself invisible beneath the studio system's glare. His reputation means nothing here—not even his history with Greta Garbo opens doors.

A family crisis forces his return to Nazi-controlled Austria, where Joseph Goebbels recognizes opportunity. The propaganda minister dangles artistic freedom and protection, but his offers carry the weight of command. Pabst convinces himself he can navigate this dangerous game, using his position to serve art rather than ideology.

The distance between artistic integrity and survival narrows with each compromise. Daniel Kehlmann crafts a psychological portrait of creative ambition colliding with authoritarian power, examining how easily principles bend under pressure. Through Pabst's ordeal, the novel interrogates whether art can remain pure when created under corrupt systems, and what price artists pay when they believe their talent exempts them from moral accountability.
short_summary: When legendary director G.W. Pabst flees Nazi Germany for Hollywood, he discovers fame doesn't travel well. Forced to return home, he faces an impossible choice between his art and his conscience.
genres: Fiction / Historical / 20th Century / World War II & Holocaust
author_bios: Born in Munich in 1975, Daniel Kehlmann has established himself through novels and plays that have earned him the Candide Prize, the Doderer Prize, the Kleist Prize, the Welt Literature Prize, and the Thomas Mann Prize. Measuring the World has reached readers in more than forty languages, while Tyll earned a spot on the 2020 International Booker Prize shortlist. Kehlmann divides his time between Berlin and New York. Translator Ross Benjamin brings German-language literature to English readers, including Franz Kafka's Diaries and Daniel Kehlmann's Tyll and You Should Have Left. His work has been recognized with a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship and the 2010 Helen and Kurt Wolff Translator's Prize.
quotes:
"The Director is engrossing and luminous, an epic act of historical imagination and an intimate parable about moral compromise and the seductions of art. After Tyll, I wasn't sure how Kehlmann could possibly top himself. He has. This book is a marvel."

—Ayad Akhtar, author of Homeland Elegies

"A wonderful book about complicity and the complicity of art. It's also funny, and brilliant."

—Zadie Smith, author of The Fraud, via the Ezra Klein Show

"Daniel Kehlmann is shockingly brilliant, a writer of extraordinary range and grace. At times absurdist, at times horrifyingly realist, The Director asks where the moral duty of the artist resides, and how the narcissism of the artistic project can bleed into complicity."

—Lauren Groff, author of The Vaster Wilds

title: Hidden Valley Road
subtitle: Inside the Mind of an American Family
long_summary:
The Galvin family appeared to embody postwar American prosperity—a large Catholic household in Colorado Springs where twelve children grew up during the height of the baby boom. Yet beneath this picture of suburban success lay a medical mystery that would captivate researchers for decades.

Six of the Galvin sons developed schizophrenia, an unprecedented concentration of the disorder within a single family. Their experiences became a crucial case study for the National Institute of Mental Health, contributing genetic material and data that shaped our understanding of mental illness. Robert Kolker traces both the family's private struggles and the broader scientific quest to comprehend schizophrenia, from primitive early treatments to modern genetic research.

The narrative reveals how one family's tragedy became intertwined with the evolution of psychiatric medicine, while never losing sight of the human cost. Kolker examines the complex dynamics within a household where mental illness created cycles of trauma, the challenges faced by unaffected siblings, and the parents' attempts to maintain normalcy. This is both an intimate family portrait and a window into how science grapples with one of its most elusive challenges.
short_summary: The devastating story of a midcentury American family with twelve children, six of them diagnosed with schizophrenia, that became central to our scientific understanding of the disease.
author_bios: Robert Kolker wrote the New York Times bestselling Lost Girls, which earned recognition as one of the New York Times's 100 Notable Books and appeared on Publishers Weekly's Top Ten Books of 2013. His magazine work has been featured in New York magazine, Bloomberg Businessweek, The New York Times Magazine, Wired, GQ, and numerous other publications. Kolker received the 2011 Harry Frank Guggenheim Award for Excellence in Criminal Justice Reporting and has been recognized as a National Magazine Award finalist.
quotes:
"This broad-ranging, highly readable, and deeply unsettling book tells the story of a family beset with schizophrenia, and in doing so provides meaningful insights into the devastation caused by the disease. It is, equally, a study of the multiple ways in which familial denial can exacerbate the inherent pain of mental illness, and of the courage required both of those who are themselves diagnosed with it and of those who choose to help and support them."

—Andrew Solomon, author of Far From the Tree

"An extraordinary case study and tour de force of reporting."

—Sylvia Nasar, author of A Beautiful Mind

"A powerful look at schizophrenia and the quest to understand it . . . A taut and often heartbreaking narrative . . . A haunting and memorable look at the impact of mental illness on multiple generations."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Disappearing Earth
long_summary:
The abduction of two young sisters from a beach in Russia's remote Kamchatka Peninsula becomes the catalyst for examining an entire community's fractures and connections. Over twelve months, we meet the women whose lives intersect with this tragedy—from those who witnessed the crime to mothers grappling with their own fears.

Phillips constructs a mosaic of voices that reveals how violence ripples outward, exposing the ethnic divisions and social hierarchies that define this isolated region. The peninsula itself becomes a character—its volcanic landscape and proximity to both Japan and Alaska creating a sense of beautiful isolation that both protects and imprisons its inhabitants.

What emerges is less a traditional mystery than an intimate portrait of how communities respond to loss. Each woman's story illuminates different aspects of Russian life in this forgotten corner of the world, where indigenous peoples navigate alongside Russian settlers, and where the search for the missing children becomes a lens for examining larger questions about belonging, suspicion, and survival. The result is a debut that uses crime as a starting point for a deeper exploration of place, identity, and the bonds that hold societies together.
short_summary: Two sisters disappear from a remote Russian peninsula, sending ripples through their community over the course of a year. Phillips weaves together multiple perspectives in this haunting debut that's part mystery, part cultural immersion.
author_bios: Julia Phillips wrote the bestselling novel Disappearing Earth, which earned National Book Award finalist recognition and was named a New York Times Book Review Top 10 Book of the Year. Phillips received a 2024 Guggenheim fellowship and currently resides in Brooklyn with her family. Her second novel, Bear, became a national bestseller and received New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice recognition.
quotes:
"Julia Phillips is at once a careful cartographer and gorgeous storyteller. Written with passion and patience, this is the story of a people and the land that shapes them. A mystery of two missing girls burns at the center of this astonishing debut, and the complexity of ethnicity, gender, hearth and kin illuminates this question and many more."

—Tayari Jones, author of An American Marriage

"An exceptional and suspenseful debut. In the opening chapter, two sisters vanish from a beach on the Kamchatka Peninsula; their disappearance sends ripples throughout the close-knit community. Subsequent chapters chart the effect of longing and loss in a series of interconnected, equally riveting stories. The climax [is] truly nail-biting . . . Phillips's exquisite descriptions of the landscape are masterful throughout, as is her skill at crafting a complex, genuinely addictive whodunit. This novel signals the arrival of a mighty talent."

—Publishers Weekly

"[An] immersive, impressive, strikingly original debut. . . an unusual, cleverly constructed thriller, and also a deep dive into the culture of Russia's remote Kamchatka peninsula. Disappearing Earth opens with a chilling crime . . . The rest of the book is about different women on the peninsula, all with the shadow of the missing girls hanging over them as a year goes by. You submerge ever more deeply into this world, which is both so different from and so much like our own. Will we ever get closure about the girls? You'll want to start over and read it again once you know."

—Kirkus

title: People Who Eat Darkness
subtitle: The True Story of a Young Woman Who Vanished from the Streets of Tokyo—and the Evil That Swallowed Her Up
long_summary:
A young British woman vanishes without a trace in Tokyo's labyrinthine entertainment quarter, leaving behind only cryptic clues and a web of unanswered questions. What begins as a missing person case evolves into something far more sinister, exposing the dark undercurrents of Japan's hostess bar culture and the predators who exploit it.

Journalist Richard Lloyd Parry spent years unraveling this mystery, following leads from Tokyo's neon-lit streets to courtrooms where unspeakable crimes came to light. His investigation reveals not just the fate of one woman, but a pattern of violence that had remained hidden for years. Through meticulous reporting and unprecedented access to investigators, families, and the accused, Parry constructs a narrative that transcends typical crime reporting.

This is more than a reconstruction of events—it's an examination of justice, cultural collision, and the vulnerability of those seeking adventure in foreign lands. The story forces readers to confront uncomfortable questions about exploitation, privilege, and the true cost of seeking escape in unfamiliar places.
short_summary: Foreign correspondent Parry reconstructs the disappearance of young Lucie Blackman in Tokyo's shadowy nightclub district. A masterful work of true crime journalism that becomes a profound moral inquiry.
author_bios: Richard Lloyd Parry serves as Asia editor and Tokyo bureau chief for The Times of London. His previous works include In the Time of Madness and People Who Eat Darkness, establishing him as a distinguished voice in international journalism and narrative nonfiction.
quotes:
"[In People Who Eat Darkness], Mr. Parry finds his voice, and it's a sturdy one. His book becomes not merely an exemplary piece of reportage but a sustained and quietly profound work of moral inquiry as well. It becomes ominous in ways that go well beyond the calculated shock value of its cover . . . Mr. Parry writes exceedingly well . . . [and] People Who Eat Darkness is surprisingly soulful, especially in its portrait of Ms. Blackman . . . He's restored her to life in this vivid book."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A big, ambitious true crime book in the tradition of Norman Mailer's The Executioner's Song and Truman Capote's In Cold Blood."

—Esquire

"A masterpiece of writing this surely is, but it is more than that--it is a committed, compassionate, courageous act of journalism that changes the way we think. Everyone who has ever loved someone and held that life dear should read this stunning book, and shiver."

—Chris Cleave, author of Little Bee and Incendiary

title: The Wide Wide Sea
subtitle: Imperial Ambition, First Contact and the Fateful Final Voyage of Captain James Cook
long_summary:
The transformation of a celebrated navigator into a brutal commander forms the dark heart of this maritime biography. James Cook earned fame for his remarkable voyages across the Pacific, mapping unknown territories while maintaining unusual respect for indigenous cultures he encountered. His reputation for fair treatment of both crew and native peoples set him apart from his contemporaries.

But Cook's third expedition reveals a different man entirely. The disciplined explorer who once approached new societies with scientific curiosity began employing savage punishments and authorizing vicious reprisals against island communities. His decision-making grew erratic, his leadership harsh and unpredictable.

What drove this dramatic shift remains one of history's most intriguing puzzles. Secret imperial directives to claim territories ahead of European competitors may have corrupted his scientific mission. The pressure to locate the elusive Northwest Passage perhaps pushed him beyond his limits. Regardless of the cause, Cook's final journey exposes how exploration and conquest intertwined, with devastating consequences for Pacific peoples.

The story reaches its climax in Hawaii, where initial cooperation between Europeans and islanders deteriorates into the violent confrontation that claimed Cook's life, marking the end of an era of Pacific exploration.
short_summary: Hampton Sides chronicles Captain Cook's final voyage—from celebrated explorer to his death on a Hawaiian beach in 1779. A gripping examination of how scientific discovery became the sharp edge of colonial conquest.
author_bios: Hampton Sides has written several New York Times bestselling historical works, including On Desperate Ground, In the Kingdom of Ice, Hellhound on his Trail, Blood and Thunder, and Ghost Soldiers, which received the PEN USA Award for Nonfiction. He makes his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
quotes:
"Hampton Sides has a gift for taking stories you thought you knew and making them feel fresh and revelatory. Along the way, he has also mastered the art of you-are-there historical narrative.  In The Wide Wide Sea, this combination is irresistible: fascinating and horrifying by turns, Sides puts us on deck with Captain Cook, one of the world's greatest and most disciplined explorers, as he comes undone in real time, in ways that make comparisons to our current planetary moment inescapable. This is a thrilling and necessary update to one of history's most consequential cultural collisions."

—John Vaillant, New York Times bestselling author of Fire Weather and The Tiger

"An acclaimed historian takes to the sea in this rousing tale of exploration . . . Sides draws on numerous contemporaneous sources to create a fascinating, immersive adventure story featuring just the right amount of historical context . . . Lusciously detailed and insightful history, masterfully told."

—Kirkus

"Gripping . . . It isn't possible in this short space to describe Side's hair-raising accounts of the journey . . . Sides recreates the newness of the experience, the vast differences in and among Indigenous cultures, and natural phenomena that were as terrifying as they were wondrous."

—The Washington Post

title: 1Q84
long_summary:
Tokyo becomes a stage for reality's unraveling in this intricate tale of two souls drifting toward an inevitable collision. Aomame discovers that her familiar city has subtly transformed into something alien—a place she dubs 1Q84, where small but unsettling details signal she's crossed into an alternate dimension. Across the city, Tengo accepts what seems like a straightforward editing job, only to find himself drawn deeper into a web involving a enigmatic teenage author and her haunting manuscript.

As both characters navigate their shifting realities, their paths interweave with a cast of unforgettable figures: a reclusive woman who shelters abuse victims, a grotesque private detective, and members of a shadowy religious movement. The novel builds toward revelations about childhood bonds, the nature of parallel worlds, and the mysterious forces that guide human connection across time and space.

Murakami constructs a labyrinthine narrative that balances philosophical inquiry with page-turning suspense, creating a reading experience that feels both dreamlike and urgently real. The result is a meditation on love, memory, and the thin boundaries between the world we know and the worlds that might exist just beyond our perception.
short_summary: In 1984 Tokyo, a woman discovers she's slipped into a parallel world while a writer becomes entangled with a mysterious cult. Murakami weaves thriller, romance, and surrealism into his most ambitious work.
author_bios: Born in Kyoto in 1949, Haruki Murakami currently resides near Tokyo and has achieved global literary recognition with translations spanning more than fifty languages. His distinguished career includes receiving the prestigious Cino Del Duca World Prize, an honor previously bestowed upon literary giants Jorge Luis Borges, Ismail Kadare, Mario Vargas Llosa, and Joyce Carol Oates.
quotes:
"Ambitious, sprawling and thoroughly stunning . . . Orwellian dystopia, sci-fi, the modern world (terrorism, drugs, apathy, pop novels)—all blend in this dreamlike, strange and wholly unforgettable epic."

—Kirkus

"Murakami's trademark plainspoken oddness is on full display in this story of lapsed childhood friends Aomame and Tengo, now lonely adults in 1984 Tokyo, whose destinies may be curiously intertwined . . . Murakami's fans know that his focus has always been on the quiet strangeness of life, the hidden connections between perfect strangers, and the power of the non sequitur to reveal the associative strands that weave our modern world. 1Q84 goes further than any Murakami novel so far, and perhaps further than any novel before it, toward exposing the delicacy of the membranes that separate love from chance encounters, the kind from the wicked, and reality from what people living in the pent-up modern world dream about when they go to sleep under an alien moon."

—Publishers Weekly

"Murakami is clearly one of the most popular and admired novelists in the world today, a brilliant practitioner of serious, yet irresistibly engaging, literary fantasy . . . Once you start reading 1Q84, you won't want to do much else until you've finished it . . . Murakami possesses many gifts, but chief among them is an almost preternatural gift for suspenseful storytelling . . . Despite its great length, [his] novel is tightly plotted, without fat, and he knows how to make dialogue, even philosophical dialogue, exciting . . . Murakami's novels have been translated into a score of languages, but it would be hard to imagine that any of them could be better than the English versions by Jay Rubin, partnered here with Philip ­Gabriel . . . There's no question about the sheer enjoyability of this ­gigantic novel, both as an eerie thriller and as a moving love story . . . I read the book in three days and have been thinking about it ever since."

—Michael Dirda, The Washington Post

title: Far From the Tree
subtitle: Parents, Children and the Search for Identity
long_summary:
At its heart, this remarkable work challenges a fundamental assumption about human nature: that our differences divide us. Instead, Andrew Solomon argues that the experience of being different forms a common thread binding all humanity together.

The book centers on an essential tension every parent faces—balancing acceptance of who their child is against the desire to help them flourish.
