Solomon examines this delicate dynamic through the lens of families raising children with conditions ranging from deafness and autism to those who are prodigies or transgender.

What emerges from hundreds of intimate conversations is a portrait of resilience that defies easy categorization. These families navigate territory where societal expectations collide with unconditional love, where difference becomes both challenge and gift. Solomon reveals how parents and children forge bonds that transcend conventional understanding, creating their own definitions of normal.

The result is an investigation into identity itself—how we define ourselves, how we relate to those closest to us, and how love adapts to circumstances that test its very foundations. Through deeply personal stories, Solomon illuminates the courage required to embrace what makes us human: our infinite capacity for both struggle and acceptance.
short_summary: Through interviews with hundreds of families, Solomon examines how parents navigate raising children with profound differences. A compassionate exploration of identity, acceptance, and the universal challenges of unconditional love.
author_bios: Andrew Solomon teaches psychology at Columbia University and serves as president of PEN American Center, contributing regularly to The New Yorker, NPR, and The New York Times Magazine. His books include Far and Away: Essays from the Brink of Change, the National Book Critics Circle Award-winning Far from the Tree (which earned thirty additional national honors), and The Noonday Demon: An Atlas of Depression, recipient of the 2001 National Book Award and Pulitzer Prize finalist. Solomon's TED talks have garnered over ten million views.
quotes:
"Solomon's first chapter, entitled 'Son,' is as masterly a piece of writing as I've come across all year. It combines his own story with a taut and elegant précis of this book's arguments. It is required reading…This is a book that shoots arrow after arrow into your heart."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Andrew Solomon has written a brave and ambitious work, bringing together science, culture and a powerful empathy. Solomon tells us that we have more in common with each other—even with those who seem anything but normal—than we would ever have imagined."

—Malcolm Gladwell, author of Revenge of the Tipping Point & Talking to Strangers

"Far from the Tree is a landmark, revolutionary book. It frames an area of inquiry—difference between parents and children—that many of us have experienced in our own lives without ever considering it as a phenomenon. Andrew Solomon plumbs his topic thoroughly, humanely, and in a compulsively readable style that makes the book as entertaining as it is illuminating."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of A Visit from the Goon Squad & The Candy House

title: Redeployment
long_summary:
The battlefield creates bonds and breaks spirits in ways that civilian life cannot comprehend. Phil Klay's collection examines the psychological landscape of modern warfare through Marines grappling with impossible moral choices and bureaucratic absurdities. 

A mortuary affairs specialist processes the remains of friend and enemy alike. A chaplain watches his faith crumble under the weight of military brutality. Another Marine carries guilt for a death that wasn't his fault, desperate to ease his friend's burden. The collection moves between combat zones where survival depends on split-second decisions and suburban homes where the same veterans struggle to connect with a world that seems impossibly distant from their experience.

Klay captures the strange mixture of boredom and terror that defines military service, where teaching baseball to Iraqis becomes a surreal diplomatic mission and routine patrols can explode into life-or-death encounters. These Marines return to families and communities that cannot fathom the moral complexity of their service, creating a second battlefield in the supposed safety of home. The result is an unflinching examination of how war reshapes human consciousness and the price of carrying violence in service of one's country.
short_summary: Klay's searing debut collection follows soldiers navigating the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan—and the equally treacherous terrain of coming home. These stories capture the brutal contradictions of modern warfare with unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Phil Klay served with the US Marine Corps and has channeled his military experience into acclaimed fiction. His debut collection Redeployment earned the 2014 National Book Award for Fiction, followed by Missionaries, which the Wall Street Journal named among 2020's Ten Best Books. Klay's essays and stories have been featured in major publications including The New York Times, The Washington Post, and The Atlantic. He currently teaches fiction at Fairfield University while serving on the board for Arts in the Armed Forces.
quotes:
"In Redeployment, his searing debut collection of short stories, Phil Klay—a veteran of the United States Marine Corps, who served in Iraq during the surge—gives the civilian reader a visceral feeling for what it is like to be a soldier in a combat zone, and what it is like to return home, still reeling from the dislocations of war. Gritty, unsparing and fiercely observed, these stories leave us with a harrowing sense of the war in Iraq as it was experienced, day by day, by individual soldiers."

—Michiko Kakutani, New York Times

"Klay grasps both tough-guy characterization and life spent in the field, yet he also mines the struggle of soldiers to be emotionally freed from the images they can't stop seeing. It's clear that Klay, himself a veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps who served in Iraq, has parlayed his insider's knowledge of soldier-bonding and emotional scarring into a collection that proves a powerful statement on the nature of war, violence, and the nuances of human nature."

—Publishers Weekly

"If you want to know the real cost of war for those who do the fighting, read Redeployment. These stories say it all, with an eloquence and rare humanity that will simultaneously break your heart and give you reasons to hope."

—Ben Fountain, Author of Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk

title: Americanah
long_summary:
Two Nigerian lovers find themselves separated by an ocean and transformed by their encounters with Western society. She discovers America through the lens of academic achievement, yet faces the jarring reality of racial consciousness in ways her homeland never demanded. He navigates London's shadows as an undocumented immigrant, his dreams of reunion postponed by geopolitical forces beyond his control.

Years pass. Both carry the weight of displacement, the complexity of belonging neither fully here nor there. Their eventual return to a changed Nigeria becomes more than homecoming—it's a reckoning with who they've become and what they've lost. The novel examines how migration reshapes not just geography but identity itself, asking whether love can survive the profound changes that distance and time impose on the human heart.
short_summary: Two young lovers leave Nigeria for the West, where they confront questions of race, identity, and belonging. Adichie's sweeping novel captures the immigrant experience with devastating precision and warmth.
author_bios: Born and raised in Nigeria, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie has become one of contemporary literature's most vital voices, with her books translated into over fifty-five languages. Her novels include Purple Hibiscus, winner of the Commonwealth Writers' Prize, and Half of a Yellow Sun, which received the Women's Prize for Fiction "Best of the Best" award. She also wrote Americanah, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award, along with The Thing Around Your Neck, We Should All Be Feminists, Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions, Notes on Grief, and Mama's Sleeping Scarf. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, she splits her time between Nigeria and the United States.
quotes:
"An expansive, epic love story."

—O: The Oprah Magazine

"An incredibly readable and rich tapestry of Nigerian and American life, and the ways a handful of vivid characters—so vivid they feel like family—try to live in both worlds simultaneously. As she did so masterfully with Half of a Yellow Sun, Adichie paints on a grand canvas, boldly and confidently, equally adept at conveying the complicated political backdrop of Lagos as she is in bringing us into the day-to-day lives of her many new Americans—a single mom, a student, a hairdresser. This is a very funny, very warm and moving intergenerational epic that confirms Adichie's virtuosity, boundless empathy and searing social acuity."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"Elegantly written, emotionally believable . . . A sensitive portrayal of distant love, broken affinities and culture clash . . . A fine, adult love story with locations both exotic and familiar."

—Kirkus

title: Malcolm X
subtitle: A Life of Reinvention
long_summary:
Malcolm X died at thirty-nine, but in his brief life he embodied multiple identities that would define African American resistance for generations. Manning Marable's exhaustive research reveals a figure far more nuanced than the mythology suggests—a man whose personal transformations mirrored the broader evolution of black political consciousness in America.

This biography excavates the forces that shaped Malcolm's worldview, from his family's early encounters with both Garveyism and white supremacist violence to his complex relationship with Elijah Muhammad and the Nation of Islam. Marable traces how Malcolm's intellectual development paralleled the shifting landscape of civil rights activism, showing how his break from the NOI positioned him at the center of emerging black nationalist thought.

Drawing on previously unavailable sources, Marable reconstructs the final months of Malcolm's life with forensic precision, offering new insights into the circumstances surrounding his murder. The result is a portrait of someone who understood that personal reinvention and political liberation were inseparable—a man whose influence on subsequent movements for racial justice cannot be overstated.
short_summary: Marable's landmark biography draws on new sources and revelatory research to present the fullest, most complex portrait yet of Malcolm X—stripping away decades of myth to reveal the man behind the icon.
author_bios: Manning Marable (1950–2011) held appointments as Professor of African-American Studies and of Public Affairs, History and Political Science at Columbia University. His published works include Black American Politics, Black Leadership, Living Black History, Beyond Black and White: From Civil Rights to Barack Obama, and Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention.
quotes:
"It will be difficult for anyone to better this book. It goes deeper and richer than a mere homage to Malcolm X. It is a work of art, a feast that combines genres skillfully: biography, true-crime, political commentary. It gives us Malcolm X in full gallop, a man who died for his belief in freedom, a man whom Marable calls the 'fountainhead' of the black power movement in America."

—The Washington Post

"In his revealing and prodigiously researched new biography, Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention, Manning Marable - a professor at Columbia University and the director of its Center for Contemporary Black History, who died just last week - vividly chronicles these many incarnations of his subject. . . Mr. Marable artfully strips away the layers and layers of myth that have been lacquered onto his subject's life - first by Malcolm himself in that famous memoir, and later by both supporters and opponents after his assassination in 1965 at the age of 39."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Unlike Bruce Perry's 1991 biography, Malcolm, which entertained the most outlandish stories in an attempt to present a comprehensive portrait, Marable's biography judiciously sifts fact from myth."

—The Atlantic

title: Dark Money
subtitle: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right
long_summary:
Behind America's political transformation lies a carefully orchestrated campaign by billionaire ideologues who built an empire of influence from the shadows. Jane Mayer's investigation reveals the sophisticated machinery these ultra-rich libertarians constructed—a vast network spanning universities, courts, and grassroots organizations—all designed to advance their economic interests while appearing as genuine political movements.

The book chronicles how fringe economic theories became accepted policy through strategic funding and patient institution-building. Mayer documents the methodical approach these donors used to capture academic departments, bankroll legal challenges, and create the intellectual framework that would later justify deregulation and tax cuts benefiting the wealthy.

What emerges is a portrait of American democracy under siege by concentrated wealth. The investigation demonstrates how a handful of families leveraged their fortunes to rewrite the rules of capitalism in their favor, often at the expense of environmental protection and economic equality. This meticulous work of journalism illuminates the hidden architecture of modern American politics.
short_summary: Five years of investigative reporting reveals how billionaire libertarians secretly funded a political revolution. Mayer traces the money behind think tanks, legal cases, and movements that reshaped America.
genres: Political Science / Political Process / Campaigns & Elections
author_bios: Jane Mayer writes for The New Yorker and has published four works of narrative nonfiction. Her collaborations include Landslide: The Unmaking of the President, 1984–1988 and Strange Justice: The Selling of Clarence Thomas, which earned National Book Award recognition. The Dark Side received the J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize and appeared on The New York Times Top 10 list. Dark Money also achieved Times Top 10 status and won the Helen Bernstein Book Award from the New York Public Library.
quotes:
"Jane Mayer's Dark Money is utterly brilliant and chilling — no matter how much you think you already know. . . . Read it!"

—Naomi Klein, bestselling author of Doppelganger: A Trip into the Mirror World, The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism & This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs the Climate

"Revelatory. . .persuasive, timely and necessary. . . . Only the most thoroughly documented, compendious account could do justice to the Kochs' bizarre and Byzantine family history and the scale and scope of their influence."

—The New York Times

"Mayer is. . . a writer whose reporting can leave a reader breathless. . . . I urge you to read Dark Money."

—Bill Moyers

title: Swamplandia!
long_summary:
Deep in the Florida Everglades, the Bigtree family has built their lives around a peculiar legacy: wrestling alligators for tourists at their ramshackle theme park. But death has a way of exposing the fragile foundations beneath even the most established traditions. After losing the family matriarch, each surviving member responds to grief in their own desperate way—one sibling chases phantoms through the marshland, another abandons everything to join the corporate enemy, and their father simply vanishes into the wilderness.

Thirteen-year-old Ava finds herself the unlikely guardian of both her family's crumbling dream and nearly a hundred dangerous reptiles. Her journey through the labyrinthine swamps becomes something far more treacherous than a simple rescue mission. Russell constructs a landscape where folklore breathes alongside harsh reality, where coming-of-age collides with economic ruin, and where the boundary between what's real and what we need to believe becomes as fluid as the wetlands themselves. This is a story about the stories we tell ourselves to survive loss, and what happens when even those stories begin to fail us.
short_summary: Thirteen-year-old Ava struggles to save her family's failing alligator theme park after her mother's death tears the Bigtrees apart. Russell's imaginative debut blends dark comedy with genuine heartbreak.
author_bios: Karen Russell has written six works of fiction, including New York Times bestsellers Swamplandia! and Vampires in the Lemon Grove. Among her many honors are a MacArthur Fellowship, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and a Pulitzer Prize nomination. Her recognition includes two National Magazine Awards for Fiction, the Shirley Jackson Award, the 2023 Bottari Lattes Grinzane Prize, and the 2024 Mary McCarthy Prize. A Miami native, Karen Russell currently makes her home in Portland, Oregon, with her family.
quotes:
"[A] cunning first novel. . . . Russell's willingness to lend flesh and blood to her fanciful, fantastical creations gives this spry novel a potent punch and announces an enthralling new beginning for a quickly evolving young author."

—Publishers Weekly

"Brilliant, funny, original . . . also creepy and sinister . . . Karen Russell's Swamplandia! is every bit as good as her short stories promised it would be. This book will not leave my mind."

—Stephen King

"Karen Russell is young and talented, and has been given just about every age-appropriate honor there is—Best Young American Novelists, 20 Under 40, 5 Under 35. With her debut novel, though, she's leaving the kids' table forever. The bewitching Swamplandia! is a tremendous achievement for anyone, period. . . . Effortless prose and [a] small, beautifully drawn cast of characters . . . as densely organic as the swamp in which it is set."

—Keith Staskiewicz, Entertainment Weekly

title: Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk
long_summary:
Billy Lynn carries the weight of war in his nineteen-year-old shoulders as he navigates a surreal day at a Dallas Cowboys stadium. Fresh from combat in Iraq, he and his squad have become reluctant celebrities after their firefight was captured on camera, turning them into poster boys for a conflict most Americans experience only through television screens.

The contrast couldn't be starker: while wealthy fans and corporate sponsors treat the soldiers like exotic trophies, Billy grapples with memories of his fallen sergeant and the knowledge that he'll soon return to the battlefield. The glittering halftime spectacle becomes a funhouse mirror reflecting America's complicated relationship with its wars—where genuine sacrifice meets manufactured patriotism, and where young men are celebrated as heroes while remaining fundamentally misunderstood.

Billy's internal struggle intensifies as he faces an impossible choice between duty and desire, between his brothers-in-arms and a chance at love. The novel dissects the machinery of modern warfare and celebrity culture with surgical precision, revealing how easily heroism becomes commodity and how the true cost of conflict remains hidden beneath layers of pageantry and political theater.
short_summary: Iraq War soldiers become unlikely celebrities at a Dallas Cowboys game, exposing the chasm between battlefield reality and American spectacle. Fountain's devastating satire skewers patriotism, consumerism, and our collective conscience.
author_bios: Ben Fountain has garnered recognition through the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction, the PEN/Hemingway Award, and the Los Angeles Book Prize for Fiction, along with a Whiting Writers Award. His literary achievements include being a National Book Award finalist and Dayton Literary Peace Prize runner-up. Fountain makes his home in Dallas.
quotes:
"[An] inspired, blistering war novel…Though it covers only a few hours, the book is a gripping, eloquent provocation. Class, privilege, power, politics, sex, commerce and the life-or-death dynamics of battle all figure in Billy Lynn's surreal game day experience."

—The New York Times

"Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk is not merely good; it's Pulitzer Prize-quality good . . . A bracing, fearless and uproarious satire of how contemporary war is waged and sold to the American public."

—San Francisco Chronicle

"A masterful echo of 'Catch-22,' with war in Iraq at the center. …a gut-punch of a debut novel…There's hardly a false note, or even a slightly off-pitch one, in Fountain's sympathetic, damning and structurally ambitious novel."

—The Washington Post

title: The Best Minds
subtitle: A Story of Friendship, Madness, and the Tragedy of Good Intentions
long_summary:
Two brilliant boys from academic families forge an unbreakable bond in 1970s New Rochelle, their friendship defined by intellectual ambition and fierce competition. Both gain admission to Yale, where one rockets through his studies with extraordinary success while the other begins to notice troubling changes beneath his friend's achievements.

A devastating phone call shatters everything: Michael Laudor has experienced a complete psychological collapse, landing him in psychiatric care with a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia. Against all odds, he fights his way back, enrolling at Yale Law School while still wrestling with delusions. The media celebrates his remarkable comeback story, Hollywood buys his memoir, and he becomes a symbol of triumph over mental illness.

But the victory proves illusory. Trapped within an unbreakable paranoid delusion, Michael commits an act of violence that destroys lives and transforms him from inspiration to cautionary tale. Jonathan Rosen examines this devastating trajectory with unflinching honesty, weaving together personal memory, cultural analysis, and hard questions about how society understands and treats mental illness. The result is both an intimate portrait of friendship's limits and a broader meditation on the distance between our best intentions and their real-world consequences.
short_summary: Two childhood friends seemed destined for greatness until one was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. Rosen's devastating memoir traces how brilliance, delusion, and society's failures converged in unthinkable tragedy.
author_bios: Jonathan Rosen has written the novels Eve's Apple and Joy Comes in the Morning alongside the nonfiction works The Talmud and the Internet: A Journey Between Worlds and The Life of the Skies: Birding at the End of Nature. His writing appears regularly in The New York Times, The New Yorker, The Atlantic, The Wall Street Journal, and various anthologies. He makes his home in New York City with his family.
quotes:
"Brave and nuanced . . . The Best Minds is too a thoughtfully built, deeply sourced indictment of a society that prioritizes profit, quick fixes and happy endings over the long slog of care . . . Effectively taking over his friend's unfinished project, braiding it with his own story of clinical anxiety as well as skeins of history, medicine, religion and true crime, the author has transcended childhood rivalry by twinning their stories, an act of tremendous compassion and a literary triumph."

—The New York Times

"Jonathan Rosen's The Best Minds: A Story of Friendship, Madness, and the Tragedy of Good Intentions takes its title from Allen Ginsberg's Howl, and could end up as just as enduring a work of American writing. Expect to see it on 'Best Of' lists, and plan to make space for its nearly 600 pages on your shelf. A memoir, a love letter, and a biblical tragedy all at once, it avoids easy answers but clings to difficult questions. A tale told with humility, it charts the path to hell by noting every good intention along the way."

—The New York Sun

"Dazzling . . . both a breathtaking and tragic portrait of a man with vast potential and a reckoning on how schizophrenia is treated and understood. This is a tough one to forget."

—Publisher's Weekly

title: The Art of Fielding
long_summary:
Baseball and fate collide at a lakeside Wisconsin college where one misplaced throw changes everything. Henry Skrimshander's professional dreams hang in the balance as he battles the mental demons that followed his crucial error. Around him, four other lives spiral into unexpected territory: a college president discovers late-in-life passion, a student-athlete navigates a risky romantic entanglement, a team captain confronts the sacrifices he's made for others, and a young woman seeks to rebuild after her marriage falls apart.

The baseball diamond becomes a stage where personal reckonings play out against the rhythm of a season building toward its finale. Each character must wrestle with questions of identity, desire, and the price of pursuing what matters most. Harbach weaves together their intersecting stories with remarkable insight into how we stumble toward understanding ourselves and each other. The result examines the space between our aspirations and reality, celebrating both the connections that sustain us and the courage required to change course when life demands it.
short_summary: One errant throw sends five lives spinning at a small Midwestern college. Baseball becomes the backdrop for a tender, expansive story about ambition, love, and finding your true path.
author_bios: Chad Harbach was raised in Wisconsin before earning his degree from Harvard in 1997. Following his undergraduate studies, he became a Henry Hoyns Fellow at the University of Virginia, completing his MFA in Fiction in 2004. Harbach serves as co-editor of the literary magazine n+1, which he helped establish, and currently resides in Virginia.
quotes:
"Reading The Art of Fielding is like watching a hugely gifted young shortstop: you keep waiting for the errors, but there are no errors. First novels this complete and consuming come along very, very seldom."

—Jonathan Franzen, author of Freedom

"An intricate, poised, tingling debut. Harbach's muscular prose breathes new life into the American past-time, recasts the personal worlds that orbit around it, and leaves you longing, lingering, and a baseball convert long after the last page."

—Téa Obreht, author of The Tiger's Wife

"Written with wit and grace and the true fan's eye and ear for the subtleties of the game. With The Art of Fielding, Harbach turns a double play that would make Skrimshander and Roth proud: The book will knock out baseball and literature fans alike."

—Sports Illustrated

title: The Copenhagen Trilogy
subtitle: Childhood; Youth; Dependency
long_summary:
Three interconnected memoirs trace a Danish woman's evolution from ambitious girl to struggling artist to addiction's grip. The narrative begins with a working-class child who dreams of literary fame despite her family's skepticism. As she matures, questions of sexuality and independence emerge alongside her first attempts at professional writing.

The final volume reveals how marriage to a physician becomes a gateway to prescription drug dependency, transforming her life into a cycle of manipulation and self-destruction. Ditlevsen examines the competing demands of creativity and conventional womanhood—how society's expectations for wives and mothers can suffocate artistic ambition.

Her stark honesty about addiction, relationships, and the writing life creates an intimate portrait of a woman caught between worlds. The work captures the particular challenges faced by female artists in mid-century Denmark, where literary circles remained largely masculine domains. Through precise, unadorned language, these memoirs reveal both the cost of pursuing art and the price of abandoning oneself to dependency.
short_summary: Ditlevsen chronicles her journey from working-class girlhood to literary ambition to devastating addiction. Her prose cuts like glass—unflinching, darkly funny, and utterly mesmerizing.
author_bios: Born into Copenhagen's working-class neighborhoods in 1917, Tove Ditlevsen published her debut poetry collection while still in her twenties. She went on to write extensively across multiple genres, with her most enduring work being the Copenhagen Trilogy: Childhood (1967), Youth (1967), and Dependency (1971). Ditlevsen died in 1976, leaving behind a literary legacy that continues to resonate with contemporary readers.
quotes:
"A particular kind of masterpiece, one that helps fill a particular kind of void. Ditlevsen's voice, diffident and funny, dead-on about her own mistakes, is a welcome addition to that canon of women who showed us their secret faces so that we might wear our own."

—The New York Times

"Ditlevsen's taut, simple prose shines a light on what life and love were like for working-class women in 20th century Copenhagen. Elena Ferrante fans, take note."

—Stylist

"Intense and elegant ... an absolute tour de force."

—Lucy Scholes, The Paris Review

title: My Friends
long_summary:
A radio broadcast featuring an unsettling tale about a man devoured by a cat becomes the catalyst that reshapes Khaled's entire existence. The story's mysterious author, Hosam Zowa, captures the young Libyan's imagination so completely that he abandons his homeland for university life in Edinburgh.

The transition from his familiar world to Britain's unfamiliar freedoms proves transformative. But participation in an anti-Qaddafi demonstration in London shatters his plans—violence erupts, leaving him wounded and stranded between countries. He cannot return to Libya, nor can he safely communicate his circumstances to his family, knowing their phone conversations are monitored by the regime.

Destiny intervenes through an unexpected hotel meeting with Hosam Zowa, the very writer whose words first stirred his soul. Their connection blossoms into an extraordinary friendship that becomes Khaled's anchor in exile. Yet as the Arab Spring ignites across the region, this bond tests him in unforeseen ways, demanding he navigate the painful contradictions between loyalty and self-preservation, homeland and sanctuary.

Matar crafts an intimate examination of how displacement reshapes identity and relationships, exploring the weight of choices that separate us from those we love most.
short_summary: When a radio story changes young Khaled's life forever, he leaves Libya for Edinburgh, only to find himself trapped in exile after a protest turns tragic. A profound meditation on friendship, family, and the impossible choices of displacement.
author_bios: Born in New York City to Libyan parents, Hisham Matar spent his early years between Tripoli and Cairo before settling in London. His memoir The Return earned him the 2017 Pulitzer Prize, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and the Rathbones Folio Prize, while his novel In the Country of Men received a Booker Prize shortlist. Matar has also published Anatomy of a Disappearance and A Month in Siena. He teaches at Barnard College and Columbia University and holds fellowships with both the Royal Society of Literature and the Royal Academy of Arts.
quotes:
"Dazzling . . . a personal, deeply felt work . . . tightly structured and controlled, looping back and forth through time and memory, building on itself in a process of gradual expansion and revelation."

—Toronto Star

"Matar channels Roberto Bolaño's theme of literary obsession in this sublime novel of a Libyan exile in London whose two friends return to Libya in 2011 to take part in the overthrow of Gadhafi. As the narrator describes his quest to understand life through literature, the novel's sense of truthfulness and urgency restores the reader's belief in what fiction can do."

—Publishers Weekly

"Riveting and humane . . . At the core of My Friends is a powerful juxtaposition of loneliness and camaraderie, self-reliance and dependence, which defines the outline of exile. . . ."

—The Atlantic

title: Priestdaddy
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Patricia Lockwood returns to her childhood home under unexpected circumstances, finding herself face-to-face with the eccentric reality of her upbringing. Her father defies every stereotype of Catholic clergy—he's a guitar-wielding, movie-loving figure whose unconventional approach to priesthood shaped Lockwood's complicated relationship with faith.

This memoir braids together memories from her youth with the surreal experience of being an adult living in her parents' rectory. Lockwood navigates the absurdities of this arrangement while reflecting on formative experiences that range from deeply personal to darkly comic. The narrative examines how we reconcile the people we've become with the families and institutions that formed us.

Lockwood's sharp wit illuminates the contradictions inherent in growing up within rigid religious structures while witnessing their human imperfections up close. She captures both the suffocating and nurturing aspects of Catholic culture, creating a portrait that's simultaneously irreverent and tender. The result is a meditation on identity, inheritance, and the complex bonds that tie us to our origins, even when we've traveled far from them.
short_summary: When a crisis forces poet Patricia Lockwood back into her guitar-obsessed priest father's rectory, hilarity and heartbreak collide. A brilliant memoir about faith, family, and finding yourself.
author_bios: Patricia Lockwood wrote the bestselling novel No One Is Talking About This, which earned Booker Prize and Dylan Thomas Prize recognition and appeared on The New York Times Book Review's 10 Best Books of 2021 list. The Atlantic included it among their Great American Novels of the past century. Lockwood has also published the memoir Priestdaddy and two poetry collections, and serves as a contributing editor at the London Review of Books.
quotes:
"Priestdaddy roars from the gate . . . it's not just that Lockwood has fresh eyes and quick wits, but that in her father she's lucked upon one of the great characters of this nonfiction decade . . . Lockwood's prose is cute and dirty and innocent and experienced, Betty Boop in a pas de deux with David Sedaris . . . I suspect it may mean a lot to many people, especially the lapsed Catholics among us. It is, for sure, like no book I have read."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Remarkable . . . Lockwood proceeds with a near unflagging sense of ironic exuberance and verbal inventiveness . . . this superabundance of comic energy and literary vigor is a measure of Lockwood's seriousness."

—The Washington Post

"Patricia Lockwood's side-splitting Priestdaddy puts the poetry back in memoir. Her verbal verve creates a reading experience of effervescent joy, even as Lockwood takes you through some of her life's darker passages. Destined to be a classic, Priestdaddy is this year's must-read memoir."

—Mary Karr, author of The Liars' Club

title: The Goldfinch
long_summary:
A terrorist bombing at the Metropolitan Museum tears apart young Theo Decker's world, claiming his mother's life and leaving him adrift in New York City. In those final moments of chaos, he makes an impulsive decision that will define his future: he takes a centuries-old Dutch masterpiece that becomes both his burden and salvation.

Rescued by an affluent family whose world feels alien to his own, Theo struggles to rebuild his identity while carrying the weight of his secret. The stolen artwork connects him to a hidden network of dealers and collectors, drawing him deeper into a realm where beauty and corruption intertwine.

Years later, Theo inhabits two different universes—the polished society of Manhattan's elite and the shadowy corners of the antique trade. The painting remains his constant companion, a reminder of love and loss that pulls him toward increasingly perilous choices. Tartt crafts a sweeping meditation on how tragedy reshapes us, how art transcends time, and how the past never truly releases its hold on our hearts.
short_summary: When a museum bombing kills his mother, thirteen-year-old Theo steals a priceless painting that becomes his obsession. Tartt's Pulitzer-winning masterpiece follows his journey from grief-stricken boy to conflicted adult navigating New York's shadowy art world.
author_bios: Donna Tartt has written novels that reach readers across forty languages worldwide. She first gained recognition with The Secret History in 1992. Her second novel, The Little Friend, earned her the WH Smith Literary Award and an Orange Prize for Fiction nomination. The Goldfinch brought Tartt both the Pulitzer Prize and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Fiction, cementing her place among contemporary literature's most celebrated voices.
quotes:
"Dazzling....[A] glorious, Dickensian novel, a novel that pulls together all Ms. Tartt's remarkable storytelling talents into a rapturous, symphonic whole and reminds the reader of the immersive, stay-up-all-night pleasures of reading."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"A long-awaited, elegant meditation on love, memory, and the haunting power of art....Eloquent and assured, with memorable characters....A standout-and well-worth the wait."

—Kirkus

"A soaring masterpiece."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Gene
subtitle: An Intimate History
long_summary:
Genetics shapes everything about us, yet how much do we truly understand about the invisible forces written in our DNA? Siddhartha Mukherjee tackles this fundamental question by tracing humanity's centuries-long effort to decode heredity's mysteries. From ancient philosophers pondering inheritance to modern scientists mapping entire genomes, this narrative captures our relentless drive to understand what makes us who we are.

The author transforms complex scientific concepts into accessible storytelling, drawing connections between groundbreaking research and intimate human experiences. His own family's struggles with mental illness serve as a lens through which larger questions emerge: How do our genes influence behavior, disease, and destiny? What ethical boundaries should guide our newfound ability to edit the genetic code itself?

This exploration reveals both the extraordinary promise and unsettling implications of genetic knowledge. As we gain unprecedented power to alter life at its most fundamental level, Mukherjee examines what it means to wield such capability responsibly. The result is a thought-provoking examination of science, identity, and the future of human evolution.
short_summary: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning author comes a sweeping exploration of genetics that weaves together scientific discovery, family memoir, and the ethical questions surrounding our genetic future.
author_bios: Siddhartha Mukherjee has written The Song of the Cell, The Gene: An Intimate History (#1 New York Times bestseller), The Emperor of All Maladies (2011 Pulitzer Prize winner), and The Laws of Medicine. Currently an associate professor of medicine at Columbia University, he works as both a cancer physician and researcher. A Rhodes Scholar with degrees from Stanford, Oxford, and Harvard Medical School, Mukherjee was elected to the National Academy of Medicine in 2023. His work appears in Nature, The New England Journal of Medicine, Cell, and The New Yorker.
quotes:
This is perhaps the greatest detective story ever told—a millennia-long search, led by a thousand explorers, from Aristotle to Mendel to Francis Collins, for the question marks at the center of every living cell. Like The Emperor of All Maladies, The Gene is prodigious, sweeping, and ultimately transcendent. If you're interested in what it means to be human, today and in the tomorrows to come, you must read this book.

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See

Sobering, humbling, and extraordinarily rich reading from a wise and gifted writer who sees how far we have come—but how much farther far we have to go to understand our human nature and destiny.

—Kirkus

Mukherjee deftly relates the basic scientific facts about the way genes are believed to function, while making clear the aspects of genetics that remain unknown. He offers insight into both the scientific process and the sociology of science... By relating familial information, Mukherjee grounds the abstract in the personal to add power and poignancy to his excellent narrative.

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Argonauts
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In this boundary-dissolving work of autotheory, a writer chronicles her experience of pregnancy while building a life with her fluidly gendered partner, artist Harry Dodge. The narrative moves fluidly between intimate domestic moments and philosophical inquiry, examining how academic theory intersects with lived experience.

Nelson interrogates fundamental questions about identity, sexuality, and what constitutes family in contemporary America. Her approach mirrors the intellectual tradition of thinkers like Susan Sontag, weaving together personal revelation with scholarly analysis. The book refuses easy categorization, functioning simultaneously as love story, philosophical treatise, and meditation on language itself.

What emerges is a fierce argument for both radical autonomy and the profound importance of care—seemingly contradictory impulses that Nelson demonstrates can coexist. Her unflinching examination of queer parenthood and partnership offers no simple answers, instead embracing the messy complexities of human connection. The result is a work that challenges readers to reconsider their assumptions about desire, commitment, and the stories we tell about our most intimate relationships.
short_summary: Nelson weaves personal narrative with critical theory to explore queer love, family-making, and identity. Intellectually rigorous yet deeply intimate, this genre-bending memoir challenges conventional thinking about desire and language.
author_bios: Maggie Nelson has written numerous acclaimed works including The Argonauts, Bluets, Like Love, On Freedom, The Red Parts, and her latest, Pathemata, Or, The Story of My Mouth. She is a professor at the University of Southern California and makes her home in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"Maggie Nelson cuts through our culture's prefabricated structures of thought and feeling with an intelligence whose ferocity is ultimately in the service of love. No piety is safe, no orthodoxy, no easy irony. The scare quotes burn off like fog."

—Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School

"What a dazzlingly generous, gloriously unpredictable book! Maggie Nelson shows us what it means to be real, offering a way of thinking that is as challenging as it is liberating. She invites us to 'pay homage to the transitive' and enjoy 'a becoming in which one never becomes.' Reading The Argonauts made me happier and freer."

—Eula Biss, author of Immunity

"It's Nelson's articulation of her many selves-the poet who writes prose; the memoirist who considers the truth specious; the essayist whose books amount to a kind of fairy tale, in which the protagonist goes from darkness to light, and then falls in love with a singular knight-that makes her readers feel hopeful."

—Hilton Als, The New Yorker

title: The Paying Guests
long_summary:
Post-war London bears the scars of conflict, its streets filled with displaced veterans and economic uncertainty. Within this fractured society, Frances Wray lives quietly with her mother in their Camberwell home—a house that once bustled with family life but now stands as a monument to their reduced circumstances.

Financial necessity compels the women to open their doors to paying tenants. The Barbers arrive as representatives of Britain's changing social fabric—young, ambitious, and unbound by the rigid conventions that have long governed the Wray household.

Frances finds herself drawn into unfamiliar territory as these newcomers challenge the boundaries she has carefully maintained. The novel examines how proximity breeds intimacy, and how the collision between different worlds can ignite desires that threaten to consume everything in their path. Waters crafts a story where social transformation becomes deeply personal, exploring the dangerous territory between respectability and rebellion in a society struggling to redefine itself.
short_summary: When a widowed mother and daughter take in lodgers in 1922 London, their genteel world fractures. Waters masterfully explores the collision of class and desire in post-war Britain.
author_bios: Sarah Waters has established herself as a master of historical fiction through novels including The Paying Guests, The Little Stranger, The Night Watch, Fingersmith, Affinity, and Tipping the Velvet. Her work has earned recognition from major literary institutions, with three Man Booker Prize shortlistings and two Orange Prize nominations. Granta selected Waters among their best young British novelists, and her books have achieved New York Times bestseller status. She makes her home in London.
quotes:
"An exquisitely tuned exploration of class in post-Edwardian Britain—with really hot sex…Tension is high from the first paragraph…Waters is a master of pacing, and her metaphor-laced prose is a delight…until the last page, the reader will have no idea what's going to happen. Waters keeps getting better, if that's even possible after the sheer perfection of her earlier novels."

—Kirkus

"An absorbing character study [and] expertly paced and gripping psychological narrative…Readers of Water's previous novels know that she brings historical eras to life with consummate skill, rendering authentic details into layered portraits of particular times and places…breathtaking"

—Publisher's Weekly

"Gripping… Sarah Waters is, quite simply, a marvelous writer…[with] complete mastery over her material."

—The Globe and Mail

title: House of Stone
subtitle: A Memoir of Home, Family, and a Lost Middle East
long_summary:
After surviving captivity and violence while reporting on the Libyan revolution, journalist Anthony Shadid makes an unexpected choice. Rather than seeking comfort in familiar places, he returns to a crumbling ancestral home in Lebanon—his great-grandfather's abandoned estate that he'd been slowly restoring.

This decision becomes the heart of a deeply personal journey that weaves together stone and memory, trauma and healing. As Shadid works to resurrect rooms and rebuild walls, he excavates his own family's story of displacement and adaptation across generations. The physical act of restoration becomes inseparable from his emotional reckoning with a life spent documenting conflict.

Through the lens of this single house, Shadid creates an intimate portrait of belonging that transcends borders. His narrative moves fluidly between the immediacy of construction work and the broader sweep of Lebanese history, between personal grief and collective memory. The result is both a love letter to a vanishing way of life and a meditation on how we construct identity from the fragments of our past.
short_summary: War correspondent Anthony Shadid rebuilds his great-grandfather's Lebanese estate while grappling with trauma from covering Middle Eastern conflicts. A profound meditation on home, heritage, and healing.
author_bios: Anthony Shadid (1968-2012) wrote Night Draws Near and distinguished himself as a journalist who revealed the human dimensions behind international headlines. His reporting from Iraq for the Washington Post earned him a Pulitzer Prize, followed by a second Pulitzer in 2010 for his coverage of the Arab Spring as the New York Times Middle East correspondent. Shadid documented uprisings across Egypt, Libya, and Syria before his death while on assignment in Syria in February 2012.
quotes:
"An honest-to-god, hands-down, undeniable and instant classic . . . written with levity and candor and lyricism that makes the book, improbably, both a compulsive read and one you don't want to end."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"This is not just the Arab world's Year in Provence. It is as if Shadid has combined the breakthrough effects of Amy Tan's The Joy Luck Club, William Faulkner's As I Lay Dying,and Frances Fitzgerald's Fire in the Lake into one enormously likeable book. It is a masterpiece."

—John Freeman, Boston Globe

"Elegiac, heartbreaking . . . A book conceived as an introspective project of personal recovery — as well as a meditation on politics, identity, craft, and beauty in the Levant — now stands as a memorial. It is a fitting one because of the writing skill and deep feeling [Shadid] unobtrusively displays."

—Steve Coll, The New York Times

"House of Stone is a haunting, beautifully realized piece of writing."

—Nick Flynn, author of The Ticking Is the Bomb

"What a beautiful introduction to a world that I knew so little about. House of Stone is engaging, poignant, and funny."

—Abraham Verghese, author of The Covenant of Water & Cutting for Stone

title: The Surrendered
long_summary:
The aftermath of war creates unexpected bonds between three damaged souls searching for meaning in the rubble of their former lives. An orphaned Korean girl, an American soldier running from his past, and a missionary's wife harboring dark secrets find themselves drawn together in ways that will define their futures.

Decades pass before fate brings them back into each other's orbits, forcing a reckoning with choices made in desperation and acts committed in the name of survival. Lee constructs a narrative that spans continents and generations, examining how trauma reshapes identity and whether redemption remains possible for those who have lost everything.

This sweeping story interrogates the true cost of heroism and questions what we owe to those we've failed. Through intricately woven timelines, Lee reveals how a single moment of connection can reverberate across a lifetime, creating bonds that neither time nor distance can fully sever.
short_summary: Three lives intersect at a Korean War orphanage, then collide again thirty years later. Lee's ambitious novel explores how love and violence echo across decades with devastating emotional precision.
author_bios: Chang-rae Lee has written six novels including Native Speaker, which earned the Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award for first fiction, and The Surrendered, recipient of the Dayton Peace Prize and a Pulitzer Prize finalist. His other works include My Year Abroad, On Such a Full Sea, A Gesture Life, and Aloft. The American Academy of Arts and Letters honored him with the 2021 Award of Merit for the Novel, and he currently teaches writing at Stanford University.
quotes:
"Lee's masterful fourth novel bursts with drama and human anguish as it documents the ravages and indelible effects of war. . . . Powerful, deeply felt, compulsively readable and imbued with moral gravity, the novel does not peter out into easy redemption. It's a harrowing tale: bleak, haunting, often heartbreaking and not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

"[The Surrendered] is epic in scope, masterful in execution, heart stopping at times, and heartbreaking at others. The meticulous narrative unfolds over 52 years and across three continents. Nothing is rushed; nothing is overlooked. We can even feel the buzz of a window pane on our fingertips as rumbling Japanese military vehicles approach along a gravel road...Lee understands that in art and in stories what is perhaps most valuable is not what can be explained but what can be felt."

—The Boston Globe

"Lee...writes dense and gorgeous prose...Lee shows great tenderness for his [characters], even as he refuses them easy redemption. The final paragraph of his beautiful and tragic novel is as sublime and transcendent as any I can remember."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Barkskins
long_summary:
Two French laborers arrive in colonial North America with nothing but debts to pay through years of servitude. Their choices set in motion centuries of consequence that will ripple across continents and generations.

René Sel endures the backbreaking work of forest clearing, eventually marrying into the Mi'kmaw community and creating a family line forever caught between worlds. Charles Duquet breaks free from his obligations through cunning and ambition, launching himself into the fur trade and ultimately establishing a vast logging dynasty.

Across three hundred years, their descendants scatter from the Canadian wilderness to the trading ports of China and the remote forests of New Zealand. Each generation faces its own trials—violence, disease, cultural upheaval, and the relentless pursuit of profit from an apparently endless supply of trees.

Proulx constructs an intricate tapestry that weaves together individual human drama with the larger story of environmental devastation. The novel examines how personal ambition and survival instincts drive broader patterns of exploitation, ultimately questioning whether the natural abundance that once seemed limitless can survive humanity's hunger for resources. Through vivid characterization spanning centuries, she illuminates the complex relationship between human progress and ecological destruction.
short_summary: Two French indentured servants in 17th-century New France take vastly different paths—one trapped between cultures, the other building a timber empire. Proulx traces their descendants across three centuries of environmental destruction.
author_bios: Annie Proulx has written eleven books, including the novels The Shipping News and Barkskins, along with the story collection Close Range. She has received numerous accolades such as a Pulitzer Prize, a National Book Award, the Irish Times International Fiction Prize, and a PEN/Faulkner award. Her story "Brokeback Mountain" became an Academy Award–winning film. Proulx makes her home in New Hampshire.
quotes:
"Annie Proulx's Barkskins is remarkable not just for its length, but for its scope and ambition. It's a monumental achievement, one that will perhaps be remembered as her finest work. . . It's exhilarating to read Proulx, a master storyteller; she is as adept at placing us in the dripping, cold Mi'kma'ki forests as in the stuffy Duke & Sons parlors. Despite the length, nothing seems extraneous, and not once does the reader sense the story slipping from Proulx's grasp, resulting in the kind of immersive reading experience that only comes along every few years."

—Publishers Weekly

"Part ecological fable à la Ursula K. Le Guin, part foundational saga along the lines of Brian Moore's Black Robe and, yes, James Michener's Centennial, Proulx's story builds in depth and complication without becoming unduly tangled and is always told with the most beautiful language. Another tremendous book from Proulx, sure to find and enthrall many readers."

—Kirkus

"Magnificent... Barkskins flies... One of the chief pleasures of Proulx's prose is that it conveys you to so many vanished wildwoods, where you get to stand 'tiny and amazed in the kingdom of pines.' This is also the great sadness of Barkskins. The propulsive tension here is generated not by wondering what will happen to each character, but by knowing that the forests will be leveled one after another... If Barkskins doesn't bear exquisite witness to our species's insatiable appetite for consumption, nothing can."

—Anthony Doerr, Outside Magazine

title: Deep Down Dark
subtitle: The Untold Stories of 33 Men Buried in a Chilean Mine, and the Miracle That Set Them Free
long_summary:
In August 2010, a catastrophic mining accident in Chile's Atacama Desert became a global phenomenon as rescue teams worked frantically to reach thirty-three trapped workers. While television cameras captured the surface drama, the underground reality remained hidden from view.

Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Héctor Tobar gained unprecedented access to the survivors, who had made a pact to tell their story as one voice. Their account reveals how ordinary men faced extraordinary circumstances in a space that became simultaneously tomb and sanctuary. In the suffocating darkness, they grappled with despair and hope, hunger and faith, creating bonds that sustained them through an ordeal that tested the limits of human endurance.

Tobar transforms their collective testimony into immersive storytelling that captures both the physical reality of their underground prison and the psychological journey of men confronting their own mortality. The narrative illuminates how crisis can reveal the deepest aspects of human nature, showing how individuals can find meaning and connection even in the most desperate circumstances.
short_summary: Thirty-three miners trapped beneath thousands of feet of rock for sixty-nine days finally tell their story. Tobar's exclusive access creates masterful narrative journalism about survival, faith, and the human spirit.
author_bios: Héctor Tobar has built a distinguished career as both journalist and novelist, earning a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting work. His books include the New York Times bestseller Deep Down Dark, along with The Last Great Road Bum, The Barbarian Nurseries, Translation Nation, and The Tattooed Soldier. Currently teaching at UC Irvine, Tobar contributes regularly to the New York Times opinion pages and has written for major publications including The New Yorker and the Los Angeles Times. Born to Guatemalan immigrant parents, he makes his home in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"The equal, if the geographical inverse, of Into Thin Air."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"That Tobar has so vividly reconstructed a life-threatening event remembered differently by thirty-three minds is a mountainous feat of reportage."

—The Washington Post

"My favorite book of the year. Perfect for fans of Unbroken."

—Ann Patchett, People

title: The Lonely Polygamist
long_summary:
At the center of an impossibly large household stands one man facing complete collapse. Golden Richards oversees a chaotic empire of four wives and twenty-eight children, but his world is cracking under the weight of financial ruin and devastating personal losses. The death of his daughter and the stillbirth of his son have left him spiritually adrift, even as his construction business crumbles and his sprawling family descends into feuds and rebellion.

Brady Udall crafts a remarkable portrait of a man whose deep religious convictions clash with human frailty. As Golden becomes involved in a relationship that could destroy his already fragile world, the novel examines how we navigate between duty and desire, faith and doubt. The story unfolds as both intimate character study and sweeping family saga, revealing the absurd and heartbreaking realities of a life lived at impossible scale.

This is American fiction at its most ambitious—a work that finds profound meaning in the collision between traditional values and modern chaos, between the sacred and the profane.
short_summary: Golden Richards, a polygamist with four wives and 28 children, struggles with desire, secrecy, and the chaos of family life. Udall blends humor and pathos in a sprawling American tragicomedy.
author_bios: Brady Udall wrote the New York Times bestseller The Lonely Polygamist along with The Miracle Life of Edgar Mint and Letting Loose the Hounds. He is a professor at Boise State University and makes his home in Boise, Idaho, where he lives with his wife and children.
quotes:
"[An] exceptional tale of an exceptional family."

—The New York Times

"The novel you must read this summer.... a riveting emotional tornado of a novel."

—Entertainment Weekly

"This is big-hearted American storytelling, the best new book I've read in years."

—Bonnie Jo Campbell, author of Once Upon a River & American Salvage

title: Fire Weather
subtitle: A True Story from a Hotter World
long_summary:
The catastrophic 2016 wildfire that consumed Fort McMurray offers a startling glimpse into humanity's evolving dance with one of nature's most elemental forces. John Vaillant uses this devastating event—which forced nearly 90,000 residents to flee and caused billions in damage—as a starting point for examining how fire has shaped human civilization and now threatens to reshape it again.

Vaillant traces the deep historical relationship between humans and fire, from our earliest use of flames for cooking and protection to the industrial machinery that powers modern life. But as climate change intensifies, this ancient partnership grows increasingly unstable. The author skillfully connects the dots between Canada's massive oil extraction operations, emerging climate science, and the new reality of megafires that can consume entire cities.

Through vivid storytelling and meticulous research, Vaillant reveals how the same fossil fuel industry centered in Fort McMurray contributes to the very conditions that made such a catastrophic fire possible. He follows the human stories behind the headlines while building a compelling case that we're entering an era where fire will play an increasingly dangerous role in our lives.
short_summary: The 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire becomes a lens for understanding our changing relationship with fire itself. Vaillant weaves together oil industry history, climate science, and human stories in this urgent exploration of our increasingly flammable world.
author_bios: John Vaillant has written several notable works including the bestselling nonfiction titles The Golden Spruce and The Tiger, along with the novel The Jaguar's Children, which earned finalist recognition for both the Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize and the International Dublin Literary Award. His writing has been honored with the Governor General's Literary Award, British Columbia's National Award for Canadian Non-Fiction, the Windham-Campbell Literature Prize, and the Pearson Writers' Trust Prize for Nonfiction. Vaillant's journalism appears in publications such as The New Yorker, The Atlantic, National Geographic, and The Guardian.
quotes:
"This acclaimed and award-winning book offers a braided history of the rise of the oil sector and climate science. Set against the backdrop of the 2016 Fort McMurray, Alta., wildfires it is just the right amount of terrifying."

—The Globe and Mail

"All-too-timely....The real protagonist here is the fire itself: an unruly and terrifying force with insatiable appetites. This book is both a real-life thriller and a moment-by-moment account of what happened—and why, as the climate changes and humans don't, it will continue to happen again and again."

—The New York Times

"There's a lot of good Elizabeth Kolbert–level popular science writing here along with grittier portraits of the lives of the people who make their living among the tar sands and scrub. Vaillant...asks interesting questions...Perhaps the one most worthy of pondering being a deceptively simple one: 'Is fire alive?' A timely, well-written work of climate change reportage."

—Kirkus

title: The Return
subtitle: Fathers, Sons and the Land in Between
long_summary:
Three decades after fleeing Libya as a child, Hisham Matar crosses back into his homeland following Qaddafi's fall. The country he finds bears little resemblance to the one his family escaped, yet the questions that drove them into exile remain unanswered. His father, once a diplomat who became an enemy of the state, vanished from Cairo's streets years earlier—another victim swallowed by the regime's machinery of repression.

The empty prison cells offer no revelations, no trace of the man who shaped Matar's understanding of courage and resistance. Instead, this homecoming becomes something more complex: an excavation of memory, identity, and the peculiar mathematics of loss. Matar navigates between his role as son and witness, between the Libya of his childhood imagination and the scarred nation emerging from dictatorship.

This memoir transcends its political backdrop to examine how absence can define a life as powerfully as presence. It reveals the ways tyranny reaches across borders and generations, while also celebrating the stubborn resilience of love and the possibility of return—even when what we seek to recover may be forever beyond reach.
short_summary: A son returns to post-revolution Libya searching for answers about his father's disappearance under Qaddafi's regime. Matar weaves personal loss with political upheaval in this haunting meditation on exile and hope.
author_bios: Born in New York City to Libyan parents, Hisham Matar spent his early years in Tripoli and Cairo before settling in London. His memoir The Return earned the 2017 Pulitzer Prize, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and the Rathbones Folio Prize. Matar's novel In the Country of Men received a Booker Prize shortlisting, and he has also published Anatomy of a Disappearance and A Month in Siena. He teaches at Barnard College and Columbia University and holds fellowships with both the Royal Society of Literature and the Royal Academy of Arts.
quotes:
"[Hisham Matar] writes with both a novelist's eye for physical and emotional detail, and a reporter's tactile sense of place and time. The prose is precise, economical, chiseled; the narrative elliptical, almost musical…. The Return is, at once, a suspenseful detective story about a writer investigating his father's fate at the hands of a brutal dictatorship, and a son's efforts to come to terms with his father's ghost, who has haunted more than half his life by his absence."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"A moving, unflinching memoir of a family torn apart by the savage realities of today's Middle East. The crushing of hopes raised by the Arab spring—at both the personal and national levels—is conveyed all the more powerfully because Matar's anger remains controlled, his belief in humanity undimmed."

—Kazuo Ishiguro, "The Best Summer Books," The Guardian

"What a brilliant book. Hisham Matar has the quality all historians—of the world and the self—most need: He knows how to stand back and let the past speak. In chronicling his quest for his father, his manner is fastidious, even detached, but his anger is raw and unreconciled; through his narrative art he bodies out the shape of loss and gives a universality to his very particular experience of desolation. The Return reads as easily as a thriller, but is a story that will stick: A person is lost, but gravity and resonance remain."

—Hilary Mantel, author of Wolf Hall & Bring Up the Bodies

title: The Sisters
long_summary:
Three daughters of a Tunisian mother and absent Swedish father carry different pieces of their fractured heritage. Each sister embodies her own form of searching—one through rigid control, another through artistic expression, the third through geographic escape and unexpected love.

Their paths intersect with Jonas, a young man whose own mixed heritage mirrors theirs in unexpected ways. Across thirty years, chance meetings and deliberate choices bind their stories together, from Mediterranean markets to Scandinavian cities to American streets.

The narrative unfolds in six distinct movements, each capturing different temporal rhythms—some covering years of gradual change, others focusing on pivotal moments that last mere minutes. Family loyalty collides with personal desire, cultural identity shifts across borders, and long-buried truths surface to reshape everything the characters believed about their origins. The disappearance of one sister becomes the catalyst for revelations that transform how they understand not just their family, but themselves.
short_summary: Three sisters navigate love, betrayal, and family secrets across continents and decades. When one disappears, a shocking revelation threatens to unravel everything they thought they knew about themselves.
author_bios: Jonas Hassen Khemiri has written six novels, seven plays, and a collection of short stories and essays. His novel The Family Clause was a finalist for the National Book Award for Translated Literature, while his play Invasion! earned an Obie Award for best script. A recipient of a Cullman Fellowship at the New York Public Library, Khemiri's writing has been featured in The New York Times, The New Yorker, and many other publications. The Sisters marks his first book written in English. He currently lives in Brooklyn with his family and teaches creative writing at New York University.
quotes:
"If you welcome this novel into your mind, it will warm and transform you."

—Tess Gunty, author of The Rabbit Hutch

"Jonas Hassen Khemiri is the very rare combination of a deep intellectual and a true storyteller, as smart as he is entertaining."

—Fredrik Backman author of A Man Called Ove

"Jonas Hassen Khemiri illuminates complex familial intimacies with utter clarity."

—Raven Leilani, author of Luster

title: Lincoln in the Bardo
long_summary:
Abraham Lincoln's personal tragedy becomes the foundation for an extraordinary literary experiment that defies conventional storytelling. After young Willie Lincoln succumbs to illness in 1862, his spirit enters a liminal space between life and death—a realm populated by restless souls unable to move on.

George Saunders constructs this otherworldly cemetery as a cacophonous theater where the dead debate, argue, and reveal their unfinished business. The narrative unfolds through a chorus of spectral voices, each carrying their own regrets and obsessions. As Lincoln himself wanders the graveyard in his grief, a battle emerges for his son's eternal fate.

This bold reimagining of historical sorrow transcends its Civil War setting to examine universal questions about mortality, attachment, and letting go. Saunders weaves together the intimate anguish of a father's loss with broader meditations on how we cling to what cannot last. The result challenges readers to consider what it means to love fully while accepting life's impermanence, delivered through an innovative structure that feels both playful and profound.
short_summary: George Saunders transforms the historical death of Lincoln's son into supernatural brilliance. Willie finds himself in a purgatory populated by quarreling ghosts, while his grieving father visits the crypt in this formally daring exploration of love and loss.
author_bios: George Saunders has published thirteen books, including his Man Booker Prize-winning novel Lincoln in the Bardo and five story collections such as the National Book Award finalist Tenth of December and Liberation Day (which President Obama selected as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). The New York Times included three of his works—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—in their 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. Saunders teaches at Syracuse University and hosts Story Club on Substack.
quotes:
"A luminous feat of generosity and humanism."

—Colson Whitehead, The New York Times

"A masterpiece."

—Zadie Smith

"An extended national ghost story . . . As anyone who knows Saunders's work would expect, his first novel is a strikingly original production."

—The Washington Post

title: Steve Jobs
long_summary:
Drawing from extensive conversations with Steve Jobs himself and interviews with more than 100 people from his inner circle, this biography reveals the mind behind one of history's most transformative business figures. The book examines how Jobs fundamentally altered six different industries through his unique ability to merge artistic vision with cutting-edge technology.

Jobs granted Isaacson complete access while refusing any editorial oversight, creating an unusually candid portrait. The narrative exposes the contradictions that defined him: his relentless pursuit of perfection, his demanding leadership style, and the personal costs of his uncompromising vision. 

This account illuminates how Jobs built Apple into a company where imaginative leaps became tangible innovations that reshaped how we interact with technology. The story serves as both inspiration and warning, revealing the complex relationship between genius and character, and questioning what we're willing to sacrifice in pursuit of revolutionary change.
short_summary: The definitive biography of Apple's mercurial cofounder, built from unprecedented access to Jobs himself and those closest to him. Isaacson captures both the visionary genius and the complicated human behind the revolution.
author_bios: Walter Isaacson has written bestselling biographies of Elon Musk, Jennifer Doudna, Leonardo da Vinci, Steve Jobs, Benjamin Franklin, and Albert Einstein. A professor of history at Tulane, Isaacson previously served as CEO of the Aspen Institute, chair of CNN, and editor of Time. He received the National Humanities Medal in 2023.

title: Iron Curtain
subtitle: The Crushing of Eastern Europe, 1944-1956
long_summary:
The aftermath of 1945 left Stalin with an unprecedented opportunity: twelve diverse nations across Eastern Europe now lay within his sphere of influence. What followed was one of history's most ambitious social experiments—the systematic dismantling of entire societies and their reconstruction according to Communist ideology.

Anne Applebaum documents this massive undertaking, examining how the Soviet apparatus methodically erased existing institutions, traditions, and ways of life. Through previously inaccessible documents and testimonies from those who lived through this transformation, she illuminates the human cost of ideological revolution. Families watched their communities disappear overnight. Citizens navigated impossible choices between survival and conscience.

The book reveals the machinery behind this continental reshaping—the propaganda campaigns, the surveillance networks, the calculated destruction of civil society. Applebaum shows how quickly familiar worlds can vanish, replaced by systems that turn neighbors into informants and reduce human relationships to political calculations. This is the story of how an entire civilization was erased and rewritten, leaving millions to rebuild their understanding of reality itself.
short_summary: Applebaum reveals how Stalin systematically converted Eastern Europe to Communism after WWII, transforming millions of lives in the process. Drawing on newly opened archives and survivor interviews, she captures a lost civilization defined by cruelty and paranoia.
author_bios: Anne Applebaum joined The Atlantic as a staff writer in 2020 following seventeen years with The Washington Post as a columnist. Her extensive body of work includes Twilight of Democracy, Red Famine, Iron Curtain, Between East and West, and the Pulitzer Prize-winning Gulag. She maintains residences in both Poland and Washington, D.C.
quotes:
"One of the most compelling but also serious works on Europe's past to appear in recent memory…In her relentless quest for understanding, Applebaum shines light into forgotten worlds of human hope, suffering and dignity."

—The Washington Post

"Remarkable…a book that reanimates a world that was largely hidden from Western eyes, and that many people who lived and suffered in it would prefer to forget….Iron Curtain gives us some idea of what it was like to be trapped in the Soviet experiment, to be a witness to the demolition and reconstruction of one's environment."

—Louis Menand, The New Yorker

"Iron Curtain is a superb, revisionistic, brilliantly perceptive, often witty, totally gripping history, filled with colorful character sketches of Stalinist monsters, based on Soviet and local archives, on hundreds of interviews with survivors, and on the widest reading, that tells the dramatic, unknown and terrifying story of the Stalinization of eastern Europe….The book is full of things I didn't know — but should have."

—Simon Sebag Montefiore, London Evening Standard

title: The Vanishing Half
long_summary:
Two sisters born into the same small town make choices that send their lives spiraling in opposite directions. While one remains rooted in their community, embracing her heritage and raising her daughter where she grew up, the other constructs an entirely new existence built on concealment—marrying into a white family that knows nothing of her true background.

Decades pass, yet the invisible threads connecting these women refuse to break. Bennett crafts a sweeping narrative that follows multiple generations as they grapple with questions of belonging, authenticity, and the stories we tell ourselves about who we are. The novel examines how the desire to escape one's circumstances can reshape not just individual lives, but entire family legacies.

This multigenerational chronicle spans from the Jim Crow South to modern California, revealing how the past continues to influence present choices in unexpected ways. More than a story about racial identity, it's an investigation into the human longing to reinvent oneself and the complex motivations that drive people to abandon their origins in pursuit of different possibilities.
short_summary: Twin sisters choose radically different paths when one decides to pass for white while the other remains in their black community. A multigenerational saga exploring identity, family secrets, and the weight of the past.
author_bios: Brit Bennett grew up in Southern California before completing her undergraduate studies at Stanford University and receiving her MFA from the University of Michigan. Her first novel, The Mothers, achieved New York Times bestseller status and earned finalist recognition for both the NBCC John Leonard First Novel Prize and PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize. The Vanishing Half immediately claimed the #1 spot on The New York Times bestseller list, received a National Book Award longlist nomination, and appeared among The New York Times' ten best books of the year. Bennett has been recognized as a National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 honoree and selected for Time's Next 100 Influential People list.
quotes:
"[Bennett's] second [book], The Vanishing Half, more than lives up to her early promise. . . more expansive yet also deeper, a multi-generational family saga that tackles prickly issues of racial identity and bigotry and conveys the corrosive effects of secrets and dissembling. It's also a great read that will transport you out of your current circumstances, whatever they are. . . Like The Mothers, this novel keeps you turning pages not just to find out what happens."

—NPR

"Bennett's gorgeously written second novel, an ambitious meditation on race and identity, considers the divergent fates of twin sisters, born in the Jim Crow South, after one decides to pass for white. Bennett balances the literary demands of dynamic characterization with the historical and social realities of her subject matter."

—The New York Times

"Assured and magnetic. . .Bennett is deeply engaged in the unknowability of other people and the scourge of colorism…calls up Toni Morrison's The Bluest Eye, the book's 50-year-old antecedent. . . .  [a] rich, sharp story about the way identity is formed."

—Kirkus

title: The Big Short
subtitle: Inside the Doomsday Machine
long_summary:
While most of Wall Street celebrated soaring housing prices and complex financial instruments, a small group of outsiders recognized the brewing catastrophe. These financial misfits—dismissed as pessimists and troublemakers—saw through the elaborate facade of mortgage-backed securities to identify the bubble that would eventually devastate the global economy.

Lewis introduces us to the unlikely prophets who dared to bet against conventional wisdom, risking their careers and reputations to short the housing market. Their stories reveal not just prescient analysis, but the psychological fortitude required to maintain conviction while an entire industry called them wrong. Through their eyes, we witness the machinery of financial self-deception and the human cost of institutional blindness.

This account transforms abstract economic concepts into visceral human drama, exposing how sophisticated markets can become vehicles for spectacular delusion.
