Lewis captures both the absurdity and tragedy of a system that rewarded complexity over clarity, showing how a few clear-eyed observers navigated the chaos to profit from others' willful ignorance.
short_summary: Michael Lewis tells the story of the contrarians who saw the 2008 financial crisis coming and bet against the system. Character-driven financial journalism with Lewis's signature wit and insight.
author_bios: Michael Lewis has written several bestselling works including Liar's Poker, Moneyball, The Blind Side, The Big Short, The Fifth Risk, and Going Infinite. He currently resides in Berkeley, California, with his family.
quotes:
"No one writes with more narrative panache about money and finance than Mr. Lewis....[he] does a nimble job of using his subjects' stories to explicate the greed, idiocies and hypocrisies of a system notably lacking in grown-up supervision....Writing in faintly Tom Wolfe-ian prose, Mr. Lewis does a colorful job of introducing the lay reader to the Darwinian world of the bond market."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"One of the best business books of the past two decades."

—Malcolm Gladwell, The New York Times

"Superb: Michael Lewis doing what he does best, illuminating the idiocy, madness and greed of modern finance. . . . Lewis achieves what I previously imagined impossible: He makes subprime sexy all over again."

—Andrew Leonard, Salon.com

title: Trust Exercise
long_summary:
The drama department at an elite arts academy becomes a crucible for teenage passion and ambition. David and Sarah navigate their first serious relationship amid the intensity of Shakespeare rehearsals and the demanding presence of their charismatic instructor, Mr. Kingsley. Their world revolves around performance and possibility, insulated from ordinary teenage concerns.

Yet reality has a way of breaking through even the most carefully constructed environments. Family obligations, financial pressures, and looming decisions about the future begin to fracture their artistic sanctuary. A series of dramatic events shatters the illusion of their protected space.

Just as readers settle into this coming-of-age narrative, Choi delivers a masterful surprise. The novel reveals that the story we've been following represents only one perspective on these events. New voices emerge to challenge and complicate our understanding, forcing us to question everything we believed about these characters and their experiences.

This innovative structure transforms a familiar story of teenage romance into something far more complex—a meditation on how memory shapes narrative, how power influences whose stories get told, and how the passage of time reveals uncomfortable truths about the relationships that define us.
short_summary: Two drama students fall in love at a competitive 1980s arts high school, but their story fractures into competing narratives about memory, power, and truth. Choi's bold novel reshapes itself before your eyes.
author_bios: Susan Choi has written five novels, including Trust Exercise, which won the National Book Award for Fiction, along with The Foreign Student, American Woman, A Person of Interest, and My Education. Her work has earned her the Asian American Literary Award for fiction, the PEN/W. G. Sebald Award, a Lambda Literary Award, and the Sunday Times Audible Short Story Award. She has received fellowships from both the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation. Susan Choi teaches in the Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"[Trust Exercise] burns more brightly than anything [Choi's] yet written. This psychologically acute novel enlists your heart as well as your mind. Zing will go certain taut strings in your chest. . . . Choi builds her novel carefully, but it is packed with wild moments of grace and fear and abandon. . . . [A] delicious and, in its way, rather delicate . . . phosphorescent examination of sexual consent."

—The New York Times

"A gonzo literary performance one could mistake for a magic trick, duping its readers with glee before leaving them impossibly moved. . . . Facts are debated in Trust Exercise, yes, but Choi always tells the truth."

—Entertainment Weekly

"What begins as the story of obsessive first love between drama students at a competitive performing arts high school in the early 1980s twists into something much darker in Choi's singular new novel . . . an effective interrogation of memory, the impossible gulf between accuracy and the stories we tell. . . . The writing (exquisite) and the observations (cuttingly accurate) make Choi's latest both wrenching and one-of-a-kind. Never sentimental; always thrillingly alive."

—Kirkus

title: The Wren, the Wren
long_summary:
Poetry can be both blessing and curse, as three generations of McDaragh women discover in their complicated relationship with family legacy. Young Nell finds herself drawn to her grandfather Phil's verses, despite never having met the celebrated Irish poet who abandoned his family decades earlier. His romantic words seem to offer guidance as she navigates Dublin's literary scene, searching for her own artistic identity and chasing intense relationships that mirror the passion in his work.

For Nell's mother Carmel, those same poems carry darker memories. She remembers how her father's charm could seduce women into reckless decisions, just as it had her own mother Terry. Yet Phil's gift for beautiful language couldn't compensate for his failures as a parent, leaving Carmel to question how someone capable of such lyrical insight could inflict such lasting damage on those who loved him most.

Enright crafts a meditation on how art and abandonment intertwine across generations, examining whether creative genius excuses personal cruelty. The McDaragh women must decide what parts of their inheritance to embrace and what to leave behind, discovering that their own capacity for love proves more enduring than any poem.
short_summary: Three generations of Irish women reckon with the legacy of a celebrated poet who was also an absent father. Enright weaves family trauma and transcendence into something luminous and unforgettable.
author_bios: Anne Enright has written eight novels, including her latest work The Wren. Her literary achievements include winning the Man Booker Prize and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction. Enright holds the distinction of being the first Laureate for Irish Fiction and received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Irish Book Awards in 2022. She makes her home in Dublin, where she continues her writing career.
quotes:
"This is a powerful, thoughtful book by one of the great living writers on the subject of family. Speaking about love in terms both domestic and transcendent, Enright coos through newly connected wires."

—The New York Times

"To call Anne Enright's new novel a moving, nuanced glimpse at three generations of Irish life underplays its thrilling expansiveness: in the end, The Wren, The Wren is an electrifying romp through language itself—its dizzying possibilities and satisfactions—led by one the most gifted writers working in English today."

—Jennifer Egan, author of A Visit From the Goon Squad & The Candy House

"The power of Enright's novel derives not so much from the age-old tale of men behaving badly, but from the beauty and depth of her own style. She's so deft at rendering arresting insights into personality types or situations."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here
subtitle: The United States, Central America, and the Making of a Crisis
long_summary:
The humanitarian crisis unfolding at America's southern border represents far more than a contemporary policy challenge—it's the inevitable consequence of generations of flawed decision-making and institutional failures. Jonathan Blitzer exposes the intricate web connecting American foreign policy missteps with the desperate exodus of families from Central America and beyond.

Through meticulous investigative work, Blitzer traces how political upheaval, endemic violence, and economic collapse have rendered entire communities uninhabitable, forcing people to undertake perilous journeys northward. His reporting illuminates the human cost of bureaucratic dysfunction, revealing how good intentions repeatedly collide with political expediency.

The book captures the experiences of those caught between worlds—migrants who risk everything for safety, officials struggling within broken systems, and communities grappling with the consequences of decades-old choices. Blitzer demonstrates how immigration has become the defining issue of our time, reshaping American politics and society in ways that extend far beyond border towns and detention centers. This is essential reading for understanding how past decisions continue to reverberate through contemporary American life.
short_summary: Forensic reporting reveals how decades of policy failures created the humanitarian crisis at the southern border. Blitzer weaves together migrant stories with political machinations in this essential chronicle of American immigration.
genres: History / United States / State & Local / Southwest (AZ, NM, OK, TX)
author_bios: Jonathan Blitzer contributes as a staff writer for The New Yorker, bringing investigative expertise to complex political issues. His journalism has earned recognition through a National Award for Education Reporting and an Edward R. Murrow Award. Blitzer served as a 2021 Emerson Fellow at New America and currently resides in New York City with his family.
quotes:
"This book will tear your heart out. Both intimate and comprehensive, it treks deep into the tragedies of El Salvador, Guatemala, and US immigration policy. Jon Blitzer's reporting is vast, meticulous, and authoritative. The main characters are drawn with the richness of great fiction."

—William Finnegan, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Barbarian Days

"As Jonathan Blitzer shows in Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here, his timely and instructive history of the immigration crisis, the trouble at the border isn't likely to be solved soon, since it is the outcome of a long and vexed entanglement between the United States and its southern neighbors . . . Conflicts over immigration often arise from similarity rather than difference, and the strangers at our border have a familiar history that Blitzer tells in meticulous and vivid detail. It is our own."

—Matthieu Aikins, The New York Times

"What we're seeing today on the southern border and in cities including New York, where more than 100,000 migrants arrived in the past year—are reverberations of a long, violent history that implicates the United States for its meddling in Central America. This is the story that Jonathan Blitzer painstakingly documents in his new book, Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here . . . Blitzer shows all the ways our immigration system is in shambles. A series of misguided actions and their consequences brought us to this point. This book begins the reckoning we desperately need."

—The Atlantic

title: The Sleepwalkers
subtitle: How Europe Went to War in 1914
long_summary:
The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand marked the beginning of a catastrophic chain reaction that would engulf Europe in its most devastating conflict yet. Christopher Clark reconstructs the intricate web of diplomatic failures, miscalculations, and political incompetence that transformed a regional incident in the Balkans into a global war claiming millions of lives.

Through a forensic examination of decision-making in Europe's major capitals, Clark exposes how a continent's leaders—despite their claims to rational governance—repeatedly chose the most destructive path forward. The book illuminates the underlying tensions and systemic weaknesses that made Europe a powder keg waiting to explode, while chronicling the specific moments when diplomacy gave way to military mobilization.

What emerges is a portrait of a political class so trapped by their own assumptions and commitments that they sleepwalked into disaster. Clark's analysis reveals how a supposedly minor crisis in southeastern Europe could unravel decades of relative stability, ultimately reshaping the modern world through unprecedented destruction.
short_summary: Clark traces Europe's stumble into World War I through thirty-seven fateful days in 1914. Meticulously researched and grippingly told, revealing how misunderstandings and ineffectual leadership dragged the world into catastrophe.
author_bios: Christopher Clark teaches modern European history at the University of Cambridge, where he serves as a fellow of St. Catharine's College. His published works include Revolutionary Spring, The Sleepwalkers, Time and Power, and Iron Kingdom, among other historical studies.
quotes:
"Excellent. . . . The book is stylishly written as well as superb scholarship. No analysis of the origins of the First World War will henceforth be able to bypass this magisterial work."

—Ian Kershaw, BBC

"The distinctive achievement of The Sleepwalkers is Clark's single-volume survey of European history leading up to the war. That may sound dull. Quite the contrary. It is as if a light had been turned on a half-darkened stage of shadowy characters cursing themselves without reason. . . . A thoroughly comprehensive and highly readable account. . . . The brilliance of Clark's far-reaching history is that we are able to discern how the past was genuinely prologue. . . . In conception, steely scholarship and piercing insights, his book is a masterpiece."

—Harold Evans, The New York Times

"Easily the best book ever written on the subject. . . . A work of rare beauty that combines meticulous research with sensitive analysis and elegant prose. The enormous weight of its quality inspires amazement and awe. . . . Academics should take note: Good history can still be a good story."

—The Washington Post

title: The Buffalo Hunter Hunter
long_summary:
Hidden within church walls for over a century, a pastor's forgotten diary surfaces to expose a terrible truth. The yellowed pages chronicle conversations with Good Stab, a Blackfeet man whose confessions reveal how 217 of his people came to die in the snow—and what followed in the wake of that slaughter.

As Good Stab's story unfolds across multiple visits to the pastor's study, a multigenerational saga of vengeance takes shape. The boundaries between the living and the dead blur as historical trauma refuses to remain buried. Jones weaves together elements of the supernatural with unflinching examination of America's violent past, creating a narrative that operates simultaneously as ghost story and historical reckoning.

This is horror rooted in real wounds—a tale where the supernatural emerges not from imagination but from the unresolved grief of genocide. Through Good Stab's voice, Jones forces readers to confront how violence echoes across time, transforming both victim and perpetrator in ways that transcend death itself.
short_summary: A Lutheran pastor's 1912 diary reveals a slow massacre tied to 217 dead Blackfeet. Told through confessional interviews with a man named Good Stab, this supernatural revenge story confronts America's bloodiest historical sins.
author_bios: Stephen Graham Jones has established himself as a powerhouse in contemporary horror fiction, penning bestsellers like The Only Good Indians, My Heart Is a Chainsaw, and I Was a Teenage Slasher. His exceptional work has earned him an NEA fellowship alongside prestigious honors including the Ray Bradbury Award, Bram Stoker Award, Shirley Jackson Award, Jesse Jones Award, Independent Publishers Award for Multicultural Fiction, and the Alex Award. He currently serves as the Ivena Baldwin Professor of English at the University of Colorado Boulder.
quotes:
"The Buffalo Hunter Hunter is Stephen Graham Jones' horror masterpiece. The prose is gorgeous and the plot is complex. The author of The Only Good Indians returns again with a spellbinding yarn about one of the bloodiest, most significant parts of the nation's history."

—NPR

"Inventive and spine-tingling, The Buffalo Hunter Hunter is the best book I've read in ages. It's a master class in voice... Queasy, uneasy, The Buffalo Hunter Hunter plays with the interplay between religion and historical guilt, identity and appetite."

—The Washington Post

"Jones has written his Interview With the Indigenous Vampire...A landmark of horror and historical fiction alike, perhaps the closest thing we have to horror's Moby-Dick."

—Vulture

title: Audition
long_summary:
In a Manhattan restaurant, an established actress sits across from a mysterious younger man whose presence unsettles as much as it intrigues. The nature of their connection remains deliberately obscured, shifting between possibility and certainty as their encounter unfolds.

Kitamura constructs a literary puzzle where dual perspectives illuminate different facets of the same relationship, each voice revealing what the other conceals. The actress, polished and successful, finds herself confronted by someone who may hold keys to understanding herself—or may simply be a stranger with his own agenda.

This psychological study dissects how we inhabit different versions of ourselves depending on who's watching. The novel questions whether we can ever truly know another person, or if we're all perpetually performing roles we've convinced ourselves are authentic. Through precise, measured prose, Kitamura examines the gap between public persona and private truth, exploring how relationships become stages where we audition for acceptance, love, or simply recognition.
short_summary: Two competing narratives unspool around a lunch between an accomplished actress and a troubling young man. A hypnotic exploration of performance, identity, and the roles we play.
author_bios: Katie Kitamura has written four novels, including A Separation and Intimacies, with the latter earning longlist recognition for both the National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award, plus finalist status for a Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her literary achievements include receiving the Rome Prize in Literature and a Lannan fellowship. Kitamura's novels have reached international audiences through translation into twenty-one languages, and she currently serves on the creative writing faculty at New York University.
quotes:
"Katie Kitamura is a dizzyingly skilled writer whose fictions always seem to manage two contradictory effects: a supple seductive surface, under which the chaos of minds and repressed realities roil. She's an original, building an entire metier of her own."

—Rachel Kushner, author of The Flamethrowers and The Mars Room

"You have never read anything like this gorgeously disquieting book. Audition challenges our preconceptions about love, art, and selfhood—and, magnificently, our very idea of how a novel should unfold. If all the world's a stage, Kitamura reminds us that we never stop auditioning for our parts."

—Hernan Diaz, author of Trust

"Katie Kitamura is one of our most brilliant writers, saying far more in her silences, blank spaces, and disruptions than most novelists can say in a hundred thousand words. Audition is eerie, a book so cold it feels hot. It hooked into my mind like a burr."

—Lauren Groff, author of The Vaster Wilds and Fates and Furies

title: Wave
long_summary:
A single morning in December 2004 severed Sonali Deraniyagala's world in two. The Indian Ocean tsunami swept away her husband, two sons, and parents, leaving her to navigate a landscape of unimaginable solitude.

Deraniyagala refuses to soften the edges of her experience. Her memoir confronts the raw mechanics of surviving catastrophic loss—the rage, the desperate bargaining with fate, the way grief can make even breathing feel like betrayal. Yet gradually, she allows herself to revisit the abundance that preceded tragedy: lazy mornings with her children, academic discussions with her husband, the particular warmth of her parents' presence.

This isn't a story about healing or finding meaning in suffering. Instead, it examines how love persists even when its objects are gone, how memory becomes both sanctuary and torment. Deraniyagala writes with surgical precision about the most tender subjects, creating something that transcends typical narratives of recovery. Her account reveals how the human spirit adapts to carrying impossible weight—not by growing stronger, but by learning to move differently through the world.
short_summary: Deraniyagala survived the 2004 tsunami that killed her entire family on a Sri Lankan beach. Her memoir traces the aftermath with devastating honesty and unexpected grace.
author_bios: Sonali Deraniyagala serves as an economics professor at SOAS, University of London. She wrote the powerful memoir Wave in 2013, which details her survival of the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and its profound personal aftermath.
quotes:
"Courageous, truthful and, above all, generous . . . What amazed me most about the book is what good company it is. Deraniyagala is accepting and tender in her record of grief . . . Wave is in fact full of persisting life."

—Globe & Mail

"A devastating but ultimately redemptive memoir . . . The craft and control reflect an exceptional literary command . . . Excellent. Reading Deraniyagala's account proves almost as cathartic as writing it must have been."

—Kirkus

"Deraniyagala has written a book teaming with beautiful ruminations on the bittersweetness of memory and the precariousness of life."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Chain-Gang All Stars
long_summary:
America has turned incarceration into entertainment, and business is booming. In arenas across the country, prisoners battle each other in televised death matches, competing for the one prize that matters: freedom. This gladiatorial system has transformed the prison-industrial complex into something even more sinister—a ratings goldmine that feeds on human desperation.

Loretta Thurwar stands on the verge of earning her liberty, wielding her signature hammer through match after bloody match. Alongside her partner Hurricane Staxxx, she's become a crowd favorite in this grotesque theater. But victory comes with an impossible burden: leaving behind the fellow prisoners who've become her family. As corporate interests circle like vultures, determined to protect their profitable enterprise, Thurwar faces a choice between personal salvation and collective resistance.

Adjei-Brenyah constructs a savage mirror of contemporary America, where systemic violence masquerades as entertainment and human dignity becomes a commodity. This unflinching examination of justice, exploitation, and survival asks whether redemption is possible within a system designed to destroy the people it claims to rehabilitate.
short_summary: Two women gladiators fight for freedom in a brutal private prison entertainment system. Adjei-Brenyah imagines American incarceration as deadly spectacle in this explosive debut novel.
author_bios: Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah wrote the New York Times-bestselling collection Friday Black and has contributed to publications including The New York Times Book Review, Esquire, and The Paris Review. Among his recognitions are selection as a National Book Foundation "5 Under 35" honoree, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, the Saroyan Prize, and finalist status for the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Award for Best First Book. A Spring Valley, New York native, he currently resides in the Bronx.
quotes:
"Given how incredible his debut collection was and is, it is no surprise to me that Adjei-Brenyah's debut novel is this extraordinary! Told with bold, muscular prose, this book is filled with surprising tenderness. Some of the best and most beautiful descriptions of action and violence I have ever read, which is not to say the book celebrates violence so much as it uses violence to explore American incarceration by imagining it as spectacle. As big as it is dazzling. Just wild how good and original this book is. A revelation!"

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars & There, There

"As vital as it is brutal. Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah illuminates darkness with the electricity of his prose. The massive weight of the subject is matched by the sheer scope of Adjei-Brenyah's imagination. A startling, important novel that will inspire and inform many conversations."

—Charles Yu, author of Interior Chinatown

"In a narrative world where the real is growingly more unbelievable than the make believe, Chain-Gang All-Stars is an uncanny, singular feat of literature. I've never read satire so bruising, so brolic, so tender and really, so pitch-perfect. It's nuts brilliant. Just read it!"

—Kiese Laymon, author of Heavy: An American Memoir

title: In the Darkroom
long_summary:
A decades-old rift between father and daughter takes an unexpected turn when Susan Faludi receives startling news from Hungary. Her estranged parent, now in their seventies, has transitioned and declares herself "a complete woman." This revelation transforms what began as an attempt to settle old scores into something far more complex.

Faludi finds herself navigating uncharted territory as she tries to reconcile this new reality with memories of the volatile, distant figure who shaped her childhood. Her journey leads her deep into her father's past lives—from American suburbia to the peaks of the Alps, from wartime Budapest's Jewish quarter to the shadows of Holocaust survival.

Their reunion in Hungary becomes more than a family reckoning. Faludi discovers a nation wrestling with its own buried truths, where historical amnesia runs deep and political currents threaten to sweep away inconvenient memories. As she pieces together her father's story, larger questions emerge about the nature of selfhood in an era obsessed with reinvention. Can we truly choose who we become, or do the forces that shape us—family, history, trauma—ultimately define our limits? Through this deeply personal lens, Faludi examines the fault lines between past and present, examining how identity forms and reforms across generations.
short_summary: When feminist writer Susan Faludi learns her estranged 76-year-old father has undergone sex reassignment surgery, she embarks on a haunting investigation into identity, family, and reinvention that spans continents and generations.
author_bios: Susan Faludi earned a Pulitzer Prize for her journalism and wrote Backlash, which received the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction. Her other books include The Terror Dream and Stiffed. Previously working as a Wall Street Journal reporter, Faludi has contributed to The New Yorker, The New York Times, Harper's, and The Baffler.
quotes:
"In the Darkroom is a compelling, lyrical, and candid exploration of identity, gender, and the intensely complex relationship between a transgendered father and her daughter. More than memoir, or biography, it's a detective story with two unforgettable characters...[and] a landmark achievement in which Faludi uses her well-honed journalistic talents to tell the most intimate story she could possibly tell, her father's journey into womanhood."

—Kirkus Reviews' Judges' Statement

"A gripping and honest personal journey."

—Entertainment Weekly

"A wrought and multi-layered memoir...Powerful and absorbing."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Sellout
long_summary:
After losing his father in a tragic police shooting, a young Black man faces a double erasure: his parent's death and his neighborhood's complete removal from official maps. Growing up in Dickens, a forgotten corner of Los Angeles, he had endured years as an unwilling test subject in his sociologist father's psychological experiments, all supposedly for a book that would justify their struggles.

The promised memoir never existed. Left with nothing but debt and rage, he embarks on an absurd mission to put his community back on the map through the most inflammatory strategy imaginable. With assistance from Hominy Jenkins—a elderly former child actor desperate to reclaim purpose—he institutes racially divisive policies that shock his neighbors and eventually attract national attention.

Beatty constructs a fearless satire that dissects America's racial contradictions through outrageous comedy. The novel questions whether progress is real or performative, examining how communities fight for recognition in a society that would prefer their invisibility. By pushing controversial ideas to their logical extremes, this provocative work forces readers to confront uncomfortable truths about identity, belonging, and the price of being seen.
short_summary: When his California hometown gets erased from the map, a young man decides to restore it through the most provocative means possible: reinstating slavery and segregation. Beatty's satirical masterpiece is both hilarious and devastatingly sharp.
author_bios: Paul Beatty has published four novels: The Sellout, Slumberland, Tuff, and The White Boy Shuffle, alongside two poetry collections, Big Bank Take Little Bank and Joker, Joker, Deuce. He edited Hokum: An Anthology of African-American Humor and currently resides in New York City.
quotes:
"The first 100 pages of [Paul Beatty's] new novel, The Sellout, are the most caustic and the most badass first 100 pages of an American novel I've read in at least a decade."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"The Sellout isn't just one of the most hilarious American novels in years, it also might be the first truly great satirical novel of the century . . . [It] is a comic masterpiece, but it's much more than just that-it's one of the smartest and most honest reflections on race and identity in America in a very long time."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"[The Sellout] is among the most important and difficult American novels written in the 21st century . . . It is a bruising novel that readers will likely never forget."

—Kiese Laymon, Los Angeles Times

title: Bossypants
long_summary:
Comedy icon Tina Fey opens her life to readers with the same sharp wit that made her a household name. This memoir traces her evolution from an awkward young woman navigating the complexities of adolescence to becoming one of television's most influential voices. 

Fey examines the contradictions of modern womanhood with unflinching honesty—the pressure to conform to beauty standards while maintaining professional credibility, the chaos of balancing career ambitions with family life, and the unexpected ways success can complicate personal relationships. Her stories range from cringe-worthy dating mishaps to behind-the-scenes moments in the competitive world of comedy writing.

What emerges is a portrait of someone who refused to let others define her limitations. Fey dissects everything from workplace dynamics to cultural expectations with the precision of a seasoned observer and the irreverence of someone who's learned not to take herself too seriously. The result is both deeply personal and universally relatable, offering insights into the entertainment industry while celebrating the power of embracing one's authentic, imperfect self.
short_summary: Tina Fey chronicles her journey from awkward nerd to comedy superstar with trademark wit and self-deprecating humor. Sharp observations on everything from motherhood to show business make this memoir irresistible.
author_bios: Tina Fey makes her home in Denver, where she shares her life with her beloved ferret, Jacoby.
quotes:
"You'd be really pretty if you lost weight."

—College Boyfriend, 1990

"Tina Fey is an ugly, pear-shaped, overrated troll."

—The Internet

"I hope that's not really the cover. That's really going to hurt sales."

—Don Fey, Father of Tina Fey

"Absolutely delicious!"

—A Guy Who Eats Books

"Totally worth it."

—Trees

"Do not print this glowing recommendation of Tina Fey's book until I've been dead a hundred years."

—Mark Twain

title: The MANIAC
long_summary:
The brilliant mathematician John von Neumann possessed an intellect so extraordinary it unnerved everyone who encountered it. His revolutionary contributions span game theory, computer science, and artificial intelligence—innovations that continue to reshape civilization in ways we're only beginning to grasp.

Benjamín Labatut constructs a three-part narrative examining the profound consequences of unchecked scientific genius. The story opens with physicist Paul Ehrenfest, Einstein's contemporary, who witnessed science's transformation from pure inquiry into something more menacing. At the center stands von Neumann himself, revealed through the voices of those who knew him—family, collaborators, and competitors who watched his mind operate at superhuman levels.

The final section leaps to our present moment: the historic confrontation between Go champion Lee Sedol and Google's AlphaGo system. This battle between human intuition and machine learning embodies von Neumann's ultimate vision—creating artificial minds capable of surpassing their creators.

Labatut weaves together scientific biography, philosophical meditation, and speculative fiction to examine how individual brilliance can unleash forces beyond our control. The result is a meditation on intelligence itself: what happens when human reason creates something that no longer needs us?
short_summary: Hungarian polymath John von Neumann invented game theory, built the first programmable computer, and pioneered AI. Labatut's haunting triptych traces how one brilliant mind unleashed forces that continue reshaping our world.
author_bios: Born in the Netherlands and raised in The Hague, Benjamín Labatut moved to Chile where he has established himself as one of contemporary literature's most distinctive voices. His works include Antarctica starts here (2009), After the Light (2016), The Stone of Madness (2021), and the internationally acclaimed When We Cease to Understand the World (2021), which has been translated into over thirty languages and earned widespread critical recognition.
quotes:
"Labatut's latest virtuosic effort, at once a historical novel and a philosophical foray, is a thematic sequel, an exploration of what results when we take reason to even further extremes . . . A contemporary writer of thrilling originality . . . The MANIAC is a work of dark, eerie and singular beauty."

—Becca Rothfeld, The Washington Post

"Labatut elegantly captures the sense of geniuses outstripping the typical boundaries of intellectual achievement and paying a price for it . . . Sharply written fiction ably capturing primitive emotions and boundary-breaking research."

—Kirkus

"After the slender yet incendiary When We Cease to Understand the World, Labatut returns with a sensational epic of the Hungarian American physicist and computer scientist John von Neumann . . . Labatut mesmerizes in his accessible depictions of complex scientific material and in his inspired portraits of the innovators. In his previous book, Labatut grappled with the ways in which scientific breakthroughs offered new means of experiencing reality; this one succeeds at showing how acts of genius might break the world forever. Readers won't be able to turn away."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Empathy Exams
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
What begins as an unusual job—acting out medical symptoms for training doctors—becomes the foundation for a remarkable investigation into how we understand and respond to suffering. Leslie Jamison uses this strange professional experience as a launching point to examine the complicated machinery of human compassion.

These essays traverse unexpected terrain: the ethics of disaster tourism, the reality of invisible illnesses, the spectacle of televised emotion, and the intersection of physical pain with social justice. Jamison refuses easy answers about whether our attempts to understand others' experiences bring us closer together or create new forms of judgment and distance.

Rather than offering simple prescriptions for better human connection, she interrogates the very foundations of how we witness pain—both authentic suffering and its more ambiguous cousins. The result is a collection that challenges readers to consider whether true understanding between people is possible, and what it costs us to keep trying. Jamison's inquiry is both philosophical and intensely personal, mapping the difficult space where individual experience meets collective responsibility.
short_summary: Jamison transforms personal experiences with illness and medical role-playing into profound meditations on empathy, pain, and human connection. Intellectually rigorous yet deeply felt.
author_bios: Leslie Jamison has written several New York Times bestsellers, including The Recovering and The Empathy Exams, alongside the essay collection Make It Scream, Make It Burn, which was a finalist for the PEN/Diamonstein-Spielvogel Award. Her novel The Gin Closet received recognition as an LA Times Book Prize finalist. Currently a contributing writer for the New York Times Magazine, Leslie Jamison's essays and articles have been featured in The Atlantic, Harper's, and Virginia Quarterly Review. She holds a teaching position at Columbia University and makes her home in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Extraordinary. . . . she calls to mind writers as disparate as Joan Didion and John Jeremiah Sullivan as she interrogates the palpitations of not just her own trippy heart but of all of ours. . . . Her cerebral, witty, multichambered essays tend to swing around to one topic in particular: what we mean when we say we feel someone else's pain. . . . I'm not sure I'm capable of recommending a book because it might make you a better person. But watching the philosopher in Ms. Jamison grapple with empathy is a heart-expanding exercise."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A virtuosic manifesto of human pain. . . . Jamison stitches together the intellectual and the emotional with the finesse of a crackerjack surgeon. . . . The result is a soaring performance on the humanizing effects of empathy."

—NPR

"The Empathy Exams is a work of tremendous pleasure and tremendous pain. Leslie Jamison is so intelligent, so compassionate, and so fiercely, prodigiously brave. This is the essay at its creative, philosophical best."

—Eleanor Catton, author of Birnam Wood & The Luminaries, winner of the 2013 Man Booker Prize

title: The Topeka School
long_summary:
Set in 1990s Kansas, this novel centers on a high school senior whose parents work as psychologists at a renowned psychiatric clinic. The protagonist navigates the complex social dynamics of teenage life while carrying the weight of his family's expectations and his own reputation as a star debater.

The story takes a dark turn as the social hierarchy shifts and an outsider becomes entangled with the popular crowd, leading to consequences that ripple through multiple generations. The narrative examines how patterns of violence and masculinity pass from fathers to sons, while also exploring a mother's struggle to break free from her own traumatic inheritance.

Lerner constructs a layered examination of American culture at a pivotal moment, revealing the early seeds of the political and social fractures that would later define the 21st century. The book interrogates questions of privilege, identity, and the ways that personal wounds become cultural pathologies. Through its portrait of one family's reckoning with their past, the novel offers insight into how individual choices and societal forces intersect to shape both personal destiny and collective future.
short_summary: Lerner weaves family drama with cultural prophecy in 1990s Kansas. A story of adolescence and toxic masculinity that traces the roots of our current political moment with devastating precision.
author_bios: Ben Lerner has published eight books spanning poetry and prose, along with various artistic collaborations. The Brooklyn College Distinguished Professor of English has earned recognition through Fulbright, Guggenheim, and MacArthur fellowships, and his work has been nominated for both the National Book Award and Pulitzer Prize.
quotes:
"[An] essayistic and engrossing novel . . . Few writers are so deeply engaged as Lerner in how our interior selves are shaped by memory and consequence . . . Increasingly powerful and heartbreaking as the story moves on. Autofiction at its smartest and most effective: self-interested, self-interrogating, but never self-involved."

—Kirkus

"The Topeka School is [Lerner's] most discerning, ambitious, innovative, and timely novel to date. It's a complete pleasure to read Lerner experimenting with other minds and times, to watch his already profound talent blooming into new subjects, landscapes, and capacities. This book is a prehistory of a deeply disturbing national moment, but it's written with the kind of intelligence, insight, and searching that makes one feel well-accompanied and, in the final hour, deeply inspired."

—Maggie Nelson, author of The Argonauts

"Ben Lerner has redefined what it means for a writer to inhabit an American present by showing how a family reckons with its past. Here the personal and political are masterfully interwoven. The Topeka School is brave, furious, and, finally, a work of love."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

title: Heavy
subtitle: An American Memoir
long_summary:
In this deeply personal memoir, Kiese Laymon addresses his mother directly, creating an intimate conversation about the lies families tell and the truths they bury. Growing up in Jackson, Mississippi, Laymon navigates the contradictions of being raised by a brilliant woman whose love comes wrapped in silence and secrets.

The book traces Laymon's evolution from childhood through academia, examining his complicated relationship with food, his body, and the expectations placed on Black men in America. He writes candidly about eating disorders, addiction, and the ways trauma reshapes both memory and flesh. Rather than offering easy redemption, Laymon interrogates the very notion of healing in a society built on systemic harm.

What emerges is both a love letter and an indictment—of family dynamics, educational institutions, and a country that preaches liberation while practicing oppression. Laymon's prose cuts through comfortable narratives about resilience and success, asking instead what it truly means to be free when freedom itself carries such weight. This memoir refuses to separate personal pain from political reality, creating a work that is as much about America as it is about one man's journey toward honest self-examination.
short_summary: Laymon's unflinching memoir examines the weight of family secrets, personal trauma, and survival as a Black man in America. Raw, brilliant, and essential—a reckoning with love, lies, and what freedom actually costs.
author_bios: Kiese Laymon grew up in Jackson, Mississippi, and currently serves as the Ottilie Schillig Professor in English and Creative Writing at the University of Mississippi. His published works include the memoir Heavy, the novel Long Division, and the essay collection How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America. In 2022, Laymon received a MacArthur Fellowship for his contributions to literature.
quotes:
"Heavy is a gorgeous, gutting book that's fueled by candor yet freighted with ambivalence. It's full of devotion and betrayal, euphoria and anguish, tender embraces and rough abuse…the liberation on offer doesn't feel light and unburdened; it feels heavy like the title, and heavy like the truth…Salvation would feel too weightless—as if [Laymon] could forget who he is and where he has been. This generous, searching book explores all the forces that can stop even the most buoyant hopes from ever leaving the ground."

—The New York Times

"There are those rare writers in the world whose work unearths the stories that have been buried in and around us for so long. They force us to confront all that we would be rather not see, and ask us to reckon with why we have failed to see it for so long. Kiese Laymon is one such rare writer. Heavy is a memoir, yes, but it is also a testament to a sort of truth and self-reflection that is increasingly rare in our world today. If for some reason you were not already convinced, there should no longer be any doubt that Kiese Laymon is one of the important writers of our time."

—Clint Smith, author of How the Word is Passed & Counting Descent

"Heavy is an act of truth telling unlike any other I can think of in American literature, partly due to Laymon's uniquely gifted mind—his ability to pursue the ways we lie to each other while also loving each other, or, not, and the humility he brings to bear while doing so, this consistently brings us back to life, to what matters in this world. Heavy is a gift to us, if we can pick it up—a moral exercise and an intimate history that is at the same time a story about America."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write an Autobiographical Novel

title: The Country of the Blind
subtitle: A Memoir at the End of Sight
long_summary:
Living with retinitis pigmentosa means Andrew Leland exists in a unique threshold—he can see, but knows that sight is slipping away. Rather than simply waiting for darkness, he decides to investigate what lies ahead. This journey becomes far more than learning to navigate without vision; it's an immersion into an entire community with its own traditions, advocacy movements, and ways of understanding the world.

Leland approaches his future with genuine fascination, treating his condition as an invitation to discover rather than merely endure. His investigation reveals blindness not as absence but as a different way of experiencing life—one with its own wisdom and perspectives. Meanwhile, he grapples with how this transformation affects his closest relationships and his understanding of who he is.

Blending personal narrative with broader cultural examination, this book refuses to treat disability as tragedy. Instead, Leland finds richness in adaptation and meaning in community. His account balances honest vulnerability with infectious enthusiasm, showing how embracing uncertainty can lead to unexpected discoveries about resilience and belonging.
short_summary: Leland chronicles his gradual transition from sight to blindness with curiosity and humor, discovering blindness as a rich culture with its own language and customs. A revelatory exploration of adaptation, identity, and finding light in unexpected places.
author_bios: Andrew Leland has contributed to The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, McSweeney's, The San Francisco Chronicle, and Art in America. He hosted The Organist podcast for KCRW from 2013 to 2019 and has worked as a producer for Radiolab and 99% Invisible. Since 2003, Leland has served as an editor at The Believer and currently resides in western Massachusetts.
quotes:
"The Country of the Blind is about seeing—but also about marriage and family and the moral and emotional challenge of accommodating the parts of ourselves that scare us. A warm, profound, and unforgettable meditation on how we adjust to new ways of being in the world."

—Rachel Aviv, author of Strangers to Ourselves

"[Leland's] education in navigating the world without his eyes is an entry point into a fascinating cultural history of blindness. The great strength of this memoir is its voracious, humble curiosity; throughout, Leland treats losing his vision as just as much an opportunity as a foreclosure."

—The Atlantic

"This is such a gorgeous book. Andrew Leland manages to deftly balance the personal, historical and political as he documents—documents is too sterile a word; he gently sings about—his becoming blind. There is a great nonfiction book here about the history of blindness and the pioneers who have built a world of access and empowerment. But crucially, Leland weaves into that larger tapestry the deeply touching story of how he, his wife Lily, and his son Oscar face their myriad new challenges—with open minds and abundant wit, and always fearlessly together."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King, The Circle & A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius

title: Great Circle
long_summary:
Twin siblings Marian and Jamie emerge from tragedy as survivors of a maritime disaster, finding themselves in the care of their unreliable uncle in Montana. Their ordinary lives shift dramatically when traveling aviators arrive with their weathered aircraft, igniting Marian's obsession with the skies.

Abandoning formal education, she secures backing from an unlikely source—a criminal entrepreneur whose support comes with strings that will shadow her ambitions. Yet this devil's bargain enables her ultimate dream: attempting an unprecedented polar route around the world.

Decades later, actress Hadley Baxter sees portraying the vanished pilot as her escape from the suffocating world of franchise filmmaking and manufactured celebrity. As Hadley delves into Marian's mysterious final flight over Antarctica, the boundaries between performer and subject blur. Both women's quests for autonomy—separated by an entire century—reveal how the desire to break free from society's constraints transcends time itself.
short_summary: Two women separated by a century share an uncompromising hunger for freedom. Shipstead weaves together the stories of a daredevil 1920s aviator and a modern Hollywood actress with breathtaking skill.
author_bios: Maggie Shipstead has written three novels and a short story collection, with her work reaching New York Times bestseller status. Great Circle earned recognition as both a Booker Prize shortlist selection and Women's Prize finalist. She completed her studies at the Iowa Writers' Workshop and has received numerous honors including a National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, the Dylan Thomas Prize, and the L.A. Times Book Prize for First Fiction.
quotes:
"A soaring work of historical fiction . . . So convincingly does Shipstead stitch her fictional heroine into the daring flight paths of early aviators that you'll be convinced that you remember the tragic day her plane disappeared. Great Circle is a relentlessly exciting story about a woman maneuvering her way between tradition and prejudice to get what she wants. It's also a culturally rich story that takes full advantage of its extended length to explore the changing landscape of the 20th century. My top recommendation for this summer."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A feat of a story in every sense."

—Entertainment Weekly

"The destinies of [Shipstead's] unforgettable characters intersect in ways that reverberate through a hundred years of story. Whether Shipstead is creating scenes in the Prohibition-era American West, in wartime London, or on a Hollywood movie set, her research is as invisible as it should be, allowing a fully immersive experience. Ingeniously structured and so damn entertaining; this novel is as ambitious as its heroines—but it never falls from the sky."

—Kirkus

title: The Patriarch
subtitle: The Remarkable Life and Turbulent Times of Joseph P. Kennedy
long_summary:
Joseph P. Kennedy's life reads like an American epic of ambition, power, and ultimate heartbreak. This comprehensive biography reveals how a scrappy Irish-American from East Boston transformed himself into one of the most influential figures of his era, accumulating wealth and political clout across multiple industries and decades.

Kennedy's restless drive propelled him through an astonishing array of careers—from banking and shipyard management to Hollywood mogul and Wall Street financier. His political acumen earned him key roles in the New Deal administration, including leadership of the newly formed Securities and Exchange Commission. Yet his greatest aspiration, the presidency, remained forever out of reach.

The ambassador's isolationist views during the lead-up to World War II marked his dramatic downfall, transforming him from Washington insider to political pariah. But Kennedy's most enduring legacy lay in his children, particularly his sons who would achieve the political heights he never reached. The personal cost proved devastating—a father's dreams realized through unimaginable loss.

Drawing from unprecedented archival access, this biography illuminates both the man and the century that shaped him, revealing how one family's trajectory mirrors America's own complex evolution.
short_summary: The definitive biography of Joseph P. Kennedy, based on exclusive access to his private papers. Nasaw chronicles the patriarch's rise from Boston outsider to Washington insider, and his transformation from New Deal hero to wartime pariah.
author_bios: David Nasaw has twice been a Pulitzer Prize finalist and written several bestselling historical works, including The Last Million, The Patriarch (selected as a New York Times Five Best Non-Fiction Books of the Year), Andrew Carnegie (a New York Times Notable Book and recipient of the New-York Historical Society's American History Book Prize), and The Chief (Bancroft Prize winner). Nasaw holds the position of Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr. Professor of History Emeritus at the CUNY Graduate Center and previously served as president of the Society of American Historians.
quotes:
"Riveting… The Patriarch is a book hard to put down…As his son indelibly put it some months before his father was struck down: 'Ask not what your country can do for you – ask what you can do for your county.' One wonders what was going through the mind of the patriarch, sitting a few feet away listening to that soaring sentiment as a fourth-generation Kennedy became president of the United States. After coming to know him over the course of this brilliant, compelling book, the reader might suspect that he was thinking he had done more than enough for his country. But the gods would demand even more."

—Christopher Buckley, The New York Times

"A spellbinding book."

—Slate

"[A] sprawling, highly readable biography of the dynast and larger-than-life figure whose presence still haunts American political life... Working from his subject's extensive archives, Nasaw (Andrew Carnegie, 2006, etc.) pieces together a sometimes-sympathetic, sometimes-critical view of Joseph P. Kennedy (1888–1969), father of John F. Kennedy and most definitely a man of parts... Exhaustive yet accessible, Nasaw's book illuminates."

—Kirkus

title: The Marriage Plot
long_summary:
Three college friends find themselves caught between academic theory and messy reality in this smart exploration of love and literature. Madeleine champions traditional romance novels while her classmates embrace postmodern criticism, but her own life becomes far more complicated than any fictional plot. Leonard, brilliant and troubled, draws her into an intense relationship shadowed by secrets about his mental health. Mitchell, meanwhile, pursues spiritual enlightenment across continents while nursing an unrequited passion for Madeleine.

As they transition from the insulated world of Brown University to adult uncertainty, each character grapples with fundamental questions about desire, faith, and meaning. Eugenides weaves together literary criticism and human emotion, examining whether the old stories about love and marriage still hold relevance in contemporary life. The result is both an intellectual comedy of manners and a tender portrait of young people discovering that real relationships resist the neat resolutions found in books.
short_summary: At Brown in the 1980s, three students navigate love, literature, and post-graduation reality. Eugenides crafts a witty, deeply felt novel that reimagines the classic marriage plot for the modern era.
author_bios: Jeffrey Eugenides grew up in Detroit before studying at Brown and Stanford Universities. He gained widespread recognition with his debut The Virgin Suicides in 1993, followed by the Pulitzer Prize-winning Middlesex in 2002, which also earned finalist status for the National Book Critics Circle Award, the International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award, and France's Prix Médicis. His third novel, The Marriage Plot, became a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist in 2011 and won both the Prix Fitzgerald and the Madame Figaro Literary Prize. Eugenides published the story collection Fresh Complaint in 2017 and currently teaches creative writing at Princeton.
quotes:
"Remind[s] us with uncommon understanding what it is to be young and idealistic, in pursuit of true love, and in love with books and ideas."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Deeply humane and elegantly constructed."

—NPR

"Playful and profound.... A great offering by one of America's best writers."

—Mark Medley, National Post

title: Mother Emanuel
subtitle: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church
long_summary:
The 2015 massacre at Charleston's Emanuel AME Church thrust a centuries-old congregation into national headlines, but the roots of this tragedy—and the remarkable response it provoked—stretch back to the earliest days of American slavery. Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Kevin Sack chronicles how this single church became a beacon of Black resistance and faith in a city where enslaved Africans first touched American shores and the Civil War erupted.

Sack traces the congregation's defiant founding in 1817, when Black worshippers broke from white-controlled churches to create their own spiritual home. Through decades of persecution, from Civil War upheaval to Jim Crow terror, the church evolved into something unprecedented: a place where forgiveness became both theological doctrine and practical strategy for survival. The families' response to their loved ones' murders—extending grace to the killer—wasn't spontaneous but the culmination of generations who transformed suffering into strength.

This is ultimately a story about endurance and the particular form of Christianity that emerged from America's most brutal chapters. Sack reveals how one community's faith became inseparable from their fight for dignity, creating a legacy that would define their response to unimaginable loss.
short_summary: A sweeping history of one of America's most important Black churches and a profound story of courage and grace amid the fight for racial justice.
author_bios: Kevin Sack brings four decades of journalism experience to his examination of race and national affairs, contributing to three Pulitzer Prize-winning reporting teams throughout his career. The Jacksonville-born Duke University graduate spent three decades at The New York Times, where he specialized in investigative reporting and long-form storytelling, particularly focusing on racial issues. His journalism has been featured in The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Los Angeles Times, and The New York Times Magazine. In 2019, Kevin Sack served as an Emerson Collective Fellow at New America.
quotes:
"Mother Emanuel is a masterpiece . . . Sack, a former reporter for The New York Times, delivers a dense, rich, captivating narrative, featuring vivid prose, prodigious research and a palpable emotional engagement that is disciplined by a meticulous attention to the facts. His excavation is an essential addition to existing histories and ought to be recognized as a singular journalistic performance."

—The New York Times

"[Mother Emanuel is a] searching history of the Charleston church brought into the headlines by mass murder . . . A sobering, expertly told history of the struggle for equality as waged from pulpit and pew."

—Kirkus Reviews, starred review

"This book shook me with its power and beauty. Mother Emanuel is a book of enormous ambition, meticulously researched, gorgeously written, and deeply fulfilling."

—Jonathan Eig, Pulitzer prize-winning author of King: A Life

title: The Son
long_summary:
At thirteen, Eli McCullough becomes a captive of Comanche raiders who destroy his family's Texas homestead. His survival depends on embracing a culture that white society considers savage, yet within the tribe he discovers a fierce code of honor and belonging. Years later, when the Comanche way of life crumbles under American expansion, Eli emerges as a man caught between worlds—neither fully white nor Indian, but something entirely new.

This transformation sets in motion a dynasty built on calculated violence and uncompromising will. As the McCullough family accumulates land, cattle, and eventually oil wealth, each generation pays a different price for their patriarch's choices. Eli's son Peter struggles with the moral weight of his father's legacy, while great-granddaughter JA must navigate a male-dominated world to preserve the family empire.

Meyer traces how frontier brutality evolves into corporate ruthlessness, examining the myths Americans tell themselves about conquest and progress. The novel questions whether civilization truly tames violence or simply redirects it toward more sophisticated ends.
short_summary: Three generations of the McCullough family build a Texas empire through violence and ambition. From Comanche captivity to oil wealth, this multigenerational saga explores the bloody price of power.
author_bios: Philipp Meyer wrote American Rust, which earned the 2009 Los Angeles Times Book Prize and recognition as an Economist Book of the Year, a Washington Post Top Ten Book, and a New York Times Notable Book. A Baltimore native and Cornell graduate, Philipp Meyer received his MFA from the University of Texas at Austin as a James Michener Fellow and currently resides primarily in Texas.
quotes:
"Sweeping, absorbing epic. . . Meyer's sophomore novel deftly opens with entwined, impending deaths across generations, joining tangled stories over three centuries, the contested line between the U.S. and Mexico, and very different cultures; if sometimes it hints of McMurtry's Lonesome Dove and Ferber's Giant, it more often partakes of the somber, doomed certainty of Faulkner. . . An expertly written tale of ancient crimes, with every period detail-and every detail, period-just right."

—Kirkus

"One of the most solid, unsparing pieces of American historical fiction to come out this century . . . a brilliant chronicle of Texas . . . stunning, raw and epic. . . . The Son is vast, brave and, finally, unstoppable."

—NPR

"The greatest things about The Son are its scope and ambition. . . . It's an enveloping, extremely well-wrought, popular novel with passionate convictions about the people, places and battles that it conjures."

—The New York Times

title: The Flamethrowers
long_summary:
In 1970s New York, a young woman named after a Nevada city chases her passion for motorcycles into the raw energy of downtown's emerging art scene. The industrial landscape of SoHo becomes her canvas as she navigates a world where creativity and danger intersect at every corner.

Her romance with Sandro Valera, whose family built an empire on rubber and racing, opens doors she never expected. Their relationship carries her across the Atlantic to Italy, where political upheaval simmers beneath ancient streets. The radical movements reshaping the country draw her deeper into a web of ideology and violence that tests everything she believes about art, loyalty, and survival.

Kushner crafts a story that pulses with the restless energy of its era, examining how personal transformation collides with historical forces. Through her protagonist's eyes, we witness the intoxicating blend of artistic ambition and political awakening that defined a generation caught between revolution and self-destruction.
short_summary: Reno arrives in 1975 New York to make art from her obsession with speed and motorcycles. Her affair with an Italian artist leads her from SoHo's exploding art scene to Italy's radical underground.
author_bios: Rachel Kushner has written the bestselling novel Creation Lake, along with The Mars Room, The Flamethrowers, and Telex from Cuba, plus the essay collection The Hard Crowd. Her work has earned the Prix Médicis and made her a two-time finalist for both the Booker Prize and National Book Award. The American Academy of Arts and Letters honored her with the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award, and she received a Guggenheim Fellowship. Publishers worldwide have translated her novels into twenty-seven languages.
quotes:
"Oscillating between the hedonistic New York artworld and Italy in the midst of the Years of Lead, The Flamethrowers is that rare thing, a novel that uses recent history not as a picturesque backdrop, but as a way of interrogating the present. Kushner's urgent prose and psychological acuity make this one of the most compelling and enjoyable novels I've read this year."

—Hari Kunzru, author of White Tears & Gods Without Men

"This rich second novel from Kushner takes place in late-'70s New York City and Italy…Kushner's psychological explorations of her characters are incisive, the novel is peppered with subtle '70s details, and it bursts with you-are-there depictions of its time and places."

—Publishers Weekly

"I loved Rachel Kushner's The Flamethrowers."

—Jonathan Franzen, The New York Times

title: No Visible Bruises
subtitle: What We Don’t Know About Domestic Violence Can Kill Us
long_summary:
Behind closed doors across America, a crisis unfolds that touches every aspect of our society, yet remains largely invisible. Rachel Louise Snyder pulls back the curtain on intimate partner violence, revealing how this pervasive issue connects to everything from workplace productivity to school shootings to mass incarceration.

Drawing on extensive research and real-world cases, Snyder dismantles the dangerous assumptions that keep us from addressing this epidemic effectively. She challenges the notion that leaving an abusive relationship is simple, questions whether treatment programs actually work, and examines why our current support systems fall short. Her investigation takes readers inside courtrooms, police departments, and advocacy organizations to understand how domestic abuse ripples outward, affecting communities in ways we're only beginning to recognize.

This isn't just about individual relationships gone wrong—it's about understanding violence as a learned behavior with societal roots. Snyder's reporting reveals the inadequacy of traditional responses while pointing toward more effective interventions. Her work illuminates how intimate partner violence intersects with other forms of violence, creating a comprehensive picture of a problem that demands urgent, systemic solutions.
short_summary: A devastating investigation into America's domestic violence epidemic that shatters myths and reveals how intimate partner violence connects to broader patterns of societal violence.
author_bios: Rachel Louise Snyder wrote Fugitive Denim, the novel What We've Lost is Nothing, and No Visible Bruises, which became a New York Times Top Ten Book of the Year and earned the J. Anthony Lukas Work-in-Progress Award, the Hillman Prize, and the Helen Bernstein Book Award. The book was also a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, LA Times Book Prize, and Kirkus Award. Her journalism has been featured in the New Yorker, the New York Times, and Slate. Snyder is a Guggenheim Fellow and teaches at American University.
quotes:
"This is terrifying, courageous reportage from our internal war zone, a fair and balanced telling of an unfair and unbalanced crisis in American family life. Snyder writes with stark lucidity and great compassion, and tells stories of utmost urgency with considerable narrative skill."

—Andrew Solomon, National Book Award-winning, bestselling author of Far From the Tree

"A powerful exploration of the sinister, insidious nature of domestic violence in America… Bracing and gut-wrenching, with slivers of hope throughout, this is exemplary, moving reportage on an important subject that often remains in the dark due to shame and/or fear."

—Kirkus

"[A] powerful investigation into intimate partner abuse . . . with closely observed, compassionate portraits of victims, advocates, abusers and police. Penetrating and wise, and written in sometimes novelistic prose, Snyder's sobering analysis will reward readers' attention."

—Publishers Weekly

title: A Constellation of Vital Phenomena
long_summary:
In a war-torn landscape where survival depends on silence and betrayal has become currency, young Havaa's world collapses in a single night. Her father vanishes into the hands of federal agents, her home reduced to ash and memory. The child's fate rests with Akhmed, a neighbor who must weigh his family's safety against his conscience.

Akhmed's choice leads them through frozen forests to a crumbling medical facility, where Dr. Sonja Rabina works alone among the ruins. Reluctantly, she accepts responsibility for the girl, though her hospital was never meant to shelter orphans. What unfolds across five pivotal days reveals how their separate tragedies have been quietly intersecting for years.

This debut novel examines how ordinary people navigate extraordinary circumstances, finding unexpected grace amid devastation. Through the unlikely bond between a frightened child, a conflicted neighbor, and a hardened doctor, the story illuminates the ways human connection persists even when everything else falls apart.
short_summary: When eight-year-old Havaa's father is taken and her house burned, a neighbor risks everything to hide her in an abandoned hospital. A luminous debut about unexpected connections and love's power to transcend brutality.
author_bios: Anthony Marra wrote the bestselling novels The Tsar of Love and Techno and A Constellation of Vital Phenomena. His debut novel earned the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize and the Anisfield-Wolf Book Award, while also receiving a National Book Award longlist selection. Both works have appeared on The New York Times bestseller list.
quotes:
"My favorite book of the year....Many people can write beautifully, but few manage to create a whole that is more valuable than the sum of its parts. Marra does this in spades. It is a brilliant book."

—Ann Patchett, New York Times bestselling author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"A Constellation of Vital Phenomena is ambitious and intellectually restless....[Marra is] a lover not a fighter, a prose writer who resembles the Joseph Heller of Catch-22 and the Jonathan Safran Foer of Everything Is Illuminated."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A flash in the heavens that makes you look up and believe in miracles....Here, in fresh, graceful prose, is a profound story that dares to be as tender as it is ghastly, a story about desperate lives in a remote land that will quickly seem impossibly close and important....I haven't been so overwhelmed by a novel in years. At the risk of raising your expectations too high, I have to say you simply must read this book."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: Lab Girl
long_summary:
Hope Jahren invites readers into the hidden universe of botanical science through a memoir that doubles as both personal odyssey and scientific revelation. From her Minnesota childhood—shaped by a demanding mother and a father whose laboratory became her playground—to building research facilities across continents, Jahren chronicles how she carved out space for herself in the demanding world of academic science.

The heart of her story lies in an unlikely partnership with Bill, a gifted but troubled collaborator who becomes her closest ally. Together, they traverse landscapes from Arctic research stations to Hawaiian labs, united by their shared devotion to understanding the natural world. Jahren's narrative illuminates the intricate lives of plants—revealing the complex machinery operating within seeds, leaves, and roots—while simultaneously exploring what it means to dedicate your existence to pursuing knowledge.

This is ultimately a story about finding your calling and the relationships that sustain you through both failure and breakthrough. Jahren demonstrates how scientific curiosity can transform not just our understanding of the world around us, but our understanding of ourselves.
short_summary: A brilliant memoir weaving together plant science, friendship, and self-discovery. Jahren transforms how you see the natural world while chronicling her journey as a woman in science.
author_bios: Hope Jahren has conducted groundbreaking paleobiology research since 1996 and earned recognition from Time magazine as one of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2016. The recipient of three Fulbright Awards, Jahren built isotope geobiology laboratories during her tenure as professor at the University of Hawaii from 2008 to 2016. She now serves as the J. Tuzo Wilson professor at the University of Oslo, Norway, where she continues her scientific work.
quotes:
"Some people are great writers, while other people live lives of adventure and importance. Almost no one does both. Hope Jahren does both. She makes me wish I'd been a scientist."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Lab Girl made me look at trees differently. It compelled me to ponder the astonishing grace and gumption of a seed. Perhaps most importantly, it introduced me to a deeply inspiring woman—a scientist so passionate about her work I felt myself vividly with her on every page. This is a smart, enthralling, and winning debut."

—Cheryl Strayed, author of Wild

"Lab Girl surprised, delighted, and moved me. I was drawn in from the start by the clarity and beauty of Jahren's prose, whether she was examining the inner world of a seed,  the ecosystem around the trunk of a tree, or recounting her own inspiring journey. With Lab Girl, Jahren joins those talented scientists who are able to reveal to us the miracle of this world in which we live."

—Abraham Verghese, The Covenant of Water & Cutting for Stone

title: The Good Lord Bird
long_summary:
In the volatile Kansas Territory of 1856, a young enslaved boy named Henry finds his world upended during a deadly confrontation involving the fierce abolitionist John Brown. Through a case of mistaken identity, Henry becomes entangled with Brown's radical mission, forced to masquerade as a girl to ensure his survival.

Renamed Little Onion by his unpredictable savior-captor, Henry navigates the dangerous world of pre-Civil War activism while hiding his true self. His deception becomes increasingly perilous as Brown's crusade builds toward the infamous assault on Harpers Ferry—a desperate gambit that would help ignite the nation's bloodiest conflict.

McBride crafts a remarkable tale that balances historical authenticity with imaginative storytelling, examining how ordinary people become caught in the machinery of momentous events. Through Henry's eyes, readers witness the complexity of heroism, the weight of moral conviction, and the lengths one will go to survive in a world where identity itself becomes both weapon and shield.
short_summary: A young enslaved boy gets swept into John Brown's antislavery crusade and must pass as a girl to survive. McBride transforms a pivotal moment in American history into an unforgettable story of identity and resilience.
author_bios: James McBride has written numerous celebrated works including The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, Oprah's Book Club pick Deacon King Kong, and The Good Lord Bird, which earned him the National Book Award. His other publications include the memoir The Color of Water, novels Song Yet Sung and Miracle at St. Anna, the story collection Five-Carat Soul, and Kill 'Em and Leave. A National Humanities Medal recipient and talented musician, McBride currently serves as distinguished writer in residence at New York University.
quotes:
"You may know the story of John Brown's unsuccessful raid on Harpers Ferry, but author James McBride's retelling of the events leading up to it is so imaginative, you'll race to the finish."

—NPR

"A boisterous, highly entertaining, altogether original novel ...There is something deeply humane in this [story], something akin to the work of Homer or Mark Twain."

—The Washington Post

"The Good Lord Bird is just so brilliant. It had everything I want in a novel and left me feeling both transported and transformed."

—John Green

title: When Breath Becomes Air
long_summary:
Paul Kalanithi's memoir captures the jarring transition from healer to patient when a brilliant neurosurgeon receives a terminal cancer diagnosis at the height of his career. Having spent years studying the brain and contemplating questions of human meaning through both literature and medicine, Kalanithi suddenly finds himself confronting his own finite existence.

The book traces his intellectual and emotional journey as someone who had dedicated his life to understanding what gives existence purpose and value. Now facing his own death while simultaneously becoming a father, he must reconcile the philosophical questions that had long fascinated him with the immediate reality of limited time.

Kalanithi examines the strange duality of his experience—intimate knowledge of mortality from a clinical perspective, yet complete unpreparedness for his own diagnosis. His reflections move between the technical realities of disease and treatment to deeper questions about legacy, love, and how we find meaning when certainty disappears. The memoir stands as both personal reckoning and broader meditation on the human condition, written by someone uniquely positioned to understand both sides of the doctor-patient relationship.
short_summary: A neurosurgeon facing terminal cancer at thirty-six grapples with mortality, meaning, and new fatherhood. Kalanithi's luminous prose transforms devastating circumstances into profound meditation on what makes life worth living.
author_bios: Paul Kalanithi combined medicine, literature, and philosophy throughout his academic career. Born in Kingman, Arizona, he studied English literature and human biology at Stanford University before pursuing an MPhil in history and philosophy of science at Cambridge. Kalanithi earned his medical degree cum laude from Yale School of Medicine and completed both his neurosurgical residency and postdoctoral fellowship at Stanford, where he received the American Academy of Neurological Surgery's top research honor. He passed away in March 2015, leaving behind his wife Lucy and daughter Elizabeth Acadia.
quotes:
"I guarantee that finishing this book and then forgetting about it is simply not an option. . . . Part of this book's tremendous impact comes from the obvious fact that its author was such a brilliant polymath. None of it is maudlin. Nothing is exaggerated. As he wrote to a friend: 'It's just tragic enough and just imaginable enough.' And just important enough to be unmissable."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Paul Kalanithi's memoir, When Breath Becomes Air, written as he faced a terminal cancer diagnosis, is inherently sad. But it's an emotional investment well worth making: a moving and thoughtful memoir of family, medicine and literature. It is, despite its grim undertone, accidentally inspiring."

—The Washington Post

"Kalanithi uses the pages in this book to not only tell his story, but also share his ideas on how to approach death with grace and what it means to be fully alive."

—James Clear, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Atomic Habits

title: Traveling
subtitle: On the Path of Joni Mitchell
long_summary:
