What drives an artist to constantly reinvent herself? Ann Powers examines this question through the lens of Joni Mitchell's restless creative spirit, using the metaphor of travel to decode one of music's most enigmatic figures.

Rather than attempting a traditional chronological biography, Powers approaches Mitchell through her perpetual motion—both physical and artistic. The book traces Mitchell's path from her polio-stricken childhood in rural Canada through her genre-defying musical transformations, examining how her collaborations and personal relationships shaped her art. Powers follows this trajectory all the way to Mitchell's recent creative resurgence following her life-threatening 2015 aneurysm.

Powers brings decades of music criticism expertise to bear on Mitchell's catalog, but she also interrogates the very nature of celebrity biography. How do we truly know an artist who has built her career on constant evolution? The book acknowledges the inherent limitations of biographical understanding while celebrating Mitchell's refusal to be pinned down or categorized.

Through archival research and interviews, Powers creates a portrait that honors both Mitchell's artistic genius and her fundamental unknowability, offering fresh insights into an artist who continues to surprise even her most devoted followers.
short_summary: Music critic Ann Powers traces Joni Mitchell's artistic evolution through her literal and metaphorical journeys. A kaleidoscopic biography that captures the restless spirit of its elusive subject.
author_bios: Ann Powers brings over three decades of music journalism experience to her writing, contributing to NPR, the Los Angeles Times, the New York Times, and numerous other outlets. Through her work at NPR, she covers music and cultural topics while making regular appearances on All Songs Considered, All Things Considered, and Morning Edition. Her published works include the memoir Weird Like Us: My Bohemian America, Good Booty: Love and Sex, Black and White, Body and Soul in American Music, and Piece by Piece, co-authored with Tori Amos. She currently resides in Nashville.
quotes:
"Brilliant and layer book...A full and generous examination of a life that feels rich, caring, done with an investment that can only come from being heolden enough to an artist and their work..."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, author of There's Always This Year & A Little Devil in America

"Remarkably insightful … Powers proves an adroit codebreaker for the uniquely complex cross-pollination of romantic ennui, class consciousness, spiritual striving and occasional narcissism that characterizes the full sweep of the Joni Mitchell enterprise."

—The Washington Post

"A vibrant critical assessment of the eclectic and enigmatic folk/jazz/pop icon...Those simply looking for loving commentaries on Mitchell classics like Blue will find them, but Powers offers more than mere hagiography, positioning Mitchell as 'an embodiment of freedom and singularity, of sorrow and of play.' A top-notch music critic set loose on a worthy subject."

—Kirkus

title: Fates and Furies
long_summary:
Lotto and Mathilde's relationship begins as a fairy tale—two beautiful young people who fall instantly and completely in love. Their friends marvel at their seemingly perfect union, watching as the couple navigates a decade of marriage that appears charmed from the outside.

Yet Lauren Groff constructs something far more intricate than a simple love story. Across more than two decades, she dissects the complex machinery of a partnership where creativity, ambition, and desire intersect in unexpected ways. The novel operates like a prism, refracting the same events through different perspectives until an entirely new picture emerges.

Groff interrogates how couples construct their shared mythology, examining the delicate balance between revelation and concealment that keeps relationships alive. Her narrative architecture mirrors the very themes she explores—what we think we understand about love often masks deeper, more complicated truths. The result is a psychological excavation that challenges assumptions about intimacy, artistic collaboration, and the stories we tell ourselves about our most important relationships.
short_summary: Twenty-four years of marriage unfold in two acts, revealing that every love story has hidden depths. Groff's dazzling novel explores the secrets that sustain relationships and the myths we build around love.
author_bios: Lauren Groff has earned three National Book Award nominations and written multiple bestselling works, including The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus the story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. Her accolades include The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Groff's fiction regularly appears in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, with translations available in thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband operate the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"One of the pleasures of reading Ms. Groff is her sheer unpredictability: She can inject her narrator's voice at any time, turn a sentence into a small hurricane."

—The New York Times

"Even from her impossibly high starting point, Lauren Groff just keeps getting better and better. Fates and Furies is a clear-the-ground triumph."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Fates and Furies is a dazzling novel, its people and its prose wondrously alive from page one. At once intimate and sweeping, this is the story of a marriage as parallel myths— flaring with passion and betrayal, with redemption and retribution, with the sort of heart-breaking, head-slapping secrets that make you want to seek out someone else who's read it. Lauren Groff is a powerful and graceful writer, one of the best of her generation."

—Jess Walter, New York Times-bestselling author of Beautiful Ruins

title: Klara and the Sun
long_summary:
Klara is an Artificial Friend with exceptional observational abilities who watches the world from her place in a store window. She carefully studies the customers who browse inside and the people who pass by on the street, remaining hopeful that someone will choose her.

When she's finally selected to be a companion for a teenage girl, Klara enters a complex human world filled with love, loss, and difficult choices. Through her unique perspective—both deeply empathetic and refreshingly naive—she navigates family dynamics, witnesses the bonds between humans, and grapples with questions about devotion and sacrifice.

Ishiguro crafts a quietly devastating exploration of what it means to love and be loved. Klara's voice is both innocent and wise, offering a fresh lens through which to examine our changing world and the fundamental connections that define us.
short_summary: Through the eyes of an Artificial Friend devoted to her human child, Ishiguro explores love, sacrifice, and connection. Klara's innocent yet wise perspective creates a quietly devastating meditation on what makes us human.
author_bios: Kazuo Ishiguro was born in Nagasaki in 1954 and moved to Britain at age five. His eight previous works have earned him the Nobel Prize in Literature and the Booker Prize. The Remains of the Day and Never Let Me Go have each sold over 2 million copies and been adapted into acclaimed films. He received a knighthood in 2018 for Services to Literature.
quotes:
"There is something so steady and beautiful about the way Klara is always approaching connection, like a Zeno's arrow of the heart. People will absolutely love this book, in part because it enacts the way we learn how to love. Klara and the Sun is wise like a child who decides, just for a little while, to love their doll. "What can children know about genuine love?" Klara asks. The answer, of course, is everything."

—Anne Enright, The Guardian

"One of the most affecting and profound novels Ishiguro has written….I'll go for broke and call Klara and the Sun a masterpiece that will make you think about life, mortality, the saving grace of love: in short, the all of it."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"What stays with you in 'Klara and the Sun' is the haunting narrative voice—a genuinely innocent, egoless perspective on the strange behavior of humans obsessed and wounded by power, status and fear."

—The Booker Prize committee

title: How to Say Babylon
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In Jamaica, a poet's journey to selfhood unfolds against the backdrop of rigid religious doctrine and patriarchal control. Safiya Sinclair chronicles her upbringing in a Rastafarian household where her father's interpretation of faith became a prison for the women in his family. His fear of Western corruption translated into severe restrictions: no modern clothing, no friendships, no independent thought.

Books became Sinclair's secret rebellion, smuggled to her by a mother who understood the power of words even as she remained trapped by circumstance. Education offered a pathway beyond the confines of prescribed womanhood, though each step toward intellectual freedom intensified the conflict at home. The memoir captures both the beauty and suffocation of a culture caught between spiritual tradition and oppressive control.

Sinclair's prose carries the musicality of her poetic background as she examines how religious fundamentalism can distort love into dominance. This is ultimately a story about the courage required to honor one's heritage while refusing to be diminished by it—a young woman's fight to claim her voice in a world determined to silence it.
short_summary: Growing up under her militant Rastafarian father's oppressive control in Jamaica, Sinclair used poetry and education to break free from patriarchal traditions. A lyrical memoir about finding voice and power.
author_bios: Born and raised in Montego Bay, Jamaica, Safiya Sinclair wrote the memoir How to Say Babylon, which earned the National Book Critics Circle Award and appeared on best books lists from The New York Times, The Washington Post, TIME, and The Atlantic in 2023. The book received finalist recognition for the Women's Prize in Nonfiction, the OCM Bocas Prize, and the Kirkus Prize, while also becoming a Read with Jenna/TODAY book club selection and landing on President Barack Obama's annual favorites list.
quotes:
"An essential memoir. Sinclair's devotion to language has been lifelong, and How to Say Babylon is the result. This book is lit from the inside by Sinclair's determination to learn and live freely, and to see her beloveds freed, too."

—Jesmyn Ward, author of Sing, Unburied Sing, Men We Reaped & Let Us Descend

"When a gifted poet applies her hand to prose, magical, even revelatory things can result. Happily, this is the case with Safiya Sinclair. In this lyrical, startling, and magnetic memoir about growing up Rastafari, she weaves a story rich in unsettling visions that goad and haunt while waves crest and soar in the background, beckoning a young girl toward a mysterious future. Her words sparkle like silver or pour like lava, depending on the need."

—Jabari Asim, author of Yonder

"Dazzling. Potent. Vital. A light shining on the path of self-deliverance."

—Tara Westover, author of Educated

title: How the Word Is Passed
subtitle: A Reckoning with the History of Slavery Across America
long_summary:
What does it mean to truly reckon with America's past? Clint Smith embarks on a deeply personal journey across the United States, visiting sites where the contradictions of American history live on in concrete and stone.

From Jefferson's Monticello—where ideals of freedom coexisted with the bondage of hundreds—to the Whitney Plantation's unflinching preservation of enslaved experiences, Smith uncovers stories that challenge comfortable narratives. His travels take him to Angola Prison, where the plantation-to-prison pipeline plays out across Louisiana farmland, and to Confederate burial grounds where memory itself becomes contested territory.

This isn't just historical excavation—it's an urgent examination of how the past shapes present realities. Smith reveals how slavery's influence permeates spaces we encounter daily: city streets built on auction blocks, holidays that celebrate liberation, monuments that sanitize brutality. Through conversations with tour guides, visitors, and community members, he demonstrates how Americans continue to grapple with inherited trauma and selective remembering.

Combining rigorous research with lyrical storytelling, Smith offers a framework for understanding how acknowledgment of difficult truths might lead toward healing rather than division.
short_summary: Smith journeys from Monticello to Angola Prison, revealing how slavery's legacy hides in plain sight across America. A poet's soul meets an educator's heart in this essential exploration of memory and history.
author_bios: Clint Smith writes for The Atlantic and created How the Word Is Passed: A Reckoning With the History of Slavery Across America, which topped The New York Times bestseller list and earned both the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction and the Hillman Prize for Book Journalism. His poetry collection Counting Descent received the 2017 Literary Award for Best Poetry Book from the Black Caucus of the American Library Association. Smith's work has been featured in The New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, Poetry Magazine, and The Paris Review. He earned his B.A. from Davidson College and Ph.D. from Harvard University.
quotes:
"Raises questions that we must all address, without recourse to wishful thinking or the collective ignorance and willful denial that fuels white supremacy."

—Martha Anne Toll, The Washington Post

"The detail and depth of the storytelling is vivid and visceral, making history present and real. Equally commendable is the care and compassion shown to those Smith interviews — whether tour guides or fellow visitors in these many spaces. Due to his care as an interviewer, the responses Smith elicits are resonant and powerful. . . . Smith deftly connects the past, hiding in plain sight, with today's lingering effects."

—Hope Wabuke, NPR

"The power of an itinerant narrator—Smith journeys to Monticello, Angola Prison, Blandford Cemetery, and downtown Manhattan—is that it reveals slavery's expansive, geographical legacy. Smith tells his stories with the soul of a poet and the heart of an educator."

—The Millions

title: The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store
long_summary:
A decades-old mystery begins to unravel in 1972 when workers unearth human remains in a Pennsylvania town, exposing the hidden history of a remarkable community. Chicken Hill once thrived as an unlikely haven where Jewish families and Black residents forged deep bonds despite existing on society's fringes.

At the neighborhood's heart stood Moshe and Chona Ludlow—he operating a theater that welcomed all, she running a corner grocery that became the community's lifeline. Their world intersects with Nate Timblin, whose role as both theater janitor and neighborhood guardian places him at the center of a desperate mission to protect a vulnerable deaf child from institutional forces.

McBride crafts an intricate tapestry of lives shaped by prejudice yet strengthened by solidarity. As layers of the past peel away, the story examines how marginalized communities create their own networks of care and resistance. The eventual revelation of long-concealed truths exposes the complicity of those in power while celebrating the resilience of ordinary people who refuse to abandon one another.
short_summary: When construction workers discover a skeleton in 1972, the secrets of Chicken Hill—a neighborhood where Jewish immigrants and African Americans lived side by side—begin to surface. McBride weaves a powerful story about community, survival, and the bonds that sustain us.
author_bios: James McBride has written numerous celebrated works including The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, Oprah's Book Club pick Deacon King Kong, and The Good Lord Bird, which earned him the National Book Award. His other publications include the memoir The Color of Water, novels Song Yet Sung and Miracle at St. Anna, the story collection Five-Carat Soul, and Kill 'Em and Leave. A National Humanities Medal recipient and talented musician, McBride currently serves as distinguished writer in residence at New York University.
quotes:
"I keep thinking every time I read one of his books, 'That's his best book.' No. THIS is his best book."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Classic McBride: He doesn't shy away from bold statements about the national catastrophes of race and xenophobia, and he always gives us a spoonful of sugar to help the medicine go down. The sugar is McBride's spitfire dialogue and murder-mystery-worthy plot machinations; his characters' big personalities and bigger storylines; his wisecracking, fast-talking humor; and prose so agile and exuberant that reading him is like being at a jazz jam session. . . . Reading McBride just feels good—we are comforted and entertained, and braced for the hard lessons he also delivers."

—The Atlantic

"The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store is one of the best novels I've read this year. It pulls off the singular magic trick of being simultaneously flattening and uplifting."

—NPR

title: Birnam Wood
long_summary:
In the aftermath of a natural disaster that isolates a New Zealand farming community, an idealistic collective of environmental activists believes they've found the perfect solution to their financial struggles. The abandoned land seems like a gift—until they discover they're not the only ones with plans for the property.

Their encounter with a wealthy American outsider transforms what began as simple trespassing into something far more complex. This stranger's offer of partnership forces the group's leader into an impossible position: accept help from someone whose values seem to contradict everything they stand for, or watch their movement collapse from lack of resources.

Catton constructs a tense examination of moral compromise, where survival demands difficult choices and trust becomes a luxury few can afford. The novel dissects the uncomfortable space between principle and pragmatism, asking whether good intentions can justify questionable alliances. As personal loyalties fracture and hidden agendas surface, the story builds toward a reckoning that tests not only what these characters believe, but what they're willing to sacrifice to see those beliefs realized.
short_summary: When a landslide cuts off a New Zealand town, a guerrilla gardening collective sees opportunity—but so does a mysterious billionaire. Catton crafts a brilliant psychological thriller about idealism, survival, and the costs of compromise.
author_bios: Eleanor Catton wrote The Luminaries, the international bestselling novel that earned both the Man Booker Prize and a Governor General's Literary Award. She made her literary debut with The Rehearsal, which claimed the Betty Trask Award and received shortlist recognition for the Guardian First Book Award and Dylan Thomas Prize. Catton also penned the screenplay for Emma's 2020 film adaptation. Though born in Canada and raised in New Zealand, she currently makes her home in Cambridge, England.
quotes:
"A generational cri de coeur . . . A sophisticated page-turner . . . Birnam Wood nearly made me laugh with pleasure. The whole thing crackles . . . Greta Gerwig could film this novel, but so could Quentin Tarantino."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Birnam Wood is terrific. As a multilayered, character-driven thriller, it's as good as it gets. Ruth Rendell would have loved it. A beautifully textured work—what a treat."

—Stephen King

"Dark in both its outlook and omnipresent humor . . . A sincere interrogation of the relationship between morality and the ability to bring about positive change."

—Lily Meyer, The Atlantic

title: Fosse
long_summary:
Bob Fosse transformed American entertainment with a singular artistic vision that left an indelible mark on both Broadway and Hollywood. His distinctive choreographic language—angular movements, tilted fedoras, and provocative staging—created a new vocabulary for musical theater that continues to influence performers today.

This comprehensive biography examines the paradox of an artist who achieved unprecedented success yet remained perpetually dissatisfied. Fosse's creative genius produced legendary works including Chicago, Cabaret, and All That Jazz, establishing him as the sole individual to claim Oscar, Emmy, and Tony honors within a single year. However, beneath his professional triumphs lay a complex psychology driven by deep-seated insecurities and compulsive behavior.

Drawing from extensive interviews with collaborators, lovers, and industry figures—many breaking their silence about Fosse for the first time—this portrait reveals how personal demons fueled extraordinary creativity. The narrative explores his complicated relationships with Broadway luminaries and Hollywood stars, showing how his relentless pursuit of perfection both elevated and tormented those in his orbit. Through meticulous research and unprecedented access to previously unavailable sources, the book illuminates the cost of genius and the price of fame.
short_summary: Behind the jazz hands and razzle-dazzle lay profound insecurity and relentless ambition. Wasson's definitive biography captures the contradictions of the only artist to win Oscar, Emmy, and Tony in one year.
author_bios: Sam Wasson has written seven books exploring cinema and entertainment history. His bestselling works include Fifth Avenue, 5 A.M.: Audrey Hepburn, Breakfast at Tiffany's, and the Dawn of the Modern American Woman; The Big Goodbye: Chinatown and the Last Years of Hollywood; and Fosse. He collaborated with Jeanine Basinger on Hollywood: The Oral History. Wasson currently resides in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"Mr. Wasson is a smart and savvy reporter, and his book abounds with colorful firsthand tales—required reading for anyone eager to understand his brand of — to use a term that appears here constantly, and can't be outdone — razzle-dazzle."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Scintillating . . . There's an enormous amount of scholarship here, yet the story never drags, so adroitly does [Wasson] blend his material into a fluent narrative around evocative scenes where character emerges novelistically."

—Publishers Weekly

"He thought he was the best, and he thought he was terrible. The man in question is legendary choreographer and director Bob Fosse, whose celebrated life and career get their due in Sam Wasson's spellbinding 695-page biography, Fosse. You don't need to be a Broadway expert to enjoy this portrait of a man whose rise to power was famously fueled by insecurity. It's all here: accounts of his monstrous, masterful directing style; the explosive personal battles behind his Tony-winning triumphs; his incendiary relationship with Gwen Verdon. Wasson simply doesn't miss a thing. Give the guy a (jazz) hand."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: G-Man
subtitle: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century
long_summary:
The name J. Edgar Hoover conjures images of authoritarian excess, yet this singular figure began his career as a promising young reformer determined to modernize American law enforcement. Beverly Gage's exhaustive biography traces how a middle-class Washington native transformed himself into one of the most influential—and controversial—power brokers in U.S. history.

For nearly five decades, Hoover wielded the FBI as both shield and sword, championing federal authority while systematically targeting those he deemed unworthy of American citizenship. His vision of national security was deeply selective: communists, civil rights leaders, and other perceived threats found themselves under relentless surveillance. Yet millions of Americans saw him as a patriotic guardian protecting traditional values.

Drawing on unprecedented access to previously classified materials, Gage constructs a complex portrait that resists easy categorization. This wasn't simply a story of unchecked power, but of how one man's contradictions—his genuine belief in government service alongside his willingness to abuse that service—shaped decades of American politics. Through Hoover's rise and reign, we see the evolution of federal authority, the machinery of surveillance, and the ongoing tensions between security and civil liberties that continue to define our political landscape.
short_summary: Beverly Gage's monumental biography draws from never-before-seen sources to reveal how J. Edgar Hoover dominated half a century of American history and planted seeds for today's conservative political landscape.
author_bios: Beverly Gage is a historian at Yale University specializing in American political history. Her biography G-Man: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century earned the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Biography along with the Bancroft Prize in American History, the National Book Critics Circle Award for Biography, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize in Biography. Gage previously wrote The Day Wall Street Exploded: A Story of America in its First Age of Terror and contributes regularly to The New Yorker, The New York Times, and The Washington Post.
quotes:
"What hath Hoover wrought? No one has answered that question as exhaustively or as astutely as the inimitable Beverly Gage. Hoover, at long last, has met his match. G-Man is unflinching, incisive, and riveting, part biography, part political thriller, and much more: an essential new history of twentieth-century America."

—Jill Lepore, author of Book of Ages & These Truths: A History of the United States

"Gage's penetrating account of Hoover's career, especially his many long-eclipsed triumphs, offers a well-timed and sobering perspective as yet another institution in our fractured country struggles to maintain trust."

—The Atlantic

"Revelatory...an acknowledgment of the complexities that made Hoover who he was, while charging the turbulent currents that eventually swept him aside."

—The New York Times

title: A Guardian and a Thief
long_summary:
Climate catastrophe has pushed Kolkata to its breaking point, and one family sees escape within reach. After years of waiting, they finally hold American visas that promise safety in Michigan. Their departure is just days away when disaster strikes: the documents vanish, stolen in the night.

What follows is a week-long race against time that reveals how crisis strips away everything except the fierce instinct to protect those we love. While Ma tears through the crumbling city searching for her family's stolen future, the person who took it faces his own impossible choices. Boomba never intended to destroy lives, but hunger makes thieves of desperate fathers.

Majumdar constructs a moral puzzle with no easy answers, where victim and perpetrator blur in the face of survival. Both families fight with everything they have, yet their battles pit them against each other in ways neither could have imagined. This is a story about the terrible mathematics of scarcity, where one family's salvation becomes another's catastrophe, and love itself becomes a force that both saves and destroys.
short_summary: Two families in a collapsing near-future Kolkata battle each other while trying to protect their children. Majumdar's taut, propulsive novel explores how desperation transforms ordinary people into both victims and perpetrators.
author_bios: Megha Majumdar wrote the New York Times bestselling novel A Burning, which received nominations for the National Book Award, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the American Library Association's Andrew Carnegie Medal. Her work earned recognition from The Washington Post, The New York Times, NPR, The Atlantic, Vogue, and TIME Magazine as one of the year's finest books. Born in Kolkata, India, Majumdar earned degrees from Harvard and Johns Hopkins and received the 2022 Whiting Award. She currently resides in New York.
quotes:
"Wondering if there's a novel out there that gives Cormac McCarthy's The Road a run for its money? Here you go."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra: A Life

"[A Guardian and a Thief] is a perfect novel: 200 pages of tightly honed panic about life in a collapsing society. . . . The book's simple structure feels reminiscent of a fairy tale, which helps account for the deep, visceral terror the story generates."

—The Washington Post

"A mesmerizing morality play that demonstrates how categories like 'victim' and 'thief' collapse under conditions of scarcity."

—The Atlantic

title: When the Clock Broke
subtitle: Con Men, Conspiracists, and How America Cracked Up in the Early 1990s
long_summary:
The collapse of the Soviet Union should have ushered in an era of American triumph and unity. Instead, the early 1990s unleashed forces of rage and division that would reshape the nation's political landscape for decades to come.

John Ganz chronicles this pivotal moment through the voices of insurgents and outsiders who challenged the established order. Pat Buchanan's fiery populism and Ross Perot's anti-establishment crusade exposed deep fractures in American society, while figures like David Duke exploited racial anxieties and conspiracy theories flourished in the heartland. From talk radio's inflammatory rhetoric to violent clashes in urban centers, the decade revealed a country grappling with economic uncertainty, demographic shifts, and the disorienting end of familiar Cold War certainties.

As traditional political coalitions splintered and new forms of extremism took root, intellectuals scrambled to decode the motivations driving Middle America's growing alienation. Bill Clinton's attempt to occupy the political center offered temporary stability, but the underlying tensions remained unresolved. Ganz demonstrates how this turbulent period planted the seeds of today's polarized politics, making sense of our current moment by excavating its chaotic origins.
short_summary: Political writer John Ganz excavates the forgotten convulsions of the early 1990s—from Crown Heights to Pat Buchanan's insurgency—revealing how America's current polarization began when the Reagan order collapsed.
author_bios: John Ganz publishes the popular Unpopular Front newsletter on Substack and contributes to major publications including The Washington Post, Artforum, and the New Statesman. His writing combines political analysis with cultural criticism, offering sharp insights into American politics and society.
quotes:
"[A] terrific new book . . . Vibrant . . . [Ganz] has the skills of a gifted storyteller-one with excellent comedic timing, too-slipping in the most absurd and telling details . . . Urgent and illuminating . . . Like the cultural moment he covers, Ganz gets energized by mixing high and low. When the Clock Broke is one of those rarest of books: unflaggingly entertaining while never losing sight of its moral core."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"A searching history of a time, not so long ago, when the social contract went out the window and Hobbesian war beset America . . . Ganz makes a convincing, well-documented case that everything old is indeed new again. A significant, provocative work."

—Kirkus

"Lucid and propulsive . . . [When the Clock Broke is] woven throughout with astute analysis of the period's political commentary . . . Ganz's dry wit is ever-present . . . This is a revelation."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Detransition, Baby
long_summary:
Three lives intersect around an unplanned pregnancy that offers each woman a chance at something she desperately wants. Reese finds herself spiraling after her relationship ends, seeking connection through fleeting encounters that leave her more isolated than before. Her former partner Ames struggles with the aftermath of his transition choices, discovering that changing his identity couldn't solve the deeper questions about who he wants to be. Meanwhile, Katrina faces an unexpected pregnancy that could reshape all their futures.

The baby becomes a catalyst that forces each character to examine what family really means and whether love can transcend the boundaries of conventional relationships. Peters crafts a story that refuses easy answers, instead diving into the complexities of identity, desire, and the human need for connection. The novel challenges readers to reconsider assumptions about gender, relationships, and parenthood while exploring how people create meaning from life's messiest moments.
short_summary: Three women—transgender and cisgender—find their lives colliding when an unexpected pregnancy forces them to confront their deepest desires for family, love, and belonging.
author_bios: Torrey Peters wrote the bestselling novel Detransition, Baby, which earned the PEN/Hemingway Award for Debut Novel and was recognized by The New York Times as one of the 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. She divides her time between Brooklyn and an off-grid cabin in Vermont, traveling between them on a pink motorcycle.
quotes:
"Detransition, Baby is so good I want to scream."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House & Her Body & Other Parties

"[Detransition, Baby] is going to play a role in defining the literature of 2021 and beyond."

—The Millions

"A tale of love, loss, and self-discovery as singular as it is universal, and all the sweeter for it."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: A Hologram for the King
long_summary:
Alan Clay finds himself stranded in the corporate wilderness of modern Saudi Arabia, betting everything on a technology presentation that could rescue him from financial ruin. His marriage has crumbled, his daughter's education hangs in the balance, and his career has become a series of missed opportunities and broken promises.

Eggers constructs a meditation on American masculinity adrift in an increasingly connected yet alienating world. Clay's predicament reflects the broader displacement felt by a generation caught between old certainties and new realities, where traditional markers of success no longer guarantee stability.

The novel examines what happens to individual identity when economic systems shift beneath our feet. Through Clay's experience in an unfamiliar culture, Eggers illuminates the universal struggle to maintain dignity while confronting personal and professional irrelevance. The result is an intimate character study that resonates far beyond one man's crisis, offering insight into how we measure worth and meaning in uncertain times.
short_summary: A struggling American businessman travels to Saudi Arabia for one last deal that might save his finances and dignity. Eggers captures middle-aged anxiety with humor and grace.
author_bios: Dave Eggers has written numerous works including The Every, The Circle, Museum of Rain, The Monk of Mokha, and A Hologram for the King, which received a National Book Award nomination. His books for younger audiences include Her Right Foot, Faraway Things, and The Lifters. Eggers established McSweeney's and ScholarMatch, helped create 826 Valencia, and received both the Muhammad Ali Humanitarian Award for Education and the Dayton Literary Peace Prize.
quotes:
"Mr. Eggers uses a new, pared down, Hemingwayesque voice to recount his story... he demonstrates in Hologram that he is master of this more old-fashioned approach as much as he was a pioneering innovator with A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius....[This] sad-funny-dreamlike story unfolds to become an allegory about the frustrations of middle-class America, about the woes unemployed workers and sidelined entrepreneurs have experienced in a newly globalized world in which jobs are being outsourced abroad.... A comic but deeply affecting tale about one man's travails that also provides a bright, digital snapshot of our times."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Eerie, suspenseful and tightly controlled? Exciting stuff."

—Cynthia Macdonald, The Globe and Mail

"A potent, well-drawn portrait of one man's discovery of where his personal and professional selves split and connect."

—Kirkus

title: Hemingway's Boat
subtitle: Everything He Loved in Life, and Lost, 1934-1961
long_summary:
Ernest Hemingway's fishing cruiser serves as both sanctuary and witness to the author's tumultuous final chapter. Between 1934 and his death in 1961, the literary giant's existence oscillated between triumph and torment, with his boat remaining the single thread of continuity through it all.

The vessel became Hemingway's refuge from a world that simultaneously celebrated and consumed him. Here he pursued massive fish, hosted luminaries, and found moments of peace with his children. Yet the same deck that witnessed his joys also bore the weight of his deteriorating mental state, fractured relationships, and growing inability to write.

Beneath the familiar narrative of literary genius turned destructive celebrity lies a more complex portrait. Through fresh archival material and conversations with Hemingway's sons, a different man emerges—one capable of profound kindness toward struggling artists and broken souls. The most heartbreaking thread follows his relationship with his youngest son Gigi, whose gender identity struggles paralleled his father's own battles with authenticity and acceptance.

This examination reveals how creativity and self-destruction can coexist within the same person, offering neither condemnation nor absolution but rather an honest reckoning with human complexity.
short_summary: Using Hemingway's beloved boat Pilar as an anchor point, Hendrickson traces the writer's final decades with remarkable nuance. Drawing on unpublished material, this biography reveals unexpected generosity beneath the familiar boorishness and cruelty.
author_bios: Paul Hendrickson has earned three National Book Critics Circle Award nominations, winning in 2003 for Sons of Mississippi. The Living and the Dead received a National Book Award nomination in 1996, while Hemingway's Boat achieved New York Times bestseller status. His work has garnered support from prestigious institutions including the Guggenheim Foundation, National Endowment for the Arts, Lyndhurst Foundation, and Alicia Patterson Foundation. Since 1998, Paul Hendrickson has been a faculty member in the Creative Writing Program at the University of Pennsylvania. He resides with his wife Cecilia in the Philadelphia area and Washington, DC.
quotes:
"Large-minded [and] rigorously fair…An indispensable document…With this sterling summation of the entire Hemingway canon, Hendrickson shows what has eluded some very able scholars. A writer's life can contain two conflicting existences, one of purely original genius and one of irreversible destructiveness. It's a lucky genius who gets credit for the first and a free pass on the second. Hendrickson issues no free pass to Papa. He gives the ravaged old man something more honest: a fair summing-up of a life like no other."

—Howell Raines, The Washington Post

"Splendid…A moving, highly evocative account…Seven years in the making, this vivid portrait allows us to see Hemingway on the Pilar once again, standing on the flying bridge and guiding her out of the harbor at sunrise. Appearing on the 50th anniversary of Hemingway's death, this beautifully written, nuanced meditation deserves a wide audience."

—Kirkus

"Admirably absorbing, important, and moving…Poignant…Acutely sensitive to his subject's volatile, 'gratuitously mean' personality, Hendrickson offers fascinating details and sheds new light on Hemingway's kinder, more generous side."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Unworthy Republic
subtitle: The Dispossession of Native Americans and the Road to Indian Territory
long_summary:
The 1830 Indian Removal Act promised orderly relocation of Native Americans beyond the Mississippi, framed by politicians as benevolent policy. Reality proved devastatingly different. Claudio Saunt excavates the true machinery behind this mass displacement, revealing how bureaucratic systems designed for efficiency instead enabled widespread death, theft, and brutality.

Through meticulous examination of federal archives and survivor testimonies, Saunt demonstrates that removal was never inevitable—it was a calculated political gamble. Southern legislators pushed the policy to open vast territories for plantation agriculture, while Indigenous communities mounted fierce resistance and many Americans condemned the betrayal of national principles.

The narrow congressional victory unleashed one of history's earliest examples of state-orchestrated ethnic cleansing. Administrative chaos compounded deliberate cruelty as 80,000 people were torn from ancestral lands. Saunt traces how racial ideology and economic ambition converged to justify systematic violence, exposing the corruption and incompetence that turned policy into catastrophe. This rigorous historical investigation connects nineteenth-century choices to contemporary America, showing how the foundations of white supremacy were built through government-sanctioned dispossession.
short_summary: Saunt chronicles the brutal reality behind Indian Removal—the 1830s policy that forcibly displaced 80,000 Native Americans. Meticulously researched and unflinching, this essential history exposes how white supremacy and greed drove state-sponsored mass deportation.
author_bios: Claudio Saunt holds the Richard B. Russell Professorship in American History at the University of Georgia. His scholarship includes the celebrated works A New Order of Things, Black, White, and Indian, and West of the Revolution, all of which have garnered significant recognition. Saunt makes his home in Athens, Georgia.
quotes:
"Unworthy Republic" is a powerful and lucid account, weaving together events with the people who experienced them up close.…Saunt has written an unflinching book that reckons with this history and its legacy."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Saunt presents a stark and well-documented case that Native American expulsion was a political choice rather than an inevitable tragedy. This searing account forces a new reckoning with American history."

—Publishers Weekly

"A significant, well-rendered study of a disturbing period in American history."

—Kirkus

title: Transcendent Kingdom
long_summary:
In her Stanford lab, Gifty manipulates neural pathways in mice, searching for answers about addiction that elude her personal life. The death of her brother from an overdose and her mother's subsequent retreat into crippling depression have left her isolated with questions that transcend scientific methodology.

As her research into reward-seeking behavior deepens, so does her confrontation with inherited trauma and the limits of empirical knowledge. The evangelical faith of her youth beckons and repels in equal measure, offering both comfort and contradiction to her scientific worldview.

Gyasi constructs a narrative that moves between laboratory precision and spiritual yearning, examining how grief reshapes identity across generations. The novel interrogates whether understanding brain chemistry can heal family wounds, and whether faith and science might coexist in the space between loss and acceptance. Through Gifty's dual pursuit of academic achievement and emotional survival, the story reveals how immigrants navigate between worlds—geographical, spiritual, and intellectual—while carrying the weight of those they've lost.
short_summary: A neuroscience PhD student researches addiction while caring for her grieving mother and grappling with her brother's overdose death. Gyasi weaves science and faith into a devastating portrait of a Ghanaian immigrant family's struggle with loss.
author_bios: Born in Ghana and raised in Huntsville, Alabama, Yaa Gyasi achieved remarkable literary recognition with her first novel. Homegoing earned her the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Award, the PEN/Hemingway Award, the National Book Foundation's "5 under 35" honors, and the American Book Award. She currently resides in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"I would say that Transcendent Kingdom is a novel for our time (and it is) but it is so much more than that. It is a novel for all times. The splendor and heart and insight and brilliance contained in the pages holds up a light the rest of us can follow."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Meticulous, psychologically complex...At once a vivid evocation of the immigrant experience and a sharp delineation of an individual's inner struggle, the novel brilliantly succeeds on both counts."

—Publishers Weekly

"Gyasi's wise second novel pivots toward intimacy... In precise prose, Gyasi creates an ache of recognition, especially for readers knowledgeable about the wreckage of addiction. Still, she leavens this nonlinear novel with sly humor... The author is astute about childhood grandiosity and a pious girl's deep desire to be good; she conveys in brief strokes the notched, nodding hook of heroin's oblivion...final chapter that gives readers a taste of hard-won deliverance."

—Kirkus

title: One of Us
subtitle: The Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway
long_summary:
The massacre that shattered Norway's sense of security began with a bomb in Oslo and ended on a small island where teenagers had gathered for a political summer camp. Åsne Seierstad reconstructs the events of July 22, 2011, through an unflinching examination of both perpetrator and victims.

Seierstad traces Anders Behring Breivik's transformation from a middle-class Oslo youth into a mass murderer driven by extremist ideology. Her investigation reveals how isolation, online radicalization, and a warped sense of patriotism converged to create a terrorist who believed he was saving his country. Equally important are the portraits of those who died—young people committed to democratic ideals and social justice, whose futures were cut short by violence.

This is both a meticulous reconstruction of a national tragedy and a broader meditation on how hatred takes root. Seierstad exposes the fragility of peaceful societies and the human cost of extremism, creating a work that functions as both memorial and warning. The result is journalism that bears witness to unthinkable loss while refusing to look away from difficult truths about radicalization and its consequences.
short_summary: Seierstad delivers a devastating account of the 2011 Norway attacks, examining both the terrorist's radicalization and his victims' lives. Forensic in its detail, compassionate in its scope.
author_bios: Åsne Seierstad has spent decades covering global conflicts and social issues as a foreign correspondent. Her seven published books have garnered international recognition, with The Bookseller of Kabul reaching readers in more than 40 languages worldwide. One of Us earned placement on the New York Times' ten best books list for 2015 and won the 2018 Leipzig Book Award for European Understanding. Most recently, Seierstad received Norway's prestigious Brage Prize for Two Sisters, continuing her tradition of illuminating complex human stories through immersive journalism.
quotes:
"Asne Seierstad's One of Us is almost unbearable to read and absolutely impossible to turn away from: its account of an unthinkable tragedy is reported with staggering rigor and recounted with grace. It's hard to leave this book without feeling incredible grief, without feeling shaken to the core, without feeling urged toward essential questions about what we call evil and how it comes to pass."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

"Engrossing, important . . . There are many, many indelible images in Seierstad's account . . . As hard as it is to read about the attack, as frustrating as it is to learn how many delaying mistakes the first responders made and as monstrous as Breivik is, [his victims] on that island that day were beautiful in their idealism. They deserve to be witnessed, which is the ultimate reason to read One of Us."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"The roughly 70 pages Ms. Seierstad devotes to [the attacks] are harrowing in their forensic exactitude . . . These scenes are balanced by moments of tremendous heroism, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't read the final half of One of Us with perpetually moist cheeks . . . The nonfiction horror story told in One of Us moves slowly, inexorably and with tremendous authority."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: A Brief History of Seven Killings
long_summary:
A shocking assassination attempt on reggae legend Bob Marley becomes the catalyst for an extraordinary literary odyssey through Jamaica's darkest chapters. Marlon James constructs a kaleidoscopic narrative that spans three tumultuous decades, giving voice to killers, politicians, spies, and spirits who witnessed the island's descent into chaos.

The novel refuses simple answers about that December night in 1976, instead diving deep into the complex web of Cold War politics, gang warfare, and social upheaval that defined modern Jamaica. Characters migrate from Kingston's volatile neighborhoods to New York's drug-ravaged streets, carrying their traumas and secrets across borders and years.

James orchestrates a symphony of perspectives, each narrator revealing fragments of a larger truth about power, survival, and the cycles of violence that trap entire generations. The result is a literary tour de force that interrogates how historical events ripple through individual lives, and how those caught in the crossfire must reinvent themselves repeatedly to endure. This is storytelling on an ambitious scale—raw, uncompromising, and utterly absorbing.
short_summary: Seven gunmen storm Bob Marley's house in 1976 Kingston, launching an epic chronicle of violence, politics, and consequence across three decades. James weaves together multiple voices in this sprawling, unforgettable exploration of Jamaica's turbulent history.
author_bios: Marlon James has written several acclaimed novels including the Man Booker Prize-winning A Brief History of Seven Killings and the National Book Award finalist Black Leopard, Red Wolf, both New York Times bestsellers. His other works include The Book of Night Women and John Crow's Devil. Currently teaching at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota, James makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"How to describe Marlon James's monumental new novel A Brief History of Seven Killings? It's like a Tarantino remake of The Harder They Come but with a soundtrack by Bob Marley and a script by Oliver Stone and William Faulkner, with maybe a little creative boost from some primo ganja. It's epic in every sense of that word: sweeping, mythic, over-the-top, colossal and dizzyingly complex. It's also raw, dense, violent, scalding, darkly comic, exhilarating and exhausting—a testament to Mr. James's vaulting ambition and prodigious talent."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"It will come to be seen as a classic of our times…that's what judges of the prestigious Man Booker Prize have said about this year's winner."

—NPR

"An astonishing portrait of the politics of everyday life…Just as he is sharply aware of the nuances of their voices, James has the confidence not to deny his characters their humanity by turning them into moral exemplars, nor paper over the infected wounds that score across the country by suggesting that the loveliness of some of its territory makes up for the savage effects of poverty."

—The Washington Post

title: Biography of X
long_summary:
After her enigmatic artist wife dies suddenly, CM embarks on a relentless investigation into the woman she thought she knew. What begins as biographical research transforms into a labyrinthine journey through decades of hidden truths and artistic manipulation.

The search leads CM deep into an alternate American history where the South became an independent fascist state after WWII, only recently rejoining the union. Against this backdrop of political upheaval, she discovers her wife's secret collaborations with cultural luminaries like Bowie, Waits, Sontag, and Acker—relationships that reveal a pattern of calculated reinvention.

As CM pieces together fragments of her wife's past, from European origins to cross-continental artistic ventures, she confronts the devastating possibility that their entire relationship was built on lies. The deeper she digs, the more she realizes that her wife's greatest artistic achievement may have been the systematic destruction of everyone who loved her.

Lacey weaves together elements of speculative fiction, literary biography, and psychological thriller to create a meditation on how we construct identity, both our own and others'. This is a novel about the stories we tell to survive grief, and what happens when those stories crumble under scrutiny.
short_summary: Wild with grief, a widow investigates her late wife's secret past and uncovers a web of artistic deceptions. Lacey constructs an ambitious literary thriller about love, art, and the stories we tell ourselves.
author_bios: Catherine Lacey has written four novels—Biography of X, Pew, The Answers, and Nobody Is Ever Missing—along with the story collection Certain American States. Her work has earned her recognition through a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Whiting Award, the New York Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award, the Brooklyn Public Library Book Prize, a Lambda Literary Award, and a residency at the Jan Michalski Foundation.
quotes:
"Biography of X is the most ambitious book I've ever read from a writer of my own generation. Epic world-building revealed through intimate emotion and dangerously honed sentences; a story that mixes fact and fiction to create a new register of truth, a register that belongs entirely to Catherine Lacey. I'm awed."

—Torrey Peters, author of Detransition, Baby

"Sly, brilliant, philosophically acute, bitingly funny, and a pure joy to spend hours with . . . Suffice it to say that it feels fairly rare for a novel to be hugely intelligent and moving and fun in equal measure, but with Biography of X, Catherine Lacey somehow-magically-makes the nearly impossible look easy."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates & Furies, Matrix & Arcadia

"This is a major novel, and a notably audacious one. Lacey is pulling from a deep reservoir. Beneath the counterfactuals, and the glamour and squalor of Manhattan nightlife, and the mythologies bought and sold, she's telling a love story of a broken sort. C.M. is flinging rope between her present and past. This book is about facing, and accepting, the things you didn't want to know."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: Killers of the Flower Moon
subtitle: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI
long_summary:
Oil transforms the Osage people of Oklahoma into America's wealthiest community during the Jazz Age, but their newfound prosperity becomes a death sentence. A pattern of suspicious deaths emerges—family members of Mollie Burkhart fall victim to shootings and poisonings that authorities dismiss or ignore.

The body count climbs as anyone who questions these convenient deaths meets similar fates. Eventually, the fledgling FBI steps in, with J. Edgar Hoover assigning former Texas Ranger Tom White to lead the investigation. White's team employs innovative undercover tactics, including placing a Native American agent within the community to gather intelligence.

What they uncover reveals a breathtaking scope of evil: a calculated plot rooted in racial hatred and financial greed that targeted an entire people for extermination. This forgotten chapter of American brutality illuminates how violence and corruption shaped the frontier, challenging romanticized notions of westward expansion with stark evidence of systematic persecution.
short_summary: The shocking true story of how the oil-rich Osage Nation became targets of a murderous conspiracy in 1920s Oklahoma. Grann's meticulous investigation exposes forgotten American horrors.
author_bios: David Grann has written multiple #1 New York Times bestsellers, including Killers of the Flower Moon and The Lost City of Z. His work Killers of the Flower Moon received a National Book Award nomination and earned an Edgar Allan Poe Award. Grann's other books include The White Darkness and The Devil and Sherlock Holmes. His investigative journalism has been recognized with a George Polk Award and additional honors.
quotes:
"[C]lose to impeccable. It's confident, fluid in its dynamics, light on its feet.... The crime story it tells is appalling, and stocked with authentic heroes and villains. It will make you cringe at man's inhumanity to man."

—The New York Times

"The best book of the year so far."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Disturbing and riveting.... Grann has proved himself a master of spinning delicious, many-layered mysteries that also happen to be true.... It will sear your soul."

—Dave Eggers, Author of A Hologram for the King

title: Crying in H Mart
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Michelle Zauner's memoir traces the complex threads connecting food, identity, and loss in the Korean American experience. Growing up in Eugene, Oregon, Zauner felt caught between worlds—neither fully Korean nor fully American—while navigating her mother's cultural expectations and her own coming-of-age struggles.

The kitchen becomes sacred ground where three generations of women forge their deepest connections. Late-night meals in her grandmother's Seoul apartment and shared recipes create a language of love that transcends words. Yet as Zauner pursues music and builds an independent life on the East Coast, these cultural ties seem to fade.

Everything shifts when her mother receives a terminal cancer diagnosis. Faced with impending loss, Zauner discovers that cooking traditional Korean dishes offers a pathway back to her heritage and a means of honoring her mother's legacy. Through intimate portraits of family meals and the rituals of caregiving, she examines how we inherit not just recipes but entire ways of being in the world.

This memoir captures the particular ache of losing a parent while simultaneously finding yourself, revealing how the act of preparing food can become both an expression of grief and a form of cultural reclamation.
short_summary: From Japanese Breakfast's Michelle Zauner comes a luminous memoir exploring Korean American identity through the lens of food and family. When her mother's terminal illness forces a reckoning with heritage, cooking becomes both grief and healing.
author_bios: Michelle Zauner leads the celebrated indie pop project Japanese Breakfast, earning widespread recognition for her musical artistry. Her discography includes Psychopomp (2016), Soft Sounds from Another Planet (2017), Jubilee (2021), and For Melancholy Brunettes (and Sad Women) (2025), albums that have garnered international acclaim and established her as a distinctive voice in contemporary music.
quotes:
"Crying in H Mart powerfully maps a complicated mother-daughter relationship . . . Zauner writes about her mother's death [with] clear-eyed frankness . . . The book is a rare acknowledgement of the ravages of cancer in a culture obsessed with seeing it as an enemy that can be battled with hope and strength. Zauner plumbs the connections between food and identity . . . her food descriptions transport us to the table alongside her. What Crying in H Mart reveals is that in losing her mother and cooking to bring her back to life, Zauner became herself."

—NPR

"Poignant . . . A tender, well-rendered, heart-wrenching account of the way food ties us to those who have passed. The author delivers mouthwatering descriptions of dishes like pajeon, jatjuk, and gimbap, and her storytelling is fluid, honest, and intimate. When a loved one dies, we search all of our senses for signs of their presence. Zauner's ability to let us in through taste makes her book stand out—she makes us feel like we are in her mother's kitchen, singing her praises."

—Kirkus

"Lyrical... Earnest... Zauner does a good job capturing the grief of losing a parent with pathos. Fans looking to get a glimpse into the inner life of this megawatt pop star will not be disappointed."

—Publishers Weekly

title: NW
long_summary:
Four childhood friends from a London council estate find themselves scattered across different social strata as adults, their shared past both connecting and dividing them. Leah, Natalie, Felix, and Nathan each grapple with questions of belonging and authenticity in a city that promises mobility but often delivers isolation.

Smith constructs a mosaic of contemporary London life, where gentrification reshapes neighborhoods and personal relationships alike. The novel examines how geography shapes identity—both the physical spaces we inhabit and the psychological territories we defend. Through fragmented narratives and shifting perspectives, the story reveals the tensions between aspiration and origin, showing how the desire to transcend one's circumstances can create unexpected forms of entrapment.

This is urban fiction that refuses easy answers, presenting London as both sanctuary and maze. Smith's formal innovations mirror the disjointed experience of modern city living, where connection and alienation exist in constant tension.
short_summary: Four Londoners who grew up in the same council estate navigate adulthood, class divides, and shifting identities. Smith's formally experimental novel captures the fractured rhythms of contemporary urban life.
author_bios: Zadie Smith has published six novels including White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud, alongside the novella The Embassy of Cambodia and short story collection Grand Union. Her nonfiction works include three essay collections: Changing My Mind, Feel Free, and Intimations. Smith also wrote The Wife of Willesden, a play adapted from Chaucer. A native of north-west London, she continues to live there today.
quotes:
"This is a book in which you never know how things will come together or what will happen next... NW represents a deliberate undoing; an unpacking of Smith's abundant narrative gifts to find a deeper truth, audacious and painful as that truth may be. The result is that rare thing, a book that is radical and passionate and real."

—Anne Enright, The New York Times Book Review

"Endlessly fascinating... remarkable. ...The impression of Smith's casual brilliance is what constantly surprises, the way she tosses off insights about parenting and work that you've felt in some nebulous way but never been able to articulate."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A powerful portrait of class and identity in multicultural London."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Stone Yard Devotional
long_summary:
Escaping the demands of city life, a woman finds herself in an unlikely sanctuary: a remote religious community on Australia's windswept plains. Despite her lack of faith, she settles into this contemplative existence, drawn to its simplicity and distance from her former world.

Her fragile peace dissolves as three disturbing forces converge. A relentless mouse invasion transforms daily life into a surreal battle for survival. The discovery of human bones—identified as her long-lost sister—resurrects painful questions about family and loss. An unexpected arrival from her past threatens to expose the very secrets she sought to escape.

This Booker Prize-shortlisted work examines the human impulse to flee from pain and the impossibility of outrunning our deepest wounds. Through quiet observation and careful prose, it questions whether true sanctuary exists anywhere but within ourselves, and whether redemption requires confronting rather than avoiding the ghosts that haunt us.
short_summary: Seeking refuge in a remote religious community, a woman confronts three unsettling events: a mouse plague, her sister's discovered remains, and a visitor from her past. Booker Prize-shortlisted fiction about retreat, forgiveness, and grief.
author_bios: Charlotte Wood has written seven novels alongside three works of nonfiction. The Natural Way of Things earned her the Stella Prize in 2016 and shared the Australian Prime Minister's Literary Award for Fiction. Her novel The Weekend became an international bestseller following its 2020 publication.
quotes:
"Founded on the same rock of introspection that anchors the Gilead series….Stone Yard Devotional not only stays aloft but soars… A strange sense of engagement with these pages gives way to sheer gratitude for the chance to be in the presence of such restraint and wisdom."

—Washington Post

"A book about what it means to be good: simply and with great humility, it asks the big questions, leaving the reader feeling kinder, more brave, enlarged."

—Anne Enright

"The novel is, in many ways, an extended meditative vigil...Activism, abdication, atonement, grace: In this novel no one of these paths is holier than another; Wood is more invested in noticing the human pursuit of holiness itself."

—New York Times

title: The Fate of the Day
subtitle: The War for America, Fort Ticonderoga to Charleston, 1777-1780
long_summary:
America's fight for independence reaches a critical juncture as the fledgling nation teeters between triumph and collapse. The Continental Army has endured devastating losses, while across the ocean, Britain grapples with mounting costs and the looming threat of European powers entering the fray.

Rick Atkinson chronicles this decisive period through multiple lenses: Franklin's delicate diplomatic dance in Versailles, Washington's relentless struggle to keep his forces equipped and fed, and British commanders questioning whether victory remains achievable. The narrative weaves together legendary confrontations—Brandywine's chaos, Saratoga's turning point, Monmouth's brutal heat—with the quiet heroism of Valley Forge's winter ordeal.

Beyond military strategy and political maneuvering, this account examines the profound sacrifices required to birth a democracy. Atkinson reveals how ordinary colonists, soldiers, and leaders confronted impossible choices that would determine their nation's fate. The result illuminates not just pivotal battles, but the character of a people willing to risk everything for an untested ideal of self-governance.
short_summary: The Revolution's brutal middle years, when Washington's army fought on the knife's edge between survival and annihilation. Atkinson brings epic battles and desperate diplomacy to vivid life.
author_bios: Rick Atkinson has written eight narrative histories spanning five American conflicts, including The Long Gray Line and the celebrated Liberation Trilogy comprising An Army at Dawn, The Day of Battle, and The Guns at Last Light, along with The British Are Coming. His works have topped The New York Times bestseller lists, and he has earned Pulitzer Prizes in both history and journalism for his distinguished career.
quotes:
"Atkinson writes with tremendous verve and detail. The result is a book that infuses the events… of the war with striking vibrancy, essentially bringing the conflict to life again. . . . Regular readers of history will have already heard of many of the people Atkinson describes—but after finishing this book, they might feel like they have met them."

—The Washington Post

"As ever with Atkinson, an exemplary work of narrative history."

—Kirkus Reviews, starred review

"Epic in scale but rich in detail, this captures the drama and world-historical significance of the revolution."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Wilderness
long_summary:
Four Black women in their twenties face the messy realities of adult life as they build careers and relationships in New York and Los Angeles. Each carries her own struggles: Desiree deals with painful family estrangement from her sister, while January grapples with unexpected pregnancy and mixed feelings about her partner. Monique discovers the double-edged nature of viral fame after challenging institutional racism, and Nakia fights to establish her restaurant while resisting family expectations about her choices.

Spanning two decades from the late 2000s to the late 2020s, their stories unfold against a backdrop of political turmoil, economic uncertainty, and environmental crisis. As external pressures mount and personal challenges evolve, these women must determine what their bond means and whether it can survive the transformations that come with growing up. Flournoy examines how friendship serves as both anchor and complication, revealing the complex ways we support and sometimes fail each other across the years that shape us most.
short_summary: Four Black women navigate two decades of friendship through the chaos of contemporary American life. Flournoy's electric prose captures how we grow and change while holding onto the people who matter most.
author_bios: Angela Flournoy wrote The Turner House, which earned recognition as a National Book Award finalist, Center for Fiction First Novel Prize finalist, Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers selection, Indie Next pick, and New York Times Notable Book of the Year. Her fiction appears in The Paris Review, while her nonfiction has been published in The New York Times, The New Yorker, and Los Angeles Times, among other publications. After completing her MFA at the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Angela Flournoy has held teaching positions at the University of Iowa, Princeton University, and UCLA.
quotes:
"Angela Flournoy's vivid second novel, The Wilderness, treats friendship with the dignity and fascination it deserves."

—Washington Post

"Astonishing.... The book's shifting perspectives trace these women as they mature and negotiate tensions within themselves and with one another, all while the world is tumbling ever more precipitously toward hell. Think: if Waiting to Exhale were also about the difficulty of breathing in the Anthropocene amid frequent wildfires and unpredictable political weather.... Transcendent."

—New York Times Book Review

"A rangy novel, crisscrossing the continent to trace the fates of five friends as they navigate relationships, career pivots and entrenchments, and the loss of or estrangement from family. The Wilderness uses social events (recent racial reckonings, the pandemic) as material but has a more seasoned perspective than that of novels written in their immediate wake. The gestation of this book seems to have served it well in that respect, giving it a wisdom—worn lightly and with humor—on the promise and reality of historic inflection points and how a tightly knit group might respond to them differently."

—Vogue

title: Shirley Jackson
subtitle: A Rather Haunted Life
long_summary:
Despite creating one of America's most famous short stories, Shirley Jackson remained oddly marginalized in literary circles for decades after her death. Ruth Franklin's biography corrects this oversight by positioning Jackson as a master of psychological terror who captured the anxieties of 1950s America with unmatched precision.

Franklin traces Jackson's development of what she terms "domestic horror" – fiction that found menace in everyday family life and suburban conformity. Long before feminism became a movement, Jackson's work exposed the suffocating realities many women faced behind closed doors. Her stories transformed ordinary households into spaces of dread and revelation.

The biography also examines the contradictions that defined Jackson's own existence. While crafting tales of isolation and madness, she maintained a public life as a faculty wife and mother in a Vermont college town. Yet this seemingly conventional existence masked growing personal turmoil – a deteriorating marriage, escalating mental health struggles, and increasing dependence on prescription drugs.

Drawing on newly available letters and extensive interviews, Franklin constructs a nuanced portrait that honors both Jackson's literary achievements and her complex humanity. The result positions Jackson not as a curiosity but as an essential voice in American fiction.
short_summary: Ruth Franklin's masterful biography rescues Shirley Jackson from literary obscurity, revealing how the author of The Lottery and The Haunting of Hill House pioneered domestic horror while navigating the contradictions of mid-century American womanhood.
author_bios: Ruth Franklin has written extensively about literature and culture, including A Thousand Darknesses: Lies and Truth in Holocaust Fiction, which received recognition as a finalist for the Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature. Her biographical work Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life earned the National Book Critics Circle Award for Biography. Franklin makes her home in Brooklyn, NY.
quotes:
"With this welcome new biography Franklin makes a thoughtful and persuasive case for Jackson as a serious and accomplished literary artist. . . . [Franklin] sees Jackson not as an oddball, one-off writer of horror tales and ghost stories but as someone belonging to the great tradition of Hawthorne, Poe and James, writers preoccupied, as she was, with inner evil in the human soul."

—Charles McGrath, The New York Times

"Ruth Franklin's sympathetic and masterful biography both uncovers Jackson's secret and haunting life and repositions her as a major artist whose fiction so uncannily channeled women's nightmares and contradictions that it is 'nothing less than the secret history of American women of her era.'"

—Elaine Showalter, The Washington Post

"This meticulous biography tackles the work of Shirley Jackson with the kind of studied seriousness some might give to a male titan of history like Robert Moses. And thank goddess for that, as Ruth Franklin wisely rescues Shirley Jackson from any semblance of obscurity. Despite her well-documented magnetism (and dalliances in the dark arts) Jackson's work was often dismissed as mere genre nonsense or, worse yet, women's fiction and Franklin's sensitive, witty and rigorous work makes an airtight case for just why this isn't right. The ire Jackson's short stories inspired in New Yorker readers is only a hint of the drama and intensity that characterized her short but beguiling life, with Franklin captures with a hefty dose of wit and suspense. One of the best literary biographies I've ever encountered."

—Lena Dunham

title: Unbroken
subtitle: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption
long_summary:
Louis Zamperini's transformation from troubled youth to Olympic athlete seems like triumph enough for one lifetime. But his most defining chapter begins when his bomber plunges into the Pacific during World War II, leaving him adrift on a tiny raft with nothing but ocean stretching endlessly in every direction.

What follows tests every boundary of human endurance. Zamperini faces weeks of exposure, starvation, and predators circling beneath his failing craft. Yet surviving the ocean proves to be only the beginning of his ordeal. The same rebellious spirit that once got him into trouble as a boy, then propelled him toward Olympic glory, now becomes his lifeline against impossible odds.

Hillenbrand chronicles this remarkable journey with meticulous attention to both historical detail and the psychological landscape of survival. She reveals how ordinary people discover extraordinary reserves of courage, creativity, and stubborn hope when pushed beyond what seems humanly possible. This is biography as adventure story, a meditation on the mysterious alchemy that allows some individuals to endure what would break others completely.
short_summary: The epic true story of Louis Zamperini—Olympic runner turned bombardier—whose extraordinary will to survive became the stuff of legend. Hillenbrand transforms wartime heroism into unforgettable storytelling.
author_bios: Laura Hillenbrand wrote the #1 New York Times bestseller Seabiscuit: An American Legend, which became a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist, won the Book Sense Book of the Year Award, and inspired an Academy Award-nominated film. Her New Yorker piece "A Sudden Illness" earned the 2004 National Magazine Award, and she has received two Eclipse Awards. Hillenbrand co-founded Operation International Children with actor Gary Sinise and makes her home in Washington, D.C.
quotes:
"Hillenbrand has once again brought to life the true story of a forgotten hero, and reminded us how lucky we are to have her, one of our best writers of narrative history. You don't have to be a sports fan or a war-history buff to devour this book—you just have to love great storytelling."

—Rebecca Skloot, author of The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks

"Moving and, yes, inspirational . . . [Laura] Hillenbrand's unforgettable book . . . deserve[s] pride of place alongside the best works of literature that chart the complications and the hard-won triumphs of so-called ordinary Americans and their extraordinary time."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"A meticulous, soaring and beautifully written account of an extraordinary life."

—The Washington Post

title: Matrix
long_summary:
Marie de France arrives at a crumbling English abbey as a teenager, banished from royal court life and thrust into leadership of a community on the brink of collapse. The nuns face starvation and disease, their institution forgotten by a world that has little use for women who don't conform to expected roles.

What begins as exile becomes transformation. Marie finds herself drawn to the radical possibilities of collective female power, her mystical visions guiding her toward an unprecedented reimagining of religious life. Drawing on the warrior blood that runs through her veins, she begins to forge something entirely new—a sanctuary where women might live and create on their own terms.

Groff constructs a world where spiritual ecstasy and earthly desire intertwine, where the boundaries between the holy and the human blur beyond recognition. Marie's story becomes a meditation on what happens when visionary leadership meets institutional resistance, and whether one woman's revolutionary dreams can survive in a world determined to crush female autonomy. The novel pulses with questions about creativity, community, and the price of refusing to accept the limitations others would impose.
short_summary: Exiled from Eleanor of Aquitaine's court, teenage Marie de France transforms a dying abbey into a radical sanctuary. Groff crafts a mesmerizing tale of mysticism, ambition, and women reshaping their world.
author_bios: Lauren Groff has earned three National Book Award nominations and written multiple bestselling works, including The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus the story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. Her accolades include The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Groff's fiction regularly appears in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, with translations available in thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband operate the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"A radiant novel about the 12th-century poet and mystic Marie de France. . . Groff richly imagines Marie's decades of exile in a royal convent, which she eventually leads. A charged novel about female ambition."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR's Fresh Air

"An audacious piece of storytelling, full of passion, wisdom and magic."

—Sarah Waters, New York Times bestselling author of The Paying Guests
