"A thrillingly vivid, adventurous story about women and power that will blow readers' minds. Left me gasping."

—Emma Donoghue, author of Room

title: Wild
subtitle: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
long_summary:
Loss has a way of stripping life down to its bare essentials, and for Cheryl Strayed, that meant confronting an impossible question: how do you rebuild when everything familiar has disappeared? Her answer defied all logic—tackle over a thousand miles of wilderness trail with zero hiking experience and a pack so heavy she could barely lift it.

The Pacific Crest Trail becomes both adversary and teacher as Strayed navigates far more than just difficult terrain. Between encounters with wildlife, equipment failures, and the relentless physical demands of the journey, she grapples with grief, guilt, and the messy aftermath of a life derailed. What emerges is neither a simple tale of triumph nor a neat resolution to pain, but something more honest—a reckoning with what it means to choose forward motion when standing still feels safer.

Strayed's voice carries the reader through moments of genuine danger and unexpected grace with equal measure, finding humor in disaster and wisdom in stubbornness. This isn't about conquering mountains or discovering some hidden version of yourself; it's about the ordinary miracle of putting one foot in front of the other when that's the only option left.
short_summary: Following her mother's death and the collapse of her marriage, Cheryl Strayed embarks on an eleven-hundred-mile solo hike along the Pacific Crest Trail. A blazingly honest memoir about breaking down and building back up again.
author_bios: Cheryl Strayed wrote the number-one New York Times bestseller Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail, which has reached more than four million readers worldwide and became an Oscar-nominated film. Her other works include the novel Torch, the collection Brave Enough, and Tiny Beautiful Things, which was adapted for both stage and a Hulu series. Strayed has also hosted the podcasts Sugar Calling and Dear Sugars. She makes her home in Portland, Oregon.
quotes:
"A rich, riveting true story . . . During her grueling three-month journey, Strayed circled around black bears and rattlesnakes, fought extreme dehydration by drinking oily gray pond water, and hiked in boots made entirely of duct tape.  Reading her matter-of-fact take on love and grief and the soul-saving quality of a Snapple lemonade, you can understand why Strayed has earned a cult following as the author of Dear Sugar, a popular advice column on therumpus.net. . . . With its vivid descriptions of beautiful but unforgiving terrain, Wild is a cinematic story, but Strayed's book isn't really about big, cathartic moments. The author never 'finds herself' or gets healed. When she reaches the trail's end, she buys a cheap ice cream cone and continues down the road. . . . It's hard to imagine anything more important than taking one step at a time. That's endurance, and that's what Strayed understands, almost 20 years later. As she writes, 'There was only one [option], I knew. To keep walking."

—Melissa Maerz, Entertainment Weekly

"In the summer of 1995, at age 26 and feeling at the end of her rope emotionally, Strayed resolved to hike solo the Pacific Crest Trail . . . In this detailed, in-the-moment re-enactment, she delineates the travails and triumphs of those three grueling months. Living in Minneapolis, on the verge of divorcing her husband, Strayed was still reeling from the sudden death four years before of her mother; the ensuing years formed an erratic, confused time 'like a crackling Fourth of July sparkler.' Hiking the trail helped decide what direction her life would take, even though she had never seriously hiked or carried a pack before. . . . Eventually she began to experience 'a kind of strange, abstract, retrospective fun,' meeting the few other hikers along the way, all male; jettisoning some of the weight from her pack and burning books she had read; and encountering all manner of creature and acts of nature, from rock slides to snow. Her account forms a charming, intrepid trial by fire, as she emerges from the ordeal bruised but not beaten, changed, a lone survivor."

—Publishers Weekly

"Unsentimental memoir of the author's solo hike from California to Washington along the Pacific Crest Trail. Following the death of her mother, Strayed's life quickly disintegrated. . . . While waiting in line at an outdoors store, [she] read the back cover of a book about the Pacific Crest Trail. Initially, the idea of hiking the trail became a vague apparition, then a goal. Woefully underprepared for the wilderness, out of shape and carrying a ridiculously overweight pack, the author set out from the small California town of Mojave, toward a bridge ('the Bridge of the Gods') crossing the Columbia River at the Oregon-Washington border. Strayed's writing admirably conveys the rigors and rewards of long-distance hiking. Along the way she suffered aches, pains, loneliness, blistered, bloody feet and persistent hunger. Yet the author also discovered a newfound sense of awe . . . stunned by how the trail both shattered and sheltered her. Most of the hikers she met along the way were helpful, and she also encountered instances of trail magic . . . A candid, inspiring narrative of the author's brutal physical and psychological journey through a wilderness of despair to a renewed sense of self."

—Kirkus

title: Station Eleven
long_summary:
In the aftermath of a devastating pandemic that has reduced civilization to scattered settlements, art becomes both refuge and rebellion. Kirsten travels with a small company of performers who carry Shakespeare and classical music between the isolated communities that dot the transformed landscape around the Great Lakes.

Their mission takes a dangerous turn in St. Deborah by the Water, where a charismatic leader rules through fear and violence, threatening anyone who questions his authority. Through interconnected stories that weave between the world before the collapse and the strange new reality that emerged from it, the novel examines how human connections endure even as everything familiar disappears.

This is a meditation on what we choose to preserve when everything else falls away, and how beauty and meaning persist in the most unlikely circumstances. The narrative moves fluidly through time, revealing how seemingly random encounters and relationships create invisible threads that bind lives together across decades.
short_summary: After a flu pandemic collapses civilization, a troupe of actors and musicians travels the Great Lakes, preserving art in the ruins. Haunting and luminous, this is survival fiction with uncommon grace.
author_bios: Emily St. John Mandel has written five novels, including Station Eleven and The Glass Hotel. Station Eleven received nominations for both the National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, and has found readers in thirty-five languages through translation. She makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"A novel that carries a magnificent depth . . . We get to see something that is so difficult to show or feel – how small moments in time link together. And how these moments add up to a life . . . Her best yet. It feels as though she took the experience earned from her previous writing and braided it together to make one gleaming strand . . . An epic book."

—Claire Cameron, The Globe and Mail

"Deeply melancholy, but beautifully written, and wonderfully elegiac . . . A book that I will long remember, and return to."

—George R. R. Martin

"Station Eleven is so compelling, so fearlessly imagined, that I wouldn't have put it down for anything."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonweath & State of Wonder

title: Strangers to Ourselves
subtitle: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us
long_summary:
The language of psychiatry promises clarity, but what about the experiences that resist easy categorization? Through intimate portraits and meticulous research, this investigation reveals the gaps between clinical frameworks and lived reality.

The narrative weaves together disparate lives: a revered healer in Indian temples whose visions challenge Western medical assumptions, a mother rebuilding relationships after emerging from psychosis, a man waging war against the analysts who failed him, and a young woman questioning whether her diagnosis has become her cage. Each story illuminates how psychiatric labels can both illuminate and obscure the complexity of human experience.

At the book's heart lies the author's own reckoning with childhood hospitalization and a friendship formed in a psychiatric ward—two parallel trajectories that ultimately diverge in devastating ways. This personal thread anchors broader questions about how diagnostic categories shape not just treatment, but identity itself. The result is an unflinching examination of medicine's reach and its limitations, revealing the stubborn mystery that remains at the core of consciousness and suffering.
short_summary: What happens when psychiatric explanations fail to capture who we really are? Aviv follows people who've hit the limits of how we understand mental illness, weaving their stories with her own powerful personal account.
author_bios: Rachel Aviv writes for The New Yorker as a staff writer, focusing on medicine, education, and criminal justice. Her profile writing earned her a 2022 National Magazine Award, and she received a Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for this book. New America named her a 2019 national fellow. She makes her home in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"In this penetrating, landmark book, Rachel Aviv investigates what she calls the 'psychic hinterlands,' drawing on her customary vivid reporting and her own extraordinary personal story to pose unsettling questions about the ways in which we reckon with mental illness by categorizing it, diagnosing it, giving it a name. Threading together the intimate and emotionally shattering stories of a series of very different people who have struggled to live with and to understand their own psychological afflictions, Aviv has created an arresting work of profound empathy and insight."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, author of Say Nothing and Empire of Pain

"Intimate and revelatory . . . attuned to subtlety and complexity . . . This isn't an anti-psychiatry book- Aviv is too aware of the specifics of any situation to succumb to anything so sweeping and polemical . . . a book-length demonstration of Aviv's extraordinary ability to hold space for the 'uncertainty, mysteries and doubts' of others."

—Jennifer Szalai, New York Times

"Aviv writes with an unpredictable mixture of intimacy and distance, exploring how psychiatric language often alters what it names. She has assembled a remarkable archive of unpublished materials-memoirs, poems, journals (including her own)-that offers a visceral counterpoint to the official languages of institutions and expertise. I admire her rigor and eloquence but also her restraint-she makes vivid experiences we can't explain."

—Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School

title: Playground
long_summary:
The Pacific Ocean becomes the stage for an extraordinary convergence of destinies in Richard Powers' latest work. A young girl discovers underwater worlds through pioneering diving equipment in Montreal's pools. An artist searches for belonging while moving between military installations. Two Chicago students forge an unlikely friendship through strategy games—one finding refuge in books, the other pushing the boundaries of artificial intelligence.

Their separate journeys lead to Makatea, a small island in French Polynesia bearing the scars of its colonial past. This remote atoll, once stripped of its phosphorus to nourish distant farmlands, now stands at a crossroads. A revolutionary proposal threatens to transform it into the foundation for humanity's boldest experiment: self-governing cities that float upon the ocean's surface.

The island's residents face an impossible choice that will determine their future and potentially reshape how humans inhabit the planet. Powers crafts a meditation on progress and preservation, examining how technology intersects with our deepest need for connection and belonging in a world balanced on the edge of transformation.
short_summary: Four interconnected lives converge on a remote Pacific atoll where residents must decide whether to host humanity's next frontier: floating cities on the open sea. Powers weaves technology, environment, and human connection into something transcendent.
author_bios: Richard Powers has written fourteen novels, among them The Overstory, Bewilderment, and Orfeo. His work has earned him the MacArthur Fellowship, the Pulitzer Prize, and the National Book Award. Powers makes his home in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.
quotes:
"Prepare to be awed… A mind-blowing reflection on what it means to live on a dying planet… I wasn't prepared for the astonishing resolution that Powers delivers. In the now-vast library of fiction and nonfiction books reminding us of the planet's imperiled condition, I can't think of another novel that treats the Earth's plight with such an expansive and disorienting vision… Powers manages to entwine our longing for friendship, paradise and immortality with the algorithms of artificial intelligence that surpass all understanding."

—Ron Charles, Washington Post

"An extraordinarily immersive journey through lives linked in mysterious ways—gripping, alarming, and uplifting."

—Emma Donoghue, author of Room

"Powers is a master of taking important topics of our times—from threats to our oceans and climate change to AI—and turning them into riveting and fiercely relevant books imbued with psychological insight and a deep awe for nature. This eloquent dance of the scientific and emotional makes him one of our finest storytellers. Playground is brilliant, captivating, and important—and the best book I've read this year."

—Andrea Wulf

title: Frederick Douglass
subtitle: Prophet of Freedom
long_summary:
Frederick Douglass stands as perhaps the most extraordinary figure in American letters—a man who transformed himself from enslaved property into the nation's most commanding voice for freedom. This comprehensive biography illuminates how Douglass wielded his remarkable intellect and oratory skills to demolish the very foundations of slavery, becoming both America's harshest critic and its most devoted believer in democratic ideals.

Blight reveals the intricate layers of Douglass's character: the brilliant strategist who understood that his own story could serve as irrefutable evidence of Black intellectual capacity, the complex family man navigating two marriages, and the aging leader who sometimes clashed with a new generation of civil rights activists. Drawing from newly available letters and Douglass's own newspaper archives, this portrait captures both the towering public intellectual and the private individual wrestling with fame, family, and an evolving America.

More than a traditional biography, this work demonstrates how one person's relentless pursuit of literacy and justice reshaped a nation's conscience, offering fresh insights into the man whose life embodied both the promise and contradictions of American democracy.
short_summary: The definitive biography of Frederick Douglass, who escaped slavery to become America's greatest 19th-century orator and a towering abolitionist. Blight masterfully captures both the public figure and the deeply human man behind the legend.
author_bios: David W. Blight serves as Sterling Professor of History at Yale University, where he also directs the Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition. His extensive scholarship includes over a dozen publications, among them Race and Reunion: The Civil War in American Memory and American Oracle: The Civil War in the Civil Rights Era, along with annotated editions of Frederick Douglass's early autobiographies. Blight's distinguished research has garnered major recognition, including the Bancroft Prize, Abraham Lincoln Prize, and Frederick Douglass Prize.
quotes:
"The first major biography of Douglass in nearly three decades. . . . Blight isn't looking to overturn our understanding of Douglass, whose courage and achievements were unequivocal, but to complicate it — a measure by which this ambitious and empathetic biography resoundingly succeeds."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Extraordinary. . . . In Blight's pages, [Douglass's] voice again rings out loud and clear, melancholy and triumphant — still prophesying, still agitating, still calling us to action."

—Adam Goodheart, The Washington Post

"Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom is a triumph—elegantly written, with much new material about one of the most famous and important men in modern history. David Blight has created a vibrant and convincing portrait of a towering figure who was also, Blight says, 'thoroughly and beautifully human.' A great American gets the stellar biography he deserves from one our country's greatest historians."

—Annette Gordon-Reed, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family & On Juneteenth

title: Young Mungo
long_summary:
In 1990s Glasgow, two teenage boys discover each other across the bitter religious divide that splits their neighborhood. Mungo finds himself drawn to James, whose devotion to his racing pigeons offers a rare glimpse of beauty in their harsh surroundings. Their connection deepens into something neither fully understands but both desperately need.

Their stolen moments together become a refuge from the violence that marks their daily lives. But secrets have consequences in a place where difference can mean danger. The story moves between Mungo's present crisis—trapped on an isolated fishing expedition with men whose intentions grow increasingly unclear—and the events that led him there.

Stuart crafts an intimate examination of first love shadowed by the weight of family loyalty, religious hatred, and economic desperation. The novel asks whether tenderness can survive in a world built on division, and what price young people pay for the chance to become themselves.
short_summary: Two boys from opposite sides of Glasgow's sectarian divide fall in love amid violence and poverty. Stuart's tender, brutal follow-up to Shuggie Bain explores queer love in a world determined to destroy it.
author_bios: Douglas Stuart grew up in Glasgow and now lives in New York. His first novel, Shuggie Bain, earned him the 2020 Booker Prize and the Sue Kaufman Prize, while also receiving nominations for the National Book Award and PEN/Hemingway Award. Young Mungo became a national bestseller and was shortlisted for the British Book Award. Stuart's writing has been featured in the New Yorker and Literary Hub.
quotes:
"Page-turning, beautifully written . . . In a narrative that weaves seamlessly back and forth between the camping trip and Mungo's life before the trip, Stuart creates a world we can almost feel."

—Deborah Dundas, Toronto Star

"The Sighthill tenement where Shuggie Bain, Stuart's Booker Prize–winning debut, unfurled is glimpsed in his follow-up, set in the 1990s in an adjacent neighborhood. You wouldn't think you'd be eager to return to these harsh, impoverished environs, but again this author creates characters so vivid, dilemmas so heart-rending, and dialogue so brilliant that the whole thing sucks you in like a vacuum cleaner . . . Romantic, terrifying, brutal, tender, and, in the end, sneakily hopeful. What a writer."

—Kirkus

"The astonishing sophomore effort from Booker Prize winner Stuart details a teen's hard life in north Glasgow in the post-Thatcher years . . . Stuart's writing is stellar . . . He's too fine a storyteller to go for a sentimental ending, and the final act leaves the reader gutted. This is unbearably sad, more so because the reader comes to cherish the characters their creator has brought to life. It's a sucker punch to the heart."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Water Mirror Echo
subtitle: Bruce Lee and the Making of Asian America
long_summary:
Bruce Lee died at thirty-two, but his cultural impact continues to reverberate decades later. Beyond the martial arts legend and Hollywood aspirations lies a more complex figure: a child of two worlds who navigated identity in ways that would reshape American culture itself.

This biography strips away the mythmaking to examine Lee's actual journey—from his birth in a racially divided San Francisco to his formative years in Hong Kong during wartime, and finally his return to an America undergoing profound social change. Chang traces how Lee's unique position allowed him to challenge existing boundaries and help establish new possibilities for Asian American identity.

Drawing on previously unavailable personal materials, family photographs, and conversations with those who knew Lee intimately, Chang constructs a portrait that balances the individual with the historical moment. The book argues that Lee's significance extends beyond entertainment—his visibility and cultural bridging helped catalyze the emergence of Asian America as a concept and community. Rather than simply celebrating an icon, this work examines how one person's navigation of cultural complexity can create lasting change.
short_summary: Jeff Chang excavates the man behind the Bruce Lee mythology, revealing how a curious kid from segregated San Francisco became both global icon and catalyst for Asian America. Intimate, sweeping, and essential cultural biography.
author_bios: Jeff Chang wrote Can't Stop Won't Stop: A History of the Hip-Hop Generation, recognized as among the finest American nonfiction works of the past twenty-five years. Chang has received the American Book Award and Asian American Literary Award, and holds a USA Ford Fellowship in Literature. His portfolio includes three additional bestselling books examining American history, culture, and arts. Chang co-created a PBS digital adaptation of We Gon' Be Alright and his work has appeared in ESPN's Be Water, PBS's Asian Americans, and CNN's This Is Life.
quotes:
"Water Mirror Echo is a remarkable story of a man, the traditions and communities that created him, and the new worlds he made possible. Like Bruce Lee himself, Jeff Chang is blessed with the vision to see things we do not yet see, thinking and writing with a restless, chasm-crossing, almost prophetic ambition."

—Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Stay True: A Memoir

"[A] panoramic biography.... Peppering the narrative with rich historical details and poignant analyses, Chang persuasively argues that Lee's presence on screen helped shape the idea of what it means to be Asian in America. This definitive account cements Chang as a preeminent chronicler of Asian American history."

—Publishers Weekly

"This book is as celebratory as it is incisive, as it is, at times, heartbreaking. A massive achievement."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, National Book Award-winning author of There's Always This Year and A Little Devil in America

title: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous
long_summary:
Little Dog sits down to compose an intimate correspondence to the woman who raised him—his mother, who never learned to read. Through this deeply personal act of storytelling, he navigates the complexities of their shared Vietnamese heritage and the American landscape they've inherited together.

The narrative moves between memory and revelation, examining the intricate bonds that connect mothers and sons across cultural divides. Little Dog confronts difficult truths about identity, belonging, and the weight of generational trauma while celebrating the fierce love that has sustained his family.

Vuong crafts a meditation on language itself—its power to bridge impossible distances and its failure to capture certain truths. The novel interrogates what it means to claim your own voice in a world that often refuses to listen, transforming silence into song and pain into profound understanding. This is storytelling as both refuge and reckoning, where the act of bearing witness becomes a form of salvation.
short_summary: A son writes to his illiterate mother, excavating family history and first love. Vuong's epistolary debut transforms trauma into something approaching grace through the sheer power of storytelling.
author_bios: Ocean Vuong has published the poetry collections Night Sky with Exit Wounds and Time Is a Mother, along with the New York Times bestselling novel On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. Born in Saigon, Vietnam, Ocean Vuong received both a MacArthur Fellowship and American Book Award for his literary work. He divides his time between western Massachusetts and New York City.
quotes:
"A bruised, breathtaking love letter never meant to be sent. A powerful testimony to magic and loss. A marvel."

—Marlon James, author of A Brief History of Seven Killings & Black Leopard, Red Wolf

"This is one of the best novels I've ever read. I always want my favorite poets to write novels and here it's happened. Ocean Vuong is a master. This book a masterpiece. On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous is an ode to loss and struggle, to being a Vietnamese American, to Hartford, Connecticut, and it's a compassionate epistolary ode to a mother who may or may not know how to read. I dog-eared so many pages the book almost collapsed—I almost did."

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars & There There

"Ocean Vuong runs up against the limits of language—this book is addressed to a mother who cannot read it—and expands our sense of what literature can make visible, thinkable, felt across borders and generations and genres. This is a courageous, embodied inquiry into the tangle of colonial and personal histories. It is also a gorgeous argument for astonishment over irony—for the transformative possibilities of love."

—Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School, Leaving the Atocha Station & 10:04

title: Invisible Child
subtitle: Poverty, Survival & Hope in an American City
long_summary:
Dasani's world exists in the shadows of Manhattan's gleaming towers, where homelessness and wealth collide in stark contradiction. Through meticulous reporting spanning nearly a decade, this book reveals how one extraordinary girl navigates systems designed to fail her—from overcrowded shelters to underfunded schools.

The narrative traces connections across generations, linking Dasani's struggles to her family's deeper history of displacement and survival. As she shoulders responsibilities far beyond her years, protecting younger siblings while pursuing her own dreams, Dasani embodies both the failures of American social policy and the unbreakable bonds of family loyalty.

The story reaches a crossroads when opportunity arrives in the form of an elite boarding school—but success demands sacrifices that threaten to sever the very relationships that define her. This tension between individual advancement and collective survival illuminates broader questions about mobility, identity, and the price of escaping poverty in America.
short_summary: Eight years in the life of Dasani, a homeless girl navigating New York's brutal inequalities. Elliott's extraordinary reporting transforms systemic injustice into an intimate, unforgettable portrait of resilience and family.
author_bios: Andrea Elliott works as an investigative reporter at The New York Times, where her journalism has garnered numerous prestigious honors including two Pulitzer Prizes, a George Polk Award, the J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize, and an Overseas Press Club award. She has held fellowships at New America and the Russell Sage Foundation, and Columbia University recognized her work with the Medal for Excellence in 2015. Elliott holds the distinction of being the first woman to receive individual Pulitzer Prizes in both Journalism and Arts & Letters. Invisible Child marks her debut as a book author.
quotes:
"From its first indelible pages to its rich and startling conclusion, Invisible Child had me, by turns, stricken, inspired, outraged, illuminated, in tears, and hungering for reimmersion in its Dickensian depths. This book is so many things: a staggering feat of reporting, an act of profound civic love, an extraordinarily moving tale about the fierceness of family love, and above all, a future American classic."

—Ayad Akhtar, author of Homeland Elegies

"A vivid and devastating story of American inequality."

—The New York Times

"A classic to rank with Orwell."

—The Sunday Times

title: Once Upon a River
long_summary:
Margo Crane possesses two defining traits: deadly accuracy with a rifle and an unwavering ability to see people for who they truly are. At sixteen, these skills become essential for survival as she navigates Michigan's waterways in search of her disappeared mother, carrying little more than a boat, basic supplies, and a book about sharpshooter Annie Oakley.

The rivers that once offered childhood refuge now present constant threats to a young woman alone. Campbell examines how violence shapes identity and tests the boundaries between victim and survivor. As Margo encounters the complex characters inhabiting rural Michigan's margins, she must decide which parts of herself to preserve and which to sacrifice.

This coming-of-age story interrogates the true cost of independence and the weight of family legacy. Margo's journey becomes less about finding her mother and more about discovering what kind of person she's willing to become in a world that offers few safe harbors.
short_summary: After her father's violent death, sixteen-year-old Margo Crane takes to Michigan's waterways searching for her missing mother. Campbell crafts a fierce coming-of-age tale about survival, identity, and the dangerous currents of both rivers and human nature.
author_bios: Bonnie Jo Campbell has written six fiction works, including the national bestseller Once Upon a River and American Salvage, which earned finalist recognition for both the National Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award. Her achievements include receiving a Guggenheim Fellowship, the AWP Grace Paley Prize for Short Fiction, and a Pushcart Prize. Campbell makes her home near Kalamazoo, Michigan, where she lives with her husband and donkeys.
quotes:
"Campbell is a bard, a full-throated singer whose melodies are odes to farms and water and livestock and fishing rods and rifles, and to hardworking folks who know the value of life as well as the randomness of life's troubles."

—Lisa Schwarzbaum, Entertainment Weekly

"...the book is a violent but inspiring tale packed with colorful river dwellers, a working-class community of power company and metal workers, farmers, hunters and housewives....Campbell has created a character with an iron gut and a heart to match, recalling powerful heroines like Clara of Joyce Carol Oates' A Garden of Earthly Delights and Ree of Daniel Woodrell's Winter's Bone."

—Liz Colville, NPR

"Mark Twain owns America's rivers, and writers who venture out on those waters are obliged to acknowledge his dominion. Bonnie Jo Campbell's tough and confident Once Upon a River, about a runaway teenager on Michigan's waterways, pays due homage to the bard of the Mississippi, but the novel also tells its own captivating story"

—Sam Sacks, Wall Street Journal

title: Some People Need Killing
subtitle: A Memoir of Murder in My Country
long_summary:
In the Philippines, thousands died during a government-sanctioned campaign against drug users and dealers. Patricia Evangelista spent six years inside this violence, interviewing those who killed and those who survived, building a meticulous record of how a democracy can transform into something unrecognizable.

The title comes from a killer's own justification—words that reveal how ordinary people rationalize extraordinary brutality. Evangelista examines the machinery of state violence and the psychology that enables it, showing how quickly the value of human life can be redefined by those in power.

This is journalism as literature, combining rigorous reporting with deeply personal reflection. Evangelista doesn't just document what happened; she interrogates why societies accept such violence and how individuals navigate moral collapse. Her work stands as both historical record and urgent warning about the fragility of human rights when authoritarianism takes root.
short_summary: Six years documenting Duterte's drug war killings becomes a searing investigation into state-sanctioned violence. Evangelista weaves unflinching reportage with personal narrative in this essential work of witness.
author_bios: Patricia Evangelista works as a trauma journalist and previously reported for Rappler as an investigative journalist. She received the Kate Webb Prize for outstanding journalism under dangerous circumstances. Evangelista has held residencies and fellowships with the Headlands Artist program, New America ASU Future Security initiative, Logan Nonfiction Program, Civitella Ranieri Foundation, and Dart Center for Journalism and Trauma. She makes her home in Manila.
quotes:
"In this blindingly ambitious, unfathomably brave, fiercely reported book, Patricia Evangelista exposes the evil in her country with perfect clarity fueled by profound rage, her narrative voice at once utterly brutal and terrifyingly vulnerable. You may think you are inured to shock, but this book is an exploding bomb that will damage you anew, making you wiser as it does so."

—Andrew Solomon, National Book Award–winning author of Far From The Tree, The Noonday Demon and Far and Away: How Travel Can Change the World

"In this haunting work of memoir and reportage, Patricia Evangelista both describes the origins of autocratic rule in the Philippines, and explains its universal significance. The cynicism of voters, the opportunism of Filipino politicians, the appeal of brutality and violence to both groups—all of this will be familiar to readers, wherever they are from."

—Anne Applebaum, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Iron Curtain, Twilight of Democracy: The Seductive Lure of Authoritarianism

"A landmark work of investigative reporting by a writer of formidable courage. Patricia Evangelista's searing account is not only the definitive chronicle of a reign of terror in the Philippines, but a warning to the rest of the world about the true dangers of despotism—its nightmarish consequences and its terrible human cost."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, New York Times bestselling author of Empire of Pain & Do Not Say We Have Nothing

title: Second Place
long_summary:
An artist's retreat becomes a psychological battleground in this incisive examination of creativity, gender, and power. The protagonist extends an invitation to a renowned painter, hoping his artistic eye might illuminate truths about her existence in an isolated coastal sanctuary. Yet his arrival transforms her sanctuary into a stage for uncomfortable revelations.

The resulting tension exposes the fault lines between artistic ambition and domestic reality, between the stories we tell ourselves and the lives we actually inhabit. Through this charged encounter, fundamental questions emerge about who holds authority in relationships and whether art can truly bridge the gap between our inner desires and outer circumstances. The novel dissects the ways we seek validation through others while revealing the costs of such dependencies.
short_summary: When a woman invites a celebrated artist to her remote coastal home, his arrival disrupts everything she thought she knew about art, power, and herself.
author_bios: Rachel Cusk has written Second Place, the Outline trilogy, and the memoirs A Life's Work and Aftermath, along with numerous other fiction and nonfiction works. A Guggenheim Fellow, she currently makes her home in Paris.
quotes:
"Cusk is at her best when she works in diversions, as she does with the deceptive simplicity of Second Place. The novel is skillfully meandering, offering consistent flashes of insight while traversing a great deal of intellectual terrain. The drama is tight and the action straightforward, but when it comes to the beguiling complexity of human nature, the wisdom offered here is significant."

—Quill & Quire

"Cusk, as always, is brilliant at the subtleties of human dynamics, which here are as ever-changing as the landscape against which they're set."

—Toronto Star

"Cusk is as brilliant as ever at revealing the tumult that occurs when people with varying strengths of personal will come into close contact with each other. Second Place is the kind of book that requires re-reading, but also rewards it."

—Globe and Mail

title: On Juneteenth
long_summary:
The declaration of freedom that reached Texas on June 19, 1865, marks more than just a date—it represents the complex intersection of personal identity, regional mythology, and national reckoning. Through the lens of Juneteenth, this work dismantles the familiar narratives of Texas exceptionalism to reveal how enslaved people and their descendants shaped the state's trajectory from its earliest days.

Rather than accepting the romanticized tales of cowboys and oil wealth, the author traces her own family's presence in Texas back to the 1820s, using their story to illuminate broader patterns of resistance, survival, and contribution that have been systematically erased from popular memory. The analysis moves beyond the Alamo mythology to demonstrate how the economics of human bondage drove not only Texas independence but also sparked wider conflicts that would ultimately tear the nation apart.

This examination arrives at a moment when America has finally recognized June 19th as a federal holiday, yet the work serves as both celebration and warning. The historical record reveals that the announcement of emancipation was only the beginning of a longer struggle, one that continued through Reconstruction's failures and Jim Crow's codified oppression, extending into our contemporary moment where true equality remains elusive.
short_summary: Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Annette Gordon-Reed interweaves personal memoir with rigorous scholarship to reveal how Juneteenth illuminates the deeper truths of American history. Essential reading that reframes our understanding of Texas and the nation.
author_bios: Annette Gordon-Reed holds the position of Carl M. Loeb University Professor at Harvard University. Her scholarship earned her the Pulitzer Prize for The Hemingses of Monticello, and she divides her time between New York and Cambridge, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"The Pulitzer Prize-winning historian interweaves her personal, trailblazing history with that of her home state to pierce many of the false narratives we learned as children about the country's treatment of African Americans.... Gordon-Reed offers a timely history lesson. She does so with beautiful prose, breathtaking stories and painful memories.... Gordon-Reed's literary gift is the ability to research and write about subjects with broadly accepted stories in a convincing way that allows readers to consider other perspectives."

—Daina Ramey Berry, The Washington Post

"Pulitzer-winner Gordon-Reed (The Hemingses of Monticello) interweaves history, politics, and memoir in these immersive and well-informed essays reflecting on the history of Juneteenth.... Despite the thorny racial history, Gordon-Reed expresses a deep fondness for her native state, writing that 'love does not require taking an uncritical stance toward the object of one's affections.' This brisk history lesson entertains and enlightens."

—Publishers Weekly

"A concise personal and scholarly history that avoids academic jargon as it illuminates emotional truths."

—Kirkus

title: The Rabbit Hutch
long_summary:
Four young adults find themselves thrown together in subsidized housing after surviving Indiana's foster care system. Among them is Blandine, whose sharp intellect and otherworldly beauty set her apart from her three male roommates in ways that create tension and distance.

Their apartment building buzzes with other struggling lives: someone who makes a living writing death notices online, a mother concealing dangerous truths, and a woman locked in solitary battle against an infestation. The crumbling complex sits in Vacca Vale, a former manufacturing hub now gasping through economic collapse.

As July's oppressive heat bears down, the residents' intersecting stories accelerate toward an shocking moment of brutality that will reshape everything. Through this microcosm of forgotten America, the novel examines how people search for connection and purpose amid isolation and decay, revealing both the cruelty and unexpected grace that emerge when dreams collide with harsh realities.
short_summary: Four foster care survivors share an apartment in a crumbling Indiana city, orbiting toward one incandescent night of violence and revelation. Gunty's choral debut captures post-industrial loneliness with devastating wit and unexpected tenderness.
author_bios: Tess Gunty completed her MFA at NYU as a Lillian Vernon Fellow. Her fiction and essays have appeared in publications including The Iowa Review, Joyland, and Los Angeles Review of Books. Originally from South Bend, Indiana, she currently makes her home in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"The Rabbit Hutch aches, bleeds, and even scars but it also forgives with laughter, with insight, and finally, through an act of generational independence that remains this novel's greatest accomplishment, with an act of rescue, rescue of narrative, rescue from ritual, rescue of heart, the rescue of tomorrow."

—Mark Z. Danielewski, author of House of Leaves

"An astonishing portrait . . . Gunty delves into the stories of Blandine's neighbors, brilliantly and achingly charting the range of their experiences. . . . It all ties together, achieving this first novelist's maximalist ambitions and making powerful use of language along the way. Readers will be breathless."

—Publishers Weekly

"Darkly funny, surprising, and mesmerizing . . . A stunning and original debut that is as smart as it is entertaining . . . Gunty pans swiftly from room to room, perspective to perspective, molding a story that . . . is extremely suspenseful and culminates in a finale that will leave readers breathless. With sharp prose and startling imagery, the novel touches on subjects from environmental trauma to rampant consumerism to sexual power dynamics to mysticism to mental illness, all with an astonishing wisdom and imaginativeness. . . . A striking and wise depiction of what it means to be awake and alive in a dying building, city, nation, and world."

—Kirkus

title: White Tears
long_summary:
Music brings together two unlikely friends in New York City: Seth, an introverted sound engineer searching for direction, and Carter, a wealthy dilettante drifting through life on inherited privilege. Their casual friendship takes a dangerous turn after Seth captures a street musician's performance and Carter decides to pass it off online as a forgotten blues recording from the 1920s, complete with a fabricated backstory about a mysterious artist named Charlie Shaw.

What starts as an elaborate joke quickly unravels when a blues expert emerges claiming knowledge of the supposedly fictional musician. The discovery forces Seth and Carter, joined by Carter's unstable sister Leonie, into a disturbing journey through America's buried racial history. Their deception becomes a doorway into generations of cultural theft, violence, and suppressed truths about how American music was built on exploitation.

Kunzru crafts a supernatural thriller that interrogates questions of artistic ownership and historical accountability. The novel examines how easily privileged outsiders can commodify and distort marginalized voices, while exploring the ways America's racist past continues to demand recognition and reckoning in the present.
short_summary: When two music-obsessed New Yorkers fake a 1920s blues recording, they discover their invented musician actually existed. A haunting exploration of cultural appropriation and America's buried history.
author_bios: Hari Kunzru has written six novels, including Red Pill, White Tears, Gods Without Men, My Revolutions, Transmission, and The Impressionist. His work has earned recognition through fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, the American Academy in Berlin, and the Cullman Center at the New York Public Library. Kunzru contributes regularly to The New York Review of Books, writes Harper's Magazine's "Easy Chair" column, and serves on the faculty of New York University's Creative Writing Program.
quotes:
"White Tears is distinguished by a knowledge of blues at its deepest, a gift for observation at its most penetrating and stretches of plain old marvelous writing, some swallowing up the pages around them the way a single song . . . swallows up the side of an album. . . . Kunzru brings a canny and original insight to his American subject. . . . [His] awareness and discernment have particular value in an America of the moment where nothing less than the country's meaning is at stake."

—Steve Erickson, The New York Times

"[White Tears is] a novel that's as brave as it is brutal, and it lets nothing and nobody off the hook. . . . Stunning [and] audacious . . . an urgent novel that's as challenging as it is terrifying. . . . completely impossible to put down . . . [Kunzru's] writing is propulsive, clear and bright, whether he's describing an old blues song or a shocking act of violence. . . . [White Tears] will shock you, horrify you, unsettle you, and that's exactly the point."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"Captivating. . . . Kunzru's graceful writing is exquisitely attuned to his material. . . . [White Tears is] neither a clever Time and Again story of time travel nor a tricky Westworld sort of past-present parallel. White Tears is a profoundly darker and more complex story of a haunting that elucidates the iniquitous history of white appropriation of black culture."

—Katharine Weber, The Washington Post

title: Good Talk
subtitle: A Memoir in Conversations
long_summary:
A child's innocent curiosity becomes the catalyst for profound reflection in this innovative graphic memoir. Jacob finds herself navigating increasingly complex territory as her young son's questions evolve from simple wonderings into challenging inquiries about race, identity, and belonging in contemporary America.

The backdrop of political upheaval transforms everyday family moments into opportunities for deeper examination of what it means to exist between cultures. Jacob draws connections between her son's present-day confusion and her own formative experiences, creating a dialogue that spans generations and perspectives.

This visual narrative combines personal storytelling with broader cultural commentary, examining how families process difficult truths together. The author's willingness to confront uncomfortable realities—both within her own family and society at large—creates space for authentic discussion about identity, prejudice, and acceptance. The result is an intimate portrait of parenthood that doubles as a meditation on American identity, rendered through both words and striking artwork that brings these crucial conversations to vivid life.
short_summary: Through illustrated conversations with her six-year-old son, Jacob explores race, identity, and love in America. A groundbreaking graphic memoir that's funny, heartbreaking, and utterly necessary.
author_bios: Mira Jacob wrote the widely praised novel The Sleepwalker's Guide to Dancing and has contributed to numerous publications including The New York Times Book Review, Vogue, Glamour, Tin House, Electric Literature and Literary Hub. She currently resides in Brooklyn with her family.
quotes:
"[A] showstopping memoir about race in America . . . by turns funny, philosophical, cautious, and heartbreaking . . . Particularly moving are the chapters in which Jacob explores how even those close to her retain closed-minded and culturally defined prejudices. . . . The memoir works well visually, with striking pen-and-ink drawings . . . collaged onto vibrant found photographs and illustrated backgrounds. . . . Told with immense bravery and candor, this book will make readers hunger for more of Jacob's wisdom and light."

—Kirkus

"Breezy but poignant . . . [Mira Jacob] employs pages of narrative prose sparingly but hauntingly. . . . The 'talks' Jacob relates are painful, often hilarious, and sometimes absurd, but her memoir makes a fierce case for continuing to have them."

—Publishers Weekly

"Mira Jacob just made me toss everything I thought was possible in a book-as-art-object into the garbage. Her new book changes everything."

—Kiese Laymon, New York Times bestselling author of Heavy

title: Lost Girls
subtitle: An Unsolved American Mystery
long_summary:
The disappearance of Shannan Gilbert in 2010 exposed a tragedy far larger than anyone imagined. Her frantic flight through an exclusive Long Island community that spring night seemed like an isolated incident involving a young escort—until investigators stumbled upon something chilling months later.

Four bodies discovered along a desolate stretch of highway revealed the work of a serial killer, yet Shannan remained missing. The victims—Maureen, Melissa, Megan, and Amber—shared disturbing similarities: young women who had traveled to Long Island seeking work in the sex trade, all found wrapped in burlap and carefully positioned.

Robert Kolker reconstructs not just a criminal investigation, but the complex lives of five women whose deaths might have gone unnoticed. He examines how the digital age created new vulnerabilities, how society's blind spots enabled tragedy, and how families fought for recognition that their daughters mattered. This investigation becomes a mirror reflecting uncomfortable truths about who we value and protect, while following one mother's determined quest to ensure her daughter's story would not be forgotten.
short_summary: Robert Kolker transforms a serial killer case into something deeper—a haunting portrait of five women failed by society and a mother's relentless fight for justice.
author_bios: Robert Kolker wrote the New York Times bestselling Lost Girls, which earned recognition as one of the New York Times's 100 Notable Books and appeared on Publishers Weekly's Top Ten Books of 2013. His magazine work has been featured in New York magazine, Bloomberg Businessweek, The New York Times Magazine, Wired, GQ, and numerous other publications. Kolker received the 2011 Harry Frank Guggenheim Award for Excellence in Criminal Justice Reporting and has been recognized as a National Magazine Award finalist.
quotes:
"Meticulously reported and beautifully written, Robert Kolker's Lost Girls is a haunting and powerful crime story that gives voice to those who can no longer be heard. It is a story that you will not be able to forget."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon & The Wager

"Kolker has grabbed hold of a ghost story, one he grounds in insistent detail.... His book becomes a lashing critique of how society, and the police, let these young women down.... Reading this true-crime book, you're reminded of the observation that easy reading is hard writing."

—The New York Times

"Beautifully and provocatively written. . . . A baffling whodunit . . . a captivating true crime narrative that's sure to win new converts and please longtime fans of the genre."

—Publishers Weekly

long_summary:
High school English teacher Jake Epping stumbles into the impossible when his dying friend reveals a time portal hidden in a diner storeroom. The destination: 1958 America, complete with its promise of second chances and the weight of unwritten history.

Armed with future knowledge and a desperate mission, Jake assumes a new identity in small-town Texas. The plan seems straightforward—track down Lee Harvey Oswald and alter the course of November 22, 1963. But the past proves to be a jealous guardian of its own timeline.

As Jake builds a life in this bygone era, falling deeply in love and becoming part of a community, he discovers that history resists change with increasing violence. Each step toward Dallas brings new obstacles, as if time itself conspires to preserve its darkest moments. The question becomes not whether Jake can prevent a national tragedy, but whether the cost of changing history might destroy everything he's come to cherish in the past—and threaten the future he once knew.
short_summary: A high school teacher discovers a portal to 1958 and embarks on a mission to prevent Kennedy's assassination. King crafts his most ambitious novel—part love story, part historical thriller, part meditation on fate and consequence.
author_bios: Stephen King has written over sixty books, each becoming a worldwide bestseller. Among his recent publications are Never Flinch, You Like It Darker (recognized as a New York Times Book Review top ten horror book of 2024), Holly (selected as a New York Times Notable Book of 2023), Fairy Tale, Billy Summers, and the Bill Hodges trilogy. His novel 11/22/63 earned the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Mystery/Thriller. King received the 2018 PEN America Literary Service Award, the 2014 National Medal of Arts, and the 2003 National Book Foundation Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters.
quotes:
"Fascinating... Captivating. It is not typical Stephen King. It is extraordinary Stephen King."

—USA Today

"Among living American novelists, Stephen King is the heavyweight champion... This may be his most haunted, and haunting, work."

—San Diego Union Tribune

title: How Beautiful We Were
long_summary:
In the village of Kosawa, toxic spills from an American oil company have poisoned the water and destroyed the soil that once sustained generations. Children fall sick, crops fail, and government officials offer empty promises while serving corporate interests over their own people.

Through the eyes of Thula and her generation, Mbue chronicles how environmental destruction becomes the catalyst for an uprising that will define their lives. As Thula matures from witness to activist, she must navigate the complex legacy of colonial exploitation and corporate greed that threatens to erase her community entirely.

This novel interrogates the true cost of resistance—both for those who fight and those who choose survival over revolution. Mbue weaves together the intimate story of one family with the broader tragedy of a people caught between powerful forces that view their land as expendable. The result is a searing examination of environmental injustice and the courage required to defend what remains of home.
short_summary: Environmental devastation pushes a fictional African village to fight back against an American oil company and their own corrupt government. Mbue crafts an urgent, unflinching story of resistance and sacrifice.
author_bios: Imbolo Mbue wrote the bestselling novel Behold the Dreamers, which earned the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and was selected for Oprah's Book Club. Her debut has been translated into eleven languages and adapted for both opera and theater. Born in Limbe, Cameroon, Mbue studied at Rutgers and Columbia Universities and currently resides in New York City.
quotes:
"Sweeping and quietly devastating . . . How Beautiful We Were charts the ways repression, be it at the hands of a government or a corporation or a society, can turn the most basic human needs into radical and radicalizing acts. . . . Profoundly affecting."

—The New York Times

"Among the many virtues of Mbue's novel is the way it uses an ecological nightmare to frame a vivid and stirring picture of human beings' asserting their value to the world, whether the world cares about them or not. One can both grieve for Kosawa and be inspired by its determined fight for life."

—Kirkus

"Imbolo Mbue has given us a novel with the richness and power of a great contemporary fable, and a heroine for our time."

—Sigrid Nunez, author of The Friend, winner of the National Book Award

title: By the Fire We Carry
subtitle: The Generations-Long Fight for Justice on Native Land
long_summary:
A murder case from the 1990s becomes the unlikely catalyst for one of the most significant Indigenous rights victories in modern American history. The crime: a Muscogee citizen killing another tribal member on what may or may not have been reservation land. The question: did Oklahoma have the right to prosecute, or did jurisdiction belong to the tribe?

This legal puzzle unravels more than a century of governmental betrayal. In the 1830s, the Muscogee people faced forced removal at gunpoint, driven from ancestral homes with promises of permanent new territory. Those promises crumbled when Oklahoma statehood erased their reservation from official recognition.

Rebecca Nagle traces how this forgotten history collided with contemporary jurisprudence, culminating in a 2020 Supreme Court decision that restored nearly half of Oklahoma to tribal jurisdiction. Through meticulous research and personal connection to the Cherokee Nation, she reveals how Indigenous communities have fought tirelessly to reclaim what was stolen, transforming legal defeats into unexpected victories that reshape our understanding of sovereignty, justice, and the ongoing struggle for Native rights in America.
short_summary: How a small-town murder in the 1990s led to a Supreme Court case that redrew the map of Oklahoma. Nagle weaves together centuries of broken promises and Indigenous resistance in this essential work of history and reportage.
author_bios: Rebecca Nagle brings both journalistic expertise and personal heritage as a Cherokee Nation citizen to her reporting on Indigenous issues. She created and hosts the acclaimed podcast This Land and has contributed to major publications including the Atlantic, the Washington Post, the Guardian, USA Today, and Indian Country Today, focusing on Native representation, federal Indian law, and tribal sovereignty. Her work has earned recognition through a Peabody Award nomination, the American Mosaic Journalism Prize, the Women's Media Center's Exceptional Journalism Award, and multiple honors from the Native American Journalist Association. She resides in Tahlequah, Oklahoma.
quotes:
"Nagle's gripping historical and legal chronicle sheds light on a centuries-long struggle for Indigenous sovereignty and tribal land in Oklahoma."

—The New York Times

"Terrific. . . . Nagle writes with sensitivity and empathy for the Native American communities she grew up in and around."

—The Atlantic

"A brilliant, kaleidoscopic debut. . . . A showstopper."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Audience of One
subtitle: Donald Trump, Television, and the Fracturing of America
long_summary:
The rise of Donald Trump cannot be understood without examining America's relationship with television itself. James Poniewozik argues that decades of media evolution created the perfect storm for a reality TV star to capture the presidency.

This cultural analysis reveals how television transformed from a unifying force in mid-20th century America into today's fragmented digital landscape of endless channels and online echo chambers. Within this shifting media environment, Trump evolved as the ultimate TV creation—a figure who understood instinctively how to manipulate cameras, headlines, and public attention.

Poniewozik chronicles Trump's metamorphosis through different media eras: the tabloid celebrity of the 1980s, the self-aware entertainer of the 1990s, the reality show boss of the 2000s, and finally the Twitter-obsessed political performer. Each reinvention reflected television's own changes, until Trump became less a person than a living embodiment of media itself.

The book examines how politics and entertainment merged into a single spectacle, where governing became performance and controversy became currency. Poniewozik dissects this phenomenon with sharp wit and cultural insight, showing how America elected not just a president, but television itself to the highest office.
short_summary: An incisive cultural history that captures a fractious nation through the prism of television and the rattled mind of a celebrity president.
genres: Political Science / Political Process / Media & Internet
author_bios: James Poniewozik serves as chief television critic for the New York Times, a position he has held since 2015. Before joining the Times, he worked as television and media critic at Time magazine and wrote a media column for Salon. He currently resides in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"In his stellar debut, Poniewozik demonstrates how Trump, over a period of four decades, “achieved symbiosis” with the TV medium.... His telling analyses of Trump’s appearances on The Apprentice, Fox & Friends, and The Howard Stern Show will come as revelations to readers unfamiliar with those programs.... The author chronicles Trump’s actions against a deeply insightful history of vast changes in the media and popular culture during the period.... This intelligent eye-opener belongs on the small shelf of valuable books that help explain how Trump created his base."—Kirkus

"Caustic, scintillating cultural history…. New York Times television critic Poniewozik sets Donald Trump’s political rise against American television’s evolution…. Trump’s own media persona—'the blunt, impolite apex predator’ on The Apprentice, the trash-talking bully in pro-wrestling cameos, the birther conspiracy theorist on Fox News guest spots—shaped his political style and then subsumed him entirely: Trump became ‘a cable news channel in human form: loud, short of attention span, and addicted to conflict,’ Poniewozik writes. ‘TV became president.’ Poniewozik’s trenchant, brilliantly witty critique of the cultural archetypes percolating into American politics is one of the best analyses yet of the Trump era."—Publishers Weekly

"We’re saturated in Trump coverage and analysis these days, but Poniewozik has been offering consistently unique, informative, and whip-smart commentary in his post as New York Times TV critic. Here he expands on his newspaper work by dissecting the president through the lens of his favorite medium."—Entertainment Weekly

title: Purity
long_summary:
Pip Tyler's life is a maze of unanswered questions. Crushed by student loans and living in an Oakland squat, she knows almost nothing about her past—not her father's identity, not why her reclusive mother lives under a false name, not how to escape the uncertainty that defines her existence.

A chance meeting opens an unexpected door: an internship with the Sunlight Project, a secretive organization that specializes in exposing hidden truths. Led by Andreas Wolf, a magnetic former East German activist now hiding in South America, the group promises access to information that could unlock the mysteries of Pip's family history. But Andreas's interest in her runs deeper than professional mentorship, challenging everything she believes about morality and justice.

Franzen constructs a labyrinthine narrative that spans generations and continents, connecting the personal struggles of parents and children with larger questions about transparency, power, and the price of truth. The novel examines how secrets shape us—both the ones we keep and the ones kept from us—while exploring the dangerous allure of those who promise to reveal everything. Through interconnected stories of idealism, betrayal, and violence, the book interrogates whether some truths are worth the destruction they bring.
short_summary: Pip Tyler, drowning in student debt and family mysteries, joins a shadowy organization that promises to reveal the world's secrets. Franzen weaves together multiple generations and continents in this sprawling exploration of truth, power, and identity.
author_bios: Jonathan Franzen has written five novels, including The Corrections, Freedom, and Purity, along with five nonfiction works such as Farther Away and The End of the End of the Earth. Farrar, Straus and Giroux publishes his books, and he makes his home in Santa Cruz, California.
quotes:
"Mr. Franzen's most fleet-footed, least self-conscious and most intimate novel yet . . . The stories of the characters in Purity zip forward aggressively in time, but open inward, burrowing into their psyches and underscoring what seems like Mr. Franzen's determination to build on the steps he took in Freedom to create people capable of change, perhaps even transcendence . . . Mr. Franzen adroitly dovetails these story lines, using large dollops of Dickensian coincidence and multiple plot twists to construct suspense and to entertain."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Purity demonstrates Franzen's ingenious plotting, his ability to steer the chaos of real life toward moments that feel utterly surprising yet inevitable . . . In Purity Franzen writes with a perfectly balanced fluency . . . From its tossed-off observations . . . to its thoughtful reflections on the moral compromises of journalism,Purity offers a constantly provocative series of insights."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A twisty but controlled epic that merges large and small concerns: loose nukes and absent parents, government surveillance and bad sex, gory murder and fine art . . . [Franzen is] admirably determined to think big and write well about our darkest emotional corners. [Purity is] an expansive, brainy, yet inviting novel that leaves few foibles unexplored."

—Kirkus

title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
long_summary:
A chance encounter on a Cambridge subway platform reunites two former friends whose shared passion for gaming will reshape both their lives. Sam and Sadie transform from struggling students into industry visionaries, crafting digital worlds that captivate millions and catapult them to unprecedented success.

Yet prosperity cannot shield them from the complexities of human relationships or the weight of their own expectations. As their partnership evolves over three decades, they navigate the treacherous terrain between friendship and romance, artistic integrity and commercial demands, personal loyalty and professional ambition.

This sweeping narrative traces their journey from East Coast academia to West Coast innovation, examining how creativity both connects and isolates us. Through the lens of game design, the story interrogates questions of authenticity, representation, and the stories we tell ourselves about success. At its heart lies an exploration of how we forge meaningful connections in an increasingly digital world, and whether love can survive the very ambitions that initially brought two people together.
short_summary: Childhood friends Sam and Sadie reunite at Harvard and become creative partners in video game design. Their collaboration brings fame, success, and heartbreak across thirty years of friendship, love, and artistic ambition.
author_bios: Gabrielle Zevin wrote Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, which dominated the New York Times Best Seller List for over a year and earned recognition from more than twenty-five publications as a top book of the year. The novel made the New York Times list of the 100 Best Books of the 21st Century in 2024. Her other acclaimed works include The Storied Life of A.J. Fikry, Young Jane Young, The Hole We're In, and Elsewhere. Publishers worldwide have translated her novels into over forty languages.
quotes:
"Delightful and absorbing...Zevin burns precisely zero calories arguing that game designers are creative artists of the highest order. Instead, she accepts that as a given, and wisely so, for the best of them plainly are...Expansive and entertaining...Dozens of Literary Gamers will cherish the world she's lovingly conjured. Meanwhile, everyone else will wonder what took them so long to recognize in video games the beauty and drama and pain of human creation."

—Tom Bissell, The New York Times

"A tour de force... A moving demonstration of the blended power of fiction and gaming....Zevin describes herself as 'a lifelong gamer.' That level of experience could very well have produced a story of hermetically sealed nostalgia impenetrable to anyone who doesn't still own a copy of 'Space Invaders.' But instead, she's written a novel that draws any curious reader into the pioneering days of a vast entertainment industry too often scorned by bookworms. And with the depth and sensitivity of a fine fiction writer, she argues for the abiding appeal of the flickering screen."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Whatever its subject, when a novel is powerful enough, it transports us readers deep into worlds not our own. That's true of Moby Dick, and it's certainly true of Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, which renders the process of designing a great video game as enthralling as the pursuit of that great white whale….There are…smart ruminations here about cultural appropriation, given that the game, Ichigo, is inspired by Japanese artist Hokusai's famous painting The Great Wave at Kanagawa….It's a big, beautifully written novel about an underexplored topic, that succeeds in being both serious art and immersive entertainment."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: When It All Burns
subtitle: Fighting Fire in a Transformed World
long_summary:
California faces an unprecedented era of catastrophic wildfires that defy every prediction and historical pattern. These blazes tear through landscapes once considered fireproof, burn year-round, and create their own devastating weather systems.

Jordan Thomas takes readers inside this apocalyptic reality through his experiences with the Los Padres Hotshots, an elite firefighting crew tasked with confronting the unconquerable. His account of one punishing fire season reveals the physical and psychological toll of battling infernos that have evolved beyond human control.

Beyond the immediate drama of firefighting, Thomas excavates the deeper story of how fire transformed from humanity's ancient ally into an existential threat. He traces this shift through colonial suppression of Indigenous burning practices, misguided forest management policies, and the rise of a massive firefighting apparatus that may be fighting the wrong war entirely.

This is both an intimate portrait of extraordinary courage under extreme conditions and a clear-eyed examination of climate change's most visible frontier. Thomas combines rigorous research with lived experience to illuminate how we might forge a different relationship with fire—one that acknowledges both its destructive power and its essential role in healthy ecosystems.
short_summary: Wildland firefighter and anthropologist Jordan Thomas chronicles one brutal fire season with California's elite hotshot crew. Part memoir, part urgent climate reckoning—visceral, deeply researched, and surprisingly hopeful.
author_bios: Jordan Thomas combines firsthand experience as a Los Padres hotshot wildland firefighter with academic training in anthropology. A Marshall Scholar who earned graduate degrees from the University of Cambridge and Durham University, Thomas has contributed to publications including the Los Angeles Times, the San Francisco Chronicle, The Seattle Times, and The Drift. He currently serves as a Chancellor's Fellow at the University of California and resides in Santa Barbara, California.
quotes:
"It is rare and wonderful when an author emerges perfectly matched to a subject and a book that also captures the spirit of the times. This gripping, deeply perceptive first-hand encounter with the devastating ferocity of 21st Century Fire reads like the Kitchen Confidential of elite wildfire fighting."

—John Vaillant, author of Fire Weather

"Thomas brings us to the front lines, deftly pulling the reader to the edge of the fire in evocative writing that reads like a thriller… Thinking about fire has never been more essential—Thomas charts a map toward the future."

—Kirkus

"Jordan Thomas draws on his experience as a hotshot to tell a story that's as scary and exciting as a wildfire. When It All Burns manages to be at once deeply personal and far-reaching in scope."

—Elizabeth Kolbert, author of Under a White Sky and The Sixth Extinction

title: Leave the World Behind
long_summary:
Two families collide in an upscale vacation rental when catastrophe strikes the outside world. Amanda and Clay have retreated to Long Island with their teenagers, seeking respite from urban life. Their sanctuary dissolves when Ruth and G.H. appear at the door, claiming ownership of the house and bearing news of a citywide blackout that has driven them from their home.

With communication networks down and information scarce, both families face an impossible situation. The vacation renters must decide whether to trust these unexpected arrivals, while the homeowners grapple with their own displacement. As uncertainty deepens and the outside world remains ominously silent, tensions simmer between the adults while their children navigate this strange new reality.

Alam constructs a psychological pressure cooker that forces characters—and readers—to confront uncomfortable truths about privilege, assumptions, and survival instincts. The novel dissects how quickly social norms dissolve when security vanishes, revealing the fault lines that run beneath polite society. In this claustrophobic setting, every interaction carries weight as two very different families must forge an uneasy alliance while the familiar world potentially crumbles beyond their isolated refuge.
short_summary: Two families become unlikely housemates when a mysterious blackout forces strangers together in an isolated vacation rental. Alam crafts a brilliant thriller about trust, survival, and what happens when civilization starts to fray.
author_bios: Rumaan Alam wrote the bestselling Leave the World Behind, which earned National Book Award recognition and became a film adaptation, along with two additional novels. His essays and criticism have been featured in major publications including The New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and The New Yorker. He makes his home in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"A slippery and duplicitous marvel of a novel…. Leave the World Behind is atmospheric and prescient: Its rhythms of comedy alternating with shock and despair mimic so much of the rhythms of life right now. That's more than enough to make it a signature novel for this blasted year."

—NPR

"'Leave the World Behind' is the perfect title for a book that opens with the promise of utopia and travels as far from that dream as our worst fears might take us. It is the rarest of books: a genuine thriller, a brilliant distillation of our anxious age, and a work of high literary merit that deserves a place among the classics of dystopian literature."

—The Washington Post

"Spectacular and ominous…. This illuminating social novel offers piercing commentary on race, class and the luxurious mirage of safety, adding up to an all-too-plausible apocalyptic vision."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Searches
subtitle: Selfhood in the Digital Age
long_summary:
The story begins with a devastating experiment: a journalist asking an AI system to help process her sister's death through writing. What emerged was something both beautiful and unsettling—prose that captured grief in ways that felt simultaneously authentic and artificial. This moment becomes the lens through which Vauhini Vara examines our increasingly intertwined relationship with digital technology.

Vara traces her own digital evolution alongside the rise of tech giants, from early internet chat rooms to her groundbreaking coverage of Facebook for the Wall Street Journal. Her personal history becomes a mirror for how Silicon Valley has quietly colonized our most intimate spaces—our thoughts, relationships, and creative processes.

The book weaves together fragments of digital life: search histories, product reviews, social media interactions, and that original viral AI experiment. Through this collage, Vara reveals how tech companies have monetized human vulnerability while promising connection and empowerment.

Yet this isn't simply a cautionary tale. Vara argues that understanding these systems—how they work, who profits, and what they cost us—opens possibilities for reclaiming agency. She envisions ways we might reshape our relationship with technology to serve human flourishing rather than corporate extraction, suggesting that our collective imagination holds the key to a more equitable digital future.
short_summary: A tech journalist uses her own viral AI experiment—asking ChatGPT's predecessor to write about her sister's death—as a starting point to examine how technology companies have shaped our inner lives. Part memoir, part investigation into digital capitalism.
author_bios: Vauhini Vara brings extensive journalism experience from major publications including The Atlantic, The New Yorker, and the New York Times Magazine to her writing. She wrote the acclaimed novels The Immortal King Rao and This is Salvaged, both of which have earned critical recognition. Based in Fort Collins, Colorado, Vara combines her background covering technology with literary storytelling.
quotes:
"In a growing lineage of books critiquing the power that tech titans wield over our physical world, Searches stands out for emphasizing how they've also shaped our private psychological terrain. Vara treats her own life as a vehicle to recount the disquieting history of the internet—or perhaps the other way around. . . . This seamless blend of personal narrative and systemic critique parallels Vara's subject: technology that has made it feel impossible to compose a self and a society without it."

—The Atlantic

"Searches is that rare thing: a genuinely thrilling book that breaks open existing forms and structures to offer something entirely new. Vara brings the rigor of a reporter and the exhilarating impulses of an artist into this extraordinary, sui generis book: with wit, insight, tenderness, humility, and clear-eyed candor, she explores the wild frontiers of what our lives have already become. The stakes are high. The ride is terrifying and illuminating at once. This book will leave you changed and stay with you for good."

—Leslie Jamison, author of Splinters: Another Kind of Love Story

"I cannot imagine a better guide through the infuriating, labyrinthine underworld of technology than Vauhini Vara. Searches is so many things—heart-stoppingly sad, a formal high-wire act, a wise and funny and thoughtful encyclopedia of our modern age—but most of all it is a book about human relationships: how imperfectly we made this thing that connects us, and how we might use this thing to re-meet ourselves and each other."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House

title: The Sense of an Ending
long_summary:
Retirement should offer Tony Webster peace, but an unexpected inheritance shatters his carefully constructed equilibrium. This bequest drags him back into relationships he'd assumed were safely buried in his past—friendships from school days that ended in tragedy and betrayal.

As Tony attempts to understand why he's been remembered in someone's will, he discovers that his recollections of crucial events don't align with reality. The comfortable narrative he's built around his younger self begins to crumble, exposing uncomfortable truths about his actions and their consequences.
