Barnes transforms this midlife reckoning into something far more unsettling than a simple trip down memory lane. The real investigation isn't into what happened decades ago, but into how Tony has edited his own history to preserve his self-image. Each revelation strips away another layer of comfortable self-deception, revealing the gap between who we think we are and who we actually were.

This meditation on aging and regret unfolds with the precision of a thriller, proving that the most devastating mysteries often lie within ourselves.
short_summary: When Tony Webster receives an unexpected inheritance, it forces him to revisit his youth and first love. A psychological detective story about memory's unreliability and the stories we tell ourselves.
author_bios: Julian Barnes has written twenty-five books and earned numerous international honors, including the Man Booker Prize, Somerset Maugham Award, and E. M. Forster Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. His literary achievements span multiple countries, with recognition including the Prix Médicis and Prix Femina in France, plus the Jerusalem Prize. The French government awarded him the Légion d'honneur in 2017. Publishers worldwide have translated his writing into more than forty languages, and he makes his home in London.
quotes:
"Dense with philosophical ideas . . . it manages to create genuine suspense as a sort of psychological detective story . . . Unpeeling the onion layers of the hero's life while showing how [he] has sliced and diced his past in order to create a self he can live with."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"An elegantly composed, quietly devastating tale about memory, aging, time and remorse. . . . Offers somber insights into life's losses, mistakes and disappointments in a piercing, thought provoking narrative. Bleak as this may sound, the key word here—the note of encouragement—is 'insights.' And this beautiful book is full of them."

—NPR

"With his characteristic grace and skill, Barnes manages to turn this cat-and-mouse game into something genuinely suspenseful."

—The Washington Post

title: Under the Skin
subtitle: The Hidden Toll of Racism on American Lives and on the Health of Our Nation
long_summary:
America's healthcare system harbors a deadly secret: the color of your skin determines your chances of survival. Linda Villarosa's investigative work uncovers the disturbing reality that medical education and practice remain tainted by centuries-old myths about racial differences in physiology.

The statistics are staggering and undeniable. A highly educated Black woman faces the same maternal mortality risks as a white woman who never finished middle school. These aren't isolated incidents but part of a larger pattern where Black patients consistently receive inferior care and experience worse outcomes across all medical specialties.

Villarosa traces how environmental injustices compound these medical inequities, as Black neighborhoods bear disproportionate exposure to toxins and pollutants. Perhaps most devastating is her examination of how the chronic stress of navigating racism literally accelerates aging at the cellular level.

Through meticulous research and deeply personal narratives, this work exposes how slavery's pseudoscientific justifications continue to influence modern medicine. The result is a healthcare apartheid that costs thousands of lives annually, demanding urgent reform of institutions that claim to heal but often harm.
short_summary: Villarosa exposes the systemic racism embedded in American healthcare, revealing how historical assumptions and daily discrimination create deadly disparities. Essential reporting anchored by powerful human stories.
author_bios: Linda Villarosa teaches journalism at the City University of New York while contributing regularly to the New York Times Magazine, where she focuses on health and racial equity. Her career spans roles as executive editor at Essence and science editor at The New York Times. Villarosa earned National Magazine Award recognition for her groundbreaking coverage of maternal mortality and contributed to The 1619 Project.
quotes:
"In Under the Skin, Linda Villarosa has written a book that will transform how you understand the relationship between race and medicine, one that makes clear the connection between our history and our health. This is a book filled with indispensable research, but also filled with humanity. Villarosa tells us important stories, and also becomes part of the story herself. I'm so glad this book exists, I will be thinking about it for a long time."

—Clint Smith, New York Times bestselling author of How the Word Is Passed

"Brilliant, illuminating. . . Meticulously researched, sweeping in its historical breadth, damning in its clear-eyed assessment of facts and yet hopeful in its outlook, Under the Skin is a must-read for all who affirm that Black lives matter."

—The Washington Post

"A damning account of how race and racism determine the quality and quantity of medical care in the U.S. . . . A closely argued case for racial and class equity in health care, revealing a medical regime sorely in need for reform."

—Kirkus

title: Master Slave Husband Wife
subtitle: An Epic Journey from Slavery to Freedom
long_summary:
Love and ingenuity collide in this remarkable account of two enslaved people who refused to accept their fate. Ellen and William Craft devised an audacious plan that would test every assumption about race, gender, and power in antebellum America. Their scheme required Ellen to transform herself completely, adopting a disguise so convincing it would fool everyone from fellow passengers to hotel clerks across a thousand-mile journey.

What began as a desperate bid for liberty transformed the couple into unlikely celebrities, their story captivating audiences from Boston to Philadelphia. Yet fame brought its own perils. The couple discovered that freedom in America remained fragile, especially as new laws turned every citizen into a potential bounty hunter. Their triumph became a catalyst for a larger reckoning about what it truly meant to be free in a nation built on contradictions.

Ilyon Woo reconstructs not just an escape, but a series of reinventions that would challenge everything Americans believed about themselves. This is history that reads like a thriller, revealing how two people's refusal to remain invisible helped expose the moral bankruptcy of an entire system.
short_summary: The extraordinary true story of Ellen and William Craft, an enslaved couple who staged a daring 1,000-mile escape in 1848, posing as master and slave. Woo brings cinematic urgency to this overlooked chapter of American history.
author_bios: Ilyon Woo has written two New York Times bestselling works of historical narrative: Master Slave Husband Wife: An Epic Journey from Slavery to Freedom and The Great Divorce: A Nineteenth-Century Mother's Extraordinary Fight Against Her Husband, the Shakers, and Her Times. Her journalism appears in major publications including The Boston Globe, The Wall Street Journal, Time, and The New York Times. Woo has earned support from prestigious institutions including the Whiting Foundation, National Endowment for the Humanities, and American Antiquarian Society. She graduated from Yale College and earned her PhD in English from Columbia University.
quotes:
"It's an edge-of-your-seat drama that will leave many wondering why the duo's remarkable story has been so overlooked by history."

—Time

"A narrative of such courage and resourcefulness it seems too dashing to be true. But it is. . . . The story is so richly dramatic, and Ms. Woo so skilled at spinning it out, that at times it's a genuine nail-biter."

—Priscilla M. Jensen, The Wall Street Journal

"Master Slave Husband Wife is a suspenseful, sensitively rendered account of [Ellen and William Craft's] four-day journey to the North. . . . Woo tells the story [with] a cinematic eye. She excels at setting scenes, conjuring the sensations experienced by the Crafts at each harrowing point. . . . The vivid details help Woo to convey the Crafts' attention to every element of their plot."

—W. Caleb McDaniel, The New York Times

title: Creation Lake
long_summary:
Espionage meets philosophy in this darkly comic thriller about deception and ancient wisdom. A calculating American operative arrives in rural France with a mission to destabilize a group of environmental activists. Her methods are precise: seduce a naive Parisian intellectual, embed herself within the commune, and execute her handlers' increasingly dangerous demands.

Yet the countryside holds unexpected mysteries. Among prehistoric caves and crumbling farmsteads, she discovers Bruno Lacombe, an enigmatic figure whose radical ideas about humanity's future lie buried in its distant past. His unconventional theories begin to unravel her certainties about control and purpose.

As surveillance becomes fascination, the spy finds herself caught between competing visions of human nature. Her corporate masters demand results, her unwitting targets trust her completely, and Bruno's seductive philosophies challenge everything she thought she understood about civilization itself. The question becomes whether she can maintain her professional detachment when confronted with ideas that shake her fundamental beliefs about progress, rebellion, and what it means to be human.
short_summary: An American secret agent infiltrates a French commune, manipulating activists and lovers alike until she encounters a mysterious mentor whose ancient philosophies threaten her carefully constructed control.
author_bios: Rachel Kushner has written the bestselling novel Creation Lake, along with The Mars Room, The Flamethrowers, and Telex from Cuba, plus the essay collection The Hard Crowd. Her work has earned the Prix Médicis and made her a two-time finalist for both the Booker Prize and National Book Award. The American Academy of Arts and Letters honored her with the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award, and she received a Guggenheim Fellowship. Publishers worldwide have translated her novels into twenty-seven languages.
quotes:
"Creation Lake reinvents the spy novel in one cool, erudite gesture. Only Rachel Kushner could weave environmental activism, paranoia, and nihilism into a gripping philosophical thriller. Enthralling and sleekly devious, this book is also a lyrical reflection on both the origin and the fate of our species. A novel this brilliant and profound shouldn't be this much fun."

—Hernan Diaz

"At last I get to say how deeply, madly, irrecoverably I loved Creation Lake… it was all stylish and cool and then somehow the book struck a blow to my heart."

—Louise Erdrich

"I was completely immersed and mesmerized. Creation Lake is a highly plotted fast-paced noir and yet full of ideas and depth. Rachel Kushner is the most exciting writer of her generation."

—Bret Easton Ellis

title: King
subtitle: A Life
long_summary:
Drawing on previously classified government documents, this biography presents Martin Luther King Jr. as both revolutionary leader and deeply human figure grappling with personal demons. Rather than offering another hagiographic account, this work reveals a man caught between his public role as advocate for nonviolence and his private battles with depression and self-doubt.

The narrative traces King's evolution from young minister to national figure, examining how government surveillance shaped his final years while he expanded his focus beyond civil rights to economic inequality and anti-war activism. This portrait challenges readers to confront the gap between the sanitized version of King often presented in popular memory and the radical thinker who understood that true equality required dismantling systemic oppression.

What emerges is a figure whose internal contradictions mirror those of the nation he sought to transform—a man whose marriage suffered under the weight of his mission, whose faith was tested by violence and hatred, yet who persisted in believing that moral force could overcome entrenched power. This account positions King not as a distant saint, but as someone whose struggles with doubt and determination remain strikingly relevant to contemporary movements for justice.
short_summary: The first major MLK biography in decades draws on newly declassified FBI files to reveal the complex human being behind the icon. Eig masterfully balances King's public triumphs with his private struggles and inner turmoil.
author_bios: Jonathan Eig previously worked as a senior writer for The Wall Street Journal and has written five books that became New York Times bestsellers, including Ali: A Life, Luckiest Man: The Life and Death of Lou Gehrig, and Opening Day: The Story of Jackie Robinson's First Season. Ken Burns has praised Eig as "a master storyteller," and his biographical works have earned recognition from major publications including The Washington Post, Chicago Tribune, Sports Illustrated, and Slate as among their annual best books.
quotes:
"Definitive . . . Monumental . . . An extraordinary achievement and an essential life of the iconic warrior for social justice."

—Kirkus

"[A] sweeping biography. Eig gives a rousing recap of King's triumphs as a civil rights leader . . . [A] complex, nuanced portrait . . . Eig's evocative prose ably conveys his bravery, charisma, and spell-binding oratory . . . An enthralling reappraisal that confirms King's relevance to today's debates over racial justice."

—Publishers Weekly

"King: A Life might be described as a deeply reported psychobiography [. . .] infused with the narrative energy of a thriller . . . Eig does a particularly nuanced job of conjuring up the mind-set of Coretta Scott King in the years before she emerged as a forceful activist in her own right . . . The most compelling account of King's life in a generation."

—Mark Whitaker, The Washington Post

title: The Book of Love
long_summary:
Three high school students materialize in their old classroom after vanishing without a trace—except now they're dead, caught between worlds in the peculiar town of Lovesend, Massachusetts. Their enigmatic music teacher offers them an impossible choice: perform a sequence of mystical challenges, and they might reclaim their interrupted lives. The catch? Absolute secrecy about their otherworldly experience.

Their return from death doesn't go unnoticed. Ancient forces and supernatural entities descend upon Lovesend, each pursuing hidden objectives that threaten to unravel the fragile fabric of the community. Meanwhile, Laura's sister Susannah wrestles with conflicting emotions as she tries to process her sibling's inexplicable reappearance.

Link constructs a universe where the extraordinary mingles with the mundane—where mystical quests unfold alongside teenage concerns, and where the bonds between friends, lovers, and family members face tests both magical and deeply human. This debut novel showcases Link's mastery of weaving supernatural elements into stories that examine how we navigate love, grief, and the complex relationships that define us.
short_summary: Three teenagers return from the dead to their small Massachusetts town, but their resurrection comes with supernatural strings attached. Link's first novel pulses with the same dark magic that made her short stories legendary.
author_bios: Kelly Link has written White Cat, Black Dog; Get in Trouble, a Pulitzer Prize finalist; Magic for Beginners; Stranger Things Happen; and Pretty Monsters. Her short fiction appears regularly in The Best American Short Stories and Prize Stories: The O. Henry Awards. Link received a MacArthur Fellowship and NEA grant, co-founded Small Beer Press, co-edits Lady Churchill's Rosebud Wristlet, and co-owns Book Moon bookstore in Easthampton, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"A luxurious, bewitching novel of exceptional beauty and power."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House

"A dizzying dream ride you will never forget."

—Leigh Bardugo, author of Ninth House

"By turns playful and harrowing, surreal and sagacious, replete with gods and other monsters, The Book of Love is an astonishing, gorgeous novel written with Link's unique wit, warmth and ability to get under your skin."

—Holly Black, author of Book of Night

title: Know My Name
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
The victim impact statement that captivated millions and sparked nationwide conversations about sexual assault was just the beginning. Behind the viral letter that changed California law and led to a judge's recall was a young woman navigating the complex aftermath of trauma within a system that often fails survivors.

This memoir reveals the stark reality of what happens after the cameras stop rolling and the headlines fade. Despite having what many considered an ideal case—witnesses, evidence, a clear perpetrator—the author's journey through isolation and self-doubt exposes how even the most supported victims struggle against institutional barriers and cultural attitudes that prioritize protecting the accused.

Miller's account dissects the machinery of a justice system built to minimize rather than heal, while simultaneously celebrating the transformative power of finding one's voice. Her narrative weaves together moments of devastating vulnerability with unexpected humor and hard-won wisdom, creating a testament to human resilience that refuses to let trauma define the survivor. This is both an indictment of systemic failures and a celebration of the words that can reshape our understanding of justice, healing, and what it means to reclaim one's story.
short_summary: Miller reclaims her identity after being known only as Emily Doe, transforming her experience of assault and the Stanford trial into a luminous memoir about survival and the power of speaking truth.
author_bios: Chanel Miller graduated with a BA in Literature from the University of California, Santa Barbara, and works as both a writer and artist. Her memoir KNOW MY NAME became a New York Times bestseller and earned recognition as a New York Times Book Review Notable Book, along with winning the National Book Critics Circle Award. Miller has been honored as a 2019 Time Next 100 recipient and received recognition as a 2016 Glamour Woman of the Year.
quotes:
"Know My Name is an act of reclamation. On every page, Miller unflattens herself, returning from Victim or Emily Doe to Chanel, a beloved daughter and sister...Know My Name marks the debut of a gifted young writer. Miller's words are purpose. They are maps. And she is a treasure who has prevailed."

—Jennifer Weiner, The New York Times

"Know My Name is a blistering, beautifully written account of a courageous young woman's struggle to hold a sexual predator accountable. Stand back, folks: This book is going to give a huge blast of momentum to the #MeToo movement."

—Jon Krakauer

"She has written a memoir that converts the ongoing experience of sexual assault into literature...Beautiful."

—The Atlantic

title: What We Can Know
long_summary:
A dinner party in 2014 becomes the epicenter of a literary mystery that reverberates across time. Francis Blundy recites an original poem to his wife, unaware that this single evening will spawn decades of scholarly debate and obsession. The poem disappears without a trace, leaving only questions in its wake.

Fast-forward to 2119: climate catastrophe has reshaped civilization, and much of the old world lies beneath rising waters. Thomas Metcalfe, an isolated academic in flooded England, fixates on the lost cultural treasures of the early 21st century. His search for Blundy's vanished verse pulls him into a web of passion, deception, and violence that challenges his understanding of truth itself.

McEwan constructs a narrative that functions simultaneously as romantic thriller and philosophical inquiry. The novel questions whether we can ever truly comprehend the motivations of others—or even our own past selves. Through parallel timelines, it examines how stories evolve, how memory distorts, and how the desire to solve mysteries can become its own form of obsession.
short_summary: A mysterious poem vanishes in 2014, then becomes an obsession for a future scholar in a climate-ravaged world. McEwan crafts an intricate puzzle spanning centuries, exploring love, loss, and the stories we tell ourselves.
author_bios: Ian McEwan has written nineteen novels and two short story collections throughout his distinguished career. First Love, Last Rites earned him the Somerset Maugham Award, while later works brought additional recognition including the Whitbread Novel Award for The Child in Time and the Booker Prize for Amsterdam. His novels include Atonement, Saturday, On Chesil Beach, Solar, Sweet Tooth, The Children Act, Nutshell, and the bestselling Machines Like Me, with multiple titles adapted for cinema.
quotes:
"It gave me so much pleasure I sometimes felt like laughing. . . . It's a sophisticated entertainment of a high order."

—New York Times

"What We Can Know feels like a direct descendant of Atonement, McEwan's most beloved work, where an illicit relationship generates unexpected tremors, and fantasy and memory rush into the gaps between facts."

—New Yorker

"This is all brilliantly, and surprisingly, plotted. . . . [T]here is a daring realignment that boldly shifts the perspective and demonstrates with shocking intensity how little we can ever really grasp about the strange evasions of the heart."

—Washington Post

title: The Woman Who Lost Her Soul
long_summary:
A murder in Haiti becomes the catalyst for uncovering decades of buried secrets in this ambitious novel that spans continents and generations. Tom Harrington, a humanitarian lawyer, finds himself drawn into investigating the death of Jackie Scott, a photojournalist whose life was far more complex than anyone realized.

As Harrington digs deeper, he discovers connections that stretch back through his own past and forward into a web of international intrigue. Jackie's story emerges as one shaped by family legacy and Cold War machinations, taking readers from the battlefields of World War II through the shadowy operations of the 1980s.

Shacochis constructs a narrative that examines how personal choices intersect with historical forces, revealing the hidden costs of America's global reach. The investigation becomes a meditation on identity, loyalty, and the ways our individual stories become entangled with larger political currents. Through multiple timelines and locations, the novel builds toward an understanding of how the seeds of contemporary conflict were planted in earlier decades of covert operations and moral compromise.
short_summary: From Haiti to Istanbul, a humanitarian lawyer's investigation into a photojournalist's murder unravels fifty years of Cold War secrets. Shacochis weaves espionage and personal betrayal into an ambitious epic about America's global entanglements.
author_bios: Bob Shacochis earned the National Book Award for his first story collection, Easy in the Islands, while his follow-up, The Next New World, brought him the Prix de Rome from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. His novels include Swimming in the Volcano, which was a National Book Award finalist, and The Woman Who Lost Her Soul, honored with the Dayton Peace Prize and named a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Shacochis has also written The Immaculate Invasion, a finalist for The New Yorker Book Award. His journalism appears in Harper's, The New York Times, The Washington Post, and The Wall Street Journal, and he serves as a contributing editor at Outside.
quotes:
"Engrossing...a soaring literary epic about the ­forces that have driven us to the 9/11 age....Shacochis darts around the globe over the span of five decades like a sorcerer of world history: Locations shift, time swirls, characters reappear in new disguises with new names. He's always so relentlessly captivating that you don't dare fall behind."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"National Book Award—winning novelist Shacochis makes a long-awaited—indeed, much-anticipated—return to fiction with this stunning novel of love, innocence and honor lost... The wait was worth it... Shacochis has delivered a work that belongs alongside Joseph Conrad and Graham Greene... [The Woman Who Lost Her Soul] moves like a fast-flowing river, and it is memorably, smartly written... An often depressing, cautionary and thoroughly excellent tale of the excesses of empire, ambition and the too easily fragmented human soul."

—Kirkus

"This big beauty of a book was worth the wait. It's tinglingly ambitious, vast in scope, and magnificently written. I could unerringly pick a Bob Shacochis sentence out of a police line-up of sentences, which is just about the highest praise I can offer to any writer."

—Michael Cunningham

title: Whiskey Tender
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Three generations of Deborah Jackson Taffa's family believed in a bargain: surrender your Native identity, and America will embrace you in return. Her grandparents endured missionary boarding schools designed to strip away their Quechan and Laguna Pueblo heritage. Her parents left reservation life behind for government job programs that promised economic mobility through cultural erasure.

But growing up between worlds—born on California's Yuma reservation, raised in Navajo country—Taffa begins to see the cracks in this inherited wisdom. Her memoir weaves together childhood recollections from the 1970s and 80s with incisive analysis of federal policies, the Red Power movement, and the ongoing criminalization of Native communities.

Taffa examines how her mixed-tribe identity fits within both pan-Indian solidarity and specific tribal belonging. She traces the personal costs of assimilation alongside its broader historical violence, revealing how Native stories remain absent from America's foundational narratives. With wit and unflinching honesty, she interrogates whether the promise of acceptance ever delivers what it claims—and what her family lost believing it would.
short_summary: Growing up between reservation and mainstream America, Taffa questions the promise of assimilation her family embraced. A powerful meditation on identity, inheritance, and what we sacrifice for acceptance.
author_bios: Deborah Jackson Taffa holds citizenship in both the Quechan (Yuma) Nation and Laguna Pueblo. She completed her MFA through the Nonfiction Writing Program in Iowa City and currently directs the MFA in Creative Writing Program at the Institute of American Indian Arts in Santa Fe. Her essays and articles have been featured in The Rumpus, Boston Review, Los Angeles Review of Books, A Public Space, Salon, Huffington Post, Prairie Schooner, The Best American Nonrequired Reading, and numerous other publications.
quotes:
"Utterly gripping."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

"I was completely taken by Whiskey Tender: its gorgeous sentences, its searing observations about identity and loss and inheritance, and its exploration of generational and terrestrial traumas. This is a strong and special book."

—Carmen Maria Machado, bestselling author of In the Dream House

"Exceptional. . . . A must-read."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Submission
long_summary:
The selection process seems straightforward until the envelope is opened. A Manhattan jury has chosen their memorial design for a terrorist attack that shattered the city, but the winning architect's identity transforms their decision into a lightning rod for national controversy. Mohammad Khan, the brilliant designer behind the selected proposal, finds himself at the center of a storm that exposes the raw nerves of a traumatized society.

Claire Burwell, the jury's only widow, initially champions Khan's vision, but her support wavers as media scrutiny intensifies and pressure mounts from grieving families, politicians, and activists with competing agendas. The controversy forces each participant to confront uncomfortable truths about prejudice, patriotism, and the complex process of collective healing.

Waldman constructs a nuanced examination of how personal trauma intersects with public memory, revealing the fault lines that emerge when a diverse city attempts to forge consensus from grief. Through multiple perspectives, the novel illuminates the ways individual histories shape our understanding of shared tragedy, questioning whether true reconciliation is possible in a society still grappling with fear and mistrust.
short_summary: When a Manhattan jury discovers their chosen memorial designer is Muslim, the selection ignites a fierce national debate about grief, art, and identity in post-9/11 America.
author_bios: Amy Waldman earned the Janet Heidinger Kafka Prize and an American Book Award for her debut novel The Submission, which also received a PEN Hemingway Award nomination. The book was named Entertainment Weekly's #1 Novel of the Year, Esquire's Book of the Year, a New York Times Best Book, and appeared on NPR's Ten Best Novels list. Waldman previously served as The New York Times South Asia Bureau Chief and worked as a national correspondent for The Atlantic. A Yale graduate, she has held fellowships at both the Radcliffe Institute and American Academy in Berlin.
quotes:
"Masterful . . . [A] scathing, dazzlingly crafted indictment of the messes people make when they mistake ideology for morality and bigotry for patriotism . . . Waldman, an ex-New York Times bureau chief, unspools her story with the truth-bound grit of a seasoned journalist and the elegance of a born novelist."

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"Frighteningly plausible and tightly wound . . . Waldman addresses with a refreshing frankness thorny moral questions and ethical ironies without resorting to breathless hyperbole."

—Publishers Weekly

"A gorgeously written novel of ideas...The Submission is sure to generate a lot of discussion in book clubs across the land."

—NPR

title: Lost in Shangri-La
subtitle: A True Story of Survival, Adventure, and the Most Incredible Rescue Mission of World War II
long_summary:
In the final months of World War II, a routine military sightseeing flight over an isolated New Guinea valley ends in catastrophe. Three survivors emerge from the wreckage to face an impossible situation: trapped in dense jungle terrain, surrounded by indigenous tribes who have never encountered outsiders, and cut off from any hope of immediate rescue.

What unfolds is a remarkable test of human endurance and cross-cultural encounter. The survivors must overcome not only the physical challenges of navigating treacherous wilderness while injured and ill-equipped, but also the delicate dynamics of first contact with a people whose way of life has remained unchanged for millennia.

Mitchell Zuckoff reconstructs this forgotten episode of history through meticulous research, drawing on military archives, personal accounts, and rare documentary footage. The result is a story that illuminates both the extremes of human survival and the unexpected connections that can form across vast cultural divides. At its heart, this is an examination of how crisis strips away everything except our most fundamental humanity.
short_summary: When a WWII sightseeing flight crashes in uncharted New Guinea jungle, three survivors must navigate hostile terrain and Stone Age tribes to stay alive. Zuckoff crafts an extraordinary true adventure.
genres: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War II
author_bios: Mitchell Zuckoff has written eight nonfiction works, including the chart-topping 13 Hours, along with Frozen in Time and Lost in Shangri-La. His investigative journalism with the Boston Globe Spotlight Team earned him recognition as a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Zuckoff has received numerous accolades throughout his career, including the Livingston Award for International Reporting, the Winship/PEN New England Award for Nonfiction, and the Heywood Broun Memorial Award.
quotes:
"Such an astonishing tale. . . . Zuckoff is able to glimpse events from alternate vantage points, and skillfully builds narrative tension and deft character portraits. He has a sharp eye for the revealing detail. . . . Zuckoff has pulled off a remarkable feat—and held the reader firmly in the grip."

—David Grann, Washington Post

"Mitchell Zuckoff has found one of the great untold yarns of World War II. In the bold tradition of The Lost City of Z and other well-crafted armchair adventures, Lost in Shangri-La takes us on a breathless descent through forbidding jungles into the heart of the Stone Age."

—Hampton Sides, bestselling author of The Wide Wide Sea, Ghost Soldiers and Blood and Thunder

"Polished, fast-paced and immensely readable—ready for the big screen."

—Kirkus

title: Beautiful Ruins
long_summary:
A chance encounter between an Italian innkeeper and a dying American actress on the Mediterranean coast in 1962 sets in motion a story that spans five decades. The mysterious woman in white disappears from his seaside hotel, leaving behind questions that echo through time until the innkeeper, now elderly, arrives at a Hollywood studio lot searching for answers.

This sweeping narrative connects past and present through an ensemble of characters navigating love, ambition, and loss. From the sun-soaked Italian Riviera to the glittering machinery of Hollywood, the story follows dreamers and cynics, idealists and opportunists as they chase elusive hopes across continents and decades.

At its heart lies an examination of how fleeting moments can reshape entire lives, and how the stories we tell ourselves about love and possibility endure long after the people who inspired them have vanished. The novel moves between romance and comedy, heartbreak and hope, building toward revelations that illuminate both the weight of the past and the unexpected paths that lead us toward our futures.
short_summary: An almost-love affair begins on the Italian Riviera in 1962 and resurfaces in contemporary Hollywood fifty years later. Walter weaves romance, comedy, and heartbreak across decades in this inventive story about dreamers chasing the impossible.
author_bios: Jess Walter has written eight novels, including bestselling titles So Far Gone, The Cold Millions, and Beautiful Ruins, along with The Zero, which was a National Book Award Finalist, and the Edgar Award-winning Citizen Vince. His collections of short fiction, The Angel of Rome and We Live in Water, have earned him the O. Henry Prize and Pushcart Prize, with stories appearing three times in Best American Short Stories. Walter's journalism earned him a Pulitzer Prize nomination in 1993 for his Ruby Ridge reporting, and he makes his home in Spokane, Washington.
quotes:
"[N]othing less than brilliant, a tour de force that crosses decades, continents, and genres, to powerful and often hilarious effect....A masterful novel of love, loss, and hard-won hope that satisfies on every level."

—Ben Fountain, author of Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk

"A monument to crazy love . . . Walter [is] a believer in capricious destiny with a fine, freewheeling sense of humor."

—New York Times

"A literary miracle."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: The Rediscovery of America
subtitle: Native Peoples and the Unmaking of U.S. History
long_summary:
American history textbooks have traditionally relegated Indigenous peoples to footnotes, treating them as obstacles rather than active participants in the nation's development. Ned Blackhawk fundamentally challenges this narrative by positioning Native nations at the center of America's story across five transformative centuries.

This groundbreaking work reveals how Indigenous communities consistently influenced major historical turning points that shaped the continent. From early colonial encounters through contemporary legal battles, Native peoples emerge not as passive victims but as strategic actors who repeatedly altered the trajectory of American development. Blackhawk traces these interconnections through pivotal moments: how Indigenous resistance affected European imperial strategies, the role of tribal politics in sparking revolutionary conflicts, and the ways Native activism transformed modern legal frameworks.

The result is a radically different understanding of American identity itself. Rather than viewing Indigenous history as separate from mainstream narratives, Blackhawk shows how Native experiences illuminate the true complexity of American development, revealing patterns of resilience and adaptation that continue to reshape the nation today.
short_summary: Five centuries of American history retold with Indigenous peoples at the center. Blackhawk demonstrates how Native nations shaped every major moment, from colonization to the Civil War to modern activism.
author_bios: Ned Blackhawk (Western Shoshone) serves as the Howard R. Lamar Professor of History and American Studies at Yale University and coordinates the Yale Group for the Study of Native America. His previous work includes Violence over the Land: Indians and Empires in the Early American West. Blackhawk resides in New Haven, Connecticut.
quotes:
"Blackhawk demonstrates how inextricably linked Indigenous history is with all aspects of American life and politics in this expansive survey, which teases out the deep connection between the aims and attitudes of the developing nation and its dealings with Native peoples. Reorienting the history of America as foremost that of an Indigenous colony, Blackhawk calls for a fundamental change of perspective."

—Publishers Weekly

"Even as the telling of American history has become more complex and nuanced, Native Americans tend to be absent. Blackhawk, a professor at Yale, confronts that absence in this sweeping account of how Native Americans shaped the country legally, politically, and culturally."

—The Washington Post

"A thoughtful, innovative, and provocative book. . . . The legends about the founding and growth of the United States have been promulgated so often and so widely that Blackhawk's conception of American history is long overdue. It is, more than any other attempt at re-interpreting our national story, US history turned upside down."

—David Shribman, Boston Globe

title: Deep House
subtitle: The Gayest Love Story Ever Told
long_summary:
In the shadow of anti-gay legislation that could separate countless couples, two men navigate love across borders and boundaries. Jeremy Atherton Lin chronicles his relationship with a British partner during a pivotal moment in LGBTQ+ history, as the Defense of Marriage Act threatens to criminalize their very existence together.

Their romance unfolds across continents and underground scenes—from clandestine retreats in nature to the pulsing nightlife of international cities. But this isn't just their story alone. Lin excavates the hidden histories of gay men who fought similar battles across generations, revealing a rich tapestry of resistance, survival, and defiance.

The narrative moves fluidly between intimate moments of domestic life and the broader political machinery that sought to deny such intimacy legal recognition. Lin introduces readers to an unlikely cast of historical figures—from activists and artists to ordinary people who became extraordinary through their refusal to remain invisible.

Blending sharp wit with genuine emotion, the book examines how love persists despite institutional hostility. It asks fundamental questions about who gets to define legitimate relationships and what it means to build a life together when society refuses to acknowledge your right to exist.
short_summary: When Congress threatens to tear apart same-sex couples with the Defense of Marriage Act, two lovers go underground in 1990s San Francisco. Atherton Lin weaves their outlaw romance through a kaleidoscopic history of queer resistance and desire.
author_bios: Jeremy Atherton Lin wrote Gay Bar, which earned recognition as a New York Times Top Book of 2021 and received the National Book Critics Circle Award. His work has appeared in prestigious publications including the Paris Review, the Times Literary Supplement, and the Yale Review, where his contributions earned him a National Magazine Award nomination. Atherton Lin has contributed book reviews to the Guardian and the Washington Post, while his audio work has been featured on NTS Radio. He divides his time between Los Angeles and East Sussex, England.
quotes:
"Deep House goes from the pensoroso of the best history of marriage equality we have to the allegro of a very hot gay love story told in the funniest, most tender way."

—Edmund White

"A strong cocktail of memoir, legal history and sociology...Atherton Lin beautifully captures the Bay Area at the turn of the millennium: the creeping gentrification, the tech bros, the video shops, the aging hippies. He's also not shy in his descriptions of sex of many kinds and configurations, with all the attendant sensations. (At times you can almost smell it.)"

—The Washington Post

"Deep House is that rare and beautiful book—equally illuminating and pleasurable. I loved its luminous transcription of queer life, its incisive and intimate legal history of gay marriage in the U.S., its transcendently sexy and propulsive love story, and its portrait of social change that promises not the fantasy of permanent liberty, but that more ephemeral reward: joy. It is exactly the book we need right now."

—Melissa Febos, author of The Dry Season and Girlhood

title: Outline
long_summary:
During a sweltering Athens summer, a novelist finds herself teaching creative writing while navigating a series of encounters that blur the boundaries between listener and storyteller. From airplane conversations with strangers to dinners with fellow writers, she becomes a repository for other people's confessions—their failed relationships, creative ambitions, and personal mythologies.

Each interaction reveals how people construct narratives about themselves, often as much fiction as truth. Students share their work, acquaintances divulge intimate details over meals, and a chance swimming companion opens up about his life. Through their revelations, questions emerge about what drives us to share our stories and whether we can ever truly know ourselves or others.

The narrator remains deliberately in shadow, her own struggles glimpsed only through absence and silence. This creates a fascinating tension between what is spoken and what remains hidden, between the stories we tell and the truths we cannot face. The result is an examination of how we use narrative to both reveal and conceal ourselves.
short_summary: A writer travels to Athens to teach a writing course. Instead of telling her own story, she listens as others reveal theirs. Spare yet layered, Outline is a meditation on identity, perception, and the act of storytelling.
author_bios: Rachel Cusk has written Second Place, the Outline trilogy, and the memoirs A Life's Work and Aftermath, along with numerous other fiction and nonfiction works. A Guggenheim Fellow, she currently makes her home in Paris.
quotes:
"Rachel Cusk's Outline is full of baking light and quiet melancholy and bodies brushing past one another in the heat; it's a subtle and utterly engrossing exploration of the ways we make ourselves known to one another--in stories and anecdotes, through seductions and disputes--and yet remain opaque; how we sketch ourselves as outlines and find these outlines interrogated. Its conversations echo each other deftly, their acute insights gracefully pulling apart the seams of its carefully composed characters to show glimpses of much messier selves within: a series of searing psychic X-rays bleached by coastal light."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

"Like the Higgs boson, which appears only when bombarded by electrons, Rachel Cusk's nearly nameless narrator flickers into visibility only through her encounters with a series of amazingly eloquent and fascinating interlocutors. Writing at the highest level and with the greatest technical restraint, Cusk manages to describe the painful realities of women's lives by a process of erasure that is itself responsible for that suffering. This is a novel where form and content meld so perfectly as to collapse into each other. I am so much the better for having read it. As if someone finally told me the truth by telling me everything, and nothing."

—Jeffrey Eugenides, author of The Marriage Plot

"Outline, in the most seemingly effortless way imaginable, winds up being completely captivating: the conversations are autobiographies in miniature, with all the holes, lies and self-deceptions lurking in that wily form . . . As you'd expect in a novel so obsessed with language, Cusk's own writing is a pleasure to read -- unfailingly precise and surprising . . . The ultimate and undeniably cerebral pleasure of Outline is it nudges you into being a more attentive reader and listener, more alert to the cracks in sentences and the messier realities that words can only try to contain."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Dept. of Speculation
long_summary:
Marriage becomes a laboratory for examining how love transforms under pressure in this innovative novel told through fragments and observations. The unnamed narrator traces the evolution of her relationship from romantic idealism to the harsh realities of parenthood and betrayal. What begins as playful correspondence between lovers gradually shifts into something more complicated as everyday struggles test their bond.

Offill constructs her story through a mosaic of moments—philosophical reflections, literary references, and stark domestic scenes that reveal how identity fractures and reforms within the confines of family life. The narrative voice shifts between "the wife" and "I," marking the protagonist's psychological journey as she grapples with lost artistic ambitions and the all-consuming nature of motherhood.

This is fiction that reads like poetry, where each carefully chosen detail carries emotional weight. The book examines how we make sense of disappointment, how we rebuild after betrayal, and whether it's possible to reconcile the person we once were with who we've become. Through its fragmented structure, the novel mirrors the way memory actually works—in flashes, associations, and sudden moments of clarity.
short_summary: Fragments of a marriage unraveling and rebuilding under the weight of betrayal and parenthood. Offill captures domestic devastation with surgical precision and unexpected humor.
author_bios: Jenny Offill has written two acclaimed novels: Last Things, which earned recognition as a New York Times Notable Book and was a finalist for the Los Angeles Times First Fiction Award, and Dept. of Speculation, shortlisted for the Folio Prize, the Pen-Faulkner Award, and the International Dublin Literary Award. She currently teaches at Syracuse University and in the low-residency program at Queens University, making her home in upstate New York.
quotes:
"Offill's unnamed heroine . . . has a lot in common with the narrators of [Renata Adler's] Speedboat and [Elizabeth Hardwick's] Sleepless Nights: she is observant and literary minded, given to seeing the odd connections (or lack of connections) among the things that make up her day-to-day life and the more subterranean thoughts that jitter around in her head. She also has a lot in common with Joan Didion's heroines . . . A genuinely moving story of love lost and perhaps, provisionally, recovered."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Absorbing and highly readable . . . Offill has successfully met the challenge she seems to have given herself: write only what needs to be written, and nothing more. No excess, no flab. And do it in a series of bulletins, fortune-cookie commentary, mordant observations, lyrical phrasing. And through these often disparate and disconnected means, tell the story of the fragile nature of anyone's domestic life . . . Intriguing, beautifully written, sly, and often profound."

—Meg Wolitzer, NPR

"A heartbreaking and exceptional book by a writer who doesn't settle for less—I've been longing for a new novel from Jenny Offill since her stunning Last Things, and it was worth every bit of the wait. Sad, funny, philosophical, at once deeply poetic and deeply engaging, this is a brilliant, soulful elegy to the hardships and joys of married life."

—Lydia Millet, author of A Children's Bible

title: Constructing a Nervous System
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Memory becomes performance art in this groundbreaking work that defies every convention of autobiographical writing. Rather than following a linear narrative, the text operates like a jazz composition—improvised, layered, and deeply rhythmic. Cultural icons serve as mirrors for self-examination: legendary musicians become conversation partners, literary figures transform into psychological landscapes, and athletic grace provides a vocabulary for understanding Black womanhood.

The author constructs identity through collision and synthesis, allowing disparate influences to speak through her voice. Family history intersects with American cultural mythology, creating a mosaic that reveals how we absorb and reimagine the figures who captivate us. This experimental approach to life writing questions the boundaries between criticism and confession, between individual experience and collective memory.

What emerges is both intimate revelation and cultural excavation—a meditation on how art shapes consciousness and how personal narrative can illuminate broader truths about American identity. The result challenges readers to reconsider what memoir can accomplish when freed from traditional constraints.
short_summary: Jefferson fragments herself on the page, weaving cultural criticism with personal history in a memoir unlike any other. Bold, innovative, and deeply moving.
author_bios: Margo Jefferson earned a Pulitzer Prize for her work as a cultural critic and served as theater critic for The New York Times. Her writing has appeared in Vogue, New York Magazine, and The Nation, while her academic career includes positions at Columbia University and Eugene Lang College. Jefferson has published On Michael Jackson and Negroland, which received the National Book Critics Circle Award for Autobiography.
quotes:
"This is a book for deep submergence, not quick flipping. This is appointment reading. Clear the schedule and commit . . . Hypnotic. . . Ravishing and rigorous . . . in an artistic tradition that includes Emily Dickinson, Frida Kahlo and Ingmar Bergman: ruthless self-excavation that is scrupulously free of solipsism . . . [Jefferson] has—along with other recent innovators in the form . . . grabbed hold of that permission slip and torn it to shreds."

—Molly Young, The New York Times

"An extraordinary reading experience—the first book I recall wanting to reread immediately after reaching the end . . . [Jefferson] lures us into a dreamy and peripatetic journey . . . [inviting] us to rethink our experiences with art while finding resonance in intimacies that she shares from her own life. I still can't say I know exactly how she manages to make this all succeed. I only know that she does, and it is splendid."

—Karen Sandstrom, The Washington Post

"Bold and roving…Pulitzer Prize-winning critic and memoirist Jefferson…creates a dance of memory and incisive cultural commentary that's deeply and refreshingly personal. This gorgeous memoir elevates the form to new heights."

—Publishers Weekly

title: A Little Devil in America
subtitle: Notes in Praise of Black Performance
long_summary:
Drawing inspiration from Josephine Baker's declaration about being "a devil in other countries," this collection of essays investigates the complex relationship between Black artistry and American society. Abdurraqib dissects moments both grand and ordinary—a vocalist's raw scream in a Rolling Stones track, childhood playground conflicts, marathon dancing, the tension before a card game begins—revealing how each contains multitudes of meaning that ripple through racial dynamics, political landscapes, and personal memory.

The author moves fluidly between icons like Michael Jackson and Patti LaBelle and intimate domestic scenes, finding equal weight in stadium performances and living room gatherings. His analysis captures both the ecstasy and anguish embedded in Black creative expression, examining how artistry becomes both liberation and burden. These essays traverse geography and decades, connecting midcentury European stages to lunar expeditions to cramped Midwestern apartments, mapping how Black performance shapes and reshapes American identity while often extracting a profound personal cost from its creators.
short_summary: Cultural critic Hanif Abdurraqib examines Black performance across decades of American culture, from Merry Clayton's vocals in "Gimme Shelter" to neighborhood spades games. Sharp, generous essays that celebrate artistry while confronting its costs.
genres: Social Science / Cultural & Ethnic Studies / American / African American & Black Studies
author_bios: Based in Columbus, Ohio, Hanif Abdurraqib works as a poet, essayist, and cultural critic who received a MacArthur Foundation "Genius" grant. A Little Devil in America earned him the Carnegie Medal and Gordon Burns Prize while becoming a National Book Award finalist. His earlier work They Can't Kill Us Until They Kill Us received recognition from NPR, Esquire, and numerous other publications as a standout book. Go Ahead in the Rain achieved New York Times bestseller status and finalist recognition for the National Book Critics Circle Award.
quotes:
"Gorgeous essays that reveal the resilience, heartbreak, and joy within Black performance."

—Brit Bennett, #1 New York Times bestselling author of The Vanishing Half

"Poignant . . . Abdurraqib has written an important book on the transformative power of . . . love."

—The New York Times

"Hanif Abdurraqib's genius is in pinpointing those moments in American cultural history when Black people made lightning strike. But Black performance, Black artistry, Black freedom too often came at devastating price. The real devil in America is America itself, the one who stole the soul that he, through open eyes and with fearless prose, snatches back. This is searing, revelatory, filled with utter heartbreak, and unstoppable joy."

—Marlon James, author of Black Leopard, Red Wolf

title: The Fraud
long_summary:
Victorian London becomes a stage for deception and moral complexity in this ambitious historical novel. At its center lies Eliza Touchet, a sharp-witted Scottish woman who manages the household of her declining novelist cousin while harboring deep doubts about the literary world's pretensions and England's social hypocrisies.

Meanwhile, Andrew Bogle carries the weight of his past as an enslaved person on a Jamaican sugar plantation. His hard-won understanding of power dynamics and human nature becomes crucial when he arrives in London to testify in one of the era's most sensational legal battles.

The notorious Tichborne case grips the nation: can a working-class Australian butcher truly be the lost heir to an aristocratic fortune? As testimony unfolds and society takes sides, both Eliza and Andrew must navigate a labyrinth of competing narratives and hidden motives.

Smith constructs a meditation on authenticity itself—who deserves belief, whose stories matter, and how personal truth intersects with historical record. The novel interrogates the very foundations of identity while exposing the economic and social structures that determine whose voice carries weight in the corridors of power.
short_summary: Set against the legal trial that divided Victorian England, Smith weaves together the stories of a skeptical Scottish housekeeper and a formerly enslaved Jamaican man navigating questions of truth, authenticity, and who gets to be believed.
author_bios: Zadie Smith has published six novels including White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud, alongside the novella The Embassy of Cambodia and short story collection Grand Union. Her nonfiction works include three essay collections: Changing My Mind, Feel Free, and Intimations. Smith also wrote The Wife of Willesden, a play adapted from Chaucer. A native of north-west London, she continues to live there today.
quotes:
"Zadie Smith's The Fraud is a lot of things: a meticulously researched work of historical fiction, a smart narrative about the importance of truth and the shortcomings of perspective, and a tale that delves deeply into authenticity and justice . . . Smith's knack for developing full secondary characters and her talent for descriptions and witty dialogue make some parts of this novel as entertaining as the wildest fiction . . . The Fraud matters because it unearths stories that need to be told, and because it asks a lot of important questions in both the unearthing and the telling. This is a novel packed with great writing and shining passages that go from humorous to deeply philosophical."

—NPR

"Mesmerizing . . . Smith weaves Eliza's shrewd and entertaining recollections of her life, a somber account of Bogle's ancestry and past, brief excerpts from Ainsworth's books, and historic trial transcripts into a seamless and stimulating mix, made all the more lively by her juxtaposing of imagination with first-and secondhand accounts and facts. The result is a triumph of historical fiction."

—Publishers Weekly

"Smith has long been fascinated by, and is expertly attuned to, the authority and status conferred on those who can wield language entertainingly or persuasively. This is the novelist's prowess—and the politician's and the swindler's. . . . Over and over, The Fraud insists on the duty of the novelist to deeply imagine the other—a project that may be doomed to fail but remains worth attempting. Smith was a convincing mouthpiece for this argument in The New York Review of Books not simply because she's a persuasive critic but because she has made a career writing novels that do this well."

—Jordan Kisner, The Atlantic

title: Moderation
long_summary:
Girlie Delmundo has mastered the art of digital cleanup, scrubbing the internet's darkest corners for a living. Her expertise lands her a coveted position moderating virtual reality content at Fairground, a move that promises to solve her family's mounting financial struggles and finally distance her from the painful memories of their lost Bay Area home.

The job offers everything she's been seeking: financial security, cutting-edge technology, and the blessed isolation that comes with working in virtual spaces. But her carefully constructed digital fortress begins to crumble when she encounters William Cheung, Fairground's sardonic co-founder who now oversees product development.

Their unexpected connection forces Girlie to confront an uncomfortable truth: no amount of technological sophistication can erase the past or predict what's coming next. As their relationship deepens, she realizes that some content simply cannot be moderated away, and the very history she's spent years trying to escape may be the key to understanding her future.
short_summary: The world's greatest content moderator gets promoted to elite VR status, but falling for her enigmatic co-founder forces a reckoning with the past she's tried to delete. Sharp, funny, and devastatingly smart about love in the digital age.
author_bios: Elaine Castillo grew up in the Bay Area and earned recognition from the Financial Times as one of "30 of the Planet's Most Exciting Young People." Her first novel, America Is Not the Heart, received nominations for the Elle Big Book Award, the Center for Fiction Prize, and the Aspen Words Literary Prize. The book appeared on 2018 best-of lists from NPR, Real Simple, Lit Hub, The Boston Globe, San Francisco Chronicle, the New York Post, Kirkus Reviews, and the New York Public Library.
quotes:
"Moderation is, at its core, a book about the moment when everything we've been repressing comes back to the surface. You can hide from yourself for only so long: until the work day ends, until your favorite show is over, until the feed runs out of content, until the digital tide recedes and all that is left is your broken, beautiful life."

—The Atlantic

"With its unyielding density of sharply observed detail, high-resolution psychological drama, and driving narrative momentum, Moderation reminded me that the novel is still the best form of virtual reality we have."

—Jenny Odell, New York Times bestselling author of Saving Time and How to Do Nothing

"Moderation is a novel that refuses to do things by halves. It is a piercing, laser-precise exploration of big tech and its imperialist intentions; it is a breathtakingly funny and complex portrait of immigrant communities in America; it is a highly charged, passionate and tender love story, willing to embrace myriad forms of love. A wonderful book."

—Kaliane Bradley, New York Times bestselling author of The Ministry of Time

title: King of Kings
subtitle: The Iranian Revolution: A Story of Hubris, Delusion and Catastrophic Miscalculation
long_summary:
In the final years of the 1970s, few observers could have predicted that one of America's most strategically important allies would vanish almost overnight. The Shah of Iran commanded vast military resources and sat atop enormous oil wealth, yet within little more than a year, his entire regime crumbled before a religious uprising that caught both Iranian elites and American intelligence completely off guard.

Scott Anderson reconstructs this stunning political collapse, examining how a ruler became so divorced from his people's reality that he failed to recognize the fury building against him. The book traces the miscalculations and willful ignorance that blinded both the Shah and his American supporters to the revolutionary forces gathering strength throughout Iranian society.

Beyond recounting this dramatic historical moment, Anderson positions the Iranian Revolution as a pivotal event that established patterns still reshaping global politics today. The uprising represented something new: religiously motivated populations overthrowing secular, Western-aligned governments. This template would echo across regions and decades, making the events of 1979 essential for understanding contemporary conflicts between traditional religious movements and modernizing elites.
short_summary: Scott Anderson chronicles the spectacular collapse of the Shah's Iran and America's catastrophic blindness to the revolution brewing beneath their noses. Essential reading for understanding how religious nationalism reshapes the world.
author_bios: Scott Anderson has written five nonfiction books and two novels, including the internationally bestselling Lawrence in Arabia, which received recognition as a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist and New York Times Notable Book. Anderson contributes regularly to The New York Times Magazine, where his extensive Middle East reporting was compiled into Fractured Lands: How the Arab World Came Apart and featured as a complete magazine issue.
quotes:
"[A] masterly new account of the Iranian revolution, illustrates the stubborn American blindness that hastened the shah's demise and helped the mullahs prevail. It was an 'obliviousness' that 'became willful, an ignorance to be maintained and defended,' Anderson writes. . . . This is an exceptional and important book. Scrupulous and enterprising reporting rarely combine with such superb storytelling."

—The New York Times

"Anderson succeeds precisely because he eschews structural, quasi-philosophical queries for an energetic account that concerns itself with, as he puts it, 'a few core questions'. . . . As a result of this inquiry, Anderson finds an answer at once simpler, more instructive, and truer than those of many scholars. . . . Anderson has also consulted the best scholarship on the revolution. . . . Anderson thus offers a readable page-turner that's also attuned to those core questions. . . . Anderson's book [is] one of the best on 1979."

—The Atlantic

"Veteran journalist Anderson takes readers through the final years of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi's regime in Iran, tracing the political machinations that kept him in power and the corruption that helped turn the Iranian public against him. It is attentive to both the shah's own oblivious rule and the world-historical mistakes that his American allies made in their attempt to prop him up."

—The Washington Post

title: Ducks
subtitle: Two Years in the Oil Sands
long_summary:
A young woman from Maritime Canada finds herself thousands of miles from home, working in Alberta's industrial oil fields to tackle crushing student debt. What begins as a practical financial decision becomes a profound reckoning with isolation, gender dynamics, and the hidden costs of resource extraction.

Through her distinctive visual storytelling, the narrative captures the stark contrast between the intimate coastal community she left behind and the massive industrial landscape where she now labors. The memoir examines how economic necessity drives people from their roots, forcing them into environments that test their resilience in unexpected ways.

The work interrogates Canada's contradictions—a nation celebrated for progressive ideals and pristine wilderness, yet built on industries that extract both natural resources and human dignity. This graphic narrative reveals the psychological toll of surviving in spaces where trauma becomes routine, where workers endure conditions that remain largely invisible to the outside world, and where women must navigate particular dangers that go unspoken and unaddressed.
short_summary: Beaton chronicles her two years in Alberta's oil sands with devastating honesty and dark humor. A brilliant graphic memoir about isolation, survival, and the brutal calculations women make in hostile environments.
author_bios: Kate Beaton hails from Mabou in Unama'ki-Cape Breton and has established herself as one of Canada's most celebrated cartoonists. Her bibliography includes the graphic memoir Ducks: Two Years in the Oilsands, the webcomic collection Hark! A Vagrant, Step Aside, Pops, and children's books The Princess and the Pony and King Baby. Beaton also executive produced the AppleTV+ series Pinecone & Pony. Her comics have earned numerous Eisner, Doug Wright, Harvey and Ignatz awards. Ducks claimed victory in Canada Reads 2023, appeared on Barack Obama's 2022 favorites list, and received recognition from Time, The New Yorker, The Washington Post, and the New York Times.
quotes:
"An exceptionally beautiful book about loneliness, labor, and survival. Beaton is a thoughtful guide through a complex landscape of class and gender, and these pages ache with grief and grace."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House

"A masterpiece, a heartbreak, a nightlight shining in the dark."

—Patricia Lockwood, author of No One Is Talking About This

"Ducks is both a coming-of-age narrative and a skillful, subtle commentary on class, misogyny, and the human costs of environmental extraction. From the oil fields to the hallways of worker housing, Kate Beaton's comics are rich with quiet revelations, intimate details, and a deadpan, devastating sense of humor. A generous and illuminating book; I suspect it will stay on my mind for a very long time."

—Anna Wiener, author of Uncanny Valley

title: The Round House
long_summary:
Thirteen-year-old Joe Coutts faces an unimaginable crisis after his mother becomes the victim of a vicious assault on their North Dakota reservation. The attack leaves Geraldine withdrawn and silent, refusing to reveal what happened or who was responsible. As his family fractures under the weight of trauma, Joe watches his father—a respected tribal judge—grapple with legal complexities that seem designed to prevent justice.

The crime's location becomes crucial: different jurisdictions mean different laws, different investigators, and potentially different outcomes. Tribal sovereignty collides with federal and state authority in ways that could let a perpetrator escape consequences entirely. Unable to stand by while bureaucratic maze-running stalls progress, Joe joins forces with his closest friends to conduct their own investigation.

Their search leads them through both the physical landscape of the reservation and the deeper cultural terrain of Ojibwe tradition and belief. What begins as adolescent detective work evolves into something far more profound—a reckoning with heritage, justice, and the painful transition from childhood innocence to adult understanding. Erdrich crafts a story where legal thriller elements merge seamlessly with spiritual questioning, creating a narrative that honors both contemporary struggles and ancestral wisdom.
short_summary: When his mother is brutally attacked on their North Dakota reservation, thirteen-year-old Joe embarks on a dangerous quest for justice. Erdrich weaves together coming-of-age storytelling with urgent questions about law, identity, and belonging.
author_bios: Louise Erdrich belongs to the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa and has written numerous acclaimed novels alongside poetry collections, children's literature, and a memoir about early motherhood. Based in Minnesota with her daughters, Erdrich also runs Birchbark Books, an independent bookstore.
quotes:
"Erdrich has given us a multitude of narrative voices and stories. Never before has she given us a novel with a single narrative voice so smart, rich and full of surprises as she has in The Round House. . . and, I would argue, her best so far."

—NPR

"The novel showcases her [Erdrich's] extraordinary ability to delineate the ties of love, resentment, need, duty and sympathy that bind families together…[a] powerful novel."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Emotionally compelling…Joe is an incredibly endearing narrator, full of urgency and radiant candor…the story he tells transforms a sad, isolated crime into a revelation about how maturity alters our relationship with our parents, delivering us into new kinds of love and pain."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Talk
long_summary:
A childhood conversation changes everything: a mother explains to her young son why he cannot play with toy guns, revealing the harsh reality that society views Black children through a lens of suspicion and threat. This moment becomes the foundation for a lifetime of heightened awareness and calculated caution.

Through original artwork and intimate storytelling, this memoir traces how early lessons about racial perception influence every aspect of growing up—from classroom interactions to neighborhood encounters. The author grapples with the weight of being seen as dangerous simply for existing, while processing the deaths of Black Americans at the hands of police.

The narrative comes full circle as the author faces his greatest challenge: explaining these same painful truths to his own young child. This graphic memoir interrogates the cyclical nature of racial trauma and the impossible burden placed on Black parents to prepare their children for a world that may not see their humanity.
short_summary: Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist Bell chronicles how "the talk" about police violence shaped his coming-of-age and now his own fatherhood. A deeply personal meditation on race, childhood, and mortality in America.
genres: Comics & Graphic Novels / Nonfiction / Biography & Memoir
author_bios: Darrin Bell launched his cartooning career at age twenty and has since earned the Pulitzer Prize along with the 2016 Berryman Award for Editorial Cartooning and 2015 RFK Award for Editorial Cartooning. Bell co-created Rudy Park and created Candorville, both nationally syndicated comic strips. His editorial work appears through King Features Syndicate, and he contributes cartoons to the New Yorker. He lives in California with his wife and four children.
quotes:
"A Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist draws on his childhood in Los Angeles to explore racism on a deeply personal level. There's a poignancy, too, in the cyclical nature of the story: Bell, now a father, is wrestling with the same questions his own parents face."

—The New York Times

"A stunning account of a young Black man navigating his way through Los Angeles and Berkeley in the 1980s and '90s, into life as a successful professional and father. The illustrations, fluctuating from the whimsically cartoonish to the painterly, are as multi-tiered and engrossing as Bell's narrative voice. Like Alison Bechdel's Fun Home and Marjane Satrapi's Persepolis, this epic portrait of an artist is destined for iconic status."

—NPR

"A beautifully drawn book, rich with insight, humor, and hard-won knowledge."

—Kirkus

title: Canada
long_summary:
A single criminal act tears apart everything Dell Parsons believed about his family and future. At fifteen, he watches his ordinary world collapse as his parents face imprisonment for bank robbery, leaving him and his twin sister to navigate the wreckage alone.

While his sister chooses escape through flight, Dell finds himself transported to the remote Canadian prairie, where a family acquaintance believes safety awaits. Instead, he encounters Arthur Remlinger, a smooth-talking American expatriate whose polished exterior conceals something far more sinister. Under the endless Saskatchewan sky, Dell must grapple with the shattering realization that the adults he trusted were strangers to him.

As Dell attempts to rebuild his understanding of himself and his place in an unpredictable world, he draws closer to a dangerous reckoning with Remlinger's true nature. Ford crafts a meditation on how quickly stability can vanish and how the search for meaning in chaos can lead us toward unexpected darkness. This is a story about the invisible lines we cross—between countries, between childhood and adulthood, between the people we think we know and who they really are.
short_summary: Dell Parsons' world implodes when his parents rob a bank, sending him into exile across the Canadian border. Ford's spare, luminous prose transforms this coming-of-age story into something profound and devastating.
author_bios: Richard Ford wrote The Sportswriter, Independence Day (which earned both the Pulitzer Prize and PEN/Faulkner Award), The Lay of the Land, and the New York Times bestseller Canada. His short fiction appears in collections such as Let Me Be Frank With You, Sorry for Your Trouble, Rock Springs, and A Multitude of Sins. Richard Ford currently resides in New Orleans alongside his wife, Kristina Ford.
quotes:
"[Canada] confirms his position as one of the finest stylists and most humane storytellers in America… his most elegiac and profound book…"

—The Washington Post

"Mr. Ford has fashioned an engaging, ruminative voice for Dell…capable of capturing the vernacular of everyday, while addressing the big philosophical questions of choice and fate. It's a voice capable of conjuring both the soporific routines of daily life in 1960 in Great Falls, before Dell's parents turn to crime, and the harrowing, Dickensian experiences he is subjected to after their arrest… Mr. Ford does a masterly job of turning the implausible into the inexorable…"

—The New York Times

"Robust and powerful… Ford is able to tap into something momentous and elemental about the profound moral chaos behind the actions of seemingly responsible people… Ford has dramatized the frightening discovery of the world's anarchic heart."

—The Wall Street Journal

title: How To Write An Autobiographical Novel
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
In this collection of essays, a writer examines the interconnected nature of personal experience and artistic creation. The pieces chronicle a journey of self-discovery that spans decades, revealing how the act of writing fiction becomes a lens for understanding one's place in the world.

The author navigates complex questions of identity—as a Korean American, as a gay man, as an artist finding his voice in contemporary America. Through intimate reflections on pivotal moments, from personal loss to national tragedies, these essays demonstrate how literature serves as both refuge and weapon in times of crisis.

The collection reveals the unglamorous reality behind a writing life: the odd jobs that pay the bills, the slow process of crafting a debut novel, the weight of bearing witness to history as it unfolds. Yet throughout, there's an underlying faith in the transformative power of storytelling—both the stories we tell about ourselves and those we share with the world.

What emerges is a meditation on survival and creation, showing how we construct meaning from chaos and find ways to preserve what matters most when everything else seems under siege.
short_summary: Chee traces his evolution from student to teacher through luminous essays that blend personal narrative with reflections on politics, art, and identity. A moving meditation on creating ourselves through storytelling.
author_bios: Alexander Chee wrote the novels Edinburgh, which earned him a Whiting Award, and the national bestseller Queen of the Night. His essay collection How to Write an Autobiographical Novel received recognition as a top book of the year from New York Magazine, the Washington Post, Publisher's Weekly, NPR, and Time, with Kirkus Reviews naming it among the hundred finest nonfiction works of the 21st century in 2025. Alexander Chee has received an NEA Fellowship in Fiction and attended residencies at the MacDowell Colony, Ledig House, and Civitella Ranieri. He makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"Alexander Chee is one of the best living writers of today. If he's not already a household name, he needs to be…powerful, powerful essays with powerful, powerful words…"

—Isaac Fitzgerald, NBC

"If writing, too, is a form of drag for Chee, it is also an act of mystic invocation and transference...Chee leavens his heaviest topics—the decimation of the gay community in the late 1980s and early '90s, the repressed memory of sexual abuse that inspired Edinburgh—with charming episodes like his stint as a waiter at William and Pat Buckley's Park Avenue maisonette, a job that prompted a crisis of conscience given Buckley's infamous proposal to brand AIDS patients on their wrists and buttocks...Even at his most mystical, Chee is generous; these pieces are personal, never pedagogical. They bespeak an unguarded sincerity and curiosity. Chee is refreshingly open about his sometimes liberating, sometimes claustrophobic sense of exceptionality...He reminds us that whomever a writer pictures as his audience, he is also writing into absence, standing in testimony for the sake of the dead. Like most of the essays here, 'After Peter' pulses with urgency, one piece from a life in restless motion. It is not necessary to agree that How to Write an Autobiographical Novel is itself a kind of novel in order to appreciate that Chee has written a moving and personal tribute to impermanence, a wise and transgressive meditation on a life lived both because of and in spite of America, a place where, he writes, you are allowed to speak the truth as long as nothing changes."

—The New York Times

"Two-thirds of the way through Alexander Chee's How to Write an Autobiographical Novel, I abandoned my sharpened reviewer's pencil in favor of luxuriating in the words.
