Chee's writing has a mesmerizing quality; his sentences are rife with profound truths without lapsing into the didactic...Chee is a very special artist; his writing is lyrical and accessible, whimsical and sad, often all at the same time. No doubt he is an inspiring writing teacher as well. His views on writing reflect his own, thoughtfully examined life."

—NPR

title: Loot
long_summary:
A teenage artisan's exceptional skill with wood transforms his destiny in ways he could never foresee. Abbas finds himself summoned to craft an elaborate mechanical tiger for a sultan's court, setting in motion a chain of events that will carry him far from his homeland. Through his collaboration with a master French clockmaker, Abbas discovers new worlds of knowledge and possibility, including an unexpected connection that draws him toward Europe.

Yet history has other plans. Colonial forces shatter the palace walls, scattering its treasures across distant lands. The magnificent creation Abbas helped bring to life disappears into the hands of those who claim ownership through conquest rather than creation. What begins as artistic apprenticeship evolves into something far more personal—a pursuit that challenges everything Abbas understands about belonging, justice, and the true meaning of home. His journey becomes a meditation on what we lose when empires rise and fall, and what we're willing to sacrifice to restore what was taken.
short_summary: When teenage woodcarver Abbas creates a mechanical tiger for an Indian sultan, he never imagines it will lead him across continents on a daring mission to reclaim stolen art from colonial plunderers.
author_bios: Tania James has written the novels Atlas of Unknowns and The Tusk That Did the Damage, along with the story collection Aerogrammes. Her fiction appears in publications including The Kenyon Review, Granta, One Story, Boston Review, A Public Space, and Guernica. She makes her home in Washington, D.C.
quotes:
"Loot is the most transporting and absorbing novel I've read in ages—a rich tapestry of an epic, thrilling at every turn. This isn't just brilliant writing: It's storytelling of the highest order."

—Rebecca Makkai, author of The Great Believers & I Have Some Questions for You

"Loot held me spellbound from the first page. This is an expertly-plotted, deeply affecting novel about war, displacement, emigration, and an elusive mechanical tiger."

—Maggie O'Farrell, author of Hamnet & The Marriage Portrait

"I read Loot in a single sitting; it is a wild, dazzling eighteenth-century romp across continents with profound things to say about invention and self-reinvention, class and fate, and the deeply human hunger to create family as both bulwark against loneliness and constant source of light and warmth."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates and Furies, Florida & Arcadia

title: The Wayfinder
long_summary:
In the ancient Pacific, where island empires rise and fall with the tides, a community faces extinction through famine. Their survival rests on the shoulders of Korero, a girl who must navigate treacherous waters and political intrigue to secure her people's future.

Johnson reconstructs a civilization that existed long before European contact, bringing to life the sophisticated maritime culture of the Tu'i Tonga Empire. Through Korero's odyssey, readers encounter a society built on complex hierarchies and oceanic mastery, where navigators read stars like maps and outrigger canoes serve as vessels of both commerce and conquest.

The novel examines how communities respond to environmental crisis and resource scarcity, questioning what individuals owe to their heritage and what sacrifices are worth making for collective survival. Johnson draws from Polynesian oral traditions to create a narrative that feels both historically grounded and mythically resonant, offering insights into how stories themselves become tools of cultural preservation and resistance.
short_summary: Set in the Polynesian islands during the Tu'i Tonga Empire, this epic follows Korero, a young girl who must undertake a perilous seafaring journey to save her starving people. Johnson weaves survival, history, and mythology into something magnificent.
author_bios: Adam Johnson writes fiction that spans continents and cultures, earning recognition for both novels and short stories. His novel The Orphan Master's Son received the Pulitzer Prize in 2012, while his collection Fortune Smiles won the National Book Award in 2015. Johnson teaches English at Stanford University, where he continues to craft narratives that bridge historical research with contemporary storytelling.
quotes:
"How lucky we are that Adam Johnson has ignited for us this wild, epic, and utterly captivating skein of human history. His years of immersion in the Polynesian oral tradition and research into the Tu'itonga Empire shimmer through The Wayfinder at every twist, but his rollicking storytelling leads the way."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of A Visit from the Goon Squad and The Candy House

"Novels are long divorced from the oral tradition; few are designed to last beyond their reading. But some books—Gabriel García Márquez's One Hundred Years of Solitude (1967), for instance, or Larry McMurtry's Lonesome Dove (1985)—continue to be passed down, like legends. Predicting posterity is impossible, but The Wayfinder is this kind of work, modern and mythological. It is good enough, wondrous enough, to endure."

—The Wall Street Journal

"The Wayfinder is a singular achievement. Everything you can ask for in a reading experience, and, because it's Adam Johnson, a little bit more. There are lines in here so pure and direct and lyrical and right, they make my teeth ache."

—Stephen Graham Jones, author of The New York Times Bestseller The Buffalo Hunter Hunter

title: All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days
subtitle: The True Story of the American Woman at the Heart of the German Resistance to Hitler
long_summary:
A young American woman pursuing her doctorate in 1930s Germany finds herself at the center of history's most dangerous resistance movement. What begins as intimate gatherings in a Berlin apartment transforms into an elaborate network of spies, saboteurs, and revolutionaries operating in the shadow of Nazi terror.

Mildred Harnack's journey from Milwaukee graduate student to underground leader unfolds against the backdrop of Hitler's rise to absolute power. She orchestrates daring missions to save Jewish lives, coordinates acts of sabotage against the Reich, and establishes covert channels to feed crucial intelligence to Allied forces. Her network grows from a handful of idealistic activists into Berlin's most significant resistance operation, with members risking everything to distribute anti-Nazi propaganda throughout the city.

Rebecca Donner reconstructs her great-great-aunt's extraordinary life using a treasure trove of personal correspondence, clandestine prison communications, and recently declassified intelligence files. The result reveals not just one woman's incredible courage, but the complex web of ordinary Germans who chose to resist fascism despite knowing the ultimate price. This meticulously researched account illuminates a hidden chapter of World War II history and the American woman who became the sole U.S. citizen to command German resistance operations.
short_summary: The astonishing true story of Mildred Harnack, the only American to lead German resistance against Hitler. Donner masterfully reconstructs her great-great-aunt's life through letters, prison notes, and declassified documents.
author_bios: Rebecca Donner received a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2022 and served as Biography Fellow at the Leon Levy Center for Biography from 2018-19. She has been honored with two fellowships from Yaddo and additional support from the Ucross Foundation. Donner's writing has been featured in the New York Times and Bookforum. This marks her third published work, following two well-received novels that established her reputation in literary fiction.
quotes:
"At once boldly imagined and lovingly researched, All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days sets the remarkable story of resistance fighter Mildred Harnack against the backdrop of daily life in Germany as Hitler tightened his grip on the nation. Epic in sweep, written with a novelist's attention to detail and a historian's perspective on social and political forces, this book opens up new possibilities for biography."

—Ruth Franklin, winner of the NBCC Award for Biography, author of Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life

"Extraordinarily intimate… Wilder and more expansive than a standard-issue biography… a real-life thriller with a cruel ending—not to mention an account of Hitler's ascent from attention-seeking buffoon to genocidal Führer."

—Jennifer Szalai, New York Times

"A stunning biography... Donner's research is impeccable, and her fluid prose and vivid character sketches keep the pages turning…This standout history isn't to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Marbles
subtitle: Mania, Depression, Michelangelo, and Me: A Graphic Memoir
long_summary:
At twenty-nine, cartoonist Ellen Forney receives a diagnosis that changes everything: bipolar disorder. The revelation launches her into a complex journey between two competing fears—the chaos of untreated mental illness and the possibility that medication might silence her artistic voice forever.

Forney turns her investigative eye toward the enduring myth that creativity and madness are inseparable partners. Through research and personal reflection, she examines the lives of artists like van Gogh and Plath, questioning whether suffering truly fuels great art or if this belief simply romanticizes genuine pain.

Using her signature black-and-white illustrations, Forney documents the reality of living with a mood disorder—the medical appointments, medication trials, and ongoing negotiation between wellness and creative expression. Her memoir refuses easy answers, instead offering an honest examination of what it means to seek balance when your brain chemistry resists stability. The result is both deeply personal testimony and broader cultural critique of how we understand the relationship between mental health and artistic achievement.
short_summary: Cartoonist Ellen Forney chronicles her bipolar diagnosis and the search for stability without sacrificing creativity. Part memoir, part investigation into the mythology of the tortured artist.
author_bios: Ellen Forney makes her home in Seattle alongside her partner. Her work earned recognition through The Stranger Genius Award for Literature in 2012, and she received the National Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis Gradiva Award the following year in 2013.
quotes:
"Witty and insightful…The long journey of medication and therapy is kept from gloom by Forney's lively, likable cartooning … Readers struggling with their own mania or depression will find Forney good company, and others searching for insight into the minds of troubled artists will find Forney an engaging storyteller."

—Publishers Weekly

"Not only does her conversational intimacy draw readers in, but her drawings perfectly capture the exhilarating frenzy of mania and the dark void of depression….Forney's story should resonate with those grappling with similar issues, while her artistry should appeal to a wide readership."

—Kirkus

"Marbles isn't just a great story; it's proof that artists don't have to be tortured to be brilliant."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: We Do Not Part
long_summary:
An emergency call from a hospitalized friend sends Kyungha racing through a brutal snowstorm to reach a remote house on Jeju Island. Her mission seems simple: rescue a white bird named Ama before it's too late. But as the blizzard intensifies and darkness closes in, what begins as an act of compassion transforms into something far more complex and terrifying.

Han Kang crafts a narrative that moves between the tangible world of ice and wind and the shadowy realm where memory and reality converge. The story excavates painful truths about Korea's suppressed past, giving voice to experiences long silenced by official histories. Through the lens of two women's deep bond, the novel examines how violence echoes across generations and how friendship can become both sanctuary and burden.

This is literature that operates on multiple levels—a survival story, a ghost tale, and a meditation on the weight of remembering what others would prefer to forget. Han Kang demonstrates how the most intimate human connections can become vessels for understanding broader historical trauma, creating a work that honors both individual relationships and collective memory.
short_summary: Through a harrowing winter journey to save a friend's beloved bird, Han Kang weaves a haunting meditation on friendship, memory, and Korea's buried history.
author_bios: Born in South Korea in 1970, Han Kang has established herself as one of contemporary literature's most distinctive voices. Her novels include The Vegetarian, which earned the International Booker Prize, along with Human Acts, The White Book, Greek Lessons, and We Do Not Part. Han Kang received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2024, cementing her position as a major literary figure.
quotes:
"Even through the veil of translation, the quiet intricacy of the author's prose glitters throughout . . . a mysterious novel about history and friendship [that] offers no easy answers."

—Kirkus Reviews, starred review

"A visionary novel about history, trauma, art and its tremendous costs. Han Kang is one of the most powerfully gifted writers in the world. With each work, she transforms her readers, and rewrites the possibilities of the novel as a form."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies

"A disquietingly beautiful novel about the impossibility of waking up from the nightmare of history. Hang Kang's prose, as delicate as footprints in the snow or a palimpsest of shadows, conjures up the specters haunting a nation, a family, a friendship. Unforgettable."

—Hernan Diaz, Pulitzer Prize winning author of Trust

title: The Good Nurse
subtitle: A True Story of Medicine, Madness, and Murder
long_summary:
For sixteen years, a trusted healthcare worker moved between hospitals, systematically ending patients' lives while institutions failed to connect the dots. Charles Graeber's investigation into this medical nightmare reveals how bureaucratic indifference and institutional self-protection created the perfect environment for unprecedented harm.

The story centers on a web of relationships that made detection nearly impossible—colleagues who considered the perpetrator a friend, administrators who prioritized public image over patient welfare, and a healthcare system designed to protect itself rather than those it serves. Through extensive interviews and documentary evidence, including recorded conversations with the killer himself, Graeber reconstructs both the crimes and the institutional failures that enabled them.

The narrative transforms from horror story to procedural thriller as investigators and healthcare workers begin to piece together the pattern. At its core lies a moral reckoning: the choice between personal loyalty and professional duty, between institutional silence and public safety. This investigation exposes fundamental flaws in how American healthcare operates while honoring those who risked everything to stop the killing.
short_summary: The terrifying true story of Charlie Cullen, a nurse who killed hundreds of patients while hospitals looked the other way. Investigative journalism at its most gripping and necessary.
author_bios: Charles Graeber's investigative work has earned him recognition including an Overseas Press Club award for Outstanding International Journalism, an Edgar nomination, and a British Medical Association citation of merit. His journalism appears in publications such as The New Yorker, New York Magazine, GQ, Bloomberg Businessweek, Vogue, MIT Technology Review, and The New York Times. Graeber's writing has been featured in collections including The Best American Crime Writing and The Best American Science Writing. An Iowa native, he currently resides near the coast.
quotes:
"A stunning book...that should and does bring to mind In Cold Blood....the story appeals to prurient interests, as does any graphic tale of true crime. But THE GOOD NURSE succeeds in being about much more than Mr. Cullen's murderous kinks. The causes of his pathology are not interesting. But the eagerness of ambitious hospital administrators to cover up his misdeeds is revelatory. And the police investigation that brought him down is a thriller in every sense of that word."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"The most terrifying book published this year. It is also one of the most thoughtful.... From a long series of conversations with Cullen, the detectives who solved the case and Amy, a nurse who once was Cullen's best friend and eventually got him to confess, among many other sources, Graeber has crafted a book that is a revelation. THE GOOD NURSE is gripping, sad, suspenseful, rhythmic and beautifully documented (the endnotes to this book are impressive)."

—Kirkus

"Graeber doesn't pull punches... A deeply unsettling addition to the true crime genre."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Writers & Lovers
long_summary:
At thirty-one, Casey Peabody finds herself caught between worlds. Grieving her mother's unexpected death and nursing wounds from a failed romance, she's landed in Massachusetts with little more than mounting debt and stubborn hope. The former golf prodigy now serves tables around Harvard Square, pouring her remaining energy into a novel that has consumed six years of her life.

While her peers have settled into conventional paths, Casey clings fiercely to her artistic ambitions. Her cramped, damp quarters beside a garage become the unlikely sanctuary where she wrestles with both her manuscript and her future. The situation grows more complicated when she finds herself drawn to two men who represent vastly different possibilities for her life.

This is the story of someone standing at a crossroads, where youthful idealism meets adult reality. Casey must navigate the impossible mathematics of survival while protecting the creative spark that defines her. King crafts an intimate portrait of artistic struggle, examining how we choose between security and passion, and what it costs to remain true to our deepest aspirations when the world seems determined to pull us in other directions.
short_summary: Casey Peabody waits tables in Harvard Square while writing a novel that's consumed six years of her life. Reeling from her mother's death and torn between two lovers, she faces the brutal choice between creative dreams and practical survival.
author_bios: Lily King has written six novels, including Euphoria and Writers & Lovers, along with the story collection Five Tuesdays in Winter. Her fiction has earned numerous honors, including the Kirkus Prize, the New England Book Award for Fiction, the Maine Book Award for Fiction, and a Whiting Award. King's novels have reached international audiences through translation into twenty-eight languages. She makes her home in Portland, Maine, and her work has appeared on the New York Times bestseller list.
quotes:
"Writers & Lovers made me happy. Even as the narrator grieves the loss of her mother and struggles to make art and keep a roof over her head, the novel is suffused with hopefulness and kindness. Lily King writes with a great generosity of spirit."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Lily King is one of our great literary treasures and Writers & Lovers is suffused with her brilliance. It is captivating, potent, incisive, and wise, a moving story of grief, and recovering from grief, and of a young woman finding her courage for life."

—Madeline Miller, author of Circe

"Elegant… The nimble, astute narration appeals. This meditation on the passing of youth is touching and ruefully funny."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Survival Is a Promise
subtitle: The Eternal Life of Audre Lorde
long_summary:
Most readers know Audre Lorde through her celebrated essays and memorable quotes about difference and identity. Yet this focus has obscured a crucial dimension of her vision: her profound connection to the earth itself.

Alexis Pauline Gumbs transforms our understanding of Lorde by diving into previously untapped archives, revealing an artist whose relationship with the natural world went far beyond metaphor. Lorde saw geology, weather patterns, and living ecosystems as literal teachers for navigating existence as a Black feminist lesbian warrior poet. Her concept of survival extended beyond personal resilience to encompass our collective relationship with a changing planet.

This groundbreaking biography refuses traditional chronological structure, instead moving through Lorde's life like natural forces themselves—cyclical, interconnected, eternal. Gumbs positions Lorde not just as a literary icon but as a cosmic presence whose ecological consciousness offers urgent guidance for our planetary moment. The result is both intimate portrait and expansive meditation on what it means to live ethically within earth's transformative cycles.
short_summary: Drawing on previously unexplored archives, Gumbs reveals how Audre Lorde's ecological vision offers radical lessons for surviving on a planet in transformation. Biography becomes cosmic meditation.
author_bios: Alexis Pauline Gumbs has written multiple poetry collections and Undrowned: Black Feminist Lessons from Marine Animals, which earned her a Whiting Writers' Award in 2022. The following year, she received a Windham Campbell Prize for poetry. She makes her home in Durham, North Carolina.
quotes:
"Layered and original . . . Gumbs's book revels in Lorde's lush multiplicity, moving through the ebbs and flows of her life with both precision and lyricism and expanding the limits of what a biography can be and hold and feel like . . . The result is a prismatic work of art."

—Danielle Amir Jackson, The Atlantic

"An endless constellation of everyone who affected and was affected by Lorde . . . Survival is a Promise admirably demonstrates the breadth and depth of Lorde's journey from Harlem to the stars . . . By recounting Lorde's story outside linear chronology, and putting her alongside the rivers, forests, radio waves and obsidian, Gumbs is faithful to her subject's great desire to be something more eternal. But Survival is a Promise finally shows that this cosmic life is achieved through grounded and deep human work."

—Zito Madu, The Washington Post

"An award-winning poet, writer, feminist and activist in her own right, Gumbs is among the first researchers to delve into Lorde's manuscript archives. The resulting book highlights the late author's commitment to interrogating what it means to survive on this planet—and how Lorde's radical understanding of ecology can guide us today."

—Erika Taylor, NPR

title: Skippy Dies
long_summary:
A student's sudden death at an elite Dublin boarding school becomes the lens through which Paul Murray examines the complex ecosystem of teenage life. The tragedy illuminates the interconnected stories of Seabrook College's inhabitants: a brilliant but lonely boy obsessed with theoretical physics, a dangerous drug dealer, ambitious faculty members, and a cast of adolescents navigating the treacherous waters between childhood and adulthood.

Murray weaves together multiple perspectives to create a kaleidoscopic view of modern education, where academic pressure, social hierarchies, and personal demons collide. The novel moves between comedy and heartbreak as it reveals how seemingly disparate lives—students struggling with identity, teachers grappling with their own failures, administrators pursuing misguided reforms—intersect in unexpected ways.

Beneath its darkly humorous surface, this sprawling narrative interrogates what happens when institutions fail the young people they're meant to protect. Murray captures the absurdity and genuine pain of adolescence while building toward revelations that reframe everything we thought we understood about the central tragedy.
short_summary: When Skippy dies in a Dublin doughnut shop, his death unravels the lives of students and teachers at an elite Irish boarding school. Murray crafts a sprawling, darkly comic epic about adolescence, love, and modern life's absurdities.
author_bios: Born in Dublin in 1975, Paul Murray gained recognition with his first novel An Evening of Long Goodbyes, which earned shortlist nominations for both the Whitbread First Novel Award and Kerry Group Irish Fiction Award. His second book, Skippy Dies, received a Booker Prize longlist selection and became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award. Murray's third novel, The Mark and the Void, claimed the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize and appeared on Time magazine's Top 10 Fiction Books list.
quotes:
"Extravagantly entertaining . . . One of the great pleasures of this novel is how confidently [Paul Murray] addresses such disparate topics as quantum physics, video games, early-20th-century mysticism, celebrity infatuation, drug dealing, Irish folklore and pornography . . . Six hundred sixty-one pages may seem like a lot to devote to a bunch of flatulence-obsessed kids, but that daunting length is part and parcel of the cause to which Skippy Dies, in the end, is most devoted. Teenagers, though they may not always act like it, are human beings, and their sadness and loneliness (and their triumphs, no matter how temporary) are as momentous as any adult's And novels about them-if they're as smart and funny and touching as Skippy Dies-can be just as long as they like."

—Dan Kois, The New York Times

"Murray's humor and inventiveness never flag. And despite a serious theme-what happens to boys and men when they realize the world isn't the sparkly planetarium they had hoped for-Skippy Dies leaves you feeling hopeful and hungry for life. Just not for doughnuts."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Dazzling . . . If killing your protagonist with more than 600 pages to go sounds audacious, it's nothing compared with the literary feats Murray pulls off in this hilarious, moving and wise book . . . It's the Moby Dick of Irish prep schools . . . Murray is an expansive writer, bouncing around in time, tense and point of view. He's unafraid to tempt sentimentality, to write directly at his deep themes, to employ shameless cliffhangers. And he's talented enough to get away with most of it . . . The mixture of tones is the book's true triumph, oscillating the banal with the sublime, the silly with the terrifying, the sweet with the tragic. In short, it's like childhood. In shorter, like life . . . Murray makes the right choices, refusing to spare kid and kidult alike the gorgeous harshness of the world, filled as it is with 'a sadness everyone can recognize, a sadness that is binding and homelike."

—Jess Walter, The Washington Post

title: Challenger
subtitle: A True Story of Heroism and Disaster on the Edge of Space
long_summary:
Seventy-three seconds after liftoff, the space shuttle Challenger disintegrated in full view of a horrified nation, claiming seven lives including teacher Christa McAuliffe. This catastrophe marked a brutal end to America's space-age optimism and exposed fatal flaws in the shuttle program.

Adam Higginbotham reconstructs the events through exhaustive research, tracing the personal journeys of the doomed astronauts while revealing the institutional failures that sealed their fate. The narrative exposes how engineers' safety concerns were systematically dismissed, how budget pressures overrode caution, and how organizational dysfunction created a culture where disaster became inevitable.

Beyond the technical breakdown, this account illuminates the human cost of bureaucratic hubris. Higginbotham chronicles the dedicated test pilots, visionary designers, and committed crew members who believed in the mission, even as warning signs accumulated around them. The result is both an intimate portrait of those lost and a damning indictment of the forces that failed them, capturing a moment when America's technological confidence collided with harsh reality.
short_summary: The definitive account of the 1986 Challenger disaster reveals how political pressure and ignored warnings led to tragedy. Higginbotham masterfully weaves together human stories with technical detail in this gripping investigation.
author_bios: Adam Higginbotham contributes to major publications including The New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, Wired, GQ, and Smithsonian. He has written Midnight in Chernobyl, which received the William E. Colby Award and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Nonfiction, along with Challenger: A True Story of Heroism and Disaster on the Edge of Space. Higginbotham currently resides in New York City with his family.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . Challenger is a remarkable book. It manages to be a whodunit that stretches hundreds of pages, a heart-pounding thriller even though readers already know the ending. The passion and ideals at the heart of human spaceflight come through, which only adds to the tragedy of understanding how many chances there were to save the astronauts aboard. Our faith in the systems that run our world is really faith in our fellow man—a chilling reality to remember."

—The Atlantic

"Superb . . . In the hands of Higginbotham, the narrative comes to life in a fresh telling fueled by meticulous detail and exacting prose. While familiar, the story is rendered dreamlike so that readers can't help but hope, as it unfolds page by page, that somehow the outcome this time will be different. . . . A compelling and exhaustively researched chronicle of the calamity that traces its full arc—the evolution of the enabling culture that allowed it, the terrible day itself, and its enduring legacy."

—The Washington Post

"Higginbotham is an intrepid journalist and skillful storyteller who takes care to humanize the dozens of major and minor players involved in NASA's many successful, and occasionally catastrophic, space missions. . . . For cynical Americans, disaster buffs, and engineers, Challenger will be a quick, devastating read. In Higginbotham's deft hands, the human element—sometimes heroic, sometimes cloaked in doublespeak and bluster—shines through the many technical aspects of this story, a constant reminder that every decision was made by people weighing risks versus expediency, their minds distorted by power, money, politics, and yes-men. It's a universal story that transcends time."

—The New York Times

title: The Slip
long_summary:
A boxing gym in late '90s Austin becomes the crossroads where multiple lives intersect in unexpected ways. Nathaniel Rothstein discovers confidence and purpose within the gym's walls, guided by an enigmatic former fighter, only to mysteriously disappear one summer night. Meanwhile, Charles Rex navigates his own search for belonging and connection in a world that offers little of either.

Years pass before Nathaniel's uncle receives information that reignites hope and launches a investigation into what really happened. The search pulls together an unlikely constellation of characters—struggling twins, an ambitious young police officer, and Alexis Cepeda, a talented boxer whose journey to America involved assuming someone else's identity.

Schaefer constructs a sprawling narrative that examines how people reinvent themselves when circumstances demand it. The novel questions what we're willing to sacrifice for acceptance, and whether true transformation comes from changing who we are or finally embracing it. Set against Austin's evolving landscape, these intersecting stories build toward revelations that illuminate the complex ways our lives shape and are shaped by the communities we choose.
short_summary: In 1998 Austin, a teenage boy finds himself through boxing, then disappears without a trace. Schaefer's debut weaves together stories of identity and transformation in an ambitious exploration of contemporary America.
author_bios: Lucas Schaefer makes his literary debut with The Slip, having written the novel while living in Austin with his family. This marks his first published work of fiction.
quotes:
"Schaefer's narration is wildly, transgressively hilarious, reminiscent of Philip Roth's early novels...This is a high-wire act, but the breadth of Schaefer's affection feels as wide as the depth of his comedy."

—The Washington Post

"Quite simply, The Slip is everything an epic novel should be, everything you want an epic novel to be: symphonic, expansive, irresistibly engrossing, utterly unpredictable. It is immense in ambition, bursting with language, dauntless in scope and imagination; an ode to the infinite crossroads of life that lead each soul to its present moment. That this is a debut staggers me."

—Téa Obreht, New York Times bestselling author of The Tiger's Wife

"Wildly ambitious and immensely rewarding...Schaefer grants depths of vulnerability to even the novel's least sympathetic characters...Suffice it to say, you're unlikely to read a more impressive first novel this year."

—The New York Times

title: The Book of Aron
long_summary:
In Nazi-occupied Warsaw, young Aron navigates a world where childhood has been obliterated by hunger, fear, and violence. As his family struggles to survive in the ghetto's crushing conditions, Aron becomes part of a dangerous network of children who slip through cracks in the quarantine walls, smuggling food and goods to keep their loved ones alive. Each day brings new threats—corrupt officials, informants, and the ever-present terror of Nazi patrols.

After losing his family, Aron finds sanctuary with Janusz Korczak, the renowned pediatrician and children's advocate who continues his work even as the ghetto closes around them. In Korczak's orphanage, Aron discovers moments of unexpected humanity amid the horror, but the shadow of deportation grows longer each day.

Shepard captures the Holocaust through the eyes of a child who refuses to surrender his voice, even in history's darkest hour. The narrative balances devastating loss with flashes of dark humor and resilience, creating a portrait of survival that honors both the victims and the complexity of human nature under impossible circumstances. This is literature that bears witness while celebrating the indomitable spirit of those who lived to tell their stories.
short_summary: Young Aron smuggles contraband through Warsaw's ghetto walls, fighting to keep his family alive during the Holocaust. Shepard transforms this harrowing story into something mesmerizing and unforgettable through a child's eyes.
author_bios: Jim Shepard has published seven novels and five story collections, establishing himself as one of America's most distinctive literary voices. The Book of Aron earned him the PEN New England Award, the Sophie Brody Medal, the Ribalow Prize, and the Clark Fiction Prize, while also receiving a National Jewish Book Award nomination. His story collection Like You'd Understand, Anyway won The Story Prize and was a National Book Award finalist. Shepard's work regularly appears in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, The Paris Review, and The Atlantic, and has been featured in The Best American Short Stories and The PEN/O. Henry Prize Stories. He is a professor at Williams College.
quotes:
"Shepard has created a stark masterpiece. His brilliant, iconic book ranks with the best literature that explores the dark side of the human soul."

—Linda Diebel, The Toronto Star

"An immensely rewarding, shocking and beautiful book. . . . Shepard, who for years has been one of this country's greatest fiction writers, is as original here as he has ever been. . . . Aron himself becomes an unforgettable character almost instantly."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"A masterpiece. . . a remarkable novel destined to join the shelf of essential Holocaust literature. . . . a story of such startling candor about the complexity of heroism that it challenges each of us to greater courage. . . . Shepard has created something transcendent and timeless."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Violinist's Thumb
subtitle: And Other Lost Tales of Love, War, and Genius, as Written by Our Genetic Code
long_summary:
DNA holds the secrets behind humanity's most fascinating quirks and mysteries, and Sam Kean serves as the perfect guide through this microscopic universe. Why do some women become obsessed with cats? What genetic anomaly leaves certain people born completely without fingerprints? How did survivors of atomic bombs pass on unexpected traits to their children?

Kean digs into the genetic code that shaped historical figures like Einstein and JFK, revealing surprising truths about intelligence, physical traits, and human evolution. The book's title references those rare individuals whose extraordinary thumb flexibility allows them to master the violin in ways others simply cannot—a perfect metaphor for how our genes create the beautiful diversity of human capability.

This isn't your typical science textbook. Kean transforms complex genetic concepts into captivating stories that span centuries and continents, showing how our DNA connects us to both our ancient ancestors and our future evolution. Each chapter uncovers another layer of the genetic puzzle that makes us uniquely human.
short_summary: From crazy cat ladies to Einstein's genius, Kean transforms genetics into witty tales of human oddity and scientific discovery. Science writing that's actually fun to read.
author_bios: Sam Kean has written several New York Times bestsellers including The Bastard Brigade, Caesar's Last Breath (which won the Guardian's Science Book of the Year), The Tale of the Dueling Neurosurgeons, The Violinist's Thumb, and The Disappearing Spoon. His writing has been recognized twice as a PEN/E.O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award finalist and appears in prestigious publications like The New Yorker, The Atlantic, and New York Times Magazine. Kean regularly contributes to NPR programs including Radiolab, All Things Considered, Science Friday, and Fresh Air, while his podcast reached #1 on iTunes science charts.
quotes:
"Kean is one of America's smartest and most charming science writers, and his new book could be perfect for summer readers who prefer some substance with their fun."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"As he did in his debut bestseller, The Disappearing Spoon, Sam Kean educates readers about a facet of science with wonderfully witty prose and enthralling anecdotes....Kean's thoughtful, humorous book is a joy to read."

—Publishers Weekly

"Kean's accessible genetic overview, written for the layman, is often as simple and elegant as a double helix."

—Keith Staskiewicz, Entertainment Weekly

title: Super Sad True Love Story
long_summary:
Middle-aged Lenny Abramov exists as a relic in tomorrow's America, clinging to obsolete habits like diary-writing and book-reading while his nation crumbles around him. This balding, health-conscious hypochondriac works in the immortality business, yet faces his own mortality daily. His life takes an unexpected turn through Eunice Park, a sharp-tongued college graduate whose youth and cruelty both attract and devastate him.

Their unlikely romance unfolds against escalating national chaos—economic meltdown, street violence, and foreign intervention threaten to end American civilization entirely. Shteyngart crafts a biting commentary on digital-age relationships and cultural decay, examining how human connection survives when society itself becomes disposable. Through Lenny's desperate attempts to preserve both love and country, the novel questions what remains essentially human in an increasingly dehumanized world.

This satirical vision feels uncomfortably prophetic, blending dark humor with genuine pathos as characters navigate technological alienation and political collapse. The story interrogates whether authentic emotion can flourish amid artificial everything else.
short_summary: Lenny Abramov keeps a diary in dystopian America where books are obsolete and the country's collapsing. His obsession with a cruel younger woman becomes both salvation and torment in Shteyngart's prescient satire.
author_bios: Born in Leningrad in 1972, Gary Shteyngart immigrated to the United States at age seven. His first novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, earned both the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. Absurdistan, his second work, received recognition as one of The New York Times Book Review's 10 Best Books of the Year. Super Sad True Love Story captured the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize, while his memoir Little Failure became a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. Publishers in thirty countries have released his works internationally.
quotes:
"[A] smart send-up of our info-overload age… Love Story is funny, on-target, and ultimately sad as it captures the absurdity and anxiety of navigating an increasingly out-of-control world."

—Entertainment Weekly

"This cyber-apocalyptic vision of an American future seems eerily like the present, in a bleak comedy that is even more frightening than funny. Though Shteyngart received rave reviews for his first two novels (The Russian Debutante's Daughter, 2001; Absurdistan, 2006), those appear in retrospect to be trial runs for his third and darkest to date."

—Kirkus

"[A] profane and dizzying satire, a dystopic vision of the future as convincing-and, in its way, as frightening as Cormac McCarthy's The Road. It's also a pointedly old-fashioned May-December love story. . . . a heartbreaker worthy of its title, this is Shteyngart's best yet."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Invisible Kingdom
subtitle: Reimagining Chronic Illness
long_summary:
Millions of Americans battle conditions that medical science struggles to categorize or treat effectively—from autoimmune disorders to post-treatment Lyme disease to long COVID. These ailments share a troubling characteristic: they remain largely invisible to a healthcare system built around clear diagnoses and straightforward treatments.

Meghan O'Rourke examines how our medical framework fails those whose symptoms defy conventional understanding. Her investigation reveals troubling patterns in who gets dismissed—women, working-class patients, and communities of color face particular skepticism when presenting with complex, hard-to-pin-down health problems.

Combining personal narrative with rigorous research, O'Rourke spent years interviewing medical professionals, researchers, and fellow patients to understand why certain illnesses exist in medicine's blind spots. Her analysis challenges fundamental assumptions about what constitutes legitimate disease and questions why conditions without simple explanations are so often met with doubt rather than curiosity.

The result is both an urgent call for medical reform and a compassionate guide for anyone navigating the frustrating terrain of chronic illness. O'Rourke's work illuminates not just individual suffering, but systemic failures that demand a complete rethinking of how we understand bodies, symptoms, and healing.
short_summary: O'Rourke combines memoir, medical investigation, and cultural criticism to expose how millions suffer from misunderstood chronic illnesses. Essential reading that argues for a complete reimagining of how we approach disease and healing.
genres: Health & Fitness / Diseases & Conditions / Immune & Autoimmune
author_bios: Meghan O'Rourke has written The Long Goodbye alongside three poetry collections: Sun in Days, Once, and Halflife. Currently serving as editor of The Yale Review, she has earned recognition including a Guggenheim Fellowship among other honors. Her work regularly appears in major publications such as The Atlantic Monthly, The New Yorker, and The New York Times.
quotes:
"The Invisible Kingdom is a vivid account of the lived experience of chronic illness. Meghan O'Rourke exposes a system of thought in which people with poorly understood illnesses are dismissed and disbelieved, blamed for their own suffering, and left to take desperate risks in pursuit of treatment. Crucially, her perspective offers insight into how we can do better."

—Eula Biss, author of On Immunity & Having and Being Had

"An authentically original voice and, perhaps more startlingly, an authentically original perspective….The book is not only a memoir of her illness, but also a document of years of research."

—Andrew Solomon, National Book Award-winning author of The Noonday Demon, in The New York Times

"With a poet's sensibility, journalist's rigor, and patient's personal investment, O'Rourke sheds light on the physical and mental toll of having a mysterious chronic illness…Readers will be left in awe."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Telling Room
subtitle: A Tale of Love, Betrayal, Revenge, and the World's Greatest Piece of Cheese
long_summary:
A chance encounter with an extraordinary cheese sets journalist Michael Paterniti on an unlikely odyssey. Years after first hearing about Paramo de Guzman—a mystical Spanish cheese rumored to unlock forgotten memories—Paterniti finally makes his way to the remote Castilian village where it's created.

What starts as a food lover's pilgrimage quickly transforms into something far more complex. The village of Guzman harbors secrets that run much deeper than ancient cheesemaking traditions, and its charismatic creator, Ambrosio, proves to be a figure of contradictions—brilliant yet broken, magnetic yet mysterious.

As Paterniti delves deeper into village life, he finds himself entangled in a web of hidden truths and long-buried revelations. The idyllic rural fantasy he imagined crumbles, replaced by a reality that challenges everything he thought he knew about memory, truth, and the stories we tell ourselves. This masterful work of literary journalism reveals how the search for one perfect thing can lead us into the most unexpected territories of human experience.
short_summary: Ten years after encountering a legendary Spanish cheese, journalist Michael Paterniti travels to a tiny Castilian village to meet its maker. What begins as culinary quest becomes something far more mysterious and profound.
author_bios: Michael Paterniti has earned recognition as both journalist and author through works including Driving Mr. Albert and The Telling Room, with the latter receiving acclaim from NPR, Entertainment Weekly, and The Christian Science Monitor as one of the year's finest books. His writing appears regularly in major publications such as The New York Times Magazine, National Geographic, Harper's, Outside, Esquire, and GQ, where he serves as correspondent. Paterniti has received eight National Magazine Award nominations along with an NEA grant and two MacDowell Fellowships. He helped establish a children's storytelling center and makes his home in Portland, Maine with his wife and three children.
quotes:
"Michael Paterniti is one of the best living practitioners of the art of literary journalism, able to fully elucidate and humanize the everyday and the epic. In his hands, every subject, every moment of personal or global upheaval, is treated with the same curiosity, respect, empathy, and clear-eyed wisdom."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"For my money, Paterniti is one of the most expansive and joyful writers around-big-hearted and humane and funny. This book is a wild and amazing ride."

—George Saunders, author of Tenth of December

"Captivating…Paterniti's writing sings, whether he's talking about how food activates memory, or the joys of watching his children grow."

—NPR

title: Mecca
long_summary:
At the intersection of California's complex identity stands Johnny Frias, a highway patrol officer whose heritage reflects the state's layered history of Indigenous peoples and Spanish colonization. Two decades ago, a split-second decision during a violent confrontation forever altered his trajectory and set in motion ripple effects he never anticipated.

Straight constructs a sprawling narrative that follows these reverberations as they touch the lives of Californians struggling to find their place in a land that promises much but delivers unevenly. The novel examines how individual moments of crisis can bind strangers together across time and geography, creating unexpected bonds between people who might otherwise remain invisible to one another.

Through interconnected stories, the book interrogates questions of belonging, survival, and identity in contemporary California. Straight illuminates the experiences of those who call the state home not by choice or opportunity, but through generations of rootedness—people whose stories rarely surface in popular narratives about the Golden State. The result is a multifaceted exploration of what it means to endure and persist in a place where the promise of reinvention often overshadows the reality of those who have nowhere else to go.
short_summary: Johnny Frias carries California's Indigenous and Spanish heritage in his blood, but a violent encounter from his past as a highway patrol officer ignites unexpected connections across communities. Straight weaves an epic portrait of native Californians fighting for survival and belonging.
author_bios: Susan Straight brings decades of storytelling experience to her work, having written nine novels including Mecca, A Million Nightingales, and Highwire Moon, along with the memoir In the Country of Women. Her literary achievements include finalist recognition for the National Book Award, Kirkus Prize, and Dayton Literary Peace Prize, plus honors such as the Lannan Prize, O. Henry Award, Edgar Award, Guggenheim Fellowship, and Robert Kirsch Award for lifetime achievement. A native of Riverside, California, Susan Straight continues to make her home there with her family.
quotes:
"Susan Straight writes like a dream. In Mecca the landscapes and the passions of California come vividly and unforgettably to life, adding another triumph to her oeuvre, and one more gift to the literature of the West. Once again, Straight shines a light on the people at the margins of our seemingly prosperous country, illuminating their lives with her boundless empathy."

—Héctor Tobar, author of Deep Down Dark & The Last Great Road Bum

"A terrifically engaging novel about a network of people related by blood, love and duty . . . what might be most impressive about this novel is how large it becomes without ever feeling bloated by extraneous plotlines or too neatly sewn up . . . Remarkably, the most persistent impression here is not one of suffering but of determined survival, even triumph."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Against the alternating currents of boosterism and doom-speak so often associated with California, Susan Straight's Mecca focuses on the people who don't usually appear in literary and cinematic depictions of a place so big it could be a country. A heartbreaker from beginning to end, Mecca both shocks and moves in its powerful and unrelenting portrait of this sunny, fiery state."

—Viet Thanh Nguyen, author of The Sympathizer and The Committed

title: A Wilder Shore
subtitle: The Romantic Odyssey of Fanny and Robert Louis Stevenson
long_summary:
Two unlikely souls collided in 19th-century France: Robert Louis Stevenson, a restless Scottish writer from privilege, and Fanny Van de Grift, a resilient Nevada miner's wife with a family to protect. Their romance defied every Victorian convention, blossoming into a creative alliance that would reshape both their destinies.

Their marriage became a catalyst for artistic brilliance and personal transformation. As Louis struggled with debilitating health issues, Fanny emerged as his fierce protector and creative collaborator. Together they wandered the globe—from European artistic communities to the Pacific islands—chasing inspiration and sanctuary. In Samoa, they discovered more than refuge; they found a cause worth fighting for alongside indigenous peoples resisting colonial oppression.

Fanny's influence extended far beyond caregiving. She documented their adventures with vivid prose, shaped Louis's manuscripts, and created the conditions that allowed him to produce immortal works. Their relationship weathered intense conflicts and passionate reconciliations, sustained by unwavering mutual admiration. This biography illuminates how an unconventional partnership between two fierce individualists generated some of literature's most beloved treasures.
short_summary: The extraordinary story of Robert Louis Stevenson and Fanny Van de Grift's creative partnership. Their unconventional marriage defied Victorian norms and fueled the creation of literary classics like Treasure Island and Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.
author_bios: Camille Peri works as both author and journalist, having established the influential website Mothers Who Think during her time at Salon. Her editorial projects include the nationally bestselling Mothers Who Think: Tales of Real-Life Parenthood and Because I Said So: 33 Mothers Write About Children, Sex, Men, Aging, Faith, Race & Themselves, which earned an American Book Award. Peri's journalism has appeared in publications including Vogue, Ladies' Home Journal, Los Angeles Times Magazine, Mother Jones, and the San Francisco Chronicle.
quotes:
"[Peri's] richly researched and vivid double portrait makes a convincing case that Fanny pulled off a rare feat, enabling Louis's genius to mature while releasing his boyish energies . . . I am grateful to Peri for telling the story of their marriage, in all its complexity, with sympathy and spirit."

—Phyllis Rose, The Atlantic

"[A book] to lift your spirits . . . [Fanny's] support allowed Stevenson to write without distraction, and their circumvention of Victorian norms allowed for a marriage where love flourished."

—The Washington Post

"Ambitious . . . Speaking for myself, after reading A Wilder Shore, I'm inspired to do two things: I want to reread Robert Louis Stevenson's three great works of fiction: Treasure Island, Kidnapped and The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. And, I want to schedule a séance with Fanny to get some one-on-one instruction on how to live more fearlessly as a woman."

—NPR

title: All This Could Be Different
long_summary:
Twenty-two-year-old Sneha graduates into economic uncertainty, clutching an office job in Milwaukee that offers more than just a paycheck—it promises the freedom to build a life on her own terms. Between spreadsheets and client calls, she discovers the intoxicating possibility of choosing her own family, whether that means covering restaurant bills for friends or wiring money across continents to her parents.

Romance arrives in the form of Marina, a dancer whose very presence seems to shift the air in rooms, yet remains mysteriously elusive. As Sneha navigates her attraction to women and the vulnerability that comes with wanting someone who feels perpetually out of reach, her carefully constructed stability begins to show cracks. Friendships deepen even as personal histories threaten to surface, and the safety net of employment proves thinner than expected.

Mathews captures the particular ache of early adulthood—the simultaneous hunger for connection and fear of being truly known. This debut illuminates how young people create chosen families from scratch, building bridges across difference while wrestling with their own capacity for honesty and trust.
short_summary: Fresh out of college, Sneha navigates corporate life, queer love, and friendship in recession-era Milwaukee. Mathews crafts an extraordinary debut about building community and finding home as a young immigrant in America.
author_bios: Sarah Thankam Mathews spent her childhood moving between Oman and India before making her way to the United States as a teenager. Her writing has earned recognition through fellowships from both the Asian American Writers Workshop and the Iowa Writers Workshop. All This Could Be Different marks her debut as a novelist.
quotes:
"All This Could Be Different is an extraordinary novel, spiny and delicate, scathingly funny and wildly moving. Sarah Thankam Mathews is a brilliant writer, one whose every ringing sentence holds both bite and heart."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates & Furies, Arcadia & Matrix

"Mathews's poignant and illuminating debut centers on an aloof 22-year-old Indian immigrant whose first job out of college brings her to the Midwest . . . Mathews [charts] the wonders of community-building, delving into the strenuous work that goes into sustaining meaningful friendships as well as the heartbreak that ensues when connections are fractured by dishonesty. [A] thoughtful exploration of how the legacies of trauma make an impact."

—Publishers Weekly

"Sarah Thankam Mathews's All This Could Be Different is a deeply honest and compelling testimony. It is breathtaking in its beauty and profound in its meaning. Mathews captures the complexities, contradictions, and dissonances of life with astounding aplomb and care. All This Could Be Different is quietly epic."

—Robert Jones, Jr., author of The Prophets

title: The Cold Millions
long_summary:
Two brothers navigate the harsh realities of Depression-era America, surviving on freight trains and temporary labor. Sixteen-year-old Rye craves stability and security, while his charismatic older brother Gig throws himself into labor organizing, believing collective action can transform their brutal world.

Their precarious existence takes a dramatic turn through an unlikely encounter with Ursula the Great, a vaudeville performer whose act features a live cougar. She draws them into the orbit of a ruthless mining baron whose obsession with her proves as dangerous as his business practices. As Gig's union activities intensify, Rye discovers his own political awakening through Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, a fierce young activist whose commitment to workers' rights and women's suffrage challenges everything he thought he knew about fighting injustice.

The brothers' relationship fractures under the weight of their different dreams and the escalating violence surrounding the labor movement. Rye must choose between the safety of anonymity and the risks of standing up for his beliefs, questioning whether small victories matter in the face of seemingly insurmountable systemic oppression. This sprawling tale captures a pivotal moment in American history through the intimate lens of family loyalty tested by conscience and circumstance.
short_summary: Two brothers ride the rails in early twentieth-century America—one an idealistic union fighter, the other just trying to survive. When they encounter a vaudeville performer and her dangerous patron, their bond faces the ultimate test.
author_bios: Jess Walter has written eight novels, including bestselling titles So Far Gone, The Cold Millions, and Beautiful Ruins, along with The Zero, which was a National Book Award Finalist, and the Edgar Award-winning Citizen Vince. His collections of short fiction, The Angel of Rome and We Live in Water, have earned him the O. Henry Prize and Pushcart Prize, with stories appearing three times in Best American Short Stories. Walter's journalism earned him a Pulitzer Prize nomination in 1993 for his Ruby Ridge reporting, and he makes his home in Spokane, Washington.
quotes:
"The fact that the same author has written books as wildly different and all as transporting as The Zero, The Financial Lives of the Poets, Beautiful Ruins, and now this latest tour de force is testimony to Walter's protean storytelling power and astounding ability to set a scene, any scene…. We have heard that Jess Walter writes nonstop: Seven days a week, 365 days a year. Please, never stop."

—Kirkus

"A work of irresistible characters, harrowing adventures and rip-roaring fun … bursting with a dazzling range of outrageous characters…. One of the most captivating novels of the year."

—The Washington Post

"The Cold Millions is a literary unicorn: a book about socio-economic disparity that's also a page-turner, a postmodern experiment that reads like a potboiler, and a beautiful, lyric hymn to the power of social unrest in American history. It's funny and harrowing, sweet and violent, innocent and experienced; it walks a dozen tightropes. Jess Walter is a national treasure."

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See & Cloud Cuckoo Land

title: The Last Train to Zona Verde
subtitle: My Ultimate African Safari
long_summary:
At eighty, Paul Theroux sets out on what he calls his last African adventure, a solo journey that winds through southern Africa's most challenging territories. This expedition strips away any romantic notions of the continent, revealing instead a landscape marked by economic struggle and colonial wounds that refuse to heal.

Theroux's path leads him through encounters that range from profound to absurd—conversations with locals who share their stories of survival, observations of well-meaning but often misguided development efforts, and moments of stark beauty amid overwhelming hardship. His writing balances admiration for Africa's resilience with unflinching criticism of its failures, while simultaneously questioning his own role as an outsider bearing witness.

The book operates on two levels: a geographic expedition across diverse terrains and cultures, and a more personal meditation on aging, purpose, and the ethics of observation. Theroux refuses to offer simple solutions or sentimental conclusions, instead presenting a complex portrait of both the places he visits and his own evolving understanding of what it means to truly see a place versus merely passing through it.
short_summary: Theroux's final African odyssey takes him from Cape Town to Angola's remote reaches. A master travel writer confronts mortality, privilege, and the continent's harsh realities with unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Paul Theroux has written numerous celebrated novels and travel narratives throughout his distinguished career. His fiction includes Burma Sahib, The Bad Angel Brothers, The Lower River, Jungle Lovers, and The Mosquito Coast, while his travel writing encompasses The Last Train to Zona Verde, Ghost Train to the Eastern Star, On the Plain of Snakes, and Dark Star Safari. Theroux divides his time between Hawaii and Cape Cod.
quotes:
"Theroux's prose is as vividly descriptive and atmospheric as ever and, though a bit curmudgeonly, he's still wide open to raw, painful interactions between his psyche and his surroundings."

—Publishers Weekly (starred review)

"In this intensely personal book, Theroux honestly confronts racism, stigma, privilege and expectations...Reading this enlightening book won't only open a window into Theroux's mind, it will also impart a deeper understanding of Africa and travel in general."

—Kirkus

"Thoroughly engrossing—from Cape Town to Namibia to the Okavango Delta, Theroux is his inimitable, delightfully grouchy and incisive self…At times tragic, often comical and always gorgeously written, this is a paean to a continent, by a writer unafraid to give it some tough love."

—Washington Post

"He has no illusions about the fact that he is just a passing visitor (a privileged one at that), but that doesn't make his observations, or exquisite writing, any less engaging."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Theroux is at his best when he tells their stories, happy and sad...Theroux's great mission had always been to transport us beyond that reading chair, to challenge himself—and thus, to challenge us."

—The Boston Globe

title: There's Always This Year
subtitle: On Basketball and Ascension
long_summary:
In the basketball courts of 1990s Columbus, Ohio, dreams collided with reality as future superstars emerged while others faded into memory. Hanif Abdurraqib uses this backdrop to craft a deeply personal meditation on ambition, community, and the stories we tell ourselves about success.

Blending memoir with cultural criticism, Abdurraqib examines the mythology surrounding athletic greatness and the quieter narratives of those who don't make it to the spotlight. His reflections move seamlessly between the hardwood and family dynamics, exploring absent fathers, present mentors, and the weight of expectations that shape young lives.

This isn't simply a book about basketball—it's an investigation into how sports become vessels for our deepest hopes and fears. Abdurraqib's signature lyrical prose transforms observations about jump shots and championship dreams into broader questions about identity, place, and the communities that sustain us. The result is a work that captures both the exhilaration of athletic achievement and the bittersweet reality that most dreams don't unfold as planned.
short_summary: Basketball becomes poetry in Abdurraqib's mixtape-memoir of Ohio gyms, LeBron, and fatherhood. A meditation on making it and not making it, propulsive as a fast break and tender as a huddle.
genres: Social Science / Cultural & Ethnic Studies / American / African American & Black Studies
author_bios: Based in Columbus, Ohio, Hanif Abdurraqib works as a poet, essayist, and cultural critic who received a MacArthur Foundation "Genius" grant. A Little Devil in America earned him the Carnegie Medal and Gordon Burns Prize while becoming a National Book Award finalist. His earlier work They Can't Kill Us Until They Kill Us received recognition from NPR, Esquire, and numerous other publications as a standout book. Go Ahead in the Rain achieved New York Times bestseller status and finalist recognition for the National Book Critics Circle Award.
quotes:
"Mesmerizing . . . not only the most original sports book I've ever read but one of the most moving books I've ever read, period."

—Steve James, director of Hoop Dreams

"Lyrically stunning and profoundly moving, the confessional text wanders through a variety of topics without ever losing its vulnerability, insight, or focus . . . A formally inventive, gorgeously personal triumph."

—Kirkus

"Cultural critic Abdurraqib returns with a triumphant meditation on basketball and belonging. . . . The narrative works as if by alchemy, forging personal anecdotes, sports history, and cultural analysis into a bracing contemplation of the relationship between sports teams and their communities. This is another slam dunk for Abdurraqib."

—Publishers Weekly

title: A Little Life
long_summary:
In the heart of New York City, four young men begin their adult lives with little more than dreams and each other. As years turn to decades, their bond deepens around Jude, whose quiet brilliance masks a devastating past that threatens to consume him.

This extraordinary novel peels back the layers of friendship, revealing how intimacy can both heal and wound. Jude's history emerges gradually, painting a portrait of survival that challenges everything his friends thought they knew about resilience and love. The story moves through time like a slow revelation, showing how the families we choose can become more vital than the ones we inherit.

Yanagihara crafts an intimate epic about the weight of memory and the fierce loyalty that binds people together through unimaginable darkness. At its heart lies a meditation on whether love alone can overcome the deepest wounds, and how friendship becomes both sanctuary and witness to a life lived in the shadow of trauma.
short_summary: Four friends navigate decades of friendship in New York, bound together by their devotion to enigmatic Jude. An unflinching exploration of trauma, love, and the families we choose for ourselves.
author_bios: Hanya Yanagihara makes her home in New York City, where she has established herself as one of contemporary literature's most fearless voices.
quotes:
"With her sensitivity to everything from the emotional nuance to the play of light inside a subway car, Yanagihara is superb at capturing the radiant moments of beauty, warmth and kindness that help redeem the bad stuff. In A Little Life, it's life's evanescent blessings that maybe, but only maybe, can save you."

—John Powers, NPR

"Through insightful detail and her decade-by-decade examination of these people's lives, Yanagihara has drawn a deeply realized character study that inspires as much as devastates. It's a life, just like everyone else's, but in Yanagihara's hands, it's also tender and large, affecting and transcendent; not a little life at all."

—Nicole Lee, The Washington Post

"This is a novel that values the everyday over the extraordinary, the push and pull of human relationships—and the book's effect is cumulative. There is real pleasure in following characters over such a long period, as they react to setbacks and successes, and, in some cases, change. By the time the characters reach their 50s and the story arrives at its moving conclusion, readers will be attached and find them very hard to forget."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Soldiers and Kings
subtitle: Survival and Hope in the World of Human Smuggling
long_summary:
The underground networks that move people across borders operate in shadows, far from public understanding. Most accounts reduce these complex operations to simple narratives of criminality, missing the human complexity beneath.

Anthropologist Jason De León spent seven years gaining access to this hidden ecosystem, documenting the lives of those who guide migrants through Mexico's dangerous terrain. His research reveals a world populated not by the stereotypical villains of popular imagination, but by individuals navigating impossible circumstances—foot soldiers entering a treacherous trade, conflicted leaders managing desperate crews, and seasoned guides grappling with moral ambiguity.

At the center of this ethnographic investigation is one smuggler's attempt to escape the life that has defined him, complicated by unexpected love and the weight of past choices. De León's immersive approach transforms abstract policy debates into deeply personal stories, illuminating how global economic forces and border enforcement create the conditions that sustain this billion-dollar shadow economy. The result challenges readers to reconsider everything they think they know about migration, survival, and the human cost of fortress-like borders.
short_summary: Seven years embedded with human smugglers across Mexico yields this unprecedented look at the clandestine world of migration. De León's intimate, character-driven narrative follows coyotes trying to survive in a billion-dollar underground industry.
author_bios: Jason De León serves as professor of Anthropology and Chicana/o Studies at UCLA, where he also directs the Cotsen Institute of Archaeology. Through his leadership of the Undocumented Migration Project and recognition as a 2017 MacArthur Foundation Fellow, De León has established himself as a leading voice in migration studies. His earlier work, The Land of Open Graves: Living and Dying on the Migrant Trail, received numerous accolades for its groundbreaking research.
quotes:
"This is a real one. A work of extraordinary reportage and compassion, Soldiers and Kings takes us deep inside the lives of smugglers guiding desperate migrants across Latin America. One breathtaking scene follows another, rendered in vibrant, unsparing prose documenting grinding poverty and violence, but also young love and redemption. It will shock you, move you, and leave you changed."

—Matthew Desmond, Pulitzer Prize-winning and New York Times bestselling author of Evicted and Poverty, by America

"A harrowing account of the work of human smugglers in bringing aspirational immigrants to America's southern border...[and] an exemplary ethnography of central importance to any discussion of immigration policy or reform."

—Kirkus

"A rare inside look at human smuggling on the border . . . Smuggling, [De León] says, 'is not the problem.' But as his own book memorably recounts, in a world with no shortage of problems, it's nevertheless one of them."

—The New York Times

title: Herscht 07769
long_summary:
In the crumbling town of Kana, Florian Herscht inhabits two worlds that seem destined to collide. By day, he absorbs physics lessons that convince him the universe faces imminent collapse—a revelation so urgent he begins writing desperate letters to Angela Merkel. By night, he works for a local extremist leader whose obsession with Bach has turned violent after someone begins vandalizing the composer's monuments with wolf imagery.

Florian finds himself trapped between his employer's escalating hunt for the mysterious vandal and his own growing certainty that physical reality itself is unraveling. As actual wolves appear in the surrounding countryside, the boundary between Florian's apocalyptic fears and the town's simmering tensions begins to dissolve.

Krasznahorkai constructs this tale as a single, breathless sentence that mirrors the relentless momentum of particles in motion. The result is a darkly comic meditation on extremism, environmental crisis, and the peculiar helplessness of watching civilization fray at its edges. Through Florian's naive yet perceptive eyes, the novel captures the disorienting experience of living through collapse while ordinary life stubbornly continues.
short_summary: Written as one sprawling sentence, this urgent novel follows a gentle giant caught between neo-Nazis, particle physics, and a mysterious graffiti artist defacing Bach monuments in eastern Germany.
author_bios: Born in Gyula, Hungary, László Krasznahorkai received the 2015 Man Booker International Prize for lifetime achievement and won the 2019 National Book Award for Translated Literature. His distinctive literary voice has established him as one of contemporary fiction's most innovative practitioners.
quotes:
"The best new novel I have read this year is written in a single sentence that sprawls over 400 pages. Herscht 07769 by the Hungarian genius László Krasznahorkai [is] an urgent depiction of our global social and political crises, rendering our impotent slide into authoritarianism with compassionate clarity. It is also a book whose timeliness derives precisely from the way its unusual style disrupts the ordinary literary mechanics of time....A masterful study in what it means to keep trudging through a world that is always ending but will not end."

—Jacob Brogan, The Washington Post

"Krasznahorkai's latest postmodern experiment explores small-town discontents in post-unification eastern Germany. Brilliant, like all of Krasznahorkai's books—and just as challenging, though well worth the effort required."

—Kirkus

"Krasznahorkai's brilliantly cacophonous novel, which conveys the sense that the end is already here, and that the trappings of civilization are easier to scrape away than paint from stone. This stands with Krasznahorkai's best work."

—Publisher's Weekly

title: The War for Gloria
long_summary:
Fifteen-year-old Corey Goltz has always been the center of his mother Gloria's world in working-class Boston. Their tight bond faces its ultimate test when Gloria receives an ALS diagnosis that will gradually strip away her independence and mobility.

As medical bills mount and Gloria's condition deteriorates, Corey finds himself thrust into an adult role he never wanted. The situation becomes more complicated when his absent father Leonard suddenly resurfaces, bringing with him a magnetic personality that masks deeper character flaws. While Leonard presents himself as a solution to their problems, Corey begins to see through the carefully constructed facade.

Caught between his desperate love for his dying mother and his growing awareness of his father's manipulative nature, Corey faces impossible choices. The weight of caregiving responsibilities threatens to crush his adolescent spirit, while Leonard's toxic influence grows stronger. This raw examination of family loyalty asks how far someone will go to save the person they love most, and whether protecting one parent might require destroying the other.
short_summary: When fifteen-year-old Corey's mother is diagnosed with ALS, his charismatic but morally bankrupt father reappears. Shouldering crushing responsibility for her care, Corey must choose between protecting his mother and confronting his father's true nature.
author_bios: Atticus Lish has written two novels: The War for Gloria and Preparation for the Next Life. His debut work, Preparation for the Next Life, earned both the 2015 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the 2016 Grand Prix de Littérature Américaine. Lish currently resides in California.
quotes:
"Solemn, punishing, kinetic, in easy contact with dark areas of the psyche, and yet heartbreaking in its portrait of a mother and son facing her mortal illness . . . Lish's novel is powerful, intelligent, brooding and most of all convincing; it earns its emotions . . . It more than pays off on the promise of his first novel, Preparation for the Next Life, which won the 2015 PEN/Faulkner award . . . You never sense [Lish] is merely writing "quality fiction"; he seems to draw instead from a deep well of experience, especially when it comes to the tastes and textures of life on the economic margins . . . The War for Gloria works because the details are so casually drilled home . . . Gloria is this novel's great, glowing presence. Lish is exacting in his portraiture."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"The War For Gloria is an ambitious book with a lot to say about family loyalty and love . . . Lish is a sensational literary craftsman, using the words in his toolbelt to construct narrative that is at once coolly dispassionate and red hot with emotion . . . I will be thinking about The War For Gloria for a long time."

—Martha Anne Toll, NPR

"Unflinching and heartbreaking . . . Lish imbues the male characters' varied pitches of toxic masculinity with great sadness, smoothing the edges off their macho posturing, and he writes with devastating empathy of Gloria's highs and lows. This is a tremendous achievement."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Blue Nights
long_summary:
In the twilight of summer evenings, Joan Didion confronts the unthinkable reality of outliving her daughter. This memoir traces the contours of grief through a mother's relentless self-examination, as Didion scrutinizes every moment, every decision, searching for answers that may not exist.

Moving between past and present, the narrative shifts from Quintana's wedding day to fragments of childhood in California, each memory both precious and painful. Didion dissects her own maternal instincts with characteristic precision, questioning whether love alone was sufficient, whether warning signs went unheeded. The very act of remembering becomes both sanctuary and torment.

Simultaneously, Didion grapples with her own mortality and physical decline—a parallel loss that amplifies the central tragedy. The blue nights of the title represent those luminous summer hours that promise endless light while quietly announcing its inevitable end. This meditation on parenthood, aging, and survival strips away all pretense, leaving only the raw truth of what it means to continue living when the natural order has been shattered.
short_summary: Didion's devastating meditation on losing her daughter Quintana weaves together memory, aging, and the impossible questions of parenthood. Incisive and haunting—essential reading.
