"It could hardly be more engaging. The Pale King is by turns funny, shrewd, suspenseful, piercing, smart, terrifying and rousing."

—Laura Miller, Salon

title: Memorial
long_summary:
A relationship reaches a crossroads in this intimate portrait of two men navigating love's complexities. Benson teaches at a daycare while his partner Mike works as a chef, their Houston life built on shared routines and genuine affection. Everything shifts when Mike's dying father summons him to Japan, leaving Benson behind with Mike's formidable mother, Mitsuko.

The separation becomes a catalyst for profound change. In Japan, Mike confronts family secrets and cultural identity in ways that reshape his understanding of himself. Meanwhile, the unlikely pairing of Benson and Mitsuko creates an unexpectedly meaningful household dynamic. Without Mike as their anchor, Benson discovers his own capacity for growth and begins to envision possibilities he'd never dared consider.

This novel examines how crisis can either fortify relationships or expose their fundamental weaknesses. Through humor and emotional honesty, it captures the messy realities of modern love while celebrating the unconventional families we create. The story asks whether two people can evolve in different directions and still find their way back to each other.
short_summary: When Mike flies to Japan to see his dying father, his boyfriend Benson gets stuck with Mike's acerbic mother as a roommate. A tender, funny exploration of love's limits and family's unexpected forms.
author_bios: Bryan Washington has written Lot, Memorial, and Family Meal. He received recognition as a National Book Award 5 Under 35 Honoree and earned the Dylan Thomas Prize, the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award, the Ernest J. Gaines Award, two Lambda Literary Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. He currently lives in Tokyo.
quotes:
"Memorial dares to insist on the mundane, thoroughly lived life as a site of perennial hope, joy, and abundance. It casts a fresh take on the American family that becomes truer because of its disparate origins, the queerness of its genesis, and the buoyed wonder it finds in surviving grief and loss towards the rare and forgiving ground of difficult, hard-won love. All of this done in sentences clean and clear as cut glass. This book, in what feels like a new vision for the 21st century novel, made me happy."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

"Bryan Washington is an expert in illuminating the way we love. Memorial perfectly captures the lives lived in-between what we do and what we say, what we need and what we allow ourselves to have. It is a beautiful heartbreak."

—Mira Jacob, author of Good Talk

"Tender like a bruise, Memorial is a novel of uncommon depth and feeling. It is about everything that matters in life: love, loss, community and communion. Bryan Washington will take your breath away."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies & A Separation

title: I'm Glad My Mom Died
long_summary:
The entertainment industry promises fame and fortune, but for some child actors, the cost proves devastating. McCurdy's memoir reveals the dark reality behind her Nickelodeon success, tracing how her mother's relentless ambition transformed childhood into a series of calculated performances both on and off camera.

From extreme dieting regimens disguised as health consciousness to invasive control over every aspect of her personal life, McCurdy lived under constant surveillance designed to manufacture the perfect young star. Even as she landed coveted roles on hit shows like iCarly and Sam & Cat, the psychological toll mounted through anxiety, disordered eating, and a complete loss of personal autonomy.

The death of her controlling mother creates an unexpected crisis of identity rather than relief. Without the familiar framework of manipulation and demands, McCurdy must navigate recovery while questioning everything she thought she knew about love, success, and her own desires. Her journey toward genuine independence unfolds through therapy, career changes, and the radical act of making choices purely for herself. This memoir combines brutal honesty with unexpected humor, offering insight into how trauma shapes us and how healing requires dismantling even our most fundamental beliefs about family loyalty.
short_summary: Former Nickelodeon star Jennette McCurdy delivers a devastating memoir about surviving child stardom and an abusive mother. Raw, funny, and unflinchingly honest about eating disorders, addiction, and finding herself after fame.
author_bios: Jennette McCurdy wrote I'm Glad My Mom Died, which earned the 2023 American Library Association Alex Award and became a #1 New York Times bestseller. The memoir remained on bestseller lists for more than eighty weeks, reached readers in over thirty countries, and has sold more than three million copies worldwide. McCurdy serves as creator, writer, executive producer, director, and showrunner for an upcoming Apple TV+ series inspired by her book, featuring Jennifer Aniston. Her first novel, Half His Age, arrives in January 2026.
quotes:
"[A] layered account of a woman reckoning with love and violence at once…[Not] a flippant exposé of childhood stardom, nor an angry diatribe directed at an abuser. This complexity is what makes I'm Glad My Mom Died feel real…Some supposed literary types will think the immense popularity of I'm Glad My Mom Died—the hardcover initially sold out at many major bookstores—is merely the result of McCurdy's former stardom and modern culture's thirst for a sensational take. With its bold headline and bright cover featuring a smirking McCurdy holding a pink urn, the book feels deliberately marketed for virality, perfect for sharing on the internet and catching the eye of bookstore browsers. I've mentioned the title of this memoir to some people who have dismissed it out of hand, remarking that being glad one's parent is dead is crude and a sentiment that should be kept to oneself. But those people haven't read the book. McCurdy takes her time to remember difficult and complex moments of her life, staying true to her younger self while ultimately trying to come to terms with who she is as an independent adult. It's a triumph of the confessional genre."

—Nina Li Coomes, The Atlantic

"[An] explosive debut…insightful and incisive, heartbreaking and raw, McCurdy's narrative reveals a strong woman who triumphs over unimaginable pressure to emerge whole on the other side. Fans will be rapt."

—Publishers Weekly

"Delivered with captivating candor and grace."

—Kirkus

title: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
long_summary:
At the dawn of the new millennium, a Columbia graduate finds herself adrift despite possessing everything society deems valuable. Her gallery job feels meaningless, her relationships hollow, and the inheritance funding her Manhattan lifestyle can't fill the emptiness consuming her from within.

Faced with this existential void, she embarks on an audacious experiment: using a cocktail of psychiatric medications to essentially sleep away an entire year. What begins as an escape from modern life's superficiality becomes something far more complex—a radical rejection of societal expectations and a deep dive into the nature of consciousness itself.

Moshfegh crafts a protagonist whose privilege becomes both shield and prison, exploring how wealth and beauty can coexist with profound spiritual bankruptcy. The novel asks uncomfortable questions about what it means to be alive in a world that prioritizes surface over substance, and whether sometimes the most rational response to an irrational world is complete withdrawal.

This is a story that finds dark humor in despair and unexpected grace in surrender, examining the fine line between self-destruction and self-preservation.
short_summary: A young woman with every advantage decides to spend a year in drug-induced hibernation on the Upper East Side. Moshfegh's darkly funny novel transforms privileged ennui into something profound and devastating.
author_bios: Ottessa Moshfegh writes fiction and hails from New England. Her first novel Eileen earned recognition as a finalist for both the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Man Booker Prize, while taking home the PEN/Hemingway Award. Both My Year of Rest and Relaxation and Death in Her Hands became New York Times bestsellers. She has also published the story collection Homesick for Another World and the novella McGlue. Moshfegh currently resides in Southern California.
quotes:
"I don't think I'm ever going to get over Ottessa Moshfegh's My Year of Rest and Relaxation."

—Parul Sehgal, The New York Times

"A strange, exhilarating triumph…Moshfegh writes with a singular wit and clarity that, on its own, would be more than enough. (Her 2015 debut, Eileen, was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize, and Rest has already been optioned for film by Australian actress Margot Robbie). But the cumulative power of her narrative—and the sharp turn she takes in its last 30 pages—becomes nothing less than a revelation: sad, funny, astonishing, and unforgettable."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Bizarrely fascinating…Moshfegh knows how to spin perversity and provocation into fascination, and bleakness into surprising tenderness."

—NPR

title: The Interestings
long_summary:
At a creative summer camp in 1974, six teenagers forge an unbreakable connection that will define their lives for decades to come. What begins as shared artistic passion and youthful ambition evolves into something far more complex as these friends navigate the realities of adult life in an ever-changing world.

Jules dreams of comedy stardom but finds herself settling for something safer and more mundane. Jonah possesses remarkable musical ability yet abandons his craft entirely. Meanwhile, Ethan and Ash—now married to each other—soar to extraordinary heights, their artistic visions flourishing alongside their bank accounts. The group's bonds remain intact, but the vast disparities in their circumstances create unexpected tensions.

Wolitzer crafts a meditation on the unpredictable nature of success and the corrosive effects of comparison. The novel questions whether raw talent guarantees fulfillment, examines how privilege shapes opportunity, and reveals the subtle ways resentment can infiltrate even our most cherished relationships. Against the backdrop of a transforming New York City, these characters grapple with the gap between adolescent dreams and middle-aged reality, discovering that the most enduring friendships must somehow accommodate both love and envy.
short_summary: Six teenagers bond at arts camp the summer Nixon resigns, then navigate decades of diverging fortunes. Wolitzer masterfully examines how talent evolves—and how envy operates even within the closest friendships.
author_bios: Meg Wolitzer has written numerous acclaimed novels including The Interestings, The Uncoupling, The Ten-Year Nap, The Position, The Wife, and Sleepwalking, many of which have appeared on the New York Times bestseller list. She has also ventured into young adult fiction with Belzhar and makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Wolitzer is as precise and rigorous an observer of social status as Tom Wolfe; she is as incisive and pitiless and clear-eyed a chronicler of female-male tandems as Philip Roth or John Updike. . . . She writes at the eye-level. . . . Wolitzer is terrific at depicting the ambiguity of modern family life, its murky moral choices and thorny dilemmas."

—Chicago Tribune

"All of Wolitzer's characters are so articulate and insightful that it's a pleasure to listen to them think. . . . [Her] scenes are intensely observed and nuanced."

—The Atlantic

"Holds a mirror up to modern America, offering a shock of recognition amid the laughter."

—People

title: What If?
subtitle: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions
long_summary:
Ever wondered about the physics of impossible scenarios? Randall Munroe transforms bizarre reader questions into scientific adventures that are equal parts educational and entertaining. From the mechanics of light-speed baseball to survival odds during robot uprisings, he approaches each absurd inquiry with genuine scientific rigor.

Munroe doesn't just guess—he dives deep into research, running complex simulations and consulting actual experts to provide real answers to unreal questions. The result is a collection that makes advanced physics surprisingly accessible, wrapped in the same irreverent humor that made his webcomic famous. His characteristic stick-figure illustrations guide readers through calculations that frequently end in spectacular disasters or at least impressive explosions.

This compilation brings together fresh material alongside expanded versions of fan-favorite responses from his website. Whether you're curious about the practical limits of everyday activities or enjoy thought experiments that push scientific boundaries, Munroe's methodical approach to the impossible offers both genuine learning and consistent laughs.
short_summary: The creator of beloved webcomic xkcd tackles absurd hypothetical questions with rigorous science and signature humor. Munroe's answers are both hilarious and genuinely informative, making complex physics accessible through stick-figure wisdom.
author_bios: Randall Munroe created the webcomic xkcd and wrote the New York Times bestselling books What If?, What If? 2, Thing Explainer, and How To. Before becoming a full-time cartoonist in 2006, he worked as a roboticist at NASA. His contributions to science communication earned him recognition when asteroid 4942 Munroe received his name from the International Astronomical Union. He currently resides in Massachusetts.
quotes:
"What If? maintains a delightfully free-wheeling tone throughout, especially when complicated calculations lead to whimsical results...Despite all the hard facts and gigantic numbers, it never feels like a textbook—and you don't have to be a rocket scientist to enjoy it. A."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Catchy and approachable...There's plenty of scientific rigor behind his elaborate explanations but he punctuates them with sly humor and winningly primitive cartoon diagrams...A cut above so many popular science and technology books."

—NPR

"It's fun to watch as Munroe tackles each question and examines every possible complication with nerdy and methodical aplomb, his distinctive scribblings providing clever running commentary of peanut-gallery jokes as his train of thought (sometimes) happily derails. The delightfully demented What If? is the most fun you can have with math and science, short of becoming your own evil genius...We feel the tug of Munroe's playful yet existentially-tinged worldview, and all that geek logic and number-crunching becomes unexpectedly poignant."

—The Boston Globe

title: Girl, Woman, Other
long_summary:
Twelve Black British women navigate modern life in this genre-defying novel that captures the complexity of identity in contemporary Britain. The narrative follows characters like Amma, a playwright grappling with newfound success and questions of sexuality, and Shirley, an educator exhausted by the challenges of teaching in an underfunded system. Their paths cross with others including Carole, who has climbed the corporate ladder but struggles with her mother Bummi's concerns about cultural disconnection.

The cast ranges from a young nonbinary influencer to an elderly woman living in rural Northern England, each bringing their own perspective to questions of heritage, belonging, and what it means to be Black and British today. Evaristo examines how colonial legacies continue to shape lives while celebrating the resilience and diversity of her characters.

The novel's distinctive style abandons traditional punctuation in favor of flowing, verse-like passages that create a rhythmic, almost musical reading experience. Through humor and sharp observation, Evaristo illuminates the connections that bind these women together despite differences in age, class, and experience, crafting a multifaceted portrait of community and survival.
short_summary: Twelve Black British women's lives intersect across generations in this Booker Prize-winning novel. Evaristo weaves their stories with innovative, poetry-inspired prose that's both witty and deeply moving.
author_bios: Bernardine Evaristo made history as the first Black woman to win the Booker Prize for Girl, Woman, Other, which also earned the Women's Prize for Fiction and Dublin Literary Award among numerous honors. Beyond this global bestseller, she has published nine additional works including verse fiction, poetry, essays, and drama that explore African diaspora experiences. Currently serving as President of the Royal Society of Literature and Professor of Creative Writing at Brunel University London, Evaristo holds an Honorary Fellowship at St Anne's College, Oxford and was awarded an OBE in 2020. Her latest work is Manifesto: On Never Giving Up.
quotes:
"Among the bustling cast of characters in Evaristo's kaleidoscopic novel about the lives of a large group of Black British women are several indelible mother-daughter pairs who try—and often fail—to make sense of one another across generational, ideological, and economic divides . . . Even when these children and parents wound one another, Evaristo takes no sides, instead extending empathy and offering insights into what compels their sometimes maddening, sometimes relatable decisions."

—The Atlantic

"Girl, Woman, Other received half a Booker Prize, but it deserves all the glory . . . A breathtaking symphony of black women's voices, a clear-eyed survey of contemporary challenges that's nevertheless wonderfully life-affirming . . . Together, all these women present a cross-section of Britain that feels godlike in its scope and insight."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A big, busy novel with a large root system . . . Evaristo has a gift for appraising the lives of her characters with sympathy and grace while gently skewering some of their pretensions . . . Evaristo's lines are long, like Walt Whitman's or Allen Ginsberg's, and there are no periods at the ends of them. There's a looseness to her tone that gives this novel its buoyancy. Evaristo's wit helps too."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: Pulphead
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
America reveals its contradictions through the lens of John Jeremiah Sullivan's wandering curiosity. This collection of essays maps the cultural landscape from forgotten 19th-century scholars to reality TV stars turned entrepreneurs, finding unexpected connections across time and geography.

Sullivan's journey takes him deep into spaces where American identity crystallizes: a Christian music festival, the aftermath of natural disasters, the childhood homes of pop icons. His subjects range from obscure historical figures to contemporary celebrities, yet each encounter illuminates something essential about how myth and reality intertwine in American life.

The author approaches his subjects with equal parts skepticism and affection, revealing the absurdities and genuine pathos that coexist in our cultural moments. Whether tracing musical traditions through the South or examining the economics of fame, Sullivan uncovers the strange logic that drives American dreams and obsessions. His writing captures both the comedy and tragedy of contemporary life, offering readers a mirror that reflects familiar experiences in startling new ways.
short_summary: Sullivan dissects American pop culture with hilarious precision and hang-dog charm. From Christian rock festivals to MTV alumni, his essays reveal the age-old strangeness of how we live now.
author_bios: John Jeremiah Sullivan contributes regularly to The New York Times Magazine and makes his home in Wilmington, North Carolina. He has published Blood Horses: Notes of a Sportswriter's Son along with the essay collection Pulphead. Sullivan's recognition includes the Whiting Award, National Magazine Award, James Beard Writing Award, and Windham-Campbell Prize.
quotes:
"[The essays in Pulphead are] among the liveliest magazine features written by anyone in the past 10 years . . . What they have in common, though, whether low or high of brow, is their author's essential curiosity about the world, his eye for the perfect detail, and his great good humor in revealing both his subjects' and his own foibles . . . a collection that shows why Sullivan might be the best magazine writer around."

—NPR

"One ascendant talent who deserves to be widely read and encouraged is John Jeremiah Sullivan . . . Pulphead is one of the most involving collections of essays to appear in many a year."

—Larry McMurtry, Harper's Magazine

"The age-old strangeness of American pop culture gets dissected with hilarious and revelatory precision…Sullivan writes an extraordinary prose that's stuffed with off-beat insight gleaned from rapt, appalled observations and suffused with a hang-dog charm. The result is an arresting take on the American imagination."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Delicious Foods
long_summary:
Tragedy fractures a family in ways that seem irreparable. A mother, consumed by loss and seeking escape through substances, disappears into a nightmare she never saw coming—a labor camp disguised as legitimate work, where debt becomes chains and freedom dissolves into fiction.

Miles away, her young son refuses to accept her absence. His childhood becomes a quest, shaped by the hollow space where his mother should be. He carries questions that have no easy answers and hope that defies logic.

James Hannaham constructs this story through an audacious narrative choice: three distinct perspectives that include the very substance that helped destroy one life while ironically becoming a voice in its telling. The result challenges readers to confront uncomfortable truths about exploitation that persists in contemporary America.

This isn't simply a story about victimization—it's an examination of resilience, the complexity of human bonds, and the ways people survive systems designed to break them. Hannaham weaves social critique with intimate family drama, creating a work that operates simultaneously as urgent political commentary and deeply personal exploration of what we owe each other, especially those we love most.
short_summary: When grief drives Darlene to drugs, she vanishes into a world of modern slavery while her young son searches desperately for her. Told through three voices—including the drug itself—this is both devastating social commentary and profound love story.
author_bios: James Hannaham wrote God Says No, which became a Stonewall Book Award finalist, and Delicious Foods, recipient of both the PEN/Faulkner Award and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award. His novel Delicious Foods also earned finalist recognition for the Los Angeles Times Book Prize and Dayton Literary Peace Prize, and appeared as a New York Times Notable Book. Hannaham teaches at the Pratt Institute and makes his home in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"This is a book of astonishing originality and power. In Delicious Foods, James Hannaham has created a wholly new world--a hallucinatory place shot through with struggle and terrible deeds--but one never lacking light or hope. Hannaham reinvents the Southern gothic with prose at once brutal and lyrical and drop-dead gorgeous. This is a hell of a novel."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King and The Circle

"James Hannaham's new novel is a tour de force. Gripping, haunting, and deeply moving, it beguiles the reader with the urgent immediacy of its characters' lives, while also reverberating with universal themes of freedom and enslavement, love and survival."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize winner for A Visit from the Goon Squad

"Hannaham's seductive and disturbing second novel grips the reader from page one... The light he shines on the realities of racial injustice, human trafficking, drug abuse, and exploitation make a deep imprint on the reader. But as devastating as Darlene, Eddie, and the other laborers' situations become, the heroic themes of love, forgiveness, and redemption carry this memorable story."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Memorial Drive
subtitle: A Daughter's Memoir
long_summary:
The murder of a parent transforms everything—identity, memory, the very ground beneath your feet. For poet Natasha Trethewey, this devastating reality arrived at nineteen, forever altering her understanding of love, violence, and survival.

In this searing memoir, Trethewey excavates the circumstances that led to her mother's death, tracing the threads of racism and domestic violence that created a perfect storm of tragedy. Growing up biracial in the Jim Crow South, both mother and daughter navigated a world hostile to their very existence. Trethewey examines how her mother's choices—born from limited options in a segregated society—ultimately placed them both in danger.

The author's poetic sensibility illuminates every page as she reconstructs not just the crime itself, but the complex woman her mother was: loving, vulnerable, fierce, and trapped. This is both an intimate portrait of grief and a broader indictment of the systems that failed to protect a woman in peril. Trethewey transforms personal devastation into art that speaks to anyone who has loved someone they couldn't save.
short_summary: When Trethewey was nineteen, her former stepfather murdered her mother in a crime that would define both women's legacies. A luminous memoir about grief, resilience, and the enduring effects of racism and domestic violence.
author_bios: Natasha Trethewey served as United States Poet Laureate and has published five collections of poetry alongside works of creative nonfiction. Currently Board of Trustees Professor of English at Northwestern University, Trethewey received the Pulitzer Prize in Poetry in 2007 for Native Guard. Her writing consistently examines themes of memory, history, and identity in the American South.
quotes:
"Beautifully composed, achingly sad...This profound story of the horrors of domestic abuse and a daughter's eternal love for her mother will linger long after the book's last page is turned."

—Publishers Weekly

"[A] graceful, moving memoir...Delicate prose distinguishes a narrative of tragedy and grief."

—Kirkus

"Natasha Trethewey has composed a riveting memoir that reads like a detective story about her mother's murder by a malevolent ex-husband. It reads with all the poise and clarity of Trethewey's unforgettable poetry—heartrending without a trace of pathos, wise and smart at once, unforgettable. The short section her mother penned as she was trying to escape the marriage moved me to tears. I read the book in one gulp and expect to reread it more than once. A must-read classic."

—Mary Karr, author of The Liars' Club, Cherry & Lit

title: The Iliad
long_summary:
Homer's ancient epic of war and divine intervention finds fresh voice in this bold new translation that strips away centuries of interpretive dust. The story unfolds across the blood-soaked plains of Troy, where heroes clash in combat that will echo through eternity, yet the real drama lies in quieter moments—a father pleading for his son's body, warriors confronting their own mortality, gods manipulating human fate from their celestial realm.

This version captures both the poem's savage intensity and its profound meditation on honor, loss, and the price of glory. The translation reveals characters who feel startlingly modern in their complexity: Achilles wrestling with rage and grief, Hector torn between duty and family, Helen bearing the weight of a war fought in her name. Ancient Greek warfare becomes visceral and immediate, while the epic's exploration of what it means to be human—caught between divine will and personal choice—resonates with contemporary urgency. The result transforms one of literature's foundational texts into something that reads like breaking news from humanity's earliest recorded conflicts.
short_summary: Homer's epic war poem gets the Emily Wilson treatment. Her translation captures both the thunder of battle and the intimate grief of loss with language that feels urgent and alive.
author_bios: The poet known as HOMER likely lived sometime between 900 and 700 B.C.E., though historical details about his life remain elusive. Traditional accounts describe him as a blind storyteller from Ionia, but these cannot be confirmed. The Iliad and The Odyssey emerged from ancient oral tradition and stand as foundational works of Western literature. Emily Wilson teaches classical studies at the University of Pennsylvania and has received both MacArthur and Guggenheim fellowships. Her translation work includes plays by Sophocles, Euripides, and Seneca.
quotes:
"Emily Wilson's translation of the Iliad brings Homer's great war story to rousing new life….propulsive….buoyant and expressive."

—Natalie Haynes, The New York Times

"Readable, relevant and from the heart, this is the Iliad we have all been waiting for, whether we knew it or not."

—Naoíse Mac Sweeney, The Washington Post

"Masterful…A bloody tale of ancient war and grief comes to vibrant life in modern-day English. Wilson has again presented a Homer that sings."

—Kirkus

title: Fourth of July Creek
long_summary:
Pete Snow works as a social worker in Montana's isolated communities, where his efforts to help vulnerable children often clash with local mistrust of outside authority. His world shifts dramatically after discovering Benjamin Pearl, an eleven-year-old boy surviving in harsh wilderness conditions with his father Jeremiah, a deeply paranoid man preparing for societal collapse.

Through patient work, Pete manages to build a tentative connection with this unusual family. Yet his professional dedication to protecting children stands in stark contrast to his personal failures—particularly his fractured relationship with his own teenage daughter. The situation becomes increasingly complex as federal agents begin investigating Jeremiah's activities, transforming Pete's quiet intervention into something far more dangerous.

Against Montana's unforgiving landscape, the novel examines how America's foundational values—liberty, self-reliance, suspicion of authority—can twist into something destructive. Henderson crafts a story that questions what we owe to each other, especially the most vulnerable among us, while exploring how good intentions can spiral beyond anyone's control.
short_summary: When a Montana social worker encounters a survivalist and his feral son living off-grid, their fragile trust unravels as FBI attention and personal tragedy collide in devastating ways.
author_bios: Smith Henderson wrote Fourth of July Creek and divides his time between California and Montana. His work captures the complexities of American life in remote Western communities.
quotes:
"This book left me awestruck; a stunning debut which reads like the work of a writer at the height of his power. Begins with the story of one struggling man and his family and soon seems to encompass and address all of modern America's problems. Fourth of July Creek is a masterful achievement and Smith Henderson is certain to end up a household name."

—Philipp Meyer, New York Times bestselling author of The Son

"Fourth of July Creek is also an impressive book —deeply so. Cormac McCarthy's shadow may loom heavy across the prose—darkling it, to use one of the McCarthyesque verbs that Henderson deploys—but the story this prose conveys, and the manner in which Henderson unfurls it, bears its own unalloyed power."

—The New York Times

"Breathtaking...heartbreaking…Henderson's immersive, colorful style makes this scenic journey worthwhile. He's a curious kind of hard-boiled poet - part Raymond Chandler, part Denis Johnson."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Largesse of the Sea Maiden
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In his final work, Denis Johnson delivers five stories that grapple with life's fundamental questions through the lens of characters confronting their own mortality. These narratives unfold with Johnson's characteristic blend of the mystical and mundane, where ordinary moments suddenly reveal profound truths about existence.

The collection showcases Johnson's ability to find beauty in life's darker corners, as his protagonists navigate aging, loss, and the weight of accumulated experience. Rather than offering easy answers, these stories embrace ambiguity and wonder, suggesting that meaning often emerges from unexpected places. Johnson's prose maintains its distinctive rhythm while taking on a more reflective quality, as if the author himself is taking stock of what matters most.

Each piece functions as both a standalone meditation and part of a larger conversation about how we make sense of our brief time here. The result is a collection that feels like a quiet but essential conversation about what it means to be human, delivered with the wisdom of a writer who understood that the most important truths often arrive disguised as simple stories.
short_summary: Johnson's final collection finds the master storyteller contemplating mortality and transcendence with his signature luminous prose. A posthumous gift that cements his status as one of literature's essential voices.
author_bios: Denis Johnson created an extraordinary literary legacy spanning nine novels, one novella, two short story collections, five poetry volumes, two play collections, and a work of reportage. His novel Tree of Smoke earned the 2007 National Book Award and received a 2007 Pulitzer Prize nomination, while Train Dreams was recognized as a 2012 Pulitzer Prize finalist.
quotes:
"A posthumous masterpiece . . . With this book, Johnson has only cemented his status as one of his generation's greatest writers. . . . Each story in Largesse is weighted by an astonishing humanity, a generosity of spirit that's evened out by lyrical dissections of time's passage and the mysteries of connection. . . . Here's an author turning toward the past, conjuring up the ghosts of those he's loved and lost, writing of wild experiences with affectionate abandon. Few have linked themselves between the reader and the page so intimately—so cosmically—as he does here."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Nobody ever wrote like Denis Johnson. Nobody ever came close . . . We're just left with this miraculous book, these perfect stories, the last words from one of the world's greatest writers."

—NPR

"Sly, open-ended, and meticulously wise . . . Johnson, in all his work, aimed to locate the hidden, actual face of things. But the new stories build without those miraculous balls of hail, and their truths are necessarily deeper, and more precise. . . . [Johnson] is a writer whose ambitions were in their own way as broad and burgeoning as Dostoyevsky's. He is for all time."

—Rachel Kushner, Bookforum

title: Replaceable You
subtitle: Adventures in Human Anatomy
long_summary:
Medical innovation has always required creative problem-solving, from ancient physicians fashioning artificial noses to modern scientists attempting to print organs in laboratories. Mary Roach investigates this fascinating intersection of desperation and ingenuity, where the limits of human biology meet cutting-edge technology.

The author's investigation spans continents and decades, examining both historical oddities and futuristic possibilities. She witnesses surgeons performing sight-restoring operations in remote locations, observes the meticulous work of tissue recovery specialists during overnight procedures, and explores facilities where researchers cultivate hair follicles using stem cell technology. Her reporting also takes her inside specialized medical environments, from sterile research facilities housing genetically modified pigs to rehabilitation centers housing vintage medical equipment.

Roach tackles the profound ethical and practical dilemmas that emerge as replacement medicine advances. At what point does amputation become preferable to reconstruction? How do we navigate the psychological complexities of receiving organs from other species or laboratory-grown tissues? Through her signature blend of scientific rigor and irreverent humor, she illuminates both the promise and peculiarities of humanity's ongoing effort to transcend biological limitations.
short_summary: Roach explores medicine's quest to replace failing body parts, from brass noses to 3D-printed organs. Her journey through burn units, pig farms, and stem cell labs reveals the wondrous complexities of rebuilding human anatomy.
genres: Science / Life Sciences / Human Anatomy & Physiology
author_bios: Mary Roach has written seven bestselling nonfiction books, including Grunt, Stiff, and Fuzz. Her work regularly appears in publications such as National Geographic and the New York Times Magazine. She currently resides in California.
quotes:
"Since she burst onto the scene with 2003's Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers, the science writer Mary Roach has been grossing readers out with curiosity, humanity — and alarming gusto. And we can't look away."

—The New York Times

"This book is so good and it's on my list because it's right on topic with Gone Before Goodbye. Replaceable You by Mary Roach is all about how in the future, we will be able to replace every organ in our body that fails."

—Reese Witherspoon

"Science writer Roach engagingly explores the past, present, and future of fabricated replacement body parts and regenerative medicine. She has previously penned books about the body, including Gulp (2013), and brings her distinctive nonfiction writing style, headlined by curiosity, enthusiasm, and lots of humor, to this subject, too. . . .  Highly recommended reading for those curious about 'fixes' for the body and the world of biotechnology."

—Tony Miksanek - Booklist

title: In the Kingdom of Ice
subtitle: The Grand and Terrible Polar Voyage of the USS Jeannette
long_summary:
At the dawn of America's Gilded Age, newspaper magnate James Gordon Bennett Jr. orchestrated what he hoped would become the century's greatest feat of exploration. His target: the mysterious North Pole, still shrouded in scientific speculation and romantic theory. Bennett selected Captain George Washington De Long to lead this ambitious quest aboard the USS Jeannette, betting that American ingenuity could conquer the planet's final frontier.

What began as a voyage fueled by national pride and scientific curiosity transformed into an epic test of human endurance. The Arctic Ocean proved far more treacherous than anyone anticipated, trapping the Jeannette in an iron grip of pack ice for nearly two years before crushing the vessel entirely. Suddenly, thirty-two men found themselves stranded on shifting ice floes, hundreds of miles from civilization, with winter closing in and their supplies dwindling.

Their only hope lay in an impossible journey across one of Earth's most hostile environments. This account reveals how ordinary sailors and officers faced extraordinary circumstances, where each decision meant the difference between salvation and death, and where the line between heroism and desperation blurred in the endless white expanse of the polar wilderness.
short_summary: The true story of the USS Jeannette's doomed 1879 Arctic expedition, when 32 men became trapped in ice and fought for survival across a thousand miles of frozen wasteland. Gripping polar adventure meets Gilded Age ambition.
author_bios: Hampton Sides has written several New York Times bestselling historical works, including On Desperate Ground, In the Kingdom of Ice, Hellhound on his Trail, Blood and Thunder, and Ghost Soldiers, which received the PEN USA Award for Nonfiction. He makes his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
quotes:
"First-rate polar history and adventure narrative...wonderfully evocative.... Sides vividly recounts the horrors [of the voyage]. In the Kingdom of Ice is a harrowing story, well told."

—The New York Times

"Unforgettable…a pulse-racing epic of endurance set against an exceedingly bizarre Arctic backdrop…[Sides'] descriptions of the physical challenges the men face and the eerie landscape that surrounds them are masterful. As De Long and his crew attempt to save themselves, the story grows in suspense and psychological complexity…More strange and fantastic turns follow, involving uncharted and uninhabited lands, and it pains me that I cannot describe them without spoiling the pleasure of those who have not yet read In the Kingdom of Ice. Sides' book is a masterful work of history and storytelling."

—The Los Angeles Times

"America's own brush with epic polar tragedy, the subject of Hampton Sides' phenomenally gripping new book, is a less well-known affair…What ensued — a struggle to survive and a nearly 1,000-mile trek across the Arctic Ocean and into the vastness of Siberia — stands as one of the most perilous journeys ever. Sides works story-telling magic as he evokes the pathos and suffering of what unfolded: De Long and his crew endured hardships that boggle the mind. But there is also beauty here… [Sides] writes superbly on the geography of Siberia and the Arctic, and the abundant bird and animal life the explorers encountered on their travels, which took them across ice, storm-tossed seas, treacherous tundra, rocky seacoasts, and volcanic islands."

—The Boston Globe

title: The Yellow Birds
long_summary:
Two soldiers arrive in Iraq carrying the weight of an oath that will define their fate. Private Bartle, barely out of his teens, swore to keep his younger comrade Murphy alive—a vow that seemed simple in training but proves impossible amid the chaos of urban warfare.

Their bond deepens as they navigate the psychological minefield of combat, where each day blurs the line between survival and moral compromise. Murphy retreats inward, his grip on reality loosening with each passing week, while Bartle watches helplessly as his friend slips away despite his desperate efforts to honor his promise.

Powers examines how violence reshapes the human soul, tracing the ripple effects that extend far beyond the battlefield to touch the lives of those waiting at home. The novel reveals how young men transform under the pressure of war, making choices that will echo long after the fighting ends. Through lyrical prose that finds moments of unexpected grace amid brutality, this story illuminates the complex relationship between duty, friendship, and the terrible mathematics of loss.
short_summary: Two young soldiers bound by an impossible promise struggle to survive the Iraq War. Powers writes with devastating beauty about friendship, loss, and the hidden costs of combat.
author_bios: Kevin Powers served as a soldier in Iraq from 2004 to 2005, an experience that shaped his acclaimed debut novel The Yellow Birds. A Richmond, Virginia native, Powers earned his undergraduate degree from Virginia Commonwealth University before completing an MFA at the University of Texas at Austin, where he received a Michener Fellowship in Poetry. The Yellow Birds garnered numerous honors, including the PEN/Hemingway Award and Guardian First Book Award, while earning National Book Award Finalist recognition.
quotes:
"Remarkable for its intensity of both feeling and expression. In this book about death, every line is a defiant assertion of the power of beauty to revivify, whether beauty shows itself in nature or (later) in art. Graves, Owen, and Sassoon would have recognised this war and the strange poetry it has bred."

—Hilary Mantel, author of Bring Up the Bodies & Wolf Hall

"Compelling, brilliantly written, and heart-breakingly true, The Yellow Birds belongs in the same category as Tim O'Brien's The Things They Carried and Norman Mailer's The Naked and the Dead. Thus far the definitive novel of our long wars in the Middle East; this book is certain to be read and taught for generations to come."

—Philipp Meyer, author of The Son & American Rust

"The Yellow Birds is harrowing, inexplicably beautiful, and utterly, urgently necessary."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

title: There But For The
long_summary:
What drives someone to stage such a dramatic retreat from the world? Miles Garth's decision to barricade himself in a bedroom during an elegant dinner party becomes the catalyst for an unexpected meditation on isolation and intimacy. Four observers—each connected to Miles by the thinnest of threads—find themselves drawn into the mystery of his self-imposed exile.

Smith constructs her narrative through these four voices: Anna, Mark, May, and young Brooke, none of whom can claim to truly know the man at the center of their fascination. Their varied attempts to decode Miles's motivations reveal as much about their own lives as his, creating a kaleidoscope of perspectives that questions whether genuine understanding between people is ever possible.

The novel transforms a seemingly simple premise into an intricate examination of the spaces between us—both the distances we maintain and the unexpected moments of recognition that can emerge from the most casual encounters. Smith's characteristic linguistic playfulness serves a deeper purpose here, illustrating how language itself can both connect and divide us as we struggle to make sense of each other's inner worlds.
short_summary: When a man locks himself in a room at a dinner party and refuses to leave, four near-strangers become unlikely witnesses to his breakdown. Smith's witty, inventive novel probes the mysteries of human connection.
author_bios: Ali Smith has written numerous fiction works, including her recent Companion Piece, the "Seasonal Quartet," Public library and other stories, and How to be both, which earned the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction, the Goldsmiths Prize, and the Costa Novel Award. Four times short-listed for the Man Booker Prize, Smith also received the George Orwell Prize for Political Fiction for Summer. A native of Inverness, Scotland, she currently resides in Cambridge, England.
quotes:
"You could call Ali Smith's new novel, There But For The, a tragicomedy . . . The fun comes in the form of Smith's satire of the media . . . of new technology users and of upper-middle-class snobbery . . . Though the locations shift and characters appear out of nowhere, Smith agilely keeps the narrative together. Everything connects—even if the people can't. A must-read."

—Toronto NOW

"In There But For The Ali Smith displays her usual fizz and artistry. She always surprises, she never disappoints."

—Kate Atkinson, author of Shrines of Gaiety, Life After Life & Started Early, Took My Dog

"A beguiling ode to human connection shot through with existential wonder and virtuosic wordplay. If you fell for Jennifer Egan's A Visit From the Goon Squad, you'll appreciate Smith's formal twists and turns—and there's more where There came from."

—Time

title: Black Is the Body
subtitle: Stories from My Grandmother's Time, My Mother's Time, and Mine
long_summary:
Emily Bernard crafts a collection of twelve essays that interrogate the lived reality of race in America through her own intimate lens. Her reflections span from childhood in the South—where she carried a surname passed down from white ancestry—to a life-altering assault at a coffee shop, to building an interracial marriage and family.

Bernard's academic life in Vermont's predominantly white landscape provides another layer of complexity as she raises two Ethiopian children while teaching in spaces where she often stands alone. Her writing refuses easy answers, instead choosing to sit with the uncomfortable tensions that define Black existence in America.

Each piece builds upon the others, creating a mosaic that challenges readers to reconsider how we discuss race beyond tired talking points. Bernard's approach is both scholarly and deeply human, drawing connections between her individual story and the larger American narrative. The result is a work that demands we confront difficult truths about identity, family, and what it costs to move through the world in a Black body.
short_summary: Twelve interconnected essays explore race, identity, and belonging through Bernard's personal experiences—from growing up Black in the South to raising adopted Ethiopian children in predominantly white New England.
author_bios: Emily Bernard grew up in Nashville, Tennessee, before earning her PhD in American studies from Yale University. She currently serves as the Julian Lindsay Green and Gold Professor of English at the University of Vermont. Bernard has been recognized with grants from the Ford Foundation and NEH, along with a W. E. B. Du Bois Resident Fellowship at Harvard University. Her essays have been featured in The American Scholar, Best American Essays, and Best African American Essays.
quotes:
"My very favorite book that I have read so far this year…It's really life changing. If you get no other book this year, get Black Is the Body by Emily Bernard."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Of the 12 essays here, there's not one that even comes close to being forgettable. Bernard's language is fresh, poetically compact, and often witty ... Bernard proves herself to be a revelatory storyteller of race in America who can hold her own with some of those great writers she teaches."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"Contemplative and compassionate ... Bernard's voice is personable yet incisive in exploring the lived reality of race ... [Her] wisdom and compassion radiate throughout this collection."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Memorial Days
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
The sudden death of a beloved spouse shatters more than just a heart—it demolishes the entire architecture of daily existence. For three years after losing her husband Tony Horwitz to an unexpected heart attack, Geraldine Brooks found herself drowning in bureaucratic obligations and social expectations that left no room for the ancient human need to simply sit with sorrow.

Determined to honor both her grief and her marriage, Brooks eventually escapes to an isolated stretch of Australian coastline. There, in deliberate solitude, she begins the work that our hurried world rarely permits: examining how different societies have always understood that mourning requires time, ritual, and space apart from ordinary life.

This memoir moves between tender recollections of a thirty-year partnership built on shared adventures, intellectual companionship, and deep affection, and Brooks's raw confrontation with widowhood. Her retreat becomes both a personal reckoning and a broader meditation on how we might better support ourselves and others through life's most devastating transitions. The result is a book that refuses easy comfort while offering something more valuable: honest witness to both the magnitude of loss and the possibility of carrying love forward.
short_summary: Brooks retreats to a remote Australian island three years after her husband's sudden death, seeking the space to grieve that modern life denied her. An exquisite meditation on loss and love.
author_bios: Geraldine Brooks has written six novels, including the Pulitzer Prize–winning March, along with Horse, People of the Book, and Year of Wonders. She is also the author of acclaimed nonfiction works Nine Parts of Desire and Foreign Correspondence. Born and raised in Australia, Brooks now splits her time between Sydney and Martha's Vineyard. Her books have been translated into more than thirty languages and have sold millions of copies worldwide.
quotes:
"Memorial Days joins Joan Didion's The Year of Magical Thinking and Michelle Zauner's Crying in H Mart as memoirs of grief worth seeking out. ... Memorial Days gives due justice to what it means to live and love and experience loss."

—Chicago Tribune

"This intimate memoir of grief is a lifeline to others dealing with loss. ... Intensely intimate and candid ... Brooks tracks the geography of grief with patience and grace as she comes to terms with the ongoing nature of outliving the ones you love most. ... Her memoir is certainly a testament to her own unique loss, but it's moreover a lifeline to others who will find themselves in this familiar, shattered landscape of grief."

—Los Angeles Times

"Brooks wield[s] precise and often beautiful language and, in the most graceful way possible, point[s] a way forward. A rich account of marriage and mourning ... Memorial Days contains much compassionate advice for those who have, or will, suffer the same ferocious blow."

—The Washington Post

title: Man in the Woods
long_summary:
A solitary man accustomed to life's margins—from Alaska's wilderness to South Dakota's manhunts—Paul discovers unexpected belonging with Kate and her daughter Ruby. Their relationship offers him his first taste of genuine connection and domestic stability.

But Paul operates by an uncompromising moral code that sets him apart from others who navigate life through convenient accommodations. After losing his construction job on a high-end Manhattan project, he pulls over at a highway rest stop to consider his next move. There he witnesses an act of shocking cruelty that demands immediate action.

The choice Paul makes in that moment becomes a catalyst that threatens to destroy the fragile life he's built with Kate and Ruby. Spencer examines how rigid principles can both define and devastate a person, exploring the tension between doing what feels morally necessary and protecting what matters most. This is a story about the weight of conscience and the price of refusing to look away from injustice.
short_summary: After witnessing brutal animal abuse at a roadside campground, a principled carpenter makes a split-second decision that unravels his carefully rebuilt life. Spencer crafts a taut psychological thriller about conscience and consequence.
author_bios: Scott Spencer has written twelve novels, including Endless Love, Waking the Dead, A Ship Made of Paper, and Willing. His teaching experience spans Columbia University, the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Williams College, the University of Virginia, and Eastern Correctional Facility through the Bard Prison Initiative. Spencer makes his home in upstate New York.
quotes:
"We don't often encounter novels that combine shrewd plotting, strong characters and gorgeous writing, but Scott Spencer's "Man in the Woods" does precisely that."

—The Washington Post

"Spencer, a deft explorer of obsessive love and violence, confronts the consequences of doing wrong for all the right reasons in his exquisite latest."

—Publishers Weekly

"[A] compelling setup and stunning conclusion...The depth of the characters, the questions they ask and the challenge they confront stay with the reader long after the conclusion."

—Kirkus

title: Heart the Lover
long_summary:
Literature becomes the backdrop for a romance that defies easy categorization. A college senior finds herself drawn into the magnetic orbit of two brilliant classmates, Sam and Yash, who share an elegant house and an infectious love of academic discourse. What begins as intellectual kinship evolves into something far more complex.

Their late-night discussions of poetry and philosophy give way to deeper intimacies, creating bonds that feel both inevitable and impossible to sustain. The trio's dynamic shifts as graduation looms, forcing decisions that will reverberate far beyond their university years.

Years pass, and what seemed like ancient history suddenly demands a reckoning. An unexpected encounter forces our narrator to revisit the intensity of those formative months and examine how the choices of youth continue to shape adult life. King crafts a meditation on the stories we tell ourselves about love, the weight of unfinished business, and the courage required to face the truth about our younger selves.
short_summary: College seniors navigate friendship, literature, and desire in this intimate novel about choices that echo across decades. When the past resurfaces unexpectedly, our narrator must reckon with her younger self and the love triangle that changed everything.
author_bios: Lily King has written six novels, including Euphoria and Writers & Lovers, along with the story collection Five Tuesdays in Winter. Her fiction has earned numerous honors, including the Kirkus Prize, the New England Book Award for Fiction, the Maine Book Award for Fiction, and a Whiting Award. King's novels have reached international audiences through translation into twenty-eight languages. She makes her home in Portland, Maine, and her work has appeared on the New York Times bestseller list.
quotes:
"Time moves like memory in Heart the Lover—urgent, intimate, elusive. What does it mean to carry a story you never get to finish? With breathtaking precision, Lily King writes about love that lingers and choices that haunt. I read it in a single, breathless sitting."

—Ruth Ozeki, author of the Women's Prize for Fiction winner The Book of Form and Emptiness

"King is a genius at writing love stories . . . Her mostly sunny version of the campus novel is an enjoyable alternative to the current vogue for dark academia. Tragedies are on the way, though, as we know they must be, as nothing gold can stay and these darn fictional characters seem to make the same kinds of stupid mistakes that real people do. Tenderhearted readers will soak the pages of the last chapter with tears. That college love affair you never got over? Come wallow in this gorgeous version of it."

—Kirkus

"Indescribably good. It is incredible that Lily has managed to tell such an epic love story in just 250 pages, and I emerged feeling ruined for all other books. I adored these characters and feel lucky to have known them. I'm in awe. A perfect literary love story."

—Florence Knapp, New York Times bestselling author of The Names

title: Kansas City Lightning
subtitle: The Rise and Times of Charlie Parker
long_summary:
The saxophone genius who transformed American music deserves more than mythology. Stanley Crouch peels back decades of romanticization to reveal Charlie Parker's formative years—not as the tortured artist of popular imagination, but as a determined young musician navigating the vibrant, dangerous world of 1930s Kansas City.

This biography excavates the human being beneath the legend: a teenager whose musical ambitions collided with personal demons, family pressures, and the harsh realities of Depression-era America. Crouch traces Parker's artistic development through the jazz laboratories of Kansas City's nightclub scene, where he absorbed influences from masters like Lester Young while battling the addiction that would eventually claim his life.

Drawing on extensive research and interviews, Crouch reconstructs Parker's world with novelistic detail—the smoky clubs, the musical rivalries, the complex relationships that shaped both his art and his self-destruction. Rather than mythologizing Parker's genius, this first volume of a planned two-part work examines how extraordinary talent emerged from ordinary circumstances, and how the seeds of both triumph and tragedy were planted in those crucial early years.
short_summary: Stanley Crouch's long-awaited biography captures Charlie Parker as a young genius coming of age in Depression-era Kansas City. An intimate portrait of the artist before the legend.
author_bios: Stanley Crouch received two National Book Critics Circle Award nominations for Notes of a Hanging Judge and The All-American Skin Game. He wrote several other books including Always in Pursuit, The Artificial White Man, and the novel Don't the Moon Look Lonesome. Crouch worked as artistic consultant for jazz programming at Lincoln Center, led the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation as president, and held membership in the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He passed away in 2020.
quotes:
"A tour de force that is the print equivalent of a long, bravura jazz performance. . . . Crouch has given us a bone-deep understanding of Parker's music and the world that produced it. In his pages, Bird still lives."

—The Washington Post

"It is from Mr. Crouch, a novelist as well as a critic and essayist, that we come to see Charlie Parker in the context of his time and place in America. . . . One comes away from Mr. Crouch's book wanting more."

—The Wall Street Journal

"A book about a jazz hero written in a heroic style. . . a bebop Beowulf."

—The New York Times

title: There is Power in a Union
subtitle: The Epic Story of Labor in America
long_summary:
The battle between workers and bosses has defined American society since the nation's earliest factories began operating in Massachusetts. This sweeping historical account traces how organized labor movements transformed not just workplaces, but the entire fabric of American life.

Through vivid portraits of strikes, negotiations, and political battles, the narrative captures the human drama behind labor's greatest victories and defeats. From factory floors to legislative chambers, these conflicts reveal fundamental questions about power, fairness, and economic opportunity that continue to resonate.

The book demonstrates how workers' fights for better conditions and representation became catalysts for broader social change, influencing everything from civil rights to political reform. As economic inequality grows and job security diminishes in contemporary America, these historical lessons offer crucial insights into ongoing debates about workers' rights and economic justice.
short_summary: An epic chronicle of American labor from the industrial age to today. Dray brings visceral storytelling to the ongoing struggle between workers and capital that has shaped our national character.
author_bios: Philip Dray has written extensively about American history and politics. His previous works include At the Hands of Persons Unknown: The Lynching of Black America, which received the Robert F. Kennedy Book Award and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist, There Is Power in a Union: The Epic Story of Labor in America, and Capitol Men: The Epic Story of Reconstruction Through the Lives of the First Black Congressmen. Dray teaches as an adjunct professor in the Journalism + Design Department at Eugene Lang College of Liberal Arts and resides in Brooklyn, New York.
quotes:
"Philip Dray's big and bold history of organized labor in America splendidly retells a story - or a multitude of stories - badly in need of retelling. The labor movement's decline in recent decades has accompanied a great national amnesia about all that the movement achieved for the nation. That amnesia threatens those achievements, so Dray's book is timely as well as gripping."

—Sean Wilentz, author of Chants Democratic: New York City and the Rise of the American Working Class & Bob Dylan in America

"The unending struggle between unions and big business has never been more vividly told. Philip Dray is a marvelous story teller who brings history memorably alive, and you will not soon forget the tales of murder and greed, commitment and sacrifice, that fill these pages. But this is more than history; the compelling saga of labor as a crucible for social change should prompt some honest and hard debate about what's happening to working men and women today."

—Bill Moyers

"Any union leader working to define and strengthen the role of organized labor in the 21st century must read There Is Power in a Union, a comprehensive and fascinating history of the American labor movement."

—Michael Winship, President, Writers Guild of America

title: Katabasis
long_summary:
Academic ambition takes a literal turn toward damnation in this darkly inventive tale of scholarly obsession. Alice Law's relentless pursuit of magical excellence has cost her everything, but she refuses to let death derail her plans—even when it's her professor's death that threatens her future.

With Jacob Grimes trapped in the underworld and her academic prospects hanging in the balance, Alice makes an audacious decision: she'll descend into Hell itself to retrieve him. The only problem? Her academic nemesis Peter Murdoch has hatched the identical plan. Armed with classical mythology as their roadmap and magical implements as their tools, these unlikely partners must navigate the infernal realm together.

What unfolds is a journey that challenges everything they thought they knew about magic, ambition, and each other. The Hell they encounter defies literary expectations, forcing them to confront not only supernatural dangers but the complicated history that binds them together. Their shared trauma might prove to be either their salvation or their undoing as they discover that some prices for success are higher than they ever imagined.
short_summary: Two rival graduate students venture into Hell to rescue their dead professor's soul—and salvage their academic futures. Dark academia meets infernal adventure in this wickedly smart fantasy about ambition, trauma, and unlikely alliances.
author_bios: Rebecca F. Kuang wrote the internationally celebrated Poppy War trilogy along with Babel: An Arcane History and Yellowface, earning her #1 New York Times and Sunday Times bestseller status. Her novels have garnered the Nebula, Locus, Crawford, and British Book Awards. As a Marshall Scholar, Rebecca F. Kuang earned her MPhil in Chinese Studies from Cambridge and MSc in Contemporary Chinese Studies from Oxford. She continues her academic work as a PhD candidate at Yale, focusing on East Asian Languages and Literatures with emphasis on diaspora, contemporary Sinophone literature, and Asian American literature.
quotes:
"Rich with allusion and illusion, Kuang crafts a witty, gory, harrowing ride that thoroughly roasts the perils and power structures of academia, while never losing sight of what it means to have a fragile, human heart."

—Leigh Bardugo, #1 New York Times bestselling author

"This is a tightly constructed novel that aims a clear lens on academia, with both its faults and its virtues. The heady draw of discovery is ever-present, even if what Alice is discovering is Hell. A learned, literary manifesto on academia—and its darkness."

—Kirkus

"What an adventure! Katabasis is a tour de force – literate, witty, and wise, it thrills and delights all the way to a hugely satisfying conclusion. I enjoyed it tremendously."

—Gareth Brown, international bestselling author of The Book of Doors

title: Toms River
subtitle: A Story of Science and Salvation
long_summary:
The picturesque coastal community of Toms River, New Jersey harbored a dark secret beneath its surface charm. While residents celebrated their children's Little League victories, industrial giants quietly transformed the area into a toxic wasteland, contaminating local waterways with chemical waste and burying countless drums of hazardous materials.

Dan Fagin masterfully weaves together the threads of this environmental catastrophe, following the brave individuals who refused to accept the status quo. At the center of his narrative are the families devastated by childhood cancer clusters, the healthcare workers who connected alarming dots, and the activists who channeled their anguish into relentless pursuit of accountability.

This investigation spans six decades of industrial malfeasance and governmental inaction, while celebrating the groundbreaking researchers who established crucial connections between environmental toxins and human disease. Fagin transforms dense scientific concepts into accessible storytelling, creating a compelling chronicle of David versus Goliath that resonates far beyond New Jersey's borders.

The book stands as both an indictment of unchecked corporate power and a testament to the strength of community organizing, offering vital lessons for any region grappling with the legacy of industrial pollution.
short_summary: Environmental disaster meets human courage in this investigation of a New Jersey town's fight against toxic pollution. Fagin transforms complex science into gripping narrative, revealing how ordinary people exposed corporate dumping and its devastating health consequences.
author_bios: Dan Fagin leads the Science, Health, and Environmental Reporting Program at New York University's Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute, where he serves as associate professor. During his fifteen-year tenure as Newsday's environmental correspondent, Fagin contributed to two teams that received Pulitzer Prize finalist recognition. His work covering cancer epidemiology has garnered prestigious honors including the Science Journalism Award from the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Science in Society Award from the National Association of Science Writers.
quotes:
"It's high time a book did for epidemiology what Jon Krakauer's best-selling Into Thin Air did for mountain climbing: transform a long sequence of painfully plodding steps and missteps into a narrative of such irresistible momentum that the reader not only understands what propels enthusiasts forward, but begins to strain forward as well, racing through the pages to get to the heady views at the end. And such is the power of Dan Fagin's Toms River, surely a new classic of science reporting . . . a sober story of probability and compromise, laid out with the care and precision that characterizes both good science and great journalism."

—The New York Times

"A thrilling journey full of twists and turns, Toms River is essential reading for our times. Dan Fagin handles topics of great complexity with the dexterity of a scholar, the honesty of a journalist, and the dramatic skill of a novelist."

—Siddhartha Mukherjee, M.D., author of the Pulitzer Prize–winning The Emperor of All Maladies & The Gene

"At once intimate and objective, Toms River is the heartbreaking account of one town's struggle with a legacy of toxic pollution. Dan Fagin has written a powerful and important book."

—Elizabeth Kolbert, author of the Pulizter Prize-winning The Sixth Extinction & Field Notes from a Catastrophe

title: The God of the Woods
long_summary:
The Van Laar family's privileged world fractures when thirteen-year-old Barbara disappears from their exclusive Adirondack retreat. Her empty bunk triggers memories of another loss—Barbara's brother vanished over a decade ago, leaving questions that still haunt the family.

As search parties comb the wilderness, the investigation exposes the fragile relationship between the camp's wealthy owners and the local residents whose livelihoods depend on their patronage. Moore constructs a complex narrative that examines how economic disparity shapes human connections and how family trauma echoes across generations.

What begins as a missing person case evolves into an examination of privilege, loyalty, and the stories people tell themselves to survive. The novel interrogates the mythology of summer camps as innocent escapes, revealing instead a world where class tensions simmer beneath the surface of recreational activities and campfire songs. Moore crafts a story that questions whether some secrets are too dangerous to uncover.
short_summary: When a teenager vanishes from her family's Adirondack summer camp, the investigation unearths secrets connecting a wealthy dynasty to the working-class community in its shadow.
author_bios: Liz Moore wrote the bestselling Long Bright River, selected for Good Morning America's Book Club and named among Barack Obama's yearly favorites. She has published additional novels including Heft and The Unseen World. Moore received the Rome Prize in Literature for 2014-2015 and currently resides in Philadelphia.
quotes:
"A riveting tale of a missing child that widens into a vast, acute portrait of youth, friendship, family secrets, and conflicting social circles. Intelligently done, and with a gimlet eye for telling detail, it's a brilliant trap full of secrets and lies."

—Douglas Stuart, Booker Prize winning author of Shuggie Bain & Young Mungo

"Riveting from page one to the last breathless word, The God of the Woods is about the many ways we find and lose both ourselves and others. This book flew by at lightning speed, but will stick with me for a very long time."

—Rebecca Makkai, New York Times bestselling author of I Have Some Questions For You

"The God of the Woods, like The Secret History, transports readers so deeply into its richly peopled, ominous world that, for hours, everything else falls away. . . . Breaking free of the spell Moore casts is close to impossible."

—The Washington Post

title: Beautiful World, Where Are You
long_summary:
Four friends stand at the precipice of adulthood, caught between intimacy and isolation in contemporary Ireland. Alice, a successful writer grappling with fame's discontents, impulsively invites Felix—a younger man from a different world—on a Roman holiday. Meanwhile, in Dublin, Eileen finds herself drawn back into the gravitational pull of Simon, a complicated relationship that has defined much of her emotional landscape since adolescence.

Through letters and lived experience, these characters wrestle with fundamental questions about connection in an uncertain age. Their romantic entanglements blur the boundaries between friendship and desire, revealing how desperately they seek meaning amid global anxieties and personal disappointments. Rooney crafts an intimate portrait of a generation suspended between hope and despair, examining whether authentic human connection can survive in a world that often feels like it's ending. The novel interrogates the weight of privilege, the complexity of desire, and the possibility of finding beauty when everything seems to be falling apart.
short_summary: Two couples navigate desire, friendship, and existential anxiety across Dublin and Rome. Rooney's epistolary novel captures millennial love with piercing intelligence and devastating clarity.
author_bios: Sally Rooney has established herself as one of Ireland's most distinctive literary voices through her novels Conversations with Friends, Normal People, and Beautiful World, Where Are You. Beyond her writing, Rooney played an active role in developing the Hulu/BBC television adaptation of Normal People, contributing to both the writing and production of the acclaimed series.
quotes:
"[Rooney's] writing about sex is taut and direct. It's a narrative style I associate with the films of Andrew Haigh and Joanna Hogg, two great visual poets of social anxiety and reticence. Rooney's dialogue is frequently perfect . . . Beautiful World, Where Are You is Rooney's best novel yet."

—Brandon Taylor, The New York Times

"A tour de force. The dialogue never falters, and the prose burns up the page."

—Anne Enright, The Guardian

"It's a testament to Rooney's curious, cerebral gifts as a writer that she not only draws her readers into tolerating long stretches of such ruminations but makes them so entertaining. We feel we're in good company with our own end-time anxieties . . . In this ambitious novel of sentiment and ideas, which is so up to the minute in its global concerns, Rooney ironically reaches back to one of the oldest forms of the novel, the epistolary or letter form, to tell her story."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: The Swerve
subtitle: How the World Became Modern
long_summary:
A manuscript hunter's chance discovery in a medieval monastery unleashed ideas that would shatter the foundations of Western thought. The text he rescued was Lucretius's *On the Nature of Things*, a radical Roman work proposing that existence unfolds without divine intervention and that reality consists of atoms moving through void.

Stephen Greenblatt chronicles how this philosophical bombshell ignited the Renaissance and continues reverberating today. The poem's atomic theory and rejection of religious dogma found their way into Galileo's telescopes and Darwin's notebooks, while its celebration of pleasure influenced everyone from Montaigne's essays to Jefferson's political vision.

This intellectual detective story reveals how precariously human knowledge hangs by a thread—one manuscript, one curious reader, one moment of recognition that changes everything. Greenblatt demonstrates that ideas possess their own momentum, capable of lying dormant for centuries before exploding into consciousness and reshaping entire civilizations. The book illuminates both the accidents that preserve wisdom and the courage required to embrace dangerous truths.
short_summary: How one forgotten Roman poem about atoms and godless universes sparked the Renaissance. Greenblatt traces the thrilling rediscovery of Lucretius and shows how dangerous ancient ideas reshaped the modern world.
author_bios: Stephen Greenblatt teaches as Cogan University Professor of the Humanities at Harvard University. His fourteen books include The Swerve, which earned both the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award, along with Will in the World, a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Greenblatt also serves as general editor for The Norton Anthology of English Literature and The Norton Shakespeare.
quotes:
"The ideas in The Swerve are tucked, cannily, inside a quest narrative. . . . The details that Mr. Greenblatt supplies throughout The Swerve are tangy and exact. . . . There is abundant evidence here of what is Mr. Greenblatt's great and rare gift as a writer: an ability, to borrow a phrase from The Swerve, to feel fully 'the concentrated force of the buried past."

—The New York Times

"In this gloriously learned page-turner, both biography and intellectual history, Harvard Shakespearean scholar Greenblatt turns his attention to the front end of the Renaissance as the origin of Western culture's foundation: the free questioning of truth."

—Publishers Weekly

"More wonderfully illuminating Renaissance history from a master scholar and historian."

—Kirkus

title: The Covenant of Water
subtitle: An Oprah’s Book Club Selection
long_summary:
In the lush landscape of Kerala, a family carries an inexplicable burden through seven decades of Indian history. Each generation faces the same tragic pattern: someone will inevitably be claimed by water. This curse shadows their lives from the colonial period through independence and into the modern era.

Abraham Verghese crafts an intimate chronicle that begins with a child bride's journey and follows her descendants as they build lives against the backdrop of a transforming nation. The family's story unfolds through moments of joy and devastating loss, while India itself undergoes seismic political and social changes.

Medicine becomes both profession and calling for several family members, offering hope for understanding their mysterious fate. Verghese draws on his dual expertise as physician and novelist to illuminate how healing arts evolve alongside the characters' personal struggles. The narrative examines how families preserve their bonds across generations, even when confronted by forces beyond their comprehension. This multigenerational saga reveals the intricate ways that love, tradition, and scientific progress intersect in the face of inexplicable tragedy.
short_summary: Three generations of a South Indian family are haunted by a peculiar curse—someone in each generation drowns. Verghese weaves medicine, history, and family saga into something transcendent.
author_bios: Abraham Verghese completed his training at the Iowa Writers' Workshop and has written several acclaimed works including My Own Country, which was a finalist for the NBCC Award, and The Tennis Partner, recognized as a New York Times Notable Book.
