His bestselling novel Cutting for Stone remained on the New York Times bestseller list for 107 weeks, reached sales of over two million copies globally, and has been translated into more than twenty languages. President Obama honored Verghese with the National Humanities Medal, and he holds membership in both the National Academy of Medicine and American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He currently serves as the Linda R. Meier and Joan F. Lane Provostial Professor at Stanford University School of Medicine.
quotes:
"One of the best books I've read in my entire life. It's epic. It's transportive . . . It was unputdownable!"

—Oprah Winfrey

"From the very first page of Abraham Verghese's The Covenant of Water, I was overtaken with joy. Truly, I caught my breath, absorbing such beauty. What a sure faith this novel is—what an agreement with language. What a glorious story of land and family. What a brilliant path written across generations."

—Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, author of The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois

"A novel of utter beauty, The Covenant of Water is worthy of all praise in its depiction of medical ingenuity and family love; it is epic and eye-opening, the sort of story that only a singular mind like Abraham Verghese's could have woven."

—Imbolo Mbue, author of How Beautiful We Were

title: After Visiting Friends
subtitle: A Son's Story
long_summary:
The death of a father creates ripples that can last a lifetime. For Michael Hainey, those ripples began at age six with the sudden loss of his newspaper reporter father in 1970s Chicago. Official explanations spoke of a heart attack, but the circumstances surrounding that night remained frustratingly unclear.

Decades later, armed with his own journalistic skills, Hainey embarks on a deeply personal investigation that takes him through Chicago's gritty newspaper culture of the era. His search leads him into a world where loyalty runs deep and secrets are carefully guarded—a place where his father's colleagues maintain their silence even years after his death.

Central to this quest is Hainey's relationship with his mother, a woman whose strength helped hold their fractured family together but whose reluctance to revisit the past creates its own obstacles. As he pieces together fragments of his father's final night, Hainey must navigate between the parent he remembers and the complex individual he's discovering.

This memoir illuminates the gap between the stories families tell themselves and the messier truths that lie beneath. It's both an intimate family reckoning and a vivid snapshot of Chicago's vanishing newspaper world.
short_summary: When his newspaper reporter father died mysteriously in 1970s Chicago, six-year-old Michael Hainey was left with questions that haunted him for decades. A moving investigation into family secrets and the vanished world of hard-drinking journalists.
author_bios: Michael Hainey serves as deputy editor at GQ magazine. A Chicago native, he currently makes his home in Manhattan.
quotes:
"After Visiting Friends is full of love for the lost world of nocturnal newspaper work and after-hours boozing."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Part what next? detective story, part moving family portrait, and part wistful ode to the whiskey-sloshed mid-century Chicago newspaper world…"

—Rob Brunner, Entertainment Weekly

"A book whose heartbreak and humor, in the true Irish tradition, can't be untangled. It's a kind of detective story, but the mystery is the past itself."

—John Jeremiah Sullivan, author of Pulphead

title: The Emperor of Gladness
long_summary:
In the decaying landscape of East Gladness, Connecticut, two broken souls find salvation in each other. Hai, a nineteen-year-old teetering on the edge of despair, encounters Grazina, an aging woman whose mind drifts between past and present. What begins as an act of desperate necessity—Hai caring for this stranger—evolves into something neither expected: a profound connection that rewrites the meaning of family.

Vuong examines the invisible threads that bind us to one another, particularly those society overlooks or discards. Through the shifting seasons, Hai and Grazina navigate the complexities of dependence, dignity, and the stories we tell ourselves to survive. Their partnership becomes a meditation on what it means to belong somewhere, to someone, when traditional structures have failed.

This novel interrogates the American experience through the lens of those existing in its shadows—immigrants, the elderly, the mentally ill, the economically forgotten. Vuong weaves together questions of identity, trauma, and resilience, creating a narrative that feels both intimate and expansive. The result is a deeply moving exploration of how human connection can emerge from the most unlikely circumstances, offering hope where none seemed possible.
short_summary: When a suicidal teenager becomes caretaker to an elderly woman with dementia, their unlikely bond transforms both their lives. Vuong crafts a tender epic about chosen family and second chances.
author_bios: Ocean Vuong has published the poetry collections Night Sky with Exit Wounds and Time Is a Mother, along with the New York Times bestselling novel On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. Born in Saigon, Vietnam, Ocean Vuong received both a MacArthur Fellowship and American Book Award for his literary work. He divides his time between western Massachusetts and New York City.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . A heartfelt and powerful examination of those living on the fringes of society, and the unique challenges they face to survive and thrive."

—Oprah Winfrey

"[A]mbitious . . . The references to Slaughterhouse-Five and The Brothers Karamazov underscore Vuong's interest in exploring war and morality, but this is remarkable as a novel that tries to look at those themes outside of conventional realism or combat porn . . . A sui generis take on the surprising and cruel ways violence is passed on across generations."

—Kirkus

"Tender and moving, The Emperor of Gladness is about people on the margins of society and sanity. To my surprise and delight, Vuong's novel is also wryly, subtly, wittily—and sometimes outrageously—a comedy as well as a tragedy."

—Rebecca Solnit, author of A Field Guide to Getting Lost and Recollections of My Nonexistence

title: Johnny Cash
subtitle: The Life
long_summary:
Music journalist Robert Hilburn leverages decades of exclusive access to Johnny Cash to craft an intimate biography that goes beyond the legend. Having witnessed pivotal moments like the iconic Folsom Prison performance and conducted final interviews with Cash and June Carter, Hilburn uncovers the complex man behind the mythology.

This portrait examines how faith and addiction waged war within Cash throughout his career, shaping both his artistry and personal relationships. Hilburn traces the contradictions of a performer who could inspire countless fans while battling his own demons, showing how Cash's music became a vehicle for hope even during his darkest periods. Through previously unrevealed stories from Cash's closest confidants, the biography illuminates how one man's struggles and triumphs helped define not just country music, but American culture itself.
short_summary: The definitive biography of an American icon whose extraordinary career stretched from Sun Records alongside Elvis to his haunting final act with the "Hurt" video at age 69.
author_bios: Robert Hilburn served as the Los Angeles Times' chief pop music critic and editor for thirty-five years, from 1970 to 2005. Following his journalism career, he turned to biographical writing, penning books about legendary musicians such as Johnny Cash, John Lennon, and Paul Simon. He currently resides in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"The Man in Black's many fans will find this huge, sympathetic yet critical study of his serial rises, falls, betrayals and redemptions definitive."

—The Globe and Mail

"Between his love of music, his experience as one of the nation's leading music critics, and his long personal friendship with the subject, there is no one on earth more qualified to write this definitive book on the roller-coaster life of Johnny Cash than Robert Hilburn. Between the amount of research and the degree of detail he's put into this book, even Johnny would have learned something about himself if he were here to read it. Highly recommended!"

—Rick Rubin, author of The Creative Act

"Robert Hilburn displays a deeply felt affinity with his subject, illuminating Johnny Cash as the moral compass of country music."

—Patti Smith, author of Just Kids

title: The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace
subtitle: A Brilliant Young Man Who Left Newark for the Ivy League
long_summary:
Robert Peace possessed the kind of intellect that could unlock any door—except perhaps the one that would free him from the circumstances of his birth. Born into Newark's most challenging neighborhoods, he excelled academically while his father served time and his mother worked multiple jobs to make ends meet. His exceptional mind earned him admission to Yale, where he studied complex sciences alongside America's privileged elite.

But academic success couldn't resolve the fundamental tension in Peace's life. He remained tethered to his community, supporting his family through means that contradicted everything his education represented. Jeff Hobbs, Peace's college roommate, constructs an intimate portrait of a young man caught between incompatible worlds—each demanding different versions of himself.

This biography examines the fault lines that define contemporary America: the persistence of racial and economic barriers, the complexity of loyalty, and the sometimes impossible mathematics of social mobility. Peace's story illuminates how exceptional talent can coexist with tragic choices, and how the pull of family and community can override even the most promising opportunities. It's an unflinching look at what happens when individual brilliance collides with systemic limitations.
short_summary: Jeff Hobbs chronicles his Yale roommate Robert Peace, a brilliant young man from Newark who navigated between two worlds—elite academia and the dangerous streets of home. A devastating portrait of talent, loyalty, and the weight of impossible choices.
author_bios: Jeff Hobbs wrote the bestselling biography The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace, which earned him the Los Angeles Times Book Prize and finalist recognition for both the Pen/Faulkner Award in Biography and Carnegie Medal in nonfiction. The book was adapted into the 2024 film Rob Peace. Hobbs has also published Show Them You're Good and Children of the State, and currently resides in Los Angeles with his family.
quotes:
"A haunting work of nonfiction.... Mr. Hobbs writes in a forthright but not florid way about a heartbreaking story."

—The New York Times

"I can hardly think of a book that feels more necessary, relevant, and urgent."

—Grantland

"The Short Tragic Life of Robert Peace is a book that is as much about class as it is race. Peace traveled across America's widening social divide, and Hobbs' book is an honest, insightful and empathetic account of his sometimes painful, always strange journey."

—The Los Angeles Times

title: And the Mountains Echoed
long_summary:
Hosseini crafts an intricate tapestry of human connection that spans continents and decades, examining how a single moment in childhood can echo through generations of family members. The narrative weaves between diverse locations—from Afghanistan to California, France to Greece—following characters whose lives intersect in ways both profound and unexpected.

At its heart, this novel interrogates the complex dynamics of family relationships: the ways we protect and harm those closest to us, the sacrifices we make in the name of love, and the unbreakable bonds that persist despite distance and time. Each character grapples with questions of identity, belonging, and the weight of choices made long ago.

The storytelling moves fluidly between multiple perspectives, creating a rich chorus of voices that illuminate different facets of the human experience. Through these interconnected stories, readers witness how individual decisions create ripple effects that touch lives across oceans and years, ultimately revealing the profound ways our histories continue to shape who we become.
short_summary: Hosseini's multivoiced epic traces how a childhood choice reverberates across decades and continents through intertwined lives. A compassionate, page-turning story about family bonds that refuse to break.
author_bios: Born in Kabul, Afghanistan, Khaled Hosseini immigrated to the United States in 1980 and has since become one of contemporary literature's most celebrated voices. His novels—including The Kite Runner, A Thousand Splendid Suns, and And the Mountains Echoed—have all achieved #1 New York Times bestseller status, along with his illustrated work Sea Prayer. Beyond writing, Hosseini dedicates himself to humanitarian efforts, working as a U.S. Goodwill Envoy to the United Nations Refugee Agency while leading The Khaled Hosseini Foundation in its mission to support the Afghan people.
quotes:
"[Hosseini's] most assured and emotionally gripping story yet . . . Hosseini's narrative gifts have deepened over the years. . . . [And the Mountains Echoed] grapples with many of the same themes that crisscross his early novels: the relationship between parents and children, and the ways the past can haunt the present. And it shares a similar penchant for mapping terrain midway between the boldly colored world of fable and the more shadowy, shaded world of realism… [W]e finish this novel with an intimate understanding of who his characters are and how they've defined themselves over the years through the choices they have made between duty and freedom, familial responsibilities and independence, loyalty to home and exile abroad… a deeply affecting choral work… a testament both to his intimate knowledge of their inner lives, and to his power as an old-fashioned storyteller."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"The beautiful writing, full of universal truths of loss and identity, makes each section a jewel . . . Hosseini's eye for detail and emotional geography makes this a haunting read."

—Publishers Weekly

"I'm not an easy touch when it comes to novels, but Hosseini's new book, And the Mountains Echoed, had tears dropping from my eyes by Page 45. . . . It's hard to do justice to a novel this rich in a short review. There are a dozen things I still want to say — about the rhyming pairs of characters, the echoing situations, the varied takes on honesty, loneliness, beauty and poverty, the transformation of emotions into physical ailments. Instead, I'll just add this: Send Hosseini up the bestseller list again."

—The Washington Post

title: Fleishman Is in Trouble
long_summary:
Dr. Toby Fleishman believes he's navigating divorce reasonably well. Sure, the marriage fell apart, but he's got his hepatology practice, weekend custody arrangements, and a surprisingly active dating life thanks to smartphone apps. Then Rachel, his ex-wife, drops their children off one day and completely disappears.

Suddenly Toby finds himself overwhelmed—managing full-time parenting while maintaining his medical career and wondering where his former spouse has gone. In his mind, the story is straightforward: he's the reasonable one married to a woman whose career ambitions ultimately consumed everything else.

Yet as the mystery of Rachel's whereabouts deepens, cracks begin forming in Toby's version of events. The truth about their relationship—and its spectacular collapse—proves far more complex than his neat explanations suggest. This debut novel dissects contemporary marriage with surgical precision, revealing how two people can live entirely different versions of the same life together, and how the stories we tell ourselves about love, success, and failure rarely capture the whole picture.
short_summary: When Toby's ex-wife vanishes after dropping off their kids, his carefully constructed post-divorce life crumbles. A razor-sharp dissection of modern marriage that's both devastatingly funny and unexpectedly profound.
author_bios: Taffy Brodesser-Akner works as a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine and has published two novels: Fleishman Is in Trouble, which she transformed into an Emmy-nominated limited series for FX, and Long Island Compromise. She makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Whip-smart, gleefully scatological . . . [Brodesser-Akner] aims a perfect gimlet eye at the city's relentless self-regard. . . . But her best trick may be the novel's narrator: An elusive presence identified at first only as an old friend of Toby's from their study-abroad days, she turns out to be both the book's Trojan horse and—in a brilliant third-act pivot—its greatest gift, transforming a fizzy comedy of manners into something genuinely, unexpectedly profound."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Many novelists have written excellent fictional indictments of interpersonal and systemic sexism. Not since Teju Cole's Open City—a very different book in all other respects—has a novelist put the reader on the wrong side the way Brodesser-Akner does. To do so, she uses a lot of intelligence, a lot of anger, a great sense of humor and a whole new variation on the magic we know from her magazine work. The result is a maddening, unsettling masterpiece, and, yes, you will be moved and inexplicably grateful at the end."

—NPR

"In her witty and well-observed debut, Taffy Brodesser-Akner updates the miserable-matrimony novel, dropping it squarely in our times. . . . Brodesser-Akner has written a potent, upsetting and satisfying novel, illustrating how the marital pledge—build our life together—overlooks a key fact: There are two lives."

—The New York Times

title: Charlie Chan
subtitle: The Untold Story of the Honorable Detective and His Rendezvous with American History
long_summary:
A single arrest in 1904 Honolulu would spawn one of America's most enduring and problematic fictional detectives. Chang Apana, a Hawaiian police officer, became the unlikely inspiration for Charlie Chan, but his real story remained buried beneath decades of Hollywood mythology.

Yunte Huang embarks on a detective story of his own, piecing together the life of this forgotten lawman through archives, cemeteries, and family records across two languages and multiple continents. What emerges is far more complex than the Hollywood caricature: a portrait of territorial Hawaii's multicultural tensions, the entertainment industry's racial blind spots, and one man's transformation into a cultural phenomenon.

This investigation reveals how Charlie Chan became both a breakthrough for Asian representation and a source of lasting stereotype. Huang connects Apana's actual police work to the broader American struggle with Asian identity, showing how popular culture can simultaneously celebrate and diminish entire communities. The result is part biography, part cultural archaeology, and part personal reckoning with how stories shape our understanding of race, representation, and the American dream.
short_summary: The fascinating true story behind Charlie Chan and the Hawaiian cop who inspired him. Huang excavates decades of research to reveal how this controversial detective both reflected and distorted American perceptions of Asian identity.
author_bios: Yunte Huang teaches as Distinguished Professor of English at UC Santa Barbara and previously held positions at Harvard University. A Guggenheim Fellow, he has written Charlie Chan and Inseparable, both recognized as NBCC finalists, with Charlie Chan receiving the Edgar Award. Huang regularly lectures on topics related to American popular culture and its cultural implications.
quotes:
"In this original, deeply personal account, Huang illuminates every conceivable aspect of Chan and his place in American culture.... vibrant narrative.... Multilayered, provocative and highly accessible."

—Kirkus

"A virtuoso of curiosity.... Huang digs up fascinating research on everything from the demographics of capital punishment in Honolulu to the origins of The Manchurian Candidate.... a work of exhaustively researched popular history that reads like a dime-store romance."

—Pico Iyer, Time

"Charlie Chan remains, in himself, a sly and delightful figure, worthy of nostalgia—and of Huang's very original, good-humored and passionately researched book."

—Richard Schickel, The New York Times

title: Beyond the Door of No Return
long_summary:
A dying botanist's final breath carries the name of a woman who has haunted him for decades. Michel Adanson's secret memoir tells of his younger self, consumed by tales of an extraordinary figure known as the revenant—a woman of royal blood who broke free from the slave fortress of Gorée Island and vanished into legend.

Driven by fascination that borders on madness, the young scientist abandons his botanical studies to chase whispers and stories across the Senegalese landscape. His quest leads him through villages where oral histories blur the line between myth and memory, deeper into a world where French colonial brutality collides with ancient traditions and enduring resistance.

The search becomes a reckoning—with the violence of empire, the complexity of desire, and the stories we tell ourselves about love and obsession. Rooted in the storytelling traditions of Senegal, this novel weaves together multiple voices and timelines to create something that feels both historically grounded and mythically resonant. It's a meditation on how legends are born from real suffering and real courage, and how the act of seeking someone can transform the seeker in ways they never anticipated.
short_summary: When a French botanist dies uttering a mysterious woman's name, his hidden memoir reveals an obsessive search through 18th-century Senegal for an escaped slave known as the revenant. Historical fiction that pulses with the power of oral tradition.
author_bios: David Diop wrote At Night All Blood Is Black, winner of the International Booker Prize and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Fiction. Having been born in Paris and spent his childhood in Senegal, Diop brings a unique perspective to his literary work. He teaches literature at the University of Pau, focusing his academic research on eighteenth-century French literature and how Europeans have portrayed Africa throughout history.
quotes:
"[A] mesmerizingly layered work of historical fiction . . . Diop, with remarkable tonal and narrative deftness, evokes and complicates [his character's] cathartic hopes in a way that feels unexpectedly timeless."

—The Atlantic

"A mesmerizing tale . . . Less brutal than Diop's International Booker Prize–winning At Night All Blood is Black (2020) but no less powerful . . . With its sumptuous physical descriptions, shades of language, and smooth overlap of truth and invention, this is masterful storytelling. The ease with which the narratives (including Aglaé's) unfold belies the emotional force they gather."

—Kirkus

"A captivating intergenerational epic influenced by Senegalese oral tradition . . . Told as a series of fast-paced stories within stories, the novel contemplates race, hierarchy, religion, legends . . . Diop writes excellently of historical and regional minutiae, as in his descriptions of the sheer heat and exhaustion his characters face on their travels. This is a novel to devour quickly, but which will leave readers contemplating its story long after."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Negroland
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Growing up in Chicago's Black aristocracy, Margo Jefferson inhabited a world few recognize—one where families balanced extraordinary privilege with the weight of representation. This elite circle, generations in the making, existed in careful tension with both white society and the wider Black community, creating its own rules and expectations.

Jefferson dissects this complex inheritance with surgical precision, revealing how cultural upheaval—from civil rights to feminism—collided with the insular world of her youth. The memoir traces the particular burden of perfection demanded by this rarefied environment, where every misstep carried outsized consequences.

What emerges is a fearless examination of identity formation under impossible pressures. Jefferson refuses easy answers, instead mapping the psychological terrain of belonging nowhere completely. Her analysis cuts through assumptions about privilege and pain, showing how protection can become its own form of imprisonment. The result is both deeply personal confession and sharp cultural criticism, illuminating corners of American experience rarely explored with such honesty and intelligence.
short_summary: Jefferson excavates her privileged upbringing in Chicago's Black elite, examining the psychological costs of living between worlds. A fearless reckoning with race, class, and identity.
author_bios: Margo Jefferson earned a Pulitzer Prize for her work as a cultural critic and served as theater critic for The New York Times. Her writing has appeared in Vogue, New York Magazine, and The Nation, while her academic career includes positions at Columbia University and Eugene Lang College. Jefferson has published On Michael Jackson and Negroland, which received the National Book Critics Circle Award for Autobiography.
quotes:
"Ever provocative and insightful, the cultural critic Margo Jefferson bravely directs the focus inward to her own life and times as a child of the rigid and nearly invisible world of black elites in pre-Civil Rights, mid-century America. By turns, melancholic and hopeful, raw and disarming, she weighs the psychic toll of constructed divisions at the intersection of race, gender, caste and privilege. A moving memoir that is an act of courage in its vulnerability."

—Isabel Wilkerson, author of Caste & The Warmth of Other Suns

"Treads briskly and fearlessly across the treacherous terrain of race, class, gender and entitlement in this tightly edited memoir that recalls her youth in 1950s and 60s Chicago. . . . [Jefferson] is a poetic and bracing memoirist. . . . Lean, specific and personal . . . enlightening."

—Robin Givhan, The Washington Post

"At the heart of Margo Jefferson's masterpiece—a phenomenal study-cum-memoir about the black bourgeoisie—is a sensibility that belongs to no group or community other than the author's sorority of one. Jefferson has lived and worked like the great reporter she is, traversing a little-known or -understood landscape peopled by blacks and whites, dreamers and naysayers, the privileged and the strivers who make up the mosaic known as America."

—Hilton Als

title: Book Lovers
long_summary:
Literary agent Nora Stephens has built her identity around fierce negotiations and protecting her younger sister—she's nobody's idea of a romantic lead. Against her better judgment, she agrees to spend a month in the quaint town of Sunshine Falls, where her sister hopes for some kind of life-changing experience.

Instead of the charming local romance her sister envisions, Nora finds herself repeatedly crossing paths with Charlie Lastra, a moody book editor she knows from New York. Their professional history is less than stellar, making each encounter awkward at best. Neither fits the mold of a typical romantic protagonist—he's no knight in shining armor, and she's far from the sweet, accommodating heroine of popular fiction.

Yet fate seems determined to throw them together at every turn. As they navigate these unexpected encounters, both begin questioning the narratives they've constructed about themselves and what they deserve. This romance cleverly dismantles familiar tropes while exploring how people can rewrite their own stories when given the chance.
short_summary: When a ruthless literary agent escapes to small-town North Carolina, she keeps colliding with a grumpy editor from her past. Sharp, self-aware romance that gleefully subverts every meet-cute expectation.
author_bios: Emily Henry has written six New York Times bestselling novels, including Great Big Beautiful Life, Funny Story, Happy Place, Book Lovers, People We Meet on Vacation, and Beach Read. After studying creative writing at Hope College, Emily Henry now lives between Cincinnati, Ohio, and the neighboring area of Kentucky.
quotes:
"Book Lovers is a rom-com lover's dream of a book. . . . Readers know that Emily Henry never fails to deliver great banter and a romance to swoon over but this may just be her best yet."

—Taylor Jenkins Reid, New York Times bestselling author of Malibu Rising

"Emily Henry's books are a gift, the perfect balance between steamy and sweet. The prose is effortless, the characters charming. The only downside is reaching the end."

—V.E. Schwab, New York Times bestselling author The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue

"Charming, earnest, and clever, Book Lovers is Schitt's Creek for book nerds. A total delight . . . Nobody does it quite like Emily Henry."

—Casey McQuiston, New York Times bestselling author of One Last Stop

title: How We Fight for Our Lives
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Saeed Jones crafts a memoir that reads like spoken word poetry, tracing his evolution from a confused boy in the South to a man who refuses to apologize for who he is. The narrative unfolds through intimate snapshots—moments of shame and defiance, encounters that leave scars and others that offer unexpected grace.

Jones examines the weight of carrying multiple identities in spaces that often reject them, exploring how family love can coexist with profound misunderstanding. His prose moves between tender vulnerability and fierce anger, capturing the exhausting work of fighting for authenticity while navigating racism and homophobia.

This isn't simply a story of struggle—it's an investigation into how we learn to protect ourselves and when we choose to remain open despite the risk. Jones writes with the precision of a poet and the unflinching honesty of someone who has earned his voice through experience, creating a memoir that feels both deeply personal and universally resonant about the cost and necessity of living truthfully.
short_summary: Jones chronicles his journey as a young Black gay man in the South, weaving poetry and raw honesty into a memoir about family, desire, and the fierce work of becoming yourself.
author_bios: Saeed Jones wrote Prelude to Bruise, which received the 2015 PEN/Joyce Osterweil Award for Poetry and the 2015 Stonewall Book Award/Barbara Gittings Literature Award. The collection earned finalist recognition for the 2015 National Book Critics Circle Award and Lambda Literary and Publishing Triangle awards. A Memphis native who grew up in Lewisville, Texas, Jones completed his BA at Western Kentucky University and received his MFA from Rutgers University-Newark. He currently resides in Columbus, Ohio.
quotes:
"[A] devastating memoir….Jones is fascinated by power (who has it, how and why we deploy it), but he seems equally interested in tenderness and frailty. We wound and save one another, we try our best, we leave too much unsaid….A moving, bracingly honest memoir that reads like fevered poetry."

—The New York Times

"A raw and eloquent memoir. One could say that Saeed Jones' new memoir, How We Fight for Our Lives, is a classic coming-of-age story….But Jones' voice and sensibility are so distinct that he turns one of the oldest of literary genres inside out and upside down. How We Fight for Our Lives is at once explicitly raunchy, mean, nuanced, loving and melancholy. It's sometimes hard to read and harder to put down."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"There will be little left to say, and so much left to make after the world experiences Saeed Jones's How We Fight for Our Lives. This is that rare piece of literary art that teaches us how to read and write on every page. It's so black. So queer. So subtextual, and amazingly so sincere. Saeed changes everything we thought we knew about memoir writing, narrative structure, and heart meat. All three are obliterated. All three are tended to over and over again. All three will never ever be the same after this book. It's really that good."

—Kiese Laymon, author of Heavy

title: Under a White Sky
subtitle: The Nature of the Future
long_summary:
Elizabeth Kolbert ventures into laboratories, research stations, and experimental sites where scientists are attempting something unprecedented: engineering solutions to reverse the environmental crises we've created. From desert pools housing endangered fish species to Icelandic facilities that transform atmospheric carbon into rock, she documents humanity's latest chapter in environmental intervention.

The irony is inescapable—the same technological prowess that brought us to the brink of ecological collapse now represents our primary strategy for planetary rescue. Kolbert encounters researchers breeding heat-resistant coral, physicists designing atmospheric cooling systems, and biologists racing to preserve species in artificial environments. Each story reveals how deeply we've altered Earth's systems and how our responses require ever more complex technological fixes.

This exploration raises fundamental questions about humanity's relationship with the natural world. Are we finally learning to work with natural processes, or simply doubling down on our tendency to control them? Kolbert's journey through these cutting-edge projects reveals both the ingenuity and the troubling implications of our current path forward.
short_summary: After documenting humanity's destructive impact on nature, Kolbert now explores a paradox: the same interventions that damaged our planet may be our only hope for saving it. Riveting science writing that's both alarming and oddly hopeful.
author_bios: Elizabeth Kolbert has written Field Notes from a Catastrophe, The Sixth Extinction—which earned her the Pulitzer Prize—and Under a White Sky, recognized by The Washington Post as a top ten book of the year. As a staff writer for The New Yorker, Kolbert has been honored with two National Magazine Awards and the Blake-Dodd Prize from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She makes her home in Williamstown, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"What makes Under A White Sky so valuable and such a compelling read is Kolbert tells by showing. Without beating the reader over the head, she makes it clear how far we already are from a world of undisturbed, perfectly balanced nature—and how far we must still go to find a new balance for the planet's future that still has us humans in it."

—NPR

"Every paragraph of Kolbert's books has a mountain of reading and reporting behind it . . . Urgent, absolutely necessary reading as a portrait of our devastated planet."

—Kirkus

"Riveting . . . Under a White Sky expertly mixes travelogue, science reporting and explanatory journalism."

—The Washington Post

title: All the Lovers in the Night
long_summary:
In the heart of Tokyo, a copy editor in her thirties exists rather than lives, isolated in routine work and minimal human connection. Her world consists mainly of professional exchanges with Hijiri, her editor—someone whose vibrant energy stands in stark contrast to her own withdrawn nature. A chance glimpse of herself in a shop window becomes a moment of reckoning, forcing her to confront the woman she's become: someone who has allowed life to happen around her rather than actively participating in it.

This recognition sparks an internal revolution. As she begins dismantling the careful barriers she's built around herself, memories she's long suppressed begin to emerge, threatening the fragile progress she's making. Kawakami navigates the delicate territory between growth and breakdown, showing how the process of becoming authentic often requires confronting the very experiences that shaped our need for protection. The result is a story that captures both the comedy and tragedy inherent in human transformation—a reminder that meaningful change demands we risk everything we've used to keep ourselves safe.
short_summary: A lonely Tokyo copy editor catches her reflection and decides to change her spiritless life. Kawakami's masterful portrait of transformation reveals how painful self-discovery can be worth the struggle.
author_bios: Born in Osaka in 1976, Mieko Kawakami first pursued music, recording three albums before discovering her calling as a writer. Her literary achievements include winning the prestigious Akutagawa Prize in 2008, along with the MEXT Award for New Artists and the Murasaki Shikibu Literary Prize for Heaven. Kawakami has also published Breasts and Eggs, establishing herself as a distinctive voice in contemporary Japanese literature.
quotes:
"The attention to sensory experience is particularly keen, concise, and meaningful...The startling vividness of Kawakami's images draws the reader deeper into the emotional intensity of the scenes....[she] has good instincts for creating an air of suspense, although that's not what sets her novels apart. It's her ability to make the mere passing of time, choosing to step outside and be alive, seem like an event."

—Idra Novey, The Atlantic

"The author dazzles with her exploration of emotions... An invigorating and empowering portrait. It's a winner."

—Publishers Weekly

"Kawakami has created a rich and notable examination of the varied ways women choose to live their lives and the gains and losses that come with the choices they've made. Kawakami writes with the tender and incisive sensibilities of a poet.... An unforgettable and masterful work."

—Kirkus

title: The Sport of Kings
long_summary:
The Forge dynasty has ruled Kentucky horse country for generations, their fortunes built on the dream of creating racing perfection. At the center of their obsession stands Hellsmouth, a magnificent Thoroughbred carrying the genetic promise of greatness. Henry Forge and his daughter Henrietta pour everything into their quest to engineer the ultimate champion—a horse that will cement their legacy forever.

Their insular world shifts dramatically with the arrival of Allmon Shaughnessy, a young Black man whose presence exposes the deep fractures running through the Forge empire. As personal ambitions collide with historical wounds, three lives become dangerously intertwined through their shared fixation on Hellsmouth's potential.

Morgan weaves together themes of inherited trauma, racial violence, and the corrupting nature of power in this expansive narrative. The novel excavates how America's original sin continues to poison relationships across class and color lines, even as characters chase their individual visions of triumph. Set against the backdrop of Kentucky's thoroughbred industry, this is an unflinching examination of how the past refuses to stay buried, and how dreams of glory often demand the highest moral prices.
short_summary: Spanning generations of a Kentucky dynasty obsessed with breeding champion racehorses, this sweeping novel confronts race, inheritance, and the brutal costs of American ambition.
author_bios: C. E. Morgan makes her home in Berea, Kentucky, alongside her husband Will Guild. Her literary works include The Sport of Kings and All the Living, establishing her as a distinctive voice in contemporary American fiction.
quotes:
"Novelists can do things that other writers can't—and Morgan can do things that other novelists can't...Tremendous."

—Kathryn Schulz, The New Yorker

"Ravishing and ambitious…It's a mud-flecked epic, replete with fertile symbolism, that hurtles through generations of Kentucky history."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"[A] sprawling, magisterial Southern Gothic for the 21st century."

—O: The Oprah Magazine

title: Soul Mining
subtitle: A Musical Life
long_summary:
From a modest upbringing in French-speaking Canada to collaborating with music's biggest names, Daniel Lanois carved an extraordinary path through the recording industry. His story begins in a household where creativity flourished despite financial constraints—a single mother supporting four children while Lanois nurtured an obsession with sound that would eventually revolutionize how albums get made.

This memoir reveals the philosophy and methods behind some of music's most celebrated recordings. Lanois doesn't just recount his collaborations with legendary artists; he opens up about the artistic principles that guide his work, the technological innovations he pioneered, and his relentless pursuit of sonic perfection. His approach combines cutting-edge techniques with respect for musical tradition, creating a distinctive production style that has shaped decades of popular music.

More than a behind-the-scenes look at famous recording sessions, this book examines what it means to dedicate one's life to artistic craft. Lanois reflects on how passion and persistence can overcome humble beginnings, and how true innovation emerges from the intersection of technical mastery and creative vision. His insights into the creative process offer valuable lessons for anyone seeking to understand the alchemy of making great art.
short_summary: The legendary producer behind U2's The Joshua Tree and Bob Dylan's Time Out of Mind shares his unconventional journey from small-town Canada to music's upper echelon.
author_bios: Daniel Lanois has earned eight Grammy Awards for his production work with legendary artists including U2, Bob Dylan, and Emmylou Harris, establishing himself among the music industry's most influential figures. Beyond his production career, Lanois creates music as a solo artist and performs with Black Dub, showcasing his talents as both a behind-the-scenes architect and front-stage performer.
quotes:
"This book is bursting with memorable anecdotes about [Lanois's] collaborators, another of the debut author's many gifts to fans of rock and country music."

—Kevin Canfield, San Francisco Chronicle

"The master musician and producer offers a typically idiosyncratic take on his life and art . . . Readers will savor the unique character of the producer's unconventional technique, which often employs setting up a jerry-rigged studio with vintage gear in an exotic locale. . . Lanois' book bursts with atmosphere and feeling. He is that rare breed, a lyrical technocrat, and he emerges from the work as one of music's most unusual and charismatic figures. There's really nothing like this oft-rapturous work in the canon of musical memoirs."

—Kirkus

"In his humble, self-effacing memoir of growing up poor in Canada, Lanois, born in a small Quebec town, describes the difficulties he faced . . . He discusses specific albums, including U2's The Joshua Tree and the Unforgettable Fire, Dylan's Oh Mercy and Time Out of Mind, and Harris's Wrecking Ball. And that makes this a real treat for serious music fans."

—Booklist

title: Here After
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Marriage transforms Amy Lin in ways she never anticipated. Her architect husband brings lightness and possibility into her carefully ordered world, encouraging her to embrace spontaneity and see herself through kinder eyes. Their shared future stretches ahead, full of plans and dreams, including an upcoming move that promises new adventures together.

Then, on an ordinary summer day, everything changes in an instant. What begins as a routine morning run becomes the moment that divides Amy's life into before and after. The memoir that emerges from this rupture refuses to offer easy consolation or tidy resolution.

Instead, Lin maps the geography of sudden loss with unflinching precision, charting how grief reshapes not just the present but the past itself. She examines the particular cruelty of losing someone just as life together was truly beginning, and the way tragedy can make even the most treasured memories feel simultaneously precious and unbearable. This is a book about the mathematics of love and loss, written by someone who has learned that some equations can never be solved.
short_summary: An unflinching memoir about profound love cut short by sudden tragedy. Lin writes with devastating clarity about grief's wilderness and love's enduring force.
author_bios: Amy Lin writes and teaches from her home in Calgary, Canada. Ploughshares has featured her work, and she has received residencies from both Yaddo and Casa Comala. Here After marks her debut as a published author.
quotes:
"It has been years since I have been so rocked, so moved, by any book, as I have been by Here After by the earthquaking new talent Amy Lin. Lin invites us into this place of exquisite pain and beauty; what a great gift she has given us."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates and Furies

"How gorgeously Here After tackles the twin specters of grief and survival; a steely, symphonic memoir of unexpected loss—and what (necessarily, unbearably) comes next."

—Carmen Machado, author of In the Dream House

"Here After is a searing account of a young couple's lost future and a writer's descent into the soul-ravaging, shape-shifting wilderness of grief. Amy Lin writes with devastating clarity about the wounds that do not heal, the stories that remain forever fractured, and love's enduring force. This is a profound and essential memoir."

—Laura van den Berg, author of The Third Hotel

title: Bleeding Edge
long_summary:
Fraud investigator Maxine Tarnow thinks she's handling a routine case involving a tech company's suspicious finances. But in the peculiar calm of early 2001 Manhattan—caught between economic uncertainty and an unimaginable tragedy yet to come—nothing stays routine for long.

What begins as corporate number-crunching spirals into a labyrinthine mystery populated by an unforgettable rogues' gallery: speedboat-piloting drug dealers, fragrance experts with disturbing historical obsessions, and ruthless corporate enforcers with particular shoe preferences. The deeper Maxine digs into the digital underground of hackers, programmers, and tech entrepreneurs, the more bodies start appearing.

Pynchon transforms this moment of technological transition into a playground for his signature blend of paranoid conspiracy, absurdist humor, and cultural satire. The novel captures an era when the internet's promise seemed both limitless and ominous, filtering it through the author's kaleidoscopic lens where pop culture references collide with existential dread, and every loose thread might unravel into something far more sinister than anyone anticipated.
short_summary: Fraud investigator Maxine Tarnow gets mixed up with tech billionaires, drug runners, and mysterious deaths in pre-9/11 New York. Pynchon's gonzo take on the early internet era is both hilarious and haunting.
author_bios: Thomas Pynchon wrote V.; The Crying of Lot 49; Gravity's Rainbow; Slow Learner, a collection of short stories; Vineland; Mason & Dixon; Against the Day; Inherent Vice; and Bleeding Edge. His novel Gravity's Rainbow earned him the National Book Award in 1974. Known for his encyclopedic knowledge and reclusive nature, Pynchon remains one of American literature's most enigmatic and influential voices.
quotes:
"Brilliantly written… a joy to read…Full of verbal sass and pizzazz, as well as conspiracies within conspiracies, Bleeding Edge is totally gonzo, totally wonderful. It really is good to have Thomas Pynchon around, doing what he does best."

—Michael Dirda, The Washington Post

"No one, but no one, rivals Pynchon's range of language, his elasticity of syntax, his signature mix of dirty jokes, dread and shining decency… Bleeding Edge is a chamber symphony in P major, so generous of invention it sometimes sprawls, yet so sharp it ultimately pierces."

—Publishers Weekly

"A much-anticipated return, and it's trademark stuff: a blend of existential angst, goofy humor and broad-sweeping bad vibes."

—Kirkus

title: Destiny and Power
subtitle: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush
long_summary:
George H.W. Bush emerges from these pages as a complex figure caught between eras—a patrician politician navigating the final decades of bipartisan governance before America's political center collapsed. Meacham gained unprecedented access to Bush's private thoughts through personal journals and family correspondence, revealing the inner workings of a president who witnessed history's most dramatic moments.

The biography traces Bush's path through pivotal global events—the dissolution of the Soviet Union, military action in the Persian Gulf, and the crumbling of the Berlin Wall—while examining how his old-school approach to leadership clashed with his party's growing conservative movement. Bush's story becomes a meditation on duty versus ambition, revealing a leader whose sense of service often conflicted with political expedience.

This account illuminates how Bush's presidency marked a turning point in American politics, as traditional Republican values gave way to more radical ideologies. Through private moments and public crises, we see a man wrestling with the weight of office while trying to maintain his moral compass in an increasingly polarized political landscape.
short_summary: Meacham crafts an intimate portrait of George H.W. Bush using personal diaries and family access. A nuanced look at the last president of the old political center.
genres: Biography & Autobiography / Presidents & Heads Of State
author_bios: Jon Meacham received the Pulitzer Prize for biography and holds the Rogers Chair in the American Presidency at Vanderbilt University. His numerous New York Times bestsellers include His Truth Is Marching On: John Lewis and the Power of Hope, The Hope of Glory: Reflections on the Last Words of Jesus, Destiny and Power: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush, Thomas Jefferson: The Art of Power, American Lion: Andrew Jackson in the White House, American Gospel, and Franklin and Winston.
quotes:
"Meticulously researched . . . a revealing biography that should serve as the starting point for future evaluations of the forty-first president."

—Kirkus

"A vivid, well-written account."

—Publishers Weekly

"This astonishing book is both timely and timeless. Based on candid interviews and intimate letters and diaries, it provides a deep insight into the character of George H. W. Bush, flavored with colorful anecdotes depicting his relationships with people ranging from Gorbachev and Reagan to his sons George and Jeb. The result is a fascinating and insightful portrayal of the life of an exemplary American citizen."

—Walter Isaacson, author of Steve Jobs

title: Normal People
long_summary:
Two teenagers from an Irish town find themselves on opposite sides of the social divide—he's accepted and she's isolated. Their unexpected connection sparks something neither anticipated, setting off a complex relationship that defies easy categorization.

At university in Dublin, their roles shift dramatically. She blossoms in academic circles while he struggles to find his footing. Their bond persists through this reversal, creating a push-and-pull dynamic that spans years. Each relationship with others seems temporary compared to their magnetic draw toward each other.

Rooney examines how class, trauma, and self-worth shape intimate connections. The novel traces two people caught between attraction and uncertainty, exploring whether love can survive when both individuals are still discovering who they are. Their story becomes a meditation on communication, vulnerability, and the ways we both protect and wound those closest to us.
short_summary: Connell and Marianne orbit each other from small-town Ireland to Trinity College Dublin, their connection surviving class differences and personal demons. Rooney's precision with intimacy and miscommunication makes this devastating.
author_bios: Sally Rooney has established herself as one of Ireland's most distinctive literary voices through her novels Conversations with Friends, Normal People, and Beautiful World, Where Are You. Beyond her writing, Rooney played an active role in developing the Hulu/BBC television adaptation of Normal People, contributing to both the writing and production of the acclaimed series.
quotes:
"A future classic."

—The Guardian

"Rooney is a tough girl; her papercut-sharp sensibility is much more akin to writers like Rachel Kushner, Mary Gaitskill, and the pre–Manhattan Beach Jennifer Egan. . . . Normal People is a nuanced and flinty love story about two young people who 'get' each other, despite class differences and the interference of their own vigorous personal demons. But honestly, Sally Rooney could write a novel about bath mats and I'd still read it. She's that good and that singular a writer."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"[Rooney] has written two fresh and accessible novels. . . . There is so much to say about Rooney's fiction—in my experience, when people who've read her meet they tend to peel off into corners to talk."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: I Hate to Leave This Beautiful Place
long_summary:
Memory can be a dangerous territory to navigate, especially for a writer whose life reads like fiction itself. Howard Norman's memoir charts the collision between lived experience and literary imagination, examining how trauma and beauty interweave to create the stories we tell.

From adolescence onward, Norman's path defied convention. A summer spent working on a traveling library introduced him to both literature and heartbreak, while family dysfunction provided an early education in human complexity. His subsequent years in the Arctic—translating Indigenous stories and absorbing their wisdom—offered both refuge and revelation. These remote landscapes became a sanctuary where ancient narratives merged with personal awakening.

Yet even the most carefully constructed life remains vulnerable to chaos. Norman explores how sudden violence can shatter the illusion of safety, transforming familiar spaces into sites of incomprehensible loss. Through it all, he searches for meaning in the fragments—finding that the act of storytelling itself becomes both wound and healing.

This memoir interrogates the mysterious alchemy through which raw experience becomes art, asking whether literature can truly make sense of life's most bewildering moments.
short_summary: Novelist Howard Norman weaves together the haunting and redemptive moments of his life—a con-man father, Arctic translations, a murder-suicide in his home. Each incident stranger than fiction, transformed into luminous art.
author_bios: Howard Norman has written novels, memoirs, and children's literature throughout his distinguished career. His fiction earned him two National Book Award nominations, and he received the prestigious Lannan Award in Literature. Norman is currently working on Rain Enters My Diary, which chronicles his correspondence with poet W. S. Merwin through an epistolary exploration of their friendship. He makes his home in Vermont.
quotes:
"Norman's tale is conversational, elegant, and full of life…All Norman's stories – even the last, of a tragedy visited on him and his family, another intimation of death-are related with grace. He shows that the pleasures of the memoir often lie not in a life of dramatic incident but in the flights and transfigurations of a contemplative mind."

—Jane Smiley, Harper's Magazine

"Some books celebrate the human condition; others commiserate with us. This memoir does both, and offers fine, subtly fey companionship to boot."

—Helen Oyeyemi, NPR

"Five stellar personal essays by Norman that shed light on his melancholy, tragedy-struck fiction and larger human failures....A bracing, no-nonsense memoir, infused with fresh takes on love, death and human nature."

—Kirkus

title: Flashlight
long_summary:
A decade-old tragedy casts its shadow across three generations in this intricate family saga. The disappearance of Serk during a nighttime beach walk with his daughter Louisa becomes the epicenter around which past and present collide. Through shifting perspectives that circle back to that fateful evening, the novel reveals a family built on deliberate erasure—parents who have cut themselves off from their histories, secrets that span continents, and the unexpected return of Tobias, whose connection to the family threatens to unravel everything.

Choi constructs a narrative puzzle that moves between Japan, Korea, and America, examining how displacement and loss echo through bloodlines. Each family member carries fragments of truth about that night, but the complete picture remains elusive. The novel asks profound questions about identity, belonging, and the stories we tell ourselves to survive. As the mystery deepens, it becomes clear that understanding what happened to Serk requires confronting the ghosts each character has spent years avoiding—and recognizing that some truths can only be seen in the dark.
short_summary: When a father vanishes during a beach walk with his ten-year-old daughter, the mystery ripples across generations and continents. Choi weaves a haunting meditation on family secrets and the weight of history.
author_bios: Susan Choi has written five novels, including Trust Exercise, which won the National Book Award for Fiction, along with The Foreign Student, American Woman, A Person of Interest, and My Education. Her work has earned her the Asian American Literary Award for fiction, the PEN/W. G. Sebald Award, a Lambda Literary Award, and the Sunday Times Audible Short Story Award. She has received fellowships from both the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation. Susan Choi teaches in the Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Instantly bewitching . . . Susan Choi's fictional investigation reveals a writer at the height of her spectacular powers."

—Jennifer Egan, author of The Candy House

"This gripping story of a family in crisis is tough to shake."

—Publishers Weekly

"Ferociously smart and full of surprises, Flashlight is thrilling to the last."

—Eleanor Catton, author of Birnam Wood

title: The Unwinding
subtitle: An Inner History of the New America
long_summary:
George Packer constructs a mosaic of American decline by following disparate lives across three transformative decades. His subjects range from displaced industrial workers to tech moguls, each story illuminating how economic forces and institutional collapse have reshaped the national landscape.

The narrative jumps between personal struggles and public failures, showing how the promises that once bound Americans together have steadily eroded. Packer examines the growing chasm between those who prospered during this period of change and those left behind, creating a portrait of a country where traditional pathways to success have vanished for vast numbers of people. This approach reveals not just what happened to America, but how it felt to live through these seismic shifts—whether you were riding the wave of new prosperity or watching your world disappear.
short_summary: Packer weaves together intimate portraits of ordinary Americans with snapshots of public figures to reveal how three decades of upheaval unraveled the social contract.
genres: Political Science / Political Ideologies / Conservatism & Liberalism
author_bios: George Packer writes for The Atlantic and has earned recognition for his penetrating examinations of American politics and foreign policy. His notable works include The Unwinding: An Inner History of the New America, which received the National Book Award, along with The Assassins' Gate: America in Iraq and Our Man: Richard Holbrooke and the End of the American Century, honored with both the Hitchens Prize and Los Angeles Times Book Prize for biography. Packer has additionally published novels, theatrical work, and served as editor for a comprehensive collection of George Orwell's essays.
quotes:
"Original, incisive, courageous, and essential. One of the best works of nonfiction I've read in years."

—Katherine Boo, National Book Award–winning author of Behind the Beautiful Forevers

"George Packer serves us the history of our own life and times in a magisterial look at the America we lost."

—Lawrence Wright, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Thirteen Days in September, The Looming Tower & Going Clear

"As with George Orwell's, each of George Packer's sentences carries a pulse of moral force. The Unwinding is a sweeping and powerful book that everyone should read."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon & The Lost City of Z

title: Open City
long_summary:
Julius, a Nigerian medical resident in New York, finds solace in long walks through the city's neighborhoods. These meandering journeys offer escape from the pressures of his medical training and space to contemplate a recent romantic separation. Despite moving through crowds of strangers, his sense of alienation persists.

His explorations extend beyond Manhattan's geography into encounters with individuals from diverse backgrounds, each interaction adding layers to his understanding of displacement and belonging. Memory carries him from present-day Brussels back to his childhood in Nigeria, while introspection forces him to confront aspects of himself he'd rather avoid.

Teju Cole crafts a meditation on what it means to exist between cultures, examining how personal history intersects with larger questions of race and national belonging. The novel's contemplative pace mirrors its protagonist's thoughtful observations about art, literature, and the weight of collective memory. Through Julius's intellectual wanderings, Cole interrogates themes of freedom, grief, and the stories we tell ourselves about who we are.
short_summary: A young Nigerian doctor wanders Manhattan, processing art, history, and memory while confronting uncomfortable truths about himself and America. Meditative and devastating in equal measure.
author_bios: Born to Nigerian parents in 1975, Teju Cole spent his childhood in Lagos before returning to the United States. His literary works span multiple genres, including the novel Open City, the essay collections Known and Strange Things and Black Paper, and the experimental photo book Blind Spot. Cole's writing has earned him the PEN/Hemingway Award, Internationaler Literaturpreis, Windham-Campbell Prize, and Guggenheim Fellowship. Currently serving as professor of creative writing at Harvard University, he also contributes regularly to The New York Times Magazine and holds membership in the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
quotes:
"A gorgeous, crystalline, and cumulative investigation of memory, identity, and erasure. It gathers its power inexorably, page by page, and ultimately reveals itself as nothing less than a searing tour de force. Teju Cole might just be a W. G. Sebald for the twenty-first century."

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See, Cloud Cuckoo Land & The Shell Collector

"Reminiscent of the works of W.G. Sebald, this dreamy, incantatory debut was the most beautiful novel I read this year—the kind of book that remains on your nightstand long after you finish so that you can continue dipping in occasionally as a nighttime consolation."

—Ruth Franklin, The New Republic

"A psychological hand grenade."

—Alexis Madrigal, The Atlantic

title: Manhattan Beach
long_summary:
The mystery begins in childhood for Anna Kerrigan, who witnesses a cryptic meeting between her father and the enigmatic Dexter Styles. The encounter plants questions that will haunt her for years, especially after her father's unexplained disappearance.

Set against the backdrop of World War II, Anna finds herself breaking barriers at the Brooklyn Naval Yard, taking on the perilous role of underwater ship repair—work that was unthinkable for women before the war changed everything. Her descent into the murky depths mirrors her deeper investigation into family secrets that have shaped her life.

A chance reunion with Styles at a smoky nightclub opens doors to a shadowy underworld where the lines between loyalty and survival blur. As Anna navigates this dangerous terrain of dock workers, criminals, and wartime opportunists, she begins to piece together the truth about her father's fate and the forces that drove him away. The novel captures a pivotal moment in American history through the lens of one woman's determination to uncover the past while forging her own unprecedented path forward.
short_summary: During World War II, Anna Kerrigan becomes the Brooklyn Naval Yard's first female diver while searching for answers about her vanished father. A noir-tinged exploration of wartime transformation and family secrets.
author_bios: Jennifer Egan has published six works of fiction, including the Andrew Carnegie Medal winner Manhattan Beach and the Pulitzer Prize-winning A Visit from the Goon Squad, which also earned the National Book Critics Circle Award. Her other novels include The Keep, Look at Me (a National Book Award Finalist), and The Invisible Circus, plus the story collection Emerald City. Jennifer Egan's fiction appears regularly in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"A bounteous miracle that makes you feel that past time, and our time, differently; everything becomes freshly energized, infused with humanity, vital, sad, and full of importance. To see the world through Egan's eyes is to be moved, through language, to new adoration of the world. I don't know a better writer working today. There is a generosity in her prose that is vastly enlivening to its reader and brings about that beautiful effect fiction sometimes causes: more, and better-grounded, fondness for reality, just as it is."

—George Saunders

"Manhattan Beach is ambitiously and deliciously plot-driven."

—NPR

"Egan's first foray into historical fiction makes you forget you're reading historical fiction at all."

—Elle

title: The End of Your Life Book Club
long_summary:
A son and his dying mother discover an unexpected sanctuary in literature during her cancer treatment. What begins as casual conversations about books evolves into something deeper—a shared journey through stories that helps them navigate the complexities of mortality, memory, and love.

Their reading list spans genres and generations, from beloved classics to contemporary fiction, each selection opening doors to discussions about life's biggest questions. These aren't just book reviews; they're explorations of faith, family legacy, and what it means to face the end with grace. The hospital waiting rooms and treatment centers become unlikely venues for literary discovery.

Schwalbe crafts more than a typical memoir about loss. He reveals how stories become bridges between people, creating intimacy even as time runs short. Each book they share offers new vocabulary for emotions too complex for ordinary conversation. The result is both a love letter to reading and a testament to the ways literature can transform our most difficult experiences into something meaningful and even beautiful.
short_summary: Schwalbe chronicles the profound book club he formed with his mother during her final battle with cancer. A tender exploration of how literature becomes lifeline, offering solace and connection when it matters most.
author_bios: Will Schwalbe brings experience from multiple facets of the literary world to his writing. He has served as an editor at Macmillan and worked in digital media, while also contributing journalism to The New York Times and South China Morning Post. Schwalbe has written Books for Living and The End of Your Life Book Club, and collaborated on Send. He makes his home in New York.
quotes:
"With a refreshing forthrightness, and an excellent list of books included, this is an astonishing, pertinent, and wonderfully welcome work."

—Publishers Weekly

"Will Schwalbe gives us two love stories in one: that of his relationship with his dynamo of a mother as her horizons shrink, and that of their mutual devotion to the printed word, infinitely and insistently engaging. Tender and touching and beautifully done."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra

"In a heartfelt tribute to his mother, Schwalbe illustrates the power of the written word to expand our knowledge of ourselves and others."

—Kirkus

title: The Mighty Red
long_summary:
Three hearts converge in rural North Dakota, where love triangles and economic uncertainty create unexpected drama. Gary Geist faces the weight of inheriting family farmland while pursuing Kismet Poe, whose unpredictable nature both attracts and mystifies him. But Gary isn't the only one captivated—Hugo, whose gentle disposition masks fierce determination, believes Kismet belongs with him instead.

Meanwhile, Kismet's mother Crystal navigates late-night trucking routes, hauling sugar beets while wrestling with her own visions and fears about what lies ahead for her family. Their interconnected stories unfold against the vast Red River Valley, where ancient geological forces meet modern crises—pesticide contamination, climate disruption, and the 2008 financial collapse that makes every dollar spent feel like a gamble.

Erdrich captures the absurd beauty of human connection amid uncertainty, crafting a story where romance blooms alongside environmental anxiety. Her characters inhabit a world where the practical and mystical intertwine, where guardian angels might appear on midnight highways, and where the future of both love and land hangs in the balance.
short_summary: Three people orbit a wedding in North Dakota farm country as economic collapse and environmental crisis reshape their world. Erdrich weaves humor and heartbreak into a luminous portrait of ordinary lives under extraordinary pressure.
author_bios: Louise Erdrich belongs to the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa and has written numerous acclaimed novels alongside poetry collections, children's literature, and a memoir about early motherhood. Based in Minnesota with her daughters, Erdrich also runs Birchbark Books, an independent bookstore.
quotes:
"[Erdrich is] a master, a legend at building stories around community. . . . This is a book about family and community. It is a book about upward mobility and finding our true passions. You will love Kismet."

—Jenna Bush Hager, The Read with Jenna Book Club

"In The Mighty Red, humor and sorrow are fused together like twined tree trunks that keep each other standing.... Erdrich is so good at romantic comedy, with her special blend of Austen sense and Ojibwe sensibility. As the funny scenes flow one after another, you may not even notice the stray drops of blood scattered along the novel's margins. . . . As usual when closing a book by Louise Erdrich, I'm left wondering, how can a novel be so funny and so moving? How can life?"

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A captivating tale of love and everyday life amid environmental upheaval and the 2008 financial crisis. . . . Erdrich excels at the slow simmer, and once again she delivers a deliciously seductive masterwork."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Book of Lives
subtitle: A Memoir of Sorts
long_summary:
Margaret Atwood's memoir opens in the untamed wilderness of northern Quebec, where she spent her formative years alongside parents who valued scientific inquiry and independence. This nomadic existence, following her entomologist father's research through remote forests, created a foundation both solitary and exhilarating.

Atwood weaves together the threads of memory and creation, showing how pivotal experiences became the seeds of her most celebrated works. A particularly difficult period at school would eventually bloom into Cat's Eye, while the unsettling atmosphere of 1980s Berlin provided the backdrop for conceiving The Handmaid's Tale.

The memoir pulses with vivid encounters—literary figures, wildlife, celebrities, and characters who seem lifted from her own fiction. Through her relationship with fellow writer Graeme Gibson and her navigation of significant historical moments, Atwood illuminates the mysterious alchemy between lived experience and literary creation. She offers readers an intimate look at how a singular imagination processes the world, transforming observation and memory into the stories that have defined contemporary literature.
short_summary: Atwood traces her unconventional childhood in the Quebec wilderness to becoming one of our most essential writers. A luminous memoir that reveals how life transforms into art.
author_bios: Margaret Atwood has published more than fifty books spanning fiction, poetry, and critical essays. Her novels include Cat's Eye, The Robber Bride, Alias Grace, The Blind Assassin, and the MaddAddam trilogy. The Handmaid's Tale, her 1985 masterpiece, found its sequel in The Testaments, which earned the Booker Prize in 2019. Atwood's accolades include the Arthur C. Clarke Award, the Franz Kafka Prize, and the PEN America Lifetime Achievement Award. She makes her home in Toronto.
quotes:
"Luminous prose, a palpable lust for life, and an invaluable glimpse into the mind of a literary giant make this a must-read."

—Publishers Weekly

"Engaging, wise, and marvelously witty—illuminating both the craft of writing and the art of living."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Atwood's long-awaited memoir covers her arc to becoming one of the leading voices of modern literature."

—New York Magazine

title: Are You My Mother?
subtitle: A Comic Drama
long_summary:
In this deeply personal graphic memoir, Bechdel examines the intricate dynamics between herself and her intellectually vibrant mother—a woman whose love of literature, theater, and music masked profound disappointments in marriage and motherhood. The relationship fractured early, marked by an absence of physical affection that began in Bechdel's childhood.

Through her signature blend of illustration and introspection, Bechdel investigates this emotional distance, weaving together insights from psychoanalytic theory, unexpected revelations found in children's literature, and reflections on her own romantic relationships. The narrative moves between past and present, theory and memory, as she attempts to understand both her mother's unfulfilled artistic dreams and their lasting impact on their bond.

What emerges is a meditation on creativity, inheritance, and the ways mothers and daughters both wound and shape each other. Bechdel's investigation becomes a form of reconciliation—tentative but genuine—offering insights that will resonate with anyone who has struggled to understand a parent's inner life.
short_summary: Bechdel follows her acclaimed Fun Home with another brilliant graphic memoir, this time exploring her complex relationship with her artistically gifted mother. A tender, funny excavation of family secrets and creative inheritance.
author_bios: Alison Bechdel gained widespread recognition through her comic strip Dykes to Watch Out For before achieving literary acclaim with her graphic memoirs Fun Home and Are You My Mother?, both New York Times bestsellers. Fun Home earned recognition as Time magazine's top book selection and inspired a Tony Award-winning Broadway musical. Her recent work The Secret to Superman Strength received designation as a New York Times Best Graphic Novel of 2021. Bechdel has been honored as a MacArthur Fellow.
quotes:
"Sad, funny, sprawling graphic memoir...An intensely personal, specific story, but Bechdel's imaginative narrative techniques make it easily as compelling as any fiction...Its stylistic flexibility accomodates more layers than any straight documentary or prose memoir could support...This work is her link in the long chain connecting her foremothers and their daughters and all of the other women who shaped her."

—The Atlantic

"...Magnificent... Whatever issues Bechdel has with her mother, one always has the sense that she likes her as much as she loves her. That affection — and the real sense one gets of her mother reading these pages, running her finger over the tenderly drawn panels of their history — gives this book an urgency and an intimacy that Fun Home, in retrospect, lacked... Bechdel's triumph is not just that she's emerged from her tunnel, with weary but clear eyes, but that she's brought her mother with her. Grade: A"

—Entertainment Weekly

"...Are You My Mother is as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs...The tragedy and comedy are so entwined, so gloriously balanced, the reader can't help being fascinated. The book delivers lightening bolts of revelation...I haven't encountered a book about being an artist, or about the punishing entanglements of mothers and daughters, as engaging, profound or original as this one in a long time. In fact, the book made such a deep impression on me that after reading it I walked around for days seeing little bits and snatches of my life as Alison Bechdel drawings."

—The New York Times

title: Lesser Known Monsters of the 21st Century
long_summary:
Reality shifts and bends in this collection of twelve speculative tales that find the uncanny hiding in plain sight. Fu crafts intimate portraits of characters navigating worlds where the impossible feels inevitable—where growing wings might be just another part of adolescence, or where mysterious toy boxes hold the power to manipulate time itself.

From children drawn to a cursed doll to a bride fleeing toward an encounter with something monstrous from the deep, each narrative creates its own internal logic. An exhausted insomniac discovers unexpected intimacy with a mythical figure, while another character confronts a home consumed by an invasion of insects that defies all reason.

Through these imaginative scenarios, Fu examines the weight of modern existence—our relationship with technology, the complexity of desire, and the ways we grapple with mortality and shame. The collection reveals how thin the membrane between ordinary and extraordinary really is, using fantastical elements to illuminate the contradictions and yearnings that shape human experience.
short_summary: Twelve speculative stories where the surreal lurks beneath everyday life. Fu transforms modern anxieties into haunting fables about technology, desire, and what it means to be human.
author_bios: Kim Fu has written two novels, a poetry collection, and the story collection Lesser Known Monsters of the 21st Century, which received the Washington State Book Award, the Pacific Northwest Book Award, and the Danuta Gleed Literary Award. The collection was also a finalist for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, the Ignyte Awards, and the Shirley Jackson Awards. Fu makes her home in Seattle, Washington.
quotes:
"The strange and wonderful define Kim Fu's story collection, where the line between fantasy and reality fades in and out, elusive and beckoning."

—The New York Times Book Review

"Stellar. . . . Fu's stories crackle with quirky plots, and her characters' problems and hunger for new possibilities are palpable. This is a winner."

—Publishers Weekly

"Powerful. . . . Fu addresses questions of technology and community with grace and subtlety."

—Kirkus

title: Get the Picture
subtitle: A Mind-Bending Journey among the Inspired Artists and Obsessive Art Fiends Who Taught Me How to See
long_summary:
What drives someone to spend their life savings on a piece of contemporary art? Journalist Bianca Bosker found herself captivated by this question after stumbling into New York's elite art scene. Her curiosity led to an immersive investigation that took her from gallery back rooms to museum guard posts, from artist studios to exclusive collector parties.
