Bosker embeds herself completely in this rarefied world, learning to stretch canvases until her hands are raw, enduring bizarre performance art, and spending hours studying single artworks as a security guard. She interviews everyone from struggling artists juggling multiple jobs to billionaire collectors who treat art as both passion and investment. Through her journey, she uncovers how the contemporary art world operates—its economics, its social hierarchies, and its cultural influence.

The result is both an entertaining exposé of art world pretensions and a genuine exploration of why visual art continues to matter in our digital age. Bosker examines everything from ancient cave paintings to social media aesthetics, questioning how we see, what we value, and whether beauty still has a place in contemporary culture. Her adventure reveals as much about human nature as it does about art itself.
short_summary: The Cork Dork author infiltrates New York's exclusive art world with her signature immersive journalism. Hilarious, revelatory, and surprisingly moving—a brilliant exploration of why art matters.
author_bios: Bianca Bosker wrote the New York Times bestselling Cork Dork and contributes regularly to The Atlantic. Her journalism has been featured in The New Yorker, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and The Best American Travel Writing. She has received recognition from the New York Press Club and Society of Professional Journalists for her work.
quotes:
"[Bosker] has written a dark comedy of manners, and what she exposes here might be a new kind of country club mentality, where the cultural elite can no longer exclude people based on race, gender or sexual identity, so they come up with clever new ways to build moats around their little castles. . . . Get the Picture is one of the funniest books I've read about New York's contemporary art scene . . . Brilliant."

—The Washington Post

"Just about every page of Bianca Bosker's deep dive into New York's exclusive art world made me laugh . . . Useful to anyone who has been intimidated by hallowed art institutions or been confounded by what's on their walls."

—NPR

"This book freaked me out. Bosker's accessible, conversational spelunking into the world of contemporary art so powerfully rehydrated the PTSD in me between the little kid artist I once was with the self-consciously constricted thinker I became in art school that at one point I simply had to put it down, shaken. If you've ever wondered 'what happened' to art—galleries, critics, collectors—and, of course, artists—then this book is a very companionable start. It's also very funny, to say nothing of very vivid. And, confoundingly, very, very difficult to put down."

—Chris Ware, New Yorker artist/writer, author of Building Stories

title: The Bright Sword
subtitle: A Novel of King Arthur
long_summary:
The age of heroes has ended. Collum, an ambitious young knight, reaches Camelot expecting glory but finds only ruins and regret. Arthur lies dead, his greatest champions scattered or fallen, leaving behind only the Round Table's forgotten members—a Saracen warrior seeking belonging, a court jester elevated beyond his station, and a sorceress haunted by her betrayal of Merlin.

Britain teeters on the edge of chaos as ancient powers stir and Morgan le Fay marshals forces that predate Christianity itself. Without Excalibur, without their king, this ragtag band of survivors faces an impossible task: rebuilding a kingdom from its ashes.

Grossman reimagines the Arthurian cycle through the eyes of those left behind, transforming familiar myths into something startlingly contemporary. Rather than celebrating perfect knights and noble quests, this tale asks harder questions about legacy, failure, and whether broken people can mend a shattered world. The result feels both ancient and immediate—a meditation on how we pick up the pieces when our heroes disappoint us and our certainties crumble.
short_summary: After King Arthur's death, his surviving misfits—outcasts, fools, and former enemies—must rebuild Camelot from the ruins. Grossman crafts a brilliant post-apocalyptic take on Arthurian legend.
author_bios: Lev Grossman wrote the internationally bestselling Magicians trilogy (The Magicians, The Magician King, and The Magician's Land), which became a popular SYFY television series spanning five seasons. Beyond fantasy novels, Grossman has penned children's books The Golden Swift and The Silver Arrow, and worked as a screenwriter. His writing has been featured in major publications including Time, Vanity Fair, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Times. He currently resides in New York City with his family.
quotes:
"For anyone who's ever craved a seat at the Round Table. Utterly enchanting."

—Rebecca Yarros, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Fourth Wing and Iron Flame

"If you love King Arthur as much as I do, you'll love Lev Grossman's The Bright Sword, a fresh and engrossing take on the Matter of Britain featuring a colorful cast of Round Table knights who don't often get as much story time as they deserve. The creator of The Magicians has woven another spell."

—George R. R. Martin, #1 New York Times bestselling author of A Game of Thrones

"The story of King Arthur has been told and substantially altered many times over the centuries, and explored by a multitude of contemporary novelists, but the author of the Magicians trilogy makes room for himself here. . . . Very few writers have explored post-Arthurian Britain or focused quite so much on developing the stories of the minor characters in the saga. . . . A fresh take."

—Kirkus

title: The Line Becomes a River
subtitle: Dispatches from the Border
long_summary:
Growing up in the Southwest borderlands, Francisco Cantú carries the region's contradictions in his very DNA—his heritage tied to both sides of an increasingly militarized divide. His decision to become a Border Patrol agent stems from a desire to understand the harsh desert terrain that shaped him, but the reality proves more complex than anticipated.

The work transforms him into a tracker of human desperation, someone who navigates between life and death in landscapes that can kill. Each shift brings encounters with people pushed to extremes, forcing Cantú to wrestle with his role in a system that reduces human stories to statistics. The psychological toll eventually drives him away from the uniform.

Yet leaving the Border Patrol doesn't mean escaping its reach. The true test comes through personal connection—a friend's simple journey to see family becomes a nightmare that refuses resolution. Through this crisis, Cantú realizes that borders aren't just geographical lines but forces that reshape everyone they touch, creating wounds that extend far beyond any map.
short_summary: A former Border Patrol agent chronicles his time policing the U.S.-Mexico border in this searing blend of memoir and moral reckoning. Cantú's unflinching prose reveals how violence follows him long after leaving the job.
author_bios: Francisco Cantú spent four years as a Border Patrol agent working across Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas deserts. His literary achievements include a Pushcart Prize, 2017 Whiting Award, and 2018 Art for Justice fellowship, along with recognition as a former Fulbright fellow. Cantú's essays and reporting have been featured in The New York Times, Best American Essays, Harper's, Guernica, and This American Life. He currently leads the Southwest Field Studies in Writing Program at the University of Arizona.
quotes:
"Fresh, urgent...A devastating narrative of the very real human effects of depersonalized policy."

—Kirkus

"Cantú's rich prose and deep empathy make this an indispensable look at one of America's most divisive issues."

—Publishers Weekly

"A beautiful, fiercely honest, and nevertheless deeply empathetic look at those who police the border and the migrants who risk – and lose -- their lives crossing it. In a time of often ill-informed or downright deceitful political rhetoric, this book is an invaluable corrective."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment

title: The Lowland
long_summary:
Two brothers grow up sharing everything in 1960s Calcutta—games, secrets, even mistaken identities. Yet their paths diverge dramatically as political upheaval sweeps through India. One brother embraces revolutionary fervor, joining the dangerous Naxalite uprising that promises to reshape society through violence. The other seeks knowledge in American laboratories, trading familiar chaos for scholarly solitude.

Tragedy strikes in the marshy lowland near their childhood home, shattering the family and leaving behind a young widow carrying secrets of her own. The surviving brother faces an impossible choice: remain safely distant in his adopted country, or return to confront the devastating legacy of idealism gone wrong.

Lahiri crafts a story that moves between continents and decades, examining how political conviction can destroy the very bonds it claims to protect. The novel questions whether we can ever truly escape the consequences of our choices, or if love and duty demand we carry others' burdens as our own. This is fiction that understands how personal and political forces intertwine, creating reverberations that shape multiple generations.
short_summary: Two brothers in 1960s Calcutta are bound by love but torn apart when one joins a violent political rebellion. Lahiri weaves a multigenerational saga of family, exile, and the wounds that echo across continents.
author_bios: Jhumpa Lahiri has written four fiction works—Interpreter of Maladies, The Namesake, Unaccustomed Earth, and The Lowland—along with the nonfiction work In Other Words. Her numerous honors include the Pulitzer Prize, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Malamud Award, Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award, Premio Gregor von Rezzori, DSC Prize for South Asian Literature, 2014 National Humanities Medal, and Premio Internazionale Viareggio-Versilia.
quotes:
"A tale of two continents in an era of political tumult, rendered with devastating depth and clarity by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author. The narrative proceeds from the simplicity of a fairy tale into a complex novel of moral ambiguity and aftershocks, with revelations that continue through decades and generations until the very last page. . . . The story of two brothers in India who are exceptionally close to each other, and yet completely different, the novel spans more than four decades in the life of [their] family, shaped and shaken by the events that have brought them together and tear them apart. . . . Lahiri has earned renown for her short stories, [yet] this masterful novel deserves to attract an even wider readership."

—Kirkus

"Lahiri's work resists pithy quotation, and until now, has avoided fireworks. But [her] first sentence works like a slow fuse. Divided consciousness has been her recurrent theme, [which] the transplanted Indian families in her earlier work know well. This time, she daringly redraws the map—[as] one of two close-knit brothers becomes a revolutionary while the other proceeds to the U.S. Loyalties are tested, twisted to extremes that become clear only toward the end. Here worlds, new and old, contain terrors."

—Ann Hulbert

"Lahiri tracks, with patience and tenacity, the emotional and geographical distances that time opens up between people, the things that get lost in those spaces, and the rare and surprising things that endure. In The Lowland, we are all emigrants, not from one country to another but from the present to the future. Lahiri's prose style is legendarily smooth, unshowy, unvarying . . . The Lowland gains tremendous power as it goes on. Language takes on the role of time itself. The Lowland feels less like a story being told than a tide slowly going out, gradually, inevitably revealing the shape of what was there all along."

—Lev Grossman

title: The Dream Hotel
long_summary:
Sara's nightmare begins at an airport, where government agents arrest her not for any crime she's committed, but for one an algorithm claims she will commit. Based on analysis of her dreams, the system has flagged her as a future threat to her husband's safety.

Trapped in a detention facility with other women branded as "dreamers," Sara discovers a world where thoughts themselves have become criminal evidence. The institution operates on shifting rules designed to extend imprisonment indefinitely, turning rehabilitation into a cruel game of survival. As months stretch into an uncertain future, Sara must navigate both the facility's oppressive bureaucracy and her fellow inmates' desperation.

The arrival of a rebellious newcomer fractures the center's carefully maintained control, forcing Sara to confront the corporate machinery that has stolen her life. Lalami constructs a terrifying vision of surveillance capitalism taken to its logical extreme, where our most private moments become data points in someone else's profit margin. This dystopian thriller interrogates the price we pay for technological convenience and asks whether our inner lives can ever truly be quantified, no matter how sophisticated the algorithms that claim to read them.
short_summary: Dreams become evidence in Lalami's chilling near-future thriller. When an algorithm predicts Sara will harm her husband based on her subconscious, she's detained indefinitely alongside other women fighting to prove their innocence.
author_bios: Laila Lalami has written five books, with The Moor's Account earning her the American Book Award, Arab-American Book Award, and Hurston/Wright Legacy Award while reaching the Booker Prize longlist and becoming a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Her latest work, The Other Americans, achieved national bestseller status, claimed the Simpson/Joyce Carol Oates Prize, and received a National Book Award nomination. With translations spanning twenty languages, Lalami has received fellowships from both the Guggenheim Foundation and Harvard University's Radcliffe Institute.
quotes:
"A gripping, Kafkaesque foray into an all-too-plausible future where data collection penetrates interior life, The Dream Hotel is also an elegant meditation on identity and what we sacrifice, unthinkingly, for the sake of convenience."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Candy House

"The Dream Hotel offers a stark vision of the future—in which America is a surveillance state, ruled by the intertwined forces of capital and government, powered by all-too-fallible algorithm that determines criminality based on citizen's dreams. That's plainly a metaphor for extant practices of social control, but Laila Lalami's extraordinary new novel is more than just a political warning; the book is an exploration of the psyche itself, the strange ungovernable forces of fate and emotion that make us human."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"The world in Lalami's novel feels one step away from ours, which makes it astonishingly easy to slip inside. The women in The Dream Hotel grapple with the ways in which capitalism and technology sell off the pieces of ourselves most personal, most vulnerable, most private. A thrilling, urgent, and large-hearted novel that I can't wait to press upon other readers."

—Kelly Link, author of The Book of Love

title: Mark Twain
long_summary:
Samuel Clemens transformed himself from a Mississippi River pilot into America's most celebrated literary voice, but the journey from small-town Missouri to international fame came at enormous personal cost. Ron Chernow's masterful biography reveals how a restless young man with big dreams reinvented himself as Mark Twain, crafting both a public persona and a body of work that would define American literature.

Chernow traces the evolution of a complex figure who craved recognition while maintaining an outsider's perspective on American society. The man who created Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn lived with equal intensity—throwing himself into risky business schemes that ultimately destroyed his fortune and forced his family into years of exile abroad. Behind the wit and public acclaim lay profound personal tragedies, including the loss of his beloved wife and two daughters.

Drawing from extensive archival research, this biography illuminates how Twain's life mirrored the nation's own growing pains during westward expansion and industrialization. Chernow presents an unflinching examination of America's greatest humorist, a man whose struggles with grief, financial ruin, and moral complexity shaped both his art and his era's understanding of slavery's enduring impact.
short_summary: Ron Chernow's monumental biography captures the magnificent and often maddening life of Samuel Clemens, the Missouri dreamer who became Mark Twain. From steamboat pilot to America's first literary celebrity, this is the definitive portrait.
author_bios: Ron Chernow has written seven acclaimed biographies and received the 2015 National Humanities Medal. His work includes the National Book Award-winning The House of Morgan, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Washington: A Life, and Alexander Hamilton, which earned the George Washington Book Prize. Chernow has been a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist twice and stands among only three living biographers honored with the Gold Medal for Biography from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"A comprehensive biography of one of the most important writers and social commentators in American history."

—Barack Obama

"It's a monstrous good time for a body to take an interest in Twain. In recent years, the humorist has seen his life and books reinterpreted by a literary darling, a graphic novel, a work of scholarship—even by himself, in an autobiography that waited a century for publication. Now, one of our most celebrated biographers is taking his own swing at a life so full, lively and multifarious—dare I say—picaresque, it would not have been out of place in one of Twain's own novels."

—NPR

"Remarkable . . . Chernow is an exceptional portraitist, adding depth and shadow to bring his subject fully to life. The impeccable research blends seamlessly into a narrative that examines Twain in all his guises: devoted family man, writer, publisher, entrepreneur, and inventor. Like his subject, Chernow has a keen ear for the perfect quote, insult, and witty rejoinder. This monumental achievement will stand as the definitive life of Mark Twain."

—Booklist

title: Connie
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Born into a family of Chinese immigrants, Connie Chung carved an extraordinary path through American television journalism at a time when newsrooms were dominated by white men. Her story begins with parents who fled war-ravaged China, ultimately settling in America where their youngest daughter would shatter glass ceilings in broadcast news.

Chung's memoir reveals the complex identity of someone caught between two worlds—honoring her family's heritage while fully embracing American culture. She faced discrimination on multiple fronts yet refused to be deterred from her ambitions. Her candid account spans decades of groundbreaking journalism, from early reporting assignments to making history at CBS.

Beyond professional achievements, she opens up about deeply personal experiences: her enduring marriage to fellow journalist Maury Povich, surviving childhood sexual abuse, and the joy of late-in-life parenthood through adoption. This isn't just another celebrity memoir—it's an unflinching examination of what it costs to be first, the price of visibility, and the resilience required to thrive in an industry that wasn't built for someone like her.
short_summary: Television news pioneer Connie Chung delivers a sharp, witty memoir that pulls no punches. From breaking barriers as the first Asian woman in network news to navigating personal trauma and triumph, she reveals it all.
author_bios: Connie Chung made television history when she became the first woman to co-anchor the CBS Evening News, joining an elite group as only the second woman ever to anchor a network evening broadcast. Throughout her distinguished career, Chung shattered barriers in an industry that had long excluded women and people of color, establishing herself as a trailblazing journalist and news anchor who paved the way for future generations of diverse voices in broadcast journalism.
quotes:
"This delightful memoir is filled with Connie Chung's trademark wit, sharp insights, and deep understanding of people. It's a revealing account of what it's like to be a woman breaking barriers in the world of TV news, filled with colorful tales of rivalry and triumph. But it also has a larger theme: how the line between serious reporting and tabloid journalism became blurred."

—Walter Isaacson, New York Times bestselling author of Steve Jobs

"[F]rank and entertaining...Chung writes breezily and with irreverent humor about the scoops, the internal politics and the pure hustle that eventually got her to the top."

—The New York Times

"Lucky for readers, Chung is a sharer; her candor is commendable and unvarnished...Chung's memoir, often enchanting and enlightening, serves as a historical account of broadcast news during its most powerful, competitive and sometimes most absurd era."

—The Washington Post

title: Matterhorn
subtitle: A Novel of the Vietnam War
long_summary:
In the dense Vietnamese highlands, Marine officer Waino Mellas discovers that survival requires more than military training. His unit faces relentless challenges from multiple fronts: an elusive enemy, unforgiving terrain, and the corrosive effects of a war that seems to have no clear purpose.

The real complexity emerges from within Bravo Company itself, where racial prejudice and competing egos create fractures as dangerous as any external threat. Leadership failures compound the chaos, leaving young soldiers to navigate impossible choices with insufficient guidance.

As enemy forces close in and the Marines find themselves trapped in hostile territory, the story examines how ordinary individuals respond to extraordinary pressure. Marlantes draws from his own combat experience to illuminate the paradoxes of warfare—the simultaneous presence of terror and loyalty, the way violence can both destroy and forge unbreakable bonds between soldiers.

This novel interrogates the mythology surrounding military service, revealing the messy realities behind heroic narratives while honoring the genuine courage required to endure such circumstances.
short_summary: Young Marines battle Vietnamese forces and their own internal divisions in the jungle hell of Vietnam. Marlantes captures war's brutality and brotherhood with devastating authenticity.
author_bios: Karl Marlantes earned his degree from Yale University and studied as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University. During his service as a Marine in Vietnam, he received numerous honors including the Navy Cross, Bronze Star, two Navy Commendation Medals for valor, two Purple Hearts, and ten air medals. Marlantes has written the bestselling novels Matterhorn and What It Is Like to Go to War, and currently makes his home in rural Washington.
quotes:
"I've laughed at Catch-22 and wept at The Thin Red Line, but I've never encountered a war novel as stark, honest and wrenching as Matterhorn. . . . By turns, this book horrified me, crushed me and beat me up, but I found it nearly impossible to stop reading. More than any living American novelist I've read, Marlantes made me feel what I already must have known: that war is worse than hell."

—NPR

"Never have we seen the particular horrors and challenges of Vietnam so richly explored, and never have we felt the tactile experience of the war depicted with such mesmerizing force. We see the big picture, but as with all great novels, it's the tiny details—the mud, the leeches, the adrenaline-drenched dread of combat, and the tender joy of comradeship—that linger with the reader long after the story is over."

—Hampton Sides, author of Ghost Soldiers and Hellhound on His Trail

"These are the words I wrote down while reading Matterhorn: authentic, funny, heartbreaking, infuriating, devastating. This great book crawled under my skin on the first page, and I suspect it will remain there for a very long time."

—David Finkel, author of The Good Soldiers

title: Absolution
long_summary:
The humid streets of 1963 Saigon become the backdrop for an unlikely friendship between two American expatriate women whose lives intersect in unexpected ways. Tricia arrives as an idealistic newlywed, following her husband's engineering assignment that masks deeper intelligence work. Charlene has already mastered the art of corporate wife diplomacy, juggling three children while orchestrating elaborate charitable missions throughout the city.

After a personal tragedy draws Tricia into Charlene's orbit, she finds herself swept into a world of organized benevolence—visiting hospitals, orphanages, and remote colonies with carefully curated gifts and unwavering determination to make a difference. Yet beneath the surface of their good works lies a more complex web of motivations and consequences.

Decades later, an unexpected phone call forces both women to reckon with the true legacy of their time in Vietnam. Through the lens of memory and hindsight, McDermott examines how the desire to do good can become its own form of colonialism, and how the ripple effects of seemingly small actions can reverberate across generations. The novel interrogates the intersection of privilege, power, and genuine compassion in a world where the line between helping and harming proves devastatingly thin.
short_summary: Two American wives navigate Saigon in 1963, their well-intentioned charity work revealing the complexities of privilege and power. McDermott delivers a masterful exploration of how good intentions can shape and stunt lives across decades.
author_bios: Alice McDermott has written eight novels published by FSG, including The Ninth Hour, Someone, After This, At Weddings and Wakes, and That Night. Three of her works—That Night, At Weddings and Wakes, and After This—received Pulitzer Prize nominations. McDermott also published What About the Baby?: Some Thoughts on the Art of Fiction, an essay collection. Her writing has been featured in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The New Yorker, and Harper's Magazine. She served as the Richard A. Macksey Professor for Distinguished Teaching in the Humanities at Johns Hopkins University for more than twenty years.
quotes:
"Alice McDermott has always been one of our greatest writers but here she exceeds every expectation. Absolution is one of the finest contemporary novels I've read. It is a moral masterpiece."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Enveloping . . . Retrospect amplifies McDermott's narrative approach; her work lives in its shimmering details . . . The debacle of America's involvement in Vietnam might easily have overdetermined McDermott's story, and it is a measure of her skill that Absolution maintains an oblique relationship to the war . . . What difference might it have made, for everyone, if those wives had been given a choice in the decision-making? Without posing this question directly, Absolution leaves the reader in its provocative shadow."

—Jennifer Egan, The New York Times

"It's futile to predict where a great writer's boundless imagination will take us and, as Absolution affirms, McDermott is a great writer . . . McDermott possesses the rare ability to evoke and enter bygone worlds-pre-Vatican II Catholicism, pre-feminist-movement marriages-without condescending to them. She understands that the powerhouses can dominate the helpmeets. She also understands that playing God is the role of a lifetime-and every human actor should turn it down."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Known and Strange Things
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
This collection brings together more than fifty essays that showcase Teju Cole's remarkable ability to find unexpected connections across seemingly disparate subjects. His intellectual curiosity leads readers through examinations of everything from classical literature to social media, from presidential politics to terrorist organizations, always with an eye for the overlooked detail that changes everything.

Cole's analytical lens reveals how art and politics intersect in surprising ways. He considers how photographer Roy DeCarava created powerful images of Black subjects despite working with film designed only for white skin, and reexamines James Baldwin's legacy through the lens of contemporary social movements. Perhaps most provocatively, he dissects what he terms the White Savior Industrial Complex, questioning how charitable impulses can mask deeper inequalities.

The essays move fluidly between high and low culture, treating Instagram posts with the same seriousness as Shakespeare's sonnets. Cole's approach suggests that understanding our moment requires this kind of intellectual range—the willingness to see how Virginia Woolf and Barack Obama might illuminate each other, how travel writing and political analysis can be part of the same conversation.
short_summary: Cole's incisive essays traverse literature, photography, politics, and travel with surgical precision. From James Baldwin to Instagram, his reflections illuminate our cultural moment with rare intelligence and humanity.
author_bios: Born to Nigerian parents in 1975, Teju Cole spent his childhood in Lagos before returning to the United States. His literary works span multiple genres, including the novel Open City, the essay collections Known and Strange Things and Black Paper, and the experimental photo book Blind Spot. Cole's writing has earned him the PEN/Hemingway Award, Internationaler Literaturpreis, Windham-Campbell Prize, and Guggenheim Fellowship. Currently serving as professor of creative writing at Harvard University, he also contributes regularly to The New York Times Magazine and holds membership in the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
quotes:
"The forms of resistance depend on the culture they resist, and in our era of generalizations and approximations and sloppiness, Teju Cole's precise and vivid observation and description are an antidote and a joy. This is a book written with a scalpel, a microscope, and walking shoes, full of telling details and sometimes big surprises."

—Rebecca Solnit, author of Men Explain Things to Me

"Cole is a literary performance artist, his words meticulously chosen and deployed with elegance and force. To read, see, and travel with him is to be changed by the questions that challenge him."

—Publishers Weekly

"Cole's insights cast fresh light on even the most quotidian of objects . . . [and his] collection performs an important service by elevating public discourse in an unsettled time."

—Booklist

title: The Ninth Hour
long_summary:
A single act of despair becomes the invisible force that shapes an entire community in early twentieth-century Brooklyn. After a tragic suicide rocks a tenement building, the Catholic neighborhood responds with silence—burying the truth beneath layers of propriety and religious conviction. But secrets have their own gravity, and this unmentionable death pulls at the lives of everyone it touches.

Sister St. Saviour and her fellow nuns step into the void left behind, caring for the widow and her newborn daughter. As years pass, the weight of what cannot be spoken alters the trajectory of multiple families, testing their capacity for mercy and their understanding of faith. McDermott traces the intricate ways that one moment of anguish echoes across decades, examining how communities both protect and damage those within them. Through the eyes of nuns who tend the sick, women who guard family secrets, and children who sense what adults refuse to name, the novel reveals the complex mathematics of love, duty, and survival in a world where salvation and judgment often wear the same face.
short_summary: When a desperate Irish immigrant takes his own life in 1920s Brooklyn, the reverberations shape generations. McDermott weaves a luminous story of nuns, widows, and the weight of unspoken grief.
author_bios: Alice McDermott has published eight novels through FSG, including The Ninth Hour, Someone, After This, At Weddings and Wakes, and That Night. Three of her works—That Night, At Weddings and Wakes, and After This—earned Pulitzer Prize nominations. McDermott also published the essay collection What About the Baby?: Some Thoughts on the Art of Fiction. Her writing has been featured in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The New Yorker, and Harper's Magazine. She served as the Richard A. Macksey Professor for Distinguished Teaching in the Humanities at Johns Hopkins University for more than twenty years.
quotes:
"McDermott delivers an immense, brilliant novel about the limits of faith, the power of sacrifice, and the cost of forgiveness . . . It's the thread that follows Sally's coming of age and eventual lapse of faith that is the most absorbing. Scenes detailing her benevolent encounters . . . are paradoxically grotesque and irresistible . . . McDermott exhibits a keen eye for character."

—Publishers Weekly

"Everything that her readers, the National Book Award committee, and the Pulitzer Prize judges love about McDermott's stories of Irish-Catholic American life is back."

—Kirkus

"A remarkable snapshot of early 20th-century Irish-Catholic Brooklyn."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Grief Is for People
long_summary:
Two devastating events collide in Sloane Crosley's life: a break-in that leaves her feeling violated and exposed, followed by the suicide of Russell, one of her dearest friends. The timing feels cruel, almost cosmically unfair, setting the stage for a memoir that refuses to follow conventional patterns of grief writing.

Crosley excavates her friendship with Russell, diving into their shared experiences navigating New York's literary scene, their creative collaborations, and the particular intimacy of chosen family. But this isn't simply a tribute to a lost friend. Instead, she interrogates the nature of security—both physical and emotional—and examines how we construct meaning from seemingly random tragedy.

Her approach combines philosophical inquiry with brutal honesty, weaving together art, memory, and the messy reality of surviving loss. The result challenges readers to reconsider their assumptions about grief while offering unexpected moments of levity. Crosley's voice remains sharp and observant even as she grapples with questions that have no satisfying answers, creating a work that speaks to anyone who has wondered how to keep living after the unthinkable happens.
short_summary: Following her friend's suicide and a devastating burglary, Crosley transforms profound loss into a darkly funny, deeply moving meditation on friendship and survival.
author_bios: Sloane Crosley has written the essay collections I Was Told There'd Be Cake (2009 Thurber Prize finalist), How Did You Get This Number, and Look Alive Out There (2019 Thurber Prize finalist), along with the novels The Clasp and Cult Classic, and the memoir Grief Is for People. She serves as a contributing editor at Vanity Fair and makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Grief Is for People captures the feeling of watching a beloved, inappropriate and wild person fit less and less with the times we live in. Like Didion's The Year Of Magical Thinking or Defoe's Journal of a Plague Year, Grief Is for People takes us through the ordinary, awful and never-quite-ending experience of loss. It also made me laugh very hard, many times. I can't stop thinking about it."

—John Mulaney

"In this vivid, and bitingly funny account, Sloane Crosley exposes the magical thinking and murk that follow a friend's suicide. Crosley's prose is honest, lucid, and always surprising; I can't imagine a better companion to guide us through the pain of losing a friend. A painful and necessary book; I will be keeping it close for years to come."

—Meghan O'Rourke, author of The Invisible Kingdom

"Potent and propulsive, a lyrical meditation on loss and what comes after. Grief Is for People is heartbreaking and wholly original."

—Tara Westover, author of Educated

title: Raising Hare
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
A chance encounter with a vulnerable baby hare transforms political advisor Chloe Dalton's understanding of wildness and freedom. After rescuing the tiny leveret from certain death, Dalton faces the nearly impossible task of keeping a wild creature alive—most hares die quickly in human care, succumbing to stress and captivity.

What begins as a rescue mission evolves into something far more complex: a relationship that challenges conventional notions of care and control. The hare grows into Dalton's nighttime companion, roaming freely through countryside darkness before returning each dawn. Dalton must reconcile her protective instincts with a deeper truth—that genuine love sometimes means accepting the possibility of loss.

This memoir weaves together intimate observations of their daily life with rich explorations of hare mythology, from ancient folklore to contemporary conservation. Dalton examines how these enigmatic creatures have captured human imagination across cultures and centuries. The result is both a deeply personal story of connection and a broader meditation on our relationship with the natural world, revealing how the most profound bonds often emerge from the most unexpected circumstances.
short_summary: During lockdown in the English countryside, a political advisor rescues an abandoned leveret and forms an unlikely bond. A tender meditation on freedom, wildness, and letting go.
author_bios: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie was raised in Nigeria and has become one of the most celebrated contemporary voices in global literature. Her novels include Purple Hibiscus, which earned the Commonwealth Writers' Prize, Half of a Yellow Sun, winner of the Women's Prize for Fiction "Best of the Best" award, and Americanah, recipient of the National Book Critics Circle Award. She has also published The Thing Around Your Neck, We Should All Be Feminists, Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions, Notes on Grief, and the children's book Mama's Sleeping Scarf. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, her writing has been translated into more than fifty-five languages. She splits her time between Nigeria and the United States.
quotes:
"An astounding debut memoir in which Dalton shows how a serene and long-misunderstood creature opened her eyes in many ways. It just might do the same for readers. . . . Soulful and gracefully written."

—Kirkus

"This book tells a story of true friendship with great respect . . . If you love animals, this book is incredibly beautiful and moving and helped me see nature differently. I think it's the best non-fiction book of the year."

—Elizabeth Gilbert

"Dalton's clear, measured prose and Denise Nestor's delicate drawings provide . . . a bit of solace in a world that has now returned to an even more frenetic state. In Raising Hare, nature, indeed, takes its course."

—The New York Times

title: The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet
long_summary:
On an artificial island in Nagasaki Harbor, cultural boundaries define everything. Jacob de Zoet arrives at this isolated Dutch trading post with clear intentions: accumulate enough wealth in five years to secure his future back home. The confined world of Dejima operates under strict rules, where foreign merchants navigate complex relationships with Japanese officials, interpreters, and locals.

Jacob's calculated plans unravel through his connection with Orito Aibagawa, a skilled midwife whose intelligence and resilience transcend the social barriers that should separate them. Their relationship challenges everything Jacob thought he understood about duty, desire, and the price of crossing forbidden lines.

Mitchell constructs a richly detailed world where East meets West under the most constrained circumstances. The novel examines how individuals navigate between competing loyalties—to homeland, to heart, to survival itself. As political tensions escalate and personal stakes rise, Jacob discovers that some choices carry consequences that ripple far beyond the confines of their island prison, reshaping not just his own destiny but the lives of everyone around him.
short_summary: A Dutch clerk arrives in 1799 Japan seeking fortune but finds forbidden love and cultural collision on the isolated trading island of Dejima. Mitchell delivers a sweeping historical epic with exquisite prose and meticulous period detail.
author_bios: David Mitchell has written seven novels including Ghostwritten, number9dream, Cloud Atlas, Black Swan Green, The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet, The Bone Clocks, and Slade House. He received the Sunday Times Award for Literary Excellence in 2018 and has been shortlisted for the Booker Prize twice.
quotes:
"An achingly romantic story of forbidden love . . . Mitchell's incredible prose is on stunning display. . . . A novel of ideas, of longing, of good and evil and those who fall somewhere in between [that] confirms Mitchell as one of the more fascinating and fearless writers alive."

—Dave Eggers, The New York Times

"The novelist who's been showing us the future of fiction has published a classic, old-fashioned tale . . . an epic of sacrificial love, clashing civilizations and enemies who won't rest until whole family lines have been snuffed out."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A beautiful novel, full of life and authenticity, atmosphere and characters that breathe."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Claire McCardell
subtitle: The Designer Who Set Women Free
long_summary:
Behind every piece of clothing in your closet lies a revolutionary story you've never heard. Claire McCardell transformed how women dress by refusing to accept that fashion should constrain rather than liberate. While her male contemporaries designed clothes that required assistance to put on and take off, McCardell championed independence through ingenious details like front-facing zippers and functional pockets.

Her innovations reads like a catalog of modern essentials: she pioneered the ballet flat, created the first hoodie, and made separates that could be mixed and matched. But McCardell's true genius lay in understanding that clothing should serve women's actual lives, not some idealized version of femininity imposed by others.

The fashion establishment fought back. When Christian Dior's restrictive "New Look" dominated post-war runways, McCardell stood as its antithesis, creating clothes for women who worked, traveled, and lived independently. Her battle wasn't just about hemlines and silhouettes—it was about women's right to move through the world on their own terms.

This biography reveals how one designer's vision became a quiet revolution, proving that the most profound changes often happen in the everyday choices we make about how to present ourselves to the world.
short_summary: The riveting hidden history of Claire McCardell, the most influential fashion designer you've never heard of. From ballet flats to wrap dresses, her revolutionary designs liberated women from corsets and convention.
author_bios: Elizabeth Evitts Dickinson has built her career chronicling untold stories across major publications including The New York Times, Harper's Magazine, The New Yorker, The Southern Review, and The Washington Post Magazine. Her journalism has earned her a National Endowment for the Arts Creative Writing Fellowship, and her essays have been featured in The Best American Essays anthology. Dickinson received Maryland's Mary Sawyers Imboden Prize for literature and makes her home in Baltimore with her family.
quotes:
"An insightful, beautifully written tribute to a designer who was ahead of her time. In a world where women are still fighting for full agency, this book reminds us that fashion, at its best, is about freedom on our own terms. It's an essential read."

—Susan Magsamen, New York Times bestselling co-author of Your Brain on Art

"In the hands of Dickinson, this is more than just the biography of a fashion revolutionary: It is a story of the fight for women's identity and, incidentally, the birth of an American industry."

—The New York Times

"Dickinson illustrates how fashion served as a mirror for sociopolitical change...Fashion aficionados won't want to miss this."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Committed
long_summary:
In this follow-up to The Sympathizer, our conflicted protagonist finds himself in Reagan-era Paris, where survival means entering the narcotics trade alongside his companion Bon. Still reeling from brutal reeducation experiences, he must navigate the contradictions of French society—a place that both attracts and repels him.

The narrator's integration into Parisian life occurs through an unlikely combination of circumstances: elegant soirées arranged by a Vietnamese expatriate relative connect him to progressive thinkers who become both intellectual companions and clientele for his illicit business. This double existence forces him to balance philosophical discourse with criminal enterprise.

Yet deeper challenges emerge as he confronts his own demons through substance abuse while living under an oppressive system that echoes the colonial structures he thought he'd escaped. Most crucially, he faces the seemingly insurmountable challenge of reconciling his two dearest relationships—Bon and Man—whose ideological differences have created an unbridgeable chasm.

Nguyen crafts a work that operates simultaneously as suspenseful crime fiction and philosophical examination, offering a scorching analysis of friendship, treachery, and the immigrant experience that solidifies his reputation as a major voice in American letters.
short_summary: The unnamed narrator from The Sympathizer navigates 1980s Paris through drug dealing and left-wing intellectual circles. Nguyen weaves crime, philosophy, and politics into a searing meditation on exile and identity.
author_bios: Born in Vietnam and raised in the United States, Viet Thanh Nguyen has established himself as a vital literary voice through multiple genres. His novel The Sympathizer earned the 2016 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, while his short story collection The Refugees and his nonfiction work Nothing Ever Dies—which received a National Book Award nomination—demonstrate his versatility as a writer. Nguyen serves as the Aerol Arnold Professor of English and American Studies and Ethnicity at USC and has been honored with both Guggenheim and MacArthur fellowships.
quotes:
"An elegy to idealism, Orientalism, and existentialism in all its tragic forms, Nguyen's novel doesn't so much inhabit early eighties Paris, as it pulls the plug on the City of Light. Think of The Committed as the declaration of the 20th ½ Arrondissement. A squatter's paradise for those with one foot in the grave and the other shoved halfway up Western civilization's ass."

—Paul Beatty

"In a decade whose fiction is dominated by autofiction, there's something de´mode´ about Nguyen's novels, which I think can fairly be considered a single artistic endeavor . . . The Sympathizer and The Committed are, to borrow James Wood's phrase for such novels, perpetual-motion machines, their exuberance perhaps a suitable method given how vast a subject he aims to tackle. The breathless voice and sprawling plots of these novels made me think of Midnight's Children: manic language and impossible story suit the strange truth of colonialism. Nguyen does Salman Rushdie one better by deploying the conventions of genre fiction; he gently seduces the reader into two rambling, discursive works passionately interested in war and violence, race and identity, colonialism and history."

—Rumaan Alam, The New York Times

"The Committed is nothing short of revelatory. As it haunts, bifurcates, and envelops us in its illumination of all that we have failed to notice about the far reaches of colonization, we are also thrilled by its many turns and charms. This book is fierce, and unrelentingly good. Hilarious and subversive, philosophical and hallucinatory, it is much more than a sequel, more like a necessary appendage in a brilliant and expansive anti-colonial body of work, from the twisted and playful mind of the one and only Viet Thanh Nguyen. Bravo."

—Tommy Orange, New York Times-bestselling author of There There

title: Fi
subtitle: A Memoir of My Son
long_summary:
At forty-nine, Alexandra Fuller finds herself navigating a perfect storm of upheaval—fresh from sobriety, mourning her father's death, and grappling with the end of a relationship. Just as she begins to steady herself in Wyoming's rugged landscape, tragedy strikes with devastating finality: her twenty-one-year-old son Fi dies unexpectedly in his sleep.

What follows is a mother's raw journey through uncharted territory of loss. Unlike previous griefs she has endured, this one threatens to break her completely. Yet Fuller refuses to disappear into her pain the way her own mother once did, leaving her surviving daughters behind. Instead, she embarks on a geographical and spiritual odyssey across the Rocky Mountain spine—from isolated sheep wagons to meditation retreats—seeking not answers, but simply a way to continue existing.

Drawing on childhood memories of Zimbabwe's indigenous wisdom, Fuller discovers that healing doesn't follow prescribed paths. Through poetry, ritual, and the unforgiving beauty of nature, she slowly learns that grieving a child requires inventing new ways to be human. This memoir captures both the searing reality of unthinkable loss and the surprising moments of grace that emerge from the wreckage.
short_summary: A devastating memoir about losing a child, told with the unflinching honesty and unexpected humor that made Fuller's previous work essential reading. Raw, beautiful, and ultimately about finding ways to survive the unsurvivable.
author_bios: Alexandra Fuller has written four memoirs, including the New York Times Notable Book Don't Let's Go To The Dogs Tonight, which won the Booksense Best Non-fiction award and received the Winifred Holtby Memorial Prize. Her other works include the New York Times bestseller Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness, two additional non-fiction books, and the novel Quiet Until The Thaw. Fuller's essays and articles have been featured in the New Yorker, National Geographic, Granta, The New York Times, Guardian, and Financial Times.
quotes:
"Fuller is sagacious and perspicacious. She is a sublime writer. In the hands of another memoirist, the story of Fi might be unbearably sad, but this book is a mesmeric celebration of a boy who died too soon, a mother's love and her resilience. It will help others surviving loss — surviving life."

—David Sheff, The New York Times

"Fuller is unyielding in her honesty, laying herself bare on the page. With unflinching candour she recounts the agonizing weeks, days, hours and minutes following Fi's death, her downward spiral into grief and her eventual reconnection with herself and the world around her. And only Fuller could inject humour into a story such as this . . . Fi will undoubtedly hit home with any readers grieving the loss of a loved one. It may also offer hope."

—The Winnipeg Free Press

"A truly extraordinary memoir about a mother's loss of her son: beautiful, fearless, raw and an utterly compelling read."

—Helen Macdonald, author of H Is For Hawk

title: Mina's Matchbox
long_summary:
A young girl's world expands beyond recognition during an unforgettable stay with relatives she barely knows. Tomoko finds herself immersed in a realm of luxury she's never experienced—a seventeen-room estate complete with exotic animals and European elegance that feels worlds away from her modest Tokyo life.

Her sophisticated relatives welcome her into their rarefied existence, where afternoon conversations flow between languages and every room holds treasures from distant places. Most captivating is her cousin Mina, whose imagination and fragile health create an intensity that both thrills and unsettles Tomoko. Together, they navigate the peculiar rhythms of this household, where beauty and strangeness intertwine.

Yet beneath the surface of this enchanted summer, Tomoko begins to sense the weight of unspoken histories. Her relatives carry shadows she cannot yet comprehend—wartime memories, private disappointments, and complex loyalties that shape their daily lives in ways both subtle and profound. Ogawa crafts a delicate meditation on how children perceive the adult world, capturing those pivotal moments when innocence encounters complexity, and understanding arrives in fragments rather than revelations.
short_summary: Twelve-year-old Tomoko spends a transformative summer with her wealthy relatives in 1970s Japan. Ogawa captures childhood's ephemeral magic while revealing the adult secrets lurking beneath a family's polished surface.
author_bios: Yoko Ogawa stands among Japan's most distinguished literary voices, having received every major award in Japanese literature. Her stories have graced the pages of The New Yorker, A Public Space, and Zoetrope: All-Story. She has written The Memory Police, The Diving Pool, The Housekeeper and the Professor, Hotel Iris, and Revenge. Ogawa makes her home in Ashiya, Japan.
quotes:
"There's such an elegance to the way Mina's Matchbox unfolds...The world Yoko Ogawa builds is quiet, warm and it should feel comforting. But there are peculiarities about the whole thing that keep you on the tips of your toes."

—NPR

"Focusing on characters of an age when the world seems full of wonder and possibility, this engaging bildungsroman explores the friendship and mutual curiosity between two extraordinary young people… Facing complicated themes with deceptively simple language, she pulls off a neat trick here, painting everything in miniature and often in hindsight without losing the immediacy of Tomoko's experiences. A charming yet guileless exploration of childhood's ephemeral pleasures and reflexive poignancy."

—Kirkus

"Captivating…Ogawa pulls off the rare feat of making childhood memories both credible and provocative. Readers will be hypnotized."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Girl on Girl
subtitle: How Pop Culture Turned a Generation of Women Against Themselves
long_summary:
Feminism seemed unstoppable in the 1990s, yet something shifted dramatically as the new millennium began. Sophie Gilbert dissects this cultural transformation, revealing how the bold, transgressive spirit of third-wave feminism gave way to an era that actively diminished women's agency and dignity.

Through meticulous examination of pop culture artifacts—from reality television's cruel spectacles to tabloid media's predatory practices—Gilbert exposes the mechanisms that engineered this regression. She demonstrates how internet pornography's mainstream emergence fundamentally altered cultural attitudes, while celebrity culture became a vehicle for public humiliation and objectification.

This isn't simply a critique of bad taste or poor judgment. Gilbert uncovers a systematic cultural project that transformed empowered women into infantilized objects of consumption. Her analysis connects seemingly disparate phenomena—fashion trends, music videos, gossip magazines—into a coherent narrative of deliberate disempowerment.

The book serves as both historical reckoning and urgent warning. Gilbert's investigation reveals how the foundations for today's anti-feminist backlash were laid during what many remember as a time of prosperity and progress. Her work challenges nostalgic memories of the early 2000s, demanding we confront the misogynistic machinery that operated beneath the surface glamour.
short_summary: Atlantic critic Sophie Gilbert excavates the cultural wreckage of the early 2000s, when third-wave feminism collapsed into hyper-objectification and cruelty. A devastating analysis of how we got here.
author_bios: Sophie Gilbert writes about television, literature, and popular culture as a staff writer for The Atlantic. Her criticism earned her the 2024 National Magazine Award for Reviews and Criticism, and she received recognition as a 2022 Pulitzer Prize finalist in Criticism. Gilbert currently resides in London.
quotes:
"Girl on Girl is a work of overwhelming meticulousness and clarity. If you're confused about the current uncertainty about feminism's power, Sophie Gilbert has done the work of painstakingly and granularly tracing every cultural thread to reveal how we got here. Gilbert unmasks an insidious cultural coup that seemingly overnight dethroned the transgressive women of the 90s; 'Just like that they were gone–replaced by girls,' she writes. Over and over, Gilbert reminds us: it wasn't always this bad–in fact, it was getting better, then it got taken away. Girl on Girl is a necessary corrective of cultural memory, but more importantly, it is a definitive archive of that disempowerment and its ensuing cruelties."

—Elamin Abdelmahmoud, host of CBC's Commotion and author of Son of Elsewhere

"Searing . . . There were several passages in Gilbert's blistering, sobering book Girl on Girl that challenged my selective nostalgia, making me wince. If you too came of age around the late 1990s and early aughts, prepare to have the balloon string of sentimentality pried from your grip. The party's over. It's been over . . . Her book is a course correction of sorts, taking a holistic tack to explain our current sociopolitical reality: one in which women's hard-fought gains are quickly eroding, and men and boys are in crisis . . . Across 10 rigorously researched but never stuffy chapters, Gilbert has compiled perhaps the first comprehensive examination of turn-of-the-millennium mainstream, cool-kid trends and ephemera, and how they were largely molded by those in power to sell a generation of girls and young women reality-warping lies . . . Gilbert isn't concerned with softening the blow. Instead, she's intent on snapping millennials out of any instinct to idealize the decades that shaped us—even if that awareness stings."

—New York Times

"So clear-eyed that it's startling . . . Girl on Girl covers how American culture writ large treated women from the 1990s to the 2010s. It's to Gilbert's credit that she makes a cohesive history emerge from this morass of references . . . Her organization is as confident and nimble as her arguments . . . The informed and persuasive essays in Girl on Girl stand alone, even as they build on one another. A chapter on the early years of reality television is exceptional . . . This ground is well-trod, but rarely trod so well . . . Gilbert is a critic skilled in the art of seeing close-up and faraway all at once, a Vertigo effect of cultural observation. Girl on Girl doesn't settle into outrage or pity, but instead offers a clear-eyed, unblinking stare that conveys one thing: I see what you're doing."

—The Washington Post

title: Wandering Stars
long_summary:
The sins of history cast long shadows across generations in this devastating chronicle of survival and institutional cruelty. Beginning with Star, a young man who witnesses unspeakable violence at Sand Creek and later faces systematic erasure at the hands of Richard Henry Pratt, the narrative follows a bloodline marked by trauma and resistance.

Decades pass, but the machinery of cultural destruction grinds on. Star's son Charles finds himself trapped within the walls of Carlisle Indian Industrial School, where the same forces that tormented his father now seek to strip away everything that connects him to his heritage. Yet even in this place designed to break spirits, moments of tenderness emerge—stolen conversations with Opal Viola become acts of rebellion against a system built on erasure.

Orange crafts a story that refuses to let America forget its deliberate attempts to destroy Native identity. This is literature that excavates buried truths, showing how violence ripples through time, shaping not just individuals but entire communities. The result is both heartbreaking and essential—a novel that honors the ancestors while demanding accountability for the wounds that never fully heal.
short_summary: From the Sand Creek Massacre to modern Oakland, Orange traces a Native family across generations, showing how historical trauma echoes through bloodlines. Epic in scope, intimate in detail.
author_bios: Tommy Orange earned his MFA from the Institute of American Indian Arts and draws from his experience growing up in Oakland, California, as an enrolled member of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma. There There, his debut novel, earned him finalist status for the 2019 Pulitzer Prize and won the 2019 American Book Award.
quotes:
"In Wandering Stars, Tommy Orange finds different pockets, not just to flex, but to really get to beyond the marrow of this wonderfully blistered world. The work is so varied and textured but also ruthlessly clear in what it's costing and what it's destroying."

—Kiese Laymon, author of Heavy

"If there was any doubt after his incredible debut, there should be none now: Tommy Orange is one of our most important writers. The way he weaves time and life together, demands we remember how our history shapes us. In this novel the pain and resilience of generations are summoned beautifully. A wonderous journey and a necessary reminder."

—Nana Kwame Adjei Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars

"In Wandering Stars, Tommy Orange opens us up to these big lives full of hope and triumph and love and freedom—but then the world comes in, history comes in, drugs and nation and bullets and the big and small lonelinesses come in. Richard Pryor said he wanted to get you laughing so your mouth would be open when he poured the poison down, and that's what Orange is doing here. Anyone can say a complicated thing in a complicated way, but Tommy says the hardest things plain—beyond artifice, beyond confection. That clarity, that radical lucidity, that's the mark of true genius, a word I use here without hyperbole. Think Kafka, Lispector, Borges. Wandering Stars is the kind of book that saves lives, that makes remaining in the world feel a little more possible. It's art of the highest order, written by one of our language's most significant and urgent practitioners."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: The Bully Pulpit
subtitle: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism
long_summary:
America stands at a crossroads in the early 1900s, grappling with massive wealth gaps, gridlocked politics, and unchecked corporate influence. Two towering figures emerge to navigate this crisis: Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft, whose personal bond would evolve into a political feud that reshapes the Republican Party forever.

Yet this story extends beyond presidential politics. A new breed of investigative journalists—including Ida Tarbell, Lincoln Steffens, Ray Stannard Baker, and William Allen White—wages war against corruption through their pens, exposing scandals and demanding accountability. Their fearless reporting becomes the engine driving national reform.

Through intimate letters and private journals, this narrative reveals how personal relationships intersect with public duty during a pivotal moment in American history. The collision of ambitious leadership, groundbreaking journalism, and grassroots activism creates a perfect storm for change, pushing the nation toward the democratic ideals it promised but had yet to fully deliver.
short_summary: The friendship and bitter rivalry between Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft shaped America's Progressive Era. Goodwin masterfully weaves together presidential politics and muckraking journalism in this vivid portrait of reform.
author_bios: Doris Kearns Goodwin has established herself as one of America's foremost presidential historians, earning the Pulitzer Prize for her scholarship. Her extensive body of work spans Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream, No Ordinary Time (Pulitzer Prize winner), Team of Rivals (Lincoln Prize recipient and inspiration for Steven Spielberg's Lincoln), The Bully Pulpit (Carnegie Medal winner), Leadership: In Turbulent Times, and An Unfinished Love Story: A Personal History of the 1960s.
quotes:
"If you find the grubby spectacle of today's Washington cause for shame and despair—and really, how could you not?—then I suggest you turn off the TV and board Doris Kearns Goodwin's latest time machine. … [Goodwin puts] political intrigues and moral dilemmas and daily lives into rich and elegant language. Imagine 'The West Wing' scripted by Henry James."

—Bill Keller, The New York Times

"Doris Kearns Goodwin tells this tale with her usual literary skill and deep research. … Goodwin not only sheds light on the birth of the modern political world but chronicles a remarkable friendship between two remarkable men."

—The Wall Street Journal

"Goodwin's evocative examination of the Progressive world is smart and engaging. . . . She presents a highly readable and detailed portrait of an era. The Bully Pulpit brings the early 20th century to life and firmly establishes the crucial importance of the press to Progressive politics."

—The Washington Post

title: The Hounding
long_summary:
In an English village where supernatural omens have always been part of daily life, five sisters find themselves at the center of a dangerous hysteria. The community's unease with the Mansfield family transforms into something far more sinister when whispers begin circulating about mysterious transformations and otherworldly sounds echoing through the night.

Told through the voices of different villagers, this Gothic tale reveals how prejudice and suspicion can poison an entire community. Each narrator brings their own perspective to the growing paranoia, exposing the complex web of resentment, fear, and social dynamics that have long simmered beneath the surface. The sisters, already outsiders in their own home, become scapegoats for anxieties that extend far beyond any actual supernatural threat.

Xenobe Purvis crafts a chilling examination of how societies turn against those who dare to be different, using the framework of historical witch trials to illuminate timeless questions about conformity, power, and the price of being an unconventional woman. The novel asks whether true monstrosity lies in alleged magical powers or in the human capacity for cruelty toward the misunderstood.
short_summary: Five sisters in an eighteenth-century English village face accusations of witchcraft when neighbors become convinced they're transforming into dogs. Gothic paranoia meets sharp social commentary in this haunting debut.
author_bios: Born in Tokyo in 1990, Xenobe Purvis completed her English Literature degree at Oxford before earning an MA in creative writing from Royal Holloway. She participated in the London Library's Emerging Writers Programme and has contributed essays to publications including the Times Literary Supplement and the London Magazine.
quotes:
"What takes this novel past conceit to commentary lies in its exploration of interiority among all of the characters, not simply the suspected women, but those who observe, accuse and fear. When a community cannot explain misfortune, who suffers? Purvis makes a clever but careful case for combining the Gothic with the paranormal."

—Los Angeles Times

"With hints of superstition akin to Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery" and the puritanical overtones of Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter, Purvis's The Hounding taps into universal themes of fear, violence, lust, and also empathy."

—Shelf Awareness

"The Hounding is a debut novel bound to be a cult classic. It's a tale set centuries ago that throbs with a bloody, living heart. It's a jewel dug from the depths of Xenobe Purvis's imagination. It's exquisite."

—Julia Phillips, author of Bear

title: The End of Drum-Time
long_summary:
The frozen expanses of 19th-century Scandinavia become the backdrop for a collision between ancient traditions and encroaching Christianity. Ivvár tends his family's reindeer herd while his father abandons their nomadic life for the promises of a zealous Lutheran minister. The responsibility weighs heavily on the young man's shoulders as their livelihood dwindles.

Everything shifts when Ivvár encounters Willa, the minister's own daughter. Their attraction defies the religious and cultural chasms that separate their worlds. As the seasons turn and the herders begin their grueling trek to northern waters, Willa makes a choice that will test the boundaries of love, loyalty, and identity.

Pylväinen captures the raw beauty of the Arctic landscape while examining how faith can both unite and divide communities. The novel illuminates a vanishing way of life through characters caught between competing visions of salvation and survival. Against the backdrop of reindeer migrations and midnight sun, questions of belonging and belief take on profound urgency in this richly textured story of hearts and cultures in conflict.
short_summary: When a reindeer herder's son meets a minister's daughter in 1851 Scandinavia, their forbidden romance bridges cultures and faiths. Pylväinen crafts an intimate epic that feels both timeless and urgent.
author_bios: Hanna Pylväinen wrote We Sinners, earning both a Whiting Award and Balcones Fiction Prize for her debut. Her writing has found homes in Harper's Magazine, the New York Times, the New York Times Magazine, Chicago Tribune, and the Wall Street Journal. Princeton University's Lewis Center for the Arts, the American-Scandinavian Foundation, and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library have all supported her work through fellowships. She has also spent time at MacDowell, Yaddo, and the Lásságámmi Foundation. Currently, she teaches in the Warren Wilson College MFA Program for Writers while making her home in Philadelphia.
quotes:
"The End of Drum-Time explores some of the most complex themes in literature in some of the most gorgeous prose imaginable. Hanna Pylväinen's novel of cultural collision in the far north is an extraordinary feat of research and imagination by an author who reminds you with every page what fiction can accomplish."

—Anthony Marra, New York Times bestselling author of A Constellation of Vital Phenomena & Mercury Pictures Present

"The End of Drum-Time is a novel like no other. It is as much a historical epic as it is an intimate love story—as much a vast cultural record as it is a detailed study of a person's soul. It is infinitely rich and rewarding. In these pages, Hanna Pylväinen tells a story of love, faith, reindeer herding, and human failing. She has written a masterpiece."

—Julia Phillips, author of the National Book Award finalist Disappearing Earth

"In prose that is both luxuriant and precise, Hanna Pylväinen vividly transports the reader to the remote Scandinavian tundra of the 1850s, introducing complicated characters who reveal their deepest joys, sorrows, fears, and hopes. This stunning novel manages to explore major themes of identity, race, politics, and faith, all while putting the focus firmly on the human stories at hand. The End of Drum-Time masterfully takes us to a place, people, and time unfamiliar to most readers but one that becomes completely alive—and closely mirrors the most divisive and potent aspects of our contemporary lives."

—The 2023 National Book Award Citation

title: Inferno
subtitle: The World at War, 1939-1945
long_summary:
After decades of studying the Second World War, historian Max Hastings presents a comprehensive examination of humanity's most catastrophic conflict. Rather than focusing solely on military strategy or political maneuvering, this work centers the experiences of individuals who lived through six years of global warfare.

The narrative moves between battlefields and home fronts, capturing both the grand sweep of history and its intimate human cost. Hastings draws from extensive research to illuminate familiar episodes alongside lesser-known tragedies—from the desperate conditions endured by civilians during prolonged sieges to the complex dynamics of resistance movements across occupied territories.

The book examines how political leaders navigated impossible choices while ordinary people faced extraordinary circumstances. Hastings explores the moral complexities that emerged during wartime, the breakdown of social order in some regions, and the resilience displayed by communities under extreme duress. His approach reveals how individual stories collectively shaped the war's outcome and legacy.

By balancing strategic analysis with personal accounts, this history demonstrates how the conflict transformed not just national boundaries but the lives of countless individuals across multiple continents. The result is a nuanced portrait that honors both the scale of the tragedy and the humanity of those who endured it.
short_summary: Hastings delivers a sweeping yet intimate portrait of World War II, weaving together major political developments with the deeply human stories of ordinary people caught in history's most devastating conflict.
genres: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War II
author_bios: Max Hastings has written more than thirty books, including Inferno and The Secret War. A fellow of the Royal Society of Literature who was knighted in 2002, Hastings previously led The Daily Telegraph as editor-in-chief and later edited the Evening Standard. He makes his home in West Berkshire, England.
quotes:
"A new, original, necessary history, in many ways the crowning of a life's work. A professional war correspondent who has personally witnessed armed conflict in Vietnam, the Falkland Islands and other danger zones, Hastings has a sober, unromantic and realistic view of battle that puts him into a different category from the armchair generals whose gung-ho, schoolboy attitude to war fills the pages of a great majority of military histories. He writes with grace, fluency and authority…Inferno is superb."

—Richard J. Evans, The New York Times

"If there is a contemporary British historian who is the chronicler of World War II, it would be Max Hastings…[Inferno] is a true distillation of everything this historian has learned from a lifetime of scholarship-and more important, of real thought-on what he calls 'the greatest and most terrible event in human history.'"

—Martin Rubin, San Francisco Chronicle

"A relatively brief review can only begin to indicate the depth, breadth, complexity and pervasive humanity of this extraordinary book. The literature of World War II is, as Hastings notes at the beginning of his bibliography, so vast as almost to defy enumeration or comprehension, but "Inferno" immediately moves to the head of the list. It is in all ways a monumental achievement."

—Jonathan Yardley, The Washington Post

title: The Book of My Lives
long_summary:
Two cities anchor this unconventional memoir-in-essays: Sarajevo, where childhood unfolds through pickup soccer games and family dynamics, and Chicago, where exile begins unexpectedly. Hemon finds himself stranded in America as war tears through his homeland, watching from afar as his family flees with nothing but their dog.

What emerges isn't a typical immigrant narrative, but something more complex—a meditation on the spaces we call home and the selves we construct within them. Soccer becomes a recurring motif, threading through memories of youth and present-day longing. The author examines how displacement reshapes not just geography but identity itself, while family relationships stretch across continents and transform under pressure.

Hemon refuses easy categorization, blending humor with grief, the mundane with the profound. His essays move between intimate family portraits and broader questions about belonging, creating a work that feels both deeply personal and surprisingly universal. The result challenges readers to reconsider their own assumptions about home, family, and the stories we tell ourselves about who we are.
short_summary: Essays spanning Sarajevo and Chicago explore displacement, family, and identity with devastating wit. Hemon transforms personal upheaval into universal truths about home and belonging.
author_bios: Aleksandar Hemon wrote The Lazarus Project, which earned finalist recognition for both the 2008 National Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award. His published works include the story collections The Question of Bruno, Nowhere Man (also a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist), and Love and Obstacles, plus the novel The Making of Zombie Wars. Hemon has authored two essay collections: The Book of My Lives and My Parents/This Does Not Belong to You. His accolades include a MacArthur Fellowship, Guggenheim Fellowship, PEN/W.G. Sebald Award, and the 2020 John Dos Passos Prize. He co-wrote The Matrix Resurrections and currently teaches at Princeton University.
quotes:
"Aleksandar Hemon is, quite frankly, the greatest writer of our generation. His literature is deep, agile, funny, graceful, searing, angry, raw, questioning. The Book of My Lives is worth it simply for the dedication: 'For Isabel, forever breathing on my chest.' He writes it, and so she breathes on ours too. Such is the function of storytelling: to get to the essence of that which might eventually break our hearts. This is a book--like all of Aleksandar Hemon's books--that is an aria for our times. I will cherish it."

—Colum McCann

"Aleksandar Hemon's work crackles with so much humor and irony, so much compassion and humanity, that The Book of My Lives's true calling almost goes by unnoticed: it is, without doubt, the most necessary, intimate, and heartbreaking portrait of a world lost to one of history's darkest conflicts."

—Téa Obreht

"I'm not quite sure Aleksandar Hemon counts as an American writer, but he is one of my favorite American writers. Before The Book of My Lives, I never really thought of him as a nonfiction person, but this new book--a memoir in essays--has some of his best writing. When Hemon's work is funny, it can make you laugh in spite of everything, and when it is sad, it's hard to stand up afterward."

—John Jeremiah Sullivan, author of Pulphead

title: Intermezzo
long_summary:
Brothers Peter and Ivan couldn't be more different—one a polished Dublin attorney, the other a chess prodigy who feels like an outsider in his own life. Their father's recent death has left both men adrift, seeking connection in unexpected places.

Peter finds himself caught between two worlds: his complicated history with Sylvia, a relationship that has endured despite its challenges, and his newer involvement with Naomi, whose youthful irreverence offers escape from his mounting anxieties. Meanwhile, Ivan discovers an intensity he's never known through Margaret, a woman whose own scars mirror his emerging understanding of loss.

As these relationships deepen and complicate, both brothers must confront how grief reshapes not just their inner lives but their capacity for love itself. What emerges is a meditation on the weight of family bonds, the courage required for intimacy, and the surprising resilience of the human heart when tested by profound change.
