short_summary: Two grieving Dublin brothers navigate love and loss in the wake of their father's death. Rooney's latest is her most emotionally expansive yet—tender, wise, and utterly absorbing.
author_bios: Sally Rooney has established herself as one of Ireland's most distinctive literary voices through her novels Conversations with Friends, Normal People, and Beautiful World, Where Are You. Beyond her writing, Rooney played an active role in developing the Hulu/BBC television adaptation of Normal People, contributing to both the writing and production of the acclaimed series.
quotes:
"Intermezzo, [Rooney's] fourth novel, is her most fully developed and moving yet . . . Intermezzo propels you to its well-earned, moving climax with nary a false move."

—Heller McAlpin, NPR

"What's fascinating about Rooney's more recent attempts is how attuned she is to every social tightrope that constrains what we might have imagined would be free adulthood . . . There's something brilliant and refreshing in Rooney's choice to follow the private love affairs of two siblings once so closely connected . . . It's a pleasure, this time, to get under the skin and into the compassionate private realities of these brothers who misperceive each other as villains."

—Lillian Fishman, The Washington Post

"Wise, resonant and witty . . . There is so much restraint and melancholy profundity in her prose that when she allows the flood gates to open, the parched reader is willing to be swept out to sea . . . Rooney has an exquisite perceptiveness and a zest for keeping us reading . . . Intermezzo wears its heart on its sleeve."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: The Antidote
long_summary:
In Depression-era Nebraska, the fictional town of Uz faces more than economic collapse and environmental catastrophe. Russell constructs a tapestry of interconnected lives against this backdrop of crisis: a mystical woman who literally stores the community's memories within her body, a Polish farmer discovering that hoarded fortune brings unexpected consequences, his basketball-playing niece who apprentices with the local witch while wrestling with profound loss, a talking scarecrow, and a government photographer whose supernatural camera captures more than documentary images.

Through these interwoven narratives, Russell excavates the deliberate erasures that built America—the stories communities choose to forget and the histories they refuse to acknowledge. The novel functions as both historical reckoning and contemporary warning, drawing stark parallels between past environmental disasters and our current climate crisis. Russell challenges readers to confront the inherited silences that shape national identity, revealing how collective amnesia perpetuates cycles of harm while also illuminating paths toward redemption and truth-telling.
short_summary: Five characters' fates intertwine after a devastating dust storm hits Depression-era Nebraska. Russell's latest is a reckoning with American amnesia—part climate warning, part magical excavation of buried histories.
author_bios: Karen Russell has written six works of fiction, including New York Times bestsellers Swamplandia! and Vampires in the Lemon Grove. Among her many honors are a MacArthur Fellowship, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and a Pulitzer Prize nomination. Her recognition includes two National Magazine Awards for Fiction, the Shirley Jackson Award, the 2023 Bottari Lattes Grinzane Prize, and the 2024 Mary McCarthy Prize. A Miami native, Karen Russell currently makes her home in Portland, Oregon, with her family.
quotes:
"The Antidote is an achingly gorgeous book about dust, memory, basketball, murder, yearning, photography, and the way the land holds both the memory of what went before and the dreams of what may come. Karen Russell is one of our most humane and generous writers; this book is as profound as it is wonderfully strange."

—Lauren Groff, author of The Vaster Wilds

"In The Antidote, Karen Russell writes indelible characters who keep choosing messy community over silo'd righteousness, motion over despair. She presents for inspection America's most persistent chorus of moral self-defense, "Better them than us," and shows how it rots the minds, hearts, and land of all who sing it. Only Karen Russell could write a dust bowl opus with such raucous brio—The Antidote soars with exigent joy and laugh-out-loud scenes, with memory witches and enchanted cameras and the world's most lovable sentient scarecrow. It's magic, a book doing this big work and also making it propulsive, eminently readable. If irony bypasses the difficulty of describing things, then the vivid sincerity on display here marks a virtuosic artist at the height of her lucidity. Russell has rendered with soul and urgency the vast inexpressible ache at the heart of American gratitude."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

"This novel swept me up and carried me away, even while somehow burying me, and digging up something about the story of this country I didn't know I needed to know. As with all of Russell's work, heaviness and levity are always kept in balance, and so I was lifted even while being devastated by the book's many brutal truths and stark beauty. I'd already considered Russell's vivid and inventive imagination to be endless, but here exploring a history of Nebraska we get an unearthing of this country's still relatively untold origin story, the part about its original people, and the cost paid in order that this country might be formed. Finishing the book I felt completely covered in the forgotten dust of what too few look back on, with rare clarity, not to mention the intricate braid of narratives masterfully woven here. The Antidote is one, for an all too poisoned American narrative about land and family and belonging."

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars

title: Falling Upwards
subtitle: How We Took to the Air
long_summary:
The age of ballooning emerges as a theater of human audacity in this vivid cultural history. Richard Holmes chronicles the extraordinary individuals who first conquered the skies, from the Anglo-French rivalries that sparked aerial competition to the remarkable exploits of pioneers like Sophie Blanchard and John Wise.

These early aviators transformed both science and imagination. James Glaisher's death-defying ascents into the thin air seven miles above Earth laid crucial groundwork for meteorological study, while the mass balloon exodus from besieged Paris became history's first civilian airlift. Holmes reveals how these aerial adventures captured the literary imagination of writers like Mary Shelley and Jules Verne, who recognized flight's power to reshape human perspective.

Blending scientific discovery with personal drama, the narrative spans from Civil War reconnaissance missions to the daredevil performances that thrilled crowds across two continents. Holmes illuminates not just the technical achievements of these balloonists, but the deeper human drive to transcend earthly boundaries and see the world from an entirely new vantage point.
short_summary: The daring pioneers who first took to the skies in balloons come alive in this captivating cultural history. Holmes weaves together science, adventure, and human folly in an irresistible chronicle of flight.
author_bios: Richard Holmes wrote The Age of Wonder, which earned recognition from the Samuel Johnson Prize shortlist and won both the Royal Society Prize for Science Books and National Book Critics Circle Award. His extensive bibliography includes Falling Upwards, Shelley: The Pursuit (Somerset Maugham Award), Coleridge: Early Visions (Whitbread Book of the Year), and Dr. Johnson & Mr. Savage (James Tait Black Prize). Holmes received the OBE in 1992 and resides in England.
quotes:
"An unconventional history of ballooning, this quirky, endearing, and enticing collection melds the spirit of discovery with chemistry, physics, engineering, and the imagination."

—Publishers Weekly

"Gripping…Meticulous history illuminated and animated by personal passion, carried aloft by volant prose."

—Kirkus

"In the same month that Julian Barnes published Levels of Life, with its melancholy meditations on balloon flight, Richard Holmes presents a full-blown, lyrical history of the same subject, investigating the strangeness, detachment and powerful romance of 'falling upwards' into a seemingly alien and uninhabitable element. Holmes lovingly charts a course from the Montgolfier brothers' first hydrogen-fuelled flights in the 1780s to the use of balloons by fugitive East Germans in the 1970s and the latest forays by polar explorer David Hempleman-Adams, a history full of awe and inefficiency…Holmes is a truly masterly storyteller."

—London Evening Standard

title: Long Island
long_summary:
Life has settled into predictable rhythms for Eilis Lacey in her Long Island neighborhood, where she navigates marriage to Tony and raises two teenagers among his sprawling Italian American family. Despite decades in America, her heart still carries the weight of her Irish origins, creating an internal tension she's learned to live with.

That delicate balance shatters when an unexpected visitor brings news that cuts to the core of everything she's built. The revelation forces Eilis to confront not just her husband's betrayal, but fundamental questions about forgiveness, family, and the price of the choices we make. Tóibín crafts a story that examines how we respond when our carefully constructed worlds collapse, and whether redemption is possible when trust has been broken. The novel becomes a meditation on the bonds that hold us—to place, to people, to versions of ourselves we thought we'd left behind.
short_summary: Eilis Lacey has built a life on Long Island with her Italian American husband and their children. When a stranger arrives with news that threatens to destroy everything, her response will define her future.
author_bios: Colm Tóibín has written eleven novels, including the Oprah's Book Club selection Long Island, The Magician (Rathbones Folio Prize winner), The Master (Los Angeles Times Book Prize winner), Brooklyn (Costa Book Award winner), and Nora Webster (Hawthornden Prize winner). His published works also include three story collections and multiple volumes of criticism. Tóibín serves as the Irene and Sidney B. Silverman Professor of the Humanities at Columbia University and held the position of Laureate for Irish Fiction from the Arts Council of Ireland from 2022–2024. He received the David Cohen Prize for Literature in 2021.
quotes:
"I was captivated. A wonderful page-turner to start your summer reading."

—Oprah Winfrey

"A brilliant novel. Beautifully crafted… makes for a riveting, wonderful read."

—Elizabeth Strout, The Guardian

"Eilis is an interesting and vivid character because she manages to make her destiny her choice... In her own mind, and in the eyes of sympathetic readers, she is free."

—The New York Times

title: Strangers in the Land
subtitle: Exclusion, Belonging, and the Epic Story of the Chinese in America
long_summary:
In the 1850s, thousands of Chinese workers crossed the Pacific Ocean chasing dreams of prosperity in what they called Gold Mountain. Yet their hopes collided with a nation that would soon turn violently against them. This meticulously researched history exposes how America constructed its first racially-based immigration restrictions, targeting Chinese laborers as economic anxieties mounted and white hostility intensified.

Michael Luo reconstructs forgotten episodes of terror: entire communities driven from their homes at gunpoint, individuals murdered by vengeful crowds, and families scattered across a hostile continent. Through figures like herbalist Gene Tong, who died at the hands of a Los Angeles lynch mob, and activist Wong Chin Foo, who courageously challenged discriminatory laws, Luo illuminates both the cruelty these immigrants endured and their remarkable resilience.

The book traces how mass expulsions across the American West created the nation's first undocumented population, while federal exclusion acts established dangerous precedents for racial discrimination. Drawing from archives across the country, Luo connects this buried history to contemporary Asian American experiences, demonstrating how questions of belonging and acceptance continue to shape communities more than a century later.
short_summary: Michael Luo chronicles the Chinese American experience from the Gold Rush to today, revealing how a community persevered through exclusion laws, violence, and systematic persecution. Essential history that illuminates ongoing struggles for belonging.
author_bios: Michael Luo serves as an executive editor at The New Yorker, where he regularly covers politics, religion, and Asian American topics. He previously worked for thirteen years at the New York Times in various roles including metro reporter, national correspondent, and investigative reporter and editor. His journalism has earned him a George Polk Award and a Livingston Award for Young Journalists.
quotes:
"Strangers in the Land is what history should be--richly detailed, authoritative, and compelling. Luo pieces together the stunning and shocking story of a people's journey to this country, and in the process reveals an essential part of the story of America."

—David Grann, New York Times-bestselling author of The Wager and Killers of the Flower Moon

"An epic of both the best and worst aspects of the American experiment, Strangers in the Land is a work of history that is deeply researched, deftly written, and highly relevant today. In the vivid, often heartbreaking, and ultimately inspiring experiences of Chinese immigrants and Chinese Americans, Luo finds a deeper story about aspiration and belonging that is as universal as it is profound."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, New York Times-bestselling author of Say Nothing

"Tracing echoes of today's debates around immigration and exclusion to the past, Luo's vividly told, carefully researched, and deeply compassionate book is an essential contribution to the continually unfolding story of the Chinese in America."

—Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Stay True

title: Underland
subtitle: A Deep Time Journey
long_summary:
Robert Macfarlane takes readers on an extraordinary subterranean odyssey that spans millennia and continents. This remarkable work delves into humanity's relationship with the world beneath our feet, from ancient burial chambers to modern nuclear storage facilities carved deep into bedrock.

Macfarlane's journey carries him through Norwegian caverns adorned with prehistoric art, down into the crystalline depths of Greenland's ice sheet, and through the bone-lined passages of Paris's underground. He discovers the intricate fungal webs that connect forest ecosystems and contemplates repositories designed to safeguard radioactive materials for geological ages.

Throughout these descents, he encounters the stories of those who came before—cave painters, urban explorers, scientists, and visionaries who sought understanding in darkness. The book weaves together mythology, science, and personal reflection to examine our role as stewards of the planet. Macfarlane challenges readers to consider the legacy we're creating for generations yet to come, making the invisible foundations of our world both tangible and urgent.
short_summary: Macfarlane descends into caves, catacombs, and ice caps on an epic journey through deep time. A lyrical exploration of the underground world that asks whether we're being good ancestors to future Earth.
author_bios: Robert Macfarlane has written numerous internationally bestselling books including Underland, The Old Ways, and The Wild Places, with translations appearing in over thirty languages. His collaborative projects feature The Lost Words and The Lost Spells created with Jackie Morris, plus various film and theatrical productions. Emmanuel College, Cambridge counts him among their fellows, and his literary achievements include receiving both the E. M. Forster and Henry David Thoreau prizes.
quotes:
"Profound in every sense of the word."

—Richard Powers

"An excellent book—fearless and subtle, empathic and strange."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Reading Macfarlane connects us to dazzling new worlds. It's a connection that brings, more than anything else, joy."

—Barbara J. King, NPR

title: Rejection
long_summary:
Tony Tulathimutte delivers a collection that dissects the brutal realities of romantic failure in the digital age. These interconnected tales follow characters whose desperate attempts at love and validation spiral into increasingly absurd disasters.

A self-proclaimed feminist discovers that his progressive politics mask deeper resentments about his romantic failures. Another character's innocent attraction morphs into destructive fixation, while a sexually inexperienced individual's fumbling attempts at intimacy result in catastrophic consequences.

The stories weave together as characters encounter each other across dating platforms and social networks, creating a web of missed connections and digital humiliations. Tulathimutte captures how technology amplifies our worst impulses, turning ordinary loneliness into performance art.

With razor-sharp wit and unflinching honesty, this collection examines the gap between our romantic fantasies and harsh reality. The author transforms cringe-worthy moments into darkly hilarious commentary on contemporary dating culture, revealing how our need for connection often becomes the very thing that isolates us.
short_summary: Seven wickedly funny, interconnected stories follow characters whose romantic disasters and digital obsessions reveal the brutal comedy of modern rejection. Tulathimutte dissects desire with surgical precision and savage wit.
author_bios: Tony Tulathimutte wrote Private Citizens and Rejection, establishing himself as a distinctive voice in contemporary fiction. His writing appears in publications including The Paris Review, n+1, The Nation, The New Republic, and The New York Times. Tulathimutte has earned recognition through an O. Henry Award and a Whiting Award, and currently leads the writing workshop CRIT in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Obsessively readable, acerbic, Foster Wallace–inflected."

—Vanity Fair

"Tulathimutte is such an acutely observant writer that I was entranced by his book despite its narrowness and emotional barbarity. One of Tulathimutte's primal topics is online culture and its diseased repercussions, and he writes about these things in the way Anthony Bourdain wrote about restaurants, Hunter S. Thompson wrote about motorcycle gangs and Molly Ivins wrote about water-headed Texas politicians. He's alert, in other words; he's tanked up, bleakly funny and always stropping his knife. . . . Tulathimutte is a big talent and he is clearly just getting started."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Rejection could be the year's feel-bad book, but Tulathimutte's inventiveness, his intellect, his sense of humor, and his precise style make his characters' mortifications a pleasure to read. . . Like [Philip] Roth, Tulathimutte knows desire can be as ludicrous as it is urgent; like Roth, he likes a good dirty joke. . . . [Rejection] deserves many and enthusiastic readers."

—Matthew Keeley, The Boston Globe

title: In the Dream House
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Carmen Maria Machado transforms personal devastation into literary innovation, dissecting an emotionally destructive relationship through a kaleidoscope of storytelling forms. Rather than following traditional memoir conventions, she fragments her experience across chapters that each adopt different genres and perspectives—from horror tropes to fairy tale analysis.

The book interrogates how we understand and discuss abuse, particularly within queer relationships where narratives of violence are often erased or ignored. Machado weaves together personal reflection with cultural criticism, examining everything from legal frameworks to pop culture representations. Her approach reveals how the same events can yield entirely different meanings depending on the lens through which we view them.

This structural experimentation serves a deeper purpose: showing how trauma resists neat categorization and how survivors must often become archaeologists of their own experiences. The result challenges both memoir as a form and our cultural conversations about intimate violence, creating something that reads like a master class in survival and storytelling.
short_summary: Each chapter uses a different narrative form to examine an abusive relationship from new angles. Machado's innovative structure transforms personal trauma into groundbreaking memoir that's both devastating and brilliant.
author_bios: Carmen Maria Machado has established herself as one of contemporary literature's most inventive voices through her memoir In the Dream House, graphic novel The Low, Low Woods, and short story collection Her Body and Other Parties. Her work has earned recognition including National Book Award finalist status, the Bard Fiction Prize, Lambda Literary Awards for both Lesbian Fiction and LGBTQ Nonfiction, Brooklyn Public Library Literature Prize, Shirley Jackson Award, and National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize. The New York Times included Her Body and Other Parties among "15 remarkable books by women shaping 21st century fiction."
quotes:
"Machado's writing is full of repressed physical energy and the raw juice of annihilating female fury."

—Louise Erdrich, The Millions

"[Machado's] use of a vivid experimental lens to show women struggling for agency is startling."

—The New Yorker

"With Machado, everything feels razed and built anew."

—Star Tribune (Minneapolis)

title: State of Paradise
long_summary:
Florida's oppressive heat mirrors the psychological pressure mounting on a ghostwriter who thought returning home would offer sanctuary. Instead, she finds her family fracturing in disturbing ways: her sister has become consumed by a VR headset called MIND'S EYE, while their mother drifts toward a mysterious religious movement.

The town itself seems infected by strangeness. Feral cats multiply in the streets, neighbors vanish without explanation, and the ghostwriter's own body begins betraying her in impossible ways. Everything escalates during a torrential storm that swallows her sister whole, only to spit her back out days later with wild stories about parallel worlds.

Determined to understand what's happening, the ghostwriter uncovers disturbing links between the tech company behind MIND'S EYE, her famous employer, and the very fabric of what we call real. Van den Berg builds a fever dream of family dysfunction and technological horror, questioning whether the stories we tell ourselves can protect us from—or trap us within—the narratives that shape our lives.
short_summary: When a ghostwriter returns to her Florida hometown, she discovers her sister obsessed with virtual reality and townspeople mysteriously disappearing. A mind-bending thriller about technology, family secrets, and reality's slippery nature.
author_bios: Laura van den Berg has published three story collections, including I Hold a Wolf by the Ears, which Time recognized as one of 2020's ten best fiction books. She has also written the novels Find Me and The Third Hotel, the latter earning finalist status for the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award. Her honors include a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the Bard Fiction Prize, and a PEN/O. Henry Award. A Florida native, Laura van den Berg divides her time between Boston and Central Florida.
quotes:
"Pitch perfect and exquisitely composed. Laura van den Berg is a gifted and audacious writer and she's written a novel of weight, power and beauty. I couldn't put it down."

—Charles Yu, author of Interior Chinatown

"State of Paradise chronicles strange pandemic days, the rise of mindless electronic escape, and grief's otherworldly whims in a wholly original and epically engaging novel from a master of episodic oddity. I'll follow Laura van den Berg wherever she wants to take me, even Florida."

—Rachel Yoder, author of Nightbitch

"State of Paradise is deeply, thrillingly weird. With missing sisters, sinkholes, cults, and floods, the novel is as surprising and compelling as Florida itself. Laura van den Berg's brilliance is only further confirmed by every book she writes—this newest one will blow your mind."

—Julia Phillips, author of Disappearing Earth & Bear

subtitle: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created
long_summary:
Columbus's arrival in the Americas triggered an unprecedented biological upheaval that fundamentally altered life on Earth. The collision between Old and New Worlds unleashed a cascade of ecological exchanges—crops, livestock, diseases, and invasive species crossed oceans and continents, reshaping ecosystems and human societies in ways that continue today.

Charles C. Mann traces how this biological revolution sparked economic transformation on a global scale. Spanish trade routes connecting Asia, Europe, and the Americas created the world's first truly international economy, with consequences that rippled across continents for centuries. Some regions prospered while others suffered devastating consequences.

This sweeping narrative connects historical events to contemporary issues, revealing how colonial-era exchanges established patterns that still influence modern debates about globalization, migration, and cultural identity. Mann's investigation into this pivotal period demonstrates that understanding our interconnected past is essential for navigating today's complex world.
short_summary: Following his bestselling 1491, Mann explores the biological collision that reshaped our world. The most momentous ecological event since the dinosaurs—told with startling research and brilliant clarity.
genres: History / Americas (North, Central, South, West Indies)
author_bios: Charles C. Mann contributes regularly to major publications including The Atlantic, Science, and Wired, while his work has appeared in Fortune, The New York Times, Smithsonian, Technology Review, Vanity Fair, The Washington Post, HBO, and Law & Order. His journalism has earned him recognition as a three-time National Magazine Award finalist, along with honors from the American Bar Association, American Institute of Physics, Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and Lannan Foundation.
quotes:
"Revelatory."

—Lev Grossman, Time

"Compelling and eye-opening."

—Publishers Weekly

"In the wake of his groundbreaking book 1491 Charles Mann has once again produced a brilliant and riveting work that will forever change the way we see the world. Mann shows how the ecological collision of Europe and the Americas transformed virtually every aspect of human history. Beautifully written, and packed with startling research, 1493 is a monumental achievement."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon, The Lost City of Z

title: Crook Manifesto
long_summary:
Three snapshots across the turbulent 1970s reveal Ray Carney's ongoing struggle to balance legitimate business with the criminal underworld that keeps pulling him back. Despite his efforts to run a clean furniture store, circumstances repeatedly force him into morally ambiguous territory—whether securing concert tickets through corrupt police contacts or investigating suspicious fires that threaten his tenants.

Alongside him stands Pepper, whose talent for violence makes him equally suited for heist work and Hollywood security details. As Harlem transforms around them, both men must navigate a landscape where survival often requires compromising one's principles.

Whitehead constructs a vivid portrait of urban decay and resilience, using crime fiction as a vehicle to examine larger questions about family loyalty, economic necessity, and the costs of trying to build something honest in a dishonest world. The result is both a rollicking caper and a meditation on how ordinary people adapt to extraordinary circumstances, finding humor and humanity even as their city burns around them.
short_summary: Ray Carney and Pepper navigate 1970s Harlem through three explosive years of crime, corruption, and survival. Whitehead's darkly comic sequel captures a burning city with masterful prose.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead has earned recognition as one of America's most vital contemporary voices, winning two Pulitzer Prizes for The Underground Railroad and The Nickel Boys, with the former also receiving the National Book Award. The #1 New York Times bestselling writer has produced twelve works spanning fiction and nonfiction. Both the MacArthur Foundation and Guggenheim Foundation have honored his contributions to literature, and he makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"Remarkable…For all its slapstick fun, this project also contains the same gravitas as August Wilson's seminal 10-play Century Cycle about Black life in Pittsburgh … When Carney is reflecting, attempting to better understand how Black Harlemites and Black Americans have survived before and will survive again, Whitehead is at his best. It makes this story feel important, not just entertaining, not just suspenseful, not just another surefire bestseller from a beloved author. These are crime novels, yes; funny and fast-paced. They are also the first two installments of a grand historical epic. Novel writing at its best. Bigger and better, together, than anything Whitehead has written before."

—The Washington Post

"Whitehead's flair for texture is as sharp as ever…Ray, May, Elizabeth and Pepper in particular are by turns exasperating and aspirational. Life gets thrown at them, and they throw themselves back in return. These are people you crave to catch up with, and in Whitehead's hands, the vast and intangible forces of society, injustice, morality, survival and love are distilled in them."

—NPR

"Dazzling … a glorious and intricate anatomy of the heist, the con and the slow game … [Whitehead] uses the crime novel as a lens to investigate the mechanics of a singular neighborhood at a particular tipping point in time. He has it right: the music, the energy, the painful calculus of loss. Structured into three time periods — 1971, 1973 and finally the year of America's bicentennial celebration, 1976 — "Crook Manifesto" gleefully detonates its satire upon this world while getting to the heart of the place and its people."

—Walter Mosley, The New York Times

title: This Strange Eventful History
long_summary:
The Cassar family exists in perpetual motion, their lives shaped by forces beyond their control across seventy years of the twentieth century. What begins with wartime separation evolves into something more complex: the particular rootlessness that comes from belonging to a place that no longer exists.

At the center stands a marriage built on romantic idealism—Gaston and Lucienne's devotion to their own love story becomes both anchor and burden for the generations that follow. Their children, François and Denise, navigate the peculiar isolation of their family's circumstances, while François's marriage to Barbara reveals how cultural divides can persist even in intimacy. Through it all, granddaughter Chloe seeks to understand how family secrets and silences have shaped them all.

Messud constructs a narrative that moves between continents and decades, examining how displacement becomes inheritance. The novel interrogates the stories families tell themselves to survive, and questions whether understanding the past can truly liberate us from it. Drawing from her own family's experience, Messud creates a meditation on belonging that feels both deeply personal and universally resonant.
short_summary: Messud traces the pieds-noirs Cassars across seven decades of displacement, from World War II through Algerian independence. A multigenerational saga about family mythology and the search for home.
author_bios: Claire Messud has published six works of fiction and teaches at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Her literary achievements include receiving Guggenheim and Radcliffe Fellowships, along with the prestigious Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"A tour de force, This Strange Eventful History is one of those rare novels which a reader doesn't merely read but lives through with the characters. Call it the War and Peace of the 20th and 21st century; call it The Long View of a family migrating through many borders, worlds, and eras; call it anything and we fall short. Claire Messud is a magnificent storyteller, and the novel, an all-encompassing history of many human hearts and any human heart, will linger and haunt us as the best and the most heartbreaking memory."

—Yiyun Li, author of the PEN/Faulkner Award-winning The Book of Goose

"[Claire Messud] paints compelling portraits of internal conflicts and tangled relationships, dropping along the way tantalizing references to crucial events that will be clarified later, in a rich narrative that defies summary…[her] gimlet eye and quietly masterful way with words make every character and incident gripping. Brilliant and heart-wrenching; Messud is one of contemporary literature's best."

—Kirkus

"[Messud] draws from her own family history for this exquisite multigenerational saga of the Cassars, a pied-noir clan exiled from Algeria by the country's 1954–62 war of independence…In her characteristically artful prose, Messud burrows inside the hearts and minds of her key players, bringing to their struggles and self-deceptions a deep-veined empathy made even more remarkable by how close she is to the story. This is an astonishment."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Command and Control
subtitle: Nuclear Weapons, the Damascus Accident, and the Illusion of Safety
long_summary:
Eric Schlosser delivers a chilling investigation into the precarious world of nuclear weapons management, revealing decades of close calls that could have changed history forever. The narrative centers on a catastrophic equipment failure at an Arkansas missile facility, but this single incident opens the door to a much larger examination of systemic vulnerabilities within America's atomic infrastructure.

Through meticulous research and exclusive interviews, Schlosser exposes the uncomfortable truth about nuclear safety: despite sophisticated safeguards and dedicated personnel, the combination of human fallibility and mechanical complexity creates an ongoing dance with disaster. The book illuminates how military leaders, engineers, and politicians have grappled with weapons designed to end civilization while simultaneously trying to prevent their accidental deployment.

What emerges is a sobering portrait of institutional overconfidence meeting technological reality. Schlosser's investigation reveals that the very systems meant to protect us may contain the seeds of our destruction, making this essential reading for anyone seeking to understand the true cost of living in the atomic age.
short_summary: Schlosser investigates the history and danger of America's nuclear arsenal, weaving gripping narrative with chilling detail. Reads like a thriller while exposing the terrifying reality of nuclear accidents.
author_bios: Eric Schlosser works as a correspondent for The Atlantic and has contributed to major publications including Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, The Nation, and The New Yorker. His investigative journalism has earned him recognition through a National Magazine Award and a Sidney Hillman Foundation Award for reporting excellence.
quotes:
"Schlosser's book reads like a thriller, but it's masterfully even-handed, well researched, and well organised. Either he's a natural genius at integrating massive amounts of complex information, or he worked like a dog to write this book. You wouldn't think the prospect of nuclear apocalypse would make for a reading treat, but in Schlosser's hands it does."

—Jonathan Franzen, The Guardian

"Nail-biting... thrilling... Mixing expert commentary with hair-raising details of a variety of mishaps, [Eric Schlosser] makes the convincing case that our best control systems are no match for human error, bad luck, and ever-increasing technological complexity."

—Publishers Weekly

"Vivid and unsettling... An exhaustive, unnerving examination of the illusory safety of atomic arms."

—Kirkus

title: The Woman Upstairs
long_summary:
At thirty-seven, Nora Eldridge has accepted her role as the dependable single woman who tends to everyone else's needs while her own artistic aspirations gather dust. Teaching elementary school in Cambridge, she exists on the periphery of more exciting lives—until the Shahids arrive and everything changes.

The family captivates her immediately: Reza, a sensitive boy in her class; Skandar, his charismatic Lebanese academic father; and Sirena, his magnetic Italian artist mother who seems to embody everything Nora has denied herself. What begins as concern for young Reza after a bullying incident evolves into something far more consuming.

Drawn into their sophisticated orbit, Nora experiences an awakening that threatens to demolish the careful constraints she's built around her life. Her dormant hunger for art, passion, and recognition resurfaces with startling intensity. But this intoxicating proximity to the life she's always wanted forces Nora to confront uncomfortable truths about desire, friendship, and the price of self-denial. Messud crafts a fierce examination of middle-aged reinvention and the dangerous allure of other people's seemingly perfect lives.
short_summary: Elementary school teacher Nora Eldridge has settled into life as the reliable woman upstairs until the glamorous Shahid family awakens her buried dreams and desires. What follows is an intoxicating, devastating reckoning with authenticity and artistic ambition.
author_bios: Claire Messud has written six works of fiction and currently teaches at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where she also resides. Her literary achievements include receiving Guggenheim and Radcliffe Fellowships, as well as the prestigious Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"Almost without knowing it, I was hungry for Nora Eldridge, the hero of Messud's new novel. The title names an archetype: the nice, unmarried lady on the third floor who smiles in the lobby and is quickly forgotten. Nora is a caring schoolteacher seemingly content to look after her ailing father, her dreams of living the life of an artist subsumed by the act of simply living a life. Bitterly funny and self-aware, she claims to be having a 'Lucy Jordan moment,' name-checking the Marianne Faithfull song . . . It seems right that Messud's follow-up to The Emperor's Children grasps furiously at life and punches back at encroaching age. In The Woman Upstairs, she abandons the polyphonic narration of the previous novel for first-person carpe diem prose that is leaner and meaner. . . . Nora [is] exhilarating, a fiery heroine who arrives to serve [both] middle-aged readers, and the young women who will soon see what it's like when the spotlight swings away, urging us to make the most of that time between here and the finish line."

—Katrina Onstad, Toronto Life

"Intimate . . . Messud's cosmopolitan sensibilities infuse her fiction with a refreshing cultural fluidity. . . . The Woman Upstairs opens with extraordinary heat and momentum . . . [and] brims with energy and ideas. . . . A suspenseful psychological thriller . . . Brilliant."

—Jane Ciabattari, NPR

"From its opening lines, Messud's new novel grips like a choke hold. . . .The most unlikely hero, Nora, self-identifies with scornful wit and rage as the titular Woman Upstairs. But oh how Messud, whose last novel was the sharp and brilliant The Emperor's Children, gives her woman room to roar. . . . Sirena awakens in her an unapologetic lust of life that Nora was previously too good or too scared to claim. The narrative burns toward an inevitable betrayal of startling proportions, one that instead of diminishing Nora lights her ablaze. This is a book sweating with rage, and an exhilarating one. Read it in an openmouthed gulp. After the final powerful paragraphs, in which Nora howls in galvanized fury, throw it down and have a drink, or a dreamless nap. Don't be surprised if you then pick it back up and start all over again."

—Karen Valby, Entertainment Weekly

title: Dead and Alive
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
Smith's intellectual curiosity spans an impressive range in this collection, moving seamlessly between art criticism, cultural observation, and personal reflection. The essays reveal an author equally at home analyzing the visual work of contemporary artists or contemplating the loss of beloved writers who shaped modern literature.

From examining government upheavals to wandering familiar London streets, Smith demonstrates how seemingly disparate experiences illuminate larger truths about our shared existence. Her approach combines rigorous analysis with genuine warmth, whether she's discussing film, mourning departed authors, or exploring what binds communities together.

The collection showcases Smith's gift for finding meaning in both grand cultural moments and intimate encounters. She moves between public and private spaces with equal facility, revealing how political shifts, artistic expression, and personal loss all contribute to our understanding of contemporary life. These essays offer readers a chance to see familiar subjects through Smith's distinctive lens—one that consistently finds depth and connection where others might see only surface or separation.
short_summary: Smith's latest essay collection roams from visual art to politics to grief with her trademark intelligence. Whether mourning literary giants or dissecting contemporary culture, she finds profound connections in unexpected places.
author_bios: Zadie Smith has published six novels including White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud, alongside the novella The Embassy of Cambodia and short story collection Grand Union. Her nonfiction works include three essay collections: Changing My Mind, Feel Free, and Intimations. Smith also wrote The Wife of Willesden, a play adapted from Chaucer. A native of north-west London, she continues to live there today.
quotes:
"Novelist and critic Smith brings an incisive eye and keen wit to art, music, fiction, politics, and more in this wide-ranging essay collection . . . Smith delivers original insights couched in sly, artful prose . . . Readers will be rewarded by this unforgettable collection."

—Publishers Weekly

"Written between 2016 and 2025, these often compelling essays are divided into five sections: Eyeballing, Considering, Reconsidering, Mourning, and Confessing. That means pieces on visual artists like Kara Walker and films like Tár, a memorial for Wolf Hall author Hilary Mantel, and a new essay about technology that is one of the book's high points . . . Smith leaves room for disagreement and still maintains her high-minded humanistic ideas."

—Vulture

"[Dead and Alive] showcases a writer whose curiosity remains undimmed. [Zadie Smith] effortlessly transitions from art critique–focusing on Toyin Ojih Odutola and Kara Walker–to musings on politics, grief and pop culture, including reflections on the artistic drama Ta´r or Stormzy's Glastonbury performance."

—The Mirror

title: Dearie
subtitle: The Remarkable Life of Julia Child
long_summary:
Julia Child's rise from an aimless young woman to America's most beloved culinary teacher reads like fiction, but Bob Spitz's masterful biography reveals the real story behind the legend. Before revolutionizing American kitchens, Child worked for a wartime intelligence agency, seemingly destined for obscurity until Paris awakened her passion for French cooking.

Spitz chronicles how Child's collaboration on Mastering the Art of French Cooking and her groundbreaking television show The French Chef transformed not just how Americans prepared meals, but their entire relationship with food. Starting her TV career at fifty, she became PBS's first educational celebrity, proving that learning could be both rigorous and delightful.

The biography illuminates Child's fearless approach to breaking conventions and her gift for making the intimidating accessible. Her partnership with husband Paul Child provides the emotional heart of a story that extends far beyond recipes and techniques. Spitz demonstrates how one woman's infectious enthusiasm and determination reshaped American culture, turning cooking from drudgery into adventure and establishing a legacy that continues to inspire home cooks today.
short_summary: From wartime spy to culinary icon, Julia Child's unlikely journey gets the biography it deserves. Spitz captures both her revolutionary impact on American cooking and the irrepressible joy she brought to every kitchen.
author_bios: Bob Spitz has written acclaimed biographies including the New York Times bestsellers The Beatles and Dearie: The Remarkable Life of Julia Child, along with six additional nonfiction works and a screenplay. His background includes managing Bruce Springsteen and Elton John during pivotal moments in their careers, and he has contributed hundreds of major celebrity profiles featuring figures from Keith Richards to Jane Fonda.
quotes:
"It's a revelation."

—Lev Grossman, Time Magazine

"Spitz captures another side of [Julia's] complex personality: her fierce diligence in mastering the science as well as the art of cooking through detailed experimentation and her concern to translate the preparation of complex French recipes for readers in America…An engrossing biography of a woman worthy of iconic status."

—Kirkus

"After wiping your drool off the page, you might wonder where Spitz uncovered such narrative gold…Author and subject almost become one, as Spitz channels the spirit of Child in his own words…His detailed research into mid-century American cooking helps us understand why exactly Child was such a big deal"

—Becky Krystal, The Washington Post

title: The Imperfectionists
long_summary:
The corridors of a crumbling English-language daily in Rome buzz with more intrigue than the stories its journalists cover. Tom Rachman's debut novel dissects the peculiar ecosystem of expatriate media, where professional ambition collides with personal catastrophe in darkly comic ways.

Each character inhabits their own brand of professional purgatory: an editor whose marriage crumbles as spectacularly as her newspaper's circulation, an obituary writer jolted from complacency by his own brush with mortality, and a cost-cutting executive whose romantic entanglements complicate her ruthless efficiency. Beyond the newsroom, correspondents navigate their own moral compromises—a Paris veteran chasing relevance through increasingly questionable means, and a naive Cairo reporter manipulated by a cynical war correspondent.

Presiding over this media menagerie is an eccentric publisher more devoted to his philosophical dog than to preserving his family's journalistic legacy. As digital media reshapes the industry and threatens the paper's survival, the institution's founding mythology slowly unravels, exposing the gap between idealistic origins and messy reality. Rachman captures journalism's existential crisis through deeply flawed characters whose professional dedication wars with personal dysfunction.
short_summary: Behind the scenes at a struggling English-language newspaper in Rome, personal dramas eclipse the headlines. Rachman's interconnected debut captures journalism's twilight with wit, heart, and sharp observation.
author_bios: Tom Rachman wrote three novels including The Italian Teacher, The Rise & Fall of Great Powers, and the New York Times bestseller The Imperfectionists. His books have reached readers in more than twenty-five languages. Originally from London and raised in Vancouver, Rachman spent years at the Associated Press working as a foreign-news editor in Manhattan and Rome before transitioning to fiction. His essays and reporting have been published in the New York Times, The Atlantic, the Washington Post, the Wall Street Journal, The New Yorker, and other publications. He currently resides in London with his family.
quotes:
"Marvelous … A rich, thrilling book that is both a love letter to and epitaph for the newspaper world…Mr. Rachman's transition from journalism to fiction writing is nothing short of spectacular. The Imperfectionists is a splendid original, filled with wit and structured so ingeniously that figuring out where the author is headed is half the reader's fun. The other half comes from his sparkling descriptions not only of newspaper office denizens but of the tricks of their trade, presented in language that is smartly satirical yet brimming with affection."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"[A] beguiling first novel…One by one these journalists are trotted through their tragicomic hamster wheels…Rachman [is] always finding new ways to surprise us."

—The Washington Post

"In his zinger of a debut, Rachman deftly applies his experience as foreign correspondent and editor to chart the goings-on at a scrappy English-language newspaper in Rome. Chapters read like exquisite short stories, As the ragtag staff faces down the implications of the paper's tilt into oblivion, there are more than enough sublime moments, unexpected turns and sheer inky wretchedness to warrant putting this on the shelf next to other great newspaper novels."

—Publishers Weekly

title: What Storm, What Thunder
long_summary:
The 2010 earthquake that shattered Port-au-Prince becomes the epicenter for examining interconnected lives across Haiti's social spectrum. Through multiple perspectives, the narrative weaves between a water company owner concealing family secrets, an architect daughter he refuses to claim, and a drug dealer yearning for love amid chaos.

The disaster exposes hidden connections: business partners convinced they're stalked by supernatural forces, a Boston taxi driver whose music carries memories of home, and a displaced woman whose lost children seem to visit her dreams. An elderly market vendor serves as the community's living memory, recognizing faces and stories that span generations.

Chancy constructs a mosaic of survival that transcends the immediate catastrophe, revealing how personal histories intersect with national trauma. The novel moves between moments of devastating loss and unexpected grace, showing how people forge meaning from destruction. Rather than simply documenting tragedy, the story illuminates the complex ways communities endure, adapt, and maintain hope when everything familiar crumbles.
short_summary: Ten interwoven voices capture life before, during, and after Haiti's devastating 2010 earthquake. Chancy transforms catastrophe into a profound meditation on resilience, grief, and the unbreakable bonds of community.
author_bios: Myriam J. A. Chancy wrote Village Weavers (Tin House), recognized as a Time Best Book of April 2024 and recipient of the 2025 OCM Bocas Prize for Fiction. Her literary achievements include the American Book Award, the Guyana Prize for Literature, the Foreword INDIES Gold Prize, and the Isis Duarte Book Prize. What Storm, What Thunder appeared on 2021 best books lists from NPR, Kirkus, Library Journal, the Boston Globe, and the Globe & Mail. She holds a Guggenheim Fellowship and serves as HBA Chair of the Humanities at Scripps College.
quotes:
"One of the finest examples of someone writing from a place of deep love and deep grief simultaneously—the story itself is wondrous and very, very human."

—Omar El Akkad, CBC

"Extraordinary. . . . lyrical. . . . dazzling. . . . Each of the voices entrances, thanks to Chancy's beautiful prose and rich themes. This is not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

"Virtuosic."

—The Globe and Mail

title: The Barn
subtitle: The Secret History of a Murder in Mississippi
long_summary:
Seventy years after Emmett Till's brutal death shook the nation, investigative threads that authorities failed to follow finally lead somewhere. Wright Thompson's meticulous detective work pieces together what really happened to the fourteen-year-old Chicago boy in the Mississippi Delta, challenging the incomplete narrative that has persisted for decades.

Through years of research and interviews, Thompson maps out the actual location where Till died and identifies witnesses whose voices were never heard. His investigation reveals how economic interests, racial terror, and institutional failures created a web of silence that protected the killers and denied justice to Till's family.

Beyond solving a cold case, Thompson examines how this single act of violence reflects larger patterns of American power and complicity. He traces the historical forces that made such brutality possible while celebrating the determination of those who refused to let the truth disappear entirely. The result is both a reckoning with past sins and a meditation on whether genuine reconciliation remains possible.
short_summary: Thompson uncovers shocking new evidence about Emmett Till's murder, revealing how global forces converged on the Mississippi Delta and why the truth remained buried for decades.
genres: History / United States / State & Local / South (AL, AR, FL, GA, KY, LA, MS, NC, SC, TN, VA, WV)
author_bios: Wright Thompson has written the bestselling books Pappyland and The Cost of These Dreams. He makes his home in Oxford, Mississippi, where he lives with his family.
quotes:
"[Thompson's] extraordinary new book The Barn is not only an intimate history of the tragedy, but also a deep meditation on Mississippi and America . . . While sifting through the dirt that buried the facts about Till's death, Thompson credits the work of the historians, journalists and filmmakers who have sought to tell the true tale. But he crafts a wider, deeper narrative. The Barn is serious history and skillful journalism, but with the nuance and wallop of a finely wrought novel . . . The Barn describes not just the poison of silence and lies, but also the dignity of courage and truth."

—The Washington Post

"The Barn is the most brutal, layered and absolutely beautiful book about Mississippi, and really how the world conspired with the best and worst parts of Mississippi, I will ever read. In Mississippi, we talk about athletes who bust their ass, skills be damned. Well, every generation you get a few writers with the engine of a 747 and the skill of a wizard. We see it in Ward, Wright, Faulkner and Trethewey. And that finely crafted motor is on full display in this work by Wright Thompson. The Barn is the new standard in research and book-making. There is one Wright Thompson. And we are so lucky he loves Mississippi. Reporting and reckoning can get no better, or more important, than this. Mississippi, goddamn."

—Kiese Laymon, author of Long Division and Heavy: An American Memoir

"Geography, wrote Ralph Ellison, is fate—an axiom painstakingly proven in the compelling architecture of Wright Thompson's The Barn. Though grounded in a small radius within the landscape of Mississippi, this capacious examination of a terrible history is both expansive and granular, national and personal. Thompson writes with a tone of relentless urgency at once tempered by a deep reflection on what becomes, ultimately, a seemingly unavoidable trajectory, a cataclysmic inevitability—the consequences of material greed and cruel disregard—into which our nation and the people in it were thrust. He writes, too, with a true storyteller's gift for language and image, and the ability to make grand connections across time and space, to see all the forces culminating in one terrible moment, all the lives destroyed or forever marked by what happened that night. Follow them though time, Thompson writes—and we do—into a world not only harrowing but also, we come to see, redeemable when the act of remembering, of looking unflinchingly at the troubled fabric of our nation is itself a kind of accountability, and redemption."

—Natasha Trethewey, author of Memorial Drive: A Daughter's Memoir

title: Another Word for Love
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Life fractures us all, but the journey toward wholeness becomes an act of profound love. Carvell Wallace transforms his personal reckoning into something far more expansive than typical trauma narratives, crafting instead a luminous exploration of what it means to rebuild oneself.

Drawing from his experiences navigating America as both Black and queer, Wallace refuses to center suffering as the defining element of his story. Instead, he traces the contours of resilience through moments both intimate and universal: finding shelter with a young mother during periods of homelessness, adapting to life in an isolating Pennsylvania town, learning to love and parent while the world seems increasingly unstable.

The same incisive lens Wallace applies to his celebrated profiles now illuminates his own existence, revealing how identity, family, sexuality, and mortality intersect in unexpected ways. This memoir operates as both personal testimony and broader meditation on repair—not just individual healing, but collective restoration. Wallace argues for embracing our full humanity, complications and all, suggesting that our capacity for connection might be our greatest strength in uncertain times.
short_summary: Wallace excavates his own history as a Black queer man in America with the same provocative sensitivity he brings to his acclaimed journalism. A radical meditation on healing that makes an irresistible case for love.
author_bios: Carvell Wallace creates compelling narratives across multiple platforms as both writer and podcast host. His journalism spans major publications including The New Yorker, The New York Times, GQ, and Esquire, where he explores intersections of race, culture, and arts. Wallace has developed acclaimed podcasts such as Closer Than They Appear, examining American identity and race, plus Finding Fred, celebrating Fred Rogers's legacy. He collaborated with Andre Iguodala on The Sixth Man in 2019 and currently resides in Oakland, California.
quotes:
"Another Word For Love is generous in how genuine the journey, the offering feels. Walking alongside a writer who is attempting to come to terms with the enormity of their survival, its joys and aches. And through this genuine nature, through this striking and beautiful prose, rich with touchable imagery, Carvell Wallace has you by the hand, and never lets go."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, author of There's Always This Year & A Little Devil in America

"This is a remarkable book by one of the finest young writers I've come across in many years. An insightful work by a young scribe of deep talent, whose courage and ingenuity is inspirational."

—James McBride, author of The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store & Deacon King Kong

"Carvell Wallace's Another Word For Love moves us symphonically, presenting an orchestra of moving parts, sounds, ideas, exquisite images to the reader as if to a beloved. It gives us a nearly unprecedented vision of life. It is one of the most beautiful memoirs I've ever read."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: Swing Time
long_summary:
In North West London, two girls share dreams of dance, though only one possesses genuine talent. The other compensates with keen observations about movement, music, and identity. Their intense bond fractures in adulthood, sending them down separate trajectories.

The talented friend pursues professional dance but finds herself struggling with the realities of grown-up existence. Meanwhile, her former companion reinvents herself as an aide to Aimee, a global superstar, gaining intimate access to wealth and celebrity culture.

Aimee's humanitarian interests eventually draw the narrative to West Africa, where multiple worlds collide: heritage-seeking visitors from the diaspora, local young people pursuing uncertain futures, and women whose movements echo the same rhythms that once connected two London girls. Through these intersecting stories, Smith examines how personal relationships mirror larger questions of privilege, cultural exchange, and the forces that both unite and divide us across continents.
short_summary: Childhood friends from London take divergent paths—one becomes a dancer, the other assists a pop star whose philanthropy leads them to West Africa. Smith weaves friendship and global inequality into a complex, rhythmic narrative.
author_bios: Zadie Smith has published six novels including White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud, alongside the novella The Embassy of Cambodia and short story collection Grand Union. Her nonfiction works include three essay collections: Changing My Mind, Feel Free, and Intimations. Smith also wrote The Wife of Willesden, a play adapted from Chaucer. A native of north-west London, she continues to live there today.
quotes:
"This is a story at once intimate and global, as much about childhood friendship as international aid, as fascinated by the fate of an unemployed single mother as it is by the omnipotence of a world-class singer . . . Smith's attention to the grace notes of friendship is as precise as ever . . . Swing Time uses its extraordinary breadth and its syncopated structure to turn the issues of race and class in every direction…We finally have a big social novel nimble enough to keep all its diverse parts moving gracefully toward a vision of what really matters in this life when the music stops."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A dance itself, syncopated, unexpected, and vital . . . Swing Time may not parse easily and fits no mold, but it is uncommonly full of life."

—Claire Messud, The New York Times

"A multilayered tour-de-force . . . Smith burnishes her place in the literary firmament with her fifth novel . . . The work is so absorbing that a reader might flip it open randomly and be immediately caught up. Its precision is thrilling even as it grows into a book-length meditation on cultural appropriation, played out on a celebrity-besotted global stage . . . Smith's novels are set in motion by character, complex portraits that are revelatory of race and class."

—Karen Long, Los Angeles Times

title: Milk Fed
long_summary:
Food becomes both prison and salvation for Rachel, whose carefully controlled existence revolves around restriction and ritual. Working at a talent agency by day and exercising obsessively by night, she's built a life around denial—until a therapeutic experiment separates her from her calorie-counting mother for three months.

This imposed silence creates space for something unexpected: Miriam, an Orthodox woman who works at Rachel's usual frozen yogurt haunt and seems determined to nourish her. Their connection defies everything Rachel thought she understood about herself, pulling her into unfamiliar territory where abundance replaces scarcity.

Broder crafts a story that moves between the sacred and profane, examining how we feed ourselves—and what we starve. Rachel's attraction to Miriam opens questions about faith, family, and the body's wisdom that her years of self-denial have silenced. The novel interrogates the complicated relationship between control and surrender, asking whether true satisfaction requires abandoning the safety of limitation for something more dangerous: actually wanting what we want.
short_summary: When Rachel meets Miriam at a frozen yogurt shop, their relationship becomes a reckoning with hunger, faith, and desire. Broder's exploration of appetites—physical, spiritual, sexual—is both devastatingly funny and deeply moving.
author_bios: Melissa Broder has published the novels Milk Fed and The Pisces alongside the essay collection So Sad Today and four poetry collections, including Last Sext. Her writing appears in The New York Times, Elle.com, VICE, Vogue Italia, and The Cut. A Pushcart Prize winner for poetry, Broder makes her home in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"With luscious descriptions of delectable foods and fantastical romps through imagination, Milk Fed oscillates between serious and playful, obsessive and free, and explores the difficulties of loving oneself in a world that prizes thinness above all else. This poignant exploration of desire, religion, and daughterhood is hard to resist."

—Publishers Weekly

"Bold, wry, and delightfully dirty... Broder is a formidable writer. She captures all the sticky sweetness, the pleasurable tensions between yearning and satiation...  a sad, funny romp about learning to let yourself want what you want."

—Kirkus

"A delectable exploration of physical and emotional hunger...  combines Broder's singular style with adventures of the calorie- and climax-filled kind, sumptuous fillings surrounded by perfectly baked plot."

—Bethanne Patrick, The Washington Post

title: The School for Good Mothers
long_summary:
A single lapse in judgment transforms Frida Liu's life into a nightmare of state surveillance and maternal testing. Already grappling with career disappointments and a crumbling marriage, Frida finds herself thrust into a government program designed to evaluate and reform supposedly inadequate mothers.

The institution operates like a laboratory for parenting, where every gesture of affection and moment of care becomes subject to clinical measurement. Here, women who dared to be imperfect—who glanced at phones, allowed independence, showed human weakness—must demonstrate their worthiness to remain mothers.

Chan constructs a world that feels disturbingly familiar, where societal expectations of maternal perfection become weaponized against women themselves. The novel interrogates how quickly love can be pathologized and how institutions can colonize the most intimate relationships. Through Frida's ordeal, we witness both the absurdity and cruelty of systems that claim to protect children while terrorizing their mothers.

This is a story about the impossible standards imposed on women, the ways society surveils and punishes maternal imperfection, and the fierce determination of a mother fighting to reclaim her child. Chan's vision reveals how thin the line between support and control truly is.
short_summary: One moment of poor judgment lands Frida Liu in a dystopian government institution designed to test whether she deserves to keep her daughter. A chilling examination of motherhood under surveillance.
author_bios: Jessamine Chan has published fiction in Tin House and Epoch, bringing her keen editorial eye from her previous role at Publishers Weekly to her creative work. She earned her MFA from Columbia University and BA from Brown University. Her writing has garnered recognition from the Elizabeth George Foundation, Bread Loaf Writers' Conference, and the Wurlitzer Foundation, among other notable residencies. Chan currently resides in Philadelphia with her family.
quotes:
"This book is like nothing I've read before--a tightly plotted, deeply moving novel that also offers profound insights into the state of contemporary motherhood within a country that offers very little in the way of societal support for parents. I found myself moved to tears by its conclusion. The School for Good Mothers is haunting and unforgettable, and I'm in awe of Jessamine Chan's mind."

—Liz Moore, author of The God of the Woods & Long Bright River

"Gutting and terrifying. Vivid and exquisite. In The School for Good Mothers, you'll find not only your favorite novel of the year, but also a new cultural touchstone, a reference point for the everyday horrors all parents experience and take for granted. This book is sharp, shocking, anxiety-provoking, superb. It is exactly what you want, and need, to read."

—Julia Phillips, author of Disappearing Earth

"Jessamine Chan captures, in heartbreaking tones, the exacting price women pay in a patriarchal society that despises them, that reduces their worth to their viability for procreation and capacity for mothering. The School for Good Mothers is not so much a warning for some possible dystopian nightmare as much as it is an alarm announcing that the nightmare is here. The book is, thus, a weeping testimony, a haunting song, and a piercing rebuke of both the misogynist social order and the traps it lays for women, girls, and femmes. Good Mothers deserves an honored place next to the works of Margaret Atwood and Octavia Butler."

—Robert Jones Jr., author of The Prophets and creator of Son of Baldwin

title: Cloud Cuckoo Land
long_summary:
Stories possess an almost magical ability to survive across time, connecting strangers separated by centuries through shared wonder. This ambitious novel traces how a single ancient tale about a man who dreams of becoming a bird ripples through different eras, touching five distinct lives in unexpected ways.

In Constantinople's final days, a young girl discovers this forgotten story while the city crumbles around her. Centuries later, an elderly man brings the same tale to life for children in an Idaho library, unaware that danger lurks nearby. Far in the future, a solitary woman aboard a spacecraft preserves these same words on whatever materials she can find.

Each character faces their own form of isolation—whether behind city walls, in small-town America, or in the vast emptiness of space. Yet the ancient story becomes their bridge to something larger than themselves. Doerr examines how literature serves as both refuge and revelation, offering solace to those who feel displaced in their own time. The novel asks profound questions about what we choose to preserve and why certain stories refuse to die, even as civilizations rise and fall around them.
short_summary: Five dreamers across centuries—from besieged Constantinople to a future spaceship—find connection through an ancient story about transformation and hope. Doerr weaves their lives into a luminous meditation on literature's power to endure.
author_bios: Anthony Doerr wrote the Pulitzer Prize-winning All the Light We Cannot See, along with the Carnegie Medal and Alex Award-winning novel. His recent work Cloud Cuckoo Land became a New York Times bestseller and National Book Award finalist. Doerr has published the story collections The Shell Collector and Memory Wall, the novel About Grace, and the memoir Four Seasons in Rome. Among his many honors are five O. Henry Prizes, the Story Prize, the Rome Prize, the Young Lions Award, the National Magazine Award for fiction, and a Guggenheim Fellowship. He makes his home in Boise, Idaho.
quotes:
"Of all our contemporary fiction writers, Anthony Doerr is the one whose novels seem to be the purest response to the primal request: tell me a story. . . . [Cloud Cuckoo Land] transports us far above the stars, and down into the mud. It dazzles, and disturbs. And I for one wanted Doerr's vast and overwhelming story to last much, much longer."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"There is a kind of book a seasoned writer produces after a big success: large-hearted, wide in scope and joyous. Following his Pulitzer winner All the Light We Cannot See, Anthony Doerr's Cloud Cuckoo Land is a deep lungful of fresh air–and a gift of a novel."

—Elizabeth Knox, The Guardian

"In a big fiction year . . . Cloud Cuckoo Land stands out. . . . Doerr's characters are astoundingly resilient, suggesting that we may yet save ourselves, with literature an essential tool."

—Hamilton Cain, Boston Globe

title: The Hypocrite
long_summary:
A daughter holds up a mirror to her father's past, and he doesn't like what he sees. In a London theater, a renowned novelist sits watching his daughter's latest production, slowly realizing she has transformed their shared memories into art that exposes his deepest flaws.

The story unfolds across two timelines: the present-day performance and a pivotal summer in Sicily years earlier, where father and daughter worked together on his manuscript. What seemed like collaboration now reveals itself as something far more complex—a young woman bearing witness to attitudes and behaviors that would later fuel her creative reckoning.

This debut novel examines how each generation inherits the moral debris of the last, and whether understanding can bridge the gap between old certainties and new consciousness. As the theatrical performance progresses, the boundaries between memory and imagination, between lived experience and artistic interpretation, begin to dissolve. The result is a meditation on family, art, and the courage required to confront uncomfortable truths about the people we love.
short_summary: A playwright transforms her novelist father's moral failings into devastating theater. Set between London and Sicily, this sharp debut examines generational reckoning with precision and unexpected tenderness.
author_bios: Jo Hamya wrote Three Rooms and contributes regularly to The New York Times, The Guardian, and the Financial Times. She is pursuing her PhD at King's College London, where she continues her literary studies.
quotes:
"The Hypocrite is a sharp book, beautifully written. Jo Hamya poses complex questions—about art and ethics, family life and sexual mores—and withholds from her reader any easy answers."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"A brilliant litmus test of a novel...What Hamya brings to this modern debacle, besides a precision of language and an aptitude for structure that ought to make her contemporaries quake, is a tenderness you don't see coming."

—The Atlantic

"Hamya deploys a fluid prose style…What is real, what is imagined, what is performed: In Hamya's confident hands, it all becomes productively confused…When Hamya allows her characters to live, breathe, spit and snarl, her fiction soars."

—The Washington Post

title: The Prophets
long_summary:
On a Mississippi plantation, two enslaved men discover solace in each other amid the brutalities of bondage. Their relationship becomes a sanctuary of tenderness in a world designed to strip away humanity. Yet their love faces a devastating threat from within their own community—a fellow enslaved person who seeks the master's approval by condemning what he sees as transgression.

Robert Jones, Jr. weaves together multiple perspectives in this sweeping narrative, giving voice to both the oppressed and their oppressors. The story examines how systems of control pit the powerless against one another, forcing impossible choices between survival and authenticity. Through lyrical prose, the novel interrogates the intersection of desire, spirituality, and resistance.

As community fractures deepen and long-simmering tensions reach a breaking point, the narrative builds toward a devastating confrontation that will determine the fate of all involved. This is both an intimate portrait of love under impossible circumstances and a broader meditation on how trauma echoes across generations, while celebrating the revolutionary act of choosing connection over isolation.
short_summary: Two enslaved men find refuge and forbidden love in each other on a Deep South plantation. When betrayal threatens their bond, their story becomes an epic reckoning with desire, faith, and survival.
author_bios: Robert Jones, Jr. wrote the bestselling debut novel The Prophets, which earned the 2022 Publishing Triangle Edmund White Award for Debut Fiction and the 2022 NAIBA Book of the Year Award for Fiction. The book reached finalist status for the 2021 National Book Award for Fiction and appeared on year-end best books lists from Time, Entertainment Weekly, USA Today, The Boston Globe, and The Washington Post. His essays and commentary have been featured in The New York Times, Essence, The Paris Review, Four Hundred Souls, and The 1619 Project.
quotes:
"What a rare marvel this book is. The Prophets fashions an epic so rich in erudition, wisdom, clarity, and power, so full of hard-earned yet too-brief joys, that it reaffirms for me literature's place as both balm and scalpel for the mind and soul. You can feel the decades of thinking embedded not only in these sentences but in how they question and build a world shamefully amputated from textbooks. Rarely is a book this finely wrought, the lives and histories it holds so tenderly felt, and rendered unforgettably true."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

"With this epic novel, Jones, who is known for his blogging and Twitter presence as Son of Baldwin, marks his entry into the literary arena....The greatest gift of this novel is its efforts to render emotional interiority to enslaved people who are too often depicted either as vessels for sadistic violence or as noble, superhuman warriors for liberation....Jones's debut novel is an important contribution to American letters, Black queer studies and the present moment's profound reckoning with the legacy of America's racialized violence."

—The Washington Post

"It is not hyperbole to say that The Prophets, which explores black queer lives on a Mississippi plantation known among the enslaved as 'Empty,' evokes the best of Toni Morrison, while being its own distinct and virtuosic work....This, then, is a novel wedded to its period but also of our times, exploring the pressing questions that have plagued America since its founding. It manages to be many things at once, stirring both the heart and the intellect in an exploration of human desire and depravity. A trenchant study of character, it is refreshing in its portrayal of the daily negotiations of humanity under slavery, practiced by both the enslaved and the enslavers. It is an ode to an enduring love."

—The Guardian

title: The Mars Room
long_summary:
Romy Hall faces the harsh reality of life imprisonment in California's Central Valley, cut off from everything that once defined her existence—her son Jackson and the San Francisco streets she knew. The walls of Stanville Women's Correctional Facility contain a complex ecosystem where survival depends on navigating unspoken rules, sudden violence, and the daily grind of institutional life.

Kushner captures the absurd bureaucracy and brutal hierarchies that govern this enclosed world, finding dark comedy amid genuine tragedy. Her prose illuminates the humanity that persists even in the most dehumanizing circumstances, revealing how women adapt, resist, and endure when society has written them off. This is neither a redemption story nor a simple condemnation—instead, it examines what it means to be forgotten by the outside world while fighting to maintain one's identity within prison walls.

The novel refuses easy answers about justice, motherhood, and second chances, instead offering an uncompromising look at America's carceral system through the eyes of those who live within it.
short_summary: Romy Hall begins two life sentences in a California women's prison, severed from her young son and former life. Kushner's unflinching portrait of incarceration is devastating and brilliant.
author_bios: Rachel Kushner has written the bestselling novel Creation Lake, along with The Mars Room, The Flamethrowers, and Telex from Cuba, plus the essay collection The Hard Crowd. Her work has earned the Prix Médicis and made her a two-time finalist for both the Booker Prize and National Book Award. The American Academy of Arts and Letters honored her with the Harold D.
