Vursell Memorial Award, and she received a Guggenheim Fellowship. Publishers worldwide have translated her novels into twenty-seven languages.
quotes:
"Like Denis Johnson in 'Jesus' Son,' Kushner is on the lookout for bent moments of comic grace…The Mars Room is a major novel."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Brilliant and devastating…Kushner doesn't make a false move in her third novel; she writes with an intelligence and a ferocity that sets her apart from most others in her cohort. She's a remarkably original and compassionate author, and The Mars Room is a heartbreaking, true and nearly flawless novel."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"Kushner's characters are so authentic and vividly drawn that with each new novel, it's easy to assume she's tapped out. Yet in The Mars Room, she brings to life another remarkable heroine."

—Time

title: A Burning
long_summary:
Three lives intersect in modern India, each driven by different dreams of advancement. A young Muslim woman's social media misstep transforms her into the prime suspect in a devastating train bombing, threatening to destroy any hope of escaping poverty. Meanwhile, a physical education instructor sees opportunity in the country's shifting political landscape, aligning himself with rising nationalist forces that demand a scapegoat.

At the center of their fates stands an transgender aspiring actress whose testimony could prove innocence—but speaking truth means sacrificing her own carefully constructed future. As accusations fly and public outrage mounts, each character faces impossible choices between self-preservation and moral courage.

Majumdar crafts a sharp examination of how ambition and survival instincts collide with justice in a society where economic mobility remains elusive and political tensions run deep. The novel reveals how quickly individual lives can become pawns in larger cultural conflicts, and how the pursuit of betterment often comes at devastating personal costs.
short_summary: Three unforgettable characters seek to rise in contemporary India—to the middle class, to political power, to fame in the movies—and find their lives entangled in the wake of catastrophe.
author_bios: Megha Majumdar wrote the New York Times bestselling novel A Burning, which received nominations for the National Book Award, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the American Library Association's Andrew Carnegie Medal. Her work earned recognition from The Washington Post, The New York Times, NPR, The Atlantic, Vogue, and TIME Magazine as one of the year's finest books. Born in Kolkata, India, Majumdar earned degrees from Harvard and Johns Hopkins and received the 2022 Whiting Award. She currently resides in New York.
quotes:
"Powerful... propulsive...This is a book to relish for its details, for the caress of the writer's gaze against the world... The interplay of choice and circumstance has always been the playing field of great fiction, and on this terrain, a powerful new writer stakes her claim."

—Parul Sehgal, The New York Times

"Majumdar demonstrates an uncanny ability to capture the vast scope of a tumultuous society by attending to the hopes and fears of people living on the margins. The effect is transporting."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Precise, human and powerful. You can feel these big intersecting currents of history, progress and technology pulling these three characters in, crushing one of them and propelling the others to great heights. It's a really tight read. I read it in one sitting."

—The Guardian

title: Circe
long_summary:
Born into divine royalty yet lacking the imposing presence of her Titan lineage, Circe finds herself an outsider in the celestial hierarchy. Her discovery of magical abilities marks the beginning of a dangerous awakening that threatens the established order of immortal power.

Exiled to an isolated isle, she must forge her own destiny among mythological legends and mortal heroes. Her solitary existence becomes a crucible for transformation as she navigates encounters with creatures of legend and faces the consequences of wielding forbidden arts.

The novel examines themes of belonging and identity through Circe's struggle between two worlds—the realm of her divine heritage and the mortal sphere that increasingly captures her loyalty. As external threats mount and ancient grudges surface, she confronts an impossible choice that will determine not only her fate but the survival of those she cherishes. Miller crafts a narrative that questions the nature of power, the price of independence, and the courage required to forge one's own path when caught between competing loyalties.
short_summary: Miller transforms the witch Circe from Homer's footnote into a fully realized heroine. An exile's journey of self-discovery unfolds through encounters with gods, monsters, and mortals in this luminous reimagining of Greek mythology.
author_bios: Madeline Miller has achieved remarkable success with her mythological retellings, including the chart-topping The Song of Achilles, which earned the Orange Women's Prize for Fiction 2012, and Circe, which received a Women's Prize for Fiction 2019 shortlisting. Her novels have reached global audiences through translations into more than thirty-two languages. Miller brings scholarly expertise to her fiction, having earned an MA in Classics from Brown University and spent over a decade teaching Latin, Greek, and Shakespeare.
quotes:
"A retelling of ancient Greek lore gives exhilarating voice to a witch... [Circe is] a sly, petulant, and finally commanding voice that narrates the entirety of Miller's dazzling second novel....Readers will relish following the puzzle of this unpromising daughter of the sun god Helios and his wife, Perse, who had negligible use for their child....Expect Miller's readership to mushroom like one of Circe's spells. Miller makes Homer pertinent to women facing 21st-century monsters."

—Kirkus

"Circe,' [is] a bold and subversive retelling of the goddess's story that manages to be both epic and intimate in its scope, recasting the most infamous female figure from the Odyssey as a hero in her own right."

—Alexandra Alter, The New York Times

"One of the most amazing qualities of this novel [is]: We know how everything here turns out - we've known it for thousands of years - and yet in Miller's lush reimagining, the story feels harrowing and unexpected. The feminist light she shines on these events never distorts their original shape; it only illuminates details we hadn't noticed before."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Bone Clocks
long_summary:
Fifteen-year-old Holly Sykes storms out after a family argument, but this isn't an ordinary teenage rebellion. Holly has always been different—she hears voices others can't, experiences visions that blur the line between reality and something far more mysterious. Her angry departure from home sets in motion events that will haunt her for decades.

Holly's psychic sensitivity draws her into an ancient conflict between opposing mystical factions, transforming what should have been a brief escape into something that permanently alters her family's fate. The reverberations of this encounter will follow Holly through every stage of her life, connecting her story to seemingly unrelated characters: an ambitious Cambridge student chasing success, a war correspondent finding purpose in dangerous places, and a novelist grappling with fading relevance.

Mitchell constructs an intricate narrative that spans continents and centuries, from alpine peaks to Australian wilderness, from bustling Shanghai to future New York. These disparate lives intersect in unexpected ways, revealing how the supernatural infiltrates the mundane world. The result is a genre-defying exploration of how a single weekend can echo across a lifetime, binding strangers together through forces beyond their understanding.
short_summary: Holly Sykes's teenage rebellion becomes something far stranger when she attracts the attention of warring mystical forces. Mitchell weaves decades and genres together in this ambitious tale of ordinary lives touched by magic.
author_bios: David Mitchell has written seven novels including Ghostwritten, number9dream, Cloud Atlas, Black Swan Green, The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet, The Bone Clocks, and Slade House. He received the Sunday Times Award for Literary Excellence in 2018 and has been shortlisted for the Booker Prize twice.
quotes:
"One of the most entertaining and thrilling novels I've read in a long time."

—Meg Wolitzer, NPR

"Dazzling . . . Mitchell's heavy arsenal of talents is showcased in these pages: his symphonic imagination; his ventriloquist's ability to channel the voices of myriad characters from different time zones and cultures; his intuitive understanding of children and knack for capturing their solemnity and humor; and his ear for language—its rhythms, sounds and inflections."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Relentlessly brilliant . . . [The Bone Clocks contains] depth and darkness, bravely concealed with all the wit and sleight of hand and ventriloquistic verbiage and tale-telling bravura of which Mitchell is a master."

—Ursula K. Le Guin, The Guardian

title: The Marriage Portrait
long_summary:
In Renaissance Florence, sixteen-year-old Lucrezia de' Medici lives contentedly in the shadows of her family's grand palazzo, pursuing her artistic interests while observing the intricate politics around her. Her quiet existence shatters when tragedy strikes: her elder sister's sudden death forces Lucrezia into an arranged marriage with Alfonso, the Duke of Ferrara.

Transported to an alien court where every gesture carries weight and enemies lurk behind courtly smiles, Lucrezia must navigate a world that views her primarily as a vessel for producing heirs. Her enigmatic husband presents a puzzle—by turns charming and calculating, artistic and autocratic. As she poses for a portrait meant to immortalize her position, Lucrezia grapples with the suffocating expectations of her role.

The pressure to secure the dynasty's future through childbearing becomes her defining challenge, while the young duchess searches for ways to claim agency in a life that seems entirely prescribed by others. O'Farrell illuminates the precarious existence of Renaissance women, even those born to privilege, creating a vivid meditation on identity, power, and the cost of survival in a world where women's value is measured by their fertility.
short_summary: When her sister dies suddenly, sixteen-year-old Lucrezia de' Medici must take her place as a political bride in the treacherous court of Ferrara. O'Farrell transforms history into luminous fiction.
author_bios: Born in Northern Ireland in 1972, Maggie O'Farrell has established herself as one of contemporary literature's most compelling voices. Her body of work includes the National Book Critics Circle Award-winning Hamnet, along with After You'd Gone, The Vanishing Act of Esme Lennox, Instructions for a Heatwave, and The Hand That First Held Mine, which earned the Costa Novel Award. O'Farrell also penned the memoir I Am, I Am, I Am: Seventeen Brushes with Death. She currently resides in Edinburgh.
quotes:
"Finely detailed. . . . This beguiling tale of power, politics and one woman's fight for agency is yet another masterpiece by the author of Hamnet."

—The Globe and Mail

"I could not stop reading this incredible true story."

—Reese Witherspoon

"Lush, provocative . . . A captivating portrait of a woman attempting to free herself from a golden cage. Fans of the accomplished Hamnet won't be disappointed by this formidable outing."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Need
long_summary:
Sleep-deprived and isolated, Molly dismisses the sounds echoing through her house as products of maternal anxiety. Every parent knows this territory—the hypervigilance, the catastrophic thinking, the way exhaustion plays tricks on the mind. But dismissal becomes impossible once she realizes someone has invaded her home, someone who possesses intimate knowledge of her family's private world.

Faced with this violation, Molly discovers that protecting her children demands confronting uncomfortable truths about herself and her limitations as both guardian and human being. The crisis pushes her consciousness into uncharted psychological terrain, where the contradictions of raising children—joy shadowed by terror, tenderness coupled with rage, mundane routines punctuated by profound revelation—merge into something approaching the surreal. Phillips crafts a narrative that uses the primal fears of parenthood as a gateway to larger questions about reality, identity, and the strange intensity of caring for small humans in an uncertain world.
short_summary: Domestic anxiety spirals into existential terror when a mother confronts an intruder who knows too much about her family. Phillips transforms the fierce delirium of parenthood into speculative horror.
author_bios: Helen Phillips has written six books, with her latest novel being Hum. The Need earned her a National Book Award nomination and recognition as a New York Times Notable Book. Phillips received both a Guggenheim Fellowship and a Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award for her literary work. Her collection Some Possible Solutions won the John Gardner Fiction Book Award, while The Beautiful Bureaucrat reached the finalist round for both the New York Public Library's Young Lions Fiction Award and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize. She currently teaches at Brooklyn College and makes her home in Brooklyn alongside artist/cartoonist Adam Douglas Thompson and their children.
quotes:
"Helen Phillips has created an existential page-turner that captures, with perfect sharpness, the fierce delirium of motherhood, the longing to understand the workings of our universe, and the wondrous and terrifying mystery that is time. The Need is a brain-bending heartbreaker of a novel, and definitive proof that Helen Phillips is one of the most spellbindingly original writers working today."

—Laura Van Den Berg, Author of State of Paradise & The Third Hotel

"I'm a big fan of Helen Phillips, and she has a dark, maternal horror story called The Need that I know is going to be brilliant."

—Karen Russell, Esquire

"The Need is a profound meditation on the nature of reality, a fearless examination of parenthood, and also somehow a thriller. This is an extraordinary and dazzlingly original work from one of our most gifted and interesting writers."

—Emily St. John Mandel, Author of Station Eleven

title: Where'd You Go, Bernadette?
long_summary:
An eccentric architect's life spirals into chaos as her social anxieties transform into complete withdrawal from the world. Once celebrated for her innovative designs, she now relies on a remote assistant to handle even the simplest tasks while her family navigates the fallout of her increasingly erratic behavior.

Everything reaches a breaking point during preparations for an ambitious family vacation. Her brilliant teenage daughter finds herself caught between loyalty to her unconventional mother and the growing concern of those around them. Through a clever mosaic of digital communications, official records, and private exchanges, the story unfolds as a detective tale of sorts—one where love, creativity, and mental health collide in unexpected ways.

This inventive narrative examines how genius can become its own prison, and how the people we think we know best can surprise us. It's a story about the complexity of family relationships, the price of artistic vision, and the lengths we'll go to understand the ones we love, even when they seem determined to disappear entirely.
short_summary: When an agoraphobic architect mysteriously disappears, her teenage daughter pieces together the truth through emails and documents. Hilarious and heartfelt, with characters so vivid they leap off the page.
author_bios: Maria Semple has written three novels: Today Will Be Different, Where'd You Go, Bernadette, and This One Is Mine, with her books reaching readers in forty different languages worldwide. She transitioned to fiction writing after working in television, and currently makes her home in New York.
quotes:
"The characters in Where'd You Go, Bernadette may be in real emotional pain, but Semple has the wit and perspective and imagination to make their story hilarious. I tore through this book with heedless pleasure."

—Jonathan Franzen, author of Crossroads & Freedom

"Where'd You Go, Bernadette is fresh and funny and accomplished, but the best thing about it was that I never had any idea what was going to happen next. It was a wild ride..."

—Kate Atkinson, author of Life After Life, Shrines of Gaiety, Case Histories & Started Early, Took My Dog

"One of the big burst-of-oxygen books this year.... clever and inventive but also genuine and heartfelt."

—Gillian Flynn, The New York Times

title: Razorblade Tears
long_summary:
Two fathers receive the worst news imaginable: their sons have been killed together in a brutal crime. Ike Randolph, a Black man who's spent fifteen years building a clean life after prison, struggles with the complicated grief of losing a son he never fully accepted. Buddy Lee Jenkins, a white ex-convict, faces his own reckoning with years of estrangement and shame.

Their sons' marriage had been a bridge neither father could cross—Ike couldn't bring himself to attend the wedding, while Buddy Lee had cut contact entirely. Now, united by loss and fury, these unlikely allies must navigate their own deep-seated prejudices while pursuing those responsible for the murders.

As they dig deeper into the investigation the police seem reluctant to pursue, both men confront uncomfortable truths about themselves and the sons they failed to understand. Their hunt for justice becomes a reckoning with their own limitations as fathers, forcing them to examine whether love can transcend the barriers they've built around their hearts.
short_summary: Two ex-con fathers—one Black, one white—unite to hunt down their murdered gay sons' killers. A searing exploration of grief, prejudice, and redemption wrapped in a relentless thriller.
author_bios: S. A. Cosby writes crime fiction from Southeastern Virginia, where he won the Anthony Award for his work. His novels include the New York Times bestsellers All the Sinners Bleed and Razorblade Tears, along with Blacktop Wasteland, which earned the Los Angeles Times Book Prize and recognition from NPR, The Guardian, and Library Journal as a best book of the year. Outside of writing, Cosby enjoys hiking and playing chess.
quotes:
"High-octane neo-noir thriller…The gritty, brutal narrative is complemented by the author's sublime use of sensory description and regional imagery. In addition, the epic, jaw-dropping chase sequences that figure prominently are reason alone to read this pedal-to-the-metal but profoundly sorrowful novel. Cosby is definitely a writer to watch."

—Publishers Weekly

"Sensationally good—new, fresh, real, authentic, twisty, with characters and dilemmas that will break your heart. More than recommended."

—Lee Child

"Blacktop Wasteland is an urgent, timely, pitch-perfect jolt of American noir. S. A. Cosby is a welcome, refreshing new voice in crime literature."

—Dennis Lehane, bestselling author of Since We Fell and Mystic River

title: King of Ashes
long_summary:
The Carruthers family business deals in death, but they never expected it to come knocking at their own door. Roman returns to Jefferson Run, Virginia, to find his father clinging to life after what appears to be a targeted attack, his brother drowning in gambling debts to the wrong people, and his sister struggling to keep their crematorium afloat.

Roman's expertise lies in making money for wealthy clients, not navigating the brutal world of organized crime. Yet as threats escalate and his family's safety hangs in the balance, he discovers that his financial acumen might be exactly what these dangerous men need. The price of his brother's freedom becomes Roman's servitude—but he underestimates just how far he's willing to go.

Meanwhile, the mystery of their mother's long-ago disappearance resurfaces, adding another layer of secrets to an already volatile situation. In a town where the Carruthers family has witnessed countless final moments, Roman must confront whether he's prepared to cross lines he never imagined crossing. The crematorium that has been their livelihood may become the key to their survival—or their destruction.
short_summary: Three siblings inherit violence along with their family crematorium when a father's accident proves no accident at all. Cosby delivers a brutal family saga where loyalty demands the ultimate price.
author_bios: S. A. Cosby writes crime fiction from Southeastern Virginia, where he has earned recognition as an Anthony Award winner. His novels include the New York Times bestsellers All the Sinners Bleed and Razorblade Tears, along with Blacktop Wasteland, which received the Los Angeles Times Book Prize and appeared on best-of-the-year lists from NPR, The Guardian, and Library Journal. Outside of writing, Cosby enjoys hiking and playing chess.
quotes:
"Dark, riveting, and accomplished. . . Cosby has built an impressive reputation for creating brutal, fast-paced novels in which bad things happen to just about everybody."

—Washington Post

"Restraint is not a hallmark of S.A. Cosby's crime fiction. His writing is rough, raw and violent. . . Cosby invests the classic noir plot of the ordinary man pulled into a nightmare with emotional depth. . . I warn you, that crematory gets put to use — a lot — but King of Ashes is so ingenious neither grit nor gore could make me stop reading it."

—NPR

"Cosby keeps things tense, making great use of the crematorium and freshening the genre with lofty philosophizing. . . Rarely has a crime fiction family been given a more bitter spin than this one. Another strong outing by a modern noir master."

—Kirkus

title: Wild Dark Shore
long_summary:
Climate change has pushed the Salt family to the edge of the world—literally. Father Dominic and his three children find themselves among the last people on Shearwater, an isolated Antarctic outpost that protects humanity's most crucial backup plan: a vast collection of seeds from across the globe.

Each family member carries their own wounds. Teenage Raff channels his pain into violent exercise, while his sister Fen seeks solace sleeping beside wild seals on the shoreline. Nine-year-old Orly clings desperately to the only home he's known, terrified of leaving behind the creatures and landscapes he loves. Their father Dominic struggles under the weight of whatever tragedy originally drove them to this desolate sanctuary.

Their fragile routine shatters when a fierce Antarctic storm delivers an unexpected visitor: Rowan, a woman with her own hidden agenda. As she recovers in their care, the Salts begin to rediscover what it means to trust and care for someone new. But Rowan's arrival coincides with disturbing discoveries—damaged equipment, fresh graves, and growing evidence that not everything about their situation is what it seems.

With evacuation looming and storms closing in, this makeshift family must navigate questions of loyalty, survival, and whether redemption is possible even at the ends of the earth.
short_summary: The last family on a remote Antarctic island nursing the world's seed bank back to health encounters a mysterious woman washed ashore during a devastating storm. Secrets, survival, and second chances collide.
author_bios: Charlotte McConaghy has written three acclaimed novels—Migrations, Once There Were Wolves, and Wild Dark Shore—with her work reaching international audiences through translations into over thirty languages. Her debut became a New York Times bestseller, establishing her as a distinctive voice in contemporary fiction. McConaghy lives and writes in Sydney, Australia.
quotes:
"A breathtaking novel of romance, mystery, and twists that will shock you...I love this book so much."

—Reese Witherspoon

"Spellbinding…Captivating…McConaghy keeps the novel moving at a blustery pace, thanks to her deft plotting and shared point of view…To read this exceptionally imagined, thoroughly humane novel feels like following the last people on Earth as they prepare to leave some part of their souls to the most beautiful place they'll ever know."

—Washington Post

"Urgent…McConaghy ratchets up the tension as the characters' paranoia and mutual suspicion increases and their motives are revealed…McConaghy blends entertainment with a sobering message about conservation and the impacts of geographic isolation."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Our Missing Hearts
long_summary:
Bird Gardner's world shifted forever three years ago when his mother Margaret disappeared, leaving behind only banned poetry and unanswered questions. Now twelve, Bird navigates life with his father—a man who once studied language but now quietly arranges books on library shelves, keeping his head down in a society that has grown suspicious of dissent.

A strange letter arrives containing nothing but an enigmatic sketch, setting Bird on an unexpected path toward answers. His search weaves through childhood memories of his mother's stories, connects him with a clandestine community of librarians protecting forbidden knowledge, and ultimately leads him to New York City where long-buried truths await.

This novel examines how fear can transform ordinary communities into places where injustice flourishes unchallenged. Through Bird's journey, it questions what we teach the next generation about courage, identity, and belonging, while celebrating art's enduring ability to inspire resistance and hope even in the darkest times.
short_summary: When twelve-year-old Bird receives a cryptic drawing, he embarks on a quest to find his missing mother—a poet whose banned books made her an enemy of the state. A haunting tale of family, resistance, and art's power to survive oppression.
author_bios: Celeste Ng has written three novels that became New York Times bestsellers: Everything I Never Told You, Little Fires Everywhere, and Our Missing Hearts. Her writing has earned recognition from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation through prestigious fellowships. Readers worldwide have embraced her work, with translations available in more than thirty languages.
quotes:
"Thought-provoking, heart-wrenching . . . It follows the story of a young boy named Bird on the search for his mother Margaret, a poet whose work was deemed unpatriotic. I was so invested in the future of this mother and son, and I can't wait to hear what you think of this deeply suspenseful story!"

—Reese Witherspoon

"Sensitive, nuanced, and vividly drawn . . . Thoroughly engrossing and deeply moving . . . Taut and terrifying, Ng's cautionary tale transports us into an American tomorrow that is all too easy to imagine."

—Kirkus

"Remarkable . . . Ng crafts an affecting family drama out of the chilling and charged atmosphere, and shines especially when offering testimony to the power of art and storytelling . . . Ng's latest crackles and sizzles all the way to the end."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Lincoln Highway
long_summary:
Emmett Watson emerges from juvenile detention with a simple goal: retrieve his younger brother Billy and escape to California. Their Nebraska home is gone, their father dead, and a new life beckons on the West Coast. But two fellow inmates have different ideas, hijacking Emmett's carefully laid plans and steering the brothers toward New York instead.

What unfolds over ten tumultuous days challenges everything these young men thought they knew about destiny and choice. Each carries his own vision of the future, his own understanding of the past, and his own reasons for the decisions that follow. The road ahead becomes a proving ground where friendship and betrayal walk hand in hand, where the weight of consequences threatens to crush teenage dreams.

This is America in the 1950s, captured through the eyes of four boys whose lives intersect in ways none of them anticipated. Their stories reveal how the paths we choose—and those chosen for us—shape who we become. Sometimes the most important journeys are the ones that force us to confront not where we're going, but who we really are.
short_summary: Four young men embark on an unexpected cross-country journey in 1950s America. What begins as one boy's plan for a fresh start becomes something far more complex and fateful.
author_bios: Amor Towles has written three New York Times bestsellers: Rules of Civility, A Gentleman in Moscow, and The Lincoln Highway. His books have reached millions of readers worldwide and been translated into more than thirty-five languages. He makes his home in Manhattan with his wife and two children.
quotes:
"[A] mischievous, wise and wildly entertaining novel . . . Towles goes all in on the kind of episodic, exuberant narrative haywire found in myth or Homeric epic . . . Each [character], Towles implies, is the central protagonist of an ongoing adventure that is both unique and universal . . . remarkably buoyant . . . permeated with light, wit, youth . . . Towles has snipped off a minuscule strand of existence—10 wayward days—and when we look through his lens we see that this brief interstice teems with stories, grand as legends."

—Chris Bachelder, The New York Times

"Not only is it one of the most beautifully written books I have ever picked up, it's a story about hope, friendship and companionship in a time when we need it so much . . . Towles brilliantly captures the inner reality of each [character] with profound and poetic prose. All eight of them are incredible forces in literature . . . Amor Towles is one of those authors that I think will become a Steinbeck of our generation and [...] I think The Lincoln Highway will be a classic that we will read for years to come."

—Jenna Bush Hager, Read With Jenna book club

"Welcome to the enormous pleasure that is The Lincoln Highway, a big book of camaraderie and adventure in which the miles fly by and the pages turn fast.  Set over the course of ten riveting days, the story of these four boys unfolds, refolds, tears, and is taped back together.  When you aren't actually reading the book, you'll be worrying about the characters, so you might as well stay in your chair and keep reading."

—Ann Patchett, author of The Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

title: Dream Count
long_summary:
Four women's lives intersect across borders and decades in this intimate examination of modern womanhood. A travel writer reflects on romantic missteps during isolation. Her accomplished friend confronts devastating betrayal that shatters her carefully constructed success. A cousin commanding Nigeria's financial world discovers unsettling truths about her own identity. A dedicated mother working in domestic service watches her American dream crumble under impossible circumstances.

Adichie crafts a mosaic of female experience that spans continents and social classes, revealing how women navigate the treacherous terrain between ambition and vulnerability. Each character grapples with the weight of expectations—cultural, personal, and professional—while searching for authentic connection in a world that often demands they choose between different versions of themselves. The novel interrogates what it means to love and be loved when geography, class, and circumstance create both bridges and barriers between people who need each other most.
short_summary: Four women navigate love, betrayal, and self-discovery across continents. Adichie's latest is an intimate masterpiece about the choices that define us and the connections that sustain us.
author_bios: Born and raised in Nigeria, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie has become one of contemporary literature's most vital voices, with her books translated into over fifty-five languages. Her novels include Purple Hibiscus, winner of the Commonwealth Writers' Prize, and Half of a Yellow Sun, which received the Women's Prize for Fiction "Best of the Best" award. She also wrote Americanah, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award, along with The Thing Around Your Neck, We Should All Be Feminists, Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions, Notes on Grief, and Mama's Sleeping Scarf. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, she splits her time between Nigeria and the United States.
quotes:
"Adichie weaves stories of heartbreak and travail that are timely, touching, and trenchant."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Adichie riffs brilliantly on what feminism means to her characters and renders each woman's story in a distinctive voice . . . . This is well worth the wait."

—Publishers Weekly

"Every aspect of this transfixing, intimate, and astute group portrait is ablaze with scorching insights into the maddening absurdities and injustices that continue to plague women's lives . . . . Adichie's magnificently vital, sharply forthright novel will be one of the year's most sought after and resounding titles."

—Booklist

title: Yonder
long_summary:
At Placid Hall plantation, bonds of friendship and love become acts of resistance against a system designed to destroy them. Cato carries the pain of losing Iris to sale, while William discovers unexpected tenderness with Margaret, whose strength matches his own quiet determination. Together with Little Zander, the artistic Milton, and beautiful Pandora, they create a family from shared suffering and hope.

Their fragile world shifts when a preacher arrives with dangerous talk of choice—the radical notion that they might decide their own fates. His words plant seeds of possibility that threaten to uproot everything they've built together. As dreams of freedom clash with the safety of familiar bonds, each member of their chosen family must weigh the cost of liberation against the relationships that have sustained them.

Jabari Asim crafts an intimate portrait of humanity flourishing in the face of dehumanization, examining how love persists even when the world denies its existence. This is a story that asks whether the promise of freedom is worth risking the connections that make survival possible.
short_summary: Enslaved at Placid Hall plantation, Cato and William navigate love, friendship, and survival under their captor's brutal whims. When a mysterious minister speaks of freedom, their tight-knit community faces an impossible choice.
author_bios: Jabari Asim serves as the Elma Lewis Distinguished Fellow in Social Justice and leads the MFA creative writing program at Emerson College. He has written nonfiction works including The N Word, What Obama Means, and We Can't Breathe, along with the children's book Preaching to the Chickens: The Story of Young John Lewis. His fiction includes A Taste of Honey and Only the Strong.
quotes:
"Asim delivers a fresh, sweeping, must-read tale."

—The New York Times

"I'm a sucker for stories that place love between Black people at the center of settings where, traditionally, Black love was thought impossible or unimaginable. I'm particularly drawn to books that re-examine that dreadful period in American history that we think we already know everything about — antebellum slavery — to reveal the layers, testimonies, and nuances that had previously been ignored. And to have this all drawn magnificently by the brilliant Jabari Asim makes this an absolute must-read for me."

—Robert Jones Jr., Entertainment Weekly

"[M]ajestic…Asim demonstrates all a novel can be: soaring and grounded, personal and epic, thrilling and quiet. A wonder-filled novel about the power of words and stories to bring hope to the most difficult situations."

—Kirkus

title: Sunset Park
long_summary:
Miles Heller spends his days documenting the remnants of foreclosed homes across Florida, capturing through his camera lens the scattered possessions of families torn from their lives by financial ruin. This solitary existence shifts dramatically when he discovers an abandoned building in Brooklyn where a small band of artists and dreamers have carved out an existence on society's margins.

The novel branches outward to illuminate other lives touched by America's economic turmoil: a theater veteran grappling with her comeback, a book publisher watching his world crumble, and the enigmatic Hospital for Broken Things where damaged objects receive careful restoration. These parallel narratives converge to examine how individuals forge meaning from chaos and build community from fragments.

Auster crafts a meditation on resilience that finds profound humanity in ordinary struggles. The characters navigate loss and uncertainty while discovering unexpected sources of grace, whether in makeshift friendships, artistic expression, or simple acts of witness. Their intersecting paths reveal how people adapt and endure, creating new forms of family and purpose when traditional structures fail.
short_summary: Miles Heller photographs abandoned belongings of evicted families until he finds refuge with young squatters in Brooklyn. Auster weaves together displaced lives during the 2008 collapse into a haunting meditation on survival and connection.
author_bios: Paul Auster wrote numerous acclaimed works including 4 3 2 1, Sunset Park, The Book of Illusions, Moon Palace, and The New York Trilogy. His honors included the Prince of Asturias Prize for Literature, Prix Médicis étranger for Leviathan, Independent Spirit Award for the screenplay of Smoke, Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Burning Boy, and Carlos Fuentes Prize for his body of work. His novel 4 3 2 1 received a Man Booker Prize shortlist. Auster held membership in the American Academy of Arts and Letters and earned recognition as Commandeur de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.
quotes:
"With a plot that encompasses war in the Middle East, economic recession and the perils of the publishing industry, a contemporary vitality distinguishes the latest from the veteran author…. Sure to please Auster fans and likely to attract new readers as well."

—Kirkus

"Passionately literary… every element is saturated with implication as each wounded, questing character's story illuminates our tragic flaws and profound need for connection, coherence, and beauty. In a time of daunting crises and change, Auster reminds us of lasting things, of love, art, and 'the miraculous strangeness of being alive.'"

—Donna Seaman, Booklist

"Auster deftly balances minute details that evoke New York City, post-financial meltdown, with marvelously drawn characters bruised but unbowed by life's vicissitudes. He has an impressive array of literary nominations to his credit, but this should be the novel that brings him a broader readership."

—Sally Bissell, Library Journal

title: The Last Animal
long_summary:
What begins as reluctant teenage accompaniment on a mother's research trip transforms into something far more extraordinary. Sisters Eve and Vera find themselves thrust into the world of Arctic science, where restless curiosity leads to an astonishing find: a millennia-old mammoth preserved in ice.

This chance discovery becomes the catalyst for an unexpected odyssey across continents, from frozen tundra to Mediterranean shores. The novel traces how scientific wonder intersects with family dynamics, examining the complex relationships between mothers and daughters against the backdrop of environmental change.

Ausubel crafts a story that balances adventure with intimate family portrait, questioning how we connect with both ancient history and uncertain futures. The narrative explores themes of female ambition in male-dominated spaces while celebrating the unpredictable bonds that hold families together through transformation and discovery.
short_summary: Two teenage sisters accidentally discover a frozen mammoth while tagging along on their mother's Arctic research expedition. What starts as summer boredom becomes a globe-hopping adventure that transforms their understanding of family, science, and second chances.
author_bios: Ramona Ausubel has written two novels and two story collections, including Awayland and Sons and Daughters of Ease and Plenty. Her fiction has earned recognition through the PEN Center USA Literary Award for Fiction and the VCU Cabell First Novelist Award, and she received a long-listing for the Story Prize. Publications featuring her writing include The New Yorker, The New York Times, and NPR's Selected Shorts.
quotes:
"I know it's hard to imagine, but The Last Animal by Ramona Ausubel, is like a sweeter, more poignant version of 'Jurassic Park. . .' This shaggy elephant story is as much about surviving family grief as it is about living in a world doomed by climate change. And yet, The Last Animal takes flight with all the improbable buoyancy of a pterodactyl."

—Ron Charles, CBS

"Every family, after all, goes extinct eventually. The paradox that this novel confronts with such tender sympathy and humor is how to love the time we have left."

—The Washington Post

"This extraordinary story hops the globe, combining wild adventures aimed at reversing climate change with a fullhearted portrait of sisterhood, family and the ways we process grief. Charming, wry and original."

—People

title: Dayswork
long_summary:
Isolation breeds unexpected fixations. Confined during quarantine, a woman finds herself drawn into the world of Herman Melville—not just his famous whale tale, but the messy realities of his domestic life. She traces his impulsive real estate decisions, his creative struggles at his Massachusetts farm, his complicated friendship with Hawthorne, and the strain his artistic dedication placed on his marriage.

What begins as literary curiosity evolves into something more consuming. Her research expands to encompass other writers and biographers, including Elizabeth Hardwick and Robert Lowell, whose personal sacrifices for art mirror Melville's own. Through these literary lives, she begins examining the uncomfortable questions about creativity, commitment, and compromise that thread through her own existence.

This meditation on artistic obsession becomes unexpectedly personal, forcing her to confront the tensions within her own marriage and the true cost of creative ambition. The novel explores how we seek understanding through the lives of others, and how the stories we tell about writers reveal as much about ourselves as about them.
short_summary: During quarantine, a woman's obsession with Herman Melville's life becomes a reckoning with her own marriage and ambition. A startlingly original, incantatory novel about marriage, mortality, and making art.
author_bios: Chris Bachelder has written four novels, with The Throwback Special earning him National Book Award recognition. Jennifer Habel published the poetry collections Good Reason and The Book of Jane, the latter receiving the Iowa Poetry Prize. Both authors make their home in Cincinnati, Ohio.
quotes:
"A love letter to literature."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write an Autobiographical Novel

"Dayswork is a wonder. I cannot think of another book, another reading experience, entirely like this one. It is suffused with the pleasures of reading, of immersion, of companionship in all its forms."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies

"I was equally charmed and fascinated by Dayswork, this slender but capacious book about marriage and solitude, about Melville and Hawthorne, about literature and obsession and whether they might not be the same thing. Wry, intimate, and wholly original, the novel surprised me and edified me with every page I eagerly turned."

—Jess Walter, author of Beautiful Ruins

title: Old God's Time
long_summary:
Tom Kettle thought retirement would bring peace. Living in sparse quarters attached to a crumbling castle by the sea, he has crafted a solitary existence where days pass without human contact. The isolation suits him—or so he believes. His thoughts drift between the present quiet and fragments of his former life: images of his wife June, their children Winnie and Joe, the weight of years spent in police work.

This fragile equilibrium shatters when two detectives arrive, reopening a case that has festered in Tom's memory for decades. What begins as routine questioning evolves into something more unsettling, forcing Tom to confront not just the unresolved investigation, but the deeper mysteries of loss, memory, and survival.

Barry crafts a meditation on how the past refuses to stay buried, examining the stories we tell ourselves and the truths we cannot escape. The novel moves between what Tom remembers and what he has forgotten, between the official version of events and the emotional reality beneath. In this liminal space—between retirement and reckoning, between solitude and connection—Tom must navigate the treacherous territory of his own history.
short_summary: Retired policeman Tom Kettle seeks solitude by the Irish Sea, haunted by memories of his family. When former colleagues arrive with questions about an old case, his carefully constructed peace unravels into something far more complex.
author_bios: Born in Dublin in 1955, Sebastian Barry has established himself as one of Ireland's most distinguished literary voices through eight novels and numerous theatrical works. Barry made history as the first novelist to claim the Costa Book of the Year award twice, earning recognition for The Secret Scripture and Days Without End. His novels have garnered multiple Booker Prize shortlistings, including A Long Long Way and The Secret Scripture, with additional longlisting recognition for Days Without End and On Canaan's Side. Barry served as Laureate for Irish Fiction from 2018–2021 and currently resides in County Wicklow, Ireland.
quotes:
"Few contemporary writers have done more with the natural resource of Irish English, or with the buried tensions at the heart of Irish identity, than [Barry] . . . A writer of almost Joycean amplitude, Barry never segregates the comic and the tragic . . . What's striking about Old God's Time is the scrupulous realism that Barry brings to his outlandish premise—and his guileful refusal ever to clarify what kind of novel we are reading . . . Barry's [prose is] casually exquisite."

—Giles Harvey, The New Yorker

"Marvelous . . . Barry reaches deep into the messenger bag of mystery fiction and turns the whole business inside out to show the soft suede of its lining and the loosening stitches of the seams . . . The story plays out in ways that repeatedly surprise, but its twists and turns are less important than its steady emotional beats, which elegantly braid the long work of mourning to the mere fact of love. As always, Barry is a prose stylist of near-miraculous skill, turning out crystalline sentence after crystalline sentence without ever leaving or betraying his protagonist's perspective. His is an aphoristic imagination, and almost every chapter ends with a revelatory pirouette."

—The Washington Post

"Few can write like Sebastian Barry, there is a real thrill as each sentence unfolds. Old God's Time is a portrait of a good man facing the failings of his past. It is wonderfully alive because Barry is so attuned to the human condition, to the poetry in ordinary lives. Full of love and grief and heartache, this is an unforgettable novel from one of our finest writers."

—Douglas Stuart, author of Shuggie Bain & Young Mungo

title: Witness
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Across ten interconnected tales, families navigate the shifting landscape of modern New York, where the act of truly seeing becomes both burden and necessity. Characters find themselves caught between the urge to speak truth and the comfort of silence, discovering that the choice to acknowledge what unfolds before them carries unexpected consequences.

Brinkley examines how ordinary people—children observing adult failures, elders carrying decades of secrets, friends testing the boundaries of loyalty—wrestle with their roles as witnesses to each other's lives. The city itself becomes a character, its constant transformation mirroring the internal changes of those who call it home.

These stories reveal how individual choices ripple through generations, creating patterns of connection and disconnection that define both personal relationships and community bonds. In moments of crisis and revelation, characters must decide whether to look away or lean in, whether to protect themselves or extend toward others despite the risk of disappointment or harm.
short_summary: Ten stories explore the moral weight of witnessing in contemporary New York. Brinkley's characters struggle with loyalty and vulnerability as their city transforms around them, finding grace in small moments.
author_bios: Jamel Brinkley wrote A Lucky Man: Stories, which earned the Ernest J. Gaines Award for Literary Excellence and received finalist recognition for the National Book Award, the PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction, the Story Prize, the John Leonard Prize, and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award. His honors include an O. Henry Prize, the Rome Prize, a Wallace Stegner Fellowship, and a Lannan Foundation Fellowship. His fiction has been published in The Paris Review, A Public Space, Ploughshares, and The Best American Short Stories. A native of the Bronx and Brooklyn, Brinkley now teaches at the Iowa Writers' Workshop.
quotes:
"Jamel Brinkley is one of the best story writers we have. Witness is a book of psychological acuity, of graceful sentences, of devastation and heart. Read everything this man writes—and know the world anew."

—Justin Torres, author of Blackouts & We The Animals

"Short stories that in their depth of feeling, perception, and sense of place affirm their author's bright promise . . . [They] carry a rich veneer worthy of such exemplars of the form as Chekhov, Eudora Welty, Alice Munro, and James Alan McPherson . . . After just two collections, Brinkley may already be a grand master of the short story."

—Kirkus

"Jamel Brinkley reminds one of the iconic short-story writers Edward P. Jones and Mavis Gallant. This is a dazzling collection by a masterful storyteller."

—Yiyun Li, author of The Book of Goose & Wednesday's Child

title: Skinship
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In these interconnected stories, Korean American families grapple with secrets that threaten to unravel carefully constructed lives. An elderly couple faces an unexpected reckoning during a religious revival. A mother struggles to bridge the gulf between herself and the child she once concealed. Well-intentioned acts spiral into devastating consequences, forcing family members to confront uncomfortable truths.

Yoon Choi illuminates the complex terrain where immigrant parents and their American-born children attempt to understand one another across cultural and linguistic divides. Her characters navigate the delicate balance between preserving tradition and embracing change, often discovering that the people closest to them remain mysteriously unknowable.

These stories reveal how families carry both visible and invisible wounds across generations, examining the ways love can simultaneously heal and harm. Choi captures the particular loneliness of living between two worlds while questioning whether true intimacy is ever fully achievable, even within our most cherished relationships.
short_summary: Korean American families navigate the tender distances between generations, languages, and heartbreak. Choi's debut collection finds profound humanity in the spaces where love and disappointment intersect.
author_bios: Born in Korea and raised in America from age three, Yoon Choi earned her MA from Johns Hopkins University and completed a Stegner Fellowship at Stanford University. Her fiction and essays have been featured in New England Review, Michigan Quarterly Review, Narrative Magazine, and The Best American Short Stories 2018. Yoon Choi currently resides in Anaheim, California, with her husband and four children.
quotes:
"To encounter these achingly truthful, beautiful stories of newcomer Americans is like gazing up at the starry vault of a perfect night sky; it's immediately dazzling and impressive, and yet the closer and deeper you look, the more you appreciate the sheer countless brilliance of Yoon Choi's observations of love and devotion and sacrifice. Here is a writer who roots you and unsettles you and then roots you again in a new and revelatory axis."

—Chang-rae Lee

"Extraordinary...Magical...Reading Choi's stories reminds me of how I felt when I first read the works of other singular sensations like Kevin Wilson or Karen Russell, writers who do things with language and storytelling that no one else has quite done before...It's Choi's approach, the way her stories unexpectedly splinter out from a single life to touch upon decades of family history shaped by immigration, that makes them something special...All these stories are standouts, but the title story is in a class of its own."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"Beautiful...A rich and engaging new voice...With refreshing amplitude, patience, and (dare I say) wisdom, Choi's stories explore the complexities of her characters' diverse experiences."

—Claire Messud, Harper's Magazine

title: Day
long_summary:
A Brooklyn brownstone becomes the stage for examining how families bend and sometimes break under pressure. At the story's heart lies a marriage in quiet crisis—Dan and Isabel navigate their complicated feelings not just for each other, but for Isabel's charismatic brother Robbie, whose presence both binds and destabilizes their household.

Cunningham structures his narrative around three April days across consecutive years, each revealing new fractures and attempted repairs. The first finds the family at a crossroads as Robbie prepares to leave their shared home. The second traps them in pandemic isolation, where proximity breeds both protection and claustrophobia—young Violet becomes a guardian of windows and safety while her brother Nathan pushes against her anxious boundaries. The final snapshot catches them emerging into an uncertain future, forever changed by what they've endured together.

This intimate portrait dissects how ordinary people weather extraordinary circumstances. Through the eyes of both adults grappling with unspoken desires and children trying to make sense of shifting ground beneath them, the novel asks what holds a family together when everything else falls apart. Cunningham transforms a single household into a microcosm of resilience, examining how love persists even as it evolves.
short_summary: Three snapshots of a Brooklyn family across three pivotal years. Cunningham captures the intimate tremors of domestic life with his signature precision and grace.
author_bios: Michael Cunningham has written seven novels, including A Home at the End of the World, Flesh and Blood, The Snow Queen, The Hours, Specimen Days, and By Nightfall. His novel The Hours earned both the PEN/Faulkner Award and the Pulitzer Prize. Cunningham also wrote Land's End: A Walk in Provincetown and currently teaches as a senior lecturer at Yale University while making his home in New York.
quotes:
"Along with George Eliot, Michael Cunningham belongs in that rare group of novelists who hold the world close, with apparently infinite respect, compassion, and tenderness, all while describing the world and its inhabitants unsparingly. Day is a portrait of the life of a family, preceding, during, and immediately after the pandemic, rendered in fragments, almost as if assembling forensic evidence, not of a crime but of quiet tragedies and quiet, heroic endurance. There's deep recognition here, bordering on revelation."

—Tony Kushner

"Michael Cunningham, the perennial master of rendering the quotidian with a profound and deeply considered eye for human frailty, returns with a book that exemplifies the hallmarks of his style: lush, erudite, voracious in its seeking. Like a true poet, he remakes the world in his descriptions, freshened with care and compassion and tinged with the radiant heat of grief. What a quietly stunning achievement."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We Are Briefly Gorgeous

"Michael Cunningham writes such eloquent, seductive sentences that we have to keep reminding ourselves to step back and pay attention to his appealing, dimensional characters and to his generous vision of childhood and adulthood, of work and love, of the pleasures and griefs of family life, and of all the rich complexities of being human."

—Francine Prose

title: Clear
long_summary:
A Scottish minister travels to a remote island carrying out what should be a straightforward task: removing the last resident from land marked for clearance. But fate intervenes when John suffers a serious accident, leaving him dependent on the very man he came to evict. Ivar has spent years in isolation, his world consisting of wind, waves, and wildlife. Their unlikely alliance challenges everything both men thought they understood about duty, survival, and human connection.

Set against the backdrop of 19th-century Highland clearances, this story examines how two people from vastly different worlds navigate the space between them. As John recovers, he discovers that communication transcends spoken language, while Ivar rediscovers what it means to be seen and understood. Davies creates a tale that questions our assumptions about belonging, displacement, and the ties that bind communities together. The novel reveals how historical forces shape individual lives, yet also celebrates the resilience that emerges when people choose compassion over obligation.
short_summary: In 1840s Scotland, a minister sent to evict the last inhabitant of a remote island instead forms a fragile bond with the man he came to displace. Davies crafts a spare, lyrical meditation on language, exile, and unexpected connection.
author_bios: Carys Davies has written the novels West, which received a Rathbones Folio Prize shortlisting and won Wales Book of the Year, and The Mission House, named The Sunday Times 2020 Novel of the Year. Her collection The Redemption of Galen Pike earned both the Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award and the Jerwood Fiction Uncovered Prize. Additional honors include the Royal Society of Literature's V.S. Pritchett Prize, the Society of Authors' Olive Cook Award, and a Cullman Fellowship at the New York Public Library. Welsh-born Davies previously lived in New York and Chicago before making Edinburgh her home.
quotes:
"The sheer beauty of Clear—with its perfect sentences, its austere tenderness, and its quiet sense of disquiet—feels timeless ... A poignant, profound depiction of both solitude and connection. Carys Davies has written a masterful, discreetly sublime book."

—Hernan Diaz, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Trust and In the Distance

"This intriguing and inventive story escorts the reader to an unexpectedly joyous ending that hints at our contemporary interest in new ideas of what a family might be. The writing style is one of clarity and reserved sensibility punctuated with an end-game needle jab. Not to be missed."

—Annie Proulx, author of Barkskins

"Clear is a compact, taut and brilliant novel with an ingenious premise: one man is sent to evict another from his land, but suddenly requires the second man's aid. Everything gets more complicated from there. The book is about belonging, a dying language, secrets, and a pistol in a box. I loved every page."

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See and Cloud Cuckoo Land

title: The Pull of the Stars
long_summary:
Three days in a makeshift maternity ward become a crucible for transformation in this intimate drama set against the chaos of 1918 Dublin. Julia Power, a dedicated nurse, finds her ordered existence upended by the arrival of two women who challenge everything she knows about duty, loyalty, and survival.

As the Spanish flu tears through the city and the Great War rages beyond, these unlikely allies navigate impossible choices while caring for vulnerable mothers and their unborn children. The cramped quarters force them to confront not only the medical crisis at hand, but their own assumptions about courage, sacrifice, and what it truly means to heal.

Donoghue transforms a single hospital room into a universe of human complexity, where political tensions simmer beneath acts of tenderness and where new life emerges despite overwhelming darkness. This is a story that finds profound meaning in the smallest gestures of care, revealing how connection can flourish even in the most desperate circumstances.
short_summary: Dublin, 1918: three women tend to expectant mothers in a flu-ravaged maternity ward. Over three intense days, they confront pandemic, war, and unexpected connection in this luminous novel of caregiving and hope.
genres: Fiction / Historical / 20th Century / World War I
author_bios: Emma Donoghue has written sixteen novels, including Room, which became both an award-winning national bestseller and the foundation for a celebrated film adaptation. Her most recent novel is The Paris Express. Beyond fiction, Donoghue has crafted screenplays for Room and The Wonder, along with nine theatrical works. She is currently developing H Is for Hawk as a film project, collaborating with Philippa Lowthorpe to adapt Helen Macdonald's memoir. Originally from Dublin, Emma Donoghue now makes her home in Ontario with her family.
quotes:
"Don't believe history repeats itself? Read this book…an arresting new page turner of a novel… [The Pull of the Stars] takes place almost entirely in a single room and unfolds at the pace of a thriller."

—Karen Thompson Walker, The New York Times

"In doing a deep dive into the miseries and terrors of the past, Donoghue presciently anticipated the miseries and terrors of our present. . . . A deft, lyrical and sometimes even cheeky writer . . . she's given us our first pandemic caregiver novel -- an engrossing and inadvertently topical story about health care workers inside small rooms fighting to preserve life."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"A visceral, harrowing, and revelatory vision of life, death, and love in a time of pandemic. This novel is stunning."

—Emily St. John Mandel, author of The Glass Hotel and Station Eleven

title: Before You Suffocate Your Own Fool Self
long_summary:
Adolescence collides with adult realities in this remarkable debut that examines the complex terrain of growing up black and mixed-race in contemporary America. These eight stories follow young women caught between competing worlds—navigating predominantly white academic spaces while grappling with family expectations, confronting unplanned pregnancies that threaten carefully laid plans, and wrestling with relationships that expose deep-seated insecurities about belonging.

Evans creates characters who are whip-smart yet vulnerable, aware of systemic inequalities but still stumbling through the universal awkwardness of coming of age. A college student questions her place among privileged peers. A daughter discovers how much distance has grown between herself and her father. A teenager spends a summer with her white grandmother that reshapes her understanding of family and race.

What emerges is a collection that refuses simple answers, instead offering nuanced portraits of young people making imperfect choices in an imperfect world. Evans captures both the humor and heartbreak of these pivotal moments with remarkable insight for such a young writer.
short_summary: Evans's debut collection captures young African-American and mixed-race characters navigating family, community, and identity with startling emotional precision. These stories are funny, devastating, and achingly real.
author_bios: Danielle Evans wrote Before You Suffocate Your Own Fool Self, which earned her the Joyce Carol Oates Prize, the PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize, the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award, and the Paterson Prize. The National Book Foundation recognized her as a 5 under 35 honoree. Her fiction has been featured in numerous publications and The Best American Short Stories. Evans currently teaches in The Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins University.
quotes:
"The most vivid characters in Danielle Evans's story collection are in- betweeners: between girlhood and womanhood; between the black middle class and Ivy League privilege; between iffy boyfriends and those even less reliable; between an extended family and living on your own. To say they're caught between worlds isn't quite accurate, though; they tend to be hard-headed, sadder but wiser and, most of all, funny."

—The New York Times

"This striking debut collection Before You Suffocate Your Own Fool Self offers rich slices of African-American life... [Evans's] stories are bolstered by memorable images... Evans's book, meanwhile, carries a strong scent of freshness and promise."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Armed with no easy answers but plenty of bad choices, the talented, too-smart- for-their-own-good protagonists are painfully aware of the consequences of their actions, even when they think they have no better choice. . . . The moral ambiguity of Evans's achingly believable world finds its best expression in the devastating final story, 'Robert E. Lee is Dead,' in which the brainy black cheerleader, CeeCee, jeopardizes her own high-school graduation with a pointless act of vandalism. Although she is instigated by her closest friend Geena, whose future is less bright, CeeCee's decision is her own. She shares this characteristic with the other survivors in this arresting book, along with the regret. A welcome new talent-with a funny and dark take on being black in America."

—Kirkus

title: The Trespasser
long_summary:
Detective Antoinette Conway faces hostility from every corner of the Murder squad, where pranks and harassment have become her daily reality. Only her partner Stephen Moran offers any support as she struggles to maintain her position on the force.

The murder of Aislinn Murray appears straightforward enough—a beautiful woman found dead in her immaculate home, a romantic evening turned fatal. Yet something nags at Conway about the victim, a sense of recognition she can't quite place. As the investigation deepens, pressure mounts from fellow detectives to quickly arrest the boyfriend and close the case.

But Conway refuses to accept the obvious answers. Strange details emerge: cryptic warnings from Aislinn's friend, a mysterious figure lurking near Conway's home, and evidence suggesting the victim was far more complex than her polished exterior revealed. Each discovery chips away at the image of Aislinn as a passive victim.

Caught between her growing paranoia and genuine instincts, Conway must determine whether this case represents another attempt to sabotage her career or if something more sinister lurks beneath the surface. The investigation becomes a test of her ability to trust herself in a world determined to undermine her.
short_summary: When a seemingly routine domestic murder lands on Detective Antoinette Conway's desk, the investigation exposes both the victim's hidden depths and the toxic dynamics threatening to destroy Conway's career.
author_bios: Tana French has written nine books, including In the Woods, The Searcher, The Hunter, and The Trespasser, establishing herself as a bestselling voice in contemporary crime fiction. Her work has reached over eight million readers globally and earned recognition through the Edgar, Anthony, Macavity, and Barry Awards, along with the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Best Mystery/Thriller and the Irish Book Award for Crime Fiction. French makes her home in Dublin with her family.
quotes:
"A tour de force . . . When you read Ms. French—and she has become required reading for anyone who appreciates tough, unflinching intelligence and ingenious plotting—make only one assumption: All of your initial assumptions are wrong."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Tana French is the most interesting, most important crime novelist to emerge in the past 10 years."

—The Washington Post

"Beautifully crafted . . . may be her best yet."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Small Rain
long_summary:
Medical catastrophe strikes without warning, transforming a writer's existence from one of intellectual contemplation to raw physical survival. The hospital becomes an unlikely stage for revelation, where sterile corridors and beeping machines frame questions about what it means to be human.

Through fever and uncertainty, consciousness drifts between past and present, between the body's demands and the mind's resistance. The clinical world reveals unexpected tenderness—in overworked nurses, in the architecture of care, in moments of grace that emerge from institutional chaos. What begins as personal crisis expands into something larger: an examination of how we hold each other through suffering, how art sustains us when flesh fails, and how love manifests in the most unlikely circumstances.

This is storytelling that finds beauty in breakdown, that discovers profound connection within isolation. The result is both intimate and expansive—a work that uses one person's medical emergency to illuminate the fragile networks of compassion that bind us together.
short_summary: When sudden illness lands a poet in the ICU, physical crisis becomes spiritual awakening. Greenwell transforms a medical emergency into profound meditation on love, art, and human connection.
author_bios: Garth Greenwell has written two previous fiction works, What Belongs to You and Cleanness. His writing has earned him a Guggenheim Fellowship and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He currently serves as a Distinguished Writer in Residence at New York University.
quotes:
"There's an unshowy genius to Garth Greenwell's prose that feels genuinely peerless among contemporary American novelists . . . Small Rain is a classic, a dawn serenade, a little miracle of exigent joy. I'll be rereading it the rest of my life."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

"Throughout Small Rain, Greenwell's massing, vascular prose, arranged in paragraphs that span many pages, deftly forces the reader to slow down and concentrate. His sentences are parataxic and branching, as organic and surprising as a network of veins . . . Greenwell's great gift: finding forms for the representation of thought, much as the Impressionist painters, more than a century ago, found new forms for the representation of light . . . The novel [has] blazing universality and grace."

—Sarah Thankam Mathews, author of All This Could Be Different

"I just didn't put it down . . . Very romantic, incredibly moving."

—Miranda July, author of All Fours

title: Arcadia
long_summary:
The dream of creating paradise on earth drives a group of back-to-the-land enthusiasts to establish their own society around a crumbling estate in 1970s upstate New York. Among the founders are Handy, whose musical talents and magnetic personality draw others to his vision, along with Astrid the midwife, Abe the carpenter, and Hannah the baker.

Their experiment in communal living produces one child early on: Bit, who knows no reality beyond the boundaries of their alternative world. As he matures, the community experiences both triumph and discord, forcing its members to confront whether their ideals can withstand the pressures of human nature and economic reality.

Bit's coming-of-age unfolds against this backdrop of social experiment, where he develops deep bonds with fellow commune members, particularly Helle, the troubled daughter of the community's founders. His story becomes one of identity and belonging—torn between loyalty to the people who raised him and the need to discover who he might become in the conventional world that lies beyond their gates.
short_summary: Born into a 1970s commune in upstate New York, Bit grows up surrounded by idealists trying to live off the land. As their utopian experiment rises and falls, he must find his place between the only world he's known and the larger one beyond.
author_bios: Lauren Groff has earned three National Book Award nominations and written multiple bestselling works, including The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus the story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. Her accolades include The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Groff's fiction regularly appears in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, with translations available in thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband operate the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"[Lauren Groff] has taken a quaint, easily caricatured community and given it true universality...And a book that might have been small, dated and insular winds up feeling timeless and vast...The raw beauty of Ms. Groff's prose is one of the best things about Arcadia. But it is by no means this book's only kind of splendor."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"I was constantly torn between wanting to gulp down this book or savor its lines. Even the most incidental details vibrate with life... Arcadia wends a harrowing path back to a fragile, lovely place you can believe in."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A moving look at the value of human connection in a scary, chaotic world."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Nix
long_summary:
Professor Samuel Andresen-Anderson thought he understood his past until his estranged mother suddenly resurfaces in the worst possible way. Faye abandoned her family years ago, leaving behind only questions and hurt. Now she's at the center of a media firestorm, accused of a bizarre act that has the entire country taking sides.

The woman splashed across headlines bears little resemblance to the quiet girl Samuel remembers from his childhood. Determined to separate truth from sensationalism, he begins investigating his family's history, following a trail that leads him from the American Midwest all the way back to Norwegian folklore and the legend of the Nix—a mythical creature that haunts those who betray the ones they love.

What Samuel discovers forces him to question everything he believed about his mother, his family, and himself. Hill weaves together multiple timelines, from the chaos of 1960s political protests to the digital age's manufactured outrage, creating a story that examines how we construct the narratives of our lives and what happens when those stories collide with reality.
short_summary: When his long-absent mother commits a crime that becomes national news, a college professor must uncover buried family secrets to save her. Hill's ambitious debut spans generations and continents with sharp humor and fierce tenderness.
author_bios: Nathan Hill wrote the bestselling novel The Nix, which Entertainment Weekly named the top book of 2016. The novel also earned recognition from The New York Times, The Washington Post, NPR, and Slate as one of the year's finest works. Hill received the Art Seidenbaum Award for First Fiction from the Los Angeles Times, and his debut has been translated into more than twenty-four languages. Originally from Iowa, Nathan Hill currently resides in Naples, Florida, with his wife.
quotes:
"It broke my heart, this book. Time after time. It made me laugh just as often. I loved it on the first page as powerfully as I did on the last."

—Jason Sheehan, NPR

"Hill has so much talent to burn that he can pull of just about any style, imagine himself into any person and convincingly portray any place or time. The Nix is hugely entertaining and unfailingly smart, and the author seems incapable of writing a pedestrian sentence or spinning a boring story…. [A] supersize and audacious novel of American misadventure."

—Teddy Wayne, The New York Times

"Irresistible…. A major new comic novelist…. Hill is a sharp social observer, hyper-alert to the absurdities of modern life…. his enormous book arrives as one of the stars of the fall season…. readers will find this novel. And they'll be dazzled."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The White Hot
long_summary:
April Soto's life feels like a pressure cooker ready to explode. Caught between family tensions and the relentless demands of motherhood, she finds herself retreating to the bathroom with headphones, desperately seeking silence. But when her breaking point finally arrives, she makes a decision that changes everything: she buys a bus ticket to wherever it will take her farthest from home.

What follows is ten days that stretch into a decade-long reckoning. April's impulsive escape becomes something far more complex—a reckoning with inherited pain, a search for identity beyond the roles others have assigned her, and ultimately a confrontation with what it means to love someone enough to hurt them. Through April's voice, speaking directly to her daughter years later, Hudes crafts an intimate meditation on the impossible mathematics of motherhood and the courage required to break patterns that have defined generations.

This is a story about the space between abandonment and liberation, told with unflinching honesty about the messy realities of family, trauma, and the radical act of choosing yourself.
short_summary: A young mother flees her suffocating life for ten days of dangerous freedom in this stunning debut. Told as a letter to her daughter, it's a raw exploration of love, abandonment, and breaking cycles.
author_bios: Quiara Alegría Hudes has built her career exploring stories of family, identity, and resilience across multiple mediums. Her achievements include winning the Pulitzer Prize for her play Water by the Spoonful and earning a Tony Award for the Broadway musical In the Heights. She has also written for film, including the animated movie Vivo, and published the essay High Tide of Heartbreak. Beyond her artistic work, Hudes co-founded Emancipated Stories with her cousin, creating a space for incarcerated individuals to share their personal narratives as part of prison reform advocacy.
quotes:
"April Soto has fled her life but has left us The White Hot—at once a reclaiming, a credo, and a heartrending letter to a beloved daughter from an unforgettable mother. In wise, searing prose, Quiara Alegría Hudes fills in a daughter's lost history while treating us to a stunning debut about the passions that whisper: to honor what you love, leave. The White Hot articulates our beautiful, unspeakable wildernesses. . . . Dignified, sexy, and true, with lines ('A mother is a life sentence'; 'How could love look like leaving?') burned indelibly into my heart."

—Marie-Helene Bertino, author of Beautyland

"[A] stunning fiction debut . . . In blunt yet vibrantly lyrical prose, Hudes reveals the good, the bad, and the profane from April's brutally candid perspective. . . . It's a profound journey of the soul. . . . This staggering gut punch of a novel shows that sometimes love looks like leaving."

—Kirkus

"The potent debut novel from playwright and memoirist Hudes . . . takes the form of a letter written by April Soto, 26, to her 10-year-old daughter, Noelle, which Noelle is meant to read when she turns 18. . . . The end of April's letter is gut-wrenching, but the novel offers profound clarity. . . . This sizzles."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Moon Witch, Spider King
long_summary:
