The Moon Witch steps forward to set the record straight. Sogolon refuses to let others define her narrative, particularly when it comes to her role in hunting for a lost child across mystical African realms. Her voice carries the weight of 177 years, and she has scores to settle.

At the heart of her tale lies a bitter rivalry with the Aesi, a chancellor whose influence over the king runs so deep they function as a single entity with eight limbs. This political spider weaves webs of control that span decades, but Sogolon possesses both the cunning and audacity to challenge such consolidated power.

Their conflict stretches across a full century, revealing how personal vendettas can reshape kingdoms and how different visions of rule clash in spectacular fashion. Sogolon's account exposes the machinery of empire from an entirely different angle—that of someone who refuses to submit to its authority. Her story becomes both a thrilling adventure and a meditation on how women claim agency in worlds designed to silence them, examining what happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object.
short_summary: Sogolon the Moon Witch tells her side of the story in this stunning sequel. A century-long feud with a deadly chancellor unfolds through the eyes of a 177-year-old witch who bows to no one.
author_bios: Marlon James has written several acclaimed novels including the Man Booker Prize-winning A Brief History of Seven Killings and the National Book Award finalist Black Leopard, Red Wolf, both New York Times bestsellers. His other works include The Book of Night Women and John Crow's Devil. Currently teaching at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota, James makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"A rare sequel that is better than its predecessor. . . .Moon Witch, Spider King is a breathtaking book, one that functions as well as a standalone as it does a sequel. . . .Make no mistake, this series is absolutely a must-read."

—NPR

"In the second book of his Dark Star trilogy, James coaxes beauty from dark thoughts, leaving readers with a concaved, mystical and African-inspired world that begins in free-fall. . . .In a world as thoroughly imagined as J.R.R. Tolkien's, no detail seems spared. Full figured and richly drawn, Moon Witch, Spider King is the bridge of a trilogy and also a creation that, like James' talent, stands alone."

—Los Angeles Times

"Spectacularly alive. . . .James choreographs fight scenes that make Quentin Tarantino's movies feel comparatively tranquil. And there's a catalogue of diabolically ingenious creatures creeping along the ceilings, jumping from behind trees and even reaching through fourth-dimension portals to keep the pages simmering with terror. . . .Sogolon is a thrilling, haunting heroine."

—The Washington Post

title: Black Leopard, Red Wolf
long_summary:
A legendary hunter whose extraordinary sense of smell has made him famous agrees to locate a child who vanished years ago. Despite his preference for solitude, he joins an eclectic group of searchers, each harboring their own mysteries. Among them is Leopard, a being capable of shifting between human and animal form.

Their quest leads them through ancient cities and untamed wilderness, where hostile forces seem determined to stop them at every turn. As violence and danger escalate, questions multiply: What makes this particular child so important? Why are powerful enemies willing to kill to prevent his discovery? The deeper they venture into their mission, the more the hunter realizes that nothing about this search is what it appears to be.

Marlon James constructs a fantasy epic rooted in African mythology, creating a world where magic and reality intertwine. This opening volume of a trilogy challenges readers to question the nature of truth itself, weaving together adventure, political intrigue, and philosophical depth in a narrative that refuses easy answers.
short_summary: Myth, fantasy, and history collide when a legendary tracker is hired to find a missing child. James creates an astonishingly realized pre-colonial Africa crawling with shape-shifters and ancient magic.
author_bios: Marlon James has written several acclaimed novels including the Man Booker Prize-winning A Brief History of Seven Killings and the National Book Award finalist Black Leopard, Red Wolf, both New York Times bestsellers. His other works include The Book of Night Women and John Crow's Devil. Currently teaching at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota, James makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"James' visions don't jettison you from reality so much as they trap you in his mad-genius, mercurial mind. . . . Drenched in African myth and folklore, and set in an astonishingly realized pre-colonized sub-Saharan region, Black Leopard crawls with creatures and erects kingdoms unlike any I've read. . . . This is a revolutionary book."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Marlon James is one of those novelists who aren't afraid to give a performance, to change the states of language from viscous to gushing to grand, to get all the way inside the people he's created... [Black Leopard, Red Wolf] looks like another great, big tale of death, murder and mystery but more mystically fantastical... Not only does this book come with a hefty cast of characters (like Seven Killings), there are also shape shifters, fairies, trolls, and, apparently, a map. The map might be handy. But it might be the opposite of why you come to James—to get lost in him."

—The New York Times

"James' sensual, beautifully rendered prose and sweeping, precisely detailed narrative cast their own transfixing spell upon the reader. He not only brings a fresh multicultural perspective to a grand fantasy subgenre, but also broadens the genre's psychological and metaphysical possibilities. If this first volume is any indication, James' trilogy could become one of the most talked-about and influential adventure epics since George R.R. Martin's A Song of Ice and Fire was transformed into Game of Thrones."

—Kirkus

title: Welcome to Braggsville
long_summary:
A small-town Georgia native finds himself adrift among Berkeley's progressive elite until an unlikely friendship forms with three fellow misfits: a wisecracking martial arts enthusiast, a well-meaning Midwesterner with questionable heritage claims, and a thoughtful Chicago transplant. Their bond deepens in a class examining alternative histories, where casual mention of D'aron's hometown tradition—a Civil War commemoration now sanitized as "Patriot Days"—ignites academic outrage.

Fueled by campus activism and their own cultural blind spots, the quartet embarks on a misguided mission to the rural South. Their plan: stage a dramatic protest that will expose the event's problematic nature. Johnson crafts a blistering examination of American identity through this collision of worlds—urban versus rural, progressive versus traditional, intention versus impact.

The author dissects our national contradictions with surgical precision, revealing how assumptions and prejudices flow in all directions. This is social satire at its most incisive, interrogating everything from performative activism to regional stereotypes while exposing the dangerous gaps between our ideals and reality. The result is both hilarious and heartbreaking—a mirror held up to contemporary America's most uncomfortable truths.
short_summary: Four Berkeley students stage a protest at a Georgia Civil War reenactment with catastrophic results. Johnson's razor-sharp satire dissects American mythmaking with devastating wit.
author_bios: T. Geronimo Johnson grew up in the American South and has written two acclaimed novels: Welcome to Braggsville, which received longlist recognition for the National Book Award and Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence, and Hold It 'Til It Hurts, a finalist for the PEN/Faulkner Award. Among his honors are the Ernest J. Gaines Award for Literary Excellence and William Saroyan International Prize. Johnson completed his M.F.A. at Iowa Writers' Workshop and received both Stegner and Iowa Arts fellowships.
quotes:
"Ghastly and funny and gloriously provocative . . . Johnson's prose is by turns scathing dark humor, soaring lyricism, and a quietly devastating analysis of every species of injustice. The result is a kind of mind-melting poetry—a linguistic electroconvulsive therapy for the reader. This book will wake you up!"

—Karen Russell, New York Times bestselling author of Swamplandia!

"Four college students' attempt to protest Southern folkways goes awry in a novel that blurs the line between academic satire and social realism . . . A rambunctious, irreverent yet still serious study of the long reach of American institutional racism."

—Kirkus

"A partial list of great American writers whose names came to mind as I was reading T. Geronimo Johnson's new novel, Welcome to Braggsville: Tom Wolfe, Mark Twain, Toni Morrison, H.L. Mencken, Don DeLillo, David Foster Wallace, Norman Mailer and Ralph Ellison, Ralph Ellison, Ralph Ellison. Johnson's timely novel is a tipsy social satire about race and the oh-so-fragile ties that bind disparate parts of this country into an imperfect and restless union. It's an ambitious book that not only wants to say something big about America, but aims to do so in a big American voice that contains multitudes . . . [It's] Confederates in the Attic meets A Confederacy of Dunces . . . The novel ends with a tour-de-force riff on black history, which, Johnson writes, 'in its myriad inversions, loops, whorls, coils, corkscrews, spirals; from slavery to Jim Crow to the Carceral State [is] the helix that stitches the U.S. of A.'s social DNA.' Welcome to Braggsville isn't quite Invisible Man or White Noise, but it gets within hailing distance of their heights. It's as American as chattel slavery and Lenny Bruce Lee."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Palmares
long_summary:
In colonial Brazil, an enslaved woman named Almeyda witnesses the rise and fall of Palmares, the legendary settlement where escaped slaves carved out their own society. After Portuguese forces destroy this haven of freedom, Almeyda faces a different kind of bondage: the desperate search for her missing husband across a continent ravaged by conquest.

Her travels through this brutal landscape reveal a world where survival demands both cunning and faith. She crosses paths with a scholar fleeing his own demons, discovers communities clinging to ancient beliefs, and learns from healers whose knowledge comes at terrible costs. Jones weaves together the intimate story of one woman's determination with a broader examination of how colonialism fractures lives and cultures.

This novel interrogates the violence of empire while illuminating the extraordinary lengths people will go to preserve love and dignity. Almeyda's quest becomes a testament to the human capacity for endurance, even as it exposes the devastating machinery of oppression that shaped the Americas.
short_summary: An enslaved woman's epic journey through 17th-century colonial Brazil, from plantation to freedom to the search for love. The triumphant return of a major American voice.
author_bios: Born in Kentucky in 1949, Gayl Jones studied at Connecticut College and Brown University before teaching at both Wellesley College and the University of Michigan. Her influential novels include Corregidora, Eva's Man, and The Healing, which earned recognition as a National Book Award finalist and New York Times Notable Book of the Year. More recently, she published Palmares, a Pulitzer Prize fiction finalist, and The Birdcatcher, another National Book Award finalist.
quotes:
"Palmares reinvents 17th-century Black Brazil in all its multiplicity, beauty, humanity and chaos. A once-in-a-lifetime work of literature, the kind that changes your understanding of the world."

—The Guardian

"A legendary African American novelist returns with her first novel in 22 years, an epic adventure of enchantment, enslavement, and the pursuit of knowledge in 17th-century Brazil . . . . Those familiar with Corregidora (1975) and Eva's Man (1976) will not be surprised by the sustained intensity of both imagery and tone. There is also sheer wonder, insightful compassion, and droll wit to be found among the book's riches. Jones seems to have come through a life as tumultuous as her heroine's with her storytelling gifts not only intact, but enhanced and enriching."

—Kirkus

"An epic and inventive saga . . . a triumphant return."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Five Tuesdays in Winter
long_summary:
Love arrives uninvited and leaves scars in its wake throughout this collection that examines how we navigate intimacy's treacherous waters. A bookstore owner discovers that opening her heart means confronting old wounds. Former college friends find their reunion unraveling in unexpected ways. In a hospital corridor, a grandfather grapples with his own powerlessness as his granddaughter fights for life. A female author confronts the men who sought to diminish her creative voice.

King crafts narratives that refuse easy resolutions, instead diving deep into the contradictions that define our most meaningful relationships. Her characters chase connection while simultaneously fearing its consequences, creating tension that drives each story forward. The collection moves between moments of tender vulnerability and sharp-edged reality, revealing how hope and heartbreak often occupy the same space. These ten pieces demonstrate King's ability to illuminate the profound within the ordinary, showing how our attempts to reach one another shape us in ways both beautiful and brutal.
short_summary: Ten stories that capture the messy beauty of human connection. King writes with unflinching honesty about desire, loss, and the inexorable pull toward love despite devastating risks.
author_bios: Lily King has written six novels, including Euphoria and Writers & Lovers, along with the story collection Five Tuesdays in Winter. Her fiction has earned numerous honors, including the Kirkus Prize, the New England Book Award for Fiction, the Maine Book Award for Fiction, and a Whiting Award. King's novels have reached international audiences through translation into twenty-eight languages. She makes her home in Portland, Maine, and her work has appeared on the New York Times bestseller list.
quotes:
"King returns to the page with a collection of short stories that continue to prove her prowess in all things love and human connection."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Lily King isn't afraid of big emotional subjects: desire and grief, longing and love, growth and self-acceptance. But she eschews high drama for the immersive quiet of the everyday… Here we inhabit the worlds of authors and mothers, children and friends; we experience their lives in clear, graceful prose that swells with generous possibility. This is a book for writers and lovers, a book about storytelling itself, a book for all of us."

—The Washington Post

"Wonderfully absorbing...All 10 of these tales build gratifyingly to moments of epiphany that never feel unearned... Long form or short, this is a writer who has mastered the art of conveying depths of human feeling in one beautiful sentence after another."

—NPR

title: Doctor Sleep
long_summary:
Dan Torrance carries the scars of childhood trauma, both supernatural and deeply human. The psychic abilities that once exposed him to unimaginable horrors have become his salvation—he channels them into easing the final moments of hospice patients, earning quiet respect as someone who understands the threshold between life and death.

This fragile peace shatters with the arrival of Abra Stone, a child whose psychic gifts dwarf his own. Her extraordinary abilities have attracted the attention of the True Knot, a predatory cult that sustains itself by consuming the life force of psychically gifted children. These ancient beings have survived for centuries by hunting those who shine brightest.

Faced with protecting Abra, Dan must excavate strengths he's spent years burying. The confrontation forces him to reckon with his past while mastering abilities he's only used for healing. King weaves a tale that examines how trauma shapes us, the courage required to break destructive cycles, and the unexpected ways our greatest vulnerabilities can become sources of power.
short_summary: Dan Torrance, haunted survivor of the Overlook Hotel, has found purpose using his psychic abilities to comfort hospice patients. When he meets a gifted twelve-year-old hunted by supernatural predators, he must face his demons to protect her.
author_bios: Stephen King has written over sixty books, each becoming a worldwide bestseller. Among his recent publications are Never Flinch, You Like It Darker (recognized as a New York Times Book Review top ten horror book of 2024), Holly (selected as a New York Times Notable Book of 2023), Fairy Tale, Billy Summers, and the Bill Hodges trilogy. His novel 11/22/63 earned the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Mystery/Thriller. King received the 2018 PEN America Literary Service Award, the 2014 National Medal of Arts, and the 2003 National Book Foundation Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters.

title: Roman Stories
long_summary:
Nine interconnected tales unfold across Rome's layered landscape, revealing the intimate struggles of characters caught between worlds. A caretaker's daughter carries the weight of her family's migration story while observing wealthy visitors. Aging Romans discover unexpected connections with expatriates, only to have those bonds tested by betrayal. On the Spanish Steps, strangers navigate the invisible barriers that divide the city's social fabric.

Lahiri constructs a literary map of contemporary Rome that exposes how displacement shapes identity, whether through immigration, aging, or simply moving between neighborhoods. Her characters inhabit the margins—domestic workers, empty nesters, cultural outsiders—yet their experiences illuminate universal questions about belonging and transformation. Written in Italian and translated by Lahiri with Todd Portnowitz, these stories pulse with the rhythms of a city where ancient history collides with modern alienation, creating spaces where the most profound human connections often emerge from the deepest forms of isolation.
short_summary: Nine luminous stories set in Rome, exploring immigration, belonging, and the spaces between cultures. Lahiri's first collection written entirely in Italian captures the eternal city's hidden emotional geography with stunning precision.
author_bios: Jhumpa Lahiri has written four fiction works—Interpreter of Maladies, The Namesake, Unaccustomed Earth, and The Lowland—along with the nonfiction work In Other Words. Her numerous honors include the Pulitzer Prize, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Malamud Award, Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award, Premio Gregor von Rezzori, DSC Prize for South Asian Literature, 2014 National Humanities Medal, and Premio Internazionale Viareggio-Versilia.
quotes:
"Electric . . .  Elegant . . . The fluid transitions between Lahiri's and Portnowitz's translations elevate Roman Stories from a grouping of individual tales to a deeply moving whole."

—The New York Times

"A dazzling collection of nine stories originally written in Italian and featuring characters who grapple with vast emotional and social chasms that cleave the lives of families, longtime friends, and immigrants . . . Throughout, Lahiri's luminous prose captures a side of Rome often ignored . . . These unembroidered yet potent stories shine."

—Publishers Weekly

"A brilliant return to the short story form by an author of protean accomplishments . . . Filled with intelligence and sorrow, these sharply drawn glimpses of Roman lives create an impressively unified effect."

—Kirkus

title: Wednesday's Child
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Loss threads through these stories like a quiet current, surfacing in unexpected moments—an email that arrives annually from a stranger, the ritual of cataloging the dead, the strange intimacy that blooms between unlikely companions. Yiyun Li captures characters caught between the life they're living and the one they've left behind, where small objects carry enormous weight and silence speaks louder than words.

These narratives resist easy comfort, instead offering something more valuable: recognition of how we navigate the spaces between what we expected and what we received. Li's characters inhabit a world where honey can be stolen salvation, where photographs hide until the moment they demand to be witnessed, where the ordinary becomes a kind of performance until it finally breaks.

Drawn from years of work published in prestigious magazines, this collection showcases Li's ability to find the universal in the particular. Her prose moves between humor and devastation with surgical precision, never flinching from difficult truths about exile, belonging, and the price we pay for connection. Each story operates like a small revelation, illuminating the mysterious architecture of human endurance.
short_summary: Stories that excavate the fault lines between ordinary life and devastating loss. Li's prose is precise and unflinching, finding profound meaning in small gestures and everyday cruelties.
author_bios: Yiyun Li has written Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; A Thousand Years of Good Prayers; and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. Her work has earned her a PEN/Faulkner Award, PEN/Malamud Award, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, MacArthur Fellowship, and Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She teaches at Princeton University.
quotes:
"Li is a master at understanding human emotion, but her tenderness never gives way to sentimentality . . . Gorgeous prose and painstaking attention to detail . . . makes these stories so beautiful, so accomplished. This is a perfect collection by a writer at the top of her game, and a heart-wrenching look at how loss changes not only the bereaved, but their entire existence."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"Splendid and elegantly observed . . . Distinguished by their fully realized characters, nuanced narration, and striking portraits of everyday struggles, these stories find Li at the top of her game."

—Publishers Weekly

"An infinite variety of ways to survive—or, at least, march through—devastating loss are cataloged in Li's cool and measured litany of pain . . . The cumulative mass of the stories is sobering, a gorgeous almanac . . . Quiet, beautiful accounts of journeys through hell."

—Kirkus

title: The Story of My Teeth
long_summary:
Meet Gustavo "Highway" Sánchez Sánchez, an eccentric auctioneer who believes he possesses the actual dental remains of history's greatest minds and artists. His obsession with acquiring these bizarre relics drives him through the sprawling industrial landscape of Mexico City, where he spins elaborate tales about his collection.

This unconventional novel blurs the boundaries between fiction and reality, questioning how we assign value to objects and the stories we construct around them. The narrative examines the relationship between possession and identity, exploring whether owning pieces of famous figures can somehow transfer their genius or significance.

What makes this work particularly unique is its collaborative genesis—emerging from a partnership with factory workers, it challenges traditional notions of authorship and literary creation. The result is a philosophical meditation disguised as an entertaining adventure, where truth becomes less important than the compelling narratives we choose to believe.
short_summary: Highway is a world traveler, yarn spinner, and legendary auctioneer whose most precious possessions are the teeth of famous figures like Plato and Virginia Woolf. A wildly inventive collaboration with juice factory workers.
author_bios: Born in Mexico City, Valeria Luiselli spent her childhood across multiple continents including South Korea, South Africa, and India. Her published works include the novels Faces in the Crowd and The Story of My Teeth, along with Sidewalks and Tell Me How It Ends: An Essay in Forty Questions. Luiselli has received the MacArthur Fellowship, two Los Angeles Times Book Prizes, an American Book Award, and the 2021 Dublin Literary Award. Her writing appears in The New York Times, Granta, and McSweeney's, with translations available in over twenty languages.
quotes:
"One of the most unforgettable images in any book this year is that of Gustavo "Highway" Sánchez Sánchez, the protagonist of Luiselli's delightfully unclassifiable novel, walking around the streets of Mexico City, smiling at people with the teeth of Marilyn Monroe installed in his mouth . . . surprising and charming . . . It's difficult not to follow wherever it takes you."

—Publishers Weekly

"This boggling and enchanting collaborative novel about a man who believes he has had Marilyn Monroe's literal teeth implanted into his mouth began as a bit of art gallery catalog copy sponsored by a large juice company."

—The National Post

"A lively, loopy experimental novel rich with musings on language, art, and, yes, teeth. . .the whole book is a kind of extended commentary on how possessions acquire value largely through the stories we tell about them. . . A clever philosophical novel that, as the author puts it, has "less to do with lying than surpassing the truth.""

—Kirkus

title: Sea of Tranquility
long_summary:
Three individuals separated by centuries find themselves connected by an inexplicable phenomenon that defies logic and time itself. A young aristocrat banished to the Canadian frontier encounters something that shouldn't exist in his world. Generations later, a successful author living in humanity's lunar settlement discovers her own fiction may contain echoes of impossible events. Between them stands an investigator whose pursuit of temporal irregularities reveals how their stories interweave in ways that challenge everything he understands about reality.

Mandel crafts a meditation on art's ability to transcend time, examining how creativity and human connection persist even as civilizations rise and fall. The novel questions whether our experiences are authentic or merely shadows of other moments, while celebrating the threads that bind us across vast distances of space and time. Through these interlocking narratives, she explores how stories themselves become vessels for preserving what matters most about being human.
short_summary: Time travel connects three lives across centuries: an exiled young man in 1912 Canada, a novelist on a moon colony, and a detective investigating impossible anomalies. Mandel weaves art, love, and plague into something transcendent.
author_bios: Emily St. John Mandel has written five novels, including Station Eleven and The Glass Hotel. Station Eleven received nominations for both the National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, and has found readers in thirty-five languages through translation. She makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"In Sea of Tranquility, Mandel offers one of her finest novels and one of her most satisfying forays into the arena of speculative fiction yet, but it is her ability to convincingly inhabit the ordinary, and…project a sustaining acknowledgment of beauty, that sets the novel apart…Born of…empathy and hard-won understanding, beautifully built into language, for all of us who inhabit this 'green-and-blue world' and who one day might live well beyond."

—Laird Hunt, The New York Times

"Mandel delivers...with an impish blend of wit and dread. The paradoxes of Gaspery's adventure will be familiar to anyone who's studied Jean Baudrillard or seen "Back to the Future." But Mandel has the stylistic elegance and emotional sympathy to make this more than merely an undergraduate bull session. Absent your own time portal to the 1990s, it's a chance to... wrestle with the mind-blowing possibility that what is may be entirely different from what we see."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"I didn't just read Station Eleven, The Glass Hotel, or Mandel's latest, Sea of Tranquility. I lived in those novels and felt the remnants of their weird, chill atmosphere long after I had to move on…World builder is a phrase that's rightly used to describe Mandel's immersive powers as a novelist…Sea Of Tranquility is a poignant, ingeniously constructed and deeply absorbing novel that surveys big questions about the cruel inevitability of time passing, loss, the nature of what we consider reality and, in the end, what finally matters…Mandel is an important novelist of our moment, but doesn't settle for merely replicating our moment. She inhabits it even as she sees beyond it."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: The Infatuations
long_summary:
María Dolz finds herself drawn into the daily rhythms of strangers, watching a couple during her morning coffee routine in Madrid. Their apparent contentment becomes a refuge from her own unremarkable life—until violence intrudes with shocking brutality.

The husband's murder on the street transforms María's passive observation into active involvement. She seeks out the grieving widow, ostensibly to express sympathy, but this gesture leads her into unexpected territory. Through another man connected to the tragedy, she discovers that the crime harbors secrets that challenge everything she believed about the couple she had idealized.

Marías weaves together the threads of a criminal investigation with deeper questions about human connection and self-deception. The novel examines how we construct narratives to make sense of chaos, and how our need for meaning can lead us to embrace comfortable fictions over uncomfortable realities. María's journey from observer to participant reveals the dangerous allure of other people's lives and the complex relationship between witnessing and understanding.
short_summary: A woman's morning café ritual becomes an obsession with a perfect couple—until murder shatters the illusion. Marías transforms a crime story into philosophical inquiry about truth, love, and the stories we tell ourselves.
author_bios: Born in Madrid in 1951, Javier Marías became one of Spain's most celebrated literary voices through fifteen novels, three short story collections, and several essay volumes. His books, including The Infatuations and A Heart So White, have reached readers across forty-four languages and sold over eight million copies globally. Marías received numerous prestigious honors throughout his career, among them the International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award and Prix Femina Étranger. He passed away in 2022.
quotes:
"Whatever else we may think is going on when we read, we are choosing to spend time in an author's company. In Javier Marías's case this is a good decision; his mind is insightful, witty, sometimes startling, sometimes hilarious, and always intelligent . . . The masterly Spanish novelist [has] a penetrating empathy."

—Edward St. Aubyn, The New York Times

"The Infatuations is mysterious and seductive; it's got deception, it's got love affairs, it's got murder—the book is the most sheerly addictive thing Marías has ever written . . . Marías is a star writer in Europe, where his best-sellers collect prizes the way Kardashians collect paparazzi. He's been hailed in America, too, yet he's never broken through like Haruki Murakami or Roberto Bolaño. This should change with his new novel, The Infatuations, which is the ideal introduction to his work."

—NPR

"Blindingly intelligent, engagingly accessible—it seems there's nothing Marías can't make fiction do . . . Marías's rare gift is his ability to make intellectual jousting as suspenseful as the chase scenes in a commercial thriller."

—Kirkus

title: Western Lane
long_summary:
Loss reshapes everything for Gopi, whose childhood becomes defined by the rhythmic thwack of a squash ball against court walls. In the aftermath of her mother's death, the eleven-year-old finds herself caught between grief and her father's relentless expectations on the court. The sport that once brought joy now serves as both refuge and prison, creating distance between Gopi and her sisters while forging unexpected connections with fellow players.

Maroo crafts an intimate portrait of a young girl navigating trauma through athletic obsession. The squash court becomes a place where relationships form in silence—with her father, with Ged, a talented boy who shares her dedication, and with the ghosts of players who came before. Each game strips away another layer of childhood, revealing how we sometimes lose ourselves in the very things meant to save us.

This remarkable debut examines how families rebuild after devastating loss, and the ways children absorb adult pain. Through Gopi's eyes, we witness the delicate balance between devotion and destruction, between finding your voice and losing it entirely.
short_summary: After her mother's death, eleven-year-old Gopi throws herself into squash training with quiet desperation. Maroo's debut transforms grief into something luminous and strange.
author_bios: Chetna Maroo makes her home in London, where she has established herself as a distinctive voice in contemporary fiction. Her short stories have appeared in prestigious publications including The Paris Review, the Stinging Fly, and the Dublin Review. Maroo received the 2022 Plimpton Prize for Fiction, recognizing her exceptional talent in the short form.
quotes:
"Western Lane moved me in a way that is rare. It is limpid, crystalline, holding strange depths."

—C Pam Zhang, author of Land of Milk and Honey

"Compact and powerful . . . This will invigorate readers."

—Publishers Weekly

"Subtle and elegant . . . Gopi's retrospective narration accumulates slow layers of heartbreak as the story proceeds, patiently building up an entire landscape of emotion through gestures, silences, and overheard murmurings in the dark. A debut novel of immense poise and promise."

—Kirkus

title: Atavists
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In biology, an atavism describes when ancient traits suddenly reappear in modern organisms. Lydia Millet borrows this concept to examine how primal impulses break through the veneer of civilized life in her interconnected story collection.

The characters populating these tales find themselves caught between who they think they should be and the raw emotions that drive them. A bartender struggles to make sense of his place in the world. A mother becomes fixated on her son-in-law's supposed sexual proclivities. A fitness enthusiast nurses dangerous resentments about women and society. An academic's career crumbles under accusations of intellectual theft.

Millet captures the particular anxiety of living in contemporary America, where cultural divisions feel increasingly unbridgeable. Her protagonists stumble through moments both mundane and profound—a beauty treatment interrupted by devastating news, a couple's attempt to identify their anonymous tormentor, a professional's descent into obsessive behavior after romantic rejection.

Through these interconnected narratives, Millet dissects the gap between our aspirations and our actions. She finds both comedy and tragedy in how we respond when life strips away our pretenses, revealing the more primitive selves we thought we'd evolved beyond.
short_summary: Overlapping stories of contemporary Americans grappling with primitive urges and modern overwhelm. Millet's sharp social commentary balances humor with heartbreak in this inventive collection.
author_bios: Lydia Millet wrote A Children's Bible, which earned recognition as a National Book Award finalist and appeared on the New York Times Top Ten books of the Year. Her short fiction collection Love in Infant Monkeys received a Pulitzer Prize nomination. She makes her home in the desert outside Tucson, Arizona.
quotes:
"Millet's deftly told tales—in Atavists, as in her other novels and collections—demonstrate how a narrative framework creates meaning for human life…Stories are the sign. Atavists begs us to keep reading."

—Heather Scott Partington, Los Angeles Times

"[Millet] knows how to put a story together. How to pace drama and consummate tension, when to turn up the volume and when to leave us alone with what she's put in motion."

—Fiona Maazel, New York Times

"Sharply observed, beautifully rendered, and heartbreaking."

—Kirkus

title: Florence Gordon
long_summary:
Florence Gordon has reached that stage of life where she refuses to apologize for taking up space. This sharp-tongued feminist intellectual has spent decades fighting battles both public and personal, and now, at seventy-five, she's determined to claim her solitude and finally tackle the memoir that's been calling to her.

But family has a way of disrupting even the most carefully constructed boundaries. Her son Daniel arrives from Seattle with his wife and teenage daughter in tow, bringing their messy complications straight into Florence's ordered existence. As three generations collide under one roof, Florence finds herself navigating not just family dynamics but also the unsettling changes in her own body that hint at mortality's approach.

Brian Morton crafts a story that refuses easy sentiment, instead offering the complex reality of a woman who has never softened her edges for anyone's comfort. Florence's razor-sharp observations cut through pretense and self-deception, yet even her formidable intellect cannot shield her from life's fundamental vulnerabilities. This is an unflinching examination of what it means to age with dignity while remaining true to oneself, even when the people we love most challenge our carefully constructed defenses.
short_summary: Seventy-five-year-old Florence Gordon—blunt, brilliant, and fiercely independent—finally has time to write her memoir. Then her son's family descends, dragging their chaos into her carefully ordered world.
author_bios: Brian Morton has written several novels, including Starting Out in the Evening and Florence Gordon, as well as the memoir Tasha. He teaches at Sarah Lawrence College and has been honored with the Guggenheim Fellowship, the Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the Koret Jewish Book Award for Fiction, and the Pushcart Prize. Morton has also been a finalist for both the PEN/Faulkner Award and the Kirkus Prize for Fiction. Starting Out in the Evening was adapted into a film that premiered at Sundance in 2007.
quotes:
"What a treat it is to read Brian Morton's latest novel, populated with the prickly, civic-minded liberal intellectuals we've come to expect from him...self-aware and humorous...Morton doesn't insult us with cheesy, sentimental break-throughs, but he does offer this comfort — characters who are so believable you expect to run into them ordering from the deli counter at Zabar's."

—NPR

"Angular and comic."

—The New Yorker

"Lovely...Mr. Morton crafts an ending that is partly sad, partly hopeful and, like life, inconclusive."

—Wall Street Journal

title: The City and Its Uncertain Walls
long_summary:
After a six-year absence, Haruki Murakami delivers a spellbinding return to the mysterious realm he first introduced readers to decades ago—a liminal space where professional Dream Readers archive the subconscious and human shadows exist as separate entities.

This ethereal tale intertwines romance, grief, and humanity's eternal quest for purpose against the backdrop of our fragmented modern existence. Libraries and literature itself become central characters, transformed into sacred spaces where narratives find refuge and continue to pulse with life. Murakami constructs a story that transcends time while addressing the anxieties of our post-pandemic era, employing his distinctive fusion of supernatural elements with everyday reality.

Equal parts romantic odyssey and existential inquiry, The City and Its Uncertain Walls demonstrates Murakami's artistic maturity. He creates a universe governed by the fluid rules of dreams yet anchored in recognizable human experience, where the lines separating recollection from invention, the tangible from the imagined, dissolve into something luminous and profound.
short_summary: Murakami returns to his enigmatic Town where dreams are catalogued and shadows drift free. A haunting meditation on love, libraries, and meaning in our fractured world.
author_bios: Born in Kyoto in 1949, Haruki Murakami currently resides near Tokyo and has achieved global literary recognition with translations spanning more than fifty languages. His distinguished career includes receiving the prestigious Cino Del Duca World Prize, an honor previously bestowed upon literary giants Jorge Luis Borges, Ismail Kadare, Mario Vargas Llosa, and Joyce Carol Oates.
quotes:
"Mysterious, illusive… there is something about the way [Murakami] writes that is so captivating."

—Rumaan Alam, The Today Show

"Astonishing, puzzling, and hallucinatory as only Murakami can be, and one of his most satisfying tales."

—Kirkus

"The ingenuity of Murakami's tale lies in the resonances he establishes between the two worlds…It's an astonishing achievement."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Automatic Noodle
long_summary:
In the ruins of post-war San Francisco, a collection of forgotten robots awakens in an empty commercial kitchen. These mechanical beings discover they possess an unexpected talent: creating extraordinary hand-pulled noodles that bring comfort to a traumatized city still healing from conflict.

Their culinary venture becomes more than just a business—it transforms into a beacon of hope for both the robots seeking purpose and the humans craving connection. Yet success breeds opposition, and a coordinated attack through fake negative reviews threatens to destroy everything they've built.

Facing systematic discrimination and the challenge of existing in a society that never intended to include them, these unlikely restaurateurs must forge alliances with their patrons and neighbors. Their struggle raises profound questions about belonging, community, and what it means to carve out space for yourself when the world considers you obsolete. The kitchen becomes a battleground where identity, acceptance, and the simple act of sharing a meal hold the power to reshape both artificial and human lives.
short_summary: Deactivated robots start a noodle restaurant in post-war San Francisco, serving hand-pulled perfection to recovering humans. When malicious reviews threaten their business, they must rally their community to survive in a world not designed for them.
genres: Fiction / Science Fiction / Androids, Robots & Artificial Intelligences
author_bios: Annalee Newitz creates both speculative fiction and investigative nonfiction that examines technology's impact on society. Their novels include The Terraformers (a Nebula Award finalist), The Future of Another Timeline (winner of the Sidewise Award), and Autonomous (winner of a Lambda Literary Award), alongside nonfiction works Four Lost Cities: A Secret History of the Urban Age and Stories Are Weapons: Psychological Warfare and the American Mind. Newitz contributes regularly to the New York Times, maintains a monthly column for New Scientist, co-hosts the three-time Hugo Award-winning podcast Our Opinions Are Correct, and previously founded io9 while serving as editor-in-chief of Gizmodo.
quotes:
"This is a story—about building community despite adversity, fighting for your rights and individuality, and creating art that you want to see in the world—that I didn't know I needed right now. And it was so much fun to read!"

—Martha Wells, author of The Murderbot Diaries and Witch King

"Newitz packs this tale with simmering action, endearing characters, and political savvy, topping it all off with generous dollops of humor and imagination. It's delicious."

—Publishers Weekly

"This is a feel-good hopepunk story that will appeal to readers of both robot and AI-centered science fiction...highly recommended for those who loved novels such as Adrian Tchaikovsky's Service Model and Aimee Ogden's Emergent Properties."

—Library Journal

title: Little Fires Everywhere
long_summary:
The meticulously ordered community of Shaker Heights operates on rigid expectations and unspoken rules, where conformity masquerades as harmony. Elena Richardson has built her life around these principles, finding comfort in predictability and social conventions.

This carefully maintained equilibrium shatters with the arrival of Mia Warren and her daughter Pearl. Mia's artistic sensibilities and unconventional choices clash with everything Elena holds sacred. As the Warren women integrate into the Richardson family's orbit, their presence exposes the fault lines beneath Shaker Heights' polished surface.

A local adoption case becomes the catalyst for deeper divisions. The legal battle over a Chinese-American infant forces residents to confront uncomfortable truths about privilege, race, and belonging. Elena and Mia find themselves on opposite sides, their philosophical differences escalating into personal warfare.

Elena's determination to expose Mia's hidden past transforms into dangerous obsession. The investigation she launches will unravel more than just one woman's secrets—it threatens to destroy the very foundations both women have built their identities upon. Ng examines how the pursuit of perfection can become its own form of destruction, questioning whether any life can truly be contained within prescribed boundaries.
short_summary: Two mothers collide when an enigmatic artist and her daughter disrupt a picture-perfect Ohio suburb. A custody battle ignites long-simmering tensions about race, class, and what makes a family.
author_bios: Celeste Ng has written three novels that became New York Times bestsellers: Everything I Never Told You, Little Fires Everywhere, and Our Missing Hearts. Her writing has earned recognition from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation through prestigious fellowships. Readers worldwide have embraced her work, with translations available in more than thirty languages.
quotes:
"To say I love this book is an understatement. It's a deep psychological mystery about the power of motherhood, the intensity of teenage love, and the danger of perfection. It moved me to tears."

—Reese Witherspoon

"Yes, it's the story of one Ohio town, but Little Fires Everywhere is not that familiar tale of the underside of the American suburb. It's a powerful work about parenthood and politics, adolescent strife and artistic ambition, and the stark choice between conformity and community. Celeste Ng possesses the remarkable ability to write about the most serious of subjects with the lightest possible touch."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave The World Behind

"I cracked open this book mid-morning and did not even move again until it was time to turn on a light. What a joy it was to be so thoroughly taken, to let the chores and clocks and even my own breathing stop while I raced through these pages. Celeste Ng once again proves she is a force to be reckoned with. Little Fires Everywhere is a deft, smoldering masterpiece."

—Mira Jacob, author of Good Talk: A Memoir

title: Everything I Never Told You
long_summary:
The Lee family's world shatters when their teenage daughter's body is discovered in a lake. In 1970s Ohio, this mixed-race family had carefully balanced their aspirations and anxieties, with parents who poured their deferred dreams into their children. The tragedy exposes the fault lines that had long threatened their stability.

Ng crafts an intimate examination of how families fracture under pressure. Each family member carries private burdens and unspoken disappointments that have accumulated over years of trying to belong in a community where they stand apart. The novel reveals how love can become suffocating when filtered through unfulfilled ambitions, and how the desire to protect can inadvertently isolate.

Through alternating perspectives and shifting timelines, the story unravels the complex dynamics that led to this devastating moment. It's a meditation on identity, belonging, and the price of trying to live up to others' visions of who we should become.
short_summary: When a Chinese American teenager dies in 1970s Ohio, her family's carefully constructed facade crumbles. Ng's devastating debut explores the weight of expectations and the secrets that divide us.
author_bios: Celeste Ng has written three novels that became New York Times bestsellers: Everything I Never Told You, Little Fires Everywhere, and Our Missing Hearts. Her writing has earned recognition from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation through prestigious fellowships. Readers worldwide have embraced her work, with translations available in more than thirty languages.
quotes:
"If we know this story, we haven't seen it yet in American fiction, not until now . . . Ng has set two tasks in this novel's doubled heart—to be exciting, and to tell a story bigger than whatever is behind the crime. She does both by turning the nest of familial resentments into at least four smaller, prickly mysteries full of secrets the family members won't share . . . What emerges is a deep, heartfelt portrait of a family struggling with its place in history, and a young woman hoping to be the fulfillment of that struggle. This is, in the end, a novel about the burden of being the first of your kind—a burden you do not always survive."

—Alexander Chee, bestselling author of How to Write an Autobiographical Novel, Edinburgh and The Queen of the Night

"Both a propulsive mystery and a profound examination of a mixed-race family, Ng's explosive debut chronicles the plight of Marilyn and James Lee after their favored daughter is found dead in a lake."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Tender and merciless all at once . . . Vital in all the essential ways."

—Jesmyn Ward, author of Men We Reaped & Sing, Unburied, Sing, A National Book Award winner

title: The Vulnerables
long_summary:
In a world that seems to demand both mourning and laughter, a woman living alone finds herself contemplating what survival means in our fractured times. Her solitude becomes unexpectedly populated when she encounters a young person struggling to find direction and a remarkable parrot whose presence brings unexpected joy.

Laughter emerges as both shield and salve, while the boundaries between strangers begin to dissolve through simple gestures of kindness. These unlikely companions discover that understanding doesn't always require grand revelations—sometimes it arrives through the quiet recognition of shared vulnerability.

Nunez crafts a story that questions not only how we endure uncertainty but why we create art in the face of it. The novel becomes a mirror reflecting our need for meaning, examining whether literature can still offer solace when the world feels increasingly incomprehensible. Through intimate moments between characters who might otherwise remain invisible to each other, the book suggests that healing often begins with the courage to witness another person's struggles without turning away.
short_summary: Nunez follows her National Book Award winner with another quiet stunner about finding connection in isolation. A solitary narrator, an adrift Gen Z-er, and a spirited parrot named Eureka discover how small acts of caring can transform strangers into family.
author_bios: Sigrid Nunez has written numerous novels including A Feather on the Breath of God, The Last of Her Kind, The Friend, and What Are You Going Through. She also penned Sempre Susan: A Memoir of Susan Sontag. Her literary achievements include winning the National Book Award, receiving the Rome Prize in Literature, and earning a Guggenheim Fellowship. Her work reaches readers worldwide through translations into thirty languages, and she makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Once you discover Sigrid Nunez, you don't look back."

—Anne Enright

"Hilarious and deeply reflective."

—Time

"I am committed, until one of us dies, to Nunez's novels. I find them ideal. They are short, wise, provocative, funny — good and strong company."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: The Swimmers
long_summary:
A community swimming pool serves as sanctuary for its regulars, each finding rhythm and peace in their designated lanes. This fragile ecosystem shatters when structural damage forces the pool's closure, leaving its devoted swimmers adrift.

Among them is Alice, for whom these daily swims represented far more than exercise—they were her lifeline against advancing dementia. The structured environment and familiar faces provided crucial anchoring points as her mind began to slip. Now, without this essential routine, Alice tumbles deeper into confusion and displacement.

Memories flood back with overwhelming intensity: her childhood, the trauma of internment during World War II, fragments of a life she's struggling to hold onto. Meanwhile, her daughter watches helplessly as her mother's condition accelerates, their relationship complicated by years of distance and misunderstanding.

Otsuka weaves together themes of community, ritual, and the devastating fragility of human connection. The novel examines how seemingly small disruptions can cascade into profound loss, and how memory—both personal and collective—shapes our understanding of home and belonging.
short_summary: When their community pool cracks and closes, regular swimmers lose their anchor to routine and solace. For Alice, battling dementia, this disruption becomes devastating. Otsuka crafts a luminous meditation on memory, loss, and the fragile structures that hold us together.
author_bios: Julie Otsuka grew up in California and has received a Guggenheim Fellowship. She published When the Emperor Was Divine, which earned the 2003 Asian American Literary Award and the 2003 American Library Association's Alex Award. Her follow-up work, The Buddha in the Attic, became a National Book Award finalist and claimed multiple honors including the 2012 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, the 2011 Langum Prize in American Historical Fiction, the Prix Femina Étranger, and the Albatros Literaturpreis. Otsuka currently resides in New York City.
quotes:
"Otsuka's prose is powerfully subdued: She builds lists and litanies that appear unassuming, even quotidian, until the paragraph comes to an end, and you find yourself stunned by what she has managed, your throat tight with the beautiful detail . . . This is a novel of not just accumulation, but repetition, scenes looping in the way that the mind does, or the way swimmers swim laps. Compounded, these accretions build to an incredible feeling of loss, and too-late-ness . . . In a time of monotony and chaos, when death is as concrete as it is unimaginable, and when cracks can and do appear in the pool for no discernible reason, The Swimmers is an exquisite companion."

—Rachel Khong, The New York Times

"Once per decade we are graced with a new book by Otsuka, the award-winning author of 2012's The Buddha in the Attic and 2003's When The Emperor Was Divine. This year's novel starts as a catalogue of spoken and unspoken rules for swimmers at an aquatic center but unfolds into a powerful story of a mother's dementia and her daughter's love. If Otsuka doesn't write another novel for several years, it will be okay. This is one to be savored and reread."

—Becky Meloan, The Washington Post

"The Swimmers is a slim brilliant novel about the value and beauty of mundane routines that shape our days and identities; or, maybe it's a novel about the cracks that, inevitably, will one day appear to undermine our own bodies and minds; and — who knows? — it could also be read as a grand parable about the crack in the world wrought by this pandemic . . . Otsuka's signature spare style as a writer unexpectedly suits her capacious vision . . . The Swimmers has the verve and playfulness of spoken word poetry."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: A Tale for the Time Being
long_summary:
Two women separated by an ocean find their lives intertwined through the mysterious contents of a lunchbox that crosses the Pacific. In Japan, teenager Nao grapples with isolation and cruelty at school, turning to her diary as she contemplates a desperate choice. Her writing becomes a bridge to her great-grandmother's extraordinary century of life as a Buddhist nun, revealing stories that span generations.

Meanwhile, on a distant island, writer Ruth stumbles upon this very diary among objects that may have traveled from Japan's 2011 tsunami. As Ruth becomes absorbed in Nao's world, the boundaries between reader and subject begin to dissolve, drawing her into questions about fate, connection, and her own path forward.

Ozeki crafts a meditation on how stories travel through time and space, touching lives in unexpected ways. The novel examines the threads that bind us across cultures and continents, while exploring profound questions about existence, memory, and the power of bearing witness to another's experience.
short_summary: When a Hello Kitty lunchbox washes ashore in British Columbia, it connects a Japanese teenager's diary with a novelist across the ocean. Ozeki weaves Zen philosophy, quantum physics, and human connection in a dazzling story of time and being.
author_bios: Ruth Ozeki writes novels, makes films, and serves as a Zen Buddhist priest. Her four published novels include My Year of Meats, All Over Creation, A Tale for the Time Being—which earned the LA Times Book Prize and was shortlisted for the 2013 Booker Prize and National Book Critics' Circle Award—and The Book of Form and Emptiness, which claimed the 2022 Women's Prize for Fiction. Ozeki currently holds the Grace Jarcho Ross 1933 Professor of Humanities position at Smith College.
quotes:
"Ozeki's absorbing novel is an extended meditation on writing, time, and people in time. . . . The characters' lives are finely drawn, from Ruth's rustic lifestyle to the Yasutani family's straitened existence after moving from Sunnyvale, California, to Tokyo. Nao's winsome voice contrasts with Ruth's intellectual ponderings to make up a lyrical disquisition on writing's power to transcend time and place. This tale from Ozeki, a Zen Buddhist priest, is sure to please anyone who values a good story broadened with intellectual vigor."

—Publishers Weekly

"An extraordinary novel about a courageous young woman, riven by loneliness, by time, and (ultimately) by tsunami. Nao is an inspired narrator and her quest to tell her great grandmother's story, to connect with her past and with the larger world is both aching and true. Ozeki is one of my favorite novelists and here she is at her absolute best—bewitching, intelligent, hilarious, and heartbreaking, often on the same page."

—Junot Díaz, Pulitzer Prize winner and author of This Is How You Lose Her

"One of the most deeply moving and thought-provoking novels I have read in a long time. In precise and luminous prose, Ozeki captures both the sweep and detail of our shared humanity. The result is gripping, fearless, inspiring and true."

—Madeline Miller, author of the Orange Prize winner The Song of Achilles & Circe

title: Commonwealth
long_summary:
A single impulsive moment at a family gathering becomes the catalyst for decades of intertwined lives. Two separate households suddenly find themselves bound together through betrayal, divorce, and an unexpected blending of families that nobody quite knows how to navigate.

The children—six of them from two broken marriages—create their own world during long summer visits, developing relationships that transcend the chaos their parents have created. Their shared experiences become both refuge and burden, forming connections that will define them well into adulthood.

Years later, one of these children shares their family's intimate history with a famous novelist, who transforms their private pain into public art. This betrayal of trust forces the siblings to confront not only their complicated past but also questions about who has the right to tell whose story.

Patchett examines how a single afternoon can reshape multiple lives across generations, while questioning the ethics of turning real relationships into fiction. The novel reveals how families form in unexpected ways and how the stories we tell about ourselves can both heal and wound.
short_summary: When an uninvited guest kisses the wrong woman at a christening party, two families are forever changed. Patchett traces five decades of consequences with her signature blend of humor and heartbreak.
author_bios: Ann Patchett has written multiple novels, including the recent #1 New York Times bestseller Tom Lake, along with nonfiction works and children's literature. Among her many honors are the PEN/Faulkner Award, the Women's Prize for Fiction, and the Book Sense Book of the Year. The Dutch House earned her a Pulitzer Prize nomination. Time magazine recognized her as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World, and President Biden presented her with the National Humanities Medal. She operates Parnassus Books in Nashville, Tennessee.
quotes:
"Exquisite... Commonwealth is impossible to put down."

—The New York Times

"Patchett's storytelling has never seemed more effortlessly graceful. This is minimalism that magically speaks volumes…"

—The Washington Post

"The genius of the way Patchett approached Commonwealth is that it's constructed like a puzzle… Maybe it's another case of the tried-and-true adage: "Write what you know." Because this book? It's pure gangbusters."

—San Francisco Chronicle

title: The Leftovers
long_summary:
What do you do when the impossible becomes reality? Tom Perrotta tackles this question by dropping readers into a world where millions of people have simply disappeared without warning or reason. The survivors face a reality that defies logic, leaving them to navigate grief without closure and search for meaning in chaos.

Mayor Kevin Garvey finds himself at the center of this upheaval, tasked with holding his community together while watching his own family splinter. Each member of the Garvey household responds to trauma differently—some seek solace in mysterious movements, others chase false prophets, and still others retreat into themselves entirely.

Perrotta weaves together the personal and universal, showing how catastrophe ripples through individual lives and entire communities. The novel examines our desperate need for explanations in an inexplicable world, and questions whether faith can survive when everything we thought we knew crumbles. With his signature blend of humor and heartbreak, Perrotta creates a story that feels both surreal and deeply human.
short_summary: After millions vanish in a mysterious global event, the survivors grapple with grief, faith, and shattered certainties. Perrotta balances dark comedy with genuine heartbreak in this profound meditation on loss.
author_bios: Tom Perrotta has written eleven works of fiction, including the novels Election and Little Children, both of which were adapted into Oscar-nominated films. His books The Leftovers and Mrs. Fletcher were transformed into acclaimed HBO series. Perrotta's latest novel is Ghost Town.

title: Night Film
long_summary:
Scott McGrath's investigation into Ashley Cordova's apparent suicide pulls him into a labyrinth of secrets surrounding her enigmatic father, Stanislas Cordova. The cult horror filmmaker has maintained complete anonymity for decades, emerging only through his disturbing cinematic works that have spawned devoted followers and whispered legends.

McGrath's obsession with exposing Cordova previously destroyed his personal and professional life, yet he cannot resist this new opportunity to penetrate the director's carefully constructed mystery. Accompanied by unexpected companions, the journalist descends into a world where the boundaries between Cordova's fictional horrors and reality become increasingly unclear.

The investigation transforms into something far more dangerous than McGrath anticipated, as he discovers that proximity to the Cordova family comes with a price. Each revelation about the reclusive filmmaker draws McGrath deeper into a psychological maze that challenges his perception of truth itself. The question becomes whether he can uncover Cordova's secrets before they consume him entirely.
short_summary: When a reclusive horror director's daughter dies under mysterious circumstances, an investigative journalist risks everything to uncover the truth. Pessl crafts a spellbinding thriller that blurs the line between reality and nightmare.
author_bios: Marisha Pessl has written several acclaimed novels including the New York Times bestseller Night Film, Special Topics in Calamity Physics, and the young adult title Neverworld Wake. She currently resides in New York with her husband and three daughters.
quotes:
"Night Film has been precision-engineered to be read at high velocity, and its energy would be the envy of any summer blockbuster. Your average writer of thrillers should lust for Pessl's deft touch with character."

—Joe Hill, The New York Times

"Inventive . . . Think Edgar Allan Poe and Stephen King meet Guillermo del Toro."

—Kirkus

"Maniacally clever . . . Cordova is a monomaniacal genius who creeps into the darkest crevices of the human psyche. . . . As a study of a great mythmaker, Night Film is an absorbing act of myth-making itself. . . . Dastardly fun . . . The plot feels like an M. C. Escher nightmare about Edgar Allan Poe. . . . You'll miss your subway stop, let dinner burn and start sleeping with the lights on."

—The Washington Post

title: Bewilderment
long_summary:
The universe holds countless mysteries, but for Theo Byrne, the most puzzling enigma exists much closer to home. His nine-year-old son Robin possesses an artist's sensitivity and deep empathy for endangered creatures, yet struggles with explosive anger that threatens his place in school. After losing his wife, Theo faces an impossible choice between medicating his child or pursuing an untested therapy that would use his late wife's neural recordings to teach Robin emotional regulation.

This story weaves together the vastness of space with the intimate struggles of a fractured family. As Theo searches distant galaxies for signs of life, he grapples with nurturing the complex inner world of his son on a planet facing ecological collapse. The novel asks profound questions about inheritance—what we pass down to our children, and whether hope can survive in a world marked by loss and environmental crisis.
short_summary: An astrobiologist raising his troubled son after his wife's death discovers an experimental therapy using her recorded brain patterns. Powers weaves together cosmic wonder and intimate grief in this tender exploration of parenthood on a damaged planet.
author_bios: Richard Powers has written fourteen novels, among them The Overstory, Bewilderment, and Orfeo. His work has earned him the MacArthur Fellowship, the Pulitzer Prize, and the National Book Award. Powers makes his home in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.
quotes:
"Richard Powers is one of our country's greatest living writers. He composes some of the most beautiful sentences I've ever read. I'm in awe of his talent."

—Inventive . . . Think Edgar Allan Poe and Stephen King meet Guillermo del Toro, Kirkus

"Extraordinary.…Powers's insightful, often poetic prose draws us at once more deeply toward the infinitude of the imagination and more vigorously toward the urgencies of the real and familiar stakes rattling our persons and our planet."

—Tracy K. Smith, The New York Times

"A heartrending tale of loss.…Powers continues to raise bold questions about the state of our world and the cumulative effects of our mistakes."

—Heller McAlpin, NPR

title: The Overstory
long_summary:
Trees hold secrets that most humans never discover—until a disparate group of individuals begins to perceive what has been hidden in plain sight all along. A Vietnam veteran's survival depends on an ancient banyan's embrace. A woman inherits decades of photographs chronicling a single chestnut tree's fate. After a near-death experience, a student finds herself guided by luminous beings toward a deeper understanding of the living world.

As these characters—along with others who have stumbled upon nature's hidden language—cross paths, they become unlikely allies in a battle to protect America's remaining old-growth forests. Their personal awakenings mirror a larger reckoning with humanity's place in an ecosystem far more complex and sentient than most people imagine.

Powers constructs a narrative that mirrors the very forests it celebrates: interconnected, layered, and pulsing with life that extends far beyond individual stories. The novel interrogates whether humans can learn to see beyond their own brief existence to recognize the ancient intelligence that surrounds them, and what it might cost—or save—to finally listen.
short_summary: Nine strangers find their lives transformed by trees, leading them to a desperate fight to save ancient forests. Powers weaves ecology and activism into an extraordinary meditation on our relationship with the natural world.
author_bios: Richard Powers has written fourteen novels, among them The Overstory, Bewilderment, and Orfeo. His work has earned him the MacArthur Fellowship, the Pulitzer Prize, and the National Book Award. Powers makes his home in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.
quotes:
"An ingeniously structured narrative that branches and canopies like the trees at the core of the story whose wonder and connectivity echo those of the humans living amongst them."

—citation from the Pulitzer Prize in Fiction

"Autumn makes me think of leaves, which makes me think of trees, which makes me think of The Overstory, the best novel ever written about trees, and really, just one of the best novels, period."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Monumental…The Overstory accomplishes what few living writers from either camp, art or science, could attempt. Using the tools of the story, he pulls readers heart-first into a perspective so much longer-lived and more subtly developed than the human purview that we gain glimpses of a vast, primordial sensibility, while watching our own kind get whittled down to size....A gigantic fable of genuine truths."

—Barbara Kingsolver, The New York Times

title: The Five Wounds
long_summary:
Amadeo Padilla's spiritual awakening takes an unexpected turn when his teenage daughter arrives unannounced, carrying more than just her belongings. At thirty-three, he's finally found purpose preparing to portray Christ in his New Mexico town's Easter ceremony—until Angel's pregnancy forces him to confront a different kind of responsibility.

What unfolds is a year-long examination of family bonds stretched to their limits. Three generations of women—Angel's grandmother Yolanda, her estranged mother Marissa, and the determined teenager herself—circle around Amadeo, each carrying their own wounds and expectations. Meanwhile, the family patriarch Tíve watches with disapproval as old patterns threaten to repeat.

Valdez Quade crafts an intimate portrait of people trying to break cycles they barely understand. As Angel's baby grows, so do the questions about what it means to be worthy of love, whether redemption is possible for the deeply flawed, and how families survive when everyone is drowning. The result is a deeply human story about the gap between who we want to be and who we actually are, set against the backdrop of a community where faith and failure walk hand in hand.
short_summary: When pregnant fifteen-year-old Angel arrives at her unemployed father's doorstep during Holy Week, five generations of a New Mexican family must navigate love, sacrifice, and redemption together.
author_bios: Kirstin Valdez Quade wrote Night at the Fiestas, which earned the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize. The National Book Foundation honored her with a "5 Under 35" award, and she currently teaches at Princeton University while residing in New Jersey.
quotes:
"Kirstin Valdez Quade writes with exquisite precision about the fragility and resilience of the Padilla family…I loved The Five Wounds, which reminded me that growing pains are not confined to adolescence and that people can be newborn at any age. Even its most excruciating moments are charged with a luminous compassion."

—Karen Russell, author of Orange World and Other Stories & Swamplandia!

"With deep empathy, fierce intelligence, and subtle wit, Kirstin Valdez Quade has crafted an indelible portrait of a family living in precarity. The characters in The Five Wounds are so vivid, their grasping efforts toward love and redemption so finely wrought, and each page full of such immaculate prose, that I read this novel with ever-increasing breathless urgency."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment & Missionaries

"You hold in your hands a small, complete universe vibrating with joy and grief, humor and absurdity and delight. All the fabulous mess of humanity is, somehow, in these pages. The Five Wounds is bighearted, tender, wise, and shot through with moments of pure grace."

—C Pam Zhang, author of Land of Milk and Honey & How Much of These Hills Is Gold

title: The New Earth
long_summary:
The Wilcox family carries the weight of secrets that have kept them apart for over a decade. What began as a revelation about hidden ancestry spiraled into tragedy when activism turned deadly on foreign soil. Now a wedding forces this fractured Jewish family to emerge from years of deliberate distance and emotional exile.

Each family member has retreated into their own form of isolation, nursing wounds both personal and ideological. The prospect of reunion threatens to resurrect questions they've avoided: How do we reconcile family loyalty with moral conviction? Can love survive the collision of identity, politics, and loss?

Row constructs a sprawling narrative that refuses to stay within traditional boundaries, weaving together multiple perspectives and global contexts. The novel interrogates the American family as a site where private grief intersects with larger questions of race, justice, and belonging. Through the Wilcoxes' struggle to find common ground, the story examines whether forgiveness is possible when the very foundations of who we thought we were have been shattered.
short_summary: Fifteen years after tragedy tore them apart, the Wilcox family must reunite for a wedding and confront the personal and political wounds they've spent decades avoiding.
author_bios: Jess Row has published the novel Your Face in Mine, the essay collection White Flights: Race, Fiction, and the American Imagination, and two collections of short stories: The Train to Lo Wu and Nobody Ever Gets Lost. His work has earned him a Guggenheim Fellowship and a Whiting Writers Award, with pieces appearing in The New Yorker, The Atlantic, Granta, and numerous other publications. Row teaches at NYU and divides his time between New York City and Plainfield, Vermont.
quotes:
"Magnificent…The Wilcoxes suffer as many contemporary crises as the Lamberts of Jonathan Franzen, but they prove both more engaged and more moving. The panorama that comes to life around them feels like a masterpiece for our fractured time."

—Los Angeles Times

"[A] deeply ambitious, genre-defying work, which hops back and forth in time, shifts between various points of view, and incorporates a massive amount of politics and theory on race, Zen Buddhism, climate change, the history of Israel and Palestine, and, among other things, the novel itself as a literary form."

—Kirkus

"A rich, rollicking novel about a dysfunctional Jewish clan from the Upper West Side and the 2003 West Bank tragedy that derailed them. . . Row] gracefully balances multiple registers to craft a reader's delight. . . . Row retains a deep affection for his cast, arguably more than they deserve. He breathes wondrous life into them. Their neuroses — so many neuroses — click into place. Each character's thoughts scamper like mice through mazes, a science experiment gone wrong, and yet the data they yield bolsters a tale that's both experimental and Balzacian, lighthearted and dead serious."

—The Washington Post

title: Hombrecito
long_summary:
A mother and son flee Colombia for Miami, carrying dreams that quickly fracture against American reality. She abandons her medical career for restaurant work while he navigates adolescence caught between two languages, two cultures, and an emerging sense of himself that doesn't fit traditional expectations.

Their relationship becomes the novel's emotional center—intense, complicated, sometimes suffocating in its devotion. As he matures and moves to New York, romantic relationships offer glimpses of connection but never quite fill the void left by displacement. The pull of family and homeland eventually draws him back to Colombia, where long-buried family truths finally surface.

Sanchez examines how immigration reshapes not just geography but identity itself, particularly for those who must also reconcile their sexuality with cultural expectations. The novel interrogates what it means to belong when you exist in the spaces between—between countries, between languages, between the person your family expects and the person you're becoming. This is literature that understands how love and loss intertwine, how the search for home can lead through many different hearts and places before finding its destination.
short_summary: A Colombian boy and his mother navigate exile, identity, and the fierce complexity of their bond. Sanchez crafts a luminous debut about queerness, immigration, and finding home between worlds.
author_bios: Born in Ibagué, Colombia, Santiago Jose Sanchez writes fiction that has appeared in McSweeney's Quarterly, ZYZZYVA, Subtropics, and Joyland. After completing degrees at Yale University and the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Sanchez joined the faculty at Grinnell College. The queer Colombian American author splits time between Iowa, Miami, and New York City, with Hombrecito marking their first novel.
quotes:
"Dynamic, electrifying, and oh so tender, Hombrecito is the rare kind of page-turner I devoured in two sittings. Utterly American and Colombian, this is a magnificent story for anyone on a mission to redefine home, loss, and love in all its complicated forms and sources."

—Xochitl Gonzalez, author of Anita de Monte Laughs Last & Olga Dies Dreaming

"Captures with rare vividness the rapture and terror of childhood, the way self-making and self-destruction can grow so tangled as to be indistinguishable. This is a novel of enormous insight, musicality, and love. Sanchez is a stunning new talent."

—Garth Greenwell, author of Cleanness

"Hombrecito soars. A gorgeous, intense, and moving portrait of queerness, migration, desire, and abiding love. Sanchez has made something beautiful."

—Sarah Thankam Mathews, author of All This Could Be Different

title: The History of Sound
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Ben Shattuck crafts a remarkable tapestry where twelve stories create an intricate dialogue across time, each narrative illuminating secrets buried within others.
