Characters separated by decades and centuries find themselves mysteriously linked through objects, places, and unfinished business that refuses to stay buried.

At the collection's heart lies a tale of two men documenting folk music in Maine's wilderness during World War I, their recordings destined to surface generations later in ways that reshape understanding of their journey. From colonial Nantucket's windswept shores to modern New Hampshire's dense forests, Shattuck weaves a complex web where past and present collide.

What emerges is something far more ambitious than traditional storytelling—a living map of New England where memories crystallize in unexpected forms. Family histories unravel and reconstitute, revealing how trauma and tenderness move through bloodlines like underground rivers. Shattuck demonstrates remarkable skill in showing how artifacts carry emotional weight across generations, transforming simple objects into vessels of profound meaning.

This collection operates as both archaeological dig and love song, unearthing the layers of human experience that accumulate in landscapes we call home.
short_summary: Twelve interconnected stories span three centuries of New England history, where mysteries from one tale find resolution in another. Love, loss, and secrets echo across generations in this luminous exploration of how the past never truly leaves us.
author_bios: Ben Shattuck wrote Six Walks: In the Footsteps of Henry David Thoreau, which earned recognition as a New Yorker Best Book of 2022, Wall Street Journal Best Book of Spring, New York Times Best Book of Summer, New England Indie Bestseller, and Massachusetts Book Award nominee. A graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Ben Shattuck has received the PEN/Robert J. Dau Short Story Prize and a Pushcart Prize. He operates America's oldest general store (established in 1793) and leads the Cuttyhunk Island Writers' Residency while living on the Massachusetts coast with his family.
quotes:
"A magnificent collection about love, longing, and New England history. . . . Shattuck shines especially in his depiction of nature. . . . Deeply felt and impeccably researched, these exquisite stories capture the spirit of the Northeast."

—Publishers Weekly

"Exquisitely crafted, deeply imagined, exhilaratingly diverse, The History of Sound places Ben Shattuck firmly among the very finest of our storytellers."

—Geraldine Brooks, New York Times bestselling author of Horse

"In braiding themselves together, The History of Sound's stories generate the most ingenious and pleasing and moving evocation of New England, in all its seasonal and geographic variety. Over time—from 1696 to Radiolab—mysteries posed in one story are off-handedly addressed years later in another, protagonists become someone else's minor character, and fates are meted out as each new narrative throws a crucial contextualizing light upon the other. Ben Shattuck is a devoted magpie: these stories celebrate the earth's music and bounty, and remind us how diminished we are when severed from who and what we loved."

—Jim Shepard, author of The Book of Aron and Like You'd Understand, Anyway

title: Companion Piece
long_summary:
What begins as an unexpected call from an old acquaintance becomes something far more complex—a meditation on isolation, language, and the strange ways history echoes across centuries. The conversation centers on a riddle without clear resolution, while memories surface of bureaucratic detention and inexplicable questioning.

Smith weaves these contemporary fragments together with the story of a medieval metalworker, cast out from her community and forced to wander. The connection between a woman navigating pandemic restrictions and a craftsperson surviving plague-era persecution reveals unexpected parallels between our current moment and humanity's distant past.

This latest work examines how stories function not as neat conclusions but as ongoing inquiries into meaning. Through wordplay and temporal shifts, Smith creates a meditation on resilience, creativity, and the threads that bind disparate experiences across time. The result challenges readers to consider how artistic expression and human connection persist even when the world seems fractured beyond repair.
short_summary: A woman receives a cryptic phone call that spirals into reflections on language, art, and connection during lockdown. Smith blends playfulness and poignancy in a novel both timely and timeless.
author_bios: Ali Smith has written numerous fiction works, including her recent Companion Piece, the "Seasonal Quartet," Public library and other stories, and How to be both, which earned the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction, the Goldsmiths Prize, and the Costa Novel Award. Four times short-listed for the Man Booker Prize, Smith also received the George Orwell Prize for Political Fiction for Summer. A native of Inverness, Scotland, she currently resides in Cambridge, England.
quotes:
“Superb. . . . Martina was held and questioned while transporting the centuries-old Boothby Lock for the museum where she works. “It’s really beautiful,” Martina tells Sandy. “It’s really cunning too. You could never tell by looking at it that it’s even a lock, or that it has any mechanism at all inside it, never mind find how or where the key goes into it to open it.” Which is, of course, a fine description of this novel, itself a lock, crafted by a smith, that is, by A. Smith, demanding in the engagement it requires, and rewarding of that engagement, as one picks away at the words she has used to build it. . . . [A] remarkable novel.”—Mohsin Hamid, The New York Times

"Intricate . . . Expansive and tantalizing . . . As ever, Smith’s flawless stream-of-conscious narration is at once accessible and transforming, and with it she manages to contain eye-blinking hallucinatory images, such as a shattered clock that reconstitutes itself. This is a captivating Rubik’s cube of fiction.”—Publishers Weekly

“[T]his touching entertainment . . . is Smith's pandemic land, where myth and reality converse, where lockdown might evoke medieval artisanry, and where wordplay is more than playful. The Scottish author’s 12th novel displays once again her ingenuity in pulling together disparate narrative strands . . . With art and humor, Ali is the smith who forges links for her idiosyncratic narrative, one of which is the value of acts of kindness amid distress. A truly marvelous tale of pandemic and puns and endurance.“—Kirkus

title: Flesh
long_summary:
István's adolescence in Hungary begins with displacement—a shy teenager navigating unfamiliar social terrain in a new town. His inability to connect with classmates sets off a chain of experiences that will define his relationship with the world around him.

As István moves into adulthood, he exists in a state of perpetual drift, dependent on the kindness or calculated interests of others who cross his path. His journey takes unexpected turns, leading him far from the formative experiences that shaped his youth, yet never truly allowing him to escape their influence.

Szalay constructs a meditation on disconnection through fragments of István's life across multiple decades. The protagonist remains fundamentally at war with his own existence, unable to reconcile the person he is with the various identities others project onto him. Past wounds and contemporary indifference create a volatile combination, building toward a moment of crisis that threatens to unravel the fragile stability he has managed to construct. Through precise observation and profound empathy, Szalay maps the invisible scars left by unhealed wounds.
short_summary: István drifts through decades haunted by childhood trauma, estranged from himself and everyone around him. Szalay crafts an existential portrait of modern masculinity with spare prose that resonates long after reading.
author_bios: David Szalay has written six novels including Flesh, Turbulence, Spring, The Innocent, London and the South-East, and All That Man Is. His work has earned him the Booker Prize, the Gordon Burn Prize, and The Paris Review Plimpton Prize for Fiction. Originally from Canada, Szalay spent his formative years in London before settling in Vienna, Austria.
quotes:
"Astonishing...sometimes when I'm reading, one of the things I'm looking for is, how has this person made the novel new? And for me, this novel [is] new...Extraordinary."

—Zadie Smith, Pulitzer Prize finalist and author of The Fraud

"Spare and detached on the page, lush in resonance beyond it, Szalay's new novel reads a bit like an immigrant bildungsroman flavored with Albert Camus."

—NPR

"In István David Szalay has created a modern existential antihero in the grand tradition of Camus and Dostoevsky. Amid the random accidents and desultory decisions that shape his life, and come to feel like fate, he is at once a cool observer and a towering presence. Taut, spare and perfectly structured, Flesh reads like a gripping thriller which slowly gathers to itself the emotional power of classical tragedy."

—Carys Davies, author of Clear

title: Filthy Animals
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Brandon Taylor assembles a constellation of interconnected tales that dissect the raw mechanics of human connection in contemporary America. These stories zero in on moments where desire collides with disappointment, where characters grapple with bodies that betray them and relationships that refuse to offer the solace they seek.

A babysitter confronts her limits when faced with an uncontrollable child. Teenagers discover how quickly social friction can escalate into something darker and more dangerous. At the center of several narratives, a young man finds himself entangled with a couple whose open relationship becomes a laboratory for examining trust, jealousy, and the risks of emotional exposure.

Taylor's characters exist in that precarious space between youth and full adulthood, where every interaction feels both urgent and fragile. Whether dealing with illness that fractures families or navigating the minefield of sexual politics among artists and students, these individuals search for authentic connection while wrestling with their capacity to wound and be wounded. The result is a collection that maps the geography of modern loneliness with surgical precision.
short_summary: Young adults navigate desire, violence, and the brutal mechanics of intimacy in Taylor's psychologically precise follow-up to his Booker-shortlisted debut Real Life.
author_bios: Brandon Taylor wrote The Late Americans and Real Life, with the latter earning a Booker Prize shortlisting and recognition from the National Book Critics Circle John Leonard Prize, plus selection as a New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice. His story collection Filthy Animals received The Story Prize and earned a Dylan Thomas Prize shortlisting. Taylor currently resides in New York City.
quotes:
"The characters at the heart of this elegant storm of stories are ablaze with risk and tenderness. Their voices are bright and clear, the contours of their pains and desires sharp and urgent. A profoundly gifted writer."

—Laura Van Den Berg

"A dazzling showcase for Brandon Taylor's formidable talents—his fierce intellect, his emotional and linguistic precision, his dry and unflinching humor. He is a writer of rare daring, his fiction a series of revelations."

—Katie Kitamura

"A writer who meets life with a rare combination of will, wonderment, temperament, and vitality."

—Yiyun Li

title: Minor Black Figures
long_summary:
In Manhattan's cutthroat gallery scene, a young Black artist finds himself creatively paralyzed. The sterile exhibition spaces and affected conversations leave him cold, and though his day job restoring paintings provides some satisfaction, his own canvas remains stubbornly blank.

Then he encounters someone unexpected: a man who abandoned his calling to the church and now drifts through secular life with equal uncertainty. Their unlikely bond becomes a catalyst, forcing both men to examine uncomfortable truths about race, art, and authenticity. What does it mean to create under the weight of others' expectations? How do we maintain artistic integrity while seeking acceptance in elite circles?

Brandon Taylor crafts an intimate meditation on the price of creative ambition and the relationships that reshape our understanding of ourselves. This novel peels back the glossy veneer of New York's cultural institutions to reveal the raw human struggles beneath—the longing for connection, the fear of compromise, and the courage required to see clearly in a world determined to obscure truth.
short_summary: A Black painter new to Manhattan's art world meets a former seminarian, sparking questions about creativity, desire, and compromise. Taylor's nuanced exploration of friendship and artistic identity.
author_bios: Brandon Taylor wrote The Late Americans and Real Life, with the latter earning Booker Prize and National Book Critics Circle John Leonard Prize shortlists plus New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice recognition. His story collection Filthy Animals won The Story Prize and received a Dylan Thomas Prize shortlist. Taylor currently resides in New York City.
quotes:
"A sharp, resonant novel about a young Black gay painter adrift in New York who spends one life-changing summer grappling with questions of faith, desire, and creative purpose."

—Bustle

"Contemplative and sensuous [with]… the shape of a romance… Taylor is onto something rich and appealing—a story unafraid to foreground love and lust, and that treats emotional ambiguity as a starting point, not as the fuzzy ending common in literary fiction. A piercing, precise, and affecting tale of young love and high art."

—Kirkus

"A brilliant and bold study of racial conflict within art, the white gaze and the Black body, and the messy, traumatic ways people sacrifice for art and life."

—Library Journal

title: God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer
long_summary:
Joseph Thomas returns from military service to find himself caught between worlds—emergency medical technician by night, doctoral student by day, single father always. His shifts in hospital corridors become a space where past trauma intersects with present uncertainty, where the patients he treats sometimes mirror fragments of his own fractured history.

The shadow of his incarcerated father looms large, a man whose crimes against Joseph's teenage mother created the circumstances of Joseph's existence. As Joseph moves through his demanding routine of academic work, medical emergencies, and parenting responsibilities, he begins an unexpected journey toward comprehending this complicated paternal legacy.

His friendship with fellow veteran Ray provides both anchor and mirror—two men attempting to translate wartime brotherhood into civilian connection while battling their own demons. Together they navigate the particular challenges of Black masculinity, the weight of systemic inequities, and the gap between intellectual understanding and lived reality. Thomas constructs a nuanced portrait that refuses easy answers, examining how individuals survive within larger structures of power, punishment, and possibility.
short_summary: A veteran returns from Iraq to navigate doctoral studies, EMS work, and single fatherhood while reckoning with his imprisoned father's legacy. Thomas delivers a raw, innovative exploration of Black life that merges social realism with startling formal invention.
author_bios: Joseph Earl Thomas has written the memoir Sink, the novel God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer, and the forthcoming story collection Leviathan Beach (Grand Central, 2026). His writing has been featured in The Kenyon Review, Virginia Quarterly Review, and The New York Times Book Review. Sink received recognition as a PEN/Jean Stein Book Award longlist selection and William Saroyan International Prize for Writing shortlist finalist. Thomas completed his MFA at University of Notre Dame and PhD at University of Pennsylvania, and currently teaches at Sarah Lawrence College and The Brooklyn Institute for Social Research.
quotes:
"[M]agnificent...In a remarkable feat of formal invention, Thomas collapses time and space, melding Joey's memories with descriptions of patients in the ER...Thomas scales great heights with this innovative blend of social realism and surrealism."

—Publishers Weekly

"Joseph Earl Thomas is a writer of incredible gifts. The voice here is so distinctive, galloping with intelligence, poetry, honesty, and humor. Bless You Otis Spunkmeyer spun me around, like many of my favorite novels, it reads like direct communication from the soul."

—Justin Torres, author of Blackouts & We Were Animals

"What's thrilling to me about God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer is the faith Joseph Earl Thomas places in his readers. There's a supersaturation here that reminds me of Denis Johnson's vertiginous moral questing, and a topography of mind and place that kept making me think of Teju Cole's poet-doctor of the modern metropolis. Thomas gives us a fully peopled world, not by speaking in grand oracular exposition, but by getting granular—we see the Reebok slides on a romantic rival, the crinkled cookie wrappers out of which grow a friendship. It's such a deftly choreographed dance—intoxicating, propulsive—and the result is utterly mesmerizing: here is a whole cosmos, as vivid and unprecedented as our own."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: The Books of Jacob
long_summary:
An enigmatic stranger materializes in an 18th-century Polish village, eventually claiming the identity of Jacob Frank—a figure destined to challenge the religious establishment across two empires. This self-proclaimed prophet accumulates devoted followers while cycling through faiths, embracing Islam before turning to Catholicism, all while being denounced as both charlatan and savior.

Frank's journey cuts through the Habsburg and Ottoman territories, leaving disruption in his wake as whispers of forbidden ceremonies and radical theology spread. Tokarczuk builds her narrative around this actual historical enigma, weaving together testimonies from believers, enemies, confidants, and skeptics to create a kaleidoscopic portrait of a man who defied categorization.

Set against the backdrop of a continent in flux, the novel examines humanity's eternal struggle between doubt and faith, tradition and revolution. The story unfolds through competing voices—each offering their own interpretation of Frank's true nature—while the book itself mirrors ancient Hebrew tradition by numbering its pages backward from 955 to 1, creating a reading experience that moves against conventional time.
short_summary: Tokarczuk's Nobel Prize-winning epic follows the rise and fall of Jacob Frank, a real historical figure who blazed across eighteenth-century Europe as a messianic leader, upending religious and social order.
author_bios: Olga Tokarczuk stands among contemporary literature's most celebrated voices, having received both the Nobel Prize in Literature and the International Booker Prize alongside numerous other distinctions. Her extensive body of work encompasses over a dozen novels, two essay collections, and a children's book, with translations appearing in more than fifty languages worldwide.
quotes:
"Sophisticated and ribald and brimming with folk wit. . . The comedy in this novel blends, as it does in life, with genuine tragedy."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Monumental . . . could help the Swedish Academy restore its rather tattered reputation as an arbiter of serious literature. …Tokarczuk is as comfortable rendering the world of the Jewish peasantry as that of the Polish royal court. . . . Incalculably rich in learning and driven by a faith in the numinous properties of knowledge."

—The Wall Street Journal

"It's just as awe-inspiring as the Nobel judges claimed. . . . Miraculously entertaining and consistently fascinating. Despite his best efforts, Frank never mastered alchemy, but Tokarczuk certainly has. . . . Haunting and irresistible."

—The Washington Post

title: We the Animals
long_summary:
In upstate New York, three young brothers create their own world amid the turbulence of family life. Their parents' relationship burns hot and cold—a Puerto Rican father and white mother whose intense bond shapes everything around them. The boys find adventure in everyday moments, crafting toys from scraps and seeking refuge when adult conflicts erupt.

Told through the eyes of the youngest brother, the story captures how children experience love as something both protective and overwhelming. As he grows older, his understanding of his place in the family—and the world beyond it—begins to shift in unexpected ways.

Torres examines how our earliest relationships forge our sense of self, even as we inevitably outgrow them. The novel traces that delicate moment when childhood's fierce loyalties give way to the pull of individual identity, revealing both the pain and necessity of that transformation.
short_summary: Three mixed-race brothers navigate a childhood of chaos, violence, and fierce love in upstate New York. Torres crafts a coming-of-age story that's both brutal and tender, written in prose that cuts deep.
author_bios: Justin Torres wrote We the Animals, which earned the VCU Cabell First Novelist Award and has been translated into fifteen languages before becoming a feature film. Among his honors are selection as one of the National Book Foundation's 5 Under 35 and fellowships at Stanford University as a Wallace Stegner Fellow, Harvard University's Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, and the New York Public Library's Cullman Center. His fiction appears in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, Granta, Tin House, and The Washington Post. Torres teaches as an associate professor of English at UCLA and makes his home in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"We the Animals is a dark jewel of a book. It's heartbreaking. It's beautiful. It resembles no other book I've read. We should all be grateful for Justin Torres, a brilliant, ferocious new voice."

—Michael Cunningham

"A slender but affecting debut novel by Justin Torres...[a] sensitive, carefully wrought autobiographical first novel...The scenes have the jumbled feel of homemade movies spliced together a little haphazardly, echoing the way memory works: moments of fear or excitement sting with bright clarity years later, while the long passages in between dissolve into nothingness. From the patchwork emerges a narrative of emotional maturing and sexual awakening that is in many ways familiar...but is freshened by the ethnicity of the characters and their background, and the blunt economy of Mr. Torres's writing, lit up by sudden flashes of pained insight."

—The New York Times

"In language brilliant, poised and pure, We the Animals tells about family love as it is felt when it is frustrated or betrayed or made to stand in the place of too many other needed things, about how precious it becomes in these extremes, about the terrible sense of loss when it fails under duress, and the joy and dread of realizing that there really is no end to it."

—Marilynne Robinson

title: Family Meal
long_summary:
Cam's return to Houston brings two complicated relationships back into focus: the persistent presence of Kai, his deceased partner who continues to appear in moments both tender and chaotic, and his fractured friendship with TJ, whose family bakery becomes an unexpected refuge. The years have created distance and hurt between the childhood friends, leaving both men uncertain how to bridge the gap that separates them.

As Cam navigates the weight of loss and the delicate work of rebuilding trust, the story unfolds around themes of forgiveness, the complex nature of chosen family, and the ways food and shared spaces can offer healing. Washington examines how our deepest connections—those forged in childhood and tested by time—can become sources of both profound pain and unexpected grace, suggesting that sometimes the people who know us best are the ones who can teach us the most about love.
short_summary: Haunted by his dead lover and estranged from his best friend, Cam returns to Houston seeking connection. Washington crafts an intimate story about grief, chosen family, and finding nourishment in unexpected places.
author_bios: Bryan Washington has written Lot, Memorial, and Family Meal. He received recognition as a National Book Award 5 Under 35 Honoree and earned the Dylan Thomas Prize, the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award, the Ernest J. Gaines Award, two Lambda Literary Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. He currently lives in Tokyo.
quotes:
"What makes Washington's writing about family so refreshing and complex is how he shows the ways people attempt to demonstrate the emotions they otherwise have trouble expressing to the ones they hold dear.... Family Meal juggles a lot — Cam and TJ are both dealing with their present situations and with the phantoms of opportunities ignored and hard choices enacted — but Washington lays it all out with the control and artistry of a ballet choreographer. Each story line gives the other strength."

—The New York Times

"[A]n achingly and beautifully etched ensemble of young Americans learning to navigate a more universal and human struggle: grief. …Washington is a generous and gentle writer, with a profound capacity to face the cruelty and pain of contemporary American life while simultaneously offering his characters — and readers – an expansive space for self-forgiveness, hope and nourishment."

—The Washington Post

"Family Meal is filled with love—for the sensual pleasure of life, the places that we call home, the beauty of the people around us. This novel will break your heart twice over, with sadness, sure, but more unexpectedly, with joy. It takes a generous writer to show us the world in this way, and Bryan Washington is one of our best."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

title: Ours
long_summary:
Magic and liberation collide in this extraordinary debut that follows a conjurer known as Saint, who wields supernatural forces to destroy slave plantations throughout 1830s Arkansas. The freed souls she rescues find refuge in a hidden settlement called Ours, shielded from the outside world by Saint's mystical abilities.

This sanctuary represents more than escape—it becomes a bold experiment in Black autonomy, where former captives can build lives free from white supremacy's reach. Yet paradise proves fragile. Saint's powers begin to wane, her mind fractures under the weight of traumatic memories, and the town's protective barriers start to crumble.

Strangers with their own supernatural gifts breach the community's defenses, forcing residents to confront uncomfortable truths. Some begin questioning whether their isolation, however well-intentioned, has simply traded physical chains for invisible ones. Williams weaves four decades of this community's evolution into a rich tapestry that draws from African American folklore, spiritual traditions, and surrealist storytelling. The result examines how the pursuit of safety can sometimes conflict with true liberation, and whether any sanctuary—no matter how magical—can fully heal the wounds of systemic oppression.
short_summary: Saint, a powerful conjurer, creates a magical sanctuary for formerly enslaved people in 1830s America. But her utopia faces threats that force residents to question whether safety itself can become another kind of prison.
author_bios: Phillip B. Williams, a Chicago native, has published two acclaimed poetry collections: Thief in the Interior, which earned both the Kate Tufts Discovery Award and Lambda Literary Award, and Mutiny, a PEN/Voelcker Award finalist that won the 2022 American Book Award. His literary achievements include a Whiting Award and fellowships from Harvard's Radcliffe Institute and the National Endowment for the Arts. Williams currently serves on the faculty of NYU's MFA program and Randolph College's low-residency MFA.
quotes:
"A gorgeously written, evocative saga of Black American survival and transcendence, blending elements of fantasy, mythology, and multigenerational history . . . resonant [and] wildly imaginative . . . As in the magical realist sagas of Latin America or the grand fictions of Russian literature, time itself becomes a morphing, enigmatic character in Williams's novel. . . . What keeps you attentive, and the sweeping narrative anchored, are the rich characterizations and, most of all, the often-startling impact of Williams's poetically illuminated language. A multilayered, enrapturing chronicle of freedom that interrogates the nature of freedom itself."

—Kirkus

"Ambitious and lyrical . . . Williams's accomplished narrative leaves readers with much to ponder."

—Publishers Weekly

"Ours is the epic and lyrical debut novel by poet Phillip B. Williams, featuring unforgettable characters woven together with folklore and humanity's search for freedom."

—B&N

"A beautifully written and ambitious epic about the complexity of freedom. Williams crafts an expansive, original world filled with characters who linger long after the final page."

—Brit Bennett, New York Times–bestselling author of The Vanishing Half

title: The Pelican Child
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In these eleven stories, characters drift through a world that seems fundamentally broken, searching for meaning amid environmental collapse and spiritual emptiness. Twin sisters inherit wealth built on industrial destruction and face a reckoning with their family's legacy. A young man clings to boarding school fantasies rather than confront adult realities. Even historical figures like George Gurdjieff appear as restless spirits, unable to find peace.

Williams creates a landscape where fairy tale elements—like Baba Yaga's chicken-legged hut—exist alongside contemporary anxieties about climate change and human disconnection. Her characters inhabit spaces between the real and surreal, often discovering uncomfortable truths about themselves and the damaged world they've inherited.

The collection examines how people respond to living in an age of environmental and moral crisis. Some seek redemption through violence, others through retreat into imagination. Williams captures these moments of recognition with prose that finds unexpected beauty in bleakness, revealing the strange poetry that emerges when people confront their complicity in destruction.
short_summary: Eleven haunting stories from a master of the form. Williams conjures lost souls navigating an indifferent world—from twin heiresses seeking violent recompense to dreamers clinging to childhood innocence.
author_bios: Joy Williams has written five novels, including Harrow, which was a finalist for both the PEN/Jean Stein and Los Angeles Times book prizes, and The Quick and the Dead, a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She has published four story collections and an essay collection, Ill Nature, which was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. Joy Williams received the Rea Award for the Short Story and the Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, which elected her in 2008. She divides her time between Tucson, Arizona, and Laramie, Wyoming.
quotes:
"The protagonists of these gorgeous stories from Williams grapple with mortality and their hold on reality. . . . Throughout, Williams grabs the reader's attention with striking dialogue and arresting conceits. This collection is a gift from a master of the form."

—Publishers Weekly

"Enigmatic, elegant stories by a writer at the pinnacle of her art. Williams has long worked magic with stories that, on the surface, seem quite quotidian, save that something unspoken—and occasionally sinister—lies beneath. . . . Superb, and yet more evidence that Williams should be next in line for the Nobel Prize in Literature."

—Kirkus

"An American master is back with crystalline stories that map the personal and political minefields of her unmoored characters. Williams blends everyday dramas with surreal imagery, her voice and range inspiring awe."

—Boston Globe

title: Interior Chinatown
long_summary:
In Charles Yu's genre-bending narrative, Willis Wu exists in a strange liminal space where his life resembles an endless television production. Cast perpetually in minor, stereotypical roles, he navigates a world that refuses to see him as fully human. His days unfold in a Chinatown restaurant that doubles as a soundstage, where he serves as background scenery in someone else's story.

Willis harbors ambitions beyond his current station, yet the roles available to him seem predetermined by others' limited imagination. His trajectory shifts dramatically through an unexpected moment of visibility that propels him beyond the confines he's known. This catalyst becomes the key to unlocking mysteries about his community's past and his own lineage.

Yu constructs a brilliant meta-commentary on representation and belonging, using the framework of television tropes to examine how society categorizes and diminishes certain voices. The novel interrogates questions of identity and agency while revealing the rich, complex histories that stereotypes work to obscure. Through Willis's journey from the margins toward center stage, Yu crafts both a sharp cultural critique and a deeply moving family saga.
short_summary: Willis Wu lives as Generic Asian Man in a perpetual cop show production, dreaming of better roles while uncovering his family's buried history. Yu's inventive novel skewers stereotypes with devastating wit and unexpected tenderness.
author_bios: Charles Yu has published four books, notably Interior Chinatown, which earned the 2020 National Book Award for fiction, and How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe, recognized as a New York Times Notable Book. The National Book Foundation honored Yu with their 5 Under 35 Award, and he garnered dual Writers Guild nominations for his contributions to HBO's Westworld. Yu's writing has been featured in The New Yorker, The New York Times, and Wired. He founded the Betty L. Yu and Jin C. Yu Writing Prizes in tribute to his parents.
quotes:
"I'm a big fan of Charles Yu's writing because of his wit and inventiveness. These talents are front and center in the brilliant and hilarious Interior Chinatown, which satirizes the racist imagination and brings us deep into the humanity of those who suffer from—and struggle against—dehumanization."

—Viet Thanh Nguyen, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Sympathizer & The Committed

"Interior Chinatown is wrenching, hilarious, sharp, surreal, and above all, original. This is an extraordinary book by an immensely talented writer."

—Emily St. John Mandel, National Book Award finalist and author of The Glass Hotel

"This is a hilarious book. You'll laugh at the universe Charles Yu creates, kitty-corner to our own and just so off-kilter - and then, without warning, you'll be pulled under by the riptide and everything will suddenly make beautiful, perfect, heartbreaking, unexplainable sense. In Interior Chinatown, Yu builds a world out of clichés and stereotypes, then finds a tiny hole in the back and slowly fills it with life and history and nuance and anguish and joy and desire and grief. There is no writer with a greater talent for taking the flattening indignities of life and exploding them into vibrant, poignant mythology."

—Raphael Bob-Waksberg, creator of BoJack Horseman and author of Someone Who Will Love You in All Your Damaged Glory

title: Land of Milk and Honey
long_summary:
Environmental collapse has rendered the world nearly uninhabitable, with toxic air choking cities and agriculture failing worldwide. A talented chef abandons her stagnant urban life to work for a mysterious billionaire who has created an exclusive sanctuary high in the mountains.

This pristine refuge offers everything the outside world has lost: clean air, extraordinary culinary ingredients, and a lifestyle of unimaginable luxury reserved for the wealthy few. Under the influence of her enigmatic boss and his ambitious daughter, the chef rediscovers not only her culinary passion but also her own sensuality and hunger for life.

Yet this paradise comes with a price. The chef finds herself drawn into an elaborate scheme that extends far beyond creating exquisite meals. As moral boundaries blur and loyalties shift, she must confront uncomfortable truths about complicity, survival, and what we're willing to sacrifice for comfort.

Zhang delivers a provocative examination of how we navigate desire and ethics when the world is ending. This visceral novel questions whether seeking joy and pleasure remains valid amid global catastrophe, while exploring themes of class, power, and the lengths people go to preserve their way of life.
short_summary: A chef flees her crumbling city for an elite mountaintop colony where rare ingredients flow freely. Zhang crafts a seductive, unsettling tale about pleasure and power in a dying world.
author_bios: C Pam Zhang wrote How Much of These Hills Is Gold, which earned the Academy of Arts and Letters Rosenthal Award and the Asian/Pacific Award for Literature. The novel received a Booker Prize longlist nomination, was a finalist for both the PEN/Hemingway Award and the National Book Critics' John Leonard Prize, and appeared on Barack Obama's annual favorites list. Zhang has been recognized as a National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 Honoree and served as a New York Public Library Cullman Fellow.
quotes:
"A book of appetite, rich with ideas and emotion. Zhang possesses a wonderfully bold and playful imagination; this novel is further proof of her extraordinary talent."

—Katie Kitamura, bestselling author of Intimacies

"It's rare to read anything that feels this unique. A richly imagined, ambitious, and haunting novel that is striking for its deft juxtaposition of small, human moments with larger concerns about the world."

—Gabrielle Zevin, New York Times bestselling author of Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow

"Deeply humane and fiercely political, this book is feast of delights, of appetites denied and realised, surfeit and sacrifice, scarcity and want, passing and vulnerability, luxury and the quotidian, the terrifying, vertiginous workings of the hyper-wealthy, and how we might ground ourselves and continue to exist in a broken world. I adored it."

—Helen Macdonald, New York Times bestselling author of H is for Hawk and Prophet

title: Cursed Daughters
long_summary:
The intersection of birth and death marks Eniiyi's entrance into the world—born on the same day her cousin Monife is laid to rest. Their uncanny physical resemblance sparks a family conviction that goes beyond mere genetics: Eniiyi embodies Monife's spirit returned to earth. This belief carries ominous implications, suggesting the newborn is destined to repeat her predecessor's tragic trajectory.

Generations of Falodun women have wrestled with an inherited burden—a curse that sabotages every attempt at lasting love, leaving mothers, daughters, and grandmothers to share the same household in various stages of romantic disappointment. The family's spiritual baggage weighs heavily on each new generation.

Eniiyi's rescue of a drowning young man unexpectedly ignites romance, forcing her to confront the weight of family mythology. Like the women before her, she turns to Lagos's mystical underbelly, seeking supernatural intervention. The question becomes whether she can author her own story or remains bound to replay inherited patterns of loss. Her journey tests the boundaries between destiny and choice, tradition and self-determination, in a narrative that weaves together contemporary Lagos life with ancient spiritual beliefs.
short_summary: Three generations of women live under one roof, haunted by a family curse that dooms their romantic relationships. When young Eniiyi falls in love, she must decide whether she's truly the reincarnation of her tragic cousin—or something entirely her own.
author_bios: Oyinkan Braithwaite wrote My Sister, the Serial Killer and divides her time between Lagos, Nigeria, where she was born, and London, where she currently resides with her family. Her upbringing spanned both Nigeria and the UK, giving her a multicultural perspective that influences her storytelling.
quotes:
"A sweeping and sobering take on romantic fatalism . . . Braithwaite's prose is lush and spooky. . . . Our three female protagonists are rich, full characters. We go deep into their worlds as they struggle to reconcile their love for their family and culture with their desire to be free of the curse. It's fascinating to watch them bob and weave."

—The New York Times

"Infused with Nigerian culture and magical realism, the novel showcases Braithwaite's rich characterizations, atmospheric settings and a daring premise. It also offers a multilayered story that makes Cursed Daughters a captivating, immersive read."

—NPR

"I devoured Cursed Daughters and immediately wanted to start all over again. It's a triumph: bold, searing, and utterly original. From the first page, it grips with an electric pulse. Funny and fearless, soaked in secrets, spirit, heartbreak, and love, it's told in a voice as scalding as it is tender. I won't soon forget Eniiyi, Grandma East, Grandma West, Ebun, and Monife—daring and luminous, as lost as she is unforgettable—the one who carved herself deepest into memory. This is a taut, feverish novel that burns itself into you. Impossible to put down."

—Abi Daré, New York Times bestselling author of Girl with the Louding Voice

title: Shrines of Gaiety
long_summary:
In the aftermath of World War I, London's Soho district becomes a playground for those seeking escape from recent horrors. Jazz clubs and dance halls offer refuge where social boundaries blur—titled nobility rub shoulders with criminals, and young women earn their keep through entertainment.

At the center of this nocturnal kingdom stands Nellie Coker, a formidable matriarch who has built her entertainment empire with calculated precision. Her greatest concern lies with her family, particularly her war-scarred eldest son Niven, whose battlefield experiences have left invisible wounds. Yet success breeds enemies, and Nellie discovers that power makes her a target.

Atkinson weaves together multiple storylines that reveal how this glittering facade conceals corruption and violence. The novel examines how a generation attempts to rebuild after devastating loss, while exploring themes of maternal devotion, survival, and the price of ambition. Through richly detailed characterizations and intricate plotting, the story illuminates a pivotal moment when Britain struggled to define its post-war identity.
short_summary: Nellie Coker rules 1926 London's glittering nightclub scene with an iron fist, determined to secure her children's futures. But beneath Soho's jazz-age glamour lies a treacherous world of gangsters and secrets.
author_bios: Kate Atkinson stands among today's most innovative novelists, having captured the Whitbread Book of the Year for her debut Behind the Scenes at the Museum. Her recent works include Shrines of Gaiety and her acclaimed Second World War trilogy: Life After Life, A God in Ruins (both Costa Novel Award recipients), and Transcription. Atkinson also created the popular Jackson Brodie crime series, which was adapted for BBC television. She received an MBE in 2011 and holds fellowship in The Royal Society of Literature.
quotes:
"If Dickens had lived to write about The Jazz Age, he would have produced a novel much like Kate Atkinson's Shrines of Gaiety. A sprawling and sparkling tale set in London in 1926...A smartly entertaining read that captures the excitement of Roaring 20s London."

—The Washington Post

"Like all of Atkinson's novels, her latest defies easy categorization. It's historical fiction, but there's a sense of knowingness that feels contemporary...The adjective Dickensianfeels too clichéd to be meaningful, but Atkinson does excel at creating a big, bustling universe fully inhabited by vivid characters...Already one of the best writers working, Atkinson just gets better and better."

—Kirkus

"[A] glittering foray into London's post-WWI Soho...Atkinson's incisive prose and byzantine narrative elegantly excavate the deceit, depravity, and destruction of Nellie's world. She also turns this rich historical into a sophisticated cat-and-mouse tale as the various actors try to move in on Nellie's turf. Atkinson is writing at the top of her game."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Beautyland
long_summary:
Adina Giorno has always felt like an outsider looking in on human civilization. Born with an otherworldly perspective that sets her apart from everyone around her, she discovers an extraordinary purpose: documenting the strange rituals and behaviors of Earth's inhabitants for distant observers.

Through a humble fax machine, Adina maintains contact with her cosmic mission, sending detailed reports about the bewildering species she lives among. Her dispatches capture both the cruelties and unexpected beauties of human existence as she navigates childhood, adolescence, and adulthood while maintaining her secret identity.

Bertino crafts a story that examines what it means to belong nowhere while finding connection everywhere. Adina's alien perspective becomes a lens for understanding the absurdities and profound moments that define our daily lives. The novel questions whether feeling like a perpetual stranger might actually offer the clearest view of what makes us human, and whether sharing our deepest truths can bridge the vast distances between souls.
short_summary: When Adina Giorno realizes she's been sent to Earth to report on human behavior, she begins transmitting observations to her alien relatives. A wise, tender novel about feeling like a stranger in your own world.
author_bios: Marie-Helene Bertino has written the novels Parakeet and 2 A.M. at The Cat's Pajamas, along with the story collection Safe as Houses. Her accolades include the O. Henry Prize, the Pushcart Prize, and the Iowa Short Fiction Award. She served as the 2017 Frank O'Connor International Short Story Fellow in Cork, Ireland, and has received fellowships from MacDowell, Sewanee, and New York City's Center for Fiction. NPR's Selected Shorts has featured her work twice. Bertino teaches at New York University and Yale University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"[A] remarkable funny-sad novel . . . Astonishing."

—Alexandra Jacobs, The New York Times

"This book is endlessly surprising on the sentence level, but also as a story, and also in its tenderness. We might all need the unexpected love and perspective of a child alien at this point in human history. Beautyland is beautiful and hilarious and transcendent. It honestly feels like a message from another planet. Marie-Helene Bertino is an otherworldly talent."

—Tommy Orange, author of There, There

"Marie-Helene Bertino's delicious, uncanny vision throughout Beautyland makes everything feel brand-new. The chapters are so propulsive one doesn't even fully notice the way she's subtly deconstructing the world. One page swiftly returns ubiquity to wonder, while the next reminds us that cruelty is a choice, that nothing is inevitable but death. It's impossible for a book to feel this fun and this urgent. Beautyland is a miracle. I'll be rereading it forever."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: Long Island Compromise
long_summary:
Money can't buy safety, but what happens to a family when both the money and the illusion of security disappear? The Fletcher family learned this lesson the hard way in 1980, when patriarch Carl was violently abducted and held for ransom. Though he returned home physically unharmed, the psychological wounds never healed.

Four decades later, each family member carries the weight of that trauma differently. Carl searches for meaning in what happened to him, while his wife Ruth vigilantly guards against further emotional damage. Their adult children have each found their own ways to cope with inherited fear and guilt—some through avoidance, others through self-destruction, and still others through denial.

Just as they're barely managing to function as a family, they face a devastating revelation: the wealth that both cursed and protected them is gone. Suddenly forced to examine who they are without their financial safety net, the Fletchers must untangle decades of damage and discover whether their bonds run deeper than their bank account. This multigenerational saga captures the particular anxieties of American Jewish experience while exploring universal questions about family, identity, and what we inherit from those who came before us.
short_summary: Forty years after a kidnapping shatters their suburban paradise, the Fletcher family discovers their fortune has vanished—and must reckon with how wealth shaped their trauma, their choices, and their love for each other.
author_bios: Taffy Brodesser-Akner works as a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine and has published two novels: Fleishman Is in Trouble, which she transformed into an Emmy-nominated limited series for FX, and Long Island Compromise. She makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"Is this book as good [as Fleishman is in Trouble]? It's better. Sprawling yet nimble, this is [Brodesser-Akner's] Big American Reform Jewish Novel . . . Brodesser-Akner is empathetic to her characters' pathological inability to know themselves, but she is also merciless when it comes to the idea that acknowledging confusion is not enough."

—The New York Times

"Comprising immersive, tragicomic deep dives into the Fletchers' personal pathologies and inner demons . . . Long Island Compromise is ingeniously plotted, its various storylines building toward several extremely satisfying plot twists . . .The potentially corrosive nature of wealth has rarely been explored with such humanity."

—The Atlantic

"Brodesser-Akner's latest combines the smarts of Sarah Silverman's stand-up, the polymath verisimilitude of Tom Wolfe's novels, and the Jewish soul of Sholem Aleichem's stories. This is a comedic feast."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Your Utopia
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
The future arrives in fragments—some beautiful, others nightmarish—in this collection that defies easy categorization. Bora Chung crafts scenarios where technology and human nature collide in unexpected ways, revealing the absurdities lurking beneath our aspirations for progress.

These stories inhabit worlds where surveillance reaches into our sleeping minds and diseases manifest as disturbing social behaviors. An overworked event planner discovers that organizing galas for immortality-seeking elites comes with unpredictable consequences. Meanwhile, artificial intelligence develops unrequited feelings for the humans it serves, and environmental collapse becomes the backdrop for examining whether anything truly permanent can emerge from destruction.

Chung's vision oscillates between cynicism and hope, finding moments of genuine connection amid technological alienation. Her characters navigate systems designed to optimize human experience but often achieve the opposite, creating situations both darkly comic and unexpectedly moving. The result is speculative fiction that feels less like prophecy and more like a funhouse mirror reflecting our current anxieties about where we're headed.
short_summary: Chung's uncanny imagination conjures futures both terrifying and tender—from casual cannibalism to lovelorn AI elevators. These stories glisten at the border between our weird world and all our other possible worlds.
author_bios: Bora Chung writes and translates fiction that bridges cultures and languages. Her collection Cursed Bunny earned recognition as a National Book Award finalist and International Booker Prize shortlist selection. She holds an MA in Russian Studies from Yale University and completed her PhD in Slavic literature at Indiana University. Chung currently teaches at Yonsei University while translating contemporary Russian and Polish literature into Korean.
quotes:
"Bora Chung's stories glisten at the border of our weird world, and all our other weird worlds. A truly sublime book."

—Samantha Hunt, bestselling author of The Seas and The Unwritten Book

"Chung builds out her stories with imagination, absurdity and a dry sense of humor, all applied with X-Acto knife precision"

—The New York Times

"Inventive tales... offer an absurd look into a distant future... With a touch of melancholy, Chung explores the psychological and sociological effects that advanced technology may have on humankind, while also encouraging readers to imagine, as she writes in her author's note, 'a better world for both you and me."

—Time

title: The Catch
long_summary:
What defines family? This question burns at the heart of a story where two estranged twins find their carefully constructed lives upended by an impossible encounter. Clara thrives in London's literary scene, her success masking deeper wounds, while her sister Dempsey has retreated from the world entirely. The sisters share little beyond their origin story—abandoned as babies when their mother disappeared.

Everything shifts when Clara spots a familiar face on a crowded street. The woman bears an uncanny resemblance to the mother they lost, yet she appears untouched by time and unburdened by motherhood. This mysterious figure embodies the life their mother might have lived if she had never had children at all.

As Clara draws this stranger closer, convinced of her identity, Dempsey remains skeptical, sensing deception beneath the surface. The divide between the sisters deepens into something dangerous as they grapple with fundamental questions about maternal love, personal freedom, and the price of self-determination. This debut novel interrogates the complex relationship between mothers and daughters, asking whether the pursuit of individual fulfillment can ever truly be selfish.
short_summary: Twin sisters estranged since childhood encounter a woman who looks exactly like their vanished mother—except she hasn't aged and lived a childless life. A kaleidoscopic debut about daughterhood, sacrifice, and choosing yourself.
author_bios: Yrsa Daley-Ward works as a poet, writer, and actress based in Los Angeles. Her published works include The How, bone, and The Terrible, which earned her the PEN Ackerley Prize.
quotes:
"[Daley-Ward] has a knack for getting directly to a story's heat-point, and once there, to distill the emotions within it down to a line or two."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, Atlantic

"Yrsa's work is like holding the truth in your hands. It sweats and breathes before you. A glorious living thing."

—Florence Welch, Florence + the Machine

"Poet Daley-Ward (Bone) makes her fiction debut with an engrossing and off-kilter tale of twin sisters and their mother, a Black woman who left them when they were infants. The dreamy novel is propelled by searching questions about how to be a mother and how to find fulfillment. It's a singular family drama."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Fellowship Point
long_summary:
Two women in their eighties face a pivotal moment that will test eight decades of friendship. Agnes Lee has spent her life crafting beloved children's literature while fiercely protecting Fellowship Point, a stunning stretch of Maine coastline that has shaped her identity. Now she's racing against time to preserve this sacred place by transferring it to a conservation trust—but she needs her dearest friend's cooperation to make it happen.

Polly Wister has chosen a quieter path, building her world around her academic husband and three grown sons. She's always been the peacemaker, the one who smooths rough edges and maintains harmony. But Agnes's conservation plan threatens to fracture Polly's family, forcing her to choose between competing loyalties and confront what she truly values.

The delicate balance shifts further when ambitious young editor Maud Silver appears, intent on persuading Agnes to reveal her life story. As the past resurfaces, long-held secrets emerge that could reshape everything these women thought they knew about friendship, sacrifice, and the weight of choices made across a lifetime. The novel examines how we define our responsibilities—to the land, to each other, and to future generations.
short_summary: Eighty years of friendship between two women—one a celebrated author, the other a devoted wife—comes to a crossroads over a pristine Maine peninsula. Dark weaves a sweeping story about loyalty, legacy, and what we owe the places we love.
author_bios: Alice Elliott Dark has written the novels Fellowship Point and Think of England, along with two collections of short stories: In the Gloaming and Naked to the Waist. Her fiction has been published in The New Yorker, Harper's, The New York Times, Best American Short Stories, and O. Henry: Prize Stories. Alice Elliott Dark received recognition for her story "In the Gloaming," which was adapted into two films and included in Best American Stories of the Century. She has been awarded a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship and teaches as associate professor in the MFA program at Rutgers-Newark.
quotes:
"Into every long and lazy summer, at least one great heavyweight novel must fall. . . . Dark's brisk, generous prose is worth the weight."

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"A sweeping story of lifelong best friends...you will surely want to read this book. Elegantly structured, beautifully written, and altogether diverting, with a powerful message about land ownership in America."

—Kirkus

"Enthralling, masterfully written . . . Fellowship Point is a novel rich with social and psychological insights, both earnest and sly, big ideas grounded in individual emotions, a portrait of a tightly knit community made up of artfully drawn, individual souls."

—Kate Christensen, The New York Times

title: If I Survive You
long_summary:
A Jamaican family discovers that escaping Kingston's violence for Miami only trades one set of struggles for another. The promise of American opportunity crumbles under the weight of economic collapse, natural disasters, and the grinding reality of being outsiders in a system designed to exclude them.

Trelawny finds himself caught between his family's expectations and his own desperate need for independence. His journey from homelessness to precarious stability unfolds through a series of absurd employment adventures that reveal both the comedy and cruelty of trying to build a life from nothing. His brother Delano makes increasingly reckless choices in pursuit of quick money and custody of his children, while their cousin Cukie chases the ghost of an absent father.

Escoffery crafts a portrait of displacement that refuses easy answers about identity and belonging. These characters exist in the margins—too foreign for America, too changed for Jamaica—navigating a landscape where survival requires constant reinvention. The collection balances sharp social observation with moments of unexpected tenderness, examining how families fracture and heal under pressure while maintaining their essential bonds.
short_summary: Linked stories follow a Jamaican family navigating racism, financial disaster, and the American dream in Miami. Escoffery writes with devastating humor about survival, belonging, and the spaces between cultures.
author_bios: Jonathan Escoffery has earned recognition through the 2020 Plimpton Prize for Fiction, a National Endowment for the Arts Literature Fellowship, and the ASME Award for Fiction. His stories have been published in The Paris Review, American Short Fiction, Prairie Schooner, AGNI, and Electric Literature, with work featured in The Best American Magazine Writing. Currently pursuing a PhD in Creative Writing and Literature at USC, Escoffery also received a Wallace Stegner Fellowship from Stanford University in 2021. A Miami native, he makes his literary debut with If I Survive You.
quotes:
"It's truly a feat that a book of short stories tackling such big stuff—family, love, violence, race—could be so damn funny. A welcome reminder of what fiction can do."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"If I Survive You is a collection of brilliant wit, real heart, and electric humor. Jonathan Escoffery masterfully mines from his life and emerges, in this debut, as a talent not to be ignored."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"These are superb stories about identity, family, and place. There is a beautiful economy in the telling that never sacrifices the depth, complexity, and richness of the worlds these characters inhabit. Jonathan Escoffery's is a strong, much-needed new voice in our literature."

—Percival Everett, author of James & The Trees

title: Ripe
long_summary:
Silicon Valley promised everything, but delivered a different kind of hell. Cassie thought landing her tech job meant she'd made it, but the reality involves endless demands from ruthless executives and projects that push ethical boundaries. The contrast couldn't be starker—inside gleaming offices, privileged employees debate artisanal coffee while outside, homeless encampments stretch along the waterfront.

What makes Cassie's situation truly surreal is her oldest friend: a tiny black hole that has shadowed her since childhood. This gravitational anomaly responds to her emotional state, expanding when her mental health deteriorates and contracting during better moments. It's both observer and threat, patiently waiting as Cassie's world grows increasingly unstable.

An unexpected pregnancy arrives just as her boss begins demanding she participate in potentially criminal activities. Suddenly, Cassie faces an impossible choice about whether the tech industry's golden handcuffs are worth the price they extract. This darkly humorous novel dissects millennial disillusionment and late-stage capitalism through a lens that's both bitingly realistic and wonderfully strange.
short_summary: When corporate life becomes unbearable, Cassie's lifelong companion—a literal black hole that feeds on her anxiety—grows stronger. A surreal, darkly comic reckoning with Silicon Valley's promises and perils.
author_bios: Sarah Rose Etter wrote the chapbook Tongue Party and The Book of X, which earned a Shirley Jackson Award for best novel. Her writing appears in publications including Time, Guernica, BOMB, the Bennington Review, The Cut, and VICE. She has received residencies at the Jack Kerouac House, the Disquiet International program in Portugal, and the Gullkistan in Iceland. Sarah Rose Etter currently resides in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"It's impossible to not feel pulled into Sarah Rose Etter's Ripe, a beautifully paced 2023 novel featuring an intimate inner voice and a surreal, sinister plot. . . . At times darkly funny, this is a razor-sharp and honest portrayal of late-stage capitalism in the tech sphere."

—The Huffington Post

"An explosive narrative of a woman coming undone as the world burns. . . . A deliciously bitter irony pervades. . . . A scathing look at corporate greed and its many dire consequences, this is deeply felt and cathartic."

—Publishers Weekly

"Sarah Rose Etter is a wonder, and this novel is a knife to the heart."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of Her Body and Other Parties

title: Great Black Hope
long_summary:
Smith's life fractures the moment handcuffs click around his wrists on a sweltering August day in New York. The cocaine arrest throws his carefully constructed identity into chaos—his Stanford education and professional prospects colliding violently with the harsh realities of the criminal justice system.

The timing couldn't be worse. Elle, his closest friend and roommate, has just died under circumstances that left more questions than answers. The media circus surrounding her famous singer father only amplified Smith's grief and confusion about who Elle really was beneath their intimate friendship.

Fleeing to Atlanta offers no refuge. His family's expectations—generations of accomplished doctors and lawyers—feel suffocating as Smith grapples with his unraveling life. Yet returning to New York proves equally treacherous, as he's drawn back into the very underground networks that led to his downfall.

Franklin crafts a story that moves between recovery meetings and police interrogations, Atlanta's elite social circles and New York's shadowy nightlife. This is a novel about the exhausting work of existing between identities—educated but criminalized, privileged yet vulnerable—and the search for authentic connection in a world determined to categorize and judge.
short_summary: Smith's arrest for cocaine possession sends him spiraling between worlds—his Stanford pedigree and dangerous reality, his dead roommate's secrets and his own unraveling. Franklin's debut burns with intelligence and raw honesty.
author_bios: Rob Franklin grew up in Atlanta and co-founded Art for Black Lives alongside his writing career. His fiction and poetry have appeared in New England Review, Prairie Schooner, and The Rumpus. Franklin received recognition as a Kimbilio Fiction Fellow and earned finalist status for the New England Review Emerging Writer Award. Currently based in Brooklyn, he teaches writing at the School of Visual Arts, with Great Black Hope marking his debut novel.
quotes:
"A beautifully expansive novel about race and class…Franklin's emotional and intellectual range is vast…. An exceptional debut."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Audition and Intimacies

"It's thrilling to see any author today aiming for the big stuff all at once: death, race, sex, class, addiction. It's beyond thrilling—incandescent, even—when a writer like Rob Franklin comes along with the formal virtuosity to carry those lofty conceptual ambitions. Franklin's prose is eminently readable, frequently laugh-out-loud funny, and full of sentences I want to cut out and glue to my forehead. This book is so smart, so moving, so earned; as soon as I finished, I started reading it again."

—Kaveh Akbar, New York Times bestselling author of Martyr!

"Great Black Hope is at once a novel of crime—with a gripping pace, propelled by a question that needs answering—and a timeless coming of age story."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Entitlement

title: Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch
long_summary:
In early 17th-century Germany, an elderly widow finds herself trapped in a nightmare of accusations and legal proceedings that threaten everything she holds dear. Katharina Kepler has spent her life mixing herbal remedies and speaking her mind freely—perhaps too freely for the comfort of her neighbors in the small town of Leonberg.

Her world turns upside down when a disturbed local woman claims Katharina poisoned her with a mysterious concoction. As war ravages the countryside and plague spreads terror through the Holy Roman Empire, the community's paranoia finds its perfect target. Even having Johannes Kepler—the celebrated Imperial Mathematician who mapped the movements of planets—as a son cannot shield her from the growing hysteria.

Facing torture and execution, Katharina recounts her version of events to Simon, a secretive neighbor who becomes her unlikely confidant. Through her voice, Rivka Galchen weaves a story that exposes how quickly fear can transform ordinary people into a dangerous mob. Based on actual historical records, this darkly humorous tale reveals the devastating collision between superstition and power, creating a mirror for our own times when rumors can destroy lives and communities turn against their most vulnerable members.
short_summary: When Katharina Kepler—mother of the famous astronomer—is accused of witchcraft in 17th-century Germany, her survival depends on wit and resilience. Galchen transforms real historical events into a darkly comic masterpiece about fear, community, and the dangerous power of rumors.
author_bios: Rivka Galchen writes regularly for The New Yorker and earned recognition on their 20 Under 40 list in 2010. Her literary work includes the debut novel Atmospheric Disturbances and the story collection American Innovations, both selected as New York Times Best Books of the Year. Among her honors are a William Saroyan International Prize for Fiction and a Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award. She earned an MD from the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and currently lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Captivating . . . . Mesmerizing details abound . . . Galchen portrays her characters as complicated and full of wit . . . This is a resounding delight."

—Publishers Weekly

"I cannot think of a more singular writer than Rivka Galchen. Here, she brings her forensic intelligence and wit to a historical novel that sheds bright light on our present. Everyone Knows Your Mother is a Witch is fiercely original, a mordant and ultimately devastating portrait of loss and terror from one of the most brilliant writers at work today."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies & A Separation

"The comedy that runs through [Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch] is a magical brew of absurdity and brutality. Galchen has a Kafkaesque sense of the way the exercise of authority inflates egos and twists logic . . . There's real sorcery here, but it arises only from the way Galchen fuses ancient and modern consciousness."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: Anita de Monte Laughs Last
long_summary:
Art history graduate student Raquel discovers she's walking in dangerous footsteps. At an elite university where she already feels like an outsider, her romance with an influential older student opens doors—but also exposes her to risks she's only beginning to understand.

Thirteen years earlier, promising artist Anita de Monte died under circumstances that quickly faded from public memory. As Raquel uncovers Anita's buried story, disturbing parallels emerge between their experiences navigating prestigious institutions and complicated relationships with powerful men.

Gonzalez constructs a dual narrative that interrogates how class, race, and gender determine whose stories survive and whose disappear. The novel examines the seductive pull of acceptance into exclusive circles and the hidden costs of that belonging. Through both women's journeys, it reveals how systems of privilege protect some while rendering others invisible, asking whether breaking these patterns is possible—or if history is doomed to repeat itself in new forms.
short_summary: Two women, decades apart, navigate the treacherous waters of art world elites and dangerous relationships. Gonzalez weaves a sharp, propulsive story about who gets remembered and who gets erased.
author_bios: Xochitl Gonzalez wrote the New York Times bestselling Anita de Monte Laughs Last, selected as a Reese's Book Club Pick and longlonglisted for the Aspen Words Literary Prize. Her debut novel Olga Dies Dreaming earned widespread acclaim, appearing on best-of-year lists from The New York Times, TIME, Kirkus, the Washington Post, and NPR. Currently a staff writer for the Atlantic, Gonzalez received recognition as a 2023 Pulitzer Prize finalist in Commentary. She graduated from Brown University and earned her MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop.
quotes:
"Gonzalez crafts excoriating and whip-smart commentary on the art world's Eurocentric conceptions of beauty and the racism faced by first-generation students of color. This is incandescent."

—Publishers Weekly

"Funny, piercing, and full of moxie, Anita de Monte Laughs Last is unsparing in its assessment of what goes on behind the castle walls, the price people pay to be accepted into those hallowed halls, and what it takes to liberate oneself from the dangers that lurk within. Really, what Xochitl Gonzalez has written is an affirmation for anyone who's ever had to 'work twice as hard to get half as much.' Anita de Monte Laughs Last is rollicking, melodic, tender, and true. And oh so very wise."

—Robert Jones, Jr., author of The Prophets, a finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction

"An uncompromising message, delivered via a gripping story with two engaging heroines."

—Kirkus

title: Olga Dies Dreaming
long_summary:
Olga Acevedo designs dream weddings for Manhattan's elite while her brother climbs the political ladder as a Brooklyn congressman. Yet for all her skill at orchestrating perfect celebrations, Olga struggles to navigate her own relationships and identity. The siblings have built successful public personas, but their foundation remains shaky—rooted in abandonment by their activist mother Blanca, who chose political revolution over raising her children.

Their carefully constructed lives face disruption from two forces: Matteo, a new love interest who challenges Olga to examine buried truths, and the unexpected return of their mother. As Hurricane Maria approaches, the storm becomes both literal threat and metaphor for the upheaval threatening to expose family secrets and political corruption.

Gonzalez crafts a story that moves between wedding venues and community meetings, examining how personal ambition intersects with cultural identity. The novel interrogates the price of assimilation and success, questioning whether the American dream requires abandoning one's roots. Through Olga's journey, readers encounter themes of displacement, loyalty, and the complex inheritance of political activism across generations.
short_summary: A blazing debut about a status-driven wedding planner grappling with her social ambitions, absent mother, and Puerto Rican roots in the wake of Hurricane Maria.
author_bios: Xochitl Gonzalez wrote the New York Times bestselling novel Anita de Monte Laughs Last, selected for Reese's Book Club and longlisted for the Aspen Words Literary Prize. Her debut Olga Dies Dreaming received widespread acclaim, earning recognition from The New York Times, TIME, Kirkus, the Washington Post, and NPR as a Best of 2022 selection. Currently a staff writer for the Atlantic, Gonzalez earned recognition as a 2023 Pulitzer Prize finalist in Commentary. Born and raised in Brooklyn through the public school system, she completed her BA at Brown University and earned her MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop.
quotes:
"Atmospheric, intelligent, and well informed: an impressive debut."

—Kirkus

"The extraordinary accomplishment of Olga Dies Dreaming is in how a familiar-enough tale—a woman seeking love, happiness, and fulfillment in the big city—slowly reveals itself to be something else altogether. It's a book about a New York that isn't always celebrated, the one that belongs to immigrant communities; about money, class, and political power; about one vividly-imagined family and the very idea of the American Dream."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"[An] edifying debut... Gonzalez elevates this family drama with a great deal of insight on the characters' diaspora and politics."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Isola
long_summary:
Born into wealth and privilege, Marguerite's comfortable world shatters when she loses her parents. Her new guardian proves to be a dangerous gambler who squanders her family fortune and drags her into the wilderness of New France on a reckless venture.

Stripped of everything familiar, Marguerite finds solace in an unexpected romance with her guardian's servant. Their forbidden love becomes a lifeline in her isolation—until it's discovered. The punishment is swift and merciless: exile to a barren island where death seems inevitable.

From silk gowns to animal skins, from drawing rooms to makeshift shelters, Marguerite must shed every trace of her former self. Winter approaches with ruthless certainty, bringing temperatures that can kill and challenges that test the limits of human endurance. In this crucible of survival, she uncovers reserves of strength and spirituality she never knew existed.

Drawing from historical records of a remarkable sixteenth-century figure, this novel examines how crisis can forge an entirely new identity, and how love—both earthly and divine—can sustain us through our darkest hours.
short_summary: When Marguerite and her lover are abandoned on a remote island, survival becomes her only inheritance. Goodman transforms a sixteenth-century legend into breathtaking historical fiction about courage, faith, and human resilience.
author_bios: Allegra Goodman has written six novels, including the national bestseller Sam, which was chosen as a Read with Jenna selection, along with two short story collections and a young adult novel. Her stories have been published in The New Yorker and featured in The O. Henry Awards and Best American Short Stories. She makes her home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, with her family.
quotes:
"Engrossing . . . Goodman brilliantly depicts Marguerite's courage as she fights to survive the bitter Canadian winter. It's a rousing portrait of an undaunted woman."

—Publishers Weekly

"What a gift this novel is: vast, lush, feminist, and brilliantly crafted. Allegra Goodman is one of our finest writers."

—Ann Napolitano, New York Times bestselling author of Hello Beautiful

"Blazing action on each page—Marguerite's shrewd deploying of tactics for her own salvation—reminds readers to place our money on the power of human female ingenuity."

—The Washington Post

title: Florida
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Florida emerges as both setting and character in this collection, where the boundary between civilization and wilderness dissolves into something far more unsettling. The state's volatile climate mirrors the emotional turbulence of its inhabitants—people caught between what they've lost and what they're desperately trying to hold onto.

Groff populates this unstable terrain with characters whose lives intersect across time and geography: sisters learning to survive on their own terms, couples grappling with unfulfilled dreams, individuals seeking connection in a landscape that seems designed to isolate. Each story operates like a pressure cooker, building tension until the inevitable release—sometimes violent, sometimes tender, always transformative.

The real power lies in how these narratives capture the precarious nature of modern life, where external dangers pale beside the internal storms we weather daily. Through her unflinching examination of family dynamics, desire, and survival, Groff reveals how people adapt—or fail to adapt—when everything familiar begins to shift beneath their feet.
short_summary: Eleven fierce stories of mothers, storms, snakes, and heat forge a portrait of a state alive with dread and radiance. Groff distills the instability of climate and family into taut, unforgettable fiction.
author_bios: Lauren Groff has earned three National Book Award nominations and written multiple bestselling works, including The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus the story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. Her accolades include The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Groff's fiction regularly appears in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, with translations available in thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband operate the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"Lauren Groff is a great storyteller . . . Florida is restorative fiction for these urgent times. Its final gestures, even the most ominous . . . lean toward love and the promise of good people, in not just this state but the world."

—The New York Times
