"She hasn't lost a step since Fates And Furies . . . Groff's language is, as always, gorgeous and precise. Her ability to map the inner contours of characters who seem to exist entirely in extremis — and, almost entirely, within a fragile shell of feigned competence and normalcy — is remarkable. Her Florida is a frightening place that bends (solely through the eyes and experiences of her characters) into a discomfortingly modern Southern Gothic tradition. Her stories — all of them — are haunted."

—NPR

"Groff fans will recognize the descriptive zest instantly. . . raw, danger-riddled, linguistically potent pieces. They unsettle their readers at every pass . . . A literary tour de force of precariousness set in a blistering place, a state shaped like a gun."

—Kirkus

title: To the End of the Land
long_summary:
Fear drives Ora into the wilderness. Rather than wait at home for news that might destroy her, this Israeli mother chooses to disappear into the Galilee hills with Avram, a man whose own wounds from war run deep. Her son Ofer has unexpectedly returned to military duty, and she believes that as long as she keeps moving, keeps talking, keeps him alive in her words, tragedy cannot find them.

Avram carries his own scars—a former artist shattered by capture and torture, now reluctant to engage with the world. Yet as they traverse the landscape together, Ora's relentless storytelling begins to resurrect not only her absent son but something within Avram as well. Through her memories of raising Ofer, she creates a vivid tapestry of ordinary moments made precious by their fragility.

Grossman examines how violence echoes across generations, how mothers love in the face of impossible odds, and how friendship can survive even the deepest betrayals. This meditation on family, survival, and the cost of conflict reveals the ways people endure when everything they cherish hangs in the balance.
short_summary: An Israeli mother, terrified her soldier son will die in combat, embarks on a hiking journey to outrun devastating news. Grossman weaves an unflinching portrait of love and loss in wartime.
author_bios: Born in Jerusalem, David Grossman has written fiction, nonfiction, and children's literature that reaches readers in more than forty languages. His work appears in publications such as The New Yorker, and he has earned prestigious recognition including the Man Booker International Prize, the Erasmus Prize, Israel's EMET Prize, the Albatross Prize, and the Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. Grossman continues to make his home in Jerusalem.
quotes:
"Very rarely, a few times in a lifetime, you open a book and when you close it again nothing can ever be the same. To the End of the Land is a book of this magnitude. David Grossman may be the most gifted writer I've ever read.... Powerful, shattering, and unflinching. To read it is to have yourself taken apart, undone, touched at the place of your own essence."

—Nicole Krauss

"This is a book of overwhelming power and intensity, David Grossman's masterpiece. Flaubert created his Emma, Tolstoy made his Anna, and now we have Grossman's Ora — as fully alive, as fully embodied, as any character in recent fiction. I devoured this long novel in a feverish trance. Wrenching, beautiful, unforgettable."

—Paul Auster

"There are some writers in whose words one recognizes the texture of life. David Grossman is such a writer. His characters don't so much lie on the page as rise before the reader's eyes, in three dimensions, their skin covered in prose that both stabs with insight and shines with compassion."

—Yann Martel

title: Theft
long_summary:
Three lives intersect in a small Tanzanian town as the modern world begins to reshape everything they've known. Karim arrives home from the capital city, his university education having given him dreams that feel too big for his surroundings. Fauzia watches from the constraints of her traditional family, recognizing in Karim's confidence a possible path toward the freedom she craves. Badar, with little money and fewer prospects, finds unexpected shelter with this unlikely pair.

Their bond forms just as their isolated community faces an influx of outside influences—tourism, new technologies, and economic possibilities that promise both liberation and disruption. Each friend responds differently to these shifting realities, their choices pulling them toward separate futures they never anticipated. The novel examines how personal agency operates within larger historical currents, questioning whether we truly control our destinies or simply respond to forces beyond our comprehension. Through these three distinct perspectives, the story reveals how friendship can both anchor and complicate our attempts to define ourselves in a rapidly changing world.
short_summary: Three young Tanzanians navigate friendship, ambition, and global change in this intimate portrait from the Nobel Prize-winning author. Gurnah captures the weight of choice in a transforming world.
genres: Fiction / World Literature / Africa / East Africa
author_bios: Abdulrazak Gurnah received the 2021 Nobel Prize in Literature and has published nine novels, including Paradise (shortlisted for the Booker Prize), By the Sea (longlisted for the Booker Prize and Los Angeles Times Book Prize finalist), and Desertion. A native of Zanzibar, Gurnah serves as Professor Emeritus of English and Postcolonial Literatures at the University of Kent and resides in Canterbury, England.
quotes:
"Compassionate, revelatory. . .a kind of argument about the value of true character, about worth calibrated outside the marketplace of money, status and drama. . .[Gurnah's] sentences follow the riverbed of some ancient legend, even as he describes complicated modern lives."

—Washington Post

"Nobel Prize-winning novelist Gurnah delivers a story whose title reverberates throughout. . . No word is wasted. . .A tightly constructed family drama with surprising complications."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Intimate. . .but the way Gurnah writes it, it all comes off as pretty heroic."

—NPR

title: The Other Black Girl
long_summary:
Editorial assistant Nella Rogers has spent too long as the sole Black face in Wagner Books' overwhelmingly white offices. The microaggressions and isolation have worn her down, so when Hazel arrives from Harlem to fill the neighboring cubicle, Nella feels a surge of relief.

But their budding friendship over shared experiences quickly sours as Hazel ascends to become management's favorite while Nella watches from the sidelines. Then threatening messages start appearing on Nella's workspace: LEAVE WAGNER. NOW.

Could Hazel really be orchestrating this campaign of intimidation? As Nella's paranoia intensifies and she digs deeper into the mystery, she discovers the danger extends far beyond office politics. The stakes escalate from professional rivalry to something much more sinister.

This razor-sharp thriller dissects workplace racism with surgical precision, creating an unsettling portrait of corporate culture where survival requires more than just talent. It captures the psychological toll of tokenism while delivering genuine suspense that will resonate with anyone who has navigated hostile professional environments.
short_summary: When a second Black woman joins a predominantly white publishing house, workplace dynamics turn sinister. Sharp social commentary wrapped in an addictive thriller about ambition, identity, and survival.
author_bios: Zakiya Dalila Harris earned her MFA in creative writing from The New School and made a stunning literary debut with The Other Black Girl, which became an instant New York Times bestseller before being adapted into a critically acclaimed Hulu Original Series. Her writing has been featured in publications including Cosmopolitan, The Guardian, The New York Times, and The Rumpus. She currently resides in Brooklyn with her husband.
quotes:
"A thrilling, edgier Devil Wears Prada that explores privilege and racism."

—The Washington Post

"Harris' genre-bending evisceration of workplace privilege is set to become the debut of the summer."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Wholly earned brilliance. Harris makes her entrance as an author with singular style. Whatever she does next might seem quieter, but watch for it: It will be brilliant."

—NPR

title: Imagine Me Gone
long_summary:
In 1960s London, Margaret makes a fateful decision to marry John despite his hospitalization for depression, setting in motion a multigenerational reckoning with mental illness. Their eldest son Michael emerges as the family's most vulnerable member—a music-obsessed intellectual whose razor-sharp humor masks deepening psychological fragility inherited from his father.

As Michael's condition deteriorates, his siblings Celia and Alec find themselves drawn into an exhausting cycle of vigilance and care. Each family member grapples differently with the weight of loving someone whose mind works against him, creating a complex web of guilt, responsibility, and fierce protectiveness.

Haslett constructs this intimate family drama through five distinct voices, revealing how depression ripples outward to touch every relationship and decision. The novel examines the impossible mathematics of sacrifice—how much can one family give before love becomes a form of slow destruction? Through Michael's brilliant, fragmented perspective and his family's unwavering commitment, the story illuminates both the devastating inheritance of mental illness and the stubborn persistence of human connection in the face of seemingly insurmountable pain.
short_summary: From a Pulitzer finalist, a devastating family saga about inherited depression and unconditional love. Told through five voices across decades, following a brilliant son's mental illness and his family's fierce devotion.
author_bios: Adam Haslett wrote You Are Not a Stranger Here, Union Atlantic, and Imagine Me Gone, earning Pulitzer Prize finalist recognition twice. His work has received National Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award finalist honors, plus the Los Angeles Times Book Prize. Haslett's accolades include a Guggenheim Fellowship, the PEN/Malamud Award, the Berlin Prize, and the Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and he leads the MFA Program at Hunter College.
quotes:
"Haslett's latest is a sprawling, ambitious epic about a family bound not only by familial love, but by that sense of impending emergency that hovers around Michael, who has inherited his father John's abiding depression and anxiety....This is a book that tenderly and luminously deals with mental illness and with the life of the mind....In Michael, Haslett has created a most memorable character. This is a hypnotic and haunting novel."

—Publishers Weekly

"An extraordinary blend of precision, beauty, and tenderness . . . Haslett's prose rises to the challenge, lushly capturing the dense fog of depression that blankets John [the father] and occasionally lifts just enough to reveal the 'beast' moving in on him. But Haslett really shows his chops channeling [oldest son] Michael's amped-up voice . . . I got caught up in the beauty of Haslett's sentences and the lives of these oh-so-human people bound by shared duress and cycles of hope. Haslett's signature achievement in Imagine Me Gone is to temper the harrowing with the humorous while keeping a steady bead on the pathos. You want sympathetic characters? You want a narrative that showcases love as a many-splendored thing capacious enough to encompass stalwart, long-suffering spouses, loyal siblings, suffocatingly obsessive crushes, and casual, noncommittal relationships (both gay and straight) that morph as if by magic into soul-sustenance? You want writing that thrums with anguish and compassion? It's all here."

—Heller McAlpin, NPR

"The family Adam Haslett has created in Imagine Me Gone feels as true and as complex as our own actual families are, and lays nearly as deep a claim upon our love and loyalty. The eldest son, Michael, is simply one of the finest characters I've ever come across in fiction. This beautiful, tragic novel will haunt you for the rest of your life and you will be all the more human for it."

—Paul Harding, Pulitzer Prize winner for Tinkers

title: The Great Reclamation
long_summary:
In Singapore's waning colonial era, young Ah Boon possesses a secret that sets him apart from his fishing village community: he alone can see and reach mystical islands that drift through the waters, invisible to all others. This supernatural ability transforms the gentle boy who never felt at home on his family's boat into someone with unique value to offer.

The magic of childhood gives way to the brutal realities of war and political upheaval. As Japanese forces occupy Singapore and independence movements gain momentum, Ah Boon and his beloved Siok Mei face wrenching decisions about loyalty, identity, and survival. Their personal struggles mirror their nation's painful transformation from colony to modern state.

Rachel Heng crafts an intimate portrait of individuals caught between disappearing traditions and an uncertain future. The novel examines how progress demands sacrifice, questioning what we lose when familiar landscapes—both physical and cultural—vanish forever. Through one boy's extraordinary gift and ordinary heartbreak, the story illuminates the human dimension of historical change.
short_summary: In colonial Singapore, a boy who can find mystical floating islands navigates first love and wartime upheaval. Heng weaves an aching tale of sacrifice, belonging, and the costs of progress.
author_bios: Rachel Heng grew up in Singapore and wrote Suicide Club, which has been translated into ten languages. Her shorter works have been published in The New Yorker, Glimmer Train, and McSweeney's. Rachel Heng earned her MFA from the Michener Center for Writers and has been recognized with fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts, Sewanee Writers' Conference, and the National Arts Council of Singapore. She teaches as an assistant professor of English at Wesleyan University.
quotes:
"Through the story of one remarkable boy, Rachel Heng's breathtaking epic of 20th century Singapore shows us the human and environmental costs of a nation's quest for freedom, prosperity, and order. Told with great tenderness and moral clarity, and alive to the beauty and mystery of the natural world as well as the human heart, The Great Reclamation is timeless, timely, and unforgettable."

—Jessamine Chan, New York Times bestselling author of The School for Good Mothers

"Heng wrings a great deal of emotion from Boon's experiences and relationships. . .skillfully capturing the inner psyche of a Singaporean everyman caught between two immovable worlds. This epic undertaking is not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

"[A] story scaffolded against a sweeping backdrop—the politics of colonialism, World War II in Southeast Asia, ecology, the inexorable forces of development and modernization—with very little of that ever mentioned, instead focusing on the experiences of the characters in language of perfect simplicity. . .Like a drop of rain that holds the reflection of the world, crystalline and beautiful."

—Kirkus

title: The Removed
long_summary:
The Echota family exists in fragments, each member isolated by their own response to unthinkable loss. Maria watches her husband Ernest slip deeper into the fog of Alzheimer's while their daughter Sonja drifts through cycles of romantic fixation. Their surviving son Edgar has spent years numbing himself with substances, running from a pain that follows him everywhere.

As the anniversary of their youngest son's death approaches—a date that coincides with the Cherokee National Holiday—the boundaries between the physical and spiritual worlds begin to dissolve. A foster child arrives who somehow clarifies Ernest's clouded mind. Sonja finds herself drawn to a man whose presence awakens ancestral memories of violence. Edgar's brush with suicide transports him to the Darkening Land, where past and present traumas converge.

Hobson constructs a narrative where Cherokee spiritual traditions illuminate the lasting wounds of both personal tragedy and historical violence. The novel examines how families survive devastating loss and how indigenous communities carry the weight of generational trauma while seeking pathways toward restoration.
short_summary: Fifteen years after their son's death in a police shooting, a Cherokee family grapples with grief and trauma. Hobson weaves folklore into a haunting meditation on loss and healing.
author_bios: Brandon Hobson belongs to the Cherokee Nation tribe of Oklahoma as an enrolled citizen. Where the Dead Sit Talking, his novel, received recognition as a finalist for the 2018 National Book Award for Fiction.
quotes:
"[A] mythic, sweeping novel."

—The New York Times

"Deeply resonant and profound, and not only because of its exquisite lyricism. It's also a hard and visceral entrance into our own reckoning as a society and civic culture with losses we created, injustices we allowed, and family separations we ignored…. The Removed is powerful storytelling."

—NPR

"If we tell ourselves stories to expand our worldview, then modern literature is one of society's most powerful tools.... Rich in Cherokee folklore."

—San Francisco Chronicle

title: Calling for a Blanket Dance
long_summary:
Family trauma ripples through generations in Oscar Hokeah's debut novel about a mixed-heritage boy caught between worlds. Ever Geimausaddle carries the weight of his father's brutal encounter with police corruption, while his mother battles to maintain stability as their household teeters on the edge.

Surrounded by relatives who each envision a different future for him, Ever must navigate competing visions of identity and belonging. His Cherokee grandmother believes proximity to family holds the key to healing. His grandfather sees salvation in traditional gourd dances and ancestral practices. Each family member carries pieces of wisdom about survival, community, and the delicate work of preserving culture across generations.

Hokeah crafts a narrative that examines how young people forge identity when society offers no clear space for their existence. The novel traces Ever's journey toward understanding the profound networks of support that exist within Indigenous and Mexican communities, and how that understanding might become a foundation for protecting future generations. This is storytelling that honors the complexity of mixed heritage while celebrating the resilience found in extended family bonds.
short_summary: Ever Geimausaddle navigates family expectations and cultural identity in this powerful debut about finding home. Hokeah writes with unflinching honesty about community, heritage, and the strength we inherit from those who love us.
author_bios: Oscar Hokeah draws from Cherokee Nation and Kiowa Tribe heritage on his mother's side, along with Mexican ancestry through his father. His educational background includes a BFA in Creative Writing from the Institute of American Indian Arts with a minor in Indigenous Liberal Studies, plus an MA in English focusing on Native American Literature from the University of Oklahoma. Hokeah has earned recognition through the Truman Capote Scholarship Award and the Native Writer Award from Taos Summer Writers Conference. His fiction appears in publications including American Short Fiction, Yellow Medicine Review, and Red Ink Magazine, while he serves his community through work in Indian Child Welfare in Tahlequah.
quotes:
"With intricate prose and unflinching vernacular, Oscar Hokeah chronicles a family and a community. We learn trials and aspirations for each generation, and witness what is woven into complicated arrival. We need these characters and their testimonies. But more than that, we crave –I crave—this kind of honest storytelling. These rhythms. These dances. This beauty. This welcoming to a place where the people speak and are unafraid."

—Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, author of The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois

"Oscar Hokeah is the real deal.  A new voice with ancient music."

—Luis Alberto Urrea, author of The House of Broken Angels

"[A] captivating debut . . . with striking insight into human nature and beautiful prose, this heralds an exciting new voice."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Rib King
long_summary:
August Sitwell has dedicated fifteen years to serving the Barclay family, managing their grounds alongside a small community of Black workers including the gifted cook Miss Mamie. Their employer's financial ruin threatens everything until a business opportunity emerges: marketing Miss Mamie's exceptional rib sauce using August's image as a demeaning mascot.

The cruel irony cuts deep—while the white family stands to recover their wealth, the very people whose labor and creativity fuel this venture receive nothing. August watches his dignity stripped away, transformed into a grotesque caricature for commercial gain. As humiliation festers into fury, the psychological toll becomes unbearable.

Hubbard constructs a devastating portrait of exploitation disguised as opportunity, examining how America has long profited from Black talent while denying Black humanity. The novel interrogates the violence inherent in racial caricature and the crushing weight of systemic dehumanization. Through August's mounting desperation, readers witness the human cost of treating people as commodities, building toward consequences that feel both inevitable and tragic.
short_summary: When a white family's fortune crumbles, they exploit their Black servants' talents for profit, using a degrading caricature without compensation. Hubbard delivers a searing examination of American racism and the dangerous seeds of rage.
author_bios: Ladee Hubbard wrote The Rib King and The Talented Ribkins, with the latter earning her the 2018 Ernest J. Gaines Award for Literary Excellence and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award for Debut Fiction. Her work has been featured in Guernica, The Times Literary Supplement, Copper Nickel and Callaloo. Hubbard has been honored with a Radcliffe Institute Fellowship, Berlin Prize Fellowship, Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award, and residencies at MacDowell, Art Omi, and Hedgebrook. Originally from Massachusetts and raised in the U.S. Virgin Islands and Florida, she now makes her home in New Orleans.
quotes:
"Ladee Hubbard's sophomore novel, The Rib King, is a fascinating story about the intersection of ambition, race and revenge. . . Hubbard crafts unforgettable characters and masterfully builds suspense."

—The Washington Post

"Hubbard's own superpower is her gift for building extraordinary worlds that examine troubled periods of America's past while shedding light on the unquestionable innovation and determination of African Americans who, perhaps improbably, thrived within them."

—Los Angeles Times

"One will be impressed at all times with Hubbard's control over her historical milieu as well as her complicated, intriguing characterizations. . . . An imaginative work craftily depicting the failure of imagination that is American racism."

—Kirkus

title: My Monticello
long_summary:
America stands on the brink of collapse, and survival demands impossible choices. In this debut collection, characters navigate a landscape where history's wounds refuse to heal and the future offers no guarantees.

The centerpiece novella thrusts readers into chaos as white supremacist violence erupts in Charlottesville. A young Black woman who carries the DNA of both Thomas Jefferson and Sally Hemings must lead her neighbors to safety—finding shelter in the very plantation where her ancestors lived as enslaved people. The irony cuts deep: seeking sanctuary in a monument to the oppression that still threatens to destroy them.

Elsewhere, a father turns his infant son into an unwitting subject of racial experimentation, documenting every moment to prove that prejudice is learned, not innate. Other stories follow characters grappling with displacement and identity—immigrants searching for belonging, mixed-race individuals crafting new selves, mothers preparing for catastrophe while clinging to hope.

Johnson crafts a collection that refuses easy answers about race, survival, and what it means to call America home. These stories interrogate our national mythology while honoring the resilience of those who endure its contradictions.
short_summary: Characters fighting to survive in an America teetering toward collapse—a woman descended from Jefferson and Hemings fleeing white militia, a professor secretly experimenting on his own son, a mother buying her first home as catastrophe looms.
author_bios: Jocelyn Nicole Johnson teaches art in public schools and makes her home in Charlottesville, Virginia. Her fiction and essays have been published in Guernica, the Guardian, Kweli, Joyland, phoebe, Prime Number Magazine, and other publications. Her story "Control Negro" appeared in Best American Short Stories 2018 and was featured on PRI's Selected Shorts, read by LeVar Burton. Johnson has received fellowships from Hedgebrook, Tin House Summer Workshops, and VCCA.
quotes:
"My Monticello is a gorgeous, devastating collection of stories spotlighting the ways a life, a country, and a planet can tend toward disaster but still be worth fighting for. Johnson's stories exquisitely balance the interior and the exterior: the world of inequalities and disappointments stacked against her characters is illuminated by their full and compelling desires, and by her honest exploration of the major and minor cruelties survival requires. This is a stunning debut by a brilliant and original new voice."

—Danielle Evans, author of Before you Suffocate Your Own Fool Self & The Office of Historical Corrections

"There is a special pleasure in discovering a voice that is vital and unlike anything else you've known before. Jocelyn Nicole Johnson is such a voice. One that is necessary and brimming with both heart and imagination, Johnson's My Monticello is a beautiful debut work of art."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, New York Times bestselling author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"My Monticello is a magnificent debut that holds so much in its gaze—great love and great oppression, tremendous individual courage and systemic racism, futures of joyful justice and futures of extremism. This breathtaking, artful book is a gift."

—Megha Majumdar, New York Times bestselling author of A Burning

title: Vladimir
long_summary:
Academia becomes a battlefield of desire and scandal in this audacious debut that refuses to look away from uncomfortable truths. At the center stands an English professor whose marriage operates on carefully negotiated freedoms—until her husband faces serious allegations from former students that threaten to destroy everything.

As the investigation unfolds, she finds herself drawn to Vladimir, a young literary star whose arrival on their small campus ignites an obsession she cannot control. The timing couldn't be worse, yet she cannot resist the pull of her own wants against the backdrop of her husband's potential downfall.

Julia May Jonas crafts a fearless examination of female desire, academic privilege, and the messy contradictions of modern relationships. This is a novel that dares to ask difficult questions about power, consent, and the stories we tell ourselves about our own moral choices. Sharp-witted and uncompromising, it captures the particular anxiety of our cultural moment while delivering a story that is both intellectually rigorous and utterly addictive.
short_summary: An English professor's marriage implodes when her husband faces accusations from former students—just as she develops her own dangerous obsession. Darkly funny and provocative.
author_bios: Julia May Jonas brings her background in theater direction and academia to her literary work, having taught at both Skidmore College and New York University. Based in Brooklyn with her family, Jonas makes her fiction debut with Vladimir, drawing on her deep understanding of academic culture and human complexity.
quotes:
"Funny, wise and instantly engaging, Vladimir is how I like my thrill rides: brainy and sexy."

—Maria Semple, author of Where'd You Go Bernadette

"Vladimir is a thrilling debut—smart, sharp, and über provocative. I devoured it with fascination and awe."

—Lily King, author of Writers and Lovers & Euphoria

"Delightful…a witty dance with the ghost of Nabokov and a razor-edged commentary on academia at our current fraught moment...by turns, cathartic, devious and terrifically entertaining."

—Jean Hanff Korelitz, The New York Times

title: Greek Lessons
long_summary:
Two strangers find themselves sharing the same space in a Greek language class in Seoul, each carrying invisible wounds. She sits in silence, unable to speak after losing both her mother and her child in a custody battle that has left her world shattered. He stands at the front of the room, teaching a language he loves while confronting the gradual loss of his eyesight and grappling with a lifetime of existing between Korean and German identities.

What emerges between them transcends traditional notions of communication. Their respective losses—her voice, his vision—become the very foundation for an unexpected understanding. Han Kang weaves their individual struggles into something larger, examining how trauma can both isolate and ultimately connect us. The novel asks profound questions about the nature of language itself: how we find meaning beyond words, how silence can speak volumes, and how two people can discover intimacy through shared vulnerability rather than conventional exchange.
short_summary: Two wounded souls meet in a Seoul language classroom—she has lost her voice, he is losing his sight. Han Kang crafts an exquisite meditation on connection and healing.
author_bios: Born in South Korea in 1970, Han Kang has established herself as one of contemporary literature's most distinctive voices. Her novels include The Vegetarian, which earned the International Booker Prize, along with Human Acts, The White Book, Greek Lessons, and We Do Not Part. Han Kang received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2024, cementing her position as a major literary figure.
quotes:
"Sinuous and sublime . . . an extraordinary meditation on language, violence, loss and intimacy. Han Kang is a writer like no other. In a few lines, she seems to traverse the entirety of human experience."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies

"A love letter to language, learning, and the hope of connection. It is about the mind and the body, our thoughts and our senses—about what it means to be a person in the world."

—Julia Phillips, author of Disappearing Earth

"[Kang] is an astute chronicler of unusual, insubordinate women. . . [Greek Lessons is] for readers drawn to considering language itself as a source of self-revelation . . . a celebration of the ineffable trust to be found in sharing language."

—The New York Times

title: Yellowface
long_summary:
June Hayward has watched her former Yale classmate Athena Liu become everything she dreamed of being—a celebrated author whose novels cross genres and capture critical acclaim. Meanwhile, June's own writing career has stagnated, leaving her bitter and desperate for recognition.

Everything changes in an instant during what should have been an ordinary evening. Faced with an opportunity she never imagined, June makes a split-second decision that will reshape her entire life. She claims ownership of an unpublished manuscript about Chinese workers' forgotten contributions to World War I—a work of experimental fiction that isn't hers to take.

Transforming herself into "Juniper Song" with carefully crafted ambiguity about her background, June watches as the stolen work catapults her to literary stardom. The acclaim, the bestseller status, the recognition she's craved for years—it all feels within reach.

Yet success built on deception proves fragile. As questions arise and suspicions mount, June finds herself trapped in an increasingly complex web of lies. The very recognition she sought threatens to destroy her as she grapples with how far she's willing to go to protect what she's taken. This cutting examination of literary ambition exposes uncomfortable truths about representation, privilege, and the price of stolen success.
short_summary: When her successful friend dies in a freak accident, struggling writer June steals her manuscript and rebrands herself as Juniper Song. A razor-sharp thriller about literary fraud and cultural appropriation.
author_bios: Rebecca F. Kuang wrote the internationally celebrated Poppy War trilogy along with Babel: An Arcane History and Yellowface, earning her #1 New York Times and Sunday Times bestseller status. Her novels have garnered the Nebula, Locus, Crawford, and British Book Awards. As a Marshall Scholar, Rebecca F. Kuang earned her MPhil in Chinese Studies from Cambridge and MSc in Contemporary Chinese Studies from Oxford. She continues her academic work as a PhD candidate at Yale, focusing on East Asian Languages and Literatures with emphasis on diaspora, contemporary Sinophone literature, and Asian American literature.
quotes:
"This is a great read. Crime, satire, horror, paranoia, questions of cultural appropriation. Plenty of nasty social media pile-ons, too. But, basically, just a great story. Hard to put down, harder to forget."

—Stephen King

"Viciously satisfying…addictive."

—The New York Times

"Well-executed, gripping, fast-paced novel."

—NPR

title: Babel
subtitle: Or the Necessity of Violence: An Arcane History of the Oxford Translators' Revolution
long_summary:
In Victorian England, translation becomes the ultimate weapon of empire. At Oxford's secretive Babel institute, scholars discover that silver can capture the untranslatable essence between languages—and transform it into magical power that fuels British dominance across the globe.

Robin Swift arrives at this academic paradise as a young Chinese orphan, groomed by his enigmatic guardian to master the linguistic arts that make imperial expansion possible. Yet as Robin delves deeper into his studies, the moral contradictions of his position become impossible to ignore. The very skills he's developing serve to strengthen the chains binding his homeland.

The Hermes Society offers an alternative—a clandestine network working to dismantle the system from within. But as tensions escalate and Britain prepares for war with China, Robin must confront a fundamental question about resistance and complicity. In a world where words literally become weapons, can scholarship ever remain neutral? The choice between loyalty and justice will force Robin to decide whether true change demands working within corrupt institutions or tearing them down entirely.
short_summary: Dark academia meets anticolonial fantasy in this brilliant exploration of language as power. Robin Swift must choose between Oxford's magical translation institute and his loyalty to China as the British Empire weaponizes words themselves.
author_bios: Rebecca F. Kuang wrote the internationally celebrated Poppy War trilogy along with Babel: An Arcane History and Yellowface, earning her #1 New York Times and Sunday Times bestseller status. Her novels have garnered the Nebula, Locus, Crawford, and British Book Awards. As a Marshall Scholar, Rebecca F. Kuang earned her MPhil in Chinese Studies from Cambridge and MSc in Contemporary Chinese Studies from Oxford. She continues her academic work as a PhD candidate at Yale, focusing on East Asian Languages and Literatures with emphasis on diaspora, contemporary Sinophone literature, and Asian American literature.
quotes:
"Babel has earned tremendous praise and deserves all of it. It's Philip Pullman's The Golden Compass by way of N.K. Jemisin's The Fifth Season: inventive and engaging, passionate and precise. Kuang is fiercely disciplined even when she's playful and experimental … Like the silver bars at its heart—like empires and academic institutions both—Babel derives its power from sustaining a contradiction, from trying to hold in your head both love and hatred for the charming thing that sustains itself by devouring you."

—The New York Times

"A fantastical takedown of 19th-century imperialism that's as meaty as its title. R.F. Kuang proved her prowess at blending history and magic with her debut series, The Poppy War, and she's done it once again in this sweeping novel that blends historical fantasy and dark academia…If, as Babel suggests, words contain magic, then Kuang has written something spellbinding."

—Oprah Daily

"It's ambitious and powerful while displaying a deep love of language and literature...Dark academia as it should be."

—Kirkus

title: Lone Women
long_summary:
The Montana Territory in 1915 offers free land to anyone willing to brave its harsh wilderness, and Adelaide Henry desperately needs a fresh start. She arrives with nothing but determination and a massive steamer trunk that never leaves her side—a trunk she keeps locked for reasons that go far beyond simple privacy.

Fleeing a tragedy in California that cost her everything, Adelaide joins the ranks of women homesteaders carving out new lives on the frontier. But the very thing she's trying to escape may prove essential to her survival in this unforgiving landscape. As Adelaide struggles to build a life among fellow outcasts and dreamers, the contents of her trunk represent both her greatest shame and potentially her only salvation.

This gothic tale transforms the American West into a stage for supernatural terror and unexpected solidarity. LaValle examines how secrets can simultaneously destroy and protect us, while exploring the bonds formed between those society has cast aside. The result is a story that questions whether redemption comes from burying our past or finally confronting what we've tried so hard to hide.
short_summary: In 1915, Adelaide Henry hauls a locked steamer trunk with a deadly secret to the Montana frontier, seeking redemption as a homesteader. Western gothic horror meets historical fiction.
author_bios: Victor LaValle has published seven works of fiction, including four novels, two novellas, and a short story collection. His books have earned spots on year-end best lists from The New York Times Book Review, Los Angeles Times, The Washington Post, and Publishers Weekly. LaValle's honors include a Guggenheim Fellowship, an American Book Award, the Shirley Jackson Award, and the Key to Southeast Queens. He is a professor at Columbia University and makes his home in the Bronx.
quotes:
"Enthralling . . . The combination of LaValle's agile prose, the velocity of the narrative and the pleasure of upended expectations makes this book almost impossible to put down . . . Lone Women deftly weaves history, horror, suspense and the perspectives of those rarely recorded in the West."

—The New York Times

"Propulsive [with] a fast-paced plot—though I found myself gripped just as much by Adelaide's defiant, glorious stubbornness and guarded wit. Lone Women combines elements of Western fiction, horror and magical realism, while featuring queer, POC characters inventing lives for themselves in the last years of the American frontier. It's impossible to categorize and impossible to put down."

—NPR

"LaValle gets coy in Lone Women, teasing us by trickling details that gradually reveal Adelaide's intricate connection to the creature. Meanwhile, he adroitly intertwines the eerie fairy tale with early 20th-century historical realism."

—The Washington Post

title: The Book of Goose
long_summary:
The death of a childhood friend becomes the catalyst for a reckoning with the past. Agnès, now living quietly in Pennsylvania, finally confronts the memories she's spent a decade avoiding—memories of growing up in rural postwar France with Fabienne, a girl whose fierce imagination and dangerous schemes would forever alter both their lives.

Their bond transcended ordinary friendship, creating a universe known only to them in a town still scarred by war. But Fabienne's ambitions extended beyond their private world, and her machinations would propel Agnès on a journey spanning continents—from provincial France to the sophistication of Paris, from the rigid confines of English boarding schools to eventual refuge in America.

This is a novel about the magnetic pull between two young women, the price of escape, and the weight of survival. Li crafts a narrative that examines how childhood alliances can become both salvation and trap, revealing the thin line between devotion and manipulation, between protection and control.
short_summary: When news of her childhood best friend's death arrives, Agnès finally tells the story of their disturbing intimacy—and the plan that launched her toward fame and loss.
author_bios: Yiyun Li has written Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; A Thousand Years of Good Prayers; and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. Her work has earned her a PEN/Faulkner Award, PEN/Malamud Award, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, MacArthur Fellowship, and Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She teaches at Princeton University.
quotes:
"A compulsively readable meditation on how our closest friendships harbor both love and hate—and how we can fail each other over and over again . . . Li's crystalline, insightful prose adds incredible depth to the drama, yet the dynamic between the girls remains the complex heart of The Book of Goose."

—Sarah Rose Etter, BOMB

"Li, of course, has never been the kind of writer who tells you what you want to hear, and this is surely part of why she has become, while still in her 40s, one of our finest living authors: Her elegant metaphysics never elide the blood and maggots."

—Megan O'Grady, The New York Times

"Exquisite . . . Knives, minerals, oranges, and the game of Rock Paper Scissors sneak into Agnès' narrative as she relates the trajectory of a once-unbreakable union. The relative hardness of those substances is a clue to understanding it all. Stunners: Li's memorable duo, their lives, their losses."

—Kirkus

title: These Summer Storms
long_summary:
Five years of exile end abruptly for Alice Storm when her billionaire father dies, forcing her back to the family's Rhode Island estate she swore never to see again. What should be a simple funeral becomes something far more complicated thanks to her father's posthumous manipulation.

The old patriarch has orchestrated one final power play: an elaborate inheritance challenge that traps the fractured Storm family together for seven days. Alice finds herself navigating not just her own complicated feelings about returning home, but the explosive dynamics of siblings who've grown into strangers. Her sister harbors a dangerous romance, her brother's ego dominates every conversation, and family tensions simmer under their mother's disapproving watch.

Complicating matters is Jack Dean, her father's enigmatic right-hand man whose presence stirs up feelings Alice thought she'd left buried. As the week unfolds, long-buried secrets surface and old resentments clash with unexpected moments of connection. This emotionally rich story examines how loss can crack open even the most guarded hearts, revealing both the wounds families inflict and their surprising capacity for healing.
short_summary: When Alice Storm returns to her wealthy family's private island for her father's funeral, she discovers he's left them an inheritance game that requires spending one torturous week together. Family secrets, forbidden romance, and old wounds collide in this addictive family drama.
author_bios: Sarah MacLean has written bestselling novels that have reached readers in more than twenty-five languages worldwide. She co-hosts the popular romance podcast Fated Mates and stands as an influential voice in contemporary romance fiction. Drawing inspiration from Rhode Island summers and New England storms, Sarah MacLean currently makes her home in New York City.
quotes:
"An addictive, engrossing story that combines generational drama, mystery, and the sizzling romance we've all come to expect from Sarah MacLean. It's perfect for fans of Succession and Knives Out."

—Ali Hazelwood, #1 New York Times bestselling author

"Poignant overtures of grief, deliciously complicated family dynamics, and forbidden love thread together in a perfect tapestry of mystery and romance."

—Ashley Poston, New York Times bestselling author of The Seven Year Slip

"From the first rumbles of thunder to the final torrential downpour, MacLean takes readers for a wild ride!"

—Abby Jimenez, New York Times bestselling author of Just for the Summer

title: The Mirror & the Light
long_summary:
Thomas Cromwell stands at the pinnacle of Tudor power, having survived the bloody spectacle of Anne Boleyn's execution to become Henry VIII's most trusted advisor. Yet for all his influence, this blacksmith's son from Putney remains fundamentally alone—dependent solely on his cunning and adaptability in a court where loyalty shifts like quicksand.

As Henry grows increasingly erratic and England faces mounting threats from within and abroad, Cromwell finds himself walking an ever-narrower path between survival and destruction. His vision of a transformed England—modern, unified, freed from the weight of its medieval past—drives him forward even as the ground beneath his feet grows treacherous.

Mantel's concluding volume examines the price of ambition and the impossibility of escaping history's long shadow. Through Cromwell's final chapter, she illuminates the eternal struggle between individual will and the forces that ultimately consume even the most brilliant political minds. The result is a meditation on power, mortality, and the question of whether any person—however gifted—can truly reshape the world without being destroyed by it.
short_summary: The final volume in Mantel's Cromwell trilogy traces his rise to unparalleled power and his brutal fall. Majestic and immersive, it completes one of the great achievements of modern historical fiction.
author_bios: Hilary Mantel wrote the acclaimed Thomas Cromwell trilogy, with Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies each earning the Booker Prize. The Mirror & the Light, which completed the series, reached the top of the New York Times bestseller list upon publication. Throughout her career, she published seventeen books, including her memoir Giving Up the Ghost, and received numerous honors such as the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction, Walter Scott Prize, Costa Book Award, and Hawthornden Prize. The British government recognized her contributions to literature by naming her Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2014. She passed away in 2022.
quotes:
"Two years ago something astonishingly fair happened in the world of prestigious prizes: the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction for 2009 both went to the right winner. The book was Hilary Mantel's Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year…It was a hard act to follow. But the follow-up is equally sublime…That ironic ending will be no cliffhanger for anyone even remotely familiar with Henry VIII's trail of carnage. But in Bring Up the Bodies it works as one. The wonder of Ms. Mantel's retelling is that she makes these events fresh and terrifying all over again."

—The New York Times

"Bring Up the Bodies isn't just her boldest book; it's also her best -- and it reaffirms Mantel's reputation as one of England's greatest living novelists."

—NPR

"the finest works of historical fiction in contemporary literature."

—The Washington Post

title: The Hero of This Book
long_summary:
A daughter carries her grief across an ocean, finding herself in London—a city that once captivated her late mother. The streets become a canvas for remembrance as she confronts the reality of loss: back home, the family house awaits new owners, its rooms already emptied of a lifetime's accumulation.

Memories surface with each step—her mother's razor-sharp humor, her boundless capacity for giving, her stubborn refusal to yield to physical frailty. Yet beneath these recollections lies a more troubling question: what right does a writer have to transform private pain into public art?

McCracken weaves together themes of inheritance and imagination, asking whether love justifies exposure, whether stories heal or exploit. The result transcends simple mourning to become an inquiry into the very nature of creation itself. Through prose that shifts between laughter and sorrow, she reveals how artists must navigate the treacherous territory between honoring the dead and honoring their secrets. This is literature as archaeology—digging through the layers of relationship to uncover what endures when everything else crumbles.
short_summary: A writer mourning her mother's death takes a trip to London and grapples with memory, grief, and the ethics of storytelling. McCracken's latest is both heartbreaking and luminous.
author_bios: Elizabeth McCracken has written eight books, with her work including The Hero of This Book, The Souvenir Museum (long-listed for the National Book Award), Bowlaway, Thunderstruck & Other Stories (winner of the 2014 Story Prize), and The Giant's House (a National Book Award finalist). Her short fiction has earned recognition through five appearances in The Best American Short Stories, three Pushcart Prizes, two National Magazine Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. McCracken currently serves as the James A. Michener Chair in Fiction at the University of Texas at Austin.
quotes:
"The Hero of This Book defies description. Just read it. . . Page by page, it's the quiet story of an adult child mourning a parent. As a whole, it's a map of how to love someone… With admirable candor, pragmatism and humor, McCracken gives us a confessional gift as she walks through the experience of processing loss."

—The Washington Post

"[H]er words create an exquisite alchemy that makes a reader ready to follow her anywhere, believe every word she writes down. Is this book a novel or is it a memoir? It matters not at all. With every vital, potent sentence, McCracken conveys the electric and primal nature of that first fundamental love."

—Janice Y.K. Lee, The New York Times

"[A] beguiling meditation on family, grief, and caretaking that also addresses the burdens of storytelling: how much freedom you have — or don't — to write about family members after they're gone. With infinite freedom to invent, McCracken sparkles."

—The Boston Globe

title: One Last Stop
long_summary:
August arrives in New York with armor made of skepticism, convinced that romance belongs only in movies and magic exists nowhere at all. Her plan is simple: keep her head down, serve pancakes at her diner job, and prove that cynicism beats hope every time.

Then Jane steps onto her subway car—leather jacket, vintage style, and a smile that makes August question everything she thought she knew about love at first sight. What starts as stolen glances during daily commutes grows into something deeper, until August discovers the impossible truth: Jane isn't just dressed like she stepped out of the 1970s punk scene. She's actually been trapped on this subway line for decades, caught in a temporal loop that defies explanation.

Suddenly August faces a choice that terrifies her—embrace the very magic she's spent years denying, or lose the person who's shown her that some things are worth believing in. With help from her eccentric roommates and a crash course in time-bending romance, August must decide whether love is powerful enough to transcend both time and her own fears.
short_summary: August's cynical worldview crumbles when she falls for Jane, a mysterious girl on the subway who turns out to be displaced from the 1970s. A magical romance about believing in the impossible.
author_bios: Casey McQuiston has written several romantic comedies that became #1 New York Times bestsellers, including Red, White & Royal Blue, One Last Stop, and I Kissed Shara Wheeler. Their work has been featured in major publications such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, and Bon Appetit. Originally from southern Louisiana, Casey McQuiston currently resides in New York City alongside their poodle mix, Pepper.
quotes:
"A breathtaking love story, filled with heart, yearning, coming of age, and the most wonderful found family. Honest, often humorous, always relevant, McQuiston's writing reads like poetry. One Last Stop is meant to be savored slowly."

—Helen Hoang, USA Today bestselling author of The Kiss Quotient and The Heart Principle

"Part romance, part fantasy, this gorgeous novel is about meeting someone on your daily commute — a girl, it turns out, who has been riding the train since the 1970s, thanks to a magical timeslip. But it's also about loneliness, and being unmoored from normal time, and missing people you've lost, and dealing with generational trauma and fearing an unknowable future."

—The New York Times

"McQuiston's joyful sophomore romp mixes all the elements that made Red, White & Royal Blue so outstanding—quirky characters, coming-of-age confusion, laugh-out-loud narration, and hilarious pop-cultural references—into something totally its own...With all the fun and camp of a drag show (of which this novel features more than one) but grounded in the tenderness of first love, this time-slip rom-com is an absolute delight."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Milk Blood Heat
long_summary:
In this striking debut collection, Florida's humid landscape serves as more than mere setting—it becomes a character itself, shaping the lives of those who navigate its complexities. Moniz crafts stories that examine how people respond to life's most jarring disruptions: grief that refuses boundaries, faith that crumbles under pressure, and family bonds that both sustain and suffocate.

The collection moves through different perspectives and ages, from adolescents grappling with sudden loss to adults whose past traumas resurface in unexpected ways. A young person questions religious expectations while facing accusations of spiritual rebellion. Siblings embark on a journey carrying their father's remains, discovering how his influence persists even in death. Each narrative reveals characters at crossroads, forced to confront truths about themselves and their relationships that they've long avoided.

Moniz demonstrates a keen understanding of how geography and identity intertwine, using Florida's unique cultural landscape to explore broader questions about belonging, heritage, and survival. The stories circle back on themselves, creating connections that illuminate the universal struggles within deeply specific circumstances.
short_summary: Florida becomes the backdrop for intimate reckonings with family, faith, and loss. Moniz's debut collection captures the elemental darkness and surprising grace found in ordinary lives pushed to extraordinary moments.
author_bios: Dantiel W. Moniz has earned recognition through the Alice Hoffman Prize for Fiction, the Cecelia Joyce Johnson Emerging Writer Award, and a Tin House Scholarship. Her stories have been published in prestigious journals including the Paris Review, Tin House, Ploughshares, the Yale Review, Joyland, and McSweeney's Quarterly Concern. Currently serving as Assistant Professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, she makes her home in Northeast Florida. Milk Blood Heat marks her debut collection.
quotes:
"Dantiel W. Moniz sings of Florida, girlhood, family, loss, and the glorious, ecstatic, devastating human body. A gorgeous debut from a wickedly talented new writer."

—Lauren Groff, author of Florida, Fates & Furies & Arcadia

"The stories in this book are rigorous and complex, lush and surprising. They are visceral, full of the intimate awe of existing in flesh. A wonder of a debut."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"These stories and the characters that drive them are like lightning—spectacular, beautiful, carrying a hint of danger. Dantiel Moniz is a brilliant new talent, her writing lush and sharp, her landscape so rich it feels we could step into it, her characters so alive and full of longing that they might step of the page and take the reader with them wherever they're headed next. Milk Blood Heat is a stunning and important debut."

—Danielle Evans, author of Before You Suffocate Your Own Fool Self

title: People Like Us
long_summary:
Violence fractures the American landscape, yet two writers refuse to surrender their humanity to despair. Jason Mott constructs a literary funhouse where the impossible becomes inevitable—peacocks materialize from thin air, sea creatures breach reality's surface, and time bends like light through a prism.

One author circles the globe, clutching a prestigious award while grappling with success's hollow weight. Meanwhile, his counterpart faces a different kind of spotlight: addressing students whose innocence was shattered by bullets. Their parallel journeys spiral toward each other through a maze of absurdist encounters and heartbreaking truths.

Mott refuses to choose between comedy and tragedy, instead forging something fiercer. His characters inhabit a universe where grief and laughter occupy the same breath, where surreal imagery serves as both shield and sword against an incomprehensible world. The result challenges readers to find meaning in chaos, hope in devastation, and connection across seemingly impossible distances. This is storytelling that risks everything—sanity, convention, easy answers—in pursuit of something more essential than comfort.
short_summary: Two Black writers seek peace in a world torn by gun violence—one on a global book tour, another speaking at a school after a shooting. Mott weaves reality and surreal dreams into something wickedly funny and achingly profound.
author_bios: Jason Mott completed his BFA in Fiction and MFA in Poetry at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington, launching a career that spans multiple genres. His work has appeared in numerous literary journals, establishing him as a versatile voice in contemporary fiction. Mott gained widespread recognition with The Returned, which became a New York Times bestseller and inspired a television adaptation that ran for two seasons. He has written four novels total, including Hell of a Book, which earned him the National Book Award for Fiction in 2021.
quotes:
"The follow-up to Mott's National Book Award-winning Hell of a Book weaves the stories of two Black authors — one on an international book tour, the other confronting a deadly school shooting — into a comedic, surreal exploration of love and loss."

—The New York Times

"The novel's mischievous humor gradually gives way to a frightening fever dream. Mott's satire is thoroughly uncompromising, which makes it all the more refreshing."

—Publishers Weekly

"A meta-novel that stings and touches the reader.... The whole book seems the literary equivalent of a post-bop jazz performance, with oblique happenings that compel attention because of the book's antic energy and lyrical passages."

—Kirkus

title: If an Egyptian Cannot Speak English
long_summary:
Two strangers cross paths in a Cairo café, their lives forever altered by the collision. She arrives from America carrying the weight of inherited nostalgia, seeking connection to an Egypt that exists more in imagination than memory. He carries a camera that once documented revolution, now silent witness to his own unraveling.

Their attraction ignites quickly, fed by mutual fascination and the intoxicating possibility of transformation through the other. Yet beneath the surface romance lurks something more complex—questions of privilege, displacement, and the stories we tell ourselves about belonging. As their relationship intensifies, the line between love and exploitation blurs, revealing uncomfortable truths about power, desire, and the price of seeking authenticity in someone else's struggle.

Through shifting viewpoints, this debut interrogates the mythology of homeland and the violence that can emerge when people become symbols rather than individuals. It asks difficult questions about who owns suffering, who profits from revolution's aftermath, and what happens when the personal becomes political in the most intimate spaces.
short_summary: Post-revolution Cairo becomes the backdrop for a toxic romance between an Egyptian American woman and a local photographer. Experimental fiction that dissects desire, identity, and the new faces of empire.
author_bios: Noor Naga, an Alexandrian writer, has received recognition through the Bronwen Wallace Award, RBC/PEN Canada Award, and Disquiet Fiction Prize. Her previous work includes the verse novel Washes, Prays, and she currently teaches at the American University in Cairo.
quotes:
"Propulsive and philosophical. . . . The novel brims with sparkling prose. Naga's sentences are precise and rich with bold, complex observations. . . . [An] exhilarating debut."

—Nadia Owusu, The New York Times

"Naga impresses with her snappy prose . . . and has a gift for exploring varied perspectives. . . . This smart story is distinguished by its surprising empathy."

—Publishers Weekly

"A fascinating novel about class and abuse. . . . [Noor]Naga's writing in the book's first two parts is gripping, but the final section, metafictional and darkly funny, is an absolute master class. She deals with important issues with a gimlet eye and a rare sensitivity-it would be a massive understatement to call this novel a must-read. In a word: brilliant."

—Kirkus

title: Tom Lake
long_summary:
During the isolation of early pandemic lockdown, a mother finds herself working alongside her three adult daughters in their family cherry orchard. The rhythm of harvest work creates space for storytelling, and the daughters press Lara to share memories of her acting days—particularly about Peter Duke, a celebrated performer who once shared her stage and her heart.

Through these intimate conversations among the cherry trees, multiple generations of women examine the mysteries that exist between parents and children. The daughters discover that their mother's life contained depths of experience they never imagined, while Lara reflects on the different forms love has taken throughout her years.

This novel weaves together questions about the stories families tell and withhold, the persistence of hope during dark times, and how we find meaning in both grand gestures and quiet moments. Against the backdrop of global uncertainty, it celebrates the sustaining power of work, memory, and the bonds that anchor us to each other and to the land we tend.
short_summary: Three daughters beg their mother to share stories of her theatrical past while picking cherries during the 2020 lockdown. A luminous meditation on love, family secrets, and finding happiness amid uncertainty.
author_bios: Ann Patchett has written multiple novels, including the recent #1 New York Times bestseller Tom Lake, along with nonfiction works and children's literature. Among her many honors are the PEN/Faulkner Award, the Women's Prize for Fiction, and the Book Sense Book of the Year. The Dutch House earned her a Pulitzer Prize nomination. Time magazine recognized her as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World, and President Biden presented her with the National Humanities Medal. She operates Parnassus Books in Nashville, Tennessee.
quotes:
"Tom Lake is about romantic love, marital love and maternal love, but also the love of animals, the love of stories, love of the land and trees and the tiny, red, cordiform object that is a cherry. . . . This generous writer hits the mark again with her ninth novel."

—The Washington Post

"Wise. Beautiful. With an elegant soft touch….Brilliant, of course."

—Good Morning America

"A quiet and reassuring book . . . highly conscious of . . . [the] human failure to appreciate the little things."

—The New York Times

title: The Rich People Have Gone Away
long_summary:
A devastating confession shatters what should have been a safe retreat from pandemic chaos. While privileged couples flee to country homes, others remain trapped in the city, fighting to preserve livelihoods and dreams amid unprecedented uncertainty.

The revelation of buried truths transforms a hiking trail into the site of an unthinkable disappearance. Suddenly, refuge becomes nightmare, and a husband finds himself at the center of a mystery that threatens to destroy everything he holds dear.

Neighbors who barely knew each other's names become unlikely allies in a desperate search. Restaurant owners, teenagers, and longtime friends must bridge divides of class and circumstance, discovering that crisis reveals both the fragility and unexpected strength of human bonds. Their investigation unearths connections between past choices and present consequences that none of them anticipated.

This novel captures the claustrophobic intensity of lockdown New York while examining how shared purpose can emerge from individual tragedy. It's a story about the weight of secrets, the complexity of urban community, and the ways people surprise themselves when everything familiar falls apart.
short_summary: When a pregnant woman disappears after her husband reveals a devastating secret, their diverse circle of New York friends and neighbors unite in the search. A gripping exploration of community, privilege, and connection during lockdown.
author_bios: Regina Porter earned recognition as both a playwright and novelist, with her debut novel The Travelers receiving PEN/Hemingway Award finalist honors and Orwell Prize longlisting. After completing her studies at Iowa Writers' Workshop, Porter has contributed fiction and essays to Harvard Review, Tin House, and Oxford American, establishing herself as a distinctive voice in contemporary literature.
quotes:
"An immersive examination of the human condition in the face of tragedy and triumph."

—Zakiya Dalila Harris, author of The Other Black Girl

"Regina Porter weaves beauty and humor with pathos, in prose that is winding, prescient, and profound."

—Bryan Washington, author of Family Meal

"Striking . . . Porter keenly explores themes of generational and racial privilege and a community's fragile bonds. This one makes the lockdown worth revisiting."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Greta & Valdin
long_summary:
Two siblings find themselves at crossroads that challenge everything they thought they knew about love and belonging. Valdin has built what seems like a stable life in Auckland—sharing a flat with his sister, maintaining his career as the office's only Māori employee, and keeping his emotions carefully compartmentalized since his breakup. But a work assignment unexpectedly lands him in Buenos Aires, face-to-face with the ex-boyfriend who shattered his world a year ago.

Meanwhile, Greta throws herself into graduate school and new romantic possibilities, determined not to let unrequited feelings derail her. Her plans for a drama-free life crumble as family chaos erupts around her: cryptic behavior from their mother, her nephew grappling with his sexuality, and Valdin's sudden disappearance to South America without explanation.

This debut novel captures the beautiful complexity of a sprawling Māori-Russian-Catalonian family whose members are all struggling to understand themselves and each other. Rebecca K Reilly weaves together questions of cultural identity, sexual awakening, and the courage required to pursue authentic connections. The result is a story that celebrates the messy, unpredictable nature of both family bonds and romantic love, finding humor and hope in life's most uncertain moments.
short_summary: Siblings navigate queerness, multiracial identity, and family chaos in this joyful New Zealand bestseller. When Valdin's work trip to Argentina reunites him with his ex, both he and sister Greta must confront what they really want from love.
author_bios: Rebecca K Reilly (Ngāti Hine, Ngāti Rehua Ngātiwai ki Aotea) was born in 1991 and grew up in Waitākere, New Zealand. She completed her BA (hons) in German and European studies at the University of Auckland before pursuing an MA at Victoria University of Wellington's International Institute of Modern Letters. During her graduate studies, Rebecca K Reilly received the Adam Foundation Prize in Creative Writing for 2019, recognizing her exceptional talent as an emerging Māori novelist.
quotes:
"Generous [and] tender. . . Reilly's warm, overflowing novel defies categorization because its characters are too complex and multifaceted to be easily summed up. They're too alive in their messiness. If this novel shows us anything, it's that love—of family, of romantic partners, of community—is most joyful when it's without limits."

—The New York Times

"The loving family at the heart of this very funny and moving novel about a brother and sister is so complex . . .  every bond in the book is written to be precious and specific. Greta & Valdin is the rare story to live up to its fearless promotional copy, which calls it a cross between Schitt's Creek and Normal People. Perhaps that sounds impossible; that's what makes it so good."

—Linda Holmes, NPR

"Say hello to your new favorite fictional family. In the wrong hands [Greta & Valdin] could all be quirk for quirk's sake, or a half-baked hybrid of Schitt's Creek and The Royal Tenenbaums. But Reilly's humor is so riotously specific, and the many moments of true poignancy so gently infused with that same humor, that the Vladisavljevics seem like no one but themselves. [. . . ] If Reilly won't give us a sequel, then we can at least hope she won't make us wait too long for her next novel."

—Kirkus

title: Liberation Day
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Nine interconnected tales examine the fragile bonds between people navigating a world where technology, politics, and circumstance conspire to isolate them. Saunders crafts scenarios both fantastical and eerily familiar: an elderly man whose memories have been deliberately erased for political gain, a grandfather writing to his grandson from a climate-ravaged future, two women confronting their shared past during a violent storm.

Each story functions as a moral experiment, testing characters against systems designed to exploit or diminish them. A worker at a macabre theme park begins to see through the illusions that have shaped his existence. Dreams deferred reveal their true cost in a brief but shattering meditation on what we sacrifice for security.

Through scenarios that range from the surreal to the achingly realistic, these narratives ask fundamental questions about loyalty, memory, and the courage required to remain human in dehumanizing circumstances. Saunders transforms the absurd into the profound, finding moments of grace and connection even in his most dystopian visions.
short_summary: Nine subversive stories that blend dystopian futures with tender humanity. Saunders explores power, ethics, and connection through his signature mix of dark comedy and devastating compassion.
author_bios: George Saunders has published thirteen books, including his Man Booker Prize-winning novel Lincoln in the Bardo and five story collections such as the National Book Award finalist Tenth of December and Liberation Day (which President Obama selected as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). The New York Times included three of his works—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—in their 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. Saunders teaches at Syracuse University and hosts Story Club on Substack.
quotes:
"It's that equilibrium of groundbreaking craft and bone-deep compassion—plus his rangy, tilt-a-whirl voice—that raises Saunders above other masters of the form."

—The Boston Globe

"Part of the Saunders elixir is that we feel more empathetic after reading his work."

—The San Francisco Chronicle

"Saunders has revealed himself to be nothing less than an American Gogol: funny, pointed, full of nuance, and always writing with a moral heart. This, his first book of short fiction in nearly a decade, only cements the validity of such a point of view. The nine pieces here are smart and funny, speculative yet at the same time written on a human scale, narratives full of love and loss and longing and the necessity of trying to connect."

—Kirkus

title: Our Country Friends
long_summary:
The early days of lockdown force an eclectic group of acquaintances into close quarters at a rural retreat, creating an intimate pressure cooker of personalities and secrets. This diverse ensemble—including a novelist and his psychiatrist wife, a tech entrepreneur, a rising essayist, and eventually a celebrity whose presence shifts the entire dynamic—must navigate six months of isolation together.

As external chaos reshapes the world, internal dramas unfold within their temporary sanctuary. Romantic entanglements develop between unexpected pairs while long-buried resentments surface, challenging everyone's assumptions about loyalty and connection. Each character confronts fundamental questions about what they truly value when stripped of their usual distractions and routines.

Shteyngart transforms the shared experience of pandemic uncertainty into an examination of how crisis reveals both our deepest vulnerabilities and our capacity for reinvention. The result combines sharp social observation with genuine tenderness, offering both biting commentary on contemporary anxieties and a surprisingly moving meditation on the bonds that sustain us through uncertainty.
short_summary: Eight friends weather the pandemic in a country house where new romances bloom and old betrayals surface. Shteyngart captures our recent chaos with the emotional depth of a Russian novel and his signature wit.
author_bios: Born in Leningrad in 1972, Gary Shteyngart immigrated to the United States at age seven. His first novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, earned both the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. Absurdistan, his second work, received recognition as one of The New York Times Book Review's 10 Best Books of the Year. Super Sad True Love Story captured the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize, while his memoir Little Failure became a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. Publishers in thirty countries have released his works internationally.
quotes:
"The novel's strengths abound. It upends clichés, pieties and commonplaces while also noticing salient details of the lockdown."

—The New York Times

"Our Country Friends has all [Shteyngart's] usual humor and absurdity, but it's deepened by a new empathy."

—Los Angeles Times

"Shteyngart knows how to make you belly laugh, and he's in his element here, poking fun at the claustrophobia of privilege. He perfectly captures the nature of adult friendships and the petty jealousies, disappointments, and dependencies that can define them."

—Vulture

title: Vera, or Faith
long_summary:
Ten-year-old Vera Bradford-Shmulkin stands at the center of a household teetering on the edge of collapse. Her adoptive father struggles to make ends meet as an editor while her Boston blue-blood mother fights to keep their unconventional family afloat. Dylan, her adoptive brother, seems destined for success in an increasingly fractured America, while Vera—caught between her Jewish and Korean heritage—searches for her place in a world that feels perpetually unstable.

Armed with an ever-growing vocabulary and an observant nature that captures both the absurd and heartbreaking details of daily life, Vera harbors three essential wishes. She dreams of finding genuine friendship at school, preventing her parents' marriage from dissolving, and most importantly, meeting her birth mother—the woman she believes holds the key to understanding her identity.

Shteyngart crafts a story that balances sharp social commentary with the innocent wisdom of childhood perspective. Through Vera's eyes, readers witness both intimate family dynamics and the broader cultural anxieties of contemporary America, creating a narrative that finds humor and hope even amid uncertainty.
short_summary: Ten-year-old Vera navigates her family's unraveling against the backdrop of America's own collapse. Shteyngart delivers a masterclass in voice—tender, funny, and devastatingly perceptive about love's fragility in chaotic times.
author_bios: Born in Leningrad in 1972, Gary Shteyngart immigrated to the United States at age seven. His first novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, earned both the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. Absurdistan, his second work, received recognition as one of The New York Times Book Review's 10 Best Books of the Year. Super Sad True Love Story captured the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize, while his memoir Little Failure became a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. Publishers in thirty countries have released his works internationally.
quotes:
"an unnerving—and very funny—portrait of America in the near future and an indelible portrait of its ten-year-old heroine, and attests to Shteyngart's magic ability to write in multiple emotional octaves and his gift for both sharp-edged humor and heartfelt tenderness."

—Michiko Kakutani, author of The Great Wave

"In its swirls of emotion, its humor, its pathos, and the unsparing humanity of its vision, Vera, or Faith is like some fabulous, hitherto-unknown creature that's been let out of its bottle and set free. It begins to seem that there's nothing Gary Shteyngart can't do."

—Michael Cunningham, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Day and The Hours

"A novel that you can read in one sitting that will stay with you forever . . . Vera instantly became one of my favorite child narrators, and her lucid bewilderment is by turns poignant, funny, and wise."

—Karen Russell, Pulitzer Prize finalist for Swamplandia!

title: The Life of the Mind
long_summary:
Dorothy exists in academic purgatory, teaching English as an adjunct with no prospects for tenure while grappling with a recent miscarriage she's told no one about—not even her therapists. The irony isn't lost on her: she wasn't certain she wanted children, yet the loss leaves her feeling like she's failed at something fundamental.

Christine Smallwood crafts a razor-sharp examination of contemporary disappointment, where professional stagnation meets personal upheaval. Dorothy's story captures the particular anguish of educated millennials caught between their expectations and reality, where even the pursuit of knowledge feels hollow. This debut novel dissects the gap between how we imagine our lives should unfold and the messy, uncertain ways they actually do.

With surgical precision and dark humor, Smallwood illuminates the small devastations of modern existence while questioning what it means to find purpose when traditional markers of success prove elusive. The result is a brilliant meditation on loss, ambition, and the search for meaning in an indifferent world.
short_summary: Dorothy is an adjunct professor drifting through academic limbo and personal crisis. Smallwood's debut is wickedly funny and devastatingly precise about modern disappointment.
