author_bios: Christine Smallwood has published fiction in The Paris Review, n+1, and Vice, while her cultural criticism appears regularly in The New Yorker and The New York Times Magazine, where she serves as a contributing writer. She writes Harper's Magazine's "New Books" column as a contributing editor and previously worked as an editor at The Nation. Smallwood earned her PhD in English from Columbia University and helped establish the Brooklyn Institute for Social Research as founding faculty.
quotes:
"Hilarious, recognizable, and helplessly wise—a perfect foil for its namesake."

—Rivka Galchen, author of Everyone Knows Your Mother is a Witch & Little Labors

"Brilliant and pleasurable, funny and dark, cerebral and visceral—a must-read for the bleeding human survivors of the modern age."

—Melissa Broder, author of The Pisces and Milk Fed

"One of the wittiest, most deliciously farcical novels I've read in a long time."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Afterparties
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In California's Central Valley, second-generation Cambodian Americans find themselves caught between worlds—honoring their parents' survival of unimaginable trauma while forging their own distinctly American futures. These characters exist in the spaces between tradition and rebellion, memory and forgetting, where family obligations clash with personal desires.

The collection introduces us to a former athlete whose midlife crisis plays out on the badminton court, siblings whose wedding celebration becomes an opportunity for family revenge, and lovers whose relationship unfolds against the backdrop of Silicon Valley ambition and literary obsession. Each story captures the particular experience of growing up in the shadow of genocide while navigating thoroughly contemporary concerns about identity, sexuality, and belonging.

So masterfully balances comedy with heartbreak, revealing how humor becomes both shield and weapon for a community still processing collective trauma. These characters are neither tragic nor triumphant—they're beautifully, messily human, struggling with the same universal questions of love and purpose while carrying the specific weight of their inherited history.
short_summary: Children of Cambodian refugees navigate identity, trauma, and belonging in California's Central Valley. So's debut collection balances razor-sharp humor with devastating tenderness, capturing the weight of inherited history.
author_bios: Anthony Veasna So (1992-2020) completed his undergraduate studies at Stanford before pursuing an MFA at Syracuse University. Born and raised in Stockton, he later taught at Colgate University, Syracuse University, and the Center for Empowering Refugees and Immigrants in Oakland. His fiction appeared in prestigious publications including The New Yorker, The Paris Review, n+1, and Granta. Afterparties, his New York Times-bestselling debut collection, received the Ferro Grumley Award for LGBTQ fiction and the NBCC John Leonard Prize, while earning a longlist nomination for the Andrew Carnegie Medal.
quotes:
"Witty and soulful stories from a writer who was just getting started . . . . [So] was gregarious, tattooed, queer: a big personality. He radiates in much the same way on the page. . . . [His] stories reimagine and reanimate the Central Valley, in the way that the polyglot stories in Bryan Washington's collection Lot reimagined Houston and Ocean Vuong's novel On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous allowed us to see Hartford in a fresh light."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Afterparties weaves through a Cambodian-American community in the shadow of genocide, following the children of refugees as they grapple with the complexities of masculinity, class, and family. Anthony Veasna So explores the lives of these unforgettable characters with bracing humor and startling tenderness. A stunning collection from an exciting new voice."

—Brit Bennett, author of The Vanishing Half

"Afterparties, by the late Anthony Veasna So, was one of the big buzz books this year and it exceeded and upended my expectations. So, who died at the age of 28 before the book came out, was a queer first-generation Cambodian American who wrote smart, flip, rude, funny, sexually explicit and compassionate stories about the Cambodian refugee community in Stockton, Calif."

—Maureen Corrgian, NPR

title: Chronicles from the Land of the Happiest People on Earth
long_summary:
Nigeria's medical establishment becomes the backdrop for a sinister trade in human remains, setting off a chain of events that threatens to destroy lives and careers. Dr. Menka stumbles upon evidence that body parts from his hospital are being harvested for dark purposes, a discovery he shares with his charismatic friend Duyole Pitan-Payne.

Duyole embodies everything his society values—engineering brilliance, royal bloodlines, and magnetic charm that makes him the center of any gathering. His appointment to a coveted UN position in New York should be the crowning achievement of his career. Instead, mysterious forces mobilize to block his path, launching attacks whose origins and motivations remain hidden.

Soyinka constructs a narrative that operates on multiple levels simultaneously. The investigation into the body-snatching scheme becomes a vehicle for exposing the rot that permeates every institution. What begins as a medical scandal expands into an examination of how corruption transforms entire societies, turning sacred spaces into marketplaces and reducing human dignity to commodity pricing. The result is both an entertaining puzzle and a fierce denunciation of the powerful who prey upon the vulnerable.
short_summary: Murder mystery meets political satire in this searing novel about corruption and power in contemporary Nigeria. Soyinka's first novel in decades showcases his brilliant wit and unflinching social commentary.
author_bios: Wole Soyinka received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1986, cementing his status as one of Africa's most important literary voices. The Nigerian-born writer, born in 1934, has built a remarkable career spanning theater, poetry, and prose, with notable works including The Interpreters and Death and the King's Horseman. His political activism has led to imprisonment twice for opposing the Nigerian government, and he famously destroyed his U.S. Green Card following Donald Trump's presidential victory.
quotes:
"Though his work has spanned multiple genres—poetry, plays, memoirs and essays—[Soyinka's] new novel manages to chart fresh territory. . . . Chronicles combines elements of a murder mystery, a searing political satire and an Alice in Wonderland-like modern allegory of power and deceit."

—Los Angeles Times

"It is Soyinka's greatest novel, his revenge against the insanities of the nation's ruling class and one of the most shocking chronicles of an African nation in the 21st century. It ought to be widely read."

—Ben Okri, The Guardian

"A biting satire that looks at corruption in an imaginary contemporary Nigeria, Chronicles is also an intriguing and droll whodunit. . . . A brilliant story that takes on politics, class, corruption, and religion from the very first chapters. It highlights Soyinka's lush, elegant language."

—Publishers Weekly

title: This Time Tomorrow
long_summary:
Alice approaches her fortieth birthday with a sense of quiet dissatisfaction. Her life has unfolded predictably—decent job, comfortable apartment, steady friendships—yet something fundamental feels absent. Her father's declining health casts a shadow over this milestone, reminding her of time's relentless passage.

Then the impossible happens: she awakens as her teenage self in 1996, inhabiting her sixteen-year-old body with four decades of accumulated wisdom. The disorientation of adolescence pales beside the gift of encountering her father as he once was—vibrant, healthy, and full of the energy that illness has stolen.

This unexpected reunion forces Alice to reconsider everything she thought she understood about their relationship and her own choices. Armed with hindsight's clarity, she begins to question whether the path she took was inevitable or simply one possibility among many. Straub crafts a meditation on family bonds and the weight of regret, asking whether knowledge of the future is blessing or burden. The result is a story that uses fantastical premises to examine deeply human truths about love, loss, and the courage required to accept both.
short_summary: When Alice wakes up on her fortieth birthday, she's somehow sixteen again—and reunited with her younger, healthier father. Straub's tender time travel novel explores second chances and the complicated love between parents and children.
author_bios: New York Times bestselling writer Emma Straub has published six books for adults, including the novels This Time Tomorrow, All Adults Here, The Vacationers, Modern Lovers, Laura Lamont's Life in Pictures, and the short story collection Other People We Married. Her work has been translated into more than 20 languages, and she has received recognition as a Guggenheim Foundation Fellow. Together with her husband, Emma Straub operates Books Are Magic, an independent bookstore in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"One of the most moving and intelligent time travel novels I have ever read. Nostalgic, wise, funny, and filled with love."

—Gabrielle Zevin, New York Times bestselling author of Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow

"If I could time travel, I'd go back just far enough to start Emma Straub's beautiful novel This Time Tomorrow again for the first time. The pages brim with tenderness and an appreciation for what we had and who we were. I could not have loved it more."

—Ann Patchett, New York Times bestselling author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"This Time Tomorrow is that rare one-in-a-million novel that not only pulls you wholly into itself, but leaves a lasting mark when it finally releases you. Never has Straub's writing been more incisive, clever, and emotionally generous— which is really saying something. The kind of book that will make you laugh, make you cry, and make you call the people you love. Exceptional."

—Emily Henry, New York Times bestselling author of Book People & People We Meet on Vacation

title: Shuggie Bain
long_summary:
In the crumbling tenements of 1980s Glasgow, a boy learns that love can be both salvation and prison. Hugh "Shuggie" Bain exists in the space between childhood and premature responsibility, watching over a mother whose beauty masks a devastating relationship with alcohol.

Agnes Bain clings to dignity through carefully applied makeup and dreams of respectability, even as economic collapse strips away the foundations of her world. Her son becomes her unlikely anchor, the one person who refuses to abandon her when sobriety gives way to binges that drain their meager resources. Their bond transcends typical family dynamics—part caretaker and patient, part conspirators against a harsh reality.

Meanwhile, Shuggie grapples with his own identity in a community that demands conformity. His difference sets him apart in ways that adults recognize but he cannot yet name, adding another layer of isolation to his already complicated existence. The novel examines how economic devastation ripples through generations, and how the fierce loyalty between parent and child can become both a lifeline and a trap that shapes the trajectory of young lives.
short_summary: Young Shuggie navigates 1980s Glasgow while caring for his glamorous, alcoholic mother Agnes. A devastating portrait of working-class life, addiction, and the complicated love between a boy and his deeply flawed parent.
author_bios: Douglas Stuart grew up in Glasgow and now lives in New York. His first novel, Shuggie Bain, earned him the 2020 Booker Prize and the Sue Kaufman Prize, while also receiving nominations for the National Book Award and PEN/Hemingway Award. Young Mungo became a national bestseller and was shortlisted for the British Book Award. Stuart's writing has been featured in the New Yorker and Literary Hub.
quotes:
"We were bowled over by this first novel, which creates an amazingly intimate, compassionate, gripping portrait of addiction, courage and love. The book gives a vivid glimpse of a marginalized, impoverished community in a bygone era of British history. It's a desperately sad, almost-hopeful examination of family and the destructive powers of desire."

—Booker Prize Judges

"This year's breakout debut . . . It has drawn comparisons to D.H. Lawrence, James Joyce, and Frank McCourt."

—Alexandra Alter, The New York Times

"I'm really, really stunned by it. It's so good. I think it's the best first book I've read in many years . . . It's a heartbreaking story, and quite hard to read at times, but it's almost like it's uplifting on behalf of literature. And it's written with great warmth and compassion for the characters."

—Karl Ove Knausgaard, The Guardian

title: Night of the Living Rez
long_summary:
Morgan Talty captures the rhythms of contemporary Penobscot life through twelve interconnected stories that balance heartbreak with unexpected moments of levity. These narratives center on characters caught between honoring their heritage and confronting the realities of modern reservation existence.

The collection moves through a landscape where ancient curses emerge from buried jars, friends stumble through drug deals gone wrong in frozen forests, and elders with fading memories blur past and present. Talty introduces us to characters plotting museum heists inspired by television shows, families wrestling with generational trauma, and individuals searching for meaning amid loss.

What emerges is a portrait of resilience that refuses easy answers or romantic notions about Indigenous experience. Talty's voice cuts through sentiment to reveal the complex ways people adapt, endure, and sometimes transcend their circumstances. The stories examine how identity gets shaped by both choice and circumstance, exploring the tension between tradition and survival in a community where both matter deeply.

This debut collection establishes Talty as an essential voice in contemporary literature, offering readers an authentic window into a world rarely seen with such nuance and honesty.
short_summary: Twelve stories set in a Penobscot community in Maine, where families navigate painful histories and uncertain futures. Talty writes with searing humor and compassion about inheritance, survival, and what it means to persevere.
author_bios: Morgan Talty holds citizenship in the Penobscot Indian Nation and wrote the nationally bestselling collection Night of the Living Rez. His fiction and essays have been featured in publications including The Georgia Review, Granta, Shenandoah, TriQuarterly, Narrative, and Lit Hub. Talty teaches as an assistant professor at the University of Maine, Orono, and serves on the faculty at both Stonecoast MFA and the Institute of American Indian Arts.
quotes:
"These stories took me in the same way Denis Johnson's Jesus' Son did when I first read it. The comparison here is meant in every way to praise Talty as a writer, and I'm sure I won't be the only one who says so, partially because of his emotional precision, his stark, unflinching, droll, intoxicating style, and also because of a certain drug/addiction element at play here. But as I got deeper into the work, into the book, and came to understand these lives and this community, the further away it felt from my initial comparison with Johnson, and the more familiar it felt—our Native communities being bound by countless common threads, strengths and afflictions both—and only then did I understand the distinct brilliance of Talty's voice as its own, and ours. I knew and felt for these people. Wanted to and knew I couldn't help them, even as they did me. There is so much brutal, raw, and beautiful power in these stories. I kept wanting to read and know more about these peoples' lives, how they ended up where they ended up, how they would get out, how they wouldn't. It is difficult to be so honest, and funny, and sad, at once, in any kind of work. Reading this book, I literally laughed and cried."

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars & There There

"Morgan Talty's Night of the Living Rez is a beautifully crafted, raw and intimate book about youth, friendship, and family on the reservation. These stories are profoundly moving and essential, rendered with precision and intimacy. Talty is a powerful new voice in Native American fiction."

—Brandon Hobson, National Book Award finalist and author of The Removed

"Magnificent."

—Lily King, The New York Times

title: Scattered All Over the Earth
long_summary:
In this dystopian landscape, Japan no longer exists—erased from geography and reduced to a culinary memory. Hiruko, now stateless, creates her own hybrid tongue called Panska to communicate with fellow displaced children in Denmark, cobbling together fragments from multiple languages because her mind can no longer contain them all.

Driven by an urgent need to find others who remember her native language, she assembles an eccentric group of travelers. Their quest becomes a picaresque adventure through a transformed Europe, where they encounter cooking contests centered on umami, deceased marine life, dangerous extremists, robotic companions, and Spanish bullfighters.

Tawada constructs a world both absurd and achingly real, where climate displacement has reshuffled human civilization. The narrative unfolds through a series of dreamlike episodes that feel simultaneously whimsical and urgent. Each encounter reveals something profound about belonging, communication, and survival in a world where entire cultures can simply disappear.

This opening volume of a trilogy captures the disorientation of living between languages and nations, mixing elements of fairy tale logic with contemporary anxieties about environmental collapse and cultural erasure.
short_summary: Japan has vanished, remembered only as the land of sushi. Climate refugee Hiruko searches Europe for anyone who speaks her mother tongue, inventing new languages along the way. Tawada's surreal odyssey is both deeply moving and magnificently strange.
author_bios: Born in Tokyo in 1960, Yoko Tawada relocated to Hamburg at age twenty-two before settling in Berlin in 2006. She creates literature in both Japanese and German, crafting stories, novels, poetry, theatrical works, and essays across both languages. Her distinguished honors include the Akutagawa Prize, Adelbert von Chamisso Prize, Tanizaki Prize, Kleist Prize, Goethe Medal, and National Book Award. New Directions has published her story collections Where Europe Begins and Facing the Bridge, along with novels such as The Naked Eye, Memoirs of a Polar Bear, The Emissary, and the Scattered trilogy.
quotes:
"Magnificently strange. Tawada is reminiscent of Nikolai Gogol, for whom the natural situation for a ghost story was a minor government employee saving up to buy a fancy coat, the natural destiny of a nose to haunt its owner as an overbearing nobleman."

—Rivka Galchen, The New York Times

"This dystopian novel is riveting, bizarre as can be, and like nothing else I've ever read. I'm terrified not enough people will read it."

—Kamil Ahsan, NPR

"Tawada expands upon the themes of language, immigration, globalization, and authenticity which underpin this slyly humorous first installment of a planned trilogy."

—Kirkus

title: Pick a Colour
long_summary:
At Susan's Nail Salon, the customers see only what they expect: quiet workers focused on their tasks. But behind the polite smiles and practiced movements lies a different reality altogether.

Ning once fought in boxing rings, her fists speaking a language of precision and power. Now she wields different tools, shaping cuticles and applying polish while her clients chat about their lives as if she weren't there. The irony isn't lost on her—this brilliant woman who observes everything, understands more than anyone realizes, yet remains invisible to those she serves.

The salon buzzes with unspoken tensions. Her coworkers carry their own stories of survival and adaptation, sharing whispered conversations that reveal dreams deferred and compromises made. Each interaction between the women who work and the women who pay exposes the fault lines of class and perception that run through their daily encounters.

As this particular day unfolds, the careful balance Ning maintains between who she is and who others assume her to be begins to shift. The question becomes whether she'll continue accepting others' limited vision of her world, or finally assert the full complexity of her existence.
short_summary: Over one transformative day in her nail salon, retired boxer Ning navigates the invisible dynamics between worker and client, observer and observed. Thammavongsa delivers intimate, razor-sharp prose about dignity, labor, and what it means to be truly seen.
author_bios: Born in a Lao refugee camp in Nong Khai, Thailand, Souvankham Thammavongsa grew up and studied in Toronto, where she continues to live today. She has published four poetry collections alongside her short story collection How to Pronounce Knife, which earned both the 2020 Scotiabank Giller Prize and 2021 Trillium Book Award. Her debut novel Pick a Color also received the 2025 Scotiabank Giller Prize. Thammavongsa's fiction has been recognized with an O. Henry Award and featured in prestigious publications including The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, The Paris Review, The Atlantic, Granta, and NOON.
quotes:
"Pick a Colour is one of the greatest novels I have ever read. In alchemical and captivating prose, this book orbits the steady flows of power and projection that exist between Ning, her employees and her clients. Love, death, joy, abandonment, deception and lust are all at stake in Susan's Nail Salon. The world of Pick a Colour is shockingly intimate. Reading this book left me with an intense desire to touch a stranger's hands."

—Rita Bullwinkel, author of Pulitzer Prize finalist Headshot

"This debut novel is a must for fans (like me) of Thammavongsa's intimate, deliciously tricky short stories. With dry humor and a keen eye for class, she's given us a hauntingly good book about the dignity and despair of work: the secret life of nail salons…When Thammavongsa writes, I read!"

—Ed Park, author of Pulitzer Prize finalist Same Bed Different Dreams

"Only as masterful an ironist as Souvankham Thammavongsa could have pulled this off: a work of urgent and impassioned solidarity that is also a defiant, even pugnacious, assertion of narrative autonomy and technical control. Pick a Colour is a knockout: every punch lands."

—Eleanor Catton, author of Birnam Wood

title: Margo's Got Money Troubles
long_summary:
Margo Millet finds herself in an impossible situation: twenty years old, single mother to an infant, and staring down eviction with no money in sight. Her unconventional upbringing—daughter of a Hooters waitress and former professional wrestler—taught her self-reliance, but that only goes so far when you're drowning in bills and desperation.

Enter her estranged father Jinx, whose timing couldn't be more perfect or complicated. In exchange for childcare help, Margo lets him crash at her place, and suddenly she's getting an education in the art of performance from someone who made a living in the wrestling ring. His lessons about building characters and captivating audiences spark an idea that's equal parts brilliant and risky.

Margo decides to try her hand at OnlyFans, applying her father's theatrical wisdom to a digital stage. What starts as a desperate experiment quickly snowballs into unexpected success, but internet stardom brings its own complications. As the money rolls in, Margo must navigate the complex terrain of online fame while figuring out what kind of person—and mother—she wants to be. The question becomes whether she's found her salvation or stepped into a different kind of trap entirely.
short_summary: Twenty-year-old Margo is broke, alone with a baby, and facing eviction when her ex-wrestler father shows up with advice about crafting personas and winning audiences. Her solution: OnlyFans meets professional wrestling wisdom.
author_bios: Rufi Thorpe has written three acclaimed novels, including The Knockout Queen, which earned a PEN/Faulkner award nomination. Her other works include Dear Fang, with Love and The Girls from Corona del Mar, which received recognition from both the International Dylan Thomas Prize and the Flaherty-Dunnan First Novel Prize through longlisting. Originally from California, Thorpe currently makes her home in Los Angeles alongside her husband and their two sons.
quotes:
"It's been a long time since I was so swept up in a book that I read it all in one swoop. Margo's Got Money Troubles is totally delightful—a page-turning plot with flawed but loveable characters, big philosophical questions, and really top-notch writing. It's funny and touching. Highly recommend!"

—Celeste Ng, New York Times bestselling author of Our Missing Hearts & Little Fires Everywhere

"Margo's Got Money Troubles is an audacious, wildly funny, completely unpredictable novel by a writer so singular that it's hard to compare her to anyone else. Rufi Thorpe writes wildness so well, the messiness of the choices we make, the strange ways we bend and twist ourselves to accommodate those choices, and she does it with the rare qualities of tenderness and empathy. An absolutely brilliant book."

—Kevin Wilson, New York Times bestselling author of Now is Not the Time to Panic, Nothing to See Here & The Family Fang

"A hilarious novel about making the most of what you've got. Sharp and funny by turns, this is an exceptionally tender look at young motherhood and love that also involves professional wrestling, and yes, OnlyFans. I gobbled it up."

—Emma Straub, New York Times bestselling author of This Time Tomorrow

title: The Safekeep
long_summary:
Isabel has built her solitary existence around order and control, finding comfort in the predictable rhythms of her inherited home in postwar Netherlands. This carefully constructed world fractures when her brother deposits Eva—a woman who embodies everything Isabel despises about carelessness and chaos—on her doorstep for an extended stay.

The collision between Isabel's rigid expectations and Eva's disruptive presence creates an electric tension that permeates every corner of the house. As household objects begin vanishing and Isabel's surveillance of her unwelcome guest intensifies, the boundary between suspicion and fascination dissolves entirely.

What emerges is a psychological excavation that reaches far beyond personal animosity. The summer heat becomes a catalyst for revelations that challenge everything Isabel believed about her family's past and her own identity. Van der Wouden constructs a narrative that interrogates how we inherit trauma, how desire can emerge from antagonism, and how the stories we tell ourselves about history often conceal the most essential truths.

This atmospheric debut transforms a domestic standoff into an exploration of postwar Netherlands' buried secrets, where the line between victim and complicity proves more complex than anyone wants to acknowledge.
short_summary: Two women circle each other in a Dutch country house during the summer of 1961. What begins as suspicion and obsession transforms into something far more dangerous and revelatory.
author_bios: Yael van der Wouden works as both a writer and educator from her home in Utrecht, Netherlands. Her first novel, The Safekeep, earned recognition as a finalist for the 2024 Booker Prize and received a longlisting for the 2025 Aspen Words Literary Prize. The book gained widespread critical acclaim, appearing on The New York Times Notable Books list and earning year-end honors from The Washington Post, Time, The Economist, Kirkus Reviews, The Times (London), The Independent, and BookPage.
quotes:
"It is the only book I have read this year that has made me cry. . . . Van der Wouden has produced the rare novel about World War II, the Holocaust, and their aftermath that succeeds in feeling fully, intimately human. . . . [The plot] twist is not what makes The Safekeep remarkable; what does is the extraordinary, emotional story Van der Wouden crafts around it, and the pitch-perfect voice she brings to the characters who experience its consequences."

—Talya Zax, The Washington Post

"Quietly remarkable. . . . Van der Wouden's writing is fine and taut. She lasers in on details, and presents unsentimental and intrinsically powerful metaphors. . . . I would have liked this book in any case, just for the pleasure of reading it. But the story is resolved in such a bold and tender way that it becomes not merely clever, but indelible."

—Lori Soderlind, The New York Times

"A brave and thrilling debut about facing up to the truth of history, and to one's own desires. . . . The tightly controlled narrative breaks open into a tale of erotic awakening, followed by an almighty twist. Anticipating that twist will not lessen its impact—fittingly enough for a novel in which everyone knows more than they can bear to admit. van der Wouden brings stunning power and control to her page-turner about trauma and repression."

—The Guardian

title: Let Us Descend
long_summary:
Annis faces an unthinkable betrayal: sold into bondage by her own father, she must endure the treacherous passage from Carolina's coastal plantations to Louisiana's merciless sugar fields. The physical journey becomes a spiritual odyssey as she draws strength from ancestral memories—her mother's wisdom and tales of a fierce African grandmother who wielded both blade and magic.

Surrounded by cruelty, Annis discovers she can access realms where ancestors dwell and elemental forces hold sway. These supernatural encounters offer both solace and danger, as not every spirit wishes her well. The American landscape itself becomes a character—swamplands and rivers bearing witness to generations of trauma while harboring ancient powers that refuse to be silenced.

Ward crafts a narrative where mythology intersects with historical horror, showing how one young woman's refusal to surrender her inner life becomes an act of resistance. Through Annis's eyes, we witness not just the machinery of oppression, but the indestructible human capacity to forge meaning from suffering and find pathways to spiritual liberation even within physical bondage.
short_summary: Ward follows an enslaved girl's journey from Carolina rice fields to Louisiana sugar plantations, weaving African spirituality through American brutality. A devastating descent that becomes triumphant ascension.
author_bios: Jesmyn Ward earned her MFA from the University of Michigan and has been honored with numerous prestigious awards including the MacArthur Genius Grant, a Stegner Fellowship, the Strauss Living Prize, and the 2022 Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction. She is a two-time National Book Award winner for Fiction, receiving the honor for both Sing, Unburied, Sing and Salvage the Bones. Her other works include Where the Line Bleeds and the memoir Men We Reaped, which earned the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. Ward teaches creative writing at Tulane University and makes her home in Mississippi.
quotes:
"Jesmyn is, quite simply, the best of us."

—Ta-Nehisi Coates, author of Between the World and Me

"In Let Us Descend, Jesmyn Ward resurrects an enslaved girl out of the lost folds of the antebellum South, twists magic through every raindrop, mushroom, and stalk of sugar cane, and drops you into the middle of her harrowing, unendurable, magnificent song. This is a gripping, mythic, bone-pulverizing descent into the grim darkness of American slavery—and yet somehow this novel simultaneously leaves you in awe of the human capacity to not only endure, but to ascend back to the light. A spectacular achievement."

—Anthony Doerr, author of Cloud Cuckoo Land & All The Light We Cannot See

"Overwhelming . . . This is a novel of triumph. . . . Running up against the limits of faith in the face of calamity, Annis eventually hammers out a relationship to the spirit world, complete with a rough-hewn existential philosophy that is both revolutionary and entirely consistent with the tools at her disposal."

—The Washington Post

title: Palaver
long_summary:
A decade of silence shatters when an unexpected visitor arrives at a Tokyo apartment just before Christmas. The reunion forces two people to confront the fractures that drove them apart—old wounds, unspoken resentments, and the weight of choices that seemed impossible to forgive.

In Japan's bustling capital, one has built a new existence teaching English and finding solace in Tokyo's vibrant nightlife, while the other carries memories spanning continents, from Jamaica to Houston. Their shared space becomes a battleground of careful conversations and guarded gestures, with only a cat as witness to their tentative attempts at connection.

As winter deepens, both begin forming unexpected bonds—one through the warmth of a neighborhood bistro, the other through chance encounters that challenge old assumptions. Between shared meals and a journey to ancient Nara, they must navigate the complex geography of belonging. Washington examines how we construct identity across oceans and generations, questioning whether reconciliation requires forgetting the past or learning to carry it differently. This is a meditation on the courage required to remain open to those who have hurt us most.
short_summary: Ten years of silence end when a mother shows up uninvited at her estranged son's Tokyo apartment. Washington crafts an intricate story of family wounds and tentative healing.
author_bios: Bryan Washington has written Lot, Memorial, and Family Meal. He received recognition as a National Book Award 5 Under 35 Honoree and earned the Dylan Thomas Prize, the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award, the Ernest J. Gaines Award, two Lambda Literary Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. He currently lives in Tokyo.
quotes:
"Few writers write about tenderness as Bryan Washington does—unadorned tenderness that is full of heart and humor but steers clear from familiar sentimentalities and convenient solutions. With deep understanding of human relationships, Palaver is a rare novel that offers companionship to solitary readers and lonely souls."

—Yiyun Li, author of Things in Nature Merely Grow

"Palaver is the pinnacle of what has become Washington's classic approach to writing: care, humor, tenderness, and an embrace of human beings at their most vulnerable, lovely, and wounded. It's such a joy to see the summation of his generosity of thinking and living actualized in the sentence. Fiction—no—life is better because Washington is writing."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous and Emperor of Gladness

"Bryan Washington speaks for people who have too long been silenced, and the voice he has found for them is defiant, compassionate, decent and profoundly human."

—Damon Galgut, author of The Promise

title: Holler, Child
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
These eleven interconnected tales traverse the emotional landscape of West Texas, where characters navigate the complex terrain between past mistakes and future possibilities. Watkins crafts intimate portraits of people caught between worlds—a former horse breeder whose past resurfaces unexpectedly, a mother confronting her son's crisis through the lens of her own history, a sister determined to reconnect with the brother who once protected her.

The collection examines how personal histories intersect with larger forces of race and class, revealing the extraordinary weight carried within ordinary moments. Each character grapples with the inheritance of their choices, seeking pathways toward redemption or understanding. Watkins demonstrates remarkable skill in distilling complex family dynamics and social realities into precisely observed scenes that resonate far beyond their immediate circumstances.

Through these interconnected lives, the collection reveals how individual struggles reflect broader questions about belonging, survival, and the possibility of transformation. The stories illuminate the ways people create meaning from hardship, finding unexpected sources of strength in their connections to place and each other.
short_summary: Eleven searingly beautiful stories about Black lives in West Texas, where guilt and love tangle in impossible knots. Watkins transforms painful reckonings into transcendent art.
author_bios: LaToya Watkins published her highly praised debut novel Perish in 2022. Her fiction and essays have been featured in A Public Space, The Sun, McSweeney's, and the Kenyon Review. She has been supported by prestigious fellowships from the Camargo Foundation, MacDowell, and Yaddo. Watkins currently teaches and resides in the Dallas area.
quotes:
"With her debut book Perish, LaToya Watkins proved herself to be a masterful novelist right out of the gate.  Now, with Holler, Child, Watkins shows herself to be a master of the short story as well. Each of these gorgeous, note-perfect stories packs the full-bodied punch of a novel, but with an economy and compression that are nothing short of miraculous.  How does she do it?  I don't know, but what I do know is that I very much want her to keep doing it."

—Ben Fountain, author of National Book Award-finalist Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk

"Above all, Holler, Child is an engrossing showcase of ordinary people struggling to get by, carefully and compactly drawn… Watkins's spare, evocative prose turns painful subject matter into thoughtful, transcendent art… an unforgettable collection."

—The Washington Post

"Eleven searingly alive stories about Black men and women from West Texas explore the ways remorse and resentment can coexist in secrecy…Granular yet transcendent storytelling."

—Kirkus

title: Harlem Shuffle
long_summary:
Furniture dealer Ray Carney has built what appears to be an honest existence in 1960s Harlem, supporting his family through legitimate business on 125th Street. Yet his criminal heritage runs deep, and maintaining complete respectability proves more challenging than anticipated.

A single favor for his troublesome cousin Freddie shatters Ray's careful balance between legitimacy and the streets. What begins as handling merchandise from a failed Hotel Theresa robbery spirals into encounters with crooked police, neighborhood power brokers, and Harlem's criminal underworld. Ray discovers that navigating between his roles as devoted family man and reluctant participant in illegal schemes requires understanding the true dynamics of urban power.

Whitehead delivers a multifaceted narrative that functions simultaneously as entertainment and social commentary. The novel captures both the vibrancy and complexity of Harlem during a pivotal decade, examining questions of morality, survival, and community through Ray's increasingly complicated circumstances. This crime story becomes a vehicle for exploring larger themes about identity, family loyalty, and the choices people make when caught between competing worlds.
short_summary: Ray Carney sells furniture and lives respectably in 1960s Harlem—until his cousin drags him into fencing stolen goods. Whitehead crafts a brilliant crime caper that doubles as both morality play and love letter to a neighborhood.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead has earned recognition as one of America's most vital contemporary voices, winning two Pulitzer Prizes for The Underground Railroad and The Nickel Boys, with the former also receiving the National Book Award. The #1 New York Times bestselling writer has produced twelve works spanning fiction and nonfiction. Both the MacArthur Foundation and Guggenheim Foundation have honored his contributions to literature, and he makes his home in New York City.
quotes:
"A rich, wild book that could pass for genre fiction. It's much more, but the entertainment value alone should ensure it the same kind of popular success that greeted his last two novels, The Underground Railroad and The Nickel Boys."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"One of the Ten Best Books of 2021"

—Laura Miller, Slate

"Colson Whitehead has a couple of Pulitzers under his belt, along with several other awards celebrating his outstanding novels. Harlem Shuffle is a suspenseful crime thriller that's sure to add to the tally — it's a fabulous novel you must read."

—NPR

title: Now Is Not the Time to Panic
long_summary:
Art has consequences—sometimes ones that echo for decades. In small-town Tennessee, two teenage outcasts discover each other during what promises to be another suffocating summer. Frankie, a would-be writer drifting through high school, finds kinship with Zeke, a gifted artist nursing his own wounds. Their collaboration births something unexpected: cryptic posters bearing a single, haunting message that begins appearing throughout their conservative town.

What starts as creative expression quickly spirals beyond their control. The community's fear transforms their anonymous art into something sinister, spawning wild theories and collective hysteria. The very thing that brought them together now threatens to destroy everything they've built.

Decades pass. Frankie has reinvented herself as Frances, a celebrated novelist who has carefully buried her teenage years. But the past refuses to stay hidden when a persistent journalist begins investigating the events that once turned her hometown upside down. Now she must decide whether to protect the life she's constructed or confront the truth about that transformative summer.

This story examines how creativity can be both liberation and trap, exploring the weight of secrets and the complicated legacy of our younger selves.
short_summary: Two misfit teenagers create mysterious art that sends their small Tennessee town into a panic. Twenty years later, one of them—now a successful novelist—must confront the past when a journalist comes calling.
author_bios: Kevin Wilson has written five novels and two story collections, establishing himself as a distinctive voice in contemporary fiction. His novels include Now Is Not the Time to Panic, Nothing to See Here, and The Family Fang, with several becoming New York Times bestsellers. Wilson's writing has earned him the Shirley Jackson Award and selection as a Read with Jenna book club pick. He makes his home in Sewanee, Tennessee, where he lives with his wife and two sons.
quotes:
"This is a wildly funny, wonderfully sincere — and a little bit devastating — story of art, our limitless past, future nostalgia and all those perfectly imperfect ways we continually come of age. Kevin Wilson's books are so full of heart. They're utterly indelible."

—Courtney Summers, The Washington Post

"Wilson's fiction will have you laughing so much that you're not prepared for the gut punch that follows. . . . Now Is Not the Time to Panic is the heartfelt culmination of many years (and many pages) spent probing the tension between the urge to make a mark on the world and the costs of doing so—and the push-pull between art's disorienting and generative powers. . . . Go read Wilson's books. You'll discover one-of-a-kind worlds opening up."

—The Atlantic

"Now Is Not the Time to Panic is a quirky, complicated story about the power of words and art, and the importance of adolescent friendships."

—Time

title: The Family Fang
long_summary:
Buster and Annie Fang grew up as unwilling participants in their parents' elaborate performance art projects. Caleb and Camille Fang transformed everyday situations into artistic statements, using their children as props in a world where the line between life and spectacle never existed.

Decades later, both siblings find themselves back in their childhood home after their adult lives fall apart. The unconventional upbringing that once defined them now seems to sabotage any attempt at normalcy. Their return coincides with their parents' announcement of an ambitious final project that threatens to pull the family back into familiar patterns.

The novel examines how artistic obsession can fracture family bonds while simultaneously creating them. Wilson crafts a story that questions whether creative vision justifies personal sacrifice, and whether children can ever truly escape the gravitational pull of their parents' choices. Through dark comedy and unexpected tenderness, the narrative reveals how the Fang family must ultimately choose between preserving their relationships or pursuing their artistic legacy.
short_summary: Two adult siblings return home to find their performance artist parents planning one final art piece. Wilson navigates this complex psychological terrain with humor and heart, examining what happens when family and art collide.
author_bios: Kevin Wilson has written five novels, including the New York Times bestsellers Now Is Not the Time to Panic, Nothing to See Here, and The Family Fang, alongside two collections of short stories. His fiction has earned the Shirley Jackson Award and was chosen for the Read with Jenna book club. Wilson makes his home in Sewanee, Tennessee, where he lives with his wife and two sons.
quotes:
"It's such a minty fresh delight to open up Kevin Wilson's debut novel, The Family Fang, and feel the revitalizing blast of original thought; robust invention; screwball giddiness. Every copy of The Family Fang sold in August should have a sticker on it imprinted with the life-giving invitation that used to be issued on movie marquees in summertime during the dawn of the air-conditioning age: "Come on in! It's cooool inside!" …a family story that's out-of-the-box, and funny, and, also, genuinely moving. Wilson's inventive genius never stops for a rest break. He spins out entertaining scenarios for the Fang performance pieces, as well as loony summaries for Buster's novels and Annie's movies, as well as what unfolds as the present-time suspense plot of the disappearance of Caleb and Camille. Is it genuine or is it yet another Fang performance piece? Early on in the novel, we're told that the strange art the Fangs create has been glowingly described by critics as "choreographed spontaneity." Wilson might as well have been writing a review for his own strange and wonderful novel, for The Family Fang indeed reads as a work of "choreographed spontaneity" that will linger in your mind long after the mall has closed and the mess in the restaurant has been cleaned up."

—NPR

"Inventive and hilarious. This is complex psychological ground, and the 32-year-old Mr. Wilson navigates it with a calm experience that his tender age shouldn't allow."

—The Wall Street Journal

"Wilson's creative and funny novel examines two young lives in the process of getting skewed, all in the pursuit of art with a capital A."

—Entertainment Weekly
